chunks.text: ix PREFACE Welcome to , your online looseleaf family law service in one volume! If you are a lawyer in general practice, a sole practitioner, a family law specialist or a barrister, I am able to identify with you and your needs in the practice of law. The Book first came into being in 1997 as a study book for my family law specialist accreditation exam. In a Lever Arch file, it contained a summary of the cases and legislation set out in the Law Society’s guidelines as required knowledge. Kept up to date with a summary of key new cases as they came through, the Book came into its own as a quick guide to family law, a “workbook”. Its regular disappearance from my room, under the arm of other family lawyers – who even gave it a name – was the first indication of demand for such a work. as it is now, however, with its coverage of both family law and routine procedures and precedents, was really launched 18 months ago when in a survey of the needs of lawyers in general practice – 100 litigation law firms – 91% of them said “bring it on”. A quiz from my business manager (“What would be the ideal product?”) then led to our own website (for links to court forms and brochures and our own advanced precedents) being combined with our looseleaf service in preference to the option of “either or both” that was offered to our survey group. This will put instant drafts of court papers and agreements on your desk to work through with your clients at your leisure, in a fraction of your usual preparation time. Both this and all the procedural guidance throughout the Book will also be a valuable training guide for the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: group. This will put instant drafts of court papers and agreements on your desk to work through with your clients at your leisure, in a fraction of your usual preparation time. Both this and all the procedural guidance throughout the Book will also be a valuable training guide for the development of paralegal and other staff. Our looseleaf service via its updates will summarise all key new cases and legislation. Our website www.thefamilylawbook.com.au will include a lively news page for members and a legal help line. Many have contributed to putting this together, including those referred to inside our title page and throughout the Book. I especially acknowledge Craig Nicol, a bright young family lawyer, for his co-authorship, particularly his streamlining of court procedures; my co-director and business manager Lucky Kalaf, who made self-publishing possible; and my daughter Lucy for her brilliant design of the Book, our website and corporate brand. My thanks also to Stephen Bourke for his precedent superannuation orders (with notes), social scientist Dr Bruce Smyth (children), the former Child Support Agency for use of extracts from its website, and the librarians and webmasters of the Family Court and FMC. And to Anna Faulkner, my virtual assistant (as she calls herself, due to her working from home in Tassie) for all her work over the past year and a half in typing the manuscript and its many drafts with such accuracy and patience. And then there is you. May your practice flourish by your subscription to . Robert Glade-Wright Principal author and editor Melbourne March 2009 Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: x ABOUT OUR LEGAL TEAM Robert Glade-Wright – Founder and former senior editor Rob was born in Somerset, England. He was educated at King’s College, Taunton, and from Year 10 at Devonport High School in Tasmania. Graduating from the University of Tasmania with a Bachelor of Laws in 1972, Rob was articled to Crisp, Wright & Brown – the formidable Sir Reg Wright QC, clerking for him in such jurisdictions as the High Court, and being tutored by his sons Christopher (later a judge of the Supreme Court of Tasmania) and Philip (later a magistrate). Rob was admitted as a legal practitioner in 1974 and, including a year in a London law firm, practised in Hobart as a barrister and sole practitioner in general practice until the late 90s when he moved to Queensland as a career change. Although he regularly appeared as counsel (and self-instructing solicitor) in the Family Court of Austra- lia, Rob’s career highlight was actually as counsel in his 20s before the Court of Criminal Appeal where his identification of a misdirection by a trial judge turned a prison visit to advise on an appeal against a seven-year sentence (several months out of time) into a successful appeal against conviction: Richardson v R [1978] TasSR 178. As well as his non-contentious practice in Hobart, Rob was counsel in a range of civil, criminal and family law matters such as for the husband in Gyselman in 1991, a trial on child and property issues that also led to the well-known Full Court appeal on child support. In 1996, he was appointed to Legal Aid’s panel of private lawyers to represent children. Accredited in 1997 as a family law specialist by the Queensland Law Society (for which His Honour Wood SJ was a referee), Rob took a position
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to the well-known Full Court appeal on child support. In 1996, he was appointed to Legal Aid’s panel of private lawyers to represent children. Accredited in 1997 as a family law specialist by the Queensland Law Society (for which His Honour Wood SJ was a referee), Rob took a position as family lawyer with the large Gold Coast law firm Attwood Marshall. By 2001, he was appointed head of their family law department, where he worked with distinction both appearing and briefing senior counsel in the Family Court of Australia in Brisbane. In 2005, he joined the Southport law firm Small Myers Hughes as head of their family law group. In 2005 and 2006, Rob wrote a weekend feature on family law for the Gold Coast Bulletin and in 2006 left practice to pursue a more creative line of work. After obtaining a Diploma of Professional Editing and Proofreading from the Australian College of Journalism he began work in 2007 on . Launched in 2009, Rob (and Craig Nicol as co-editor) saw the Book into its second decade. In 2021 Craig took over the reins as editor and Keleigh Robinson became co-editor. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: xi Craig Nicol – Editor Craig was born in Toowoomba to Scottish parents who came to Australia in the 70s. The family later moved to Gympie, then Rockhampton and Brisbane, where he attended Brisbane Boys Grammar School. Craig graduated with a Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Laws with Honours in 2001 from Griffith University. Its advanced family law course and his time as a volunteer at the Caxton Legal Centre, giving free legal advice to the community, were the catalyst for his choosing family law as his future profession. He was articled to Gold Coast firm Attwood Marshall and admitted in 2003, working as a family lawyer there until 2005 when he joined Small Myers Hughes at Southport where he became a partner. Craig was a volunteer at the Gold Coast Community Legal Service, giving free legal advice to the com- munity and practical tuition to undergraduates from Bond University. His talents extend to being a volunteer broadcaster at Radio 4EB in Brisbane from 2000 to 2001 for the National Indigenous Radio Service broadcast of “Undercurrents”, canvassing alternative current affairs. Craig also co-wrote two plays which were finalists in Underground Productions’ Short Play Competition in 2003 and 2004, the latter winning the “People’s Choice Award”. In 2015 Craig was accredited as a specialist in family law by the Queensland Law Society, which also awarded Craig the program’s Highest Achiever as “a recognition of his true level of expertise in this area”. Co-editor since the Book’s launch in 2009, Craig took over the reins as editor in 2021. Keleigh Robinson – Co-editor Keleigh was admitted to practice in 2006 after completing a Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Laws (Honours) at Deakin University. After completing articles and working in a suburban Melbourne firm she joined the boutique Melbourne family law
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: took over the reins as editor in 2021. Keleigh Robinson – Co-editor Keleigh was admitted to practice in 2006 after completing a Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Laws (Honours) at Deakin University. After completing articles and working in a suburban Melbourne firm she joined the boutique Melbourne family law firm Carew Counsel in 2008. Specialising in family law, Keleigh gained experience in a vari- ety of family law cases. As well as instructing counsel, Keleigh appeared as solicitor in the Family Court of Australia, FCC and the Magistrates Court of Victoria and represented clients at mediations. As a Law Australasia member, Keleigh worked on the improvement of family law precedents used by the group’s member firms. Keleigh completed her Masters of Applied Law (Family Law) at the College of Law in 2009 and in 2011 was accredited by the Law Institute of Victoria (LIV) as a family law specialist. Keleigh has been a member and chairman of the Junior Family Lawyers Committee, a member of LIV’s Maintenance and Property Committee and a member of the LIV Family Law Executive. She volunteered for 10 years at Women’s Legal Service Victoria, at Inner Melbourne Community Legal Centre (CLC) and at Eastern CLC. Keleigh takes a thorough, client focused approach to family law and has been giving subscribers to The Family Law Book the benefit of her experience since 2016 when she joined its legal help line panel. In 2021 (when Craig Nicol became editor) Keleigh was appointed as co-editor and joined our board of directors. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER ONE 1– 2 INTRODUCTION Welcome to – family law and procedure in one volume! Welcome also to our members’ website www.thefamilylawbook.com.au featuring ’s Online Forms and Precedents. In this new publication may you find what you need in your practice of family law – quick access to the essence of family law, its legislation and case law and to its routine procedures in an easy-to-follow, and always current family law service. A looseleaf service with your own website for links to court and other forms, prescribed brochures and our own precedents for instant draft court and other documents such as child support and financial agreements, as well as News, Legal Help Line and other member benefits. This first chapter is also a review of all those other resources already available to lawyers to streamline how to go about this line of work. If you have a busy general practice, you are likely to appreciate any input that will improve the management of the family law aspect of your work. So take the time to put in place the following people, support systems and resources, and then accustom yourself and your staff to making use of them all the time. No more panic stations or crisis management. The only way to practise family law is for you to be on top of things, and that means organisation. Your delegation of key functions to people you can rely on and your use of other available resources will make life so much easier and more rewarding. Your family law will hum! Our aim is for you to have the convenience of a thorough but compact looseleaf service that will take you quickly to family law and its routine procedures and, through its website, enable instant production of draft court papers and other
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: easier and more rewarding. Your family law will hum! Our aim is for you to have the convenience of a thorough but compact looseleaf service that will take you quickly to family law and its routine procedures and, through its website, enable instant production of draft court papers and other routine documents. is divided equally between law and practice. The areas of law covered are modelled on the guidelines now used by all law societies Australia-wide for specialist accreditation in family law – with emphasis on what is essential knowledge. Practice comprises all routine procedures and forms, and 300 pages of well-crafted precedents. There are nine easy-to-read chapters. This chapter (essential resources) and the next (client preliminaries) will get you underway, followed by divorce, children, child support and maintenance, spousal mainte- nance, property, other routine procedures and financial agreements. “Other routine procedures” has been used for routine matters such as consent orders, subpoenas and discovery of documents so as to avoid clutter in the central child and financial chapters. Members will enjoy the following additional benefits: • updates that you need to receive • alerts and links to new court forms • an alert to new court procedures • summary of new key legislation Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ESSENTIAL RESOURCES 1– 3 • latest notable cases online monthly • a website including eBook (+ free app) • 3–400 pp of expert precedents (linked at our eBook & “forms and precedents”) • a legal helpline by 24-hour email • our appreciation for all useful suggestions • Members’ Practice News (family law, court, child support news) • Members’ Archive (past case notes, useful papers) • a friendly, helpful team May you find this family law workbook an invaluable companion in your practice of law. DOWNLOADING OUR ONLINE FORMS AND PRECEDENTS Our members’ website – www.thefamilylawbook.com.au – offers subscribers ’s Online Forms and Precedents for links to routine court and other forms, brochures, precedents for orders sought, sample affidavits and other documents such as child support and financial agreements. Also downloadable from our eBook (at name of document). This site will operate as an automated drafting service at the level of counsel, offering an instant draft of the orders your client should be seeking, and an instant draft of what their affidavits should say in support of their case. This will enable you to sit down with your clients and go through those drafts at your leisure and, if necessary, without delay, adapting the issues and evidence to their case. The amount of time you will save by using this service is likely to be enormous, and should flow strongly through to your bottom line. Instructions for use of our members’ website As well as being available online at our website, court and other forms and prescribed brochures are identified for each chapter and our precedent court documents, letters and agreements are set out in full in hard copy below for easy selection of forms and precedents. All links to other sites throughout this service are also available at our website.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: court and other forms and prescribed brochures are identified for each chapter and our precedent court documents, letters and agreements are set out in full in hard copy below for easy selection of forms and precedents. All links to other sites throughout this service are also available at our website. Treat our precedent “interim orders” and “final orders” as separate attachments to the court’s Application or Response, and our precedent affidavit text as a separate attachment to the court’s affidavit form. Other precedents such as agreements and letters may be downloaded as their own independent documents, as can court brochures. Once you have selected the documents you need, ask your assistant (see “an assistant or paralegal” below) to: • Go online via our member log-in. Select the relevant chapter, then click on the form, brochure or precedent you want. Or search by keyword, selecting relevant chapter. • When accessing a form, it will take you directly to a court or other link. Select which format best suits you, then save and print. Brochures can be simply printed. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER ONE 1– 4 • Saving the form. While in the document go to File, Save As e.g. “(Client name – Affidavit of (name) – (date)” in your place of choice (such as “my documents” or “desktop”). Do not use \ / or | when naming your document. • Complete the form (or a draft of it) by entering the required details, using those given by your client in their Client Information Sheet (Chapter 2). • Simply insert “see attached” in the Application or Response under “orders sought” (interim and final), doing the same for the affidavit where it calls for your evidence. • Next, click on the link under “precedents” for the precedent interim and/or final orders you want for your Application or Response, and for the sample text required for your affidavit in support. Save and print those too. • These precedent orders and sample affidavit text will become separate attachments to your completed Application or Response, and to your affidavit. • Precedents such as child support agreements or financial agreements, precedent pre-action and other letters may be saved and printed as their own independent drafts. • In a financial case, the Financial Statement, or at least a good draft of it, could be completed between your assistant and your client. • This ready set of draft court papers will then be on your desk for you to work through at leisure with your client and adapt to the needs of their case. USEFUL LINKS • www.austlii.edu.au for case law (Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia, Full Court, High Court and FCWA) and all Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation • www.fcfcoa.gov.au for FCFCA forms, brochures, fact sheets and practice directions • www.familycourt.wa.gov.au for the Family Court of Western Australia • www.humanservices.gov.au/customer/themes/child-support-and-separated-parents for the Child Support Agency’s website
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: case law (Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia, Full Court, High Court and FCWA) and all Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation • www.fcfcoa.gov.au for FCFCA forms, brochures, fact sheets and practice directions • www.familycourt.wa.gov.au for the Family Court of Western Australia • www.humanservices.gov.au/customer/themes/child-support-and-separated-parents for the Child Support Agency’s website • www.familyrelationships.gov.au for information about your local private or Family Relationships Centre family dispute resolution provider • www.aifs.gov.au for publications by the Australian Institute of Family Studies, Australia’s leading centre for research and information on family wellbeing • www.ag.gov.au for the Attorney-General’s Department website, which includes information about a variety of family law topics • www.familylawsection.org.au for the professional association for family lawyers in Australia • various other websites that are referred to throughout Note – Links to these sites are available at our website under this chapter. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ESSENTIAL RESOURCES 1– 5 ESSENTIAL RESOURCES Make life easier for yourself by entering into a reliable working relationship with competent professionals in the following routine areas of family law practice. An assistant or paralegal Use an assistant or paralegal, or promote a staff member to work as one, to take on much of your time-consuming but uneconomic gathering and processing of information. Introduce them to your clients from Day 1 as being their secondary point of contact (charged at a clerical rate), for matters or concerns not requiring professional assistance. Using a paralegal (or an apprentice, junior lawyer, secretary, receptionist or clerk) in this way will free up your time for your clientele and enable your time to be charged at a proper (professional) rate. Your clients too will appreciate being given the option of much of their work being done at a cheaper rate. By way of staff training, ask your assistant to familiarise themselves with Chapters 1 and 2, the procedural sections of Chapters 3 to 8 and with the operation of our website for the downloading of draft court documents for you to work through with your clients. They should soon be able to handle your firm’s divorce applications and other case management, and download the necessary documents for your other matters. Let them complete the formal details of the Application or Response and Affidavit from the Client Information Sheet completed by the client (“client preliminaries” below), presenting them to you with the draft orders sought and draft affidavit in support. Example – Simply ask them to “put together, from our online ‘forms’ and ‘precedents’ from the relevant chapter(s), a draft Initiating Application (or Response) seeking final property orders (plus routine interim orders); a blank Financial Statement plus the one page addendum sheet attached to the back;
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: draft affidavit in support. Example – Simply ask them to “put together, from our online ‘forms’ and ‘precedents’ from the relevant chapter(s), a draft Initiating Application (or Response) seeking final property orders (plus routine interim orders); a blank Financial Statement plus the one page addendum sheet attached to the back; and an affidavit in support”. In an instant, you will have draft court papers in front of you to work through with your client so as to adapt them to the needs of their case. They should also check on the procedure for each kind of case, including any prescribed pre-action procedure. The role of your assistant or paralegal might include: • dealing with clients’ questions that they are competent to deal with • chasing the client up as to matters requiring attention and other follow-up • handling divorce applications from start to finish • downloading required forms and precedents (see above) • completing Application/Response from Client Information Sheet (see above) • arranging completion of Financial Statement for checking by you • liaising with witnesses, including valuers and other experts • liaising with your process server and all other professionals covered in this chapter Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER ONE 1– 6 • keeping properly updated as updates arrive • compiling and keeping up to date a referrals sheet for all the following You will soon find that this approach will do wonders for client approval, staff morale and professional development, and boost your firm’s efficiency and profitability. A family law barrister It is crucial to have an able, reliable family law barrister (and one or two as back-up) who is always available for giving you advice when you need it (at short notice, if necessary), for settling your court papers (which you should be able to email counsel for their prompt attention), or for appearing in court with you and your client. Look into who is available as counsel, ask around. Make appointments with some barristers to see how available and dependable they would be. There may be some trial and error involved, but work towards choosing your primary and back-up counsel, and then use them consistently. Note – Using a family lawyer local to your filing registry who is routinely involved in agency work is an alternative to briefing counsel to appear on your more formal interim applications. Using counsel for ready advice; to settle your court papers; and to appear in court, will add depth and expertise to your family law work and develop the credibility of your practice. A family counsellor (and FDR provider) Go about choosing your primary counsellor and, say, a back-up counsellor in the same way. Seek out someone experienced in family law disputes and family counselling, who is also a registered family dispute resolution (FDR) provider and available at short notice and after normal hours. Being also an FDR provider enables early counselling to be combined with the mandatory pre-action FDR procedures in child matters, including the issue of an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: family law disputes and family counselling, who is also a registered family dispute resolution (FDR) provider and available at short notice and after normal hours. Being also an FDR provider enables early counselling to be combined with the mandatory pre-action FDR procedures in child matters, including the issue of an FDR certificate to you for filing with your papers as required. See “family counselling” and “family dispute resolution” in chapter “children”. A family consultant (report writer) This is the person who will interview your clients’ children, will observe the children’s interaction with their parents, record the children’s views, and then report all that to the court. See “family consultants” in chapter “children”. Family lawyers for opposing parties routinely appoint a family consultant for preparation of such a report. And these reports are usually influential with the court. It is therefore crucial to identify available family consultants (and any particular strengths or leanings they may have), so as to fully inform your choice when either nominating three of them for the selection of a report writer by the other party or choosing from a list of three received from the other party for selection by you. If you do not specialise in family law, those who do should be able to recommend family consultants. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ESSENTIAL RESOURCES 1– 7 A process server Experienced process service is priceless – someone to do all of your process serving work and do it efficiently. Again, seek a referral from among your colleagues and, if necessary, do an internet search for a firm that advertises family law work. An experienced operator is likely to prepare the affidavit of service and the acknowledgment of service correctly (even if you send the forms to them blank) and return it to you properly completed, ready for filing in the court registry. Note – Court papers are usually just served on the other party’s lawyer without objection or formality. But whenever personal service is required (such as divorce papers) or service may be controversial (such as an unrepresented party or a lawyer saying they “have no instructions to accept service”, or “are awaiting instructions”), arrange personal service. You will certainly save time and money by getting your papers to your process server to effect personal service without waiting for others to co-operate with you. Avoid postal service, because of the onerous requirements of what has to be filed by way of proof. A forensic accountant Again, ask around among your colleagues (including your barrister) for the name of a good forensic accountant or two, with experience as an expert witness in court, for the valuation of businesses, valuing complex superannuation interests, giving tax advice in your clients’ matters and the investigation of transactions and books of account. Miscellaneous valuers You will benefit from word of mouth recommendations from your colleagues as to registered valuers for different kinds of property, including real estate, complex superannuation interests and such property as motor vehicles, boats, antique furniture and so on. Keeping a ready bank of able valuers will result in more consistent and reliable service and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: word of mouth recommendations from your colleagues as to registered valuers for different kinds of property, including real estate, complex superannuation interests and such property as motor vehicles, boats, antique furniture and so on. Keeping a ready bank of able valuers will result in more consistent and reliable service and a quicker, more streamlined procedure for seeking and obtaining the various types of valuation sought in your cases. CONCLUSION Arrange for your assistant to draw up and keep updated and on hand a referrals sheet with a page for each of the above, with their names, addresses and contact details for quick reference. Without such a record, you will find yourself wasting much time attempting to locate an appropriate person each time you need someone from one of those categories. These people and resources are essential capital for the efficient management of the family law aspect of your practice. No longer should it be necessary for any lawyer to say (as one did to the writer [RGW] when he polled 100 law firms as to their interest in a work such as this) “family law is 50% of my practice but it takes 75% of my time”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER TWO 2 – 2 PHONE INQUIRIES Be available Be available, if someone phones wanting to ask a legal question. “Being available” is high on the list of things clients like a lawyer to be, so your taking their call – and always being available if they become your client – would be good practice and good for business too. Preparation Brief your receptionist, when taking calls from people wanting to speak to you or to “one of your lawyers” with some family law queries: • to say “I’ll see if X is available. I should also mention our ‘initial consultations’ that we offer here for $Y.” (Doing this lets the caller know that that option is available.) • to put such calls through to you. If you are in the middle of something, take the call anyway. Introduce yourself and ask if you may ring them back when you’re free in, say, an hour or whatever time you need. Take their first name and number. The phone inquiry The phone inquiry allows a caller to sound you out, without having to commit to an interview. They may be less interested in your answers than how you speak to them. They may be comparing what you say and how you say it with the responses of other lawyers they have rung. Just be yourself. Be a sympathetic listener, and answer their queries clearly. Ask if reconciliation is out of the question, and say that non-court options such as family counselling and settlement negotiations are usually first steps. Keep these calls and your answers short, letting no one take advantage of your availability. Wind up with something like “I hope that helps. We do offer initial consultations here for a discounted fee. If you’d be interested in that later, give us
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: and settlement negotiations are usually first steps. Keep these calls and your answers short, letting no one take advantage of your availability. Wind up with something like “I hope that helps. We do offer initial consultations here for a discounted fee. If you’d be interested in that later, give us a call and our receptionist can arrange that for you.” If they want to make an appointment then and there, put them back to your receptionist to arrange that. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CLIENT PRELIMINARIES 2 – 3 INITIAL CONSULTATION Preparation Brief your receptionist, when taking a call from someone seeking one of your initial consultations, to: • put anyone through to you who is wanting to ask a question first (“phone inquiries” above) • obtain the caller’s name and phone number • ask the full name of their spouse, for a conflict of interest check to ensure that you have not been consulted by their spouse • (if no conflict of interest) let them know the fee for the interview, and that it is “payable on the day” This briefing should also be as to a system of receipting the fee at the end of the initial consultation and making the next appointment. Note – Initial consultations are often given at a reduced fee. This is a bonus for potential clients and can also be an incentive for what is often a tentative, nervous step by someone unsure of how to proceed or whether to proceed at all. The interview itself • Be an attentive, considerate listener to what potential new clients have to say • Make allowances for family law clients, allowing them to give vent to their emotions • Answer any questions simply, and avoid lecturing them on law and procedure • Ask if there is any prospect of reconciliation, and whether relationship counselling should be considered before going further • If a client appears to be struggling to cope with the separation, ask if they might like a referral to their own counsellor first • For child matters, explain that non-court options are available, such as family counselling and compulsory family dispute resolution (FDR) • Check for time limits (12 months after divorce order in which to apply for property settlement or spousal maintenance; or 12 months of separation
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to their own counsellor first • For child matters, explain that non-court options are available, such as family counselling and compulsory family dispute resolution (FDR) • Check for time limits (12 months after divorce order in which to apply for property settlement or spousal maintenance; or 12 months of separation before filing a divorce application) • Be in a position to refer them to a counsellor, for either individual or joint counselling. Let them know that the counsellor(s) you use are also FDR providers for the purpose of the mandatory FDR in child matters. See “essential resources” above • Limit your note-taking, leaving client details and history until the next step Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER TWO 2 – 4 • As to costs, explain that if the matter goes further: – a costs agreement will be sent out, explaining how legal costs are charged – your policy is for you to keep them informed as to costs and for clients to pay as they go – they are asked to pay an initial deposit (of say $2,500) – your clients basically pay money up front as work is done – you try to keep the bills manageable – your clients are given a rough idea as to how much each stage will be costing. • Recommend that they make a new will to update their nominated trustee and beneficiaries • If you have succeeded in connecting with a potential client by the end of the interview, they will let you know by wanting a second appointment • Allow them at the end of the interview to take the initiative as to the next step (“So what happens next?”) • If the client does ask that question, explain that you will send them some lawyer-client documentation – a costs agreement; a Client Information Sheet for completion; and a brochure on how the court works; Checklist of Documents (financial cases); and a request for the initial deposit. • If the client is interested in making a new will, ask if you can arrange for your wills person (identify them) to ring them to arrange a separate appointment for that. If that person is you, instructions for the will may be taken at their second appointment with you. After the interview Introduce the person to your receptionist to: • receipt their fee • book their next appointment with you • arrange for your wills person to contact them Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CLIENT PRELIMINARIES 2 – 5 LAWYER-CLIENT DOCUMENTATION If your client wishes to proceed, represented by you, write to them as follows: Sample of first letter to client As discussed, I now enclose for your attention: 1. Our costs agreement in duplicate (the copy being for your records) 2. Client Information Sheet for completion 3. The brochure “Marriage, Families and Separation” 4. Checklist of Documents I confirm that your next appointment is on (date) at (time). Would you kindly bring with you at that appointment: • Signed and witnessed costs agreement • Completed Client Information Sheet • The documents referred to in 4 above • Your initial deposit towards costs in the sum of $2,500. Yours faithfully, About the enclosures Links follow to all law society websites for you to obtain a costs agreement (and disclosure statement) applicable to the law in your State or Territory. These links (and all other links given in this service) are available at our website under the relevant chapter. Items 2, 3 and 4 are also available online at our website, www.thefamilylawbook.com.au Note – Our precedents are also set out in hard copy below for your convenience. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER TWO 2 – 6 Enclosure 1 – Costs agreement Amendments to Chapter 19 of the Family Law Rules 2004 dealing with lawyer-client costs took effect on 1 July 2008. The rules then dealing with costs agreements (FLR 19.12-19.17) were repealed and the preamble to Chapter 19 then provided that for a dispute between a lawyer and a client about the costs charged by the lawyer for: • proceedings issued after 30 June 2008 or • under a costs agreement entered into after 30 June 2008 see the State or Territory legislation governing the legal profession in the State or Territory where the lawyer practises. The legislation in each State and Territory on costs disclosure, costs agreements, and assessment of disputed costs (including, in the case of NSW and NT, mediation), and the law society links to precedent costs agreements in each State and Territory are set out on the opposite page. Costs agreements may be set aside In McMurphy & G and G (A law firm) [2010] FamCA 1032 Cleary J set aside a costs agreement for not being fair and reasonable. The reasoning for that conclusion is set out at paras 164-177. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CLIENT PRELIMINARIES 2 – 7 New South Wales Part 4.3 Legal Profession Uniform Law (NSW) www.lawsociety.com.au – or via our own website link – for costs disclosure and costs agreement commencing 1 July 2007” Victoria Part 4.3 Legal Profession Uniform General Rules 2015 (Vic) www.liv.asn.au – or via our own website link – for a pro forma costs agreement South Australia Division 8, Part 3 Legal Practitioners Act 1981 (SA) Refer to this legislation. The Law Society of SA discontinued this service to its members following a case where a costs agreement was rescinded for not being fair and reasonable: see McNamara v Kasmeridis (2007) SASC 90 at para 48. Western Australia Part 10 Legal Profession Act 2008 (WA) The Law Society of WA has referred this issue to the Family Law Practitioners Association of WA, a contact person for which can be obtained from the law society at www.lawsocietywa.asn.au – or via our own website link. Northern Territory Part 3.3 Legal Profession Act (NT) www.lawsocietynt.asn.au – or via our own website link Queensland Sections 308-344 Legal Profession Act 2007 (Qld) www.qls.com.au – or via our own website link Australian Capital Territory Part 3.2 Legal Profession Act 2006 (ACT) www.actlawsociety.asn.au – or via our own website link Tasmania Sections 291-331 Legal Profession Act 2007 (Tas) www.lst.org.au – or via our own website link Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CLIENT PRELIMINARIES 2 – 17 THE SECOND APPOINTMENT Preliminaries Receive from your client: • signed costs agreement • completed Client Information Sheet • documents sought in Checklist of Documents • the requested deposit towards initial costs and outlays Answer any questions about the costs agreement. Go through the Client Information Sheet and complete any parts that have been left blank (after your paralegal or assistant has been through it with your client). Receipt their payment. Note – A completed Client Information Sheet will enable your PA to complete most of the parties’, lawyers’ and other case specific details required for the court’s forms, and should also give you a rough idea before you get underway as to what type of case it is going to be. Your next step Go to the relevant chapter for your matter – for its law, procedure and precedents. This is governed by the type of case it is. Matters may be singular, such as divorce, or combined, such as property and spousal maintenance; or child matters with spousal maintenance and property. The 2021 merger of courts changed the venue for court proceedings to the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (FCFCA) (in Division 1, being the former Family Court of Australia) or Division 2, be- ing the old FCC). The FCWA continues for WA proceedings. For combined matters, much of the procedure will overlap, however it is necessary to check the procedure in each relevant chapter so that no special requirements are overlooked. The procedure for seeking orders in combined proceedings is simple. Simply list all your child orders under “orders sought” in your Application or Response either immediately before or after all the property and/or spousal maintenance orders you are seeking. The “sameness” of procedure for, say, spousal maintenance and property proceedings
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: The procedure for seeking orders in combined proceedings is simple. Simply list all your child orders under “orders sought” in your Application or Response either immediately before or after all the property and/or spousal maintenance orders you are seeking. The “sameness” of procedure for, say, spousal maintenance and property proceedings includes the filing of the one Financial Statement for both applications. Although the affidavit in support differs between causes of action, our precedents should help by directing you by the use of sub-headings to the required evidence for the various issues involved (whether your client is an applicant or respondent). The “court forms” sections of our main chapters set out the documentation required to be filed. Spousal maintenance and property combined It is best to follow the spousal maintenance procedure and then work through the “property” procedure so as also to attend to requirements required for property but not spousal maintenance cases. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER TWO 2 – 18 Child and property matters combined It is best to go to the procedure for child matters first – for its requirement of early counselling and compulsory family dispute resolution (FDR) – and then work your way through the procedure for property matters. Child, spousal maintenance and property combined Follow the procedure for child matters, then the procedure for spousal maintenance, then for property matters. Note – The merger of courts brought with it a shift in how family law cases proceed, with a greater em- phasis on dispute resolution both before and during a proceeding, and new rules to facilitate that shift. These brochures will summarise pre-action procedures for your clients – “Before you file – pre-action procedure for parenting cases” “Before you file – pre-action procedure for financial cases” Before the start of any case you must give your client the FCFCA’s Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management made on 1 September 2021. Costs Each party pays their own costs in family law proceedings in almost all cases: see “costs and security for costs” in the chapter “other routine procedures”. You will see that you are required to give written notice to your client before each court event and upon any offer to settle of their costs to date and future costs. Example – you could summarise in a letter to your client that their costs up to and including the first court hearing (it could be an interim hearing) were, say $5–10,000 (amount paid) with a further, say $8,000 payable up to and including the next court event (conciliation conference). At that second hearing, you could adapt your letter so as to cover costs to date and estimate costs for the final hearing at say $10,000 for a one day trial
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: $5–10,000 (amount paid) with a further, say $8,000 payable up to and including the next court event (conciliation conference). At that second hearing, you could adapt your letter so as to cover costs to date and estimate costs for the final hearing at say $10,000 for a one day trial to cover you and your barrister (including preparation) and say $2–4,000 a day (beyond the first day) if more time is required (plus the expenses of any expert witnesses). A word about style If you are a lawyer in general practice, you may be accustomed to the adversarial nature of litigation, going hard at your opponent, being awarded costs when you win. Family law is different, being law related to families and their arrangements both financial and as to children after separation. It requires a more subtle, polite approach, even where only financial matters are concerned. You are likely to find that a non-adversarial style will almost always work best in your practice of family law, except when confronted with the most recalcitrant opponent. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER THREE 3 – 2 JURISDICTION Divorce proceedings may be issued in this country if, at the time of filing, either spouse has Australian citizenship or domicile or been ordinarily resident in Australia for the past year: s 39(3) Family Law Act 1975 (FLA). “Ordinarily resident” includes “habitually resident”: s 4(1) FLA. Also see Russell (No. 5) [2012] FamCA 917 at [9]-[63]. Young J (at [49]) cited House of Lords authority that “habitually” required “residence adopted voluntarily and for [a] settled purpose”. Also see LK v Director-General Department of Community Services [2009] HCA 9 at [27]-[45] The court can decline to exercise jurisdiction where divorce proceedings are pending in another country. In Henry v Henry [1996] HCA 51 the High Court held that its ruling in Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd [1990] HCA 55 applies to divorce proceedings. The ruling was that a party who has properly issued proceedings in Australia has a prima facie right to have the proceedings determined by an Australian court, unless Australia is the clearly inappropriate jurisdiction. See also Ferrier-Watson v McElrath [2000] FamCA 219. The opinion of a family law specialist or counsel is advisable where assets are held both here and overseas. GROUND OF DIVORCE Divorce is available after 12 months’ separation. The actual ground of divorce is irretrievable breakdown of marriage, established by evidence of the parties having lived separately and apart for a continuous period of 12 months immediately before the filing of the application: s 48(1) and (2) A divorce order will not be made if the court is satisfied that there is a reasonable likelihood of cohabita- tion being resumed: s 48(3) RESUMPTION OF COHABITATION Where cohabitation has been resumed on one occasion of less than three months or any other period the court considers “not substantial”
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: A divorce order will not be made if the court is satisfied that there is a reasonable likelihood of cohabita- tion being resumed: s 48(3) RESUMPTION OF COHABITATION Where cohabitation has been resumed on one occasion of less than three months or any other period the court considers “not substantial” the previous and later periods of separation may be added in cal- culating the total period of separation: s 50 The resumption of cohabitation must have been by agreement: Todd (No. 2) [1976] FamCA 12 at [7]; and Clarke [1986] FamCA 29 at [2]-[10] and [32]-[40]. Sexual intercourse has been held not to constitute a resumption of cohabitation: Todd (No. 2) at [7] and Bell [1979] FamCA 44 at [17] (“acts of self-gratification unrelated to the marital relationship per se”). And see the Full Court in Spanos [1980] FamCA 10 at [22]-[23] (sexual intercourse is a component of a marriage relationship but its occurrence would not alone mean a resumption of cohabitation). MEANING OF SEPARATION “Separation” may occur: • from the action or conduct of one of the parties: s 49(1); or • under the one roof (“notwithstanding that the parties have continued to reside in the same residence or that either has rendered some household services to the other”): s 49(2). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: DIVORCE 3 – 3 The word “separation” does not mean physical separation, but simply the effective breakdown of the matrimonial relationship: Watson J in Todd (No. 2) (above) at [5] approved by the Full Court in Pavey [1976] FamCA 36 at [7]-[23]: “’Separation’ means more than physical separation – it involves the breakdown of the marital relationship (the consortium vitae). Separation can only occur in the sense used by the Act where one or both of the spouses form the intention to sever or not to resume the marital relationship and act on that intention, or alternatively act as if the marital relationship has been severed. What comprises the marital relationship for each couple will vary. Marriage involves many elements some or all of which may be present in a particular marriage – elements such as dwelling under the same roof, sexual intercourse, mutual society and protection, recognition of the existence of the marriage by both spouses in public and private relationships, and the nurture and support of the children of the marriage.” The Full Court applied that meaning in Falk [1977] FamCA 46 at [21], adding as a requirement the communication of the intention to sever the marital relationship to the meaning of “separation”. The Full Court in Pavey (above) (at [31]) said: “It also seems necessary to comment upon the fact that so often evidence in a case of this kind turns upon cooking, washing and housework…(It) is not possible to apply some mathematical formula to these activities and determine whether a ‘separation’ has occurred. Rather the evidence should examine and contrast the state of the marital relationship before and after the alleged separation.” The Court went on to refer to the requirement of independent corroboration: “The party or parties alleging separation must satisfy the Court about this
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: and determine whether a ‘separation’ has occurred. Rather the evidence should examine and contrast the state of the marital relationship before and after the alleged separation.” The Court went on to refer to the requirement of independent corroboration: “The party or parties alleging separation must satisfy the Court about this by explaining why the parties continue to live under the one roof, and by showing that there is a change in their relation- ship, gradual or sudden, constituting a separation. For this reason many of the judges of the Family Court of Australia have adopted the practice of requiring corroboration of the applicant’s evidence in cases where parties reside in the same residence. We do not wish to lay down an inflexible rule that evidence from a witness other than the parties to a marriage must be given, but an applicant should always be ready to call such evidence. Whether the judge will require such evidence will depend on the circumstances of each case.” Parties have been held not to have “separated” after the husband left the home as they still acted as a married couple by maintaining a sexual relationship, attending social functions and staying in hotel rooms together and operating a joint bank account: Campbell & Cade [2012] FMCAfam 508. Applying for divorce when under same roof A party wishing to apply for divorce while still living under the same roof with their spouse, instead of the usual option of first separating and then being apart for 12 months, should be advised of the greatly increased costs in proving the case (time spent preparing evidence by affidavit from applicant and corroborating witness(es) and the case being argued – perhaps by counsel – in court), and the risk of losing. See “precedents” for a sample affidavit. It may be
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: months, should be advised of the greatly increased costs in proving the case (time spent preparing evidence by affidavit from applicant and corroborating witness(es) and the case being argued – perhaps by counsel – in court), and the risk of losing. See “precedents” for a sample affidavit. It may be wise to brief counsel to settle (fine-tune) your affidavit evidence – including any independent witness’s affidavit – and to appear at the hearing. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER THREE 3 – 4 MARRIAGES OF LESS THAN TWO YEARS A divorce application shall not be filed within two years after the date of marriage, without the leave of the court, unless a certificate is filed with the application stating that the parties have considered a reconciliation with the assistance of an approved family counsellor, signed by that counsellor: s 44(1B) If the court is satisfied that there are special circumstances why the matter should proceed where the parties have not considered a reconciliation, it may grant leave for the application to be filed or (if it has been filed) declare that it is so satisfied: s 44(1C) See “precedents” for sample affidavit (but when doing so see Price [2013] FCCA 1372 at [50]-[65]). DIVORCE ORDER A divorce order under s 48(2) takes effect one month after it is made, or after a Section 55A declaration (whichever is the later): s 55(1). A Certificate of Divorce issues at that time, whereupon the parties are free to remarry. The one month period can be extended with regard to “the possibility of an appeal” per s 55(2)(a), but only reduced where “there are special circumstances” per s 55(2)(b): see Aguilar & Friel [2020] FCCA 1532. SECTION 55A DECLARATION A divorce order does not take effect unless the court has declared that it is satisfied: • that there are no children of the marriage who have not attained 18 years of age; or • that the only children of the marriage who have not attained that age are the children specified in the court’s order and that: “(i) proper arrangements in all the circumstances have been made for the care, welfare and development of those children; or (ii) there are circumstances by reason of which the divorce order should take effect even
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: MARRIAGES OF LESS THAN TWO YEARS

chunks.text: have not attained that age are the children specified in the court’s order and that: “(i) proper arrangements in all the circumstances have been made for the care, welfare and development of those children; or (ii) there are circumstances by reason of which the divorce order should take effect even though the court is not satisfied that such arrangements have been made.” Where the court is in doubt whether the arrangements are proper, it may adjourn the proceedings until a family report has been obtained as to those arrangements: s 55A(2) The section covers a child who was treated by the parties as a child of their family: ss 55(3) and (4) The Full Court said this about Section 55A declarations in Maunder [1999] FamCA 1430 at [32]: “We do not feel that the…wife’s conduct in this case can properly be said…to hold the husband to ransom. She was appropriately concerned to ensure that proper arrangements had been made for the welfare of the children. There was a positive obligation on the Court not to allow the… divorce order to…take effect unless it was so satisfied as to the arrangements or unless it was satisfied that there were circumstances by reason of which it should…take effect notwithstanding it was not so satisfied.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: MARRIAGES OF LESS THAN TWO YEARS

chunks.text: DIVORCE 3 – 5 McInnis FM said in M & M [2001] FMCAfam 329 at [20]: “I should stress that in my view, on an application for dissolution, it is not the court’s role to ef- fectively conduct an alternative hearing or dispute in relation to the issues of contact, residency and/or child support. It is sufficient that the arrangements that have been made are the arrange- ments which are, in all the circumstances, the best that could be achieved on the material before me.” EFFECT OF DIVORCE ON WILLS Throughout Australia (except WA) divorce revokes a gift of property or appointment of trusteeship made in a will in favour of a spouse, in the absence of a contrary intention being evident: the Succession Acts of NSW (s 13) and Qld (s 15) and Wills Acts of Vic (s 14), SA (s 20A), Tas (s 20), ACT (s 20A), and NT (s 15). The entire will is revoked in Tasmania (in the absence of a contrary intention or the will being made in contemplation of divorce). On 9 February 2008 WA’s Wills Act was amended to provide that wills are revoked upon divorce orders made after that date in the absence of a contrary intention in the will or other evidence of such intention (s 14A). EFFECT OF DIVORCE ON PROPERTY AND SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE APPLICATIONS There is a time limit of 12 months after a divorce order has taken effect for filing applications for property and spousal maintenance, except by leave of the court or consent of the parties: s 44(3). See chapter on “property” (under heading “time limit”) for applications for leave to extend time. A tip It can pay to keep an eye on when the 12 months are up after a separation. If your client does not
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: MARRIAGES OF LESS THAN TWO YEARS

chunks.text: leave of the court or consent of the parties: s 44(3). See chapter on “property” (under heading “time limit”) for applications for leave to extend time. A tip It can pay to keep an eye on when the 12 months are up after a separation. If your client does not need to apply for any property orders because, say, their assets are already registered in their name, advise them to issue divorce proceedings as soon as they can because the 12 month deadline will operate against their spouse for the issue of financial proceedings against your client. Conversely, the deadline can be overlooked during the distraction of negotiations and lead to your client incurring the strategic disadvantage of having to seek the other party’s consent to their (your client) issuing proceedings out of time, and having to apply for leave if consent is withheld. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: MARRIAGES OF LESS THAN TWO YEARS

chunks.text: DIVORCE 3 – 7 PROCEDURE FOR DIVORCE APPLICATIONS An application for divorce is made under Part VI of the Family Law Act 1975 and is filed in the FCFCA (Division 2) or (in WA) in the Family Court of WA. E-filing is compulsory in each Court via: • the Commonwealth Courts Portal; • in WA, the eCourts Portal of Western Australia. The practice direction “Divorce proceedings” made on 1 September 2021 applies to applications for divorce filed before or after that date. The FCFCA website has: • a step by step pathway for the filing of an Application for Divorce here. • a brochure, setting out the Court pathway, checklists and timeframes here. General notes about procedure Further to the eFiling procedure set out in the links (available at our eBook) above, the following rules still apply: • The brochure “Marriage, Families and Separation” should be given to the applicant and served on the respondent. • A marriage certificate must be filed with your application unless already filed. • Where a marriage certificate is not in English, obtain a translation and file an affidavit from an accredited translator with this form. See “precedents” below for sample affidavit. • Parties to marriages of less than 2 years (above), must attend reconciliation counselling and file a counsellor-signed certificate (“forms” below). Where such counselling is not feasible, the applicant must file an affidavit explaining why. See “precedents” for sample affidavit. • Filing fee for the application is $1,100 (or $365 if application for reduction of fee is granted) and a hearing fee of $770 if defended. • Personal service is required. Parties may not serve their own court papers. See Divorce Service Kit and for WA Service Kit. • Use process servers familiar with family law work to serve the respondent personally, within
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: reduction of fee is granted) and a hearing fee of $770 if defended. • Personal service is required. Parties may not serve their own court papers. See Divorce Service Kit and for WA Service Kit. • Use process servers familiar with family law work to serve the respondent personally, within the dead- line of 28 days before the hearing or 42 days before the hearing if served overseas (in WA cf. FCR 36). Provide them with the papers and a blank Affidavit of Service (Divorce) and Acknowledgement of Service (Divorce) (“forms” below). • Good process servers will return the service papers to you properly completed. The Affidavit may be filed without a signed Acknowledgement attached, or with it attached if it has been signed by the respondent. Any photo used to identify a respondent is also attached. File the Affidavit of Service. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER THREE 3 – 8 • Don’t be tempted to send it to the respondent or their lawyer in the hope that either of them will dutifully sign and return the acknowledgement before the service deadline. Rarely goes to plan. • Where the respondent cannot be found, you should file an Application to dispense with service or for substituted service under FLR 2.34 (in WA, FCR 136) (this rule sets out the matters the court may take into account) (see “forms” below) and an affidavit in support (“precedents” below). • Applicants need not attend the hearing where there are no children but should attend if there are children. At the hearing the court, if satisfied that the ground has been made out, will grant a Divorce Order and make a Section 55A declaration as to children. • One month later, the court will issue and send a Certificate of Divorce (certifying that the divorce order has taken effect) to each party or their lawyer if legally represented: s 56. • A respondent’s disagreement with some aspects of the applicant’s stated arrangements for the welfare of children is not a ground for opposing divorce and should be kept for their separate child-related parenting proceedings. Raising such matters at the divorce might only lead to the adjournment of the hearing for a report under s 55A(2). • There is no filing fee on a Response to Divorce. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: DIVORCE 3 – 9 COURT FORMS REQUIRED FROM APPLICANT FOR DIVORCE Online forms The following court forms can be downloaded here at our eBook or from our website www.thefamilylawbook.com.au • Copy marriage certificate E-file it in your court portal without a cover sheet. • Application for Divorce (for WA see WA’s Divorce Kit) • Affidavit of Service by Hand (Divorce) • Acknowledgment of Service (Divorce) Experienced process servers will have their own supply of these forms and be able to supply you with a sworn affidavit for filing. AND THESE FORMS WHERE APPLICABLE • Counselling certificate for applicants married less than two years To be filed by the reconciliation counsellor where parties do attend counselling • Application for order dispensing with service or an order for substituted service Use an Application in a Proceeding. No filing fee is payable. To be filed with an affidavit (see form and “precedents” below). • Application for reduction of payment of court fees – general (card holders and other categories) • Application for reduction of court fees on the basis of financial hardship (financial hardship) • Affidavit See “precedents” below for sample affidavits. ONLY IF RECOMMENDED BY A SPECIALIST OR COUNSEL • Response to Divorce See “precedents” below for order sought. Filing this without the advice of a family law specialist or counsel is not recommended. An affidavit in support is required (next form below). • Affidavit (of respondent in support of Response to Divorce) Let your specialist or barrister supply the text for this affidavit. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT FORMS REQUIRED FROM APPLICANT FOR DIVORCE

chunks.text: CHAPTER THREE 3 – 10 PRECEDENTS Online precedents The following precedents can be downloaded here or from our website www.thefamilylawbook.com.au APPLICATION FOR DIVORCE Note – E-filing of divorce applications now applies: see above. APPLICATION FOR SUBSTITUTED SERVICE Order sought That the Court make an order dispensing with service of the application for divorce on the respondent or make an order for substituted service. APPLICATION FOR ABRIDGEMENT OF TIME Order sought 1. That the Application for Divorce be heard on an urgent basis and that all times for service be abridged. 2. That pursuant to section 55(2)(b) of the Family Law Act 1975, the period at the expiration of which the divorce order will take effect be reduced to nil. Note – This application should be made by an Application in a Proceeding and be supported by an affidavit of the applicant explaining the reasons for the application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: DIVORCE 3 – 11 AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT IN SUPPORT OF AN APPLICATION TO DISPENSE WITH SERVICE OR SUBSTITUTED SERVICE 1. I am the applicant. 2. I am the [wife/husband] of [spouse’s full name] (“[spouse’s short name, e.g. Bill]”) whom I married at [place of marriage] on [date]. 3. On [date of filing] I filed an Application for Divorce in this Court, which is listed for hearing on [date]. 4. Attached to this affidavit are a copy of an instructing letter from my solicitors [firm name] to their process servers for service of my Application on [spouse’s short name] and a copy of their report. 5. [Explain when and in what circumstances your client last saw their spouse] 6. [Specify the steps your client has taken to locate their spouse through friends, family or work] 7. [Have your client identify any real estate, business, bank accounts or other property owned by their spouse] 8. [Ask your client to specify the steps taken to bring divorce proceedings to their spouse’s attention] 9. [Have your client indicate any places frequented recently by their spouse, and the likelihood of their spouse receiving it if the Application were sent or delivered there] 10. [If applicable, have your client explain any reason for their spouse to be avoiding your client or process servers] 11. [Have your client explain whether any particular advertising would be likely to come to spouse’s attention] 12. [Have your client specify any court orders or child support assessments relating to their spouse] 13. [Have your client specify the extent to which their attempts to locate their spouse may be causing your client financial hardship] 14. In these circumstances, I respectfully seek an order either dispensing with service of my Application for Divorce or an order for substituted service. Update 64 March 2025

chunks.text: CHAPTER THREE 3 – 12 AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT IN CASE OF SEPARATION UNDER THE ONE ROOF 1. I am the applicant. 2. I married [spouse’s full name] (“[spouse’s short name]”) at [place of marriage] on [date]. 3. [If applicable] We have [number] children, namely: (a) [insert first name and date of birth] (b) [insert first name and date of birth] They no longer live with us [or whatever the situation]. 4. [Explain how the marital breakdown occurred, e.g. Our marriage was fine until about [number] years ago, when we stopped talking to each other as a loving couple. Our main problems were [insert just a line or two]] 5. In about [month and year], we agreed that our marriage had no future. [If applicable – ] We had tried counselling and things had not worked out between us. We had reached screaming point with each other. We discussed the idea of one of us moving out, but the enquiries we each made came up with the same reality that neither of us could afford to move out until our house was sold. 6. We agreed on dividing the house into separate living areas, so that we could each live quite separate lives until we were able to move out and find complete independence from each other. [Specify any other reason for remaining in the same home together. Also specify any intention to change that situation] 7. Before our marital breakdown, we lived as husband and wife, being and sleeping together, sitting down to meals, socialising together, talking together about our children/our shared lives. I would cook, wash and do housework and [spouse’s short name] would do our gardening and household maintenance and look after our cars. Every morning and evening before and after work would be spent with each other.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT IN CASE OF SEPARATION UNDER THE ONE ROOF

chunks.text: sitting down to meals, socialising together, talking together about our children/our shared lives. I would cook, wash and do housework and [spouse’s short name] would do our gardening and household maintenance and look after our cars. Every morning and evening before and after work would be spent with each other. 8. After [same approx date as in 5 above], however, everything changed [OR] by the time of [same approx date] everything had changed. We had stopped sleeping together, we moved into separate bedrooms, we began cooking our own meals and doing our own laundry, living as strangers. We never went out with each other again on family outings or other shared activities, and we also stopped having friends round. We stopped talking to each other. [Give detail – in the applicant’s own language – of all other evidence of living quite separate lives] 9. [Add any other evidence relevant to the breakdown of the marriage] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: DIVORCE 3 – 13 AFFIDAVIT OF TRANSLATOR OF MARRIAGE CERTIFICATE 1. I am an approved translator. 2. I am accredited by the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters. 3. At the request of the Applicant’s lawyer I conducted a translation of the certificate of marriage between the parties, a true copy of which is attached to this affidavit. 4. Also attached is my translation of the marriage certificate which I certify as a correct translation from [language in which marriage certificate written], in which the marriage certificate is written, into English. AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT IN SHORT MARRIAGE WHERE COUNSELLING NOT ATTENDED 1. I am the applicant. 2. My [wife/husband] (“[spouse’s first name]”) and I were married on [date]. 3. I am advised by my lawyer that as my marriage took place less than two years before the filing of my divorce application, my spouse and I are required to consider a reconciliation with the assistance of a family counsellor. 4. (If respondent failed to attend counselling) An appointment was made for us to attend a family counsellor at [place] on [date] at [time]. 5. [spouse’s first name] was notified by my lawyer of that appointment and the necessity to attend. Attached is a copy of that notification. 6. I attended the appointment but [spouse’s first name] failed to attend. [Briefly add any known circumstances why he/she did not attend, e.g. “On (date) (spouse’s first name) rang me and said “I’m not going to that counsellor; you can go on your own”.] 7. I respectfully apply to this Court for leave for the divorce to proceed in the absence of a counselling certificate having regard to these special circumstances. 4. (Or if applicant is afraid to attend counselling) I am afraid of my [husband/wife], who has a history of violence,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF TRANSLATOR OF MARRIAGE CERTIFICATE

chunks.text: your own”.] 7. I respectfully apply to this Court for leave for the divorce to proceed in the absence of a counselling certificate having regard to these special circumstances. 4. (Or if applicant is afraid to attend counselling) I am afraid of my [husband/wife], who has a history of violence, abuse and intimidation throughout our time together. 5. For my protection, a domestic violence order was made against [him/her] in the [name of court] on [date]. 6. I would be petrified to have to undergo counselling with [him/her]. 7. I respectfully apply to this Court for leave for the divorce to proceed in the absence of a counselling certificate having regard to these special circumstances. RESPONSE TO DIVORCE Order sought That the application for divorce filed on [date of filing] be dismissed. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 4 JURISDICTION Proceedings relating to children are issued under Part VII of the Family Law Act (FLA). They may be issued if the child, a parent or a party to the proceedings is either present or ordinarily resident in Australia or an Australian citizen when the initiating application is filed (s 69E FLA). The Act applies to all children, whether born of or before marriage or of a de facto relationship, and whether adopted, born by artificial conception or under a surrogacy agreement (ss 4, 60F and 69E and, in the case of children of unmarried parents, a referral of State powers to the Commonwealth). Division 2 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (FCFCA) is your venue for child-related applications. A case may be transferred to Division 1 of the Court for being complex, suitable for the Magellan List or for any of the other reasons set out in paras 4.8 to 4.13 of the Court’s Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management made 1 September 2021. Note – Before issuing proceedings, both you and your clients are required to follow certain pre-action procedures. These are set out in “family dispute resolution” and “procedure” below. The court can decline to exercise jurisdiction where proceedings are pending in another country. The Full Court dealt with such a case in B & B (Re Jurisdiction) [2003] FamCA 105. The court cited the High Court decision of Henry v Henry [1996] HCA 51, adjourning proceedings in the Family Court of Aus- tralia pending a decision by the District Court of New Zealand (where proceedings were issued after the Australian proceedings were filed). The High Court applied its decision in Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd [1990] HCA 55 in which the Court held that
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: in the Family Court of Aus- tralia pending a decision by the District Court of New Zealand (where proceedings were issued after the Australian proceedings were filed). The High Court applied its decision in Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd [1990] HCA 55 in which the Court held that a party who has properly issued proceedings in Austra- lia has a prima facie right to have the proceedings determined by an Australian court unless Australia is the clearly inappropriate jurisdiction (the doctrine of forum non conveniens). In ZP v PS [1994] HCA 29 the High Court held that in a custody case involving a foreign element where the child is within the jurisdiction the doctrine of forum non conveniens does not apply and that instead the court must determine what is in the best interests of the child. Jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction State magistrates have federal jurisdiction for Part VII proceedings (s 69J). Matters not by consent (except the Magistrates Court of WA constituted by a Family Law Magistrate of WA) are transferred to the Fed- eral Circuit Court (s 69N). Note – Your local State Magistrates Court may be used to file an urgent application if an earlier hearing is available there than from the FCFCA; but if a consent order cannot be negotiated, your case will be transferred to the FCFCA without the order sought being made. Child protection and parenting orders In Dunstan & Jarrod [2009] FamCA 480, Murphy J held at [50]-[56], applying the ruling of the former Chief Justice in Re Alex [2004] FamCA 297, that the written consent of a child welfare authority provid- ed jurisdiction to the court to make parenting orders in respect of a child under the care of that authority. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 5 OBLIGATIONS OF LAWYERS The merger of courts in 2021 brought with it a shift in how family law cases proceed, with a greater emphasis on dispute resolution before and during a proceeding, and new rules to facilitate that shift. Lawyers must assist their clients to comply with their duty at all times to act consistently with the main purpose of the rules of court, being the just and timely resolution of disputes at a reasonable cost to the parties: FLR 1.04 (in WA, FCR 5-8). Also see ss 95 and 96 FLA introduced in 2023. You must comply with the lawyers’ obligations set out in clause 6 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 FLR (financial proceedings) and clause 6 of Part 2 (parenting proceedings). In the FCWA see clause 6 of Division 1 of Schedule 1 FCR (financial cases) and clause 12 of Division 2 of that Schedule (parenting cases). You are still required (s 12E FLA; s 65F FCA) to give your clients (when obtaining their instructions, we suggest) the brochure Marriage, families and separation. Explain that it is about the impact of separa- tion, any safety concerns, help lines, counselling, mandatory family dispute resolution, the advantages of reaching agreement, pre-action procedures and the steps involved in court proceedings. By their second appointment we suggest that your clients also receive the brochures Before you file – pre-action procedure for parenting cases (and, if applicable, Before you file – pre-action procedure for financial cases).
