This judicial shift in emphasis is contained in the FCFCA’s Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management, which requires “the parties and their lawyers [to] think about the best way to conduct their cases” in accordance with that shift (para 1.3). “The Court expects parties and their lawyers to have in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: shift in emphasis is contained in the FCFCA’s Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management, which requires “the parties and their lawyers [to] think about the best way to conduct their cases” in accordance with that shift (para 1.3). “The Court expects parties and their lawyers to have in mind, at all times, the cost of each step in the proceedings and whether it is necessary … [P]arties and lawyers are expected to approach proceedings in a manner directed towards identifying the issues in dispute and ascertaining the most … cost efficient method of resolution or determination. This includes … engaging in … resolution-focused communica- tion with [the] other part[y] … [A]ggressive and unnecessarily adversarial conduct will not be tolerated. … [P]arties must avoid filing evidence that is … lengthy or … of limited relevance to the issues genuinely in dispute [para 1.4].” “Any failure to comply with these requirements may attract costs orders against parties and/or practitio- ners and other consequences including … the drawing of adverse inferences, the making of a summary decree pursuant to [s 45A FLA] or orders … that a matter be heard on an undefended basis [para 1.5]” In the FCFCA you must give a copy of this Central Practice Direction to your clients before filing an initiating application (and give it to any unrepresented party as soon as possible): [1.8]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 6 FAMILY COUNSELLING Confidential family counselling is available at any time through the FCFCA’s Counselling Service or private family counsellors to help parents individually or jointly work through personal issues and care arrangements for children (see ss 10B–10E). Most family counsellors are also authorised FDR practitio- ners for the mandatory family dispute resolution stage (see FDR below). A family counsellor may decide whether or not to disclose counselling notes sought under subpoena despite the parties’ consent to disclosure: UnitingCare – Unifam Counselling & Mediation & Harkiss and Anor [2011] FamCAFC 159. Some tips Use an experienced family counsellor, who is a registered FDR provider. Find one in your area by word of mouth or by searching at www.familyrelationships.gov.au here in our eBook. A private counsellor will offer quicker appointments and after-hour times, for joint counselling and an FDR certificate in the one session if necessary. Encourage your clients to make the most of counselling, with as many joint sessions as they like where progress is being made with negotiations (perhaps, even, as to trialling a different arrange- ment of sharing the care of the children before issuing court proceedings). If your client would like counselling on their own initially, or is unwilling to talk to their spouse, refer them to another family counsellor for individual counselling first to talk through feelings that may be blocking their acceptance of the marital breakdown and readiness to discuss arrangements for the children. In such a case, the parties will need to be referred to another provider for FDR. To attempt joint counselling or any negotiations before both parties are ready to do so emotion- ally can be counterproductive. Recommended reading The following publications were designed for the information of parents (one is for children) and are available in PDF
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: need to be referred to another provider for FDR. To attempt joint counselling or any negotiations before both parties are ready to do so emotion- ally can be counterproductive. Recommended reading The following publications were designed for the information of parents (one is for children) and are available in PDF here at our eBook and at our online Archive (under “children” at “court and other brochures”): Me and my Kids: Parenting from a Distance, produced by the former Child Support Agency Because it’s for the kids – Building a secure parenting base after separation (for parents and profession- als) by child psychologist Jennifer McIntosh, Ph.D Children and separation booklet for parents by Family Relationships Online Questions and Answers about separation for children booklet by Family Relationships Online Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 7 FAMILY DISPUTE RESOLUTION Family dispute resolution (FDR) is compulsory, with some exceptions (see below). Parents are required to make a genuine effort to resolve any child-related dispute before issuing proceedings by attending FDR with an FDR practitioner (s 60I) (that’s the capital letter “I”). See ss 10H and 10J as to confidentiality. For an FDR provider near you, search the Family Relationships link under “family counselling” above. A certificate given by the FDR practitioner to your client is to be filed with your application (s 60I(7)) failing which a parenting application may be dismissed (Ellwood & Ravenhill [2019] FamCAFC 153 at [21]-[28]). FDR practitioners (who can double as family counsellors – see “family counselling” above) must comply (s 10K) with the regulations. See Part 7 of the Family Law (Family Dispute Resolution Practitioners) Regula- tions 2008. These cover FDR procedure and include the FDR provider’s discretion to dispense with FDR if satisfied that FDR would be inappropriate because a party is unable to negotiate freely due to their emotional, psychological or physical health; any unequal bargaining power; any history of violence or safety concerns; risk of child abuse; or any other reason. The FDR certificate, under s 60I(8), may certify that FDR: • did not proceed as the other party failed or refused to attend, or • did not proceed as FDR was not considered appropriate as above, or • was attended and the parties made a genuine effort to resolve the issues, or • was attended but either party did not make a genuine effort to resolve the issues. The certificate may also be dispensed with by the court under s 60I(9) for consent orders, pending Part VII proceedings, cases of alleged violence or abuse, serious contravention of an order made within 12 months, urgency
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: attended but either party did not make a genuine effort to resolve the issues. The certificate may also be dispensed with by the court under s 60I(9) for consent orders, pending Part VII proceedings, cases of alleged violence or abuse, serious contravention of an order made within 12 months, urgency (see Conlon [2019] FCCA 2195 at [23]-[41]) or inability to attend FDR, if the appli- cant files an affidavit under s 60J. For sample affidavit, see “precedents” below. Note – Instead of an affidavit and seeking a court order, it is easier in such a case for the applicant to attend FDR on their own to explain the circumstances to the FDR provider, who may issue a certificate on the second ground above (where he or she agrees that the circumstances are such that FDR would be inappropriate). Also note – the 12 month rule. Under Reg 26 of the above regulations an FDR provider must not give and an applicant must not file a certificate more than 12 months after the latest FDR or attempted FDR. Some suggestions If lawyers use FDR providers for certificates to dispense with FDR in cases that are not genuinely inappropriate for FDR, they may find the Act being amended so that only the court may dispense with FDR upon the filing of evidence by the applicant. FDR is a potent opportunity for resolution, and should not be rushed or waived unless a real exception applies. Also note – especially if parties live far from each other or one party fears being in the same room as the other – that telephone FDR is available (via internet search for “telephone dispute resolution” or “telephone mediation”). See also below “strategies for both parents to have meaningful involvement”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 8 INTERIM INJUNCTIONS The law Injunctions for the protection of a party or a child may be issued: • under s 68B(1) of the Family Law Act (and s 235 of the Family Court Act (WA)) for the personal pro- tection of a child or parent with whom the child is to live or spend time. This includes an injunction restraining a person from entering or remaining in a place of residence, employment or education of the child or parent. • under s 114(1) FLA (and s 235A FCA) as the court “considers proper”. Such injunctions include: (a) an injunction for the personal protection of a party (b) an injunction restraining a party from entering or remaining in the home or other party’s home, or a specified area that includes either property (c) an injunction restraining a party from entering the place of work of the other party (f) an injunction relating to the use or occupancy of the home Paragraph (d) is not relevant, and paragraph (e) relates to the property of a party to the marriage (covered by “injunctions” in the chapter “property”). A tip – Due to the absence of a clear remedy under the Family Law Act upon a breach of a personal protection injunction we recommend instead that you or the police apply to your local magistrates court for a domestic violence order (upon any contravention of which your client’s complaint to police would lead to the offender being charged with a breach of the order). PERSONAL PROTECTION The Full Court has held that where an injunction was made restraining a wife “from communicating with the husband by any means other than through their respective legal advisers”, it was not also proper (or necessary) for the wife to be restrained from
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a breach of the order). PERSONAL PROTECTION The Full Court has held that where an injunction was made restraining a wife “from communicating with the husband by any means other than through their respective legal advisers”, it was not also proper (or necessary) for the wife to be restrained from coming within 100 metres of the home of the husband’s new partner (who lived near the wife) where the husband had not sought an injunction in relation to his own premises. The Court held that a personal protection injunction could not be made in favour of a third party; that the third party had her own remedies in trespass; and that the non-communication injunction was “sufficiently broad to preclude the wife from communicating with the husband by physically entering or remaining upon the (new partner’s) premises”: Oates & Crest [2008] FamCAFC 29 at [67] and [71] (despite the husband’s evidence that the “wife’s behaviour in driving past, walking, cycling and coming to the residence of (his new partner) causes great distress to him and to (his new partner)”. What to file? For the wording of an injunction, see “injunction for protection of child or party” under “interim orders sought” and “affidavits for interim hearings” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 9 Power of arrest If a police officer believes, on reasonable grounds, that a person has breached an injunction by: • causing, or threatening to cause, bodily harm to the protected person or • harassing, molesting or stalking that person the police officer may arrest the person without warrant: ss 68C and 114AA The use of reasonable force in making an arrest is authorised by ss 122A and 122AA. Procedure on arrest Under ss 68C and 114AA a police officer shall bring the arrested person before the court before the due date and the person may be kept in custody if the proceedings have not been completed on the day the arrested person is brought before the court, until the court gives its decision; or orders that the person be released; or adjourns the hearing for more than 24 hours (whichever happens first). Domestic violence orders Separating parties usually find the domestic violence legislation of their State or Territory a quicker option for the protection of themselves and their children than an order from the FCFCA, so that parties will usually come to that court already protected by a domestic violence order, either interim or final. Q and A from the family law column of the writer [RGW] in the Gold Coast Bulletin – Q How do I know if a protection order from the court will keep my husband away from me and keep me safe? I’m asking because I’ve heard that court orders don’t protect women from seriously abusive partners. A I have developed a three-dimensional view about such orders (apprehended violence orders as they are called in New South Wales): 1. In most cases of low level partner violence upon a relationship ending, the outbreak is uncharacteristic and unlikely to be repeated once the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: women from seriously abusive partners. A I have developed a three-dimensional view about such orders (apprehended violence orders as they are called in New South Wales): 1. In most cases of low level partner violence upon a relationship ending, the outbreak is uncharacteristic and unlikely to be repeated once the crisis of the moment (knowing it’s over) is past. In those cases, I recommend crisis counselling in preference to an order as court action can be a blunt instrument that often makes things worse. 2. Where there is a fear of repetition of harassment, but no history of violence or other worrying conduct, then protection orders have their place in keeping people safe. Partners in this category are usually deterred from further misbehaviour. 3. In a small minority of cases the partner is so unpredictable that a protection order is not going to help, so other methods should be discussed with your counsellor and family lawyer. Lawyers will rightly be cautious when dealing with a client’s risky partner but will still often find them manageable through appropriate means including counselling and other non-adversarial strategies. See at our online archive a paper by Dr Lesley Laing “Risk assessment in Domestic Violence”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 10 SOLE OCCUPANCY Sole occupancy is not easy to obtain. The court may “as it considers proper” grant “an injunction relat- ing to the use or occupancy of the matrimonial home”: s 114(1)(f). The section applies to de facto partners as to the “use or occupancy of a specified residence of the parties” and restraint of a party from entering or remaining in that residence or specified area in which it is situated: s 114(2A). As to the court’s approach, the Full Court in Davis [1982] FamCA 73 at [10] cited with approval the fol- lowing passage from Lindenmayer J in an unreported judgment of Price delivered 12 July 1982: “…[I]t is no longer necessary that such an applicant show that it is impossible or intolerable for him or her to continue in co-occupation of the house with the other party, or that there has been some conduct by the other party which justifies his exclusion from the home. All that is necessary, it seems, is that the Court should regard the situation between the parties as being such that it would not be reasonable or sensible or practicable to expect them to continue to remain in the home together.” In Priddle [2009] FMCAfam 258 at [30]-[39] Brown FM cited Davis in which it was said that the fac- tors relevant to whether sole occupancy was “proper” included the means and needs of the parties; the needs of any children; hardship to either party or children; and, if relevant, conduct justifying one party being expelled from the home. Inconvenience was said not to be a factor and the court should “be alive to the risk that a spouse may use a sole occupancy injunction as a tactical weapon in any ongoing matrimonial conflict”. H’s alcoholism, violence
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: and, if relevant, conduct justifying one party being expelled from the home. Inconvenience was said not to be a factor and the court should “be alive to the risk that a spouse may use a sole occupancy injunction as a tactical weapon in any ongoing matrimonial conflict”. H’s alcoholism, violence and abuse towards W was found to be harming an older child in O’Dea [1980] FamCA 23. It was held that the children’s needs were such that they and W should remain in the home; that W could not be adequately housed elsewhere; and that there would be less hardship on H if he were to leave. The balance of convenience may decide the case: Kale & Karmel [2012] FamCA 851 at [17]. For a review of relevant matters, see Kimberley [2011] FamCA 406 at [39]-[61]. Conflict Conflict that is harming a party or children may tip the balance in favour of an applicant for sole and exclusive use and occupation in a close case (e.g. Grenfell and Ors [2010] FamCA 1078 at [79]-[81]). In cases of significant conflict we suggest your client apply for an interim order for sole occupancy until the final hearing. Email your barrister a full statement of your instructions as to events between the parties – especially conflict – with a brief to advise on the adequacy of those facts for a sole occupancy injunction, and as to the form of the injunction if one is recommended. In Rainsford [2010] FMCAfam 231 at [37]-[68] W failed to discharge the onus of proving that she needed sole occupancy. See Ledarn [2010] FamCA 1107 as to sole occupancy of business premises. In Krusaroski and Anor [2012] FamCA 201 at [17]-[26] weight was given to the “needs … of the children” and a co-owner (H’s brother) was found
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: failed to discharge the onus of proving that she needed sole occupancy. See Ledarn [2010] FamCA 1107 as to sole occupancy of business premises. In Krusaroski and Anor [2012] FamCA 201 at [17]-[26] weight was given to the “needs … of the children” and a co-owner (H’s brother) was found to have acquiesced in the parties living there. In Sarto [2022] FedCFamC1A 16 at [30] H failed to show that it would be “proper” for W to be denied possession of a property solely owned by her. Where the existence of a de facto relationship is in issue sole occupancy may not be granted except in compelling circumstances: Norton & Locke [2013] FamCAFC 202. See “precedents” (“interim parenting orders”) for our sole occupancy injunction, and for more cases see our archived children’s (or property) case notes under “sole occupancy”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 11 PARENTING ORDERS Section 64B(2) provides that a parenting order (which may be made in favour of a parent or non-parent, including a grandparent or other relative of the child) may deal with one or more of the following: (a) the person with whom a child is to live; (b) the time a child is to spend with another person; (c) the allocation of parental responsibility for a child (including the making of decisions about major long-term issues in relation to the child: subsection (3), as to which see s 61D(3) and s 61DAA relating to parenting orders dealing with allocating responsibility for making decisions about major long-term issues); Note – The FLA contemplates non-parents being granted parental responsibility (see ss 64B(2)(d), 61D(1) and 65C) despite ss 61B, 61C and 61DA appearing to limit such responsibility to parents. (d) the form of consultations those who share parental responsibility are to have with each other about decisions to be made when exercising that responsibility; (e) the communication a child is to have with another person (by letter, phone, email, other electronic or other means: subsection(4)); (f) maintenance of a child; (g) the steps to be taken (including consultation with a family dispute resolution practitioner: subsection (4A)) to take account of the changing needs or circumstances of a child or the parties before an application is made to a court for a variation of an order; (h) the process to be used for resolving disputes about the terms or operation of an order (including consultation with a family dispute resolution practitioner: subsection (4A)); (i) any other aspect of the care, welfare or development of, or parental responsibility for, a child. What to file? For the wording of parenting orders and affidavits in support, see “interim orders” and “final orders”
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: operation of an order (including consultation with a family dispute resolution practitioner: subsection (4A)); (i) any other aspect of the care, welfare or development of, or parental responsibility for, a child. What to file? For the wording of parenting orders and affidavits in support, see “interim orders” and “final orders” and sample “affidavits for interim hearings” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 12 Who may issue child-related proceedings? A parent, the child, a grandparent or any other person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child: s 65C As to non-parent applications, leading case law was cited in Venkatesan & Pawar [2007] FMCAfam 1109 at [9] by Altobelli FM who said: “ … [W]hat is interesting about these cases is the common feature … that there has to be some relationship between, or involvement with, the child in a meaningful sense in order that the person who makes the application can have standing.” On 1 March 2009, the FLA’s definition of “children” was extended, so that now both parties to a mar- riage or de facto relationship (opposite or same sex) will be parents, under the Act and for child support purposes, of a child: • of whom each party is the biological parent or a child adopted by either or both with the consent of the other: ss 60F and 60HA • born through artificial conception procedures where one of the parties is the birth mother and the donor of the genetic material has consented to its use: s 60H(1) • born as part of a surrogacy arrangement where a court has made an order under a State or Territory law concerning parentage: s 60HB A couple caring for a child under a traditional Torres Strait Islander (Kupai Osmasker) adoption were “persons concerned with the care of the child” although the court could not decide that they had become the adoptive parents under local laws of adoption: Lara, Marley & Sharp [2003] FamCA 1393 (Nicholson CJ). In Halifax & Fabian & Ors [2009] FMCAfam 972 at [34]-[5], where former partners each had a child from different sperm donors, Purdon-Sully FM held that one of those
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: that they had become the adoptive parents under local laws of adoption: Lara, Marley & Sharp [2003] FamCA 1393 (Nicholson CJ). In Halifax & Fabian & Ors [2009] FMCAfam 972 at [34]-[5], where former partners each had a child from different sperm donors, Purdon-Sully FM held that one of those donors and his new [male] partner could apply for an order opposing the relocation sought by one mother. The court held the male couple [and the other mother] to be “persons concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child” under s 65C, finding at [46]-[55] that the mother had agreed they be involved in her child’s life; and that they had been involved. See also Wilson and Anor & Roberts and Anor (No. 2) [2010] FamCA 734 at [8], [38]-[52], [325]-[336] and [338] (homosexual parents v homosexual non-parents). Counselling before parenting orders A court must not make such an order unless the parties have attended family counselling to discuss the matter: s 65F. Exceptions are: • the court is satisfied of an urgent need for the order • some other special circumstance such as family violence • the court is satisfied of it not being practicable to require counselling • orders by consent or interim orders (those made “until further order”) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 13 Consent orders • require the court’s sanction. FLR 10.07 (in WA, FCR 169) provides that if a party applies for a consent order the court may make the orders sought or dismiss the application. It may also require a party to file additional information. In T & N [2003] FamCA 1129 Moore J refused to make a consent order for unsupervised contact as allegations indicating an unacceptable risk to the children from such an order had not been tested. The court also informed the child welfare authorities of the prospect of an informal ar- rangement being made between the parties. From 6 May 2024, s 60CC(4) provides that if the court is considering whether to make a parent- ing order by consent it may, but is not required to, have regard to all or any of the matters set out in s 60CC(2) or (3). • Consent orders in favour of a non-relative require the parties to attend a conference with a family consultant to discuss the proposed order unless the court is satisfied that there are circumstances that “make it appropriate” to make an order without such a conference: s 65G. • For how to enter into a consent order, see “consent orders” in Chapter 8. Obligations and consequences of contravention These may (and usually are) explained to the parties in an attachment to the order supplied by the court: s 65DA. See “contravention of parenting orders” below. Compliance may be supervised or assisted by a family consultant: s 65L Cessation of parenting orders • when a child turns 18 or is married or in a de facto relationship: s 65H • when a child is adopted subsequent to a parenting order being in force (s 65J) unless leave to adopt was not granted under
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a family consultant: s 65L Cessation of parenting orders • when a child turns 18 or is married or in a de facto relationship: s 65H • when a child is adopted subsequent to a parenting order being in force (s 65J) unless leave to adopt was not granted under s 60G • when the parent with whom the child is to live dies (Note – the surviving parent is not authorised to require such a child to live with them): s 65K Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 14 OBJECTS OF PART VII – CHILDREN From 6 May 2024, s 60B provides that the objects of Part VII are: (a) to ensure that the best interests of children are met, including by ensuring their safety; and (b) to give effect to the Convention on the Rights of the Child done [sic] at New York on 20 November 1989. Note – The text of the Convention is set out in Australian Treaty Series 1991 No. 4 ([1991] ATS 4). Note – While the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 removed paras (a) to (e) of s 60B(1) as to how “best interests” are to be met (such as ensuring a child’s meaningful involvement with both parents) and s 60B(2) (as to the underlying principles, such as a child’s right to know both parents), such matters may nevertheless be arguable under the amended s 60CC (below) (and see Articles 7, 9, 10 and 29(1)(c) of Part 1 of the Convention above) as a consideration for what is in a child’s best interests. CHILD’S BEST INTERESTS PARAMOUNT CONSIDERATION Section 60CA requires the court, when deciding whether to make a parenting order, to regard “the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 15 DETERMINING CHILD’S BEST INTERESTS From 6 May 2024, s 60CC reads as follows: (1) Subject to subsection (4), in determining what is in the child’s best interests, the court must: (a) consider the matters set out in subsection (2); and (b) if the child is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander child—also consider the matters set out in subsection (3). General considerations (2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(a), the court must consider the following matters: (a) what arrangements would promote the safety (including safety from being subjected to, or exposed to, family violence, abuse, neglect, or other harm) of: (i) the child; and (ii) each person who has care of the child (whether or not a person has parental responsibil- ity for the child); (b) any views expressed by the child; (c) the developmental, psychological, emotional and cultural needs of the child; (d) the capacity of each person who has or is proposed to have parental responsibility for the child to provide for the child’s developmental, psychological, emotional and cultural needs; (e) the benefit to the child of being able to have a relationship with the child’s parents, and other people who are significant to the child, where it is safe to do so; (f) anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of the child. (2A) In considering the matters set out in paragraph (2)(a), the court must include consideration of: (a) any history of family violence, abuse or neglect involving the child or a person caring for the child (whether or not the person had parental responsibility for the child); and (b) any family violence order that applies or has applied to the child or a member of the child’s family. Additional considerations—right to enjoy Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture (3)
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: or a person caring for the child (whether or not the person had parental responsibility for the child); and (b) any family violence order that applies or has applied to the child or a member of the child’s family. Additional considerations—right to enjoy Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture (3) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), the court must consider the following matters: (a) the child’s right to enjoy the child’s Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture, by having the support, opportunity and encouragement necessary: (i) to connect with, and maintain their connection with, members of their family and with their community, culture, country and language; and (ii) to explore the full extent of that culture, consistent with the child’s age and developmental level and the child’s views; and (iii) to develop a positive appreciation of that culture; and (b) the likely impact any proposed parenting order under this Part will have on that right. Consent orders (4) If the court is considering whether to make an order with the consent of all the parties to the proceedings, the court may, but is not required to, have regard to all or any of the matters set out in subsection (2) or (3). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 16 PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY “Parental responsibility” means all the duties, powers, responsibilities and authority which, by law, par- ents have in relation to children: s 61B. Parents are legally responsible for their children until a parenting order or plan provides otherwise: s 61C. Parenting plan Parenting plans are not recommended, mainly because they cannot be enforced as an order can (except indirectly via an application for a parenting order under s 65C as to which the court must have regard to the terms of any parenting plan “if doing so would be in the best interests of the child” under s 65DAB). An Application for Consent Orders is the way to go, and the cost is about the same. For those parties who would nevertheless prefer their own informal arrangement see our precedent parent- ing plan (with explanatory notes) at our online “forms and precedents”. Consultation between parents on major long-term issues “If it is safe to do so, and subject to any court orders, the parents of a child who is not yet 18 are encouraged: (a) to consult each other about major long-term issues in relation to the child; and (b) in doing so, to have regard to the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration.” (s 61CA introduced by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023) Orders as to responsibility for major long-term issues “A parenting order that deals with the allocation of responsibility for making decisions about major long-term issues in relation to the child (see subsection 64B(3)) may provide for joint or sole decision-making in relation to all or specified major long-term issues.” (s 61D(3)) “Major long-term issues” These are defined in s 4(1) as issues about: • the child’s education (current and future) (see “child’s education” below) • the child’s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to the child (see subsection 64B(3)) may provide for joint or sole decision-making in relation to all or specified major long-term issues.” (s 61D(3)) “Major long-term issues” These are defined in s 4(1) as issues about: • the child’s education (current and future) (see “child’s education” below) • the child’s religious and cultural upbringing (see para (g) of “section 60CC factors” below) • the child’s health • the child’s name (see “change of child’s name” below) • “changes to the child’s living arrangements that make it significantly more difficult for the child to spend time with a parent” (e.g. a proposed relocation with a new partner) (see “relocation” below) • any other long-term issue about the care, welfare and development of the child “It is … imperative that [such] orders … be accompanied by as little ambiguity as practicable … especially … given the extent to which third parties such as schools and hospitals [also passports office, registry of births etc: Ed] rely upon court orders to satisfy themselves about the authority of parents to make decisions about their children”: Chappell [2008] FamCAFC 143 (FC) at [69]. Also see Withers & Russell and Anor [2016] FamCA 793 at [447]-[471]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 17 Effect of orders for joint decision-making on major long-term issues Section s 61DAA introduced by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 provides: “(1) If a parenting order provides for joint decision-making by persons in relation to all or specified major long-term issues in relation to a child, then, except to the extent the order otherwise specifies, the order is taken to require each of the persons: (a) to consult each other person in relation to each such decision; and (b) to make a genuine effort to come to a joint decision. (2) To avoid doubt, this section does not require any other person to establish, before acting on a decision about the child communicated by one of those persons, that the decision has been made jointly.” Note – Where there is an order for joint decision-making, the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 only obliges consultation and a genuine effort to agree as to long-term decisions. There is no longer a requirement that the decision be made jointly (as s 65DAC was repealed). Arguments for joint decision-making on major long-term issues Note – While cases heard between 2006 and 2023 that ruled in favour of a statutory presumption of equal shared parental responsibility that has been repealed, they are nonetheless arguable in sup- port of a case for joint decision-making on major long-term issues under the Family Law Amendment Act 2023, not as factual comparisons but by reference to the type of evidence which led those courts to hold that such decisions should be jointly made. Examples are: Reddin & Bickett [2022] FedCFamC1F 910 at [193] (final order made for joint decision-making despite the parents’ “toxic relationship and a mutual disrespect for each other” ([204]) as “both parents spoke of a willingness and desire to co-parent into
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to hold that such decisions should be jointly made. Examples are: Reddin & Bickett [2022] FedCFamC1F 910 at [193] (final order made for joint decision-making despite the parents’ “toxic relationship and a mutual disrespect for each other” ([204]) as “both parents spoke of a willingness and desire to co-parent into the future”). Goode (No. 2) [2007] FamCA 315 at [61]-[63] (interim hearing; F involved in children’s arrangements and capable of compromise since separation). Bookhurst [2009] FamCA 6 at [158]-[162] (final hearing; F found to have been violent and lack insight into children’s health, religious and cultural upbringing was granted a share of other deci- sion-making as to which “the parties appear to be at one”; “such parental input should be for [the children’s] benefit”). Pilcher & Schneider [2007] FMCAfam 1163 at [70]-[72] (interim hearing; M said F was a bully but did not allege violence by him since separation more than a year ago). C & B [2007] FMCAfam 855 at [47] (interim hearing; while findings about violence and drugs were left to a final hearing, both parties were “capable of having a useful role in E’s life”). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 18 The case against – Cases where sole decision-making was ordered Note – While these cases were decided in the context whether a presumption of equal shared parental responsibility should apply (which was repealed by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023), they none- theless may be useful not as factual comparisons but as the type of evidence which led those courts to require sole decision-making relating to major long-term issues. In N & M [2006] FamCA 958 M was given sole decision-making where F, who had been violent but not since separation, was unreliable, failed to cooperate about the children and undermined their relation- ship with M. In R & R [2007] FMCAfam 29 at [84], [86], [91] and [109]–[115] Brown FM made the same order, finding in the face of contested allegations of violence against F that there was “a significant level of dysfunction in the parental relationship” and that the court had “considerable reservations about whether the parties [were] likely to be able to engage in such a consultative and consensual decision- making process about their children”. In Penski & Kocher [2013] FamCA 255 at [71]–[73] an order that M have sole responsibility was preferred to F’s proposed division of responsibilities. In Grant & Terry [2008] FMCAfam 694, sole responsibility was given to M where F was a bully; and in Mashman & Lockwood [2009] FMCAfam 1171 at [47], [69]–[72], where, due to M’s regular abuse of alcohol and nitrazepam, “it would simply be dangerous for the child for M to be left in charge”. See Slade & McIntosh [2009] FamCA 1187 (mental health and drug abuse); Robins & Ruddock [2010] FamCA 35 (risk of emotional abuse of children from parental conflict) and Snell & Bagley [2011] FMCAfam 526 at [120] (high degree of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: dangerous for the child for M to be left in charge”. See Slade & McIntosh [2009] FamCA 1187 (mental health and drug abuse); Robins & Ruddock [2010] FamCA 35 (risk of emotional abuse of children from parental conflict) and Snell & Bagley [2011] FMCAfam 526 at [120] (high degree of conflict). An interim order for sole responsibility was upheld in Gainforth [2012] FamCAFC 24 (FC) at [22]–[27]. Where F held rigid views and the parties had “very different parenting styles” sole responsibility was given to M in Luu & Xia [2013] FMCAfam 35. No need to consult on day to day issues Section 61DAB, introduced by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023, provides: “(1) If a child is spending time with a person at a particular time under a parenting order, the order is taken not to require the person to consult a person who: (a) has parental responsibility for the child; or (b) shares parental responsibility for the child with another person; about decisions that are made in relation to the child during that time on issues that are not major long-term issues. Note – This will mean that the person with whom the child is spending time will usually not need to consult on decisions about such things as what the child eats or wears because these are usually not major long-term issues. (2) Subsection (1) applies subject to any provision to the contrary made by a parenting order.” In VR & RR [2002] FamCA 320 at [28]-[30] the Full Court said that the court will not interfere with how a parent sees fit to care for a child in their care under an order unless “the welfare of the child will be clearly advanced” by doing so (M unsuccessfully took issue with F’s arrangements while the children
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the Full Court said that the court will not interfere with how a parent sees fit to care for a child in their care under an order unless “the welfare of the child will be clearly advanced” by doing so (M unsuccessfully took issue with F’s arrangements while the children were on “his” time). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 20 EQUAL TIME OR UNEQUAL TIME Note – The concept of equal time was introduced to the Act in 2006 but repealed by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023. Equal time will nevertheless continue to be the care arrangement of choice for many parents and may still be an arrangement imposed by the court under existing interim or final orders. See our archived children’s case notes under “equal time” for cases in which it was found that either an equal or unequal time arrangement would be in the best interests of the children. Research findings In a presentation to Queensland’s Family Law Residential on 15 August 2008, a leading social scien- tist, Dr Bruce Smyth, referred to preliminary analysis of trends since the introduction of shared care as pointing to 53% of shared care arrangements in the general population ending within 12 months. He argued that shared care can work really well for some families, but badly for others, especially those marked by high conflict. In the writer’s view [RGW], equal care is not something our clients should be aspiring to because, like Everest, “it’s there”. We should ensure that clients seeking equal care are, in the interests of the children, being realistic as to the long-term feasibility of their proposal. Arguments in favour of equal time In Astor [2007] FamCA 355 O’Reilly J concluded that the children’s best interests would be served by an order that they spend equal time with each parent and did so ([195]) after “carefully considering” two pre-2006 decisions. Her Honour said at [104]-[106]: “[Mr Jordan of counsel for the father] referred to the decision of the Chief Justice (then Chief Federal Magistrate Bryant) in C & O’N [2003] FMCAfam 154 as authority for the proposition that, despite differences between parties,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: so ([195]) after “carefully considering” two pre-2006 decisions. Her Honour said at [104]-[106]: “[Mr Jordan of counsel for the father] referred to the decision of the Chief Justice (then Chief Federal Magistrate Bryant) in C & O’N [2003] FMCAfam 154 as authority for the proposition that, despite differences between parties, shared care may still be in the children’s best interests. In that case, it was determined that the children’s best interests would be served by week about equal time (7pm Sunday to 7pm Sunday) despite the circumstances that there had been verbal and physical altercations between the parties (par 22); resentment in one of the parties (par 22); and inclusion in the family report of the observation that ‘one of the difficulties with shared care is that usually for shared care to work in the children’s best interests it is necessary for the parties to co-operate and facilitate this arrangement’ (par 32). However, taking into account all relevant factors, and in particular ‘the children’s excellent relationship with both parents and desire to have both parents playing an important role in their lives’, Her Honour concluded on balance in favour of an equal time shared care regime. See the reasons at par 62-67. Mr Jordan (as was appropriate) did not seek to make any factual comparison between that deci- sion and the present case, but rather referred to it as showing that cooperation and communi- cation difficulties do not always lead to the result that equal time will not be ordered if for other good reason equal time is found to be in the children’s best interests. Mr Jordan referred also to the decision of Ryan J (then Federal Magistrate Ryan) in T & N [2001] FMCAfam 222 at par 93, in relation to the factors that a court should ‘particularly
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: if for other good reason equal time is found to be in the children’s best interests. Mr Jordan referred also to the decision of Ryan J (then Federal Magistrate Ryan) in T & N [2001] FMCAfam 222 at par 93, in relation to the factors that a court should ‘particularly examine’ in cases where a party seeks orders that share a child’s time equally between parents, to demon- strate, it would appear, that the matter of the parties’ capacity to communicate on matters relevant to the children’s welfare is but one factor to be considered. In the particular circumstances of this case, I will set out par 93 in full: Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 21 ‘The factors that the court should particularly examine in cases where a party seeks orders that share a child’s time equally between its parents (or others) include the following: • The parties’ capacity to communicate on matters relevant to the child’s welfare. • The physical proximity of the two households. • Are the homes sufficiently proximate that the child can maintain their friendships in both homes? • The prior history of caring for the child. Have the parties demonstrated that they can implement a 50/50 living arrangement without undermining the child’s adjustment? • Whether the parties agree or disagree on matters relevant to the child’s day to day life. For example, methods of discipline, attitudes to homework, health and dental care, diet and sleeping pattern. • Where they disagree on these matters the likelihood that they would be able to reach a reasonable compromise. • Do they share similar ambitions for the child? For example, religious adherence, cultural identity and extra-curricular activities. • Can they address on a continuing basis the practical considerations that arise when a child lives in 2 homes? If the child leaves necessary school work or equipment at the other home will the parents readily rectify the problem? • Whether or not the parties respect the other party as a parent. • The child’s wishes and the factors that influence those wishes. • Where siblings live.’ O’Reilly J’s conclusion as to best interests is at [192]-[193], the order for equal time being found ([196]-[200) to be “reasonably practicable”. Note – While the Court so found so as to satisfy the provi- sion of the now repealed s 65DAA, courts post-2023 will still be considering whether an equal time arrangement is workable (practicable), as the checklist set out in T & N above
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: found ([196]-[200) to be “reasonably practicable”. Note – While the Court so found so as to satisfy the provi- sion of the now repealed s 65DAA, courts post-2023 will still be considering whether an equal time arrangement is workable (practicable), as the checklist set out in T & N above demonstrates. In Biss [2009] FamCA 1234 at [214] O’Reilly J concluded that “having considered the positive and neg- ative factors as to whether equal time is in the children’s best interests, I have determined firmly that it is”. A positive factor in that case ([179]) was the fact that an equal time arrangement had been “successfully implemented” by the parties for 10 months, O’Reilly J saying: “ … [W]hilst it is true that the case authorities and other literature traditionally have not favoured equal time arrangements where parties have a lack of communication, I would refer again to my observation during the trial of genuine willingness by each to address this matter. There is good reason to think … that as time goes on and the parties’ mutual bitterness recedes their communi- cation skills in relation to the children will improve, as each gets on with his and her separate life.” In Reddin & Bickett [2022] FedCFamC1F 910 Kari J said at [193]: “While these matters [at [204] the parents’ ‘toxic relationship and a mutual disrespect for each other’] appear to contra indicate these parents being able to effectively co-parent in any way moving forward, I am conscious that both parents spoke of a willingness and desire to co-parent into the future. … ” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 22 Her Honour concluded at [199] and [200]: “I accept that often times, such findings would suggest that it is best that the children have a pri- mary base with one parent, and very limited time spending with the other parent. What is inescapable however, is: (a) That both parents have contributed to the current state of affairs; and (b) That these children, if permitted by each of their parents, derive significant benefit from the relationship that they have with each of their parents.” In Rappel [2010] FamCA 280 at [173] Murphy J concluded: “On balance, I consider that K should have the benefit of such parenting as each of her parents are able to provide by spending equal amounts of time with each parent.” In Banning & Wylie [2009] FMCAfam 1049 Lapthorn FM made an order that F’s time be increased incrementally towards equal time once the child (aged 3 years and 10 months) began school. The Court (at [62]) disagreed with the family consultant’s view that the parties were unable to “cooperate and be respectful in their parenting relationship”. Arguments against equal time Again, our archived children’s case notes under “equal time” contain cases where week about care has been rejected, such as the following: Marchand & Mahony [2017] FCWA 67 – Shift working F’s application for equal time dismissed as it was neither in the child’s best interests nor reasonably practicable – Order made for lesser time, to be com- menced based on F’s work roster. Willis & Field [2014] FCCA 514 – Parents had been spending equal time with 2 young children for 11 months as a (reluctant) compromise – Continuation of equal time opposed by M who proposed that children live with F if not with her in preference to equal
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: F’s work roster. Willis & Field [2014] FCCA 514 – Parents had been spending equal time with 2 young children for 11 months as a (reluctant) compromise – Continuation of equal time opposed by M who proposed that children live with F if not with her in preference to equal time – M found to be more in tune with children’s needs – Parenting order in her favour (“the ability of the parties to implement the arrangement and to communicate to resolve difficulties is so poor that equal time is not reasonably practicable [workable]” ([44])). Thackeray & Rand [2013] FCCA 875 – Long-standing equal time arrangement varied at final hear- ing – F’s “uncompromising”, abusive treatment of M – Recommendation of week about time by family report writer not followed (“F undermines and denigrates the importance of the relationship with M and with others significant in his life, and that is a factor which weighs heavily in emphasising the need for a reduction in time with F and a corresponding increase in time to be spent with M” ([118])). Holman-Lloyd & Lloyd [2010] FamCA 840 – Failure of equal time – Children’s desire for home base Akston & Boyle [2010] FamCAFC 56 (FC) – Order of FMC for equal time set aside – “Unacceptable risk” to child – F’s drug use (“a very harrowing history of abuse of the child” per O’Ryan J at [41]). Connelly & Wilshire [2022] FedCFamC2F 928 – Equal time in place for 4 years was varied to alterna- tive weekends to F – Escalating parental conflict – Poor co-parenting – Mental health concerns Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 24 RESEARCH STUDIES Different kinds of “time” Altobelli FM in M & K [2007] FMCAfam 918 at [14], under the heading “significance of time”, referred to a 2005 paper by leading Australian researcher, Bruce Smyth, “Time to Rethink Time?”, which found that: “…the greater the range of context for interaction between parents and their children, the better (for)…children’s social, emotional and cognitive development…(and for) opportunities for parents to build emotional bonds with their children”. The court went on to refer to the paper’s reference to the importance of a mix of activities and experiences of time forming the hub of family life, such as overnight, one-on-one together, out- door, fun or special and, in particular, “being-in-the-moment” time. The court referred to (the now repealed) s 65DAA(3) as the Act’s attempt to incorporate this social science perspective into law. The wide variety of activities and time experiences described at [14] of the judgment should help your clients set out in their affidavits their own case for the benefit to the children of having a relationship with your client (s 60CC(2)(e)). Options for parental care have been identified from research by Bruce Smyth (above) and Richard Chisholm (former judge of the Family Court of Australia), “Exploring options for parental care of children following sepa- ration: A primer for family law specialists” (2006) 20 Australian Journal of Family Law 193”, which included the following conclusions: • “The alternating weekend pattern…simply assigned mothers all the work of raising children, including discipline, homework, and child care, and…excluded fathers from these normal parenting responsibilities and opportunities” (US researcher, Joan Kelly at p 197). • Although fathers, in particular, are now seeking and being granted more time, through longer weekends, more midweek time, and time with children at an earlier age than was
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: discipline, homework, and child care, and…excluded fathers from these normal parenting responsibilities and opportunities” (US researcher, Joan Kelly at p 197). • Although fathers, in particular, are now seeking and being granted more time, through longer weekends, more midweek time, and time with children at an earlier age than was allowed before, the traditional arrangement of alternate weekends and half the school holidays still works well for dads with demanding work schedules or who cannot afford extended time, and where children need stability or want the freedom to connect with peers (as with teenage children) (p 205). • “Any discussion between parents should always start with the children’s needs and weekly activities. Some patterns of care can look horrendous on paper but can work well when children’s activities are the pivot points around which changeovers and care arrangements occur” (p 201). • A block of 3-4 nights a fortnight from Thursday or Friday night to Monday morning before school, with some midweek time built around the children’s after-school activities (taking them, being there, then sharing a meal, taking them home) is emerging as a means of greater involvement by dads with their children, with minimal disruption to the school week (also, respite for the primary carer). One or two nights precede a school day (Thursday being the least disruptive for overnight care as it winds down to the last day of the school week), so dad is involved not just in “fun time” but during the children’s midweek routine, e.g. by being around more, preparing school lunches, homework help, bedtime and the morning ritual of getting the children off to school (p 205). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 25 • 50/50 care requires cooperation, financial resources and great effort, especially by children, to make it workable, and so is “typically adopted in Australia by a relatively small group of well-educated, dual career, parents with primary school aged children”. Many developmental psychologists view such arrangements as not suiting some children, including young children and those caught in the middle of high levels of conflict (pp 199 and 207). • “Most (research) models emphasise the importance of stability and predictability for infants (0–18 months) and young children (18 months–3 years) – including daily time with each parent where possible, a predictable eating and sleeping routine, and limited overnight stays with the (other) parent until children are older – although there is… debate and little data about when overnights should start” (p 212). (Cited research on this included T Altobelli’s paper, “Rethinking contact arrangements involving young children” (2005) 19 AJFL 29–43.) • Where there is high and continuing parental conflict, spending time with an abusive parent may be highly inappropriate, with serious, long-lasting adverse effects on children (pp 200 and 211). • Blocks of time with an after-school pick-up and before school drop-off reduces the opportunity for parental conflict (Kelly at p 206). • A lengthy discussion of age-based parenting plans by US researcher Dr Robert E Emery in his book “Two Homes, One Childhood”. • “Parents need to be encouraged to think more laterally about what arrangements might work best for their children and themselves. One of the aims of this article is to highlight the importance of unstructured (‘being-in-the-moment’) time with children in the hope that what matters is how time is spent and experienced, not just how it is…distributed.” (p 217) • Child-sensitive assistance is available at Family Relationship Centres (and from private family counsellors)
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the aims of this article is to highlight the importance of unstructured (‘being-in-the-moment’) time with children in the hope that what matters is how time is spent and experienced, not just how it is…distributed.” (p 217) • Child-sensitive assistance is available at Family Relationship Centres (and from private family counsellors) (p 217). Overnight contact for young children Altobelli FM’s paper “Children’s Attachment – Its Impact on Family Law Practice” presented at the Independent Children’s Lawyer Training Program, Law Council of Australia, Melbourne,November 2006, questions the conventional view that young children (under 3) should have frequent but not overnight time with (usually the father) so as not to compromise their attachment with the primary carer (usually the mother), referring to child development theory that young children form multiple attachments which should be maintained by including overnight time with each parent, even dur- ing infancy. Judge Altobelli kindly gave permission for us to publish his two papers above and the latter paper (“Children’s Attachment”) was supplied by courtesy of the Family Law Section of the Law Council. How to use research studies Cite research findings that parental conflict predicts poor outcomes for a shared care ar- rangement, as adopted by Altobelli FM in Beadle [2009] FMCAfam 1147 at [25]-[30] and [103]-[109] and SCVG & KLD [2010] FMCAfam 641 at [26]-[31]. The Court can only rely on academic articles if the parties have received procedural fairness as to same; and where the article is in evidence: Shell & Armel [2022] FedCFamC1A 83 at [42] and Berry & Andrews [2022] FedCFamC1A 120 at [15] and [16]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 26 THE COURT’S APPROACH TO INTERIM HEARINGS Interim hearings proceed “on the papers” (the filed application and affidavits in support are tendered and submissions made), instead of oral evidence being taken and the parties and their witnesses cross- examined as occurs at the final hearing. The Full Court’s decision of Goode [2006] FamCA 1346 will no longer be good law, given that it was decided on sections of the Act introduced in 2006 to create the concept of equal time, which from 6 May 2024 have been repealed. Goode does contain at [66]-[71] a discussion of Cowling [1998] FamCA 19, a decision of the Full Court decided before the 2006 amendment of the Family Law Act, at a time when “it was left to case law to formulate the methodology to be adopted in interim applications” ([66]). The repeal of the law on which Goode was decided effectively reinstates the authority of Cowling as to the courts’ approach to interim hearings. Applying previous authority ([15]) as to that approach as “still relevant”, the Full Court in Cowling said at [18]: “( … ) The issue for determination at an interim hearing involves a consideration of what orders should be made to properly regulate the position of the children pending the final determination of the matter. Such proceedings are an abridged process where the scope of the inquiry is necessarily significantly curtailed. As a consequence, the Court needs to exercise considerable caution against being drawn into matters properly dealt with in the trial process. Ordinarily, at interim hearings, the Court should not be drawn into issues of fact or matters relating to the merits of the substantive cases of each of the parties. Accordingly, in determining what orders should be made, the Court traditionally looks to the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: properly dealt with in the trial process. Ordinarily, at interim hearings, the Court should not be drawn into issues of fact or matters relating to the merits of the substantive cases of each of the parties. Accordingly, in determining what orders should be made, the Court traditionally looks to the less contentious matters, such as the agreed facts, the care arrangements prior to separation, the current circumstances of the parties and their children and the parties’ respective proposals for the future. In some cases, it may also be necessary to consider child protection issues.” The Court then ([19]-[25]) summarised the relevant criteria for determining interim proceedings: 1. “The best interests of the child” are “paramount” (s 60CA). 2. “Those interests will normally be best met by ensuring stability in the life of the child pending a full hearing.” 3. “Where the evidence clearly establishes that … the child is living in an environment in which he or she is well settled, the child’s stability will usually be promoted by the making of an order which provides for the continuation of that arrangement until the hearing for final orders, unless there are strong or overriding indications relevant to the child’s welfare to the contrary … [e.g.] convincing proof that the child’s welfare would be really endangered by his/her remaining in that environment.” 4. “In determining what weight to place upon [the importance of retaining the child’s current living arrangements] … the Court [should] take account of the circumstances giving rise to the current status quo. In particular: • whether the current circumstances have arisen by virtue of some agreement between the parties or as a result of acquiescence. • whether the current arrangements have been unilaterally imposed. • the duration of the current arrangements and … any undue delay in instituting
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the current status quo. In particular: • whether the current circumstances have arisen by virtue of some agreement between the parties or as a result of acquiescence. • whether the current arrangements have been unilaterally imposed. • the duration of the current arrangements and … any undue delay in instituting proceedings or in [their] being listed for hearing.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 27 5. “Where the evidence does not establish that … the child is living in an environment in which he or she is well settled, some limited evaluation of the relevant matters referred to in s 68F(2) [repealed, so see s 60CC] needs to be undertaken to ensure that … the order promotes the child’s best interests … ” 6. “In determining whether, at the date of hearing, a child is living in a settled environment, consideration should be given, inter alia, to the following: • the wishes, age and level of maturity of the child [but see s 60CC(2)(b)]. • the current and proposed arrangements for the day to day care of the child [arguable under s 60CC(2)(f)]. • the period during which the child has lived in the environment [arguable under s 60CC(2)(f)]. • whether the child has any siblings and where they reside [see s 60CC(2)(e)]. • the nature of the relationship between the child, each parent, any other significant adult and his or her siblings [see s 60CC(2)(e)]. • the educational needs of the child [(see s 60CC(2)(c), (d) and (f)].” See “unilateral relocation” below for interim orders which allowed unilateral relocation. In McDermott & Bond [2009] FamCA 1161 at [19]-[46] it was ordered that a child who had been living with M live with F until further order having regard to a court expert’s opinion (shared by the local child welfare authority) that M had coached the child to falsely allege sexual abuse by F and the court’s find- ing that the expert’s report of her interview with the child was inconsistent with M’s allegations. In Hendrickson & Murrell (No. 3) [2012] FamCA 1010 an interim order was made suspending a par- ent’s time with a child but in doing so the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: abuse by F and the court’s find- ing that the expert’s report of her interview with the child was inconsistent with M’s allegations. In Hendrickson & Murrell (No. 3) [2012] FamCA 1010 an interim order was made suspending a par- ent’s time with a child but in doing so the court was able to rely not on the evidence of the other parent but a psychiatric report. In Sebastian (No. 3) [2012] FamCA 707 an interim order was made that M install an alcohol monitoring system in her home and undertake a breath test before driving the children. M claimed she had abstained for 14 months but did not deny her past excessive drinking. The Full Court in Marvel (No. 2) [2010] FamCAFC 101 at [123] cited this statement of Boland and Thackray JJ in SS & AH [2010] FamCAFC 13 at [100]: “The intuition involved in decision-making concerning children is arguably of even greater impor- tance when a judge is obliged to make interim decisions following a hearing at which time con- straints prevent the evidence being tested. Apart from relying upon the uncontroversial or agreed facts, a judge will sometimes have little alternative than to weigh the probabilities of competing claims and the likely impact on children in the event that a controversial assertion is acted upon or rejected. It is not always feasible when dealing with the immediate welfare of children simply to ignore an assertion because its accuracy has been put in issue.” In Salah [2016] FamCAFC 100 the Full Court at [59]-[63] held that the trial judge should have given weight to F’s “without admissions” consent to superv ision as being a concession by him that supervision was in the best interests of the children. An interim order that F spend no time with his
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: FamCAFC 100 the Full Court at [59]-[63] held that the trial judge should have given weight to F’s “without admissions” consent to superv ision as being a concession by him that supervision was in the best interests of the children. An interim order that F spend no time with his child was set aside for the making of concluded findings as to family violence instead of the hearing being confined to assessing interim risk: Lim & Zong [2020] FamCAFC 20 at [33]-[54]. In Tanberg & Remmy [2021] FamCAFC 49 at [18] differing variations of an interim consent order sought by the parties were both rejected as being unlikely to “improve the position of the child”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 29 STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS • Be aware that a party will often have to work through unresolved personal feelings about the relationship breakdown before they are ready to discuss arrangements for the children. Arrange for such a party to see their own counsellor first, before joint counselling begins. • Lawyers should keep a low profile until the parties have been through the gentler medium of counselling – where negotiated gains are more likely – and then follow up on arrangements discussed or agreed to at counselling. • Let your client know at the outset that the purpose of the Family Law Act, except in genuine cases of violence or child abuse, is to see that children have the benefit of a relationship with both parents and other significant people. • Trialling a parenting arrangement before taking action is preferable and more likely to be what the family wants than a timetable imposed by the court. • Consider how to meet the needs of any child under 3 with a primary attachment, usually to the mother (but see “overnight contact for young children” under “research studies” above). • As to whether (or not) to advise a client to obtain a domestic violence order, see “domestic violence orders” under “interim injunctions” above. • Where family violence or child abuse, drug or alcohol use or mental ill health is alleged, advise your client to consider at an early stage strategies for mitigating risk to child and bettering the parent’s case if litigation is required. This may include attendance at a “parenting after separation” or behavioural change course, engaging with a counsellor or psychologist for regular treatment and an undertaking, or volunteering to undertake urine or hair follicle testing. Make enquiries as to supervised
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: to child and bettering the parent’s case if litigation is required. This may include attendance at a “parenting after separation” or behavioural change course, engaging with a counsellor or psychologist for regular treatment and an undertaking, or volunteering to undertake urine or hair follicle testing. Make enquiries as to supervised contact centres or private supervision prior to the interim hearing. Being proactive in anticipating and addressing the likely issues can assist your client’s case at an interim hearing. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 30 SECTION 60CC FACTORS From 6 May 2024, s 60CC(1)(a) provides that in determining what is in a child’s best interests, the court must consider the following matters as set out in subsection (2) called “general considerations” and under s 60CC(1)(b) if the child is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander child, also consider the cultural matters set out in subsection (3). Subsection (4) deals with consent orders. General considerations Section 60CC(2)(a) – What arrangements would promote the safety (including safety from being subjected to, or exposed to, family violence, abuse, neglect, or other harm) of (i) the child and (ii) each person who has care of the child (whether or not a person has parental responsibility for the child) “Abuse”, in relation to a child means an assault of the child, including a sexual assault; a person involving the child in a sexual activity in which the child is used directly or indirectly as a sexual object, where there is unequal power in the relationship between the child and that person; causing the child to suffer serious psychological harm, including (but not limited to) when that harm is caused by the child being subjected to or exposed to family violence; or serious neglect of the child: s 4(1) A child is “exposed to family violence” if the child sees or hears family violence or otherwise experiences the effects of family violence: s 4AB(3) Examples of situations that may constitute a child being exposed to family violence include (but are not limited to) the child overhearing threats of death or personal injury by a family member towards another member of the child’s family; seeing or hearing an assault of a family member by another family member; comforting or providing assistance to a family member who has
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: violence include (but are not limited to) the child overhearing threats of death or personal injury by a family member towards another member of the child’s family; seeing or hearing an assault of a family member by another family member; comforting or providing assistance to a family member who has been assaulted by another family member; cleaning up a site after a family member has intentionally damaged property of another family member; and being present when police or ambulance officers attend an incident involving the assault of a family member by another family member: s 4AB(4) “Family violence” means violent, threatening or other behaviour that coerces or controls a family member or causes them to be fearful: ss 4(1) and 4AB(1) Examples of behaviour that may constitute family violence include (but are not limited to) an assault; a sexual assault or other sexually abusive behaviour; stalking; repeated derogatory taunts; intentionally damaging or destroying property; intentionally causing death or injury to an animal; unreasonably deny- ing the family member the financial autonomy that he or she would otherwise have had; unreasonably withholding financial support needed to meet the reasonable living expenses of the family member, or his or her child, at a time when the family member is entirely or predominantly dependent on the person for financial support; preventing the family member from making or keeping connections with his or her family, friends or culture; and unlawfully depriving a family member of his or her liberty: s 4AB(2) Section 60CC(2A) provides that “[i]n considering the matters set out in paragraph (2)(a), the court must include consideration of: (a) any history of family violence, abuse or neglect involving the child or a person caring for the child (whether or not the person had parental responsibility for the child); and Update 64 March
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: that “[i]n considering the matters set out in paragraph (2)(a), the court must include consideration of: (a) any history of family violence, abuse or neglect involving the child or a person caring for the child (whether or not the person had parental responsibility for the child); and Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 31 (b) any family violence order that applies or has applied to the child or a member of the child’s family” [but arguably not an interim family violence order where no finding of family violence, abuse or neglect has been made: Arman [2008] FamCA 923 at [73]-[75]]. The case law The “highly detrimental” effect of a child’s exposure to violence was summarised in T & N [2003] FamCA 1129 at [34]-[41], a case where, in the absence of any “track record for [a] change in habits or attitude”, a consent order for unsupervised contact was rejected and an order made for supervision. In a sexual abuse case where the father’s appeal against supervision was dismissed, W & W (Abuse allegations: unacceptable risk) [2005] FamCA 892 at [92]-[115] the Full Court confirmed this case law: • Standard of proof as to alleged sexual abuse is the balance of probabilities: M v M [1988] HCA 68 at [22] (appeal against order for no time with child dismissed) • The court should not grant time to a parent if doing so “would expose the child to an unacceptable risk of sexual abuse” (even supervised time may involve “a risk of disturbance to a child”): M v M (above) at [24]-[25] • An expert’s role is to be objective, not an advocate: Re W (Abuse allegations; expert evidence) [2001] FamCA 216 (FC) at [160]-[165] and [190] • Fogarty J’s statement in N & S and the Separate Representative [1995] FamCA 139 at [108] and [111]-[112] that sexual abuse of a child is “alien to the concepts and actions of most people” but the possibility of false allegations should be acknowledged • In determining whether “unacceptable risk” has been established the court should ask questions as to the nature of the alleged
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS
