chunks.text: at [108] and [111]-[112] that sexual abuse of a child is “alien to the concepts and actions of most people” but the possibility of false allegations should be acknowledged • In determining whether “unacceptable risk” has been established the court should ask questions as to the nature of the alleged events; who made the allegations; genuinely believed by them; made to whom; in what detail; reasonably based; over what period; effects exhibited by child; likely future effects; what expert evidence; any innocent explanations i.e. “the essential weight must be attached to the magnitude of the harm to which the risk relates”: N & S (above) at [139]-[141] Other relevant issues • Violence may be found without corroboration: Amador [2009] FamCAFC 196 (FC) at [79]-[81]. • Assessment of unacceptable risk is a predictive exercise that includes mere possibilities: Isles & Nelissen [2022] FedCFamC1A 97 at [7] and [34]. • A primary carer’s anxiety due to a genuine belief that a child has been abused, which is likely to adversely affect the carer’s parenting capacity, is relevant to whether any order for time (includ- ing supervised time) should be made: R & C [1993] FamCA 62 (FC) at [29]-[43]. Also see Keane [2021] FamCAFC 1 at [73]-[85] and [109]-[111]. • Supervision inappropriate (and interim findings impossible) if accuser has failed to act to remove child from alleged harm: Chapa [2012] FMCAfam 1420 at [26]-[31]. Also see Snow & Curran (No. 2) [2023] FedCFamC1F 1120 at [17] where M had previously agreed to F’s unsupervised time. • No time granted where M afraid (H & R [2006] FamCA 878; Maluka [2009] FamCA 647; Dunst [2014] FamCA 964) or a genuine belief of M that child would not be safe in F’s care, which would impinge on her parental capacity (Starkey (No. 2) [2013]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: F’s unsupervised time. • No time granted where M afraid (H & R [2006] FamCA 878; Maluka [2009] FamCA 647; Dunst [2014] FamCA 964) or a genuine belief of M that child would not be safe in F’s care, which would impinge on her parental capacity (Starkey (No. 2) [2013] FamCA 977 at [144]-[154] and [176]-[178]). The magnitude of any risk to M’s parenting and mental health should be determined: Blinko [2015] FamCAFC 146 at [18]-[33]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 32 • Coercion or control is not a matter of opinion, but to be evaluated objectively: Pickford [2024] FedCFamC1A 249 at [46]-[53], [105], [124]. • “It is too far a stretch to suggest that because of … violence [in the distant past] there was an existing risk of harm” Soulos & Sorbo [2019] FamCAFC 231 at [35]. • M’s allegations unfounded, care reversed to F: L & T [1999] FamCA 1699; Dalziel & Belladonna [2009] FamCA 254; Mackillop & Jell [2009] FamCA 191. • No unacceptable risk if lawful chastisement: Cao [2018] FamCAFC 252 at [42]. • Admissibility of statements by children: DT & JT [1999] FamCA 473. Section 68P governs the court’s obligations when making a parenting order that is inconsistent with a State or Territory AVO (“family violence order”). See Brainard & Wahlen and Anor [2011] FamCA 610 at [106]-[114] as to how the court deals with an inconsistent family violence order. The court must provide the parties with an explanation (see [114]) of the matters set out in s 68P(2)(c) and (d) and the parent- ing order must confirm the inconsistency and explain how the allotted time with a parent is to take place (subsec (2)(a) and (b)). Also see [115] of the order made in that case. Case management to ensure the safety of your client and their child When an Initiating Application or Response to same is filed in the FCFCA, parties will be emailed by the Court and asked to complete the Family DOORS Triage risk screen questionnaire, assisting its special- ised Lighthouse Team to allocate a case management path according to risk. Answers given are con- fidential and may not be used as evidence for or against your client. High risk cases are moved to the Evatt List (see
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: complete the Family DOORS Triage risk screen questionnaire, assisting its special- ised Lighthouse Team to allocate a case management path according to risk. Answers given are con- fidential and may not be used as evidence for or against your client. High risk cases are moved to the Evatt List (see “procedure for child matters” under “child abuse or family violence” below). You may also consider (as an in-house tool only) taking your client through a Domestic Violence Safety Assessment Tool (“DVSAT”) as referred to by a single expert and the Court in Harendra & Veda (No 3) [2024] FedCFamC2F 27 at [16], [18], [67] and [70]. Reading the guide on how to use it first, use it not as evidence but to assess how you should be acting towards resolution in a way that ensures the safety of your client or their child. Procedure for allegations of abuse or family violence A Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk is to be filed with all applications and responses seeking parenting orders whether risk is alleged or not: FLR 2.04(1). In WA a Form 4 is filed only if such allegations are made. An affidavit must also be filed as to the evidence on which any allegation is based: FLR 2.04(2). The court must notify a prescribed child welfare authority (s 67Z(3)) and take prompt action as set out in s 67ZBB. A new Notice (with affidavit) must be filed if further child abuse, family violence or risk is alleged to have arisen since the first Notice was filed: FLR 2.06. An applicant must also file a copy of any relevant family violence order: FLR 2.10. Supervision The question is “whether [F’s or M’s] past behaviour presents an unacceptable risk to the children … if they spend unsupervised time with
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: to have arisen since the first Notice was filed: FLR 2.06. An applicant must also file a copy of any relevant family violence order: FLR 2.10. Supervision The question is “whether [F’s or M’s] past behaviour presents an unacceptable risk to the children … if they spend unsupervised time with him [or her]”: Robins & Ruddock [2010] FamCA 35 at [58]. Bryant CJ and Kay J (with whom Warnick J agreed) said in Napier & Hepburn [2006] FamCA 1316 (at [84]): “This [evaluation of the prospect of a future act of abuse] is not a search for a solution that will eliminate any prospect of serious harm. It is a search to balance the harm that will follow if the Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 33 risk is not minimised and the harm that will follow if a normal healthy relationship between parent and child is not allowed to prosper.” In Darrow [2015] FamCA 597 at [61]-[64] no supervision was imposed where the risk of drug use affecting F’s parenting was “not unacceptably high”. The risk of child sexual abuse is not unacceptable if the possible abuser’s time is limited to day time and supervised: Giordano & Sica [2012] FamCA 64 at [97]-[101]. In Tate & Ralph [2012] FMCAfam 279 at [118]-[139] the court found an unacceptable risk and ordered no time due to the lack of suitable supervisors. A commercial supervisory agency was preferred to F’s fiancée in Joelson [2014] FamCA 788 (but see Canfeld & Falkins [2020] FCCA 2570 where M could no longer afford professional supervision). An indefinite supervision order should usually include liberty to apply for unsupervised time: Slater & Light [2013] FamCAFC 4 at [69]-[70]. The Full Court said in C & J [1996] FamCA 86 at [97] that supervision can both comfort M and protect F against further allegations of abuse. In Green & Graham [2011] FamCAFC 248 a non-supervision interim order was reversed (in a non-abuse case) as reassurance to M where F had a history of non-contact. In Gong & Wei [2017] FamCAFC 55 an interim supervision order was set aside where F adduced positive notes from his supervisor. For a children’s contact service near you, search “contact service” here at our eBook or at our online “forms and precedents”. Children in care under a child welfare law Before issuing or continuing proceedings for such a child you must seek the written consent of the child welfare authority to do so: s 69ZK. In the absence of that consent your proceedings could be dismissed
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: at our online “forms and precedents”. Children in care under a child welfare law Before issuing or continuing proceedings for such a child you must seek the written consent of the child welfare authority to do so: s 69ZK. In the absence of that consent your proceedings could be dismissed for want of jurisdiction: Tanner & Wagner [2011] FMCAfam 663. You should also, under FLR 3.02(d) and 3.02(2), join the authority as a respondent, the procedure for which is in FLR 3.03. A child welfare authority may also intervene under s 91 (Byrne & Smith & Anor (No. 2) [2009] FMCAfam 1115) and be removed if joined as a party where intervention was not sought and the child is not in care under a child welfare law (Messmer & Cable & Anor [2011] FMCAfam 167 at [69]-[70]). For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under relevant topics such as “child welfare”, “family violence order”, “family violence, abuse or neglect” and “supervision”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 34 Section 60CC(2)(b) – Any views expressed by the child These may be expressed in a family report (s 60CD) but are not compulsory (s 60CE). While the Family Law Act, as amended in 2023, no longer provides for the court to consider “any factors (such as the child’s maturity or level of understanding) that the court thinks are relevant to the weight it should give to the child’s views”, the courts will no doubt do so anyway (as they did in the following case law). In a review of studies of children after separation, Nicholson CJ in ZN & YH [2002] FamCA 453 at [113] referred to this finding of the Children’s Issues Centre at the University of Otago in 1997: “One of the most important conclusions to be drawn from our study is that children do have views about their lives after parental separation and…are highly capable of expressing their views. Even children as young as five…can talk about their feelings and what situations mean to them despite the complexity of the experiences…(The) view that children’s capacities to understand and partici- pate have been underestimated is reinforced for us by this study.” Nicholson CJ took the unusual course of a chambers meeting with the children – aged 14, 12 and 9 – at their request, the outcome of which was that the children expressed a wish opposite to that in evidence from the report writer. Hannon J’s view in Doyle [1992] FamCA 88 that weight should be given to wishes “soundly based”, “founded upon proper considerations” and “well thought through” was approved by the Full Court in R & R: Children’s Wishes [2000] FamCA 43 (which held that a court must carefully consider, but is not bound by, a child’s views). There, the report
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: weight should be given to wishes “soundly based”, “founded upon proper considerations” and “well thought through” was approved by the Full Court in R & R: Children’s Wishes [2000] FamCA 43 (which held that a court must carefully consider, but is not bound by, a child’s views). There, the report writer felt that the reasons for the children wanting to live with their father stemmed from their lack of contact when he was overseas and wish to spend more time with him. The father’s limited insight into the children’s needs was also considered relevant. In H & W [1995] FamCA 30 at [58] the Full Court said: “... [I]n the face of conflicting evidence…the Court will attach varying degrees of weight to a child’s stated wishes depending upon, amongst other factors [arguably any overt acts (e.g. run- ning away) or parental manipulation of a child’s views], the strength and duration of those wishes, their basis, and the maturity of the child, including the degree of appreciation by the child of the factors involved in the issue before the court and their longer term implications.” Faced with children of 6 and 8 said to be “pining” for their mother who had moved from Hobart to Launceston, the Full Court in K & Z [1997] FamCA 56 at [7.9] said: “( ... ) If both parents offer reasonable homes for a child with comparable standards of excellent child care, then the child’s level of contentment and happiness in one household as compared with that in the other must become a most significant, and almost determinate factor in deciding with which parent the child should live. The Court should avoid the spectre of placing or leaving a child in a situation of sadness and continued unhappiness where it is able to so do
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: with that in the other must become a most significant, and almost determinate factor in deciding with which parent the child should live. The Court should avoid the spectre of placing or leaving a child in a situation of sadness and continued unhappiness where it is able to so do consistently with otherwise meeting the ‘best interests’ criteria.” For the court’s approach to a child’s views and wishes see Segur (No. 2) [2010] FamCA 801 at [306]-[318] and Bondelmonte [2016] FamCAFC 48 at [97]. Where children began refusing to see their father, an order made in hope, rather than the experience of compliance with an interim order was set aside: Masih & El Saeid [2020] FamCAFC 152. For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under “child’s views, wishes”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 35 Section 60CC(2)(c) – The developmental, psychological, emotional and cultural needs of the child See “research studies” above, including our archived research papers referred to there. Children’s social, emotional and cognitive development In M & K [2007] FMCAfam 918, cited under “research studies” above, Altobelli FM (as Altobelli J then was) said at [14]: “According to [social scientists] Kelly and Lamb (2000), the greater the range of contexts for inter- action between parents and their children, the better. They suggest that different contexts facilitate children’s social, emotional and cognitive development, as well as afford greater opportunities for parents to build emotional bonds with their children.” Young children The High Court in Gronow [1979] HCA 63 upheld the first instance decision of Evatt CJ giving custody of a 4 year old child to the father. Both parents worked full-time and were suitable carers. The High Court held that it should not be an inflexible rule in custody cases that a young daughter was best left with the mother. All judges commented on changing social conditions and family life with the advent of “working mothers”. See “research studies” above, including “overnight contact for young children” and the research cited by Altobelli FM (as Altobelli J then was) in M & K under “section 60CC(2)(e)” below. Also see our note at the end of our sample final parenting orders below (“For the wording of orders in specific scenarios”). Cultural needs In DKI & OBI [1979] FamCA 34 Lusink J considered the cultural differences between an Asian mother and an Australian father, granting the mother custody on her undertaking not to leave the State and to give notice of any change of situation. In King & Smith & Anor [2010] FMCAfam 690 a seven year old child (“X”) had been in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: the cultural differences between an Asian mother and an Australian father, granting the mother custody on her undertaking not to leave the State and to give notice of any change of situation. In King & Smith & Anor [2010] FMCAfam 690 a seven year old child (“X”) had been in the care of a non-parent (Ms King) since the age of eight months by arrangement with his Fijian parents (it being “part of Fijian culture that children be left in the care of a third person who raises [them]” ([87]). The arrange- ment was confirmed by parenting order. Baker FM said at [84]-[86]: “[X] and his parents are Fijian. [X] will not be intensely exposed to the parent’s culture if he lives with Ms King. A child’s cultural identity is an important factor in deciding where he or she should live. [Moses & Barton [2008] FamCA 590 cited.] [Family consultant] Ms E acknowledged that [X]’s culture is very important, but that he must feel psychologically secure and happy before he can appreciate his culture. She said that cultural mat- ters will be more intensely absorbed by him when he is spending time with his [biological] parents. In Ms King’s household [X] lives with [Y], an eight year old Fijian child. Ms King has Fijian friends and was married to the Fijian nephew of the mother. Her evidence was that she promotes Fijian culture to [X].” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 36 In Moses & Barton (cited above), a case about the culture of the people of the Torres Strait Islands, Moore J (at [29]) referred to a family report which stated: “It is important to acknowledge that while the achievement of stable and affectionate attachment is a highly important developmental goal for all children, the achievement of a coherent sense of identity based upon cultural affiliation is also extremely important. This occurs particularly for children when they reach early and later childhood and can be identi- fied as a deep sense of belonging that is the foundation of the child’s identity. This sound founda- tion assists the child to develop a balanced and stable adult personality.” For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under relevant topics, such as “alcohol and drugs”, “alienation”, “cultural issues”, “estrangement”, “mental health”, “parental responsibility”, “reversal of care”, “social science research”, “special needs child”, “teenage child” and “young children”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 37 Section 60CC(2)(d) – The capacity of each person who has or is proposed to have parental responsibility for the child to provide for the child’s developmental, psychological, emotional and cultural needs In a case typical of warring parents, Telford (No. 3) [2020] FamCA 755, Harper J said ([201]) as to the capacity of parents to provide for the emotional, intellectual and other needs of a child (before including in the orders an order that the parties continue attending a parenting course and facilitate the children’s attendance): “The evidence disclosed a number [of] ways in which the capacity of each parent to provide for the needs of the children was compromised. When [family consultant] Ms BB was asked whether either party had demonstrated an insight as to whether their ‘toxic’ relationship had any impact on the children, Ms BB said that she had noted some parental incapacity on the part of both of the parties and that, while the parties may have been aware of it, they did not seem to be able to prioritise the children over their angry feelings about each other.” Such parental incapacity may be not mutual but unilateral, as in a case of alienation, an example of which is Goldman (No. 2) [2017] FamCA 531. In that case Cleary J reversed the care of children from M to F, saying at [310]: “Overall, I formed the impression that the mother … has been almost entirely focused … on punishing [the father] … and on turning the children’s affections away from him. She has caused emotional harm to the children and represents an unacceptable risk to the children of such harm continuing.” A mother lost her share of responsibility for and time with her child due to a “personality disorder that impaired her
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: and on turning the children’s affections away from him. She has caused emotional harm to the children and represents an unacceptable risk to the children of such harm continuing.” A mother lost her share of responsibility for and time with her child due to a “personality disorder that impaired her capacity to provide for the children’s needs” but was granted a re-hearing to adduce evi- dence from a psychologist to the effect that the mother was suffering from misdiagnosed post-traumatic stress disorder consistent with serious violence and abuse against her by the father (evidence which was to be supported by a social worker whose opinion was that an assessment of the violence and abuse allegations was warranted): T & S [2001] FamCA 1147. For a case of a father being granted graduated time with an autistic child (in need of “routine and structure”) and an older sibling where mother was alienating both from him, see Roberts [2009] FMCAfam 912 at [99]-[102], [120]-[121] and [227]. Also see our archived children’s case notes under relevant topics, such as “alcohol and drugs”, “alienation”, “education (choice of school)”, “estrangement”, “mental health”, “parental responsibility”, “reversal of care”, “social science research”, “special needs child”, “teenage child” and “young children”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 38 Section 60CC(2)(e) – The benefit to the child of being able to have a relationship with the child’s parents, and other people who are significant to the child, where it is safe to do so Hayne J (with whom Gleeson CJ and McHugh J agreed) said in U v U [2002] HCA 36 at [176]: “It is now recognised as self-evidently true that, apart from some cases of abusive relationships, children benefit from the development of good relationships with both their parents. The right to know and be cared for by both parents and the right of contact on a regular basis with both parents are said to be principles underlying the objects of Pt VII of the Act [Ed – His Honour’s foot- note here cites s 60B(2)(a) and (b). While the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 repealed those provisions they did contain s 60CC(2)(e) which acknowledged ‘the benefit to the child of being able to have a relationship with the child’s parents’.]” Cited under “research studies” above, Altobelli FM (as Altobelli J then was) in M & K [2007] FMCAfam 918, a case about an eight year old son, said at [14] under the heading “significance of time”: “Like many disputes relating to children, this is a dispute about dividing the child’s time between the parents. A leading Australian researcher has reflected on this phenomenon in an article enti- tled “Time to rethink time? The experience of time with children after divorce” [Bruce Smyth, “Time to rethink time? The experience of time with children after divorce” Family Matters No. 76, Winter 2005 page 4]. Smyth refers to the notion of time as part and parcel of the ‘custody wars’ between parents. He says about time at page 4: ‘ ... Parents fight about
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: Smyth, “Time to rethink time? The experience of time with children after divorce” Family Matters No. 76, Winter 2005 page 4]. Smyth refers to the notion of time as part and parcel of the ‘custody wars’ between parents. He says about time at page 4: ‘ ... Parents fight about it, courts divvy it up, and children long for it.’ Smyth goes on to say some important things about time at page 9 of the article: • A solid body of data also suggest that it is the quality of relationships between parents, and between parents and children, that exerts a critical influence on children’s wellbeing, not the amount of time per se (Amato and Gilbreth 1999; Pryor and Rodgers 2001). Of course, an emotionally close and warm relationship between parents and children requires time to sustain it. ‘Quality time’ needs time. • According to Kelly and Lamb (2000), the greater the range of contexts for interaction between parents and their children, the better. They suggest that different contexts facilitate children’s social, emotional and cognitive development, as well as afford greater opportunities for parents to build emotional bonds with their children. • It is the intermingling of different activities and the different experiences of time that diverse contexts bring that form the hub of family life, and which are critical for family wellbeing. For instance, overnight stays allow for the experience of mundane everyday routines, as well as special moments – such as putting children to bed, reading to them, saying good night, and starting the day together over breakfast. Focused one-on-one together time (such as playing a game, talking in the car, reading a book together, or helping with homework) sends a clear signal to children that they matter. Outdoor time (such as fishing, netball, or hiking) provides opportunities
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: saying good night, and starting the day together over breakfast. Focused one-on-one together time (such as playing a game, talking in the car, reading a book together, or helping with homework) sends a clear signal to children that they matter. Outdoor time (such as fishing, netball, or hiking) provides opportunities for children’s emotional, physical, social and cognitive development, and give parents the chance to mentor, and to remain engaged with, their children. Fun time (such as long-weekends and school holidays) or special time (such as birthdays, Mothers’ or Fathers’ Day, and Christmas) foster the pursuit of mutually rewarding experiences for children and parents, help create bonds between each and symbolise those bonds, and can create positive life-long memories. • But while these, and other, types of time are important for children’s and parent’s wellbeing, one type of time warrants special attention: being-in-the-moment time. This type of time involves unstructured, spontaneous, intimate time where a parent and child are free to ‘hang out’, talk about things, or engage in activities that are important to them (such as a teenage daughter talking about boyfriend problems while her father peels potatoes). Post-separation parenting arrangements that Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 39 involve thin slices of parent–child time, such as daytime-only contact each Saturday afternoon, work against the experience of ‘being’ time as this sort of time needs to feel natural and unimpeded to create the conditions for free-flowing interpersonal engagement.” The Full Court said in R & R (Children’s Wishes) [2002] FamCA 383 at [177] that the “serious” act of “depriving the father of contact in circumstances … engineered by the mother … cannot be in a child’s best interests”. Care was reversed in such a case in Irish & Michelle [2009] FamCA 66 and McDermott & Bond [2009] FamCA 1161. An innocent parent’s time was increased in Hacker [2009] FMCAfam 217. For proof of alienation, see Roberts [2009] FMCAfam 912 at [120]-[121] and [227]. For the use of published research, see McGregor [2012] FamCAFC 69. Separation of siblings The Full Court held in Hayman [1976] FamCA 98 that the trial judge placed too much emphasis on reuniting young siblings who were strangers to one another, and not enough on the loving extended family and stable environment the child was enjoying at the time of the hearing. But see Doyle under “sexual orientation” below (siblings not to be separated except in special or exceptional circumstances, such as in Patrick [2009] FMCAfam 326 where a 13 year old was allowed her wish to live with the father despite separation from her siblings aged 12 and 10). Grandparents For the court’s approach to a toxic mum/gran relationship, see Simm & Forest and Anderson [2009] FMCAfam 369 and in Danes & Anor [2013] FMCAfam 281 the court dismissed the application of a grandmother found to lack insight into the children’s needs. For a review of grandparent v parent cases see Kay & Jasper and Ors [2007] FamCA 1646 at [67]-[74].
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: & Forest and Anderson [2009] FMCAfam 369 and in Danes & Anor [2013] FMCAfam 281 the court dismissed the application of a grandmother found to lack insight into the children’s needs. For a review of grandparent v parent cases see Kay & Jasper and Ors [2007] FamCA 1646 at [67]-[74]. For “special grandmother time” see Schroeder & Raleigh & Anor [2012] FMCAfam 834 at [119]-[125]. In Chandler & Bonner [2022] FedCFamC1A 210 it was held that parents’ unified opposition to a grandmother spending interim time does not displace judicial scrutiny of a child’s best interests. Non-parents The Full Court in Rice & Miller [1993] FamCA 87 held that while parenthood is to be regarded as important and significant, it does not establish a presumption in favour of a natural parent. For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under relevant topics, such as “alienation”, “estrangement”, “non-parents (including grandparents)”, “siblings, separation of” and “shiftwork”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 41 Section 60CC(2)(f) – Anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of the child Religious differences In a case of Jewish parents of differing levels of orthodoxy, the Full Court held that it would be unusual that different proposals for the degree of religious upbringing should carry weight as a factor; and that the question of continuation or change of a child’s religion may be relevant, but as a lifestyle, not a religious issue: N & N [1981] FamCA 90 at [42]. In Macri [2010] FMCAfam 662 a father was allowed to defer formal entry into the Jewish faith by children of 8 and 10. Where the youngest child was with the mother who had become a Jehovah’s Witness and the father had the two eldest children with him and his new partner, the court did consider the narrowness of the moth- er’s environment but awarded custody to the father because of doubt that the mother would encourage close contact between the child and the child’s father and siblings: Paisio [1978] FamCA 82. Where a father was found to be dogmatic on religious matters, the Full Court held that the trial judge was not incorrect to restrain the father from taking the child to a church other than that specified by the mother: Morrison [1995] FamCA 124. In a dispute between a mother who, having emigrated here from Lebanon as a Muslim child, married (in a Muslim marriage ceremony) an Australian-born man who was a Catholic Maronite, neither being active in their faith: H & H [2003] FMCA Fam 31, Ryan FM held: • A child’s best interests are met by being raised in an environment that is respectful of the child’s cultural heritage, culture and religion being inextricably linked. • An important consideration is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: Catholic Maronite, neither being active in their faith: H & H [2003] FMCA Fam 31, Ryan FM held: • A child’s best interests are met by being raised in an environment that is respectful of the child’s cultural heritage, culture and religion being inextricably linked. • An important consideration is whether the cultural significance of religion is reflected in the parties’ actions and attitudes. • The parents had already moved away from strict religious adherence, and the child’s extended Lebanese Australian family accepted second generation children and would not stigmatise them for not strictly adhering to the father’s religion. • The child should not be exposed to a school that will victimise him because he does not practise his father’s religion; nor should he be exposed to religious education inconsistent with values to which he is accustomed. By attending a school that is not biased in favour of either religion, the child would not be exposed to the narrow application of patriarchy from a peer group. Sexual orientation Where a father argued likely stigmatisation, child’s awareness of mother’s lesbianism, and the need for male/female role modelling, a homosexual mother was granted custody where it was found that she offered stable, consistent full-time care and supervision and was more sensitive to the children’s needs and emotional development: L & L [1983] FamCA 20. In a case of sons of 9 and 13, a father had lived in a homosexual relationship after separation and the eldest son had, a year before the hearing, moved in with the father with the mother’s consent. The dispute was over the youngest child, who wanted to live with his father too. The mother argued moral danger. Hannon J in Doyle [1992] FamCA 88 held that: • The sexual orientation of parents is a factor, but is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: hearing, moved in with the father with the mother’s consent. The dispute was over the youngest child, who wanted to live with his father too. The mother argued moral danger. Hannon J in Doyle [1992] FamCA 88 held that: • The sexual orientation of parents is a factor, but is of limited relevance to the welfare of a child. • A parent’s lifestyle is of no relevance without evidence of its effect on a child’s wellbeing. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 42 • Homosexuality is relevant only if it affects the parenting ability or welfare of the child. • Child’s wishes were soundly based and thought through, without undue influence from others. • Siblings should not be separated except in special or exceptional circumstances. A father was preferred as custodian to a mother in a lesbian relationship. The Full Court was influenced by the counsellor’s view of the importance of the father as a balancing figure in the child’s emotional development, where the parties lived a long way from each other: A & J [1995] FamCA 56 at [26]-[33]. See also Wilson and Anor & Roberts and Anor (No. 2) [2010] FamCA 734 at [8], [38]-[52], [325]-[336] and [338] (homosexual parents v homosexual non-parents). See W & G (Stage 3) [2005] FamCA 617 at [32]-[44] for a review of case law. Other issues For cases on these, see “parental responsibility” above and our archived children’s case notes under “education (choice of school)”, “name of child”, “overseas travel”, “parental responsibility”, “passports”, “religion” and “same sex parties”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 43 Additional considerations – right to enjoy Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture Section 60CC(3) provides that for the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), the court must consider the follow- ing matters: (a) the child’s right to enjoy the child’s Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture, by having the support, opportunity and encouragement necessary: (i) to connect with, and maintain their connection with, members of their family and with their community, culture, country and language; and (ii) to explore the full extent of that culture, consistent with the child’s age and developmental level and the child’s views; and (iii) to develop a positive appreciation of that culture; and (b) the likely impact any proposed parenting order under this Part will have on that right. Note – See also s 61F which requires the court to have regard to “any kinship obligations, and child- rearing practices, of the child’s Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture”. The Full Court held in Goudge [1984] FamCA 6 that there is no prima facie rule that the welfare of a child from mixed racial parentage will be served better by being in the custody of either the indigenous or non-indigenous parent, each case to be determined on its own merits in light of all relevant factors. In R & R (Aboriginal Origin) [1982] FamCA 53 it was held to be in a part-Aboriginal child’s best inter- ests that custody be awarded to her Aboriginal mother. Factors were the likely loss of contact with the mother’s background; lesser discrimination; and easier contact assimilation. Also see Hallett & Malcolm & Anor [2020] FCCA 835 at [450]-[456]. The Full Court held that a trial judge, in ruling against a Tiwi Islander mother in a custody dispute with a Thursday Islander woman to whom the children had
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: the mother’s background; lesser discrimination; and easier contact assimilation. Also see Hallett & Malcolm & Anor [2020] FCCA 835 at [450]-[456]. The Full Court held that a trial judge, in ruling against a Tiwi Islander mother in a custody dispute with a Thursday Islander woman to whom the children had been brought to live, had misunderstood Tiwi cul- ture and the child’s own distinctive cultural heritage as a Tiwi child to which his identity was inextricably bound: Re CP [1997] FamCA 10. In M & L (Aboriginal Culture) [2007] FamCA 396, a case between Aboriginal parents, the Full Court held that the children’s primary attachment to the mother was not outweighed by the indigenous sociali- sation benefits argued by the father as flowing from the children being placed in his care. The father’s history of violence and alcohol abuse was also relevant. Torres Strait Island culture prevailed over an absent father in Waugh & Bannon [2014] FCCA 893. For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under “cultural issues”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 45 MAJOR LONG-TERM ISSUES FOR THOSE WITH PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY CHILD’S EDUCATION The Full Court in Re G: Children’s Schooling [2000] FamCA 462 at [91]–[92] and [95] said: “We think the wife’s acknowledged greater understanding of the children tempers concerns about the consequences of change upon these children and bolsters the weight we should place upon her assessment of the benefits to the children from a change in schools (…) In addition…where… parents are unable to agree as between two schools which are prima facie satisfactory, we see advantages to the children attending a school which is closer to the children’s residence.” The Court also found that a prior agreement as to choice of a school “does not carry much weight in the changed circumstances of a family”. In Whitton and Anor (No. 2) [2010] Fam CA 1119 the best interests of the children were held to be paramount, not the mother’s freedom to choose a school near where she might decide to live. In Hamill [2009] FamCA 1324 at [19] Faulks DCJ granted a mother sole responsibility (previously equally shared) to resolve a choice of school dispute. In Dreyfus & Kearney [2010] FamCA 1054 a child was allowed to choose from two schools nominated by the mother. In Bardot & Benjamin [2013] FCCA 1024 a bullied child was allowed to change schools. In Bilz & Breugelman [2013] FamCA 578 a public school was preferred to a Christian school as child was “immersed in religion” ([90]). The issue is not to compare school “league tables” or choose between private and government schooling: Ryan & Janosi [2011] FMCAfam 774 at [44] (unless party proposing private school is paying: Dawson [2012] FMCAfam 94). In Vance & Riley [2008] FMCAfam 578 the father was allowed to choose a more expensive private
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: is not to compare school “league tables” or choose between private and government schooling: Ryan & Janosi [2011] FMCAfam 774 at [44] (unless party proposing private school is paying: Dawson [2012] FMCAfam 94). In Vance & Riley [2008] FMCAfam 578 the father was allowed to choose a more expensive private school if he could afford to pay for it. A parent’s unilateral change of school was reversed in Josey & Meibos [2009] FMCAfam 470. In Bates & Churchill [2012] FMCAfam 1495 a primary school was preferred to home-schooling. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 46 CHILD’S PASSPORT Riethmuller FM held in Re Child’s Passport Application [2008] FMCAfam 1031: “Where a person with parental responsibility for a child (by court order, or through paternity or maternity) seeks to have a passport issued for a child… a) Ordinarily application should be made to the Minister [under s 11 of the Australian Passports Act 2005 (Cth)] for a passport with the consent of the other parent (or person with parental responsibility). [Note – The Minister may waive consent in some circumstances: see s 11(2)] b) Application for the issue of a passport without the consent of the other parent (or person with parental responsibility) should be made to the Minister unless: i. The other person is objecting to the issue of a passport; ii. There are court orders restraining the child’s travel, such as an airport watch-list order; or iii. There is another good reason why the administrative process would not provide an appropriate remedy; or iv. The administrative process has resulted in a refusal to issue a passport. c) Where application is made to the court the supporting material ought to set out why the ad- ministrative process is unsuitable and provide appropriate evidence. Applications need to also address the relevant factors under Part VII of the Family Law Act. d) Applications to the court must be served upon the other parent (or person with parental responsibility) unless orders are obtained for substituted service or, in the exceptional case, that service be dispensed with. Applications for substituted service, or to dispense with service, should be supported by clear and detailed material.” Note – The mother’s court application for the issue of a passport for her child was dismissed as she had not applied to the Minister under s 11 (above); it was
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: dispensed with. Applications for substituted service, or to dispense with service, should be supported by clear and detailed material.” Note – The mother’s court application for the issue of a passport for her child was dismissed as she had not applied to the Minister under s 11 (above); it was not claimed that any existing court order restricted travel or that the father had refused or was likely to refuse to consent; nor was there any evidence of attempts to locate him (in Turkey) or apply for substituted service, or any demonstration of urgency. Also see Withers & Russell and Anor [2016] FamCA 793 at [447]-[471]. Overseas travel The leading case is Kuebler [1978] FamCA 26 at [15] where the Full Court set out these factors relevant to an application to temporarily remove a child from Australia: • The length of the proposed stay out of the jurisdiction • The bona fides of the application • The effect on the child of any deprivation of time with the other parent • Any threat to the welfare of the child by the circumstances of the proposed environment • The credibility of a party’s promise to return to the jurisdiction • The provisions of Part VII, including ss 65Y [Ed: also now see s 65Z] and 60CC Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 47 See also Line [1996] FamCA 145 applied in Bose & Mehra [2010] FMCAfam 353 (whether country of travel is a signatory to the Hague Convention); V & V [2004] FamCA 1074 (threat of terrorism) and Dart & Graham [2008] FamCA 824 (DFAT travel advice). Guidelines for payment of security were set out in Line (above): see Cadena & Beltran [2010] FMCAfam 1165 at [94], [167] and [220]-[223]. As to non-compliant signatories see Ardagh (No. 2) [2018] FamCAFC 160 at [21]-[28]. For an order for passports to issue see Wiltcher [2010] FamCA 369. For passports to be delivered to the court under s 67ZD FLA see Mason [2013] FMCAfam 99. If a fraudulent application for passports is suspected see “child alert request” under “abduction and recovery of children” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 48 CHANGE OF CHILD’S NAME The Full Court held in Chapman & Palmer [1978] FamCA 86 at [56]-[57] that a court will not prevent a parent from changing a child’s surname (or direct that a changed name be restored) unless it is satisfied that the change was made without the consent of the other parent and does not promote the welfare of the child. The child’s welfare (now “best interests”) stands above the parents’ wishes. Relevant factors: • Welfare (now, best interests) of child • Effect on child’s relationship with their father • Confusion of identity • Embarrassment if name is different from mother’s • Short- and long-term effects of name change • Effect of frequent or random changes of name The mother was restrained from using a new surname for the children due to the father’s continuing contact with them. Connor J (of the FCWA) in Beach & Semmler [1979] FamCA 1 added: • Short- and long-term advantages to child of no change of name • Extent of contact (now, time) with father (past and future) • Extent to which child identifies with father • Extent to which child identifies with mother and her new partner • Degree of identification with a child to be born to mother and new partner • The desire of the father that his name be restored The mere registration of the child’s name does not act as an estoppel against considering what is in the child’s best interests: Mahony & Mckenzie [1993] FamCA 78. A name change was not allowed where the father was in continuing contact with the child (Skrabl & Leach [1989] FamCA 67) and allowed where the father had had little contact with the child (Re Skipworth [1989] FamCA 72). See also Flanagan & Handcock [2000]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: & Mckenzie [1993] FamCA 78. A name change was not allowed where the father was in continuing contact with the child (Skrabl & Leach [1989] FamCA 67) and allowed where the father had had little contact with the child (Re Skipworth [1989] FamCA 72). See also Flanagan & Handcock [2000] FamCA 150. A hyphenated surname has been approved as a compromise (Mahony & Mckenzie (above)) and the father’s surname preferred to a hyphenated surname (Fooks & McCarthy [1993] FamCA 117). In Fooks Warnick J held that the child’s best interests stood above a parent’s wishes; the child identified with the father’s surname; and a change of name was likely to lead to the child being exposed to the father’s resentment and increased animosity between the parties. Type of order The Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration Acts of NSW (s 22(3)), Vic (s 28(2)), Tas (s 26(2)), SA (s 27(2)), WA (ss 22(5) or (6) or s 33), NT (s 26(2)) and ACT (s 26(2)) provide that the registrar of births may register a change of name that is made by an order of a court. There is no such provision in the Qld Act, which (s 17) only allows joint applications however the following suggested wording of the order should apply in Qld too. The order made in Mahony & Mckenzie (above) was (1) that the husband and wife: (i) henceforth exclusively use the name “Mckenzie-Mahony” as the surname of the child of the marriage Jake Eliot, formerly known as Mahony and also known as Mckenzie; (ii) forthwith do all things necessary, individually and jointly including making application and executing documents, to seek the alteration of the registration of the name of the said child in the register of births in the State of Queensland from the surname “Mahony” to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: Mahony and also known as Mckenzie; (ii) forthwith do all things necessary, individually and jointly including making application and executing documents, to seek the alteration of the registration of the name of the said child in the register of births in the State of Queensland from the surname “Mahony” to the name “Mckenzie-Mahony”; and (iii) pay in equal shares such fees, if any, as are applicable to an application for alteration of the register as aforesaid. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 49 For a discussion of the policy behind the courts’ role as to the registration of such information (including parentage), see Dent & Rees [2012] FMCAfam 1303 at [243]-[257]. What evidence to file? See “any other relevant fact or circumstance” at the end of the samples “affidavits for interim hearings” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: STRATEGIES FOR CHILD TO HAVE A RELATIONSHIP WITH BOTH PARENTS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 50 RELOCATION Relocation (“change to a child’s living arrangements that make it significantly more difficult for the child to spend time with a parent”) is defined as a “major long-term issue” such that once a joint decision- making order is made, those with parental responsibility are required to discuss and make a genuine effort to resolve the matter. See s 61DAA and the definition of “major long-term issues” in s 4(1). The High Court decision in U v U The Full Court in Bolitho & Cohen [2005] FamCA 458 (Bryant CJ, May and Boland JJ) said at [72]: “We discern that the decision in U v U [[2002] HCA 36] has ameliorated the somewhat rigid and/or formulaic suggested approach set out in A v A [A & A: Relocation Approach [2000] FamCA 751]. In U v U the High Court said that the proper approach to be adopted in a reloca- tion case is a weighing of competing proposals, having regard to relevant s 68F(2) [now s 60CC] factors, and consideration of other relevant factors, including the right of freedom of movement of the parent who wishes to relocate, bearing in mind that ultimately the decision must be one which is in the best interests of the child.” The Full Court added at [84] that Hayne J in U v U at [171] and [172] “also dealt with the requirement, in some cases, for a trial judge to look beyond the proposals of the parties, in his or her … task of en- suring the parenting orders made are in the best interests of a child”. In U v U [2002] HCA 36 Hayne J as a member of a 5:2 majority of the High Court (with whom Gleeson CJ and McHugh J agreed) said at
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: his or her … task of en- suring the parenting orders made are in the best interests of a child”. In U v U [2002] HCA 36 Hayne J as a member of a 5:2 majority of the High Court (with whom Gleeson CJ and McHugh J agreed) said at [170]-[176]: “What have come to be known as ‘relocation cases’ present difficult questions. Much of that difficulty stems from the fact that to take a child from the place where one of the parents lives (and, in some cases, works) to some distant place will, if the other parent does not move, necessarily affect the way in which the child’s relationship with that other parent can be maintained and allowed to develop. It follows that the needs and the wishes of each parent and the needs of the child (and, if of sufficient age, the child’s wishes) all bear upon the question to be considered by the Family Court. In the end, as the … Act … makes plain [Ed – The footnote here that cites s 65E should now be read as s 60CA], the Fam- ily Court ‘must regard the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration’, but that does not deny the fact that there are at least three persons who will be affected by the order that is made: two adults and the child. And very often, of course, there will be other relatives of the child whose contact with the child will be curtailed if the child lives in one place rather than another. In these circumstances, it would be quite wrong to treat the decision that is to be made as confined to a choice between whatever may be the particular ‘proposals’ that the parents may make for the residence of, and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: curtailed if the child lives in one place rather than another. In these circumstances, it would be quite wrong to treat the decision that is to be made as confined to a choice between whatever may be the particular ‘proposals’ that the parents may make for the residence of, and contact with, the child. So to confine the inquiry would, in this case, have required the … Court to ignore admittedly relevant evidence that was led about what the mother would do if it were decided that the child should live in Australia rather than India. More fundamentally, it would confine the Court’s in- quiry to what the parents suggested would be in the best interests of the child, regardless of whether those suggestions were informed, even wholly dictated, by the selfish interests of one or other of the parents. To confine the inquiry in this way would, therefore, disobey the fundamental requirement of the Act that the Court regard the best interests of the child as paramount. Those interests may, or may not, coincide with what one or both of the parents put forward … as appropriate arrangements for residence and contact. That is not to say that the … Court is to embark upon some roving inquiry about the matter, unfettered by any regard for the evidence led and the matters which the parties seek to contest. Due account must be taken of the fact that proceedings … are conducted in a framework of adversarial procedure familiar to the common law. … Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 51 In this case, there were only three outcomes which were raised by the parties in the proposals which they made ... Put shortly … those … were that the child would reside with the father in Australia, with the mother in India or with the mother in Australia. All of those outcomes assumed that the father would remain in Australia. There may have been some … compelling reason for the parties to make that assumption and to conduct the litigation on this premise. But neither the premise nor the reasons for adopting it were explored in evi- dence or in argument in the courts below and therefore these matters could not be tested or examined in this Court. The premise is not one which, in relocation cases, should be accepted as a matter of course. When one parent … wishes a child who is, or is to be, resident with that parent to move to a place distant from the other parent, it should not be assumed that that other parent cannot, or should not, contemplate moving to be near the child. There may be … compelling reason for that other parent … not to move, but it would ordinarily be expected that these reasons would be explored in evidence and the validity of any assumption that the other parent will not move would be examined. Just as, in this case, the mother was asked what she would do, if she could not have the child reside with her in India, so too it might have been expected that the father would be asked what he would do, if the mother were to have the child reside with her in India. Such questions should not be treated as mere forensic tests of parental devotion, to which
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: reside with her in India, so too it might have been expected that the father would be asked what he would do, if the mother were to have the child reside with her in India. Such questions should not be treated as mere forensic tests of parental devotion, to which only one answer is seen as being satisfactory proof of being a loving parent. Rather, they are no more than a prelude to a deeper inquiry about where the best interests of the child may lie and what arrangements will best serve those interests. It is now recognised as self-evidently true that, apart from some cases of abusive relationships, children benefit from the development of good relationships with both their parents. The right to know and be cared for by both parents and the right of contact on a regular basis with both parents are said to be principles underlying the objects of Pt VII of the Act [Ed – His Honour’s footnote here cites s 60B(2) (a) and (b). While the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 repealed those provisions they did contain s 60CC(2)(e) which acknowledged ‘the benefit to the child of being able to have a relationship with the child’s parents’.] If effect is to be given to those principles, it must not be assumed that one parent (the father) cannot move and that the mother must, in every case, subordinate her ambitions and wishes, not to the needs of the child, but to the wishes of the father to pursue his life in a place of his choosing. It is the interests of the child which are paramount, not the interests or needs of the parents, let alone the interests of one of them.” Other relocation cases In AMS v AIF [1999] HCA 26, Hayne J (a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: father to pursue his life in a place of his choosing. It is the interests of the child which are paramount, not the interests or needs of the parents, let alone the interests of one of them.” Other relocation cases In AMS v AIF [1999] HCA 26, Hayne J (a member of a 6:1 majority) said at [217]-[218]: “Of course, the decision of a parent who is about to move and who seeks custody may well be affected … by whether he or she will have custody of the child if that proposed move is carried out. And it is, then, not surprising that counsel for the mother told the … judge (in effect) that if the mother’s having custody of the child depended upon her staying in Perth then she would not move to Darwin. But that does not mean that the question for the Court is whether the mother is to be permitted to move to Darwin. And it does not mean that the question is whether the mother has shown a ‘good’ or a ‘compelling’ reason for wanting to move. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 52 To translate the question into this form – has the mother shown a good, or good enough, reason for wanting to move – focuses attention upon the reasons and motives of the mother. But that is not the proper focus of inquiry. The proper focus is which is better for the child – to be in the custody of the father (in Perth) or to be in the custody of the mother (in Darwin). That, of course, requires attention to what benefits will the child have, and what detriments will the child suffer, from being in the mother’s custody in Darwin. If the mother had wished to move to marry and establish a new family in Darwin, or to take up new and better employment or training in Darwin, it may well have been possible to conclude that in all the circumstances the child’s welfare would be advanced by his being committed to the mother’s custody. The circumstances to be considered would include not only the fact of relocation but also all of the consequences that would follow – separation from the non-custodial parent, the creation of a new family in which the child would thereafter live (with all the concomitant advantages and disadvantages), the better economic posi- tion of the custodial parent, and so on. In that sense, inquiring about why the mother wished to move was relevant but it was only one inquiry among the many that go into deciding the ultimate question. (…)” An applicant’s fall-back concession should not be treated as a proposal: Jurchenko & Foster [2014] FamCAFC 127 (FC comprising Bryant CJ, Thackray and Duncanson JJ). The Full Court also at [111] cited the passage from Hayne J’s decision in AMS v AIF set out above. Note – Except where
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (…)” An applicant’s fall-back concession should not be treated as a proposal: Jurchenko & Foster [2014] FamCAFC 127 (FC comprising Bryant CJ, Thackray and Duncanson JJ). The Full Court also at [111] cited the passage from Hayne J’s decision in AMS v AIF set out above. Note – Except where their reasons turn on an interpretation of sections of the Act introduced in 2006 but repealed by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023, the following decisions may be useful not as factual comparisons but as to the types of evidence where relocation was allowed and “relocation” principles where pre-2006 decisions have been discussed. Also see Cowley & Mendoza [2010] FamCA 597 (overseas relocation disallowed as court found child- focused parents’ proposals equally legitimate; but allowed in Hannigan & Sorraw [2010] FamCA 807 where respondent father was abusive, lacked insight). See Hunt & Planey [2013] FamCA 442 (mother with “major depression and anxiety” was “unable to function fully as a parent” if not allowed to move to the US); Mallahan [2010] FamCA 631 (poor parental communication, mother’s move from Gold Coast to Vic allowed); Collu & Rinaldo [2010] FamCAFC 53 (FC) at [332] to [346] (“month about” time between Dubai and Sydney). In Wendland [2017] FamCAFC 244 F unsuccessfully appealed an order that M be permitted to relocate wherever she was posted in her employment with the ADF; also see Bryce & Bonig [2010] FamCA 999 where Dawe J allowed an overseas relocation where the applicant was granted sole parental responsibility. What to file? For the order to seek; and samples of affidavit in support of a mother seeking to relocate and affidavit of father opposing relocation, see “final orders sought” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 53 Unilateral relocation Note – Despite the repeal by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 of the “equal time” sections in- troduced to the Act in 2006, any post-2006 cases that follow may still be useful where principles that applied prior to 2006 are discussed or pre-2006 authority or research is cited. In Morgan & Miles [2007] FamCA 1230 Boland J upheld Brewster FM’s interim order for the mother to return a child after she had moved 144 km away before the interim hearing. Boland J analysed the issue of relocation at [58]-[61] and [72]-[74], interim relocation at [83] (which cites Cowling, which we deal with under “the court’s approach to interim hearings”) and local v interstate v overseas relocation at [89]-[91], saying at [88]: “ … [T]he very difficult issues in cases involving a relocation ( … ) make it highly desirable that, except in cases of emergency, the arrangements which will be in the child’s best interests should not be determined in an abridged interim hearing, and these are the type of cases in which the child’s present stability may be extremely relevant on an interim basis. It further appears to me the comments of Warnick J in C and S remain apt and relevant to determination of these cases.” In C & S [1998] FamCA 66 Warnick J (expressing the Full Court’s view) said: “ … [I]t is clear that the interests of any child … are very much connected with any questions directly affecting (the child), such as a relocation, being determined by a court without the im- pediment of a situation of recent development, which … significantly alters the relationship … or circumstances of the child with regard to one of its parents from what it or they had been immedi- ately
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: affecting (the child), such as a relocation, being determined by a court without the im- pediment of a situation of recent development, which … significantly alters the relationship … or circumstances of the child with regard to one of its parents from what it or they had been immedi- ately beforehand.” In Deiter [2011] FamCAFC 82 the Full Court set aside a return order made without first “conducting a discrete hearing to deal with the allegations of violence” alleged against the father (F) ([55]). In Chapa [2012] FMCAfam 1420 an anxious mother (M) with no home support who alleged child abuse and family violence by F was not sent back where F’s own case supported hers. Interim relocation was allowed in Robson & Johns [2008] FMCAfam 721 given the “short period [7 months] before the final hearing” (M soon to give birth; allegedly angry F granted fortnightly time at a contact centre); in Pace & Wilson [2009] FMCAfam 367 (a 5-year-old had not seen F for 3 years); and in Franklyn [2019] FamCAFC 256 at [29] (the move did not prevent M from adhering to order for child to see F once a fortnight). But in Silas & Barry [2009] FMCAfam 448 M was ordered to return and injoined from changing a child’s name. In West [2012] FamCA 35 an interim order allowed M to relocate from Sydney to Newcastle where her new partner (to whom she was pregnant) lived and worked, as the children’s relationship with F would not be compromised. M’s unilateral relocation was allowed in Wadsworth & Gale [2009] FMCAfam 537 where F, who did not protest for several months, was held to have acquiesced in the relocation and in Moreau & Trejo [2009] FMCAfam 1184 where F in a letter had agreed to the move. For
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: be compromised. M’s unilateral relocation was allowed in Wadsworth & Gale [2009] FMCAfam 537 where F, who did not protest for several months, was held to have acquiesced in the relocation and in Moreau & Trejo [2009] FMCAfam 1184 where F in a letter had agreed to the move. For more cases, search “unilateral relocation” at our online “case notes – children”. For an injunction see our precedent “interim orders sought” and “affidavits for interim hearings”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 55 COURT SANCTION OF SPECIAL MEDICAL PROCEDURES Sterilisation The High Court in Marion’s case (Department of Health and Community Services v JWB and SMB) [1992] HCA 15 held that a decision to authorise sterilisation of a child for a non-therapeutic purpose (as opposed to being a by-product of medical treatment for some therapeutic purpose), particularly one who is intellectually disabled, is beyond “the ordinary scope of a parental power to consent to medical treatment. Court authorisation is necessary.” In Re Marion (No. 2) [1992] FamCA 87 Nicholson CJ held that the performance of a hysterectomy was in Marion’s best interests, and he set out several factors which apply in determining the question. On the other hand, Warnick J in L & GM & MM [1993] FamCA 124 refused an application by par- ents for an order for sterilisation of their hospitalised 17 year old, physically and intellectually disabled daughter (which the parents were arguing was necessary for reasons of hygiene, control of epilepsy and prevention of pregnancy), not being satisfied “on the balance of probabilities, to a firm degree on clear and convincing proof, that the proposed procedure was in the child’s best interest”. No special weight was given to the parents’ wishes in that case. The Full Court did allow a hysterectomy (without removal of the ovaries) upon a severely intellectu- ally disabled child to prevent menstruation and the risk of pregnancy, where the parents’ application was supported by the child’s separate representative (now ICL). See also Re Angela [2010] FamCA 98 (hysterectomy for 11 year old girl). Major surgery Re Michael [1994] FamCA 29 was about whether surgery (a “Senning procedure”) should be carried out to treat a child’s serious congenital heart abnormality. Ultimately, the Full Court was not required to decide (as the surgeons
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT SANCTION OF SPECIAL MEDICAL PROCEDURES

chunks.text: also Re Angela [2010] FamCA 98 (hysterectomy for 11 year old girl). Major surgery Re Michael [1994] FamCA 29 was about whether surgery (a “Senning procedure”) should be carried out to treat a child’s serious congenital heart abnormality. Ultimately, the Full Court was not required to decide (as the surgeons did not pursue their recommendation of the procedure and the parents put in place alternative treatments) and so the case turned solely on the powers of the Victorian Public Advocate. Sex reassignment In Re: Kelvin [2017] FamCAFC 258 the Full Court heard a case stated by Watts J as to the father’s application for the court’s sanction in accordance with Re: Jamie [2013] FamCAFC 110 of the com- mencement of “Stage 2” treatment for Gender Dysphoria (“the distress experienced by a person due to incongruence between their gender identity and their sex assigned at birth”: Re: Kelvin at [6]) for his then 16 year old child “Kelvin” who was born female but ([27]) “transitioned socially as a transgender person” from Year 8. The Full Court held in Re: Jamie that the court’s approval under s 67ZC FLA was not required for “Stage 1” treatment (“puberty blocking treatment”) but that Stage 2 treatment (“gender affirming hormone treatment”) involving the use of oestrogen or testosterone with irreversible effects would require the court’s approval. However, a full bench of the Full Court in Re: Kelvin departed from Re: Jamie by hold- ing that the court’s sanction is no longer required for Stage 2 treatment of Gender Dysphoria where the child is capable of giving informed consent and the child’s parents do not object to the treatment; and that where a child is incapable of giving valid consent those with parental responsibility may authorise such treatment without the court’s approval. For a statement of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT SANCTION OF SPECIAL MEDICAL PROCEDURES

chunks.text: treatment of Gender Dysphoria where the child is capable of giving informed consent and the child’s parents do not object to the treatment; and that where a child is incapable of giving valid consent those with parental responsibility may authorise such treatment without the court’s approval. For a statement of established principles and a reconciliation of Re: Jamie and Re: Kelvin, see Re: Imogen (No. 6) [2020] FamCA 761 at [28]-[34]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT SANCTION OF SPECIAL MEDICAL PROCEDURES

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 56 Bone marrow donation A 10 year old child was allowed by Hannon J to donate bone marrow to his maternal aunt, who suf- fered from leukaemia. In GWW & CMW [1997] FamCA 2 the court found that although surgery was involved, the procedure involved less risk than that of sterilisation or organ transplant; and that the psychological benefit to the child of being allowed to donate his bone marrow outweighed the minimal risks, and that it was therefore in the child’s best interests to be allowed to participate as a donor. What to file? For the orders to seek and sample affidavits of applicant and medical expert in support, s ee “final orders sought” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below. Scope of parental authority Section 61B of the Family Law Act provides that in Part VII “parental responsibility in relation to a child means all the duties, powers, responsibilities and authority which, by law, parents have in relation to children”. Re: Sean and Russell (Special Medical Procedures) [2010] FamCA 948 contains a review of the Act by Murphy J as to the circumstances in which proposed special medical procedures come within the scope of parental responsibility or require the sanction of a court. Also see Re: Lucy (Gender Dysphoria) [2013] FamCA 518 in which Murphy J held that the treatment of a 13 year old child with Gender Dysphoria by injections of a drug called Lucrin to stay the progress of puberty did not require the court’s approval. In Director Clinical Service, Child & Adolescent Health Services & Kiszko & Anor [2016] FCWA 19 Thackray CJ made an order against the parents’ wishes on the application of the Princess Margaret Hospital subjecting a child to chemotherapy. Also see Director Clinical Service, Child &
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT SANCTION OF SPECIAL MEDICAL PROCEDURES

chunks.text: not require the court’s approval. In Director Clinical Service, Child & Adolescent Health Services & Kiszko & Anor [2016] FCWA 19 Thackray CJ made an order against the parents’ wishes on the application of the Princess Margaret Hospital subjecting a child to chemotherapy. Also see Director Clinical Service, Child & Adolescent Health Services & Kiszko & Anor [2016] FCWA 34 in which the Court upon hearing medical evidence adjourned the Hospital’s application for commencement of radiotherapy. In Executive Director Medical Services, Perth Children’s Hospital and Cutcheon & Anor [2023] FCWA 257 parents were restrained (on an interim basis) from removing a child from terminal care upon application by the Perth Children’s Hospital. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT SANCTION OF SPECIAL MEDICAL PROCEDURES

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 57 PATERNITY Presumption of paternity The starting point is the legal presumption of paternity. Under the Family Law Act, a presumption of par- entage arises from marriage (s 69P), cohabitation (s 69Q), registration of birth (s 69R), a court finding (s 69S), a signed acknowledgment of paternity (s 69T), and artificial conception (s 60H). Rebuttal of presumption The presumption of paternity is rebuttable by proof on the balance of probabilities (s 69U). This section would be relevant where an alleged father refuses to undergo a parentage test (subject to G v H below) and adduces evidence pointing to the improbability of him being the father. Power of court to order parentage testing If the paternity of a child is “in issue”, the court may require a parentage testing procedure to be carried out for the purpose of obtaining information to assist in determining the parentage of the child: s 69W. Mullane J in Diggins [1991] FamCA 100 said: “It is not a proper use of the section to allow a fishing expedition by way of paternity tests… in situations where there is no real evidence to place the paternity of the child in issue.” The court held that an order should not be made so that an alleged father can satisfy his doubts as to a child’s paternity. The court continued: “There must be some real issue as to paternity, some evidence which places the paternity of the child in doubt, before a court can embark upon the process of subjecting the child to the procedures for paternity testing and making an order for that purpose.” (It has been held that the court will make the order if an applicant has an honest, bona fide and reason- able doubt: Butler J in F & R [1992] FamCA
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the process of subjecting the child to the procedures for paternity testing and making an order for that purpose.” (It has been held that the court will make the order if an applicant has an honest, bona fide and reason- able doubt: Butler J in F & R [1992] FamCA 86.) Section 69W goes on to say that the order can be made on the court’s own initiative, or on the applica- tion of a party or an ICL representing a child’s interests under s 68L; and that an order may be directed to the child, the mother or any other person relevant to the question of determining paternity. For a review of the legislation and case law as to the court’s power to make a parentage testing order see the judgment of Bryant CJ of the Full Court in Brianna [2010] FamCAFC 97 at paras 17-31.
