Refusal to submit to test A majority of the High Court said in G v H [1994] HCA 48 at [12] of its judgment: “ … in the circumstances … the … inference to be drawn from G’s continuing contravention of the order that he submit to testing was that it was more probable than not that the outcome of the test would be unfavourable to him. And that must lead to the finding that, on the probabilities, he was the father of the child.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 58 A religious objection to the taking of blood was accepted by the court in F and R (above) – an objection that would no longer be tenable where testing now proceeds by means of a mouth swab. The court is reluctant to deny an application for parentage testing. See the Full Court decision in Duroux & Martin [1993] FamCA 125, where the court held that paternity should fundamentally be regarded as a medical rather than a legal issue. Where alleged father is under 18 The testing of minors requires the consent of a parent or responsible person: F & R (above) at p 79,274–5. A child may be forcibly tested if he refuses when a parent or responsible person has consented on his behalf: see s 69Z and 69ZA. The regulations are made under s 69ZB, and test results may be received in evidence under s 69ZC. Testing should be carried out by laboratories accredited by the National Association of Testing Authori- ties, Australia (NATA): Regulation 21N. For an accredited lab near you, go to www.nata.com.au here at our eBook; click “find organisation” then enter “parentage” as your keyword then your state or territory, then “search”. Scroll down for the results. Procedure This is set out in Regulations 72 to 73 of the Family Law Regulations. Other necessary orders a court may make are set out in s 69X. Declarations of parentage Under s 69VA, upon determining the issue of parentage of a child, the court may also issue a declaration of parentage that is conclusive evidence of paternity for the purpose of all laws of the Commonwealth, including s 29(2)(c) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 as the basis for a child support assessment against the person found to be the child’s father.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: court may also issue a declaration of parentage that is conclusive evidence of paternity for the purpose of all laws of the Commonwealth, including s 29(2)(c) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 as the basis for a child support assessment against the person found to be the child’s father. See Chapter 5 under “paternity disputes” (for the law relevant to child support) and under “precedents” for our sample applications for declarations under s 106A (respondent is the father) and s 107 CSAA (applicant is not the father) and our precedent affidavits in support. What to file? For the order to seek and an affidavit in support, see “final orders sought” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below. For our precedent applications for declarations under s 106A and 107 CSAA and affidavits in support, see “precedents” in Chapter 5. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 59 VARIATION OF PARENTING ORDERS Section 65D(2) empowers a court to discharge, vary, suspend or revise some or all of an earlier parent- ing order. Reconsideration of a final parenting order is governed by s 65DAAA enacted by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023. “65DAAA Reconsideration of final parenting orders (1) If a final parenting order is in force in relation to a child, a court must not reconsider the final parenting order unless: (a) the court has considered whether there has been a significant change of circumstances since the final parenting order was made; and (b) the court is satisfied that, in all the circumstances (and taking into account whether there has been a significant change of circumstances since the final parenting order was made), it is in the best interests of the child for the final parenting order to be reconsidered. (2) For the purposes of determining whether the court is satisfied as mentioned in paragraph (1)(b), and without limiting section 60CC, the court may have regard to any matters that the court considers relevant, including the following: (a) the reasons for the final parenting order and the material on which it was based; (b) whether there is any material available that was not available to the court that made the final parenting order [Rice & Asplund at [7] referred to “some factor which was not disclosed at the previous hearing which would have been material”] (c) the likelihood that, if the final parenting order is reconsidered, the court will make a new parenting order that affects the operation of the final parenting order in a significant way (whether by varying, discharging or suspending the final parenting order, in whole or in part, or in some other way); (d) any potential benefit, or detriment, to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: is reconsidered, the court will make a new parenting order that affects the operation of the final parenting order in a significant way (whether by varying, discharging or suspending the final parenting order, in whole or in part, or in some other way); (d) any potential benefit, or detriment, to the child that might result from reconsidering the final parenting order. (3) Despite subsection (1), the court may reconsider a final parenting order with the agreement or consent of all the parties to that order. (4) The failure of a court to comply with subsection (1) does not affect the validity of any order made by the court.” In Radecki [2024] FedCFamC1A 246 a majority of the Full Court held that the common law rule in Rice & Asplund [1978] FamCAFC 128 was codified by s 65DAAA and that to vary an order, there must be a significant change of circumstances. It was held that “there is no discernible difference between the first stage test or threshold to be applied under the new statutory regime, and the common law principles espoused by the rule in Rice and Asplund” ([63]). The majority said (at [79]): “… The word ‘consider’ in s 65DAAA should be construed to mean the Court is required to con- template the evidence and to make findings of fact as to what changes in circumstances (if any) there have been since the making of the anterior parenting orders. If there is no positive finding of changed circumstances, that is the end of the matter. If there is a positive finding as to changed circumstances, the second stage of the process requires the Court to make its determination, subject to the overarching best interests principle, as prescribed by s 65DAAA(1)(b) and otherwise having regard to relevant s 60CC considerations
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: is the end of the matter. If there is a positive finding as to changed circumstances, the second stage of the process requires the Court to make its determination, subject to the overarching best interests principle, as prescribed by s 65DAAA(1)(b) and otherwise having regard to relevant s 60CC considerations and the matters referred to in s 65DAAA(2).” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 60 In Freeman [1986] FamCA 23 Strauss J said that it was “usually in the interests of children that an order is treated as determining the dispute and be given the necessary support” and, further, that “stability in the lives of children ... is an essential prerequisite to their well-being”. Preliminary matter or part of the final hearing The Full Court in Bennett [1990] FamCA 148 at [63] said that it was discretionary as to whether the rule should be applied as a threshold question, but in that case it preferred the rule to be dealt with as a preliminary matter. In King & Finneran [2001] FamCA 344 it was held that as the previous order had been made so recently (within a year) the rule should be dealt with at a preliminary hearing. The application for a re-hearing failed. In SPS & PLS [2008] FamCAFC 16 Warnick J said at [51] that Evatt CJ “formulated the rule as one to be applied as a preliminary matter” as a means “to discourage ‘endless litigation’” ([56]). The variation was allowed as it accorded with newly expressed wishes of the children and only amounted to a relatively small increase in their time with their father. Examples of facts where variation allowed In Radecki (above from [87]) the Full Court held that the destruction of a formerly cooperative parent- ing arrangement combined with the 6+ years that had passed since orders were made (and the child’s greater maturity) were “a significant change of circumstances”. Variation was allowed in SCVG & KLD [2009] FMCAfam 708 (children wanting more time with F; M blocking him from decision-making) (also Morton & Berry [2014] FamCAFC 208 as to child’s wishes); in Galvez & Rendon [2009] FMCAfam 201 (prior consent order; M repartnered interstate;
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: “a significant change of circumstances”. Variation was allowed in SCVG & KLD [2009] FMCAfam 708 (children wanting more time with F; M blocking him from decision-making) (also Morton & Berry [2014] FamCAFC 208 as to child’s wishes); in Galvez & Rendon [2009] FMCAfam 201 (prior consent order; M repartnered interstate; parental con- flict); in Hamill [2009] FamCA 1324 at [19] where M granted sole parental responsibility (where it had been equally shared) to determine a choice of school dispute; in Prewett & Mann [2013] FamCAFC 130 at [57] despite a child’s difficult situation having been created by a parent’s breach of the order; and where an order was “entirely unworkable” in Deakin & Parry [2008] FMCAfam 590 at [5]-[6]. For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under “variation of parenting order”. Examples of facts where variation refused Variation was refused where previously alleged allegations of violence were alleged in Langmeil & Grange (No. 2) [2012] FamCA 588 and, as to the need to show more than the applicant’s wish to spend more time with the children, see Hackworth & Abani [2012] FamCAFC 172 at [14]-[16]. For more cases, see our archived children’s case notes under “variation of parenting order”. Subsequent applications where the section does not apply In Cameron & Brook [2018] FamCAFC 175 at [34]-[37] M’s application, 3 years after a final parent- ing order, for an order allowing the child to attend a school program arose out of parental responsibility that was provided for in that order. It was held that there was “no attempt to reagitate issues previously agitated” so the rule did not apply and if the parents could not agree the court had jurisdiction to hear the matter. What to file? See “final orders sought” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: order. It was held that there was “no attempt to reagitate issues previously agitated” so the rule did not apply and if the parents could not agree the court had jurisdiction to hear the matter. What to file? See “final orders sought” and “affidavits for final hearings” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 62 ABDUCTION AND RECOVERY OF CHILDREN The removal of children, a threat to do so, and a disappearance can be international, interstate or within a state; each calling for different responses. These usually take the following forms: • Flight risk within Australia • Unilateral relocation within Australia • Disappearance by other party with child • Overseas flight risk • Child passport alert (PACE Alert) • Overseas child abduction The steps you should take in each case are set out below. Flight risk within Australia If your client has reason to believe that the other party intends to move interstate or out of the region with a child without their consent, you should make an urgent appointment for the parties to see an FDR provider, then urgently send a letter to that party or their lawyer stating: • your client’s concern and the factual basis for that concern • that any relocation of a child should be discussed between both parents, who must make a genuine effort to resolve the issue (see “parental responsibility” under “relocation” above) OR if there is an order in place, that relocation would be in breach of the order • notice of the appointment for the parties to discuss the matter with an FDR provider • a request that, say, within one hour or other such short but reasonable notice, the other party (or their lawyer): – confirm in writing that they/their client will keep the counselling appointment – give their written undertaking not to remove the child without your client’s consent or a court order (“failing which a court application will be filed without further notice, for an injunction preventing departure, and an order that you/your client pay our client’s costs of these proceedings”) If the risk passes, then follow the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: undertaking not to remove the child without your client’s consent or a court order (“failing which a court application will be filed without further notice, for an injunction preventing departure, and an order that you/your client pay our client’s costs of these proceedings”) If the risk passes, then follow the pre-action steps (see “family dispute resolution” above), then file an ap- plication in the FCFCA for interim and final parenting orders (interim orders as to the time the child is to spend with each party pending the final hearing; and to restrain the other party from relocating). In the case of a risk of flight overseas, see “overseas flight risk” below as to the Watch List procedure. Refusal to undertake not to relocate Given your decisive action in putting the flight risk on paper and warning about legal costs, a party considering relocating without consent will usually relent and give the undertaking. If not, issue an urgent application in the FCFCA, filing it via the ePortal (and upload a letter to the Urgent Listings Registrar in support), seeking an interim injunction against the party (an order that the party “be and is hereby restrained from removing the child from the child’s current place of residence at” etc). See below our precedent orders and affidavit in support. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 63 Unilateral relocation within Australia For the court’s approach to unilateral relocation, see “unilateral relocation” under “relocation” above. Your client either will or will not know where the respondent has taken the child. If the child’s whereabouts are known apply to the FCFCA for an urgent listing and either a recovery order or the injunction at our precedent “interim parenting orders” under the headings “recovery order” and “injunction – unilateral relocation within Australia” (which requires the respondent to return and, if applicable, to re-enrol the child at school). An order for urgent listing is in our precedent under “recovery order”. You would usually only seek an ex parte order if there were a risk of harm to the children if the order were not made without notice to the respondent. Also see Drew & Jensen [2017] FCCA 656 from [26] and Chapter 8 (“applying for interim or procedural order without notice”). The court’s power to make a recovery order is under s 67U of the Family Law Act. If their whereabouts are not known your client may apply for a location order addressed to Centrelink and (for 4 quarterly address checks) a Commonwealth information order (see “disappearance by other party with child” below and our precedent “interim parenting orders”). An applicant may apply for a recovery order whether a parenting order is in force (see s 67T(a)-(caa)) or not, under s 67T(ca) as a grandparent of the child or s 67T(d) as a person concerned with the care, wel- fare or development of the child. For example, see Tesluk & Gordon [2009] FamCA 952 at [11] where the child’s primary carer was granted a recovery order. The court must determine an application for a recovery order (or list it for an urgent hearing), not adjourn it for
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: care, wel- fare or development of the child. For example, see Tesluk & Gordon [2009] FamCA 952 at [11] where the child’s primary carer was granted a recovery order. The court must determine an application for a recovery order (or list it for an urgent hearing), not adjourn it for mention only: Ghorbani & Saeed [2013] FamCAFC 167 at [16]-[25]. In Renald (No. 2) [2017] FamCAFC 133 Thackray J (on appeal from a family law magistrate of the FCWA) agreed with M ([18]-[19]) that the delay in listing (“notwithstanding [that] the school year was about to commence” ([2])) was not justified and (in making the recovery order refused by the magistrate) said (at [82]) that “parents should not take matters into their own hands where there is no evidence of risk”. What to file? For the wording of your recovery order, injunction for the return of a child and injunction (flight risk) see “interim parenting orders” at our precedent orders below. Costs In cases like this, where a respondent’s misconduct has forced your client to incur the cost of legal proceedings, include with your orders sought an order that the respondent pay your client’s taxed costs of and incidental to the application. Attach to your supporting affidavit a copy of any letter from you cautioning the other party against absconding with the child. Disappearance by other party with child As this next procedure can be slow to produce results, make every effort to ascertain the respondent’s whereabouts instead of taking the following action. Most absconding parents do not disappear but go to the home of a relative or friend. So make appropriate inquiries as to their whereabouts so as to avoid having to take the cumbersome steps under this heading. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 64 Apply to the FCFCA for a location order under s 67K (and if necessary, a Commonwealth information order under s 67N). These orders should be sought as interim orders in addition to your interim and final parenting orders (as above). A location order requires a person (e.g. friend or family member) or a Commonwealth department such as Centrelink or the ATO (which may have a record of a child’s address) to inform the court registry of that address: s 67J. The court arranges for that person or department to be served with the order and if you have also applied for leave under s 67P (see our precedent “interim parenting orders”) the registry will notify you. Also seek an adjournment and then arrange personal service of your court papers con- taining the new return date. A Commonwealth information order is the same, but requires the depart- ment’s records to be searched for that address every 3 months for a year. If a child cannot be located through a location or Commonwealth information order, a publication order can be sought (as a further interim order) under s 121. A publication order is one that permits a person to publish in a newspaper or periodical publication or by radio broadcast or television an account of family law proceedings, and a request for assistance from the public to locate the child. A precedent publication order is available at our online “forms and precedents”. The pre-action steps can be waived on the ground of urgency. What to file? For the wording of your location order (and, if applicable, Commonwealth information order) and a sample affidavit in support, see “interim orders sought” and “affidavits for interim hearings” in “precedents” below. See “unilateral relocation” under “relocation” above as to the court’s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: waived on the ground of urgency. What to file? For the wording of your location order (and, if applicable, Commonwealth information order) and a sample affidavit in support, see “interim orders sought” and “affidavits for interim hearings” in “precedents” below. See “unilateral relocation” under “relocation” above as to the court’s tendency to grant the order sought, in the case of a unilateral relocation prior to a final hearing. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 65 Overseas flight risk This can occur if the child has a passport, or if the parent in question may try to obtain one without your client’s consent under s 11(2) of the Australian Passports Act 2005. Place your child’s name on the Australian Federal Police (AFP) Watch List. This will prevent the child from leaving from any international airport or seaport in Australia. To do this: • you must have a court order prohibiting the child’s removal from Australia, OR • you must show that you have applied for such an order (see next paragraphs). Watch List procedure Act immediately, waiving the pre-action steps on the ground of urgency. Prepare and file an application to the FCFCA for interim and final parenting orders (see “precedents” below). The final and interim orders you seek may be identical. Include, as an interim order, a Watch List order (for this and for a sample affidavit in support, see under “interim orders sought” and “affidavits for interim hearings” in “precedents” below). Add an interim order for delivery of the child’s passport under s 67ZD if that section applies. File your papers either by email or via the Commonwealth Courts Portal (or in WA, the eCourts Portal of Western Australia). Email your existing court order (restraining the child’s removal from Australia), if you have an exist- ing order; OR your court-sealed application for such an order to the AFP Operations Coordina- tion Centre (AOCC) the contact details for which are at www.afp.gov.au and here at our eBook. When placing a child on the AFP Watch List, ensure that you include all of the following: • A copy of your order OR court-sealed application for an order prohibiting child’s removal from Australia • Full names, gender and dates of birth of all
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: www.afp.gov.au and here at our eBook. When placing a child on the AFP Watch List, ensure that you include all of the following: • A copy of your order OR court-sealed application for an order prohibiting child’s removal from Australia • Full names, gender and dates of birth of all children to be placed on the Watch List • Contact details for your client and the respondent • Contact details for the lawyer submitting the application Note – The Alert will remain until discharged by court order. So once the situation has settled down with no further risk of flight, an order should be made to discharge the order and a copy sent to the AFP. If you overlook this, a later innocent attempt to travel overseas would be blocked. One way to avoid children being unexpectedly stopped at the airport some time down the track would be to limit your order to say 2 or 3 years (putting the onus on a parent seeking an exten- sion to apply for one). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 66 Child Alert Request To prevent a party from applying for a child’s passport without your client’s consent, lodge the Depart- ment of Foreign Affairs and Trade’s Child Alert Request form at any Australian Passport Office or send it to Passport Operations (PC9), GPO Box 9807 in your nearest capital city. They can be reached by phone on 131 232. A parent or person with parental responsibility for a child is entitled to do this. Such a request warns the passport office that the other party may apply for a child’s passport without consent. It is actioned imme- diately, and a Child Alert will remain in force for 12 months or until the child turns 18, marries or a court order discharges it. Child Alert Request form To request a child alert you must lodge or send a Child Alert Request form (PC9) to DFAT as above. The form is available by phone 131 232 (the Australian Passport Information Service) and at passport offices. Note – Your Request is to be accompanied by either a certified copy of any existing parenting order or (if not stated on the request form itself) a statement confirming that your client is entitled to make the request, being a parent or a person who has parental responsibility under s 61C of the Family Law Act. You should also include a statement to explain why you are requesting a child alert. If court proceedings are pending, the court has power under s 67ZD of the FLA where “there is a pos- sibility or threat that a child may be removed from Australia” to order the passport of the child to be delivered to the court upon such conditions as the court considers appropriate. If the child already has or may have
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: s 67ZD of the FLA where “there is a pos- sibility or threat that a child may be removed from Australia” to order the passport of the child to be delivered to the court upon such conditions as the court considers appropriate. If the child already has or may have a passport we recommend applying for a Watch List order instead (see “Watch List procedure” above). Sending a copy of your sealed application to the Australian Federal Police will place the child on the Watch List immediately (without having to await the order). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 67 Overseas child abduction Australia and most other countries are parties to the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction signed at The Hague on 25 October 1980 (known as the Hague Convention) and have made reciprocal regulations to put the Convention into effect as between convention countries. Our regulations are the Family Law (Child Abduction Convention) Regulations 1986. The court of a convention country to or in which a child (under 16) has been removed or retained in breach of a person’s rights of custody is required by its regulations, upon a request (in our regulations, above, now called an “application”) being made by that person, to make an order for the return of the child to the child’s home country (Reg 11(1)). Unless specified circumstances apply, the court’s discretion to refuse to order the return of a child is limited: Reg 16(3). Action is to be taken as quickly as a proper consideration of the matter allows: Reg 5(1) and (3). Persons with “rights of custody” – being most parents in Australia, under the definition below – are entitled to make such a request if the child has been removed or retained in breach of those rights: Reg 11(1). Each convention country uses a Central Authority as its enforcement agency, through which requests for the return of a child wrongly removed or retained are made. The Central Authority then refers the application to the Central Authority of the convention country to which the child has been abducted. We have a Central Authority for the Commonwealth and one for each State and Territory (Regs 8 and 9). It is there your request is to be lodged (Reg 11). It is then transmitted to the Commonwealth Central Authority for action (Reg 13). For a list
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: child has been abducted. We have a Central Authority for the Commonwealth and one for each State and Territory (Regs 8 and 9). It is there your request is to be lodged (Reg 11). It is then transmitted to the Commonwealth Central Authority for action (Reg 13). For a list of the convention countries, search “convention countries” at our online “forms and precedents” and see below for the contact details for the Central Authority in your State or Terri- tory (where the request is to be lodged). Note – It can be easier to recover a child from overseas than from interstate, unless the child is taken to a non-convention country (in which case something more ingenious may be called for) or the case is contested in the foreign court. Also note – If a parenting order is in force, it is a crime to remove a child from Australia without the other parent’s prior written consent or an order authorising such travel (s 65Y of the FLA), punishable by up to three years imprisonment. This could be a trap for any parent who believes that they can take an overseas holiday with their child during their scheduled time without notifying and obtaining the consent of the other parent. Other orders the court can make Beyond an order for the return of the child, other orders available under Regulation 14(1) include a warrant for the location and recovery of the child and other injunctions. Arrangements for return of child Regulation 20 provides that the (Commonwealth) Central Authority must coordinate the making of arrangements necessary to give effect to the return order. The child must be returned after the lapse of seven days after the return order is made if the order has not been stayed in that time. (Central Authorities
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 20 provides that the (Commonwealth) Central Authority must coordinate the making of arrangements necessary to give effect to the return order. The child must be returned after the lapse of seven days after the return order is made if the order has not been stayed in that time. (Central Authorities are not required to pay for the costs of travel or other arrangements.) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 68 There is provision in the application form itself and in s 111B(1C) of the FLA for the Central Authority arranging to place the child with an appropriate person to secure the child’s welfare until a court makes an order for the child’s care, welfare or development. This will usually authorise your client to collect and accompany the child from the foreign country or collect the child upon return to Australia. Application for the return of a child – Form 1 • Download it here at our eBook or at “forms and precedents” at www.thefamilylawbook.com.au Completion of the form is straightforward. For “V – FACTUAL OR LEGAL GROUNDS JUSTIFYING THE REQUEST” insert “See attachment”; then prepare one of the attachments (that appear below, and which are also available from our website) under your letterhead, attaching it to Form 1. This is all you will need to do if the proceedings go undefended in the foreign court (although see “arrangements for return of child” below). The shaded section “relevant factors for any contested proceedings” (that follows the two alterna- tive attachments to Form 1 overleaf) covers issues that will not arise unless raised in the foreign court by the respondent. If they are, your client may be called on to file an affidavit in response to the claims made in the respondent’s affidavit. The Central Authority will tell you what is required, and your barrister can always be asked to prepare it or settle your draft. Note – You may also be asked by the Central Authority’s foreign lawyer to swear the legal aspects of the attachment to your client’s application in an affidavit, in which case ask him/her to email you the template for that. Email and post your completed Form 1 to the Central Authority
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: – You may also be asked by the Central Authority’s foreign lawyer to swear the legal aspects of the attachment to your client’s application in an affidavit, in which case ask him/her to email you the template for that. Email and post your completed Form 1 to the Central Authority in your State or Territory (see contact details below). The State/Territory Central Authority must send a valid request to the Commonwealth Central Authority (Reg 11(3)), who must take action under the Convention if the request complies with the Regulations (Reg 11(4)), by liaising with the Central Authority of the convention country where the child is held for the application to be brought before a court of that country. “Rights of custody” Rights of custody are defined by s 111B(4) of the Family Law Act which states that the following persons should be regarded as having rights of custody in respect of a child for the purposes of the Hague Convention: (a) Each of the child’s parents, unless the parent due to an order has no parental responsibility (b) A person who, under a parenting order, a child is to live with or has parental responsibility (c) A person without an order but who has parental responsibility for a child due to the operation of the FLA (such as s 61C) and is responsible for the day-to-day or long-term care, welfare and development of the child. “Parental responsibility” Can be sole or joint: see Reg 4(1)(b). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 69 (Attachment to Form 1 – use this for wrongful removal to convention country) V – FACTUAL OR LEGAL GROUNDS JUSTIFYING THE REQUEST 1. On [date] the [Mother/Father] removed the child from Australia to [name of country] being a conven- tion country, in breach of the [Mother/Father]’s rights of custody under a law in force in Australia, namely the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) (“the Act”). 2. Attached is a true copy of Division 2 of Part XIIIAA of the Act, Section 111B(4)(a) of which provides that for the purposes of the Convention each of the parents of a child should be regarded as having rights of custody in respect of the child unless the parent has no parental responsibility for the child because of any order of a court. 3. The [Mother/Father] is a parent of the child and no such order has been made. 4. (If no parenting order is in force, the next 2 paras apply) The [Mother/Father] also has rights of cus- tody in respect of the child under Section 111B(4)(c) in that [he/she] has parental responsibility for the child because of the operation of the Act, specifically Section 61C(1) of the Act, and is responsible for the day-to-day and long-term care, welfare and development of the child within the meaning of Section 61B of the Act. 5. Section 61C(1) provides that “each of the parents of a child who is not 18 has parental responsibility for the child”, “parental responsibility” being defined by Section 61B as meaning “all the duties, pow- ers, responsibilities and authority which, by law, parents have in relation to children”. (OR) 6. (Where a parenting order is in force, the next 2 paras apply) Attached is a true copy of a parenting order made by [name of court]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: by Section 61B as meaning “all the duties, pow- ers, responsibilities and authority which, by law, parents have in relation to children”. (OR) 6. (Where a parenting order is in force, the next 2 paras apply) Attached is a true copy of a parenting order made by [name of court] on [date]. 7. The [Mother/Father] has parental responsibility for the child under that parenting order, and therefore also has rights of custody under Section 111B(4)(b)(ii) of the Act. (OR) The [Mother/Father] is the person with whom the child is to live under that parenting order, and therefore also has rights of custody under Section 111B(4)(b)(i) of the Act. DATED: SIGNED: (your name and firm’s name as Father’s/Mother’s lawyers) Note – Remember also to attach the documents referred to in paragraphs 2 and 4, as applicable. A link to further information and assistance Further information and assistance is available at a link here in our eBook to the Australian Government’s “international parental child abduction”. Also see “seeking access to a child overseas”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 70 (Attachment to Form 1 – use this for refusal to return child from convention country on agreed date) V – FACTUAL OR LEGAL GROUNDS JUSTIFYING THE REQUEST 1. The [Mother/Father] took the child to [name of country], being a convention country, on [date] with the [Mother/Father]’s consent for a temporary stay until [second date]. 2. (In case of consent, which was in writing or even referred to in writing by either party or anyone else:) Attached is a true copy of [that consent/the agreement] between the parties [ / ] a letter from [X] to [Y] that refers to the parties’ agreement (OR if not in writing:) The purpose of the stay was [insert – e.g. to stay with relatives] and it was agreed orally between the parties that the [Mother/Father] would return to Australia with the child on [second date] e.g. in time for recommencement of the child’s (Australian) school year. 3. On [second date] the [Mother/Father] retained the child in a convention country in breach of the [Mother/Father]’s rights of custody under a law in force in Australia, namely the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) by refusing to return the child. (Attach a copy of any written refusal or, if not in writing, specify what words of request and refusal about the child’s return were exchanged between the parties after the due date.) 4. Attached is a true copy of Division 2 of Part XIIIAA of the Act, Section 111B(4)(a) of which provides that for the purposes of the Convention each of the parents of a child should be regarded as having rights of custody in respect of the child unless the parent has no parental responsibility for the child because of any order of a court. 5. The [Mother/Father] is a parent

The [Mother/Father] is a parent of the child and no such order has been made. 6. (If no parenting order is in force, the next 2 paras apply) The [Mother/Father] also has rights of custody in respect of the child under Section 111B(4)(c) in that [he/she] has parental responsibility for the child because of the operation of the Act, specifically Section 61C(1) of the Act, and is responsible for the day-to-day and long-term care, welfare and development of the child within the meaning of Section 61B of the Act. 7. Section 61C(1) provides that “each of the parents of a child who is not 18 has parental responsibility for the child”, “parental responsibility” being defined by Section 61B as meaning “all the duties, powers, responsibilities and authority which, by law, parents have in relation to children”. (OR) 8. (Where a parenting order is in force, the next 2 paras apply) Attached is a true copy of a parenting order made by [name of court] on [date]. 9. The [Mother/Father] has parental responsibility for the child under that parenting order, and therefore also has rights of custody under Section 111B(4)(b)(ii) of the Act. chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 71 Summary of forms and procedure Child abduction proceedings are brought under the Family Law (Child Abduction Convention) Regulations 1986. The forms are under Schedule 3. Convention countries have mirror regulations. Upon receiving your Form 1 request for the return of a child – available at our online “forms and precedents” – the Central Authority (CA) will file an application in the foreign court. The CA’s application to the court here or overseas is Form 2. A child removed to or retained in Australia comes under Reg 14(1); a threat of removal from Australia under Reg 14(2); removal from Australia or wrongful retention in a convention country under Reg 14(3). A person served with a Form 2 must file an answer, or an answer and a cross-application in Form 2A. The applicant (CA) may file a reply in accordance with Form 2B. In contested cases the following statutory issues will apply. RELEVANT FACTORS FOR ANY CONTESTED PROCEEDINGS The following is the law applied reciprocally either by a foreign court in a convention country (which may hear an application of yours for the return of a child) or the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia where a child has been wrongfully brought here from overseas. At the overseas hearing of your case, the law applied will be confined to the court’s obligation under the regulations to make an order for the return of your client’s child if (which often occurs) their application goes undefended in the foreign court. Should you receive instructions to represent a party where a parent is alleged to have brought a child to Australia wrongfully, you should refer a full statement of the facts to your barrister with a brief to advise, to prepare any necessary court papers and appear at the hearing.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: court. Should you receive instructions to represent a party where a parent is alleged to have brought a child to Australia wrongfully, you should refer a full statement of the facts to your barrister with a brief to advise, to prepare any necessary court papers and appear at the hearing. Child abduction proceedings under the Regulations should normally be heard before and not at the same time as proceedings for a parenting order under Part VII of the Family Law Act: Depart- ment of Families & Moore [1999] FamCA 284 at [10]. The best interests of the child are not the paramount consideration in proceedings for the return of a child under the child abduction regulations: McCall & State Central Authority [1994] FamCA 120 (FC) at [26]. Proceedings should normally be heard summarily and without the cross-examination of de- ponents on their affidavits: Department of Families & Bennett [2000] FamCA 253 at [12]. An abducting parent and the other parent are not normally required for cross-examination unless both are available for cross-examination without undue delay: Regino [1994] FamCA 147 at [40]-[42]; also Re K [1997] 2 FamLR 212 at p 214. An affidavit of a witness residing outside the country hearing the proceedings is admissible despite the non-attendance of the witness for cross-examination: Reg 29(3). This would cover an affidavit from the person seeking the return of the child and also their solicitor (as to rights of custody). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 72 Where the precise location of a child is unknown, the Commonwealth Attorney-General or the foreign Central Authority may conduct searches in an effort to locate the child. Foreign court’s obligation to make a return order Regulation 16 of the Regulations sets out the pre-requisites for the return of a child, and will be reciprocal with those of the country to which the child has been taken: see our Reg 1A(2)(c). Under Reg 16(1) the court must make the order if: • An application (by the Central Authority on your client’s behalf) for a return order is made; and • The application is filed within one year after the child’s removal or “retention” (see below); and • The Central Authority satisfies the court that the child’s removal or retention was wrongful. “Wrongful removal or retention” Reg 16(1A) states that a child’s removal or retention is wrongful if ALL of the following apply: (a) The child was under 16; (b) The child “habitually resided” (see below) in a convention country immediately before removal or retention; (c) The applicant had rights of custody in relation to the child in that country; (d) The removal or retention is in breach of those rights of custody; (e) At the time of the removal or retention, the applicant was “actually exercising those rights” (either jointly or alone, or would have done if the child had not been removed or retained) (see below). “Retention” only occurs where a child has been taken to another country by consent – for a holiday, or contact with a parent or for some other reason – when the parent fails to return the child when they are due to do so under the parties’ agreement: House of Lords in Re H (minors) [1991] 2 AC 476;
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to another country by consent – for a holiday, or contact with a parent or for some other reason – when the parent fails to return the child when they are due to do so under the parties’ agreement: House of Lords in Re H (minors) [1991] 2 AC 476; also Re S (minors) [1994] Fam70. The date of retention is the day after the due date of return, not the date on which a threat to retain the child is made: Department of Families & BW [2003] FamCA 335. “Habitually resident” The High Court has applied NZ authority which held that “habitual residence” was a “broad fac- tual inquiry” as to “all relevant factors, including settled purpose, the actual and intended length [and] purpose of the stay, the strength of ties to the [current and previous places], the degree of assimilation … including living and schooling arrangements, and cultural, social and economic integration: LK v Director-General Department of Community Services [2009] HCA 9 at [21]-[45] (adopted by the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in State Central Authority & Camden [2012] FamCAFC 45). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 73 “Actually exercising rights of custody” is a question of fact. A person may be exercising rights of custody even though they have del- egated their rights to someone else, such as a relative, temporarily: Department of Community Services & Crowe [1996] FamCA 122. It was held in Handbury & State Central Authority and Anor [2020] FamCAFC 5 that M’s repudiation of an agreement for the family’s temporary stay in Australia was a breach of F’s rights of custody in UK. Applications more than one year after removal: when court must order child’s return Reg 16(2). The prerequisites for the court doing so are the same as for applications made within a year, except that instead of proving “wrongfulness”, it is necessary for the court to be satisfied that the person opposing the return has not established that the child has “settled in their new environment”: Reg 16(2) (defined below). Cases where this will apply will be where a child is taken overseas by consent for, say, a year (e.g. for study, or some other reason) but is not returned at the end of that time (the date of “retention” being the date of failure to return on the due (agreed) date, not the date of any threat not to return the child: see cases above as to “retention”). “Settled in his or her new environment” This can occur even though the child is still experiencing problems: Department of Community Services & M & C [1998] FamCA 1518 at [62]. When court may refuse to order child’s return Under Reg 16(3) a court may refuse to make an order if the person opposing return establishes that: (a) The applicant: (i) was not actually exercising rights of custody when the child was removed and those rights would not
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 1518 at [62]. When court may refuse to order child’s return Under Reg 16(3) a court may refuse to make an order if the person opposing return establishes that: (a) The applicant: (i) was not actually exercising rights of custody when the child was removed and those rights would not have been exercised if the child had not been removed; or (ii) had consented or subsequently acquiesced in the child being removed to or retained in the country in question (see “consent” and “acquiescence” below); or (b) There is a grave risk that the return of the child would expose the child to physical or psychological harm or otherwise place the child in an intolerable situation (see “grave risk” and “intolerable situation” below). (c) Each of the following applies: (i) The child objects to being returned; (ii) The child’s objection shows a strength of feeling beyond the mere expression of a preference or of ordinary wishes; (iii) The child has attained an age, and a degree of maturity, at which it is appropriate to take account of their views: (see “child’s objection” below). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 74 Note – The Family Law Amendment Act 2023 that commenced 6 May 2024 repealed s 111B(1B) which enabled regulations that allowed a child’s objection to return to be taken into account, so Reg 16(3)(c) above no longer applies. The mere fact that a person opposing the return of a child establishes a ground under Reg 16(3) does not mean that the court must then refuse to make an order for the child’s return. If a ground is established, the court has a discretion whether to order the return of the child: Department of Families & Bennett [2000] FamCA 253 at [48] and [49]. “Consent” cannot be real if it results from fraud, duress, deceit or undue influence, or if it results from mistaken advice from a legal adviser: Re S (minors) [1994] 1 FamLR 819 at p 831. Consent can be inferred from words and actions if the inference of consent is clear: Re C [1996] 1 FamLR 461; Re K [1997] 2 FamLR 212 at pp 217–8; P v P [1998] 1 FamLR 630 at p 633. In Commissioner of Police for State Central Authority of South Australia & Garnett [2021] FamCA 86 F was found to have consented to M’s wrongful removal by handing M a child’s passport while M packed her bags to return to Australia. “Acquiescence” can be either active or passive, express or implied, but must involve an appreciation by the person concerned that whoever has removed the child has done so unlawfully and that there are remedies against that person: Treyvaud J in State Central Authority & McCall [1994] FamCA 156 at [34]. Mere passivity, even for eight months, does not constitute acquiescence; especially where the person concerned is confused, uncertain or in emotional turmoil: Laing & The Central
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: done so unlawfully and that there are remedies against that person: Treyvaud J in State Central Authority & McCall [1994] FamCA 156 at [34]. Mere passivity, even for eight months, does not constitute acquiescence; especially where the person concerned is confused, uncertain or in emotional turmoil: Laing & The Central Authority [1996] FamCA 146. See also Department of Health & Casse [1995] FamCA 71 at [38]-[44] (Kay J). Writing a reassuring letter to a child does not constitute acquiescence if other action by the writer indicates otherwise: Emmett & Perry [1995] FamCA 77 at [14]-[22] (Jordan J). “Grave risk of physical or psychological harm” In ruling that these words should be given their ordinary meaning, the majority of the High Court said that the words meant “a grave risk of exposure to harm”: DP v Commonwealth Central Authority [2001] HCA 39. Where a mother was found to be at serious risk of committing suicide if the child were ordered to return to Australia, the court held that the real possibility of the mother’s suicide would expose the child to serious psychological harm, therefore the court should not order the return of the child: Department of Families & RSP [2003] FamCA 623. Evidence of grave risk must be clear and compelling: Dept of Families & Bennett [2000] FamCA 253 at [31]. Some distress to a child is not sufficient: DP v Commonwealth Central Authority (above) at [40] per Gaudron, Gummow and Hayne JJ and [132] per Kirby J. Also see Walpole & Secretary, Department of Communities and Justice [2020] FamCAFC 65 at [58]-[61]. Courts in child’s own country can remedy any risk to the child: Gsponer & Johnstone [1988] FamCA 21 at [57]-[64]. But see Walpole (above) at [61]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 75 Note – The court in that case expressed “real concern about the disingenuous adoption of stances designed to achieve the purposes of abductors in resisting orders for the return of children”. This stance taken by an abductor should be met by appropriate evidence such as evidence of any history of any theatrical conduct by the abductor prior to the abduction and other evidence impugning the abductor’s credit and bona fides. “Intolerable situation” It has been held in England that a child may be placed in an intolerable situation in their home country if it were to be deprived for an appreciable period of the day to day care of the person who had previously been his or her primary caregiver: Re O [1994] 2 FamLR 349 at p 362. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 77 CONTRAVENTION OF PARENTING ORDERS From 6 May 2024 an Application – Contravention is to be filed where your client alleges a breach of a parenting order: FLR 11.64. The Application – Enforcement is no longer to be used in a parenting case. The form to be filed in WA will be governed by FCR 433. As s 60I extends to contravention applications, an applicant must first make a genuine effort to resolve the matter by means of family dispute resolution (FDR) with the respondent. The usual exceptions and the option of seeking an exemption from attending FDR apply and are explained in the new Application – Contravention (as are what is to be filed with the Application). Applicants will be required to specify the orders being sought. An accompanying notice to the respondent confirms that the court may: • vary or suspend the relevant parenting order • order the respondent to attend a post-separation parenting program • make an order for make-up time • require the respondent to enter into a bond • order that the respondent pay all or some of the applicant’s legal costs • order that the respondent pay compensation for reasonable expenses lost as a result of the contravention (for example, air fares) • order the respondent to pay a fine • order that the respondent be imprisoned Applicants must file an affidavit annexing the relevant order, containing proof that the respondent is aware of the order and evidence in support of each alleged contravention (and of any orders sought). Respondents may file an affidavit but are not required to (FLR 11.67; FCR 437) (and, we suggest, an Application in a Proceeding with affidavit in support should be filed if they are seeking an order too). Failure of a respondent to attend
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: each alleged contravention (and of any orders sought). Respondents may file an affidavit but are not required to (FLR 11.67; FCR 437) (and, we suggest, an Application in a Proceeding with affidavit in support should be filed if they are seeking an order too). Failure of a respondent to attend is dealt with in FLR 11.68 (FCR 438). See FLR 11.63 and Family Law Practice Direction – National Contravention List. The Application – Contravention and associated documents are not filed via the Commonwealth Courts Portal but are filed by email in the Contravention List contraventionlist@fcfcoa.gov.au. Once received, applications are considered by a contravention registrar within 14 days. If the application is deficient or non-compliant with the FLR, the contravention registrar may decline to accept the application for filing. Contravention proceedings should be confined to the clearest cases: see Biddell & Ervin [2012] FMCAfam 926 at [32]-[39]. An applicant must prove (s 70NAC) that the respondent: • intentionally failed to comply with the order, or • made no reasonable attempt to comply with the order. A respondent may claim to have a reasonable excuse for contravening a child-related order within the meaning of s 70NAD but must prove it (s 70NADA). The standard of proof for both parties is proof on the balance of probabilities (s 70NAE). Contravention no longer takes priority over a parenting case: Maddax & Danner [2019] FamCAFC 38 at [45]-[54]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 78 Division 13A of Part VII of the Act – Orders in proceedings relating to contraventions of child-related orders The former Division 13A was repealed by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 which substituted the following Division 13A governing proceedings relating to contraventions of child-related orders. What constitute a “child-related order” are set out in s 70NBA(2). The principal objects of Division 13A Section 70NAB – They are to meet the best interests of children … by: (a) supporting compliance with child-related orders; (b) resolving difficulties associated with [such] orders … which have contributed to non-compliance … (including by varying or making further orders); (c) deterring non-compliance … ; (d) … enforcing compliance … [if] necessary and appropriate; and (e) … sanctions for a person who contravenes … without reasonable excuse. Meaning of contravene a child-related order Section 70NAC(1)(a) provides that a person contravenes a child-related order only if he or she intention- ally fails to comply with it or makes no reasonable attempt to comply with it. Meaning of reasonable excuse for contravening a child-related order (s 70NAD) Where person did not understand obligations (1) A person has a reasonable excuse for contravening a child-related order if: (a) the person contravened the order because at the time of the contravention the person did not understand the obligations imposed by the order; and (b) the court considers that the person ought to be excused in respect of the contravention. (2) If the court decides that a person has a reasonable excuse under subsection (1) for contravening a child-related order, the court must explain to the person, in language likely to be readily understood by the person: (a) the obligations imposed on the person by the order; and (b) the consequences that may follow if the person
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: person has a reasonable excuse under subsection (1) for contravening a child-related order, the court must explain to the person, in language likely to be readily understood by the person: (a) the obligations imposed on the person by the order; and (b) the consequences that may follow if the person contravenes the order again. Protection of health or safety of a person (3) A person has a reasonable excuse for contravening a child-related order if: (a) the person contravened the order because the person reasonably believed that the person’s actions constituting the contravention were necessary to protect the health or safety of the person, a child or any other person; and (b) the period of the contravention was not longer than necessary to protect the health or safety of the person, child or other person. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 79 Section does not limit circumstances of a reasonable excuse (4) This section does not limit the circumstances in which a person may have a reasonable excuse for contravening a child-related order. Burden of proof in relation to reasonable excuse Section 70NADA provides that a person who claims to have a reasonable excuse for contravening a child-related order has the legal burden of proving the excuse. Standard of proof Section 70NAE provides that the standard of proof to be applied in determining matters in proceedings under this Division (other than s 70NBF(1)(d) where the standard is beyond reasonable doubt for contra- ventions where a fine and imprisonment may be imposed) is proof on the balance of probabilities. Orders relating to contraventions of child-related orders Section 70NBA(1) which provides for the court’s power to make orders against a contravening respon- dent notes that the court does not need to find that the respondent contravened a child-related order to make certain orders. The court may make these orders at any stage of the proceedings: (a) a make-up time parenting order under s 70NBB; (b) an order varying or suspending a parenting order under s 70NBC; and (c) an order requiring the respondent and any other party to attend a post-separation parenting program under s 70NBD. Make-up time parenting orders “If a child does not spend time with a person as required by a child-related order as a result of the alleged contravention mentioned in [s] 70NBA(1), then, in lieu of that time, the court may make a … make-up time parenting order that the child spend time with the person: s 70NBB(1). Such an order may be made “at any stage of the proceedings”: subsection (2). Subsection (3) pro- vides that “[t]o avoid doubt, the amount of time specified
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of that time, the court may make a … make-up time parenting order that the child spend time with the person: s 70NBB(1). Such an order may be made “at any stage of the proceedings”: subsection (2). Subsection (3) pro- vides that “[t]o avoid doubt, the amount of time specified in the make-up time parenting order may be different from the amount of time that the child missed with the person as a result of the alleged contra- vention”. From 6 May 2024, registrars have delegated power to make such orders. Variation and suspension of child-related orders “The court may, at any stage of the proceedings, vary a child-related order … ”: s 70NBC(1). Subsection (2) provides that “[s]ubsection (1) does not limit the circumstances in which a court having jurisdiction under this Act may vary a child-related order … ” Subsection (3) provides for suspension of such orders. The Full Court in Irvin & Carr [2007] FamCA 492 agreed with Warnick J’s observations in Sandler & Kerrington [2007] FamCA 479 at [41]-[53] and statement at [48] that a variation (in that case under s 70NBA) “is to be approached no differently to any other application for parenting orders”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 80 Post-separation parenting programs “The court may, at any stage of the proceedings, make an order requiring the respondent and, if ap- propriate, one or more other parties to the proceedings, to attend a post-separation parenting program or other specified program.”: s 70NBD(1). Note 1: Before making an order under this section, the court must consider seeking the advice of a fam- ily consultant about the services appropriate to the party’s needs (see section 11E). Note 2: Things said, or admission made by, a person in a post-separation parenting program are generally not admissible in a court: see section 10PA. [Ed – The section excludes an adult’s admission and a child’s dis- closure of abuse or a risk of abuse unless there is sufficient evidence of same available from other sources.] (2) The court must advise the program’s provider of the making of the order as soon as reasonably practicable. (3) The provider of the program must inform the court, and any other party to the proceedings, if: (a) the provider considers that a person ordered to attend the program is unsuitable to attend the program; or (b) a person ordered to attend the program fails to attend the entire program, or any part of it. (4) The court may make any order (other than an order under paragraph 70NBF(1)(d)) that it considers appropriate if a person ordered to attend a program is considered as being unsuitable to attend the program, or fails to attend any part of the program. (5) If the court has found that the respondent has contravened the child-related order without having a reasonable excuse, then the court must take into account the seriousness of that contravention when making an order under subsection (4). Orders where contravention established without reasonable excuse Section
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: part of the program. (5) If the court has found that the respondent has contravened the child-related order without having a reasonable excuse, then the court must take into account the seriousness of that contravention when making an order under subsection (4). Orders where contravention established without reasonable excuse Section 70NBF(1) provides that [“i]f the court finds that the respondent has contravened a child-related order without having a reasonable excuse, the court may make any of the following orders: (a) an order requiring the respondent to enter into a bond in accordance with section 70NCA; (b) if an order is made under paragraph (a), and the respondent fails, without having a reasonable excuse, to enter into the bond—an order imposing a fine not exceeding 10 penalty units [PU] on the respondent [PU means $313 as at 1 July 2023, indexed 3-yearly under s 4AA of the Crimes Act 1914 (Cth)]; (c) where the contravention resulted in a child not spending time with, or living with, a person (the affected person) for a period—an order requiring the respondent to compensate the affected person for some or all of any expenses the affected person reasonably incurred as a result of the contravention; (d) where the court is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the respondent contravened the order: (i) an order imposing a fine not exceeding 60 penalty units; (ii) an order imposing a term of imprisonment. Note: For subparagraph (d)(ii), see subsection (4), subsection 70NCC(2) and section 70NCE for limits on how and when the court may impose a term of imprisonment on the respondent. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 81 Matters to be considered by the court (2) In making an order mentioned in subsection (1), the court must have regard to: (a) the likely effects of making the order on any child, or any other person; and (b) the seriousness of the contravention. (3) Without limiting the matters the court may take into account, the following matters must be taken into account by the court when having regard to the seriousness of the contravention: (a) whether a court has previously found that the respondent has contravened a child-related order without having a reasonable excuse; (b) whether the respondent behaved in a way that showed a serious disregard of the respondent’s obligations under the child-related order mentioned in subsection (1); (c) the behaviour of any person with whom the child is to live or spend time under the child-related order mentioned in subsection (1). (4) The court may sentence the respondent to imprisonment under subparagraph (1)(d)(ii) only if the court is satisfied that, in all the circumstances of the case, it would not be appropriate for the court to deal with the contravention in any other way under subsection (1). Matters relating to bonds Section 70NCA contains the matters dealt with in bonds and the duty to explain a bond and s 70NCB the procedure for enforcing bonds. Matters relating to imprisonment Section 70NCC contains limits on sentences of imprisonment, provides for good behavior bonds and the requirement that a court state its reasons why it is satisfied pursuant to s 70NBF(4). Section 70NCD contains the court’s powers to release an imprisoned respondent or suspend a sentence. In D & C (Imprisonment for Breach of Contact Orders) [2004] FamCA 814 at [12] Kay J said that “[t]he primary purpose of enforcement proceedings for non-compliance with an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: is satisfied pursuant to s 70NBF(4). Section 70NCD contains the court’s powers to release an imprisoned respondent or suspend a sentence. In D & C (Imprisonment for Breach of Contact Orders) [2004] FamCA 814 at [12] Kay J said that “[t]he primary purpose of enforcement proceedings for non-compliance with an order is to try to ensure compliance with the order”. Court may issue warrant for arrest of alleged offender Section 70NDA as to a warrant applies if the court is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the respondent has contravened the order on any of the three grounds mentioned in the table in s 70NAC(2) and a warrant is necessary to ensure that the respondent will attend court. Dealing with people who have been arrested The Family Law Amendment Act 2023 has inserted a subdivision in Division 14 that applies if a person is arrested under a warrant issued under subsection 70NDA(1) (warrants for arrest of persons alleged to have contravened a child-related order) or arrested without warrant under a recovery order: s 70PA. Further sections are as to an arrested person being brought before a court (s 70PB); obligation of the court where a contravention application is before it (s 70PC) or where no application is before it but a contravention application is before another court (s 70PD) or where no contravention application is before any court (s 70PE); and orders to be made upon any adjournment (s 70PF). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 82 Costs “A court may also award costs against a party under s 117 if satisfied there are circumstances that justify it doing so”: Note at s 70NAA (Simplified outline of the former Division 13A introduced by the Family Law Amendment Act 2023). For a review of the former Division 13A see Finn J’s judgment in McClintock & Levier [2009] FamCAFC 62 (FC). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 83 FAMILY CONSULTANTS Family consultants are social workers or psychologists contracted by the court to assist parties and the court once proceedings have been issued. Their primary function is to provide reports to the court under s 62G (and, at divorce hearings where necessary, under s 55A). See ss 11A to 11G. The court may require parties and children to see a family consultant (s 11F). Although one of their roles is to help parties resolve disputes, there is no confidentiality. Your clients should be advised that anything said to a family consultant may be reported. They will prepare reports (for interim and final hearings); and for final hearings be required for cross-examination. Family consultants may also be called on to supervise or assist compliance with parenting orders (s 65L) or to recommend that the parties attend a post-separation parenting program (s 65LA). Family reports Terms of reference for these reports should be the relevant considerations under s 60CC: Hardwick [2013] FCWA 57 at [36]-[38]. A family consultant may be directed under s 62G(2) to give the court a report on matters relevant to a child’s best interests. The section goes on to cover adjournments until the report is given and the requirement that the views of the child be ascertained (unless inappropriate). A child’s views may also be placed before the court through the child’s ICL (see “ICL” below). The report may be received in evidence under s 62G(8). For the procedure see FLR 8.11 (in WA, FCR 235). Family reports are usually prepared after the family consultant has had an opportunity to interview each of the parents individually and with the children, also the children individually, and any others significant to the children such as grandparents. Parties are entitled to access to a family consultant’s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: WA, FCR 235). Family reports are usually prepared after the family consultant has had an opportunity to interview each of the parents individually and with the children, also the children individually, and any others significant to the children such as grandparents. Parties are entitled to access to a family consultant’s notes but a court’s refusal of access is not necessarily appellable: Doherty [2014] FamCAFC 20 at [78]-[84]. The Full Court held in Hall [1979] FamCA 73 at [24]: (a) There is no magic in a family report. A court is not bound to accept it; (b) Reports are meant to be and usually are valuable material to assist the court in forming ultimate conclusions; (c) A counsellor does not usually have the same opportunity as the court to weigh the evidence, observe the demeanour of witnesses and make findings of fact; (d) A counsellor’s assessment of parties may be based on facts which turn out to be wrong or may be different from the court’s assessment after testing of the credit of the parties; (e) A report may be neutral, by concluding that a child’s best interests will be equally well (or ill) served by either party. Hall was applied in Summerby & Cadogen [2011] FamCAFC 205 at [118]-[119]. Note – A family consultant may be discharged if not seen to have been objective and independent: Gaines [2013] FMCAfam 108 at [13]-[23]. What to file? For the wording of your order for a family report, see “interim orders sought” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 84 INDEPENDENT CHILDREN’S LAWYER Court order for independent representation of child’s interests Section 68L applies to a case where a child’s best interests are, or a child’s welfare is, the paramount, or a relevant, consideration. This includes proceedings under regulations made for the purposes of s 111B (about the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction): s 68L(1). An independent children’s lawyer (“ICL”) is a court-appointed legally aided lawyer independently repre- senting a child’s interests in proceedings: s 68L(2). The child, an organisation concerned with the welfare of children or any other person may apply for such an order: s 68L(4). The court may (subject to subsection (6) as to the child’s age, maturity or some other special circumstance) make an order allowing the ICL to find out what the child’s views are: s 68L(5) (although a child may not be required to express a view: s 60CE). The Full Court in Re K [1994] FamCA 21 held that the criteria for such an appointment include the following: • Alleged child abuse • Neither party legally represented • Unsuitability of either parent • A parent’s sexual preferences • Intractable parental conflict • Special medical procedure for child • Proposal to remove child far away • Anti-social conduct of a parent • Alienation from a parent • Strong wish of mature child for change • Proposal to separate siblings • Medical or other disorder of parent • Cultural/religious differences Role of an independent children’s lawyer • Forms an independent view of what is in the child’s best interests, on the available evidence: s 68LA(2)(a) • Acts in what the ICL believes to the child’s best interests: s 68LA(2)(b) • Makes submissions for the court to act in a particular way in the best interests of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: • Forms an independent view of what is in the child’s best interests, on the available evidence: s 68LA(2)(a) • Acts in what the ICL believes to the child’s best interests: s 68LA(2)(b) • Makes submissions for the court to act in a particular way in the best interests of the child: s 68LA(2)(c) • Represents child’s interests (not child) so not obliged to follow child’s wishes: s 68LA(4) • May disclose information from child, even if against wishes: s 68LA(7)–(8) Requirement to meet with the child and give the child the opportunity to express their views This requirement applies to proceedings instituted on or after 6 May 2024 or beforehand where a final hearing has not commenced. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 85 (5A) Subject to subsection (5B), the independent children’s lawyer must perform the following duties (not necessarily at the same time): (a) meet with the child; (b) provide the child with an opportunity to express any views in relation to the matters to which the proceedings relate. Note: A person cannot require a child to express the child’s views in relation to any matter (see section 60CE). (5AA) The independent children’s lawyer has discretion in relation to the following matters (subject to any order or direction of the court with respect to the matter, for example under paragraph 68L(2)(b) or paragraph (5D)(b) of this section): (a) when, how often and how meetings with the child take place; (b) when, how often and how the child is provided with an opportunity to express views. (5B) The independent children’s lawyer is not required to perform a duty if: (a) the child is under 5 years of age; or (b) the child does not want to meet with the independent children’s lawyer, or express their views (as the case requires); or (c) there are exceptional circumstances that justify not performing the duty. (5C) Without limiting paragraph (5B)(c), exceptional circumstances for the purposes of that paragraph include that performing the duty, would: (a) expose the child to a risk of physical or psychological harm that cannot be safely managed; or (b) have a significant adverse effect on the wellbeing of the child. (5D) If the independent children’s lawyer proposes not to perform a duty because of paragraph (5B)(c), the court must do the following before making final orders: (a) determine whether it is satisfied that exceptional circumstances exist that justify not performing the duty; (b) if the court determines that those circumstances do not exist—make an order requiring the independent children’s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: perform a duty because of paragraph (5B)(c), the court must do the following before making final orders: (a) determine whether it is satisfied that exceptional circumstances exist that justify not performing the duty; (b) if the court determines that those circumstances do not exist—make an order requiring the independent children’s lawyer to meet with the child or provide the child with an opportunity to express their views (as the case requires). Note: The court may also make such other orders it considers necessary to secure the independent representation of the child’s interests (see paragraph 68L(2)(b)). Courts’ guidelines for independent children’s lawyers The FCFCA’s guidelines for ICLs are available here and from our online Members’ Archive (“useful papers”) and are summarised in Somers & Chubb [2012] FMCAfam 480 at [12]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
