chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 86 Disclosure of information An ICL may disclose to the court any information a child communicates to the ICL if the ICL considers the disclosure to be in the best interests of the child: s 68LA(7) (even if the disclosure is made against the wishes of the child: s 68LA(8)). Order that child be made available for examination The court may, on application by the ICL, order a parent or other person who has parental responsibility to make a child available for an examination for the purpose of preparing a report about the child for use by the ICL: s 68M. Removal of an independent children’s lawyer Kemp FM in Somers & Chubb (above) at [13]-[17] reviewed case law as to whether and in what circum- stances an ICL should be removed. In Baker & Borthwick and Ors [2010] FamCA 1018 Ryan J criticised the ICL for “aggressively pursuing” a particular finding (unacceptable risk of sexual abuse of child) “without considering [other key evi- dence]”, ultimately finding that some of the material relied on by the ICL “had little or no forensic value”. In Kingley & Arndale (No. 2) [2010] FamCA 968 where bias was alleged against an ICL, O’Reilly J discussed the role of an ICL and dismissed the allegation, saying at [31]: “It is fundamental … that even in cases of alleged apprehended bias, some actual conduct of the person sought to be impugned be identified, and that there be a finding that such conduct, in the view of the objective bystander, realistically could give rise to the opinion that the person is not impartial.” In Fisher [2021] FamCA 236 it was held that an ICL’s failure to properly respond to reasonable enquiries made by a self-represented litigant does not warrant the ICL’s removal.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: conduct, in the view of the objective bystander, realistically could give rise to the opinion that the person is not impartial.” In Fisher [2021] FamCA 236 it was held that an ICL’s failure to properly respond to reasonable enquiries made by a self-represented litigant does not warrant the ICL’s removal. What to file? For the wording of your order for the appointment of an independent children’s lawyer, see “interim orders sought” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 87 PROCEDURE FOR CHILD MATTERS Parties must first have complied with the pre-action procedure summarised in the prescribed bro- chure Before you file – pre-action procedure for parenting cases. Which court? After the pre-action procedures have been completed (unless FLR 4.01(3) or, in WA, FCR 22 ap- plies), a parenting proceeding is filed in the FCFCA or, in WA, the FCWA. In both Courts e-filing is compulsory via: • the Commonwealth Courts Portal • the eCourts Portal of Western Australia When an Initiating Application is filed in the FCFCA, it will be listed before Division 1 or Division 2 (the old FCC) at or before the first court event. The Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management (below) made on 1 September 2021 applies to FCFCA parenting applications filed before or after that date. Allocation between Divisions is discretionary, the Court to have regard to complexity or importance; any international issues; multiple parties or experts; length of case; the Divisions’ workload; impact on litigants of a transfer; any serious criminal conduct; or other reason for referral to a specialist list. Also see Family Law Practice Direction – Parenting proceedings made on 1 September 2021 and the FCWA’s Case Management Guidelines. Both parties 1. Before starting a parenting case, both parties must comply with the pre-action procedures in Schedule 1 FLR (FCR in WA) (see below), unless FLR 4.01(3) (or FCR 22(2)) applies (the case is urgent; involves allegations of child abuse or family violence (or a risk thereof); or there has been a previous parenting case in the previous 12 months. 2. Those procedures include the requirement that both parties make a genuine effort to resolve the matter by attending family dispute resolution pursuant to s 60I FLA, unless s 60I(9) applies. 3. Give your client:
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: risk thereof); or there has been a previous parenting case in the previous 12 months. 2. Those procedures include the requirement that both parties make a genuine effort to resolve the matter by attending family dispute resolution pursuant to s 60I FLA, unless s 60I(9) applies. 3. Give your client: • Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management Explain to your client that these brochures will summarise how the court works; its reconciliation counselling service; how their matter should begin with joint family counselling (see “family coun- selling” above) and family dispute resolution (“FDR”) (see above). Also explain that within 5 months of filing the parties will be referred again to mediation (and/or arbitration if they agree) (see “dispute resolution event” below). 4. Refer any client who is taking the separation badly to their own family counsellor for individual counselling beforehand, to talk through feelings that may be blocking their acceptance of the marital breakdown and readiness to discuss arrangements for the children. 5. See “child abuse or family violence” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 88 Applicants 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9): • Make an appointment for your client to attend FDR alone, briefing the FDR provider as to the FDR exception that may apply (e.g. your client has come to the appointment alone due to concern for her safety due to other party’s propensity for intimidation) whereupon an FDR certificate is likely to issue (under s 60I(8)(aa) as to FDR not being appropriate). Pre-action steps may be waived under FLR 4.01(3) (urgency, violence or abuse, or previous application within the past 12 months) (in WA, FCR 22). Note – If neither party attends, an affidavit will have to be filed under s 60J. • Once an FDR certificate issues, you may issue proceedings (filing the FDR certificate with your Application and waiving the pre-action procedure below). Now go to 8. 7. If no FDR exception applies: • Write to the other party or their lawyer proposing: – “without prejudice” the terms of a consent order; or – that the parties jointly attend a family dispute resolution practitioner. (For a sample FDR letter, see “letters” under “precedents” below. If the matter settles, FDR is not required.); or – that they attend a conference with their lawyers to discuss a possible settlement. • If the appointment with an FDR practitioner is not kept by the other party, your client is likely to be given an FDR certificate of non-attendance of the other party (under s 60I(8)(a)); or • If both parties attend, an FDR certificate will issue to the effect that a genuine effort to resolve issues was either made (para (b) of s 60I(8) or not made (para (c)). 8. Once the certificate is obtained, send a pre-action procedure letter to the other
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: s 60I(8)(a)); or • If both parties attend, an FDR certificate will issue to the effect that a genuine effort to resolve issues was either made (para (b) of s 60I(8) or not made (para (c)). 8. Once the certificate is obtained, send a pre-action procedure letter to the other party or their lawyer, for a sample of which go to “letters” under “precedents” below (setting out prescribed matters and attaching the required brochure/s). Note – If the case does not settle after pre-action procedures go to 9. 9. You can now issue proceedings: • Obtain from your client the details needed to complete an Initiating Application; a Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk; an Undertaking as to Disclosure (FLR 6.02; in WA, FCR 211); and a Genuine Steps Certificate: see “forms” and “precedents” below. A Parenting Questionnaire must be filed if no interim orders are sought. • In WA, your client is to complete an Initiating Application and a case information affidavit (FCR 27 FCR). A Notice of Child Abuse and Family Violence (or risk) – Form 4 is to be filed only if there are allegations of child abuse, family violence or a risk thereof. • File the FDR certificate with your Application. If no type of FDR certificate is available, then you either need to include content to support a s 60I(9) exception (see above) in your client’s affidavit in support, or if no interim orders are sought, file an “Affidavit – Non-filing of a Family Dispute Resolution Certificate” (“forms”). See the precedent below. Note – This affidavit is a nuisance. Avoid having to file it by ensuring that some kind of FDR certificate is obtained from the counsellor (and filed with your papers). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 89 • In the FCFCA, only file an affidavit if interim orders are sought, limited to 25 pages and 10 an- nexures (Div 1) and 10 pages and 5 annexures (Div 2) (FLR 5.08(2)). In WA, affidavits for interim orders in a parenting case require leave (para 5 of the FCWA’s Case Management Guidelines).” Note – There is no need to file a Parenting Questionnaire if an affidavit is required to be filed. • Hand up at the first hearing an Acknowledgement – Information from a Family Counsellor or FDR practitioner (see “forms” under “applicants” below). 10. A Reply, or in WA, a Reply to Response to Initiating Application, should be filed and served by an applicant if the respondent applies for orders in a cause of action not brought in the initi- ating application (e.g. if the applicant seeks financial orders only and the respondent applies for parenting orders as well). Respondents 1. After 1-4 (“both parties” above) arrange for your client to attend FDR (or not to attend if a likely exception applies, e.g. safety, informing the FDR provider of that). 2. After the issue of an FDR certificate, take instructions from your client for a letter in reply to the applicant’s pre-action procedure letter. 3. If proceedings have been filed by the other party: • If the applicant has not complied with pre-action procedures, your client is entitled to raise this at the first hearing and argue for their costs (or a stay pursuant to FLR 4.04(1)). • Instructions should be obtained in sufficient detail for completion of a Response to Initiating Application and, if no interim orders are sought, a Parenting Questionnaire (FLR 8.09); a Genuine Steps Certificate; and a supporting affidavit (only to be filed if interim orders are sought in either
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: to FLR 4.04(1)). • Instructions should be obtained in sufficient detail for completion of a Response to Initiating Application and, if no interim orders are sought, a Parenting Questionnaire (FLR 8.09); a Genuine Steps Certificate; and a supporting affidavit (only to be filed if interim orders are sought in either the Initiating Application or the Response). Note – A Response must be filed and served within 28 days of service of the application to which it re- lates: FLR 2.18(2) (or, in WA, at least 7 days before the hearing to which the Response relates: FCR 153). Child abuse or family violence In the FCFCA a Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk must be filed by any party seek- ing parenting orders whether risk is alleged or not. In the FCWA if a risk of harm is alleged file a Form 4 and include an order for supervision. And in both courts an affidavit with evi- dence of any such alleged fact. See “procedure for allegations of abuse or family violence” under “determining child’s best interests” above. See also “subpoenas” in Chapter 8 for production of corroborative police or welfare documents. All registries of the FCFCA have a specialist list for “parenting only” cases, called “the Light- house Project” to identify and case manage risk of harm, moving any high risk cases to the “Evatt List”. Family Law Practice Direction – Evatt List is here. If a s 60I certificate is not filed due to a s 60I(9) exception, include evidence in your client’s affidavit in support of the exception, but if no affidavit is to be filed (i.e. only final orders are sought), file an Affidavit – Non-Filing of Family Dispute Resolution Certificate. See the precedent below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 90 Change of venue See the factors set out in FLR 9.01 (in WA, FCR 186,187) and Romano & June [2010] FamCA 1027 at [72]-[132] for a discussion of those factors. Urgent listing For urgent cases, seek an interim order “that the application be heard on an urgent basis and that all times for service be abridged”, explaining the urgency in your covering letter to the registry. In Myers [2011] FMCAfam 1104 at [87] Halligan FM held that a case should be listed urgently if the Registrar is satisfied as to a reasonably arguable case; prejudice beyond the norm in the absence of an urgent listing; no unreasonable or unexplained delay; and a judicial officer being available to hear the application. It was held in Ghorbani & Saeed [2013] FamCAFC 167 at [16]-[25] that a recovery application must be heard immediately or listed urgently. Review of registrar’s order A registrar’s powers are set out in FLR 14.04 and Schedule 4 FLR (in WA, FCR 321). For an appli- cation for review of a registrar’s order e.g. refusal to list urgently, see Hathaway [2012] FMCAfam 1447. File an Application for Review (no affidavit). It will be listed as a hearing de novo. Duty of disclosure Parties must disclose relevant documents, e.g. criminal records, filed AVO documents, medical reports, school reports (FLR 6.05; in WA, FCR 197) and an expert’s report (FLR 7.14). Expert witnesses Family reports under s 62G FLA are governed by FLR 8.11 (in WA, FCR 235). For expert evidence as to a significant issue in dispute, see Chapter 7 FLR (in WA, Div 5 of Part 15 FCR). First court event In WA, the first hearing is to be within 42 days after the case starts (see FCWA procedures at Case Management Guidelines). The
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: FCR 235). For expert evidence as to a significant issue in dispute, see Chapter 7 FLR (in WA, Div 5 of Part 15 FCR). First court event In WA, the first hearing is to be within 42 days after the case starts (see FCWA procedures at Case Management Guidelines). The Court will consider any need for urgent or interim orders and case management directions, e.g. for a family report or Case Assessment Conference. In the FCFCA, see Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management (“CPD”). The timeframe is within 1-2 months for directions by a Judicial Registrar. Before that event, each lawyer must provide to the court and each party notice that their client has made a genuine attempt to resolve issues in dispute; of the costs paid and anticipated; likely duration of final hearing and costs thereto; of whether a party is legally aided; and of whether the parties have agreed to privately fund the cost of any expert report and dispute resolution. The Court will make any orders by consent; list any interim hearing; direct any parties who have not complied with the pre-action procedures to do so; identify the issues in dispute and the steps required to resolve them; consider whether the case is suitable for court-based dispute resolution, having regard to the means and resources of the parties, or whether it is suitable for referral to ex- ternal dispute resolution (or, with the consent of the parties, arbitration); consider whether the case Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 91 requires individual case management or is so urgent or exceptional that it requires immediate transfer to a judge or Senior Judicial Registrar; and make orders e.g. for future listings, prepara- tion of expert reports, subpoena issuing and exchange of documents. The Court will also consider whether an ICL should be appointed; and whether a written or oral family report should be obtained from a social scientist, psychologist, psychiatrist or other expert e.g. a Child Impact Report from a Court Child Expert: FLR 8.11 (in WA, FCR 235). Interim hearings Applications for interim orders will be listed at the first court event having regard to urgency and the need for any report. Before applying, parties must make a genuine attempt to arrive at consent orders (FLR 4.03; in WA, FCR 79). Not less than 2 business days before an interim hearing, the parties must forward to the associate of the judge or Senior Judicial Registrar a minute of orders sought and an Outline of Case Document (Interim Hearing). An interim hearing proceeds on the papers (without oral evidence or cross-examination). Parties may only file up to 2 Applications in a Proceeding without leave, unless an urgent “high risk” matter: para 5.22 CPD. Dispute resolution event Within 5 months of filing in the FCFCA, the parties will be referred to a privately funded mediation (if they can afford it) (and/or arbitration, if they agree) OR court-based dispute resolution such as a Conciliation Conference, a Judicial Settlement Conference or FDR Conference with a Judicial Registrar (as an FDR provider) or a Court Child Expert (as a family counsellor) – at which lawyers will be expected to identify the disputed issues and the relevant evidence (para 5 CPD). Parties must exchange any FLR 6.05 documents by 14 days before the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: FDR Conference with a Judicial Registrar (as an FDR provider) or a Court Child Expert (as a family counsellor) – at which lawyers will be expected to identify the disputed issues and the relevant evidence (para 5 CPD). Parties must exchange any FLR 6.05 documents by 14 days before the dispute resolution event and give a Confidential Case Outline Document (Dispute Resolution) to the mediator and parties 7 days beforehand, with a Certificate of Dispute Resolution for completion by the mediator. In WA, a Conciliation Conference is listed (paras 17 & 21 CMG). Form NP9 Conciliation Con- ference Particulars is to be filed and served by 14 days before the Conference: FCR 190, 191. After the dispute resolution event If the case does not settle, the Court at a compliance and readiness hearing (within 6 months of filing if possible) will assess whether the parties have complied with all orders; explore whether genu- ine efforts to resolve the matter have been exhausted and, if so, make directions for a final hearing (and for the parties to file evidence they wish to rely on at that hearing). Parties must file and serve a Certificate of Readiness by 7 days before that hearing. A trial management hearing may be listed, to ensure that the case is ready to proceed to trial. Trial directions and final hearing For any final hearing, the CPD contains standard trial directions that include an exchange of any amended application or response; a consolidated trial affidavit and financial statement; the filing of an Outline of Case Document (Final Hearing) by 2 days before trial; and a list of authorities. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 6. Attend to steps 1–4. If any FDR exception applies under s 90I(9):

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 93 COURT FORMS Forms for use in the FCWA See our link to the FCWA forms here at our eBook and at our online members’ Practice News (“FCWA”). The following are the forms of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia. Applicants • Initiating Application (Family Law) Insert the interim and final orders from “interim orders sought” and “final orders sought” in “prec- edents” below. An interim order not sought in an Initiating Application may be sought by filing an Application in a Proceeding (below) and an affidavit explaining why the interim order is sought. A birth certificate is no longer required to be filed with an Initiating Application. • Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk This form must be filed with an Initiating Application or Response seeking parenting orders whether risk is alleged or not (and if risk is alleged your affidavit should include the facts relied on). The form is here at our eBook and at our online “forms and precedents”. The FCWA has its own Form 4 as per “FCWA forms” above, to be filed if such an allegation is made. In both courts any relevant family violence order is to be filed too. • Affidavit An affidavit should not be filed until you are directed to do so except in support of an interim ap- plication. See “precedents” below for sample affidavit of applicant both for interim and for final hearings. If seeking final orders only, use the precedent below for an “affidavit for final order”. If seeking interim and final orders use the affidavit for the interim orders (filing an affidavit for final orders later). • Certificate of Dispute Resolution This is obtained from the parties’ FDR provider. If you are unable to obtain an FDR certificate from the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: for an “affidavit for final order”. If seeking interim and final orders use the affidavit for the interim orders (filing an affidavit for final orders later). • Certificate of Dispute Resolution This is obtained from the parties’ FDR provider. If you are unable to obtain an FDR certificate from the FDR provider you must file Affidavit – Non-filing of a Family Dispute Resolution Certificate • Acknowledgement – Information from a Family Counsellor or Family Dispute Resolution Practitioner (if abuse or violence is alleged). To be handed up at the first hearing. • Genuine Steps Certificate as to compliance with the pre-action procedures of Schedule 1 FLR. • Parenting Questionnaire – not required to be filed if an affidavit is filed with the application. • Undertaking as to Disclosure Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 94 • Subpoena Sample subpoenas (to hospital, welfare and police) are at Chapter 8. • Pay filing fee by credit card when lodging on the Commonwealth Courts Portal (or eCourts Portal of WA) or complete (if required): Application for exemption from fees – general (card holders and other categories) Application for exemption from fees – financial hardship • Swear and file the documents via the Commonwealth Courts Portal. (Also see Portal Navigation.) Upon allocation of a date for the first court event, serve the documents including court brochures and notices no later than 3 days before an interim and 7 days before a final hearing. In WA, filing is required via the eCourts Portal of WA. • Personally serve your papers on a party (where not served on a lawyer by arrangement) and prove service by filing process server’s Affidavit of Service with Acknowledgment of Service attached. Experienced process servers will have their own supply of these forms and be able to supply you with a sworn affidavit for filing. • A Reply should be filed and served by an applicant if the respondent applies for orders in a cause of action not brought in the initiating application (e.g. if the applicant seeks parenting orders only and the respondent applies for financial orders as well as parenting orders). Respondents • Response to Initiating Application (or Submitting Notice if the orders sought by the applicant are agreed). (See “Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk” under “Applicants” above.) • Affidavit (see opposite) Only file one when directed unless it is in support of an interim application. • Acknowledgment – Information from a Family Counsellor or Family Dispute Resolution Practitioner (see this item under “applicants” above) • Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk; Genuine Steps
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: “Applicants” above.) • Affidavit (see opposite) Only file one when directed unless it is in support of an interim application. • Acknowledgment – Information from a Family Counsellor or Family Dispute Resolution Practitioner (see this item under “applicants” above) • Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk; Genuine Steps Certificate; and Undertaking as to Disclosure. A Parenting Questionnaire is only filed if no affidavit is filed with the Response. • File with fee or apply for fee reduction as above. Serve your court papers within 28 days at the ap- plicant’s address for service specified in the Initiating Application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 95 Both parties Undertaking An undertaking is commonly sought from a party at an interim hearing as part of a negotiated consent to interim parenting orders where there are concerns that the party while caring for a child may not keep the peace, may consume alcohol to excess, take illicit drugs, not secure the child in a proper seat restraint or may compromise the child in some other way. Mutual undertakings, such as to keep the peace towards each other, may also be appropriate. Under- takings are usually drawn up informally at court. Sample text is at our online “forms & precedents”. Consent orders The terms of any settlement may be documented as a consent order, signed by the parties and filed in the court. For these terms, see “interim orders sought” and “final orders sought” below. For precedent cover sheets, see “consent orders” in the chapter “other routine procedures”. Later interim applications Interim orders (if not sought in the Initiating Application) “(IA)” may be sought after an IA has been filed, by filing an Application in a Proceeding and an affidavit in support. Respondents must file a Response to an Application in a Proceeding and an affidavit replying to each paragraph of the applicant’s affidavit. Amended applications Any new orders may be sought after an IA as “Amended Initiating Application” showing the new orders sought underlined in red, and “amended” appearing wherever “initiating application” is mentioned). No filing fee is payable. An affidavit setting out the facts relied on for the new orders sought can be contained in an affidavit filed before the final hearing, unless your new orders sought are interim in which case you would have to file another affidavit prior to the interim hearing. While, strictly, leave is required if the amendment is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: facts relied on for the new orders sought can be contained in an affidavit filed before the final hearing, unless your new orders sought are interim in which case you would have to file another affidavit prior to the interim hearing. While, strictly, leave is required if the amendment is being sought after the first court date or procedural hearing (FLR 2.50, FCR 182), the prac- tice is to file an amendment without leave but seek leave at the next return either formally or if the other side is taking an objection. Need a different court form? The forms are available here and at our website. See “affidavit” under “applicants” above. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 96 COURT FEES (for both courts unless otherwise stated) • Application for Consent Orders $200 • Initiating Application (parenting or financial, final only) $425 • Initiating Application (parenting or financial, final and interim) $570 • Initiating Application (parenting and financial, final only) $695 • Initiating Application (parenting and financial, final and interim) $840 • Response to Initiating Application $425 • Application in a Proceeding $145 • Setting down for final hearing (FCFCA Div 1 and FCWA) $1,045 • Daily hearing fee (excluding first day) (FCFCA Div 1 and FCWA) $1,045 • Setting down for final hearing (FCFCA Div 2 and magistrate FCWA) $770 • Daily hearing fee (excluding first day) (FCFCA Div 2 and magistrate FCWA) $770 • Conciliation conference $480 • Subpoena $65 • Application to register a NZ judgment under the Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010 (Cth) (TTPA) (FCFCA) $130 • Application under TTPA (FCFCA) $145 Note – From 1 January 2013, an application for reduction of fee will only be available for divorce applications: see Chapter 3 (“procedure for divorce applications”). As to the court fees above, an “application for exemption from fees – general” or “application for exemption from fees – financial hardship” (see “court forms” above for both forms) may be lodged on behalf of card holders (and other categories) and those claiming financial hardship respectively. ICLs please note that you are exempt from the interim application fee and the subpoena fee. Note – These fees are current and are now increased annually on 1 July every year. See FL(Fees) Reg. See “court fees” for FCFCA and FCWA. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 97 PRECEDENTS Online precedents The following precedents are set out in full below in hard copy and are also available online at our website. LETTERS Family dispute resolution letter (to other party or their lawyer) We have been retained by [insert client name] in regard to parenting issues. At this stage, we have recommended to our client that [you both/the parties] discuss arrangements for the [child/children] with the assistance of a Family Dispute Resolution (FDR) practitioner. We find that better progress is usually made at the early stage of a separation by not involving lawyers until after the parties have discussed child issues informally with an FDR person. We have given our client the name of an experienced FDR provider who would be available, namely [insert FDR provider’s name, address and telephone number/s]. Any agreement reached during FDR can be documented and filed in the court as a joint application for binding consent orders. Although FDR is compulsory, would you please confirm that you agree to attending, and let us know of any preferred times. An appointment would then be made for FDR to occur at a convenient time. We suggest the FDR provider’s fee be shared equally, unless for some reason it is not reasonable for the fee to be shared. We look forward to hearing from you soon. Yours faithfully, Note Send a copy of this letter to your client for their information. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 98 Pre-action procedure letter (to other party or their lawyer) (FCFCA and FCWA) We enclose for your attention: 1. [Where parenting orders are being sought] Copy brochure “Before You File – Pre-Action Procedure for Parenting Cases” 2. [Where financial orders are also being sought] Copy brochure “Before you File – Pre-Action Procedure for Financial Cases” This letter is required by the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021 [in WA, the Family Court Rules 2021] to be sent before the issue of proceedings. [Delete this sentence if no parenting orders are being sought.] As family dispute resolution has either been attended by the parties or declined by one or both of them and the parenting dispute remains unresolved, our client intends to begin court proceedings. The issues in dispute [Set out issues in dispute] The court orders to be sought [Set out the orders to be sought – for interim and final orders, see “precedents” below] Genuine offer by our client to resolve the issues [Set out your/your client’s proposal to resolve the matter] Nominated time We nominate 14 days from the date of this letter within which we require you to reply. You should state in your reply whether our client’s offer is accepted. If it is, then we can prepare an Application for Consent Orders. If not, you are required to set out: • The issues in dispute; • The court orders you/your client seek(s); • Your/your client’s genuine counter-offer to resolve the issues; • Your nominated time for our reply (at least 14 days from your reply). If you do not respond within 14 days, we will be free to issue proceedings without further notice. Yours faithfully, Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 99 INTERIM ORDERS Interim orders – to apply until the final hearing – may be sought by an applicant in an Initiating Application (or, for later applications, Application in a Proceeding) or by a respondent in a Response to Initiating Application (or Response to Application in a Proceeding) (“forms” above). For any interim financial orders, simply add them at the end of the parenting orders sought. Note – In an urgent case, file your papers with an FDR certificate as to FDR being inappropriate and a covering letter to the Registrar explaining the urgency, and seek an urgent appointment. Interim parenting orders 1. That until further order, [insert those paras of the “final orders sought” below that your client will be needing before the final hearing. These will include an order “until further order” as to where the child is to live; the time to be spent with the other parent; parental responsibility; changeover arrangements; and any special days and holidays that are likely to precede the final hearing]. (Family report) 2. That pursuant to Section 62G of the Family Law Act [insert name of proposed report writer] be appointed to prepare a family report in relation to [insert any specific issues to be addressed – e.g. wishes of the children as to the time they wish to spend with each parent; alleged parental alienation and if parental alienation has occurred, and the impact that such alienation has had on the children, and recommended treatment; as to the children’s relationship with each parent]. 3. Each party pay one half of the costs of the family report, upon demand. (If seeking the appointment of an independent children’s lawyer) 4. That the [child/children] be independently represented in these proceedings and it is requested that Legal Aid [insert State/Territory] arrange
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the children’s relationship with each parent]. 3. Each party pay one half of the costs of the family report, upon demand. (If seeking the appointment of an independent children’s lawyer) 4. That the [child/children] be independently represented in these proceedings and it is requested that Legal Aid [insert State/Territory] arrange such representation, and that the independent children’s lawyer be at liberty to peruse and/or take copies of all documents filed in these proceedings upon the making of an appointment to do so with the Court Registry. (Recovery order) 5. That the application for interim orders filed the [date of filing] be heard urgently and that all times for service be abridged. 6. That this recovery order made pursuant to Section 67U of the Family Law Act 1975 is addressed to the Marshal of the Court, all officers of the Australian Federal Police and all officers of the State and Territory police services. 7. That the persons to whom this recovery order is addressed are authorised and directed to find, recover and deliver the [child/children] [insert full name] to the [Mother/Father], namely [insert full name] or a person nominated by [his/her] in writing, and for that purpose to stop and search any vehicle, vessel or aircraft and to enter and search any premises or place in which there is or was reasonable cause to believe that the [child/children] may be found. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 100 8. That the [Father/Mother], [his/her] servants or agents, be and are hereby restrained from again removing or causing the removal of the [child/children] from the care of the [Mother/Father], upon any breach of which injunction the persons to whom this recovery order is addressed are autho- rised and directed to arrest the [Father/Mother] without a warrant. 9. This recovery order will remain in force for 12 months. 10. That the [Father/Mother] pay the [Mother’s/Father’s] costs of and incidental to this application fixed in the sum of $5,000. 11. That the [Father/Mother] be served with a copy of the applicant’s application and affidavit[s] filed [date] and a copy of this order. 12. That the parenting order made by [this/the] [specify] Court on [date] be suspended as to its provision for the [child/children] to spend time with the [Father/Mother] until further order upon application being made by the [Father/Mother] for a parenting order in [his/her] favour. 13. That this matter be adjourned for further hearing on [date and time]. (Injunction – unilateral relocation within Australia) 14. That no later than [date and time] the [father/mother] [insert full name] return the [child/children] to the [child’s/children’s] former address at [specify] or to live within 20 kilometres of that address. 15. That the [father/mother] forthwith upon [his/her] return re-enrol the [child/children] at [specify] School. 16. That until further order [Insert paragraph 1 above and any other paragraphs of “final orders sought” below that your client will be needing upon return of child/children as interim orders]. 17. That the respondent pay the applicant’s costs of and incidental to this application fixed in the sum of $5,000. 18. That the matter be adjourned for further hearing on [date and time]. (Injunction – where flight risk) 19. [Within Australia] That until further order
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 8. That the [Father/Mother], [his/her] servants or agents, be and are hereby restrained from again

chunks.text: of child/children as interim orders]. 17. That the respondent pay the applicant’s costs of and incidental to this application fixed in the sum of $5,000. 18. That the matter be adjourned for further hearing on [date and time]. (Injunction – where flight risk) 19. [Within Australia] That until further order the [Father/Mother] [insert full name], and [his/her] servants or agents, be and are hereby restrained from removing or causing the removal of the [child/children] [insert full name/s] from their current address at [specify] OR beyond a radius of 20 kilometres from [specify CBD, post office or other local landmark]. (Watch List order) 20. That until further order the [Father/Mother] [full name and date of birth], and [his/her] servants or agents be and are hereby restrained from removing or attempting to remove or causing or permitting the removal of the [child/children] from the Commonwealth of Australia AND IT IS REQUESTED that the Australian Federal Police give effect to this order by placing the [name/ names] of the said [child/children] on the Watch List in force at all points of arrival and departure by air or sea in the Commonwealth of Australia and maintain the [child’s/children’s] [name/ names] on the Watch List until the Court orders its removal. Note – Where the child has no passport but the other party might apply for one without your client’s consent see “child alert request” under “abduction and recovery of children”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 101 (Location order) 21. That pursuant to Section 67M of the Family Law Act 1975 Centrelink provide to the Registry Manager of this Registry of the Court such information as is contained in the records of Centrelink about the location of the [child/children], [full name/names] born [date] and the [mother/father] [insert full name], being a person whom the Court has reasonable cause to believe has the child. 22. That for the purpose of this order “information” includes the name of payee, financial institution, and name and number of account to whom and into which any payment by Centrelink is made in respect of the child or the [mother/father] or any other person with whom its records suggest the child may be. 23. That pursuant to Section 67P(1) of the Act the Registry Manager is granted leave to disclose infor- mation provided pursuant to this order to the lawyers for the [mother/father] being [insert lawyer’s name] at [address]; to a process server engaged by those lawyers in these proceedings; and the persons to whom the recovery order in these proceedings concerning the child are addressed. 24. This location order will remain in force for 12 months. (Commonwealth information order) 25. That, pursuant to Section 67N of the Family Law Act 1975 Centrelink provide to the Registry Manager of this Registry of the Court such information as is contained in or comes into the records of Centrelink about the location of the [child/children], [full name/names] born [date] and the [mother/father] [insert full name], being a person whom the Court has reasonable cause to believe has the child. 26. That for the purpose of this order “information” includes the name of payee, financial institution, and name and number of account to whom and into which any payment by Centrelink is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 21. That pursuant to Section 67M of the Family Law Act 1975 Centrelink provide to the Registry

chunks.text: [mother/father] [insert full name], being a person whom the Court has reasonable cause to believe has the child. 26. That for the purpose of this order “information” includes the name of payee, financial institution, and name and number of account to whom and into which any payment by Centrelink is made in respect of the child or the [mother/father] or any other person with whom its records suggest the child may be. 27. That the records to which this order applies shall include records that are up to 2 years old of the date of this order, records to be searched within 14 days and then at least once every 3 months and the Registrar Manager of this Court is to be notified of the result of each search within 7 days after each search. 28. This Commonwealth information order will remain in force for 12 months. 29. That pursuant to Section 67P(1) of the Act the Registry Manager is granted leave to disclose infor- mation provided pursuant to this order to the lawyers for the [mother/father] being [insert lawyer’s name] at [address]; to a process server engaged by those lawyers in these proceedings; and the persons to whom the recovery order in these proceedings concerning the child are addressed. Note – This order will not be made unless at least 7 days beforehand you have served a copy of your application on Centrelink: s 67N(3). Information can also be sought as to actual or threat- ened violence to the child, a person related to the child or a person who has a connection to the child: ss 67N(3), (9) and 67NA. (If seeking the drug testing of a party) 30. The [specify] [full name] [X] is restrained from using drugs of abuse. 31. Until [date] X is to submit

The [specify] [full name] [X] is restrained from using drugs of abuse. 31. Until [date] X is to submit to urinalysis and hair follicle tests for the detection of such drugs randomly at appointments made by the Applicant’s lawyers, not being more often than twice per month for urinalysis or once in every three months for hair follicle tests. chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 102 32. For the purpose of hair follicle tests, X shall not cut [his/her] hair shorter than 3 centimetres until the date specified in the preceding paragraph of this order. 33. Within 24 hours of the date of this order X obtain from a medical practitioner a referral to a pathologist for the conduct of such tests. 34. The tests be conducted at a laboratory accredited by the National Association of Testing Authori- ties, Australia in accordance with the current Australian Standard for the collection and detection of drugs of abuse. 35. X provide the pathologist with photographic identification, to be recorded before each test, and the authority to provide the results of each test to the Applicant’s lawyers and Respondent’s lawyers immediately upon its completion. 36. Each test shall be for the detection of amphetamine-type substances, cannabis, opiates (including heroin and morphine), sedative-type drugs, cocaine, chronic alcohol use and any other drugs of abuse. 37. The Applicant pay the cost of such tests (and the referral), except that X pay for any positive test. 38. In the event of a positive test or any breach of this order by X, X’s time with the [child/children] under this order is suspended until further order, each party in that event having liberty to apply at short notice. Note – Urinalysis detects use of drugs within the past 1-3 days whereas a hair follicle test can detect a pattern of drug use over several months (hair length determining the period of drug use). See the paper on drug testing at our online Members’ Archive. For an accredited lab, visit www.nata.com.au > facilities list by field > forensic science. For the wording of final orders see [8]-[18] of the orders made in Vokic & Vlass [2012] FamCA 56. (If

Note – Seeking this order is unusual, being kept for clear cases of mental or emotional disturbance. A mutual order is usually made where one party is wanting the other party to be examined. See Sewell & Jacobs [2011] FMCAfam 1377 for an assessment of parties and child. (Injunction for the protection of a child or party) 40. [Add injunction for protection as above, if necessary.] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 104 APPLICANT’S AFFIDAVIT – NON-FILING OF A FAMILY DISPUTE RESOLUTION CERTIFICATE (In case of risk of abuse) 1. I am the applicant Mother. 2. I have filed an urgent application seeking parenting orders such that the [child/children] spend supervised time with X pending the appointment of an independent children’s lawyer, family report and our obtaining psychiatric evaluations. 3. I have sought orders pertaining to psychiatric assessments as a result of my having witnessed: 3.1 [Set out evidence of violence or mentally erratic behaviour, whether any condition has been diagnosed, responses to prescribed medication etc.] 4. The [child/children] currently reside/s with me, and I will do everything possible to keep [him/her/ them] safe pending the Court’s determination as to their best interests. 5. In the meantime, while I do not wish to disrupt the bond between X and the [child/children], nor disrupt the [child/children]’s development, I am fearful as to X’s capacity to care for the [child/ children] on an unsupervised basis, and the environment the [child/children] would be exposed to while in his care. 6. On [date] I made an appointment to attend the [place] Family Relationship Centre. The first available date for an intake was [time] on [date]. 7. On [date] I spoke to [name] at the [place] Family Relationship Centre who informed me and I believe that it will be approximately [number] weeks following the intake before an appointment can be made for both parties to attend. 8. I telephoned the Court’s Registry today, [date] and was informed (and I believe) that the earliest available date I could expect if an application was filed today was [date]. 9. I infer from the above that if I attended the Family Relationship Centre and then applied to the Court, my Application would not be heard until

This course could leave the children in the position of not spending time with [name], or [name] not being medically assessed for longer than is absolutely necessary. 11. I do not want the [child/children] to be without the care of both of [his/her/their] parents for any longer than is necessary, and have therefore brought this Application. (In case of urgency) 1. I am the applicant. 2. I am applying for an order which will enable me to travel overseas with my [son/daughter] for a holiday, departing [place] airport on [date] and returning on [date]. 3. On [date] I spoke to [name] at the [place] Family Relationship Centre who informed me and I believe that it will be approximately [number] weeks following the intake before an appointment can be made for both parties to attend. I telephoned the Court’s Registry today, [date] and was informed (and I believe) that the earliest available date I could expect if an application was filed today was [date]. 6. I infer from the above that by the time I obtain a Family Dispute Resolution Certificate, it is unlikely that I will be able to obtain a hearing date which will allow me sufficient time to obtain a passport for my son/daughter prior to my intended departure date. UNDERTAKING [SURNAME OF PARTIES (written in capitals) followed by case number] I, [insert full name] of [address] undertake to the Court that: 1. I will keep the peace at all times towards [other party’s name]. 2. I will not consume alcohol to excess or take illicit drugs. 3. Whenever driving with the child I will ensure that the child is secured by a proper seat restraint. 4. [Insert any other undertakings you have been able to negotiate with the other party or obtain from the court]. I acknowledge that this undertaking has the same effect as an order of the Court and I agree to be bound by it until [specify expiry date, if any] or excused by the Court. DATED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– SIGNED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Note – If filing in the FCFCA or the FCWA use the form here at our eBook or at our online “forms & precedents”. A tip Undertakings are not enforceable as if they were court orders unless “given to and accepted by the court” under the definition of “order under this Act” in s 112AA(c). In Elia [2000] FamCA 1314 Mullane J held that an undertaking that was filed by lawyers five days after a hearing, when proceedings were no longer pending, did not come within that definition and was therefore not enforceable.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: court” under the definition of “order under this Act” in s 112AA(c). In Elia [2000] FamCA 1314 Mullane J held that an undertaking that was filed by lawyers five days after a hearing, when proceedings were no longer pending, did not come within that definition and was therefore not enforceable. An undertaking should therefore be handed up to the court during the hearing so that the court may both receive the undertaking and accept it, for the undertaking to be enforceable as an order of the court. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 106 FINAL ORDERS Final orders – to be made at the final hearing – may be sought by an applicant in an Initiating Application (or, for later applications, Application in a Proceeding) or by a respondent in a Response to Initiating Application (or Response to Application in a Proceeding) (“forms” above). For any interim financial orders, simply add them at the end of the parenting orders sought. Note – In an urgent case, file your papers with an FDR certificate as to FDR being inappropriate and a covering letter to the Registrar explaining the urgency, and seek an urgent appointment. Final parenting orders (If seeking joint decision-making) 1. That parental responsibility be allocated for joint decision-making by the parties about all major long-term issues in relation to the [child/children] [full name/names] born on [date/s]. 2. That the parties are not required to consult the other when making decisions while the [child/chil- dren] [full name/names] born on [dates of birth] [is/are] in their care under this order about issues that are not major long-term issues. (If seeking sole decision-making) 3. That parental responsibility be allocated for sole decision-making by the [Mother/Father] about all major long-term issues in relation to the [child/children] [full name/names] born on [date/s]. [OR specify the issues where sole decision-making is sought, adding a clause that for all other major long-term issues parental responsibility be allocated for joint decision-making.] 4. That the parties are not required to consult the other when making decisions while the [child/chil- dren] [full name/names] born on [dates of birth] [is/are] in their care under this order about issues that are not major long-term issues. (Equal time in seven-night blocks – where workable for both children and parents) 5. The [child/children] live with each party in each fortnight as follows:
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the [child/chil- dren] [full name/names] born on [dates of birth] [is/are] in their care under this order about issues that are not major long-term issues. The [child/children] live with each party in each fortnight as follows: 5.1 with the [Father/Mother] from 5.00 pm on Monday in the first week until 5.00 pm on Monday in the second week; 5.2 with the [Mother/Father] from 5.00 pm on Monday in the second week until 5.00 pm on Monday in the following week. (Equal time other than in seven-night blocks) 6. The [child/children] spend time with and/or live with each party at all times as may be agreed, but failing agreement, in each fortnight as follows: 6.1 with the Father: 6.1.1 from the end of school on Thursday in the first week, until the start of school on Monday in the second week; Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

That the [Father/Mother] spend time with the [child/children] at all times as may be agreed, but failing agreement, as follows: 8.1 from the conclusion of school on alternate Thursdays/Fridays, until the commencement of school the following Monday; 8.2 from the conclusion of school to 8.00 pm on the other Thursday, to include being there for the [child’s/children’s] [insert name of extracurricular activity] practice, a meal afterwards and homework supervision before return home. 8.3 every Tuesday from the conclusion of school to 8.00 pm on the other Thursday, to include being there for the [child’s/children’s] [insert name of extracurricular activity] practice, a meal afterwards and homework supervision before return home. That the [child/children] spend time with the [Father/Mother] as follows: 13.1 from 2.00 pm to 4.00 pm each Saturday, to be supervised by [insert name of supervisor, e.g. family counsellor or relative]; 13.2 each week

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 108 (School holidays) 14. That the [child/children] spend time with the Father for one half of all gazetted school holiday periods, being the first half in odd numbered years and in alternate years thereafter and the second half in even numbered years and in alternate years thereafter; and that any provision for time in this order that is inconsistent with school holiday time be suspended during gazetted school holiday periods. 15. That the [child/children] spend time with the Mother for one half of all gazetted school holiday periods, being the second half in odd numbered years and in alternate years thereafter and the first half in even numbered years and in alternate years thereafter; and that any provision for time in this order that is inconsistent with school holiday time be suspended during gazetted school holiday periods. 16. That in all even numbered years: 16.1 the [child/children] spend time with the Father from 12 noon Christmas Eve until 12 noon Christmas Day; and 16.2 that the [child/children] spend time with the Mother from 12 noon Christmas Day until 12 noon Boxing Day; 17. That in all odd numbered years: 17.1 the [child/children] spend time with the Mother from 12 noon Christmas Eve until 12 noon Christmas Day; and 17.2 the [child/children] spend time with the Father from 12 noon Christmas Day until 12 noon Boxing Day. (Special days) 18. That the [child/children] spend time with the Father from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm on Father’s Day and that any provision for time under this order that is inconsistent with this paragraph be suspended so as to facilitate time under this paragraph. 19. That the [child/children] spend time with the Mother from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm on Mother’s Day and that any provision under this order

(Specific issues) 23. That each party is hereby authorised to obtain from the [child’s/children’s] school/s all notices, letters, school reports and invitations and to attend parent/teacher interviews or other activities to which parents are invited. 24. That the [Father/Mother] and [child/children] communicate with each other by telephone on [days] at [times] and at such other times as may be agreed between the parties. 25. That the parties advise the other of any change of telephone number or residential address within 24 hours of such change occurring. 26. That the parties not criticise or denigrate the other party or the other party’s family in the presence of or within hearing of the [child/children]. 27. That the parties encourage and not undermine each child’s relationship with the other party. 28. Any other order as this Honourable Court sees fit. (Alternative dispute resolution) 29. In the event of any dispute as to the interpretation, implementation or enforcement of this order (including any claim by a party that it should be varied) the parties shall first attend family dispute resolution (FDR) with an FDR practitioner appointed by the parties and make a genuine attempt to resolve the dispute. Failing agreement as to that appointment the party raising the dispute shall nominate three FDR practitioners, one of whom shall be chosen by the other party within 14 days. chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 111 (Variation of parenting order) 1. That the order made by the [specify] Court on [date] be discharged [then, in separate paras, set out the new order sought]. [OR if your client only seeks a variation of a para or two] 1. That the order made by the [specify] Court on [date] be varied so as to delete paragraphs [specify para numbers sought to be deleted] and the following paragraph[s] be substituted in their place. [insert the new paras] (Paternity testing) Interim orders 1. That a parentage testing procedure be carried out on the parties and the child [child’s full name] born on [date of birth] under Section 69W(3) of the Family Law Act 1975 (“the Act”). 2. That the parentage testing procedure be carried out: 2.1 in accordance with Division 7 of Part 7 of the Family Law Regulations 2024; and 2.2 at a laboratory that is accredited by the National Association of Testing Laboratories, Australia for the purpose of carrying out parentage testing procedures; and 2.3 in accordance with standards of practice that entitle the laboratory to be so accredited. 3. That within 14 days after the date of this order the Respondent [insert full name] be and is hereby required under Section 69X(3) of the Act to provide a bodily sample for the purposes of the parentage testing procedure. 4. That the procedure be supplemented by a report under Regulation 21M. Final orders 1. A declaration of parentage under Section 69VA of the Act. 2. That if the Respondent is found to be the father of the child, the Respondent shall pay all of the costs in relation to the carrying out of the parentage testing procedure and preparation of the report and the Applicant’s costs incidental to these proceedings. Update 64 March 2025

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 113 (Permission for overseas relocation) Note – This sample is an edited version of the judgment of Dessau J in M & S (2006) FamCA 1408 (save that para 1 would provide for joint decision-making about major long-term issues to reflect the Family Law Amendment Act 2023), where the mother was allowed to move with a child of almost 7 to the UK for a limited time (3 years). 1. That the parties have equal shared parental responsibility for the child [name] born on [date]. 2. That the child lives with the Mother. 3. That the Mother be permitted to relocate with the child to the United Kingdom (“UK”) until [date]. 4. That the Mother cause the child to resume living in Australia no later than [date]. 5. That when the child lives in Australia the child spends time with the Father as follows: (a) [This is for the first 3 weeks after the Order] From [date] to [date]; (b) If the Mother has not relocated with the child on or before [a date seven weeks hence], from [date] to [date] [for a few days before due departure]; (c) For the first half of school holidays including Christmas Day in even numbered years and the second half in odd numbered years, except that in the [specify mid year] holiday the Father have the first 10 days in even number years and the last 10 days in odd numbered years; and (d) On three weekends during every [State/Territory] school term as follows: (i) From Friday to Sunday in [specify place] on one weekend; (ii) From Thursday to Sunday, or Friday to Monday, in [place] on one weekend (any school day missed not to be a day of an important test, event or extracurricular activity); and (iii) From the

That while the Mother lives with the child in the UK, the child spend time with the Father: (a) For 21 days in Australia during the English July (or summer) holidays, commencing in [place] on the fourth day of the holiday; (b) For 21 days in [place] Australia commencing on or about [date in January a year hence]; (c) For 21 days in [place] Australia commencing on [date in December two years hence]; (d) For a further 21 days in each calendar year to begin and end in the UK (not including any part of the UK summer holiday) to be exercised in the UK or Europe, upon the Father giving the Mother 60 days notice; and (e) As the parties may otherwise agree. 8. That for the purposes of paragraph 7: (a) The Mother arrange at her expense the child’s transport to and from the [specify Australian airport] accompanied by an adult at the beginning and end of [his/her] time in Australia; (b) The Father pay the cost of his travel to and from the UK to spend time with the child in the UK (or Europe) and the cost of his and the child’s accommodation and travel during such time; and (c) That if either party is not personally transporting the child to or

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 117 A NOTE ABOUT INTERIM AFFIDAVITS This note applies to the following sample affidavits for interim hearings. An affidavit may be relied on at an interim hearing if it does not exceed 25 pages and contain more than 10 annexures unless leave is granted by the court: FLR 5.08 (cf. FCR 84 in WA). If leave is sought, apply for an order “that leave be granted to [etc] to rely upon the affidavit of [name of deponent] notwithstanding its non-compliance with Rule 5.08 of the [FLR]” and each affidavit should contain facts relevant to why leave should be granted for further material e.g. multiple issues needing to be addressed at the interim hearing (parenting, spousal maintenance, interim injunctions about property); complexity; significant welfare risks to a child that could not otherwise be addressed via subpoena). For general provisions about interlocutory applications, see FLR 5.01 to 5.10 and Central Practice Directions 5.15 to 5.25. A respondent may file a longer affidavit if they are responding to both interim and final issues: Genesalio [2020] FamCAFC 113 at [131]-[134]. SAMPLE AFFIDAVITS FOR INTERIM HEARINGS • It is advisable for you to give your client an outline of the law set out above in this Chapter; and • for your client to make the most of the non-threatening environment of counselling and FDR to negotiate as much of the desired child-sharing arrangement as possible before applying to the court for interim orders. • If the other party has stopped short of agreeing to a reasonable arrangement, file your application, but make your client’s affidavit work for you – keep it simple and in their (not your) language, and keep to the points you need to get across. (See “the court’s approach to interim hearings” for the issues your client’s evidence will
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: agreeing to a reasonable arrangement, file your application, but make your client’s affidavit work for you – keep it simple and in their (not your) language, and keep to the points you need to get across. (See “the court’s approach to interim hearings” for the issues your client’s evidence will need to address.) The following precedents are set out below in hard copy for easy selection and are also available online at our website. Delete the sections that do not apply. I am the applicant for a recovery order in relation to the [child/children] of my [marriage/ unmarried relationship] with [insert full name of other party] (“[short name]”) [in this sample affidavit referred to as “X”]. 2. We [were married/began living together] at [place] on [date]. 3. Our [child is/children are]: 3.1 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date]. [He/She] is [insert] years of age. chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 122 AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS Note – The Family Law Amendment Act 2023, which repealed the concept of equal time that was introduced in 2006, means that from 6 May 2024 interim applications will be guided not by Goode but by the status quo concept of cases leading up to Cowling [1998] FamCA 19 (FC), which applied before 2006. Such cases held that at an interim hearing a child’s “best interests will normally be best met by ensuring stability in the life of the child pending a full hearing”. This precedent has been framed accord- ing to the Cowling factors, but see above “the court’s approach to interim hearings” for the issues your client’s evidence will need to address. Introduction 1. I am the [Applicant/Respondent] seeking interim parenting orders in relation to the [child/children] of [marriage/unmarried relationship] with [insert full name of other party] (“[short name]”) (in this sample affidavit referred to as “X”). 2. We [were married/began living together] at [place] on [date]. 3. Our [child is/children are]: 3.1 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Y” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 3.2 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Z” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 4. X and I separated on [date]. 5. I am [insert] years of age and work as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name] on [insert work hours and any scope for flexibility] [OR] I am unemployed [specifying any prospect of work in foreseeable future]. 6. X is [insert] years of age and works as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name]. Care arrangements before separation 7. During our [marriage/relationship], my role was that of father and breadwinner and X’s that of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: flexibility] [OR] I am unemployed [specifying any prospect of work in foreseeable future]. 6. X is [insert] years of age and works as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name]. Care arrangements before separation 7. During our [marriage/relationship], my role was that of father and breadwinner and X’s that of mother, caring for the [child/children] [full-time/part-time] (if applicable – when she was not working in her part-time/casual job (specify number of hours) hours a week), with some help from me with the children, meals and housework [specify] after getting home from work and more of a share of seeing to the children and domestic chores on weekends. 8. Since their birth, I have been a daily part of our [child’s life/children’s lives]. 8.1 Before our separation the time I spent with him/her/them was virtually continuous. I participated daily in [his/her/their] [life/lives] and took a keen interest in [his/her/their] development (summarise the average day’s duties from morning to night). 8.2 I accept that X has always been more directly involved with our [child’s/children’s] everyday routine than me, but my concern is that Y and Z be allowed to have as meaningful a relationship with me as they can now that we are no longer all under the same roof. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

What arrangements would promote the safety (including safety from being subjected to, or exposed to, family violence, abuse, neglect, or other harm) of (i) the child and (ii) each person who has care of the child (whether or not a person has parental responsibility for the child) 11. [EITHER where this consideration does not apply as there is no history of family violence, abuse or neglect and no family violence order has ever been in force for the purposes of s 60CC(2) and (2A).] Not applicable [OR this and the other sample paragraphs under this heading] [Specify in what way the child/children are unsafe.] 12. [Specify in what way your client is unsafe.] 13. [Specify in what way the child/children are subjected to family violence, abuse, neglect or other harm.] 14. [Specify in what way the child/children are exposed to family violence, abuse, neglect or other harm.] 15. [Specify in what way your client is subjected to family violence, abuse, neglect or other harm.] 16. [Specify what arrangements would promote the safety of the child/children and/or your client.] 17. [Annex any family violence order that is or has been force.] 18. [Summarise the circumstances of needing to apply for the family violence order.] 19. [Specify any history of family violence, abuse or neglect by X (toward the child/children and your client).] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 124 Any views expressed by the child 20. [A family report, or evidence from an ICL, should record a child’s wishes, but your client adducing evidence of statements by child/children of sufficient maturity to have a considered view [say 8–10 upwards] is worthwhile too e.g. Just yesterday [date], [child’s first name] said to me on the phone before his bedtime “Can’t I live with you, Dad?” or “Can’t we spend more time together than we do?” Describe the date and circumstances of any overt acts by a child such as running away.] The developmental, psychological, emotional and cultural needs of the child 21. [Specify the stage of development of each child (showing insight into their personal develop- ment, discipline, interactions with other children and both parents, school or pre-school progress, homework needs, hobbies, sports, cultural interests, their state of happiness, doing things with their parents and any other particular needs).] The capacity of each person who has or is proposed to have parental responsibility for the child to provide for the child’s developmental, psychological, emotional and cultural needs 22. [Specify what each parent does (or does not do) to provide for the needs specified under the previous subheading.] The benefit to the child of being able to have a relationship with the child’s parents, and other people who are significant to the child, where it is safe to do so 23. [Describe the relationship between each child and each parent.] 24. [Describe the relationship between each child and each grandparent.] 25. [Describe the relationship between each child and each other person who is significant to the child.] [If your client is seeking more time with the child/children than X is willing to allow.] 26. [Specify any conflict, disagreement or obstruction over child/children spending time with his/her/
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: child and each grandparent.] 25. [Describe the relationship between each child and each other person who is significant to the child.] [If your client is seeking more time with the child/children than X is willing to allow.] 26. [Specify any conflict, disagreement or obstruction over child/children spending time with his/her/ their father since separation e.g.] On [date] I rang X to ask if I could see Y and Z on [dates/ proposal]. X said “[insert response]”. 27. On [date] I had to instruct my lawyer to ask that I have the children on [date] and that I pick them up from school. Annexed to this affidavit is a true copy of my lawyer’s letter dated [date]. I received no reply. [OR] Annexed is a true copy of the reply from X’s lawyer. 28. [If other requests for time with the child/children have been obstructed, or any child-related deci- sions made by X unilaterally, set out that evidence, giving date, time, context and exact wording of statements by X indicative of her attitude. Avoid making too much of this, though, unless X is hardened against your client having time with the child/children or attempting to alienate the child/ children. It is best, especially if equal or substantial time is being sought, to emphasise your client’s hope that he and X can talk more about the children and his intention to do all he can to commu- nicate better with X so as to have the arrangements running smoothly.] 29. My work hours allow me to spend a whole lot more time with Y and Z than X is allowing, specifi- cally the following occasions every fortnight: [specify every period of time each week he would be able to see Y and Z. Add, after each time period, the activity that the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: hours allow me to spend a whole lot more time with Y and Z than X is allowing, specifi- cally the following occasions every fortnight: [specify every period of time each week he would be able to see Y and Z. Add, after each time period, the activity that the time would allow e.g.] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
