chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 125 29.1 Alternate Wednesdays/Thursdays/[specify] after school through to following Monday for start of school – so I can be involved in [his/her/their] school routine, at least for a couple of days (seeing to homework being done; discussing school progress; getting [him/her/them] ready; preparing lunches; taking [him/her/them] and picking [him/her/them] up). 29.2 Thursdays in the off week – to pick our [child/children] up from school; take [specify] to hockey practice; home for a meal afterwards; homework and return to Mother. 29.3 Every Tuesday – to pick our [child/children] up from school; take [specify] to piano lessons; home for a meal afterwards; homework and return to mother. 29.4 Saturday/Sunday afternoons in the off week – to watch [him/her/them] play [specify], collect- ing and returning them to mother afterwards. 30. I am applying for these arrangements so that I can be more than just a visitor or someone Y and Z come to for weekend and school holiday “fun time” only. 31. The time I am seeking with the [child/children] is workable by fitting easily into [his/her/their] rou- tine without putting [him/her/them] under any strain, such as from any significant interruption of the school week, any significant extra travel, or other such inconvenience. 32. Other things I would like to be able to do with Y and Z (and have them benefit from), as well as those activities referred to above, are [specify everyday and, even, mundane things such as being there and taking an interest]. 33. [Describe how the child/children has/have adapted easily to any changes in his/her/their school week routine since separation that your client has been able to negotiate with X.] 34. My proposal would mean little adjustment of Y’s and Z’s routine of living with their mother. [He/She/They] will continue to live at home with their
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: child/children has/have adapted easily to any changes in his/her/their school week routine since separation that your client has been able to negotiate with X.] 34. My proposal would mean little adjustment of Y’s and Z’s routine of living with their mother. [He/She/They] will continue to live at home with their mother, and stay with me in just one block of time per fortnight. 35. Change to [his/her/their] school week would be minimal too. Staying with me from Wednesday/ Thursday night to the Monday morning would involve little change by commuting between school and my home; by getting collected from and delivered to school by me on just 2–3 days a fortnight (plus the three other days that I propose collecting [him/her/them] from school for piano and hock- ey practice); Fridays being a wind-down day for students on the eve of a weekend. 36. Our [child/children] would benefit from having a relationship with both their parents. [If your client is concerned that X is seeking unrealistic time that will be unworkable for the children] 37. I accept that X should be meaningfully involved in our [child’s life/children’s lives]. 38. I am concerned about [his/her/their] already busy school week, and [if applicable] the young age of Z. [Specify, for each child, their daily school week routine including after-school and weekend activities; the times of each activity; the times and distance of car or other travel; and describe any evidence of the children being tired from what they are already doing] 39. X’s proposal will mean adding the following arrangements to Y’s and Z’s current routine [specify]. 40. The care arrangement I have sought [summarise it e.g. alternate weekends, X to collect from and return to school on the Friday and Monday; plus half the holidays] fits much more easily into [his/ her/their]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: proposal will mean adding the following arrangements to Y’s and Z’s current routine [specify]. 40. The care arrangement I have sought [summarise it e.g. alternate weekends, X to collect from and return to school on the Friday and Monday; plus half the holidays] fits much more easily into [his/ her/their] normal pattern without placing too many demands on [him/her/them], particularly as to excessive movement between our two homes [specify], interruption of the school week [specify], extra travel [specify distance X lives from school and your client’s home] and [specify any other burdensome inconvenience]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 126 41. [Give examples of any other trouble the child/children has/have coping with X’s routine.] 42. Z is just [specify] years of age and is only used to being in my care. X’s involvement with Z to date has been extremely limited. [He/She] has already been showing signs of not taking the separation well, by frequently disturbed sleep, bed wetting and, whenever I leave [him/her] at day care/my parents for a couple of hours, fretful behaviour such as holding on to me and not letting go. 43. Z has [not/rarely] stayed overnight with his father. When [he/she] has, X has often rung me to say he is unable to stop [him/her] crying [specify any problems with overnight or any other time with father] 44. Y and Z have always done things together around my home, and are used to each other’s com- pany. My concern is that were Y to spend time with [his/her] father but not Z (due to [his/her] age), neither child may be all that comfortable. 45. Because X and I always seem to argue when trying to discuss our [child/children], a shared care arrangement will increase our [child’s/children’s] exposure to our conflict, such as through overheard telephone calls between us, changeovers involving them or other witnessed contact between us. 46. I also doubt that X has the time available from his job to be available at the times he gives, as he always told me when we were together that he was not able to take any time off work [give any specific instance of that]. 47. [Specify any other evidence causing concern about possible adverse effects on the child/children.] Anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of the child 48. [Specify anything else that is relevant to the particular
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: not able to take any time off work [give any specific instance of that]. 47. [Specify any other evidence causing concern about possible adverse effects on the child/children.] Anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of the child 48. [Specify anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of each child.] 49. [Where disagreement over choice/change of school] [If a party is going back on their pre-separation agreement for child/children to attend a particular school, or type of school e.g. private, specify the date and content of the agreement; refer to the parties’ reasoning behind that earlier decision and confirm that that reasoning e.g. jointly perceived likelihood of a better/ more religiously suitable/more affordable education/more convenient location/financial capacity for payment of the school’s fees, still applies.] Note – A prior agreement will not carry much weight if the family’s circumstances have changed significantly. [Where no prior agreement, describe the different school routines being compared, including which would be likely to best meet the children’s educational, extra-curricular, peer group needs and practical aspects such as comparable time of travel to each school and any other inconve- niences [and why]. An affidavit showing insight into a child’s needs is likely to be considered care- fully. Add any other aspects relevant to the best interests of the children.] 50. [Any proposed or unilateral change of child’s name] [Where the name has already been changed without consent, specify the evidence of the child being given another name, and the content of any discussions between the parties beforehand or afterwards about it, including the content of any request to reinstate child’s correct name and of any refusal to do so. The person objecting should specify the extent of their continuous contact with the child/children in terms of the amount of time regularly
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING INTERIM PARENTING ORDERS

chunks.text: any discussions between the parties beforehand or afterwards about it, including the content of any request to reinstate child’s correct name and of any refusal to do so. The person objecting should specify the extent of their continuous contact with the child/children in terms of the amount of time regularly spent with them; give evidence of any problems being caused to the child due to the name change; and explain why use of the former name would be in the child’s best interests, such as a child’s right to be able to identify by name with that parent, and any evidence that the child already identifies with the former name. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

Note – A parent who has had little contact with a child may not be able to resist change of name where the primary parent has re-partnered and begun a new family unit. If hyphenation is proposed as a compromise, set out the proposal and the reasons for it.] 51. [Specify any other evidence relevant to your client’s application. Also, add in separate paragraphs the evidence in support of any interim financial orders being sought at the same time as the above orders.] [If a child is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander child] Child’s right to enjoy Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture by having the support, opportunity and encouragement necessary: (a) (i) to connect with, and maintain their connection with, members of their family and with their community, culture, country and language [give particulars]; (ii) to explore the full extent of that culture, consistent with the child’s age and developmental level and the child’s views [give particulars]; (iii) to develop a positive appreciation of that culture [give particulars]; and (b) the likely impact any proposed parenting order under this Part will have on that right [give particulars]. 52. [Specify all instances where an indigenous/non-indigenous conflict involves adverse effects on a child’s well-being, such as the likely loss of contact with an indigenous parent’s background; lesser discrimination; and easier assimilation.] Note – See also s 61F which requires the court to have regard to “any kinship obligations, and child-rearing practices, of the child’s Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture”. X and I do discuss our [child/children] and consult each other about arrangements, although we have had differences of opinion about things. 54. I have applied for an order for sole decision-making about major long-term issues] as there has been no sign of X being willing to co-operate with me regarding arrangements for our [child/ children]. [Specify which issues if seeking sole decision-making in relation to some, not all, major long-term issues, explaining why.] 59. [Where X does communicate, but ineffectively] X and I never sit down and talk calmly about our [child/children]. Issues arising from our break-up usually come to the surface and we end up with raised voices or X trying to dictate terms [give examples of this] 60. When I try to reason with her/him, X just gets louder. I have suggested we attend counselling so as to improve how we communicate, but X says they will not go. 61. All the above facts are within my own knowledge except those which are deposed to from informa- tion only, my means of knowledge and sources of information for which appear in this affidavit. Note – Briefing counsel to settle your draft is advisable. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 129 SAMPLE AFFIDAVITS FOR FINAL HEARINGS The following precedents are set out below in hard copy for easy selection and are also available online at our website. AFFIDAVIT OF PARENT SEEKING FINAL PARENTING ORDERS Introduction 1. I am the [Applicant/Respondent] seeking parenting orders in relation to the [child/children] of my [marriage/unmarried relationship] with [insert full name of other party] (“[short name]”) (in this sample affidavit referred to as “X”). 2. We [were married/began living together] at [place] on [date]. 3. Our [child is/children are]: 3.1 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Y” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 3.2 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Z” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 4. X and I separated on [date]. 5. I am [insert] years of age and work as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name] on [insert work hours and any scope for flexibility] [OR] I am unemployed [specifying any prospect of work in foreseeable future]. 6. X is [insert] years of age and works as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name]. Care arrangements before separation 7. During our [marriage/relationship], my role was that of father and breadwinner and X’s that of mother, caring for the [child/children] [full-time/part-time] (if applicable – when she was not working in her part-time/casual job (specify number of hours) hours a week), with some help from me with the [child/children], meals and housework [specify] after getting home from work and more of a share of seeing to the children and domestic chores on weekends. 8. Since their birth, I have been a daily part of our [child/children]’s [life/lives]. 8.1 Before our separation the time I spent with the [child/children] was virtually continuous. I participated daily in

(summarise the average day’s duties from morning to night). 8.2 I accept that X has always been more directly involved with our [child/children]’s everyday routine than me, but my concern is that Y and Z be allowed to have a relationship with me now that we are no longer all under the same roof. 8.3 I would also like to share parental responsibility for all future major long-term issues equally with X. My proposal would mean little adjustment of Y and Z’s routine of living with X. He/She/They will continue to live at home with X, and stay with me in just one block of time per fortnight. 37. Change to [his/her/their] school week would be minimal too. Staying with me from Wednesday/ Thursday night to the Monday morning would involve little change by commuting between school and my home; by getting collected from and delivered to school by me on just 2–3 days a fort- night (plus the three other days that I propose collecting [him/her/them] from school for piano and hockey practice); Fridays being a wind-down day for students on
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: change by commuting between school and my home; by getting collected from and delivered to school by me on just 2–3 days a fort- night (plus the three other days that I propose collecting [him/her/them] from school for piano and hockey practice); Fridays being a wind-down day for students on the eve of a weekend. 38. Our [child/children] would benefit from having a relationship with both their parents. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 133 [If concerned that X is seeking unrealistic time that will be unworkable for the children] 39. I accept that X should be meaningfully involved in our [child’s life/children’s lives]. 40. I am concerned about [his/her/their] already busy school week, and [if applicable] the young age of Z. [Specify, for each child, their daily school week routine including after-school and weekend activities; the times of each activity; the times and distance of car or other travel; and describe any evidence of the children being tired from what they are already doing] 41. X’s proposal will mean adding the following arrangements to Y’s and Z’s current routine [specify]. 42. The care arrangement I have sought [summarise it e.g. alternate weekends, X to collect from and return to school on the Friday and Monday; plus half the holidays] fits much more easily into [his/her/their] normal pattern without placing too many demands on [him/her/them], particu- larly as to excessive movement between our two homes [specify], interruption of the school week [specify], extra travel [specify distance X lives from school and your client’s home] and [specify any other burdensome inconvenience]. 43. [Give examples of any trouble the child/children already has/have coping with their current routine] 44. Z is just [specify] years of age and is only used to being in my care. X’s involvement with Z to date has been extremely limited. [He/She] has already been showing signs of not taking the separation well, by frequently disturbed sleep, bed wetting and, whenever I leave [him/her] at day care/my parents for a couple of hours, fretful behaviour such as holding on to me and not letting go. 45. Z has [not/rarely] stayed overnight with X. When [he/she] has, X has often rung me to say he is unable to stop [him/her] crying
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: whenever I leave [him/her] at day care/my parents for a couple of hours, fretful behaviour such as holding on to me and not letting go. 45. Z has [not/rarely] stayed overnight with X. When [he/she] has, X has often rung me to say he is unable to stop [him/her] crying [specify any problems with overnight or any other time with X] 46. Y and Z have always done things together around my home, and are used to each other’s company. My concern is that were Y to spend time with X but not Z (due to [his/her] age), neither child may be all that comfortable. 47. Because X and I always seem to argue when trying to discuss our [child/children], a shared care arrangement will increase our [child’s/children’s] exposure to our conflict, such as through overheard telephone calls between us, changeovers involving them or other witnessed contact between us. 48. I also doubt that X has the time available from his job to be available at the times he gives, as he always told me when we were together that he was not able to take any time off work [give any specific instance of that]. 49. [Specify any other evidence causing concern about possible adverse effects on the child/children.] Anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of the child [Specify anything else that is relevant to the particular circumstances of each child.] 50. [Where disagreement over choice/change of school] [If a party is going back on their pre- separation agreement for child/children to attend a particular school, or type of school e.g. private, specify the date and content of the agreement; refer to the parties’ reasoning behind that earlier decision and confirm that that reasoning e.g. jointly perceived likelihood of a better/more religiously suitable/more affordable education/more convenient
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: pre- separation agreement for child/children to attend a particular school, or type of school e.g. private, specify the date and content of the agreement; refer to the parties’ reasoning behind that earlier decision and confirm that that reasoning e.g. jointly perceived likelihood of a better/more religiously suitable/more affordable education/more convenient location/financial capacity for payment of the school’s fees, still applies. Note – A prior agreement will not carry much weight if the family’s circumstances have changed significantly.] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 134 [Where no prior agreement, describe the different school routines being compared, including which would be likely to best meet the children’s educational, extra-curricular, peer group needs and practical aspects such as comparable time of travel to each school and any other inconveniences [and why]. An affidavit showing insight into a child’s needs is likely to be considered carefully. Add any other aspects relevant to the best interests of the children.] 51. [Any proposed or unilateral change of child’s name] [Where the name has already been changed without consent, specify the evidence of the child being given another name, and the content of any discussions between the parties beforehand or afterwards about it, including the content of any request to reinstate child’s correct name and of any refusal to do so. The person objecting should specify the extent of their continuous contact with the child/children in terms of the amount of time regularly spent with them; give evidence of any problems being caused to the child due to the name change; and explain why use of the former name would be in the child’s best interests, such as a child’s right to be able to identify by name with that parent, and any evidence that the child already identifies with the former name. Specify instances of any increasing conflict between the parties over the name change dispute, being conflict that would be resolved by the old name being restored. Note – A parent who has had little con- tact with a child may not be able to resist change of name where the primary parent has re-partnered and begun a new family unit. If hyphenation is proposed as a compromise, set out the proposal and the reasons for it.] [If a child is an Aboriginal or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: little con- tact with a child may not be able to resist change of name where the primary parent has re-partnered and begun a new family unit. If hyphenation is proposed as a compromise, set out the proposal and the reasons for it.] [If a child is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander child] Child’s right to enjoy Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture by having the support, opportunity and encouragement necessary: (a) (i) to connect with, and maintain their connection with, members of their family and with their community, culture, country and language [give particulars]; (ii) to explore the full extent of that culture, consistent with the child’s age and developmental level and the child’s views [give particulars]; (iii) to develop a positive appreciation of that culture [give particulars]; and (b) the likely impact any proposed parenting order under this Part will have on that right [give particulars]. 52. [Specify all instances where an indigenous/non-indigenous conflict involves adverse effects on a child’s well-being, such as the likely loss of contact with an indigenous parent’s background; lesser discrimination; and easier assimilation.] Note – See also s 61F which requires the court to have regard to “any kinship obligations, and child- rearing practices, of the child’s Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander culture”. Parental responsibility [If seeking final order for joint decision-making about major long-term issues] 53. X and I do discuss our [child/children] and consult each other about arrangements, although we have had differences of opinion about things. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILDREN 4 – 135 54. [Specify any problems with communication or co-operation regarding child arrangements] 55. I agree to an order for joint decision-making about major long-term issues. [If seeking final order for sole decision-making about major long-term issues] 56. [Where you have previously written to X or X’s lawyer to complain about X’s behaviour] Annexed to this affidavit is a true copy of my lawyer’s letter to [X/X’s lawyer] dated [date], and a true copy of [his/her/their] reply/[OR] to which there was no reply. 57. [If applicable] X failed/refused to attend family counselling with me, or compulsory family dispute resolution, before these proceedings were issued. [Specify any words of refusal used by X] 58. I have applied for an order for sole decision-making about major long-term issues as there has been no sign of X being willing to co-operate with me regarding arrangements for our [child/ children]. [Specify which issues if seeking sole decision-making in relation to some, not all, major long-term issues, explaining why.] 59. [Where X does communicate, but ineffectively] X and I never sit down and talk calmly about our [child/children]. Issues arising from our break-up usually come to the surface and we end up with raised voices or X trying to dictate terms [give examples of this] 60. When I try to reason with her, X just gets louder. I have suggested we attend counselling so as to improve how we communicate, but she says she will not go. 61. [Specify any other evidence relevant to your client’s application. Also, add in separate paragraphs the evidence in support of any final financial orders being sought at the same time as the above orders.] 62. All the above facts are within my own knowledge except those which are deposed to from informa- tion only, my means
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to your client’s application. Also, add in separate paragraphs the evidence in support of any final financial orders being sought at the same time as the above orders.] 62. All the above facts are within my own knowledge except those which are deposed to from informa- tion only, my means of knowledge and sources of information for which appear in this affidavit. Note – Briefing counsel to settle your draft is advisable. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 136 AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT SEEKING TO RELOCATE WITH CHILD [Notes about your client’s evidence • In Bolitho & Cohen [2005] FamCA 458 the Full Court said at [71] that some s 60CC factors (set out below) may be more relevant than others. So deal with those factors in order of relevance. • The Court said ([72]) that in U v U [2002] HCA 36 the High Court held that “the proper approach … in a relocation case is a weighing of competing proposals, having regard to relevant … [s 60CC] factors, and … other relevant factors, including the right of freedom of movement of the [applicant] … [U]ltimately the decision must be … in the best interests of the child”. • The Full Court added ([84]) that Hayne J in U v U also said that a judge may look beyond the (“selfish”) proposals of the parties (F in U v U had not considered the prospect of his relocating too). • “The proper focus is which is better for the child – to be in the custody of the [respondent] father (in Perth) or to be in the custody of the [applicant] mother (in Darwin). That … requires attention to what benefits will the child have, and what detriments will the child suffer, from being in the moth- er’s custody in Darwin.” per Hayne J in AMS v AIF [1999] HCA 26 at [218]. • Also see our archived children’s case notes under “relocation” for the type of evidence considered in cases similar to yours.] Introduction 1. I am the mother/father, the Applicant for parenting orders in relation to the [child/children] of my [marriage/unmarried relationship] with [insert full name of other party] (“[short name]”) (in this sample affidavit referred to as “X”). 2. We [were
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT SEEKING TO RELOCATE WITH CHILD

chunks.text: the type of evidence considered in cases similar to yours.] Introduction 1. I am the mother/father, the Applicant for parenting orders in relation to the [child/children] of my [marriage/unmarried relationship] with [insert full name of other party] (“[short name]”) (in this sample affidavit referred to as “X”). 2. We [were married/began living together] at [place] on [date]. 3. Our [child is/children are]: 3.1 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Y” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 3.2 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Z” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 4. X and I separated on [date]. 5. I am [insert] years of age and work as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name] on [insert work hours and any scope for flexibility] [OR] I am unemployed [specifying any prospect of work in foreseeable future]. Note – a recent promotion offer interstate is covered a few clauses later. 6. X is [insert] years of age and works as a [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] at [employer’s name]. 7. The [child/children] are [in good health/poor health – give details]. 8. The [child/children] have been attending the following [day care centre(s)/school(s)] during these hours [specify and state which parent delivers and collects, including after school activities]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FOUR 4 – 142 AFFIDAVIT OF RESPONDENT OPPOSING RELOCATION APPLICATION [Notes about your client’s evidence • In Bolitho & Cohen [2005] FamCA 458 the Full Court said at [71] that some s 60CC factors (set out below) may be more relevant than others. So deal with those factors in order of relevance. • The Court said ([72]) that in U v U [2002] HCA 36 the High Court held that “the proper approach … in a relocation case is a weighing of competing proposals, having regard to relevant … [s 60CC] factors, and … other relevant factors, including the right of freedom of movement of the [applicant] … [U]ltimately the decision must be … in the best interests of the child”. • The Full Court added ([84]) that Hayne J in U v U also said that a judge may look beyond the (“selfish”) proposals of the parties (F in U v U had not considered the prospect of his relocating too). • “The proper focus is which is better for the child – to be in the custody of the [respondent] father (in Perth) or to be in the custody of the [applicant] mother (in Darwin). That … requires attention to what benefits will the child have, and what detriments will the child suffer, from being in the moth- er’s custody in Darwin.” per Hayne J in AMS v AIF [1999] HCA 26 at [218]. • Also see our archived children’s case notes under “relocation” for the type of evidence considered in cases similar to yours.] Introduction 1. I am the Respondent. 2. I am the father/mother of the following [child/children] of my [marriage/unmarried relationship] with the Applicant [full name of other party] (“[first name]”) (referred to as “X” in this sample affidavit): 2.1 [full name of child]

chunks.text: of evidence considered in cases similar to yours.] Introduction 1. I am the Respondent. 2. [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 2.2 [full name of child] (“[insert first name]”) born [date] (called “Z” in this sample). [He/She] is [insert] years of age. 3. X and I separated on [date]. 4. I am [insert] years of age and work as a [occupation] [OR specify your client’s situation.] 5. X is [insert] years of age and works as a [occupation] [OR specify applicant’s situation.] 6. I am strongly opposed to X’s relocation application. 7. [Refer to any failure by X to discuss the relocation with your client] 8. [Specify any evidence of X planning relocation unilaterally e.g. enrolling the child in an interstate school; travelling interstate to look for a new house; applying for an interstate position. Refer to any statements made by X that might indicate an ill-conceived relocation proposal or an inappro- priate parental attitude.] My proposal in response to X’s application 9. [Summarise here the outcome your client proposes (e.g. the child/children continuing to live where they are, in regular touch with both parents). As we suggest you deal with s 60CC factors in order of relevance this sample leads with s 60CC(2)(e). Include why your client cannot relocate too (see Hayne J’s judgment in U v U under “relocation” above).] The benefit to the child of being able to have a relationship with both parents (and other people who are significant to the child) 10. Relocation would, for me and the [child/children] and our relationship, be the last straw. 15. [If applicable] Z is only [age] and in my parental opinion lacks the maturity to be able to cope with the kind of contact with me X is proposing. 17. chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 3 INTRODUCTION Child support is assessed by the Child Support Registrar c/- the Australian Government Department of Human Services (DHS). This is done by applying a formula under Part 5 of the Child Support (Assess- ment) Act 1989 (the “Assessment Act” or the “CSAA”). In the words of the Full Court, in the renowned case of Gyselman [1991] FamCA 93: “The Assessment Act, combined with the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 enables, and in some cases obliges, the assessed liability to be collected through and enforced by the Child Support [Registrar].” Editor’s connection with Gyselman The editor [RGW] was solicitor and counsel for the husband in Gyselman before Frederico J in Hobart, bringing what was to be the last court application for departure from a child support assessment before the introduction of administrative review. The wife’s appeal to the Full Court in Melbourne against the departure order led to the decision cited above. The development of a system of administrative review of assessments has both reduced the lawyer’s role and opened up new avenues for lawyers to act in child support matters. Before examining the work that has been left to lawyers, here is a summary of the new child support scheme introduced to the Assessment Act on 1 July 2008 and of how the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act (CSR&CA), since its own amendments on 1 January 2007, has been used to add further administrative layers to the review of assessed child support. These Acts extend to the maintenance of ex-nuptial children except in WA (s 13 CSAA; s 5 CSR&CA) The website of the Australian Department of Human Services is not that easy to navigate and is ever- changing but it does contain the following: • The Child Support
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: assessed child support. These Acts extend to the maintenance of ex-nuptial children except in WA (s 13 CSAA; s 5 CSR&CA) The website of the Australian Department of Human Services is not that easy to navigate and is ever- changing but it does contain the following: • The Child Support Guide • Administrative forms • Child support estimator Our online child support news See “child support news” at our members Practice News for all notable developments published by the Department of Human Services. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 4 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSESSMENT Right to apply Part 4 of the Assessment Act allows a parent (s 25) or non-parent carer (ss 25A and 7B) to apply for an administrative assessment of child support to be paid by a parent for a child. “Parent” is defined by s 5 as including an adoptive parent and a parent of a child born by means of artificial conception under s 60H of the FLA. An application may be made by phone to the Child Support Registrar (131 272); online at https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/how-to-apply-for-child-support-assessment or in writing by com- pleting an “Application for Child Support Assessment”. The completed form may be lodged at a DHS office. Once an application is accepted, the Child Support Registrar will send the parties a notice of child sup- port assessment showing the amount assessed and how it was calculated. The Child Support Registrar is entitled to accept an applicant’s claim that the respondent is a parent if satisfied that the child was born during the parties’ marriage; or the respondent’s name is on the birth certificate; or there has been a court finding of paternity. Eligible children also include an adopted child; a child of a separated married couple born within 44 weeks after resumption of cohabitation; and a child born to an unmarried couple who cohabited between 44 and 20 weeks before the birth (s 29). Child support is assessed at an annual rate, payable monthly, and ends when the child turns 18 or becomes “a member of a couple” (s 24) or on other terminating events such as adoption (s 12). A child who turns 18 in their last year of school may have their child support extended to the end of that school year if the carer entitled to child support applies before
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: “a member of a couple” (s 24) or on other terminating events such as adoption (s 12). A child who turns 18 in their last year of school may have their child support extended to the end of that school year if the carer entitled to child support applies before the 18th birthday: s 151B The child support formula A new child support scheme was introduced on 1 July 2008 as a fairer means of assessment of child support, based on the actual costs of children and the capacity of both parents to meet those costs having regard to their respective incomes. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 5 A summary of the child support formula The following is taken from the former Child Support Agency’s website under “child support formula” and is unchanged since child support came under the control of the DHS. This material is copyright of the Commonwealth of Australia, and is reproduced under permission of the Com- monwealth: “Every family is unique, and the child support formula is flexible and takes into account many different family circumstances. It ensures a balanced and flexible way of working out child support payments. The key components of the formula are: • the costs of raising children, based on independent research, are the basis of the formula • both parents’ incomes are taken into account and considered equally • the same self-support amount is deducted from each parent’s income before child support is worked out • the level of care each parent provides is taken into account • children from first and subsequent families are treated in a similar way We follow eight steps to calculate child support: 1. Work out your child support income (If you have dependent children or more than two child support assessments, this will be taken into account at this step). 2. Work out the combined child support income 3. Work out your income percentage 4. Work out your care percentage 5. Work out your cost percentage 6. Work out your child support percentage 7. Work out the cost of your child (You will get either a positive or negative child support percentage. If the percentage is positive, you need to pay child support.) 8. Work out the child support amount (This is the) basic formula (which) applies to parents with one child support assessment and no other dependent children. This is the formula we use for
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: positive or negative child support percentage. If the percentage is positive, you need to pay child support.) 8. Work out the child support amount (This is the) basic formula (which) applies to parents with one child support assessment and no other dependent children. This is the formula we use for most child support assessments.” Reference is then made to how child support is calculated for parents with other dependent children, parents with more than one assessment and carers who are not parents. Note – See our eBook or website for a link to “child support assessments”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 6 The eight steps to calculate child support 1 Work out each parent’s child support income This is each parent’s taxable income (plus any net rental loss and fringe benefits) less the “parenting self support amount” which is $18,252 as at 2008 (indexed annually). If a person has other dependent children or more than two child support assessments, a deduction is made at this step. 2 Work out the combined child support income The combined child support income is the child support income of the parents added together. 3 Work out your income percentage By combining the child support income at step 2, each parent’s child support income can be viewed as a percentage. Example: If Jane’s child support income amount is $20,000 and John’s is $60,000 at step 1, then: • the combined child support income is $80,000 (step 2); • Jane’s income percentage is 25%; and • John’s income percentage is 75%. 4 Work out your care percentage A parent’s care percentage is based on the number of nights in a 365 night calendar year the child lives with each parent. Example: If the above couple had one child who lived with Jane for 292 nights a year, and John 73 nights a year: • Jane’s care percentage is 80%; • John’s care percentage is 20%. 5 Work out your cost percentage Each party’s cost percentage is calculated from their percentage of care (step 4), using this table in s 55C (CSAA): Care percentage Cost percentage Nil to less than 14% Nil 14% to less than 35% 24% 35% to less than 48% 25% + 2% for every % > 35% 48% to 52% 50% More than 52% to 65% 51% + 2% for every % > 53% Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Cost percentage Nil to less than 14% Nil 14% to less than 35% 24% 35% to less than 48% 25% + 2% for every % > 35% 48% to 52% 50% More than 52% to 65% 51% + 2% for every % > 53% Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 7 More than 65% to 86% 76% More than 86% to 100% 100% Example: Jane’s care percentage (step 4) was 80%, so her cost percentage is 76%. John’s care percentage was 20%, so his cost percentage is 24%. 6 Work out your child support percentage Each parent’s income percentage (step 3) minus their cost percentage (step 5) represents their child support percentage. Example: • Jane: 25% – 76% = – 51% child support % • John: 75% – 24% = 51% child support % If the child support percentage is positive, you need to pay child support – the liable parent. If the child support percentage is negative, you are entitled to receive child support – the parent entitled to child support. 7 Work out the cost of your child This is calculated by the table in Schedule 1 (CSAA) that is updated annually and can be found on the DHS website here at our eBook. Example: The combined child support income of John and Jane (step 2) was $80,000. Under the table, if their child is under 12, the cost of the child is $8,761 plus $0.12 for every dollar over $54,756. So the cost of their child would be $8,761 + ($25,244 x 0.12) = $11,790.28. 8 Work out the child support amount Finally, multiply the liable parent’s child support percentage (step 6) by the cost of the child (step 7). Example: John, being the liable parent, would be assessed to pay 51% of $11,790.28 = $6,013.04 per annum, or $501.08 per month. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 8 The relevant legislation Administrative assessments are made under Part 5 of the CSAA based on: • eligibility definitions for children, parents and non-parents as set out in Part 4 • the applicable formula from the several formulas set out in ss 35–40 • working out parent’s child support income and amount for self-support: ss 41–47 • percentage of care of a parent or non-parent carer: ss 48–55 • each parent’s child support percentage – the difference between their income percentage (capacity to meet costs of child) and their or non-parent’s cost percentage (extent to which they have met those costs through care): s 55A–E • the cost of the child under ss 55F–55HA and Schedule 1 of the CSAA Child support income – new definition From 1 July 2009, salary sacrificed superannuation contributions and net investment losses are counted as child support income. The exclusion of extra income after separation Your client may apply to the Child Support Registrar for any post-separation income, such as from second jobs or overtime, to be excluded from the child support assessment for up to three years if that income would not normally have been earned: s 44 Regular care of children Where a paying parent has “regular care” of a child (defined in s 5(2) as between 14% and 35% of care, or between two and five nights a fortnight), child support assessments are reduced (according to the DHS website) “to acknowledge that the parent directly contributes to the cost of raising the child through (that) care”. Shared care of children Where parents share care of a child, child support is further adjusted. Both parents may receive family assistance payments to help them with the cost of children. Shared care is defined by s 5(3) as between 35%
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the cost of raising the child through (that) care”. Shared care of children Where parents share care of a child, child support is further adjusted. Both parents may receive family assistance payments to help them with the cost of children. Shared care is defined by s 5(3) as between 35% and 65% of care, or between five and nine nights a fortnight. For “care estimator” see here at our eBook or at our online “forms and precedents”. Child support estimator An estimator of child support (and of child support/family assistance combined) is available here at our eBook or at our online “forms and precedents”. Further information about the formula or other aspects of the legislation is to be found at the DHS website. For “Application for child support assessment” see “administrative forms” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 9 ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW There are no fewer than six opportunities for administrative (in-house) review available to parties, with some intermediate avenues enabling them to go directly to court. These opportunities are by means of informing the Child Support Registrar (“Registrar”) of any change to a formula element; a change of assessment initiated by the Registrar; applying for an administrative change of assessment (administrative departure from the assessment); lodging an objection requiring the Registrar to reconsider a decision; review of the reconsidered decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT); and an appeal to a court from the AAT on a question of law. For more information see The Child Support Guide. 1. Notification by a parent of change to a formula element The easiest way that a parent can ensure the correctness of their assessment is by keeping the Registrar (via their child support officer) informed of: • any new care arrangement for the children (ss 52 or 74A) • any change in the number of dependent children (s 73A) • any change of income (ss 34A, 58A and 63A) • any terminating event (ss 74 and 12) ensuring that they inform the Registrar of any such change within 14 days (s 160). If a liable parent’s income decreases by more than 15%, they can lodge with the Registrar an “Estimate of income for use in a child support assessment” under s 60 of the CSAA (for the form, see under “administrative forms” below). An estimate of income, if accepted by the Registrar, becomes that parent’s adjusted taxable income amount for the purpose of the administrative formula. Once lodged, the Registrar will review the estimate and either accept or reject it. Note – If you help a client lodge such an estimate, you should advise
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: estimate of income, if accepted by the Registrar, becomes that parent’s adjusted taxable income amount for the purpose of the administrative formula. Once lodged, the Registrar will review the estimate and either accept or reject it. Note – If you help a client lodge such an estimate, you should advise them that if the Registrar finds that their income has been underestimated, the Registrar can: • retrospectively reassess the liable parent; and • impose a penalty if their income is found to be at least 10% greater than the estimated amount (s 64A) The advantage of a party informing their child support officer of any such change is the recalculation of the assessment to take that change into account without the need for any formal application for a departure. See “Child support or maintenance change” under “administrative forms”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 10 2. Change of assessment initiated by Child Support Registrar The Registrar can initiate a change of assessment without an application from the payer or payee if it is satisfied that the assessment is “unfair” (the wording used in the DHS website) because of a parent’s income, earning capacity, property or financial resources, and that it is just and equitable and otherwise proper to change the assessment (ss 98K and 98L CSAA). The Registrar may also make a discretionary amendment of an assessment in certain circumstances as set out in s 75. 3. Administrative change of assessment in special circumstances Part 6A of the CSAA (s 98B) empowers the Child Support Registrar, upon the application of a liable parent or carer entitled to child support, to depart from a child support assessment upon any of the several grounds for departure contained in s 117(2) that a court once could use to review an administra- tive assessment (Gyselman, above), and still can in the circumstances set out below (see “application to court for a departure order”). Note – Although the departure grounds are meant to be the same, the form of application to the Registrar (see below) uses a simplified (and somewhat different) version of those grounds which are called “The 10 reasons for making an application” and comes with examples of the financial circumstances giving rise to each of those administrative grounds. A Senior Case Officer hears the parties either in conference together or separately (even by phone); examines the application, response (see below for these forms) and any documents produced by either party in support of their case; and then, if the parties cannot agree on the amount of child support to be paid, gives the decision and its reasons to each party. Parties are
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Change of assessment initiated by Child Support Registrar

chunks.text: by phone); examines the application, response (see below for these forms) and any documents produced by either party in support of their case; and then, if the parties cannot agree on the amount of child support to be paid, gives the decision and its reasons to each party. Parties are not allowed to be represented by another person: s 98H(5) The Registrar may refuse to make a determination if satisfied that the issues raised by the application are too complex to be dealt with under Part 6A, and recommend that the applicant apply to the court for a departure order instead: s 98E For “Your Application: Changing your child support assessment in special circumstances” and “Your response: changing your child support assessment in special circumstances” see “administrative forms” below. 4. Objection requiring Child Support Registrar to reconsider Part VII of the CSR&CA was introduced on 1 January 2007 to provide for internal reconsideration of decisions of the Registrar under the CSAA and CSR&CA before they may be reviewed by the AAT (Step 5). Part VII is invoked when a person lodges an objection in writing to a Registrar’s decision. For the type of decision and who may object, see s 80 of the CSR&CA. An objection to a decision to accept an application for administrative assessment may not be lodged on the ground that the person is not a parent of the child: s 80(4) An objection, fully stating its grounds, is to be lodged in writing within 28 days (ss 81 and 84) and a copy served by the Registrar on the other party (s 85); may be lodged out of time (s 82); may be opposed (s 86); and must be considered within 60 days (s 83). There is no prescribed form for an objection. Update 64 March
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Change of assessment initiated by Child Support Registrar

chunks.text: (ss 81 and 84) and a copy served by the Registrar on the other party (s 85); may be lodged out of time (s 82); may be opposed (s 86); and must be considered within 60 days (s 83). There is no prescribed form for an objection. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.section: 2. Change of assessment initiated by Child Support Registrar

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 11 5. Review by Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) Reviews by the AAT are governed by Part IV of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 (Cth) (AATA) subject in some respects to Part VIIA of the CSR&CA. A person dissatisfied with the Registrar’s decision on reconsideration under Part VII (at Step 4 above) may (subject to s 89 CSR&CA) apply to the AAT for review of the decision (an “AAT first review”). An application to the Tribunal for review of a decision must be made in writing or by oral application (s 29 AATA). The usual time limit for doing so is 28 days (s 90 CSR&CA). The form Application for Review of Decision (with attached guide to applying for review) is downloadable here at our eBook or at our online “forms and precedents”. Your client may apply for an “AAT second review” if dissatisfied with a decision of the AAT to refuse an extension of time to apply for AAT first review; a decision on AAT first review of a care percentage deci- sion; or a decision in relation to the date of effect of a decision on AAT first review of a care percentage decision (s 96A CSR&CA). Appeals to a court from the AAT are governed by Part IVA of the AATA (see below “appeal to a court from AAT on a question of law”). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 12 ADMINISTRATIVE FORMS Administrative forms are available online with explanatory notes at “child support forms”. These forms and notes are set out below and may be downloaded from our eBook or the Australian Government’s child support website. In alphabetical order, the administrative child support forms are as follows: • Application for child support assessment (Its link is at p 5-4 above, the others being on the government website above.) • Application for fixed annual rate not to be used form • Application for Post Separation Income to be Excluded form • Application to add a child to an existing child support assessment form • Application to change your assessment - special circumstances form • Application to reduce minimum assessment to nil form Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
