chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 16 CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE WORK STILL AVAILABLE TO LAWYERS There are still many child support and child maintenance avenues in which you may be called on for assistance, some of which are already evident, such as: • Negotiating for your clients a private child support arrangement • Explaining the administrative assessment and review procedures above, and the availability of guid- ance from the DHS website, to clients content to have the Child Support Registrar deal with their child support matter • Helping your clients complete any of the administrative applications or other forms set out above • Either you or your barrister representing your client for the purpose of making submissions to the AAT on your client’s behalf • Advising in property and spousal maintenance matters under the FLA as to the level of child support that is or is likely to be paid being a relevant factor under s 75(2)(na) • Advising in a child matter as to the child support consequences of a parenting arrangement, based on the amount of time the children will spend with each parent • Issuing the various court proceedings set out below Which court? The FCFCA or, in WA, the FCWA. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE WORK STILL AVAILABLE TO LAWYERS

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 17 PATERNITY DISPUTES For presumptions of paternity and the court’s power to order parentage testing, see “paternity” in Chapter 4. Application to court for a declaration as to paternity There are two types of declaration: 1. If the Registrar refuses to accept an application for child support, one of the reasons for which is the Registrar not being satisfied that the other party is a parent, an application may be made to a court for a declaration that a person should be assessed in respect of the costs of the child because the person is a parent of the child: s 106A of the CSAA. 2. If the Registrar accepts an application for administrative assessment of child support for a child, an application may be made to a court for a declaration that a party should not be assessed in respect of the costs of the child because the party is not a parent of the child: s 107 of the CSAA. The court will usually order that a parentage testing procedure be carried out for the purpose of obtain- ing information to assist in determining the parentage of the child: s 69W of the FLA. Under s 69W the order can be made on the court’s own initiative or on the application of a party; and may be directed to the child, the mother or any other person relevant to the question of determining paternity. Time limits The application must be filed within 56 days of receiving notice of the Registrar’s refusal to assess (s 106A CSAA) or its acceptance of an application for child support (s 107 CSAA): FLR 1.13(3) (in WA, FCR 69). The court may extend that time limit under FLR 15.06 (in WA, FCR 15). As to the relevant
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 56 days of receiving notice of the Registrar’s refusal to assess (s 106A CSAA) or its acceptance of an application for child support (s 107 CSAA): FLR 1.13(3) (in WA, FCR 69). The court may extend that time limit under FLR 15.06 (in WA, FCR 15). As to the relevant fac- tors, see Jordan & Fielding [2013] FCCA 725 at [28]-[30]. Refusal to submit to test A majority of the High Court said in G v H [1994] HCA 48 at [12] of its judgment: “ … in the circumstances … the … inference to be drawn from G’s continuing contravention of the order that he submit to testing was that it was more probable than not that the outcome of the test would be unfavourable to him. And that must lead to the finding that, on the probabilities, he was the father of the child.” A religious or cultural objection to the taking of blood (F & R [1992] FamCA 86) is no longer tenable as DNA testing is now by means of a mouth swab. The court is reluctant to deny an application for parent- age testing. See Duroux & Martin [1993] FamCA 125 where the Full Court held that paternity should fundamentally be regarded as a medical rather than a legal issue. Where alleged father is under 18 The testing of minors requires the consent of a parent or responsible person: F and R (above) at p 79,274–5. A child may be forcibly tested if he refuses when a parent or responsible person has consented on his behalf: see s 69Z and 69ZA. Testing procedure The regulations are made under s 69ZB, and test results received in evidence under s 69ZC. The testing Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 18 procedure is set out in FLRegs 21A to 21N. Testing should be carried out by laboratories accredited by the National Association of Testing Authorities, Australia (NATA): Regulation 21N. For an accredited lab near you, go to www.nata.com.au here at our eBook; click “find organisation” then enter “parentage” as your keyword then your state or territory, then “search”. Scroll down for the results. Suspension of payments A declaration under s 107 that a party should not be assessed because the party is not a parent does not operate as a stay of the assessment (s 109A). But an Applicant can notify Child Support of their application whereupon payments to the payee are suspended: s 79A of the CSR&CA. The liable parent must continue to pay the assessment, but the Child Support Registrar will retain amounts paid pending the Court’s decision. Under s 107(5), a successful s 107 application negates the assessment, and the court must as soon as practicable consider making an order under s 143 that any child support paid by such an applicant be recovered from the payee (see next paragraph). Recovery of child support from payee Overpaid amounts are recoverable from the payee, not the Registrar: Child Support Registrar & Z & T [2002] FamCA 182. While an application for recovery must be served on the Child Support Registrar, the liable parent and payee should be the only parties to the proceedings. Whether to require a payee to repay child support to a non-liable payer is discretionary: s 143 CSAA. Matters to be considered by the court as to whether to make such an order, as to the amount of any order and whether lump sum or periodic payment, are set out in s 143(3B) as follows: (a) whether the payee or payer
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: non-liable payer is discretionary: s 143 CSAA. Matters to be considered by the court as to whether to make such an order, as to the amount of any order and whether lump sum or periodic payment, are set out in s 143(3B) as follows: (a) whether the payee or payer knew or suspected, or should reasonably have known or suspected, that the payer was not a parent of the child; (b) whether the assessment resulted from the conduct or omission of either party; (c) any delay by the payer in applying for a declaration once they knew or should reasonably have known they were not a parent; (d) whether any other child support may become payable by the person who is a parent; (e) the relationship between payer and child; (f) the financial circumstances of payee and payer. Here are two cases – in the first, recovery was not required, but in the second, it was. “I met my other daddy” This remark to a father from one of his children set the cat among the pigeons in B & M [2003] FMCAfam 113, a case before Bryant CFM (as the Chief Justice of the Family Court then was). The ensuing paternity test confirmed “daddy” not to be the father of the eldest two of his three children, for whom he had been paying child support during an on/off kind of relationship over a period of some years. A number of other factors were at work, however, which now appear as matters to be considered in s 143(3B) (above), and in respect of which Bryant CFM (at paras 46–50) said this: Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 19 “The applicant contends that the wife was at best reckless and at worse deceitful towards him as regards paternity of both R and L. I do not accept that to be the case. This is not a case where the doubts about the children’s paternity were kept from (him). I am satisfied that (he) was aware that there were doubts about L’s paternity and about R, although I find that the mother did lead the father to believe in relation to R that it was highly likely that he was his child. Nevertheless, deceit as to paternity was not an issue. Unquestionably the husband hoped that both children were his but he was not deceived as to the possibility, however remote, that they might not be. That is important in my view because the husband thereafter made decisions about the support of the children and about the way in which the parties would conduct themselves as a family in this knowledge. The husband could at any time after the child support assessment was initially made in 1999 have requested paternity testing to satisfy himself that he had an obligation to support the children. He is not to be criticised for this because the actions he took were clearly done on the basis that both he and the wife accepted that they had a family unit and the issue simply did not arise. Their relationship was one which was described as ‘on/off’ for a number of years and did not finally break down until mid-2001. Even since that time the husband regards himself as having an important role in the children’s lives and there are orders for him to have contact with the children albeit that there are some problems with the contact with
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: number of years and did not finally break down until mid-2001. Even since that time the husband regards himself as having an important role in the children’s lives and there are orders for him to have contact with the children albeit that there are some problems with the contact with R. This reflects the reality of the ongoing personal relationship between the husband and the children. It is a relationship based upon the fact that he has been a father to all three of them and they have regarded him as such. It is in that context that the payments made by him occurred. Insofar as the wife is concerned she conducted herself on a similar basis to the husband, namely that despite their interpersonal difficulties, they had a family unit comprising the husband, wife and three children. There were periods of time up until their final separation when both of them were genuinely trying to reconcile despite their personal difficulties and the other relationships which each of them had at times. The wife has not in the past pursued the biological father of the children for child support, which is again commensurate with the way in which these parties conducted their lives together, as a family. I take all of (these) matters…into account and note that since August 2001 the husband has paid considerably less child support for A than was otherwise due. Having regard to the financial circumstances of each of the parties and to the history of their relationship, in my view a just and equitable result would be a situation where in effect the slate is wiped clean, there are no arrears for child support payments.” Note – The court also took into account (para 70) that the wife had the option of approaching the biological
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: their relationship, in my view a just and equitable result would be a situation where in effect the slate is wiped clean, there are no arrears for child support payments.” Note – The court also took into account (para 70) that the wife had the option of approaching the biological fathers for child support; would also have the assistance of her new partner; and that she herself was working. What to file? For both types of declaration and affidavits in support, see “procedure” and “precedents” in this chapter below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 20 A contrary view A contrary view was taken on the facts of DRP & AJL [2004] FMCAfam 440 by Riethmuller FM. In that case: • The parties agreed that the liable parent was not the biological father of the child. • While the father had paid over $20,000 to the mother in child support, he only sought recovery of $5,000 as he considered that reasonable. • It was held at [65]: “There is clearly a prima facie entitlement on the part of the applicant to a refund of the child support paid as provided for in section 143(1). This is subject to orders that the court may make adjusting the rights of the parties and the child under section 143(3) and the court’s power to make such orders as are ‘just and equitable’ to give effect to the rights of the parties and child.” • It was found at [68] that the mother’s conduct was “unfortunate” in that “she must have been aware throughout that there was the possibility that the applicant was not the father. Her failure to disclose this information, at least at the time she sought child support, has led to the circumstances with which the Court is now confronted”. • The parties earned similar incomes at the date of trial, and the mother had received a greater share of the parties’ property settlement. • The mother was ordered to re-pay the Applicant $5,000. Another partial repayment In Forsythe & Latimer & Anor [2010] FMCAfam 478, after $39,000 had been paid, $9,743 was or- dered to be repaid by the mother, being the amount paid to her after the DNA test result had become known. Examples of full repayment In Levine [2011] FMCAfam 821 at [61] the respondent, who (it was found)
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Anor [2010] FMCAfam 478, after $39,000 had been paid, $9,743 was or- dered to be repaid by the mother, being the amount paid to her after the DNA test result had become known. Examples of full repayment In Levine [2011] FMCAfam 821 at [61] the respondent, who (it was found) “must have had some idea that the Applicant was not the father”, was ordered to repay $13,000 plus costs of $4,000. Scarlett FM held that the court had no jurisdiction to order repayment of $5,400 paid under a voluntary agreement prior to the administrative assessment. In Radcliffe & Hall [2011] FMCAfam 781 at [64] the mother was ordered to repay by instalments the $3,730 sought, the key issue being the parties’ financial circum- stances. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 21 APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER Eventually, we get back to a Gyselman application, although via a different route. How and when? It is also a case of going back to the Assessment Act (CSAA) for this. Departure applications may be made to a court under Division 4 of Part 7 of the CSAA. Section 116(1) enables a liable parent or carer entitled to child support to apply to a court for an order departing from an administrative assessment in the special circumstances of the case if: (a) the Registrar has refused to make a determination under Part 6A and an objection to that refusal has been disallowed; (aa) after an objection to a decision about an assessment the Registrar has refused to make a Part 6A determination; (ab) the AAT has refused to make a Part 6A determination; (b) either is a party to an application pending before the court, and the court is satisfied that it would be in their interest for the court to consider making such an order; or (c) a liable parent has been assessed for the minimum annual rate of child support. Pending court proceedings? Paragraph (b) – the existence of pending proceedings in court (which can be in relation to any kind of matter) offers lawyers the readiest avenue to the court for a departure application, even if a Part 6A administrative review (Step 2 above) has not been conducted. Obtain advice from counsel first, however, as to the merits of taking this course if all the various administrative remedies have not been exhausted. Grounds for departure order A return to Gyselman [1991] FamCA 93, although s 117 of the CSAA is much changed since the obser- vations made about its wording and effect by
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: however, as to the merits of taking this course if all the various administrative remedies have not been exhausted. Grounds for departure order A return to Gyselman [1991] FamCA 93, although s 117 of the CSAA is much changed since the obser- vations made about its wording and effect by the Full Court in that case. Note – These are the same grounds as for an application for an administrative change of assessment before the Registrar (para 2 of “administrative review” above). While the form of application for administrative change (departure) might, for the court at least, over- simplify these grounds as being “the 10 reasons for making an application”, the form nevertheless contains a number of examples of each ground which it is useful to set out below as annotations to each ground of departure by the court. Section 117(1) provides that where an application is made to a court for an order departing from an administrative assessment of child support in the special circumstances of the case and the court is satisfied: • that one or more of the grounds for departure set out in s 117(2) exist; and • that it would be just and equitable for the child, the carer entitled to child support and liable parent Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 22 (relevant matters being in s 117(4) and (6)–(10) as set out below); and • otherwise proper (relevant matters being in s 117(5) summarised below), to make a departure order; the court may make the order. “Special circumstances” The Full Court in Gyselman at [39] said that the requirement of “special circumstances” in s 117(2): “…is intended to emphasize that the facts of the case must establish something which is special or out of the ordinary. That is, the intention of the Legislature is that the Court will not interfere with the administrative formula result in the ordinary run of cases.” The Court at [35] confirmed what is clear from this section, that the court “must address each of those three separate issues”. The grounds (The examples given below are by the former Child Support Agency and are copyright of the Common- wealth of Australia, and are reproduced under permission of the Commonwealth.) The grounds for departure under s 117(2) are: (a) that, in the special circumstances of the case, the capacity of either parent to provide financial support for the child is significantly reduced because of: (i) the duty of the parent to maintain any other child or another person (ii) special needs of any other child or person the parent has a duty to maintain Note – “This would include such things as unusual medical expenditure, facilities for a [disabled] child, etc. If necessary it could include ‘special needs’ in education”: Lightfoot & Hampson [1996] FamCA 8, or the needs of a gifted child: Kay J in Blamey [1994] FamCA 161. Examples • Your child has an ongoing medical condition that costs you extra for medical appointments, medication and therapy after deducting rebates and refunds from medical insurance. • Your child has a disability
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: [1996] FamCA 8, or the needs of a gifted child: Kay J in Blamey [1994] FamCA 161. Examples • Your child has an ongoing medical condition that costs you extra for medical appointments, medication and therapy after deducting rebates and refunds from medical insurance. • Your child has a disability and it costs you extra to cover special care arrangements. • You cannot claim normal costs of food, clothing, medical or day care. (iii) commitments of the parent necessary to enable the parent to support: (A) himself or herself The Full Court said in Gyselman at [96]: “The use of the word ‘necessary’ is not intended to produce an unrealistically low Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 23 standard of living for the non-custodian. (In) determining the financial capacity of the respondent to meet the claim for child maintenance, there is to be deducted from his income unavoidable or compulsory expenses together with necessary living expenses.’’ The writer [RGW] had argued before the trial judge for the deduction of the husband’s expenses and repayment of debt. The Full Court (at [103]) said: “Whether a particular obligation to pay off a debt should or should not be included within paragraph (a)(iii) depends upon the circumstances of the individual case… Pre-separation debts are not a separate category in their own right but they do arise from joint liabilities of the parties entered into prior to the separation and which one party may be left to meet. Debts incurred by the absent parent necessary to meet his changed circumstances, including furniture and accommodation, may fall within that provision. Many debts would not be included either because they are not sufficiently connected with the paragraph or because they are not reasonable in amount or could by rearrangement of that person’s finances or circumstances have been avoided.” The Court (at [114]) found that the husband’s credit card liability “was part of the property settlement adjustment and should…be disregarded”. The Court (at [70] and [114]) said that a post-separation car loan may not be allowable without some evidence of the necessity to buy the car beyond its being needed during time with the children; and as to furniture said (at [115]-[116]): “The husband borrowed about $2,500 to purchase furniture which he is repaying at $100 per fortnight. As he had no furniture of his own when he moved into his flat, it appears that this was necessary for his support. On the other hand (he) will receive
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: furniture said (at [115]-[116]): “The husband borrowed about $2,500 to purchase furniture which he is repaying at $100 per fortnight. As he had no furniture of his own when he moved into his flat, it appears that this was necessary for his support. On the other hand (he) will receive (a) property settlement. The question will then arise whether it would be appropriate for him to pay off these loans and thus rid himself of the periodic payments. It may not be reasonable for him to apply the whole of his property to this and in addition he may have significant legal costs. ( ... )” The Court referred (at [117]) to his claimed living expenses such as food, clothing, power, transport to which “there does not seem to have been any serious challenge”. Examples • You are still paying off a loan that you and the other parent had (Gyselman, above). • You have a medical condition costing you extra to support yourself. • Excessive superannuation or loan payments for a recreational vehicle/boat… will not be considered. (B) any other child or person the parent has a duty to maintain; A husband’s repayments on a loan for a car used by the wife was regarded as child support by Bryant CFM in B & M [2003] FMCAfam 113 at [40]. Examples • The necessary expenses of that child or person. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 24 • Your current spouse is financially dependent upon you because they are unable to support themselves due to a medical condition. (iv) high costs in enabling a parent to spend time with or communicate with any other child or person they have a duty to maintain if it costs more than 5% of the parent’s child support income as calculated in s 117(2B), but if the parent has at least 14% of the care of the child – one night a week – only travel costs enabling that care are allowed under s 117(2C). Examples (see “high costs” of enabling time with child at s 117(2)(b)(i) below) (aa) that, in the special circumstances of the case, the capacity of either parent to provide financial support for the child is significantly reduced because of the responsibility of the parent to maintain another child (the resident child) of the parent “Resident child” means a stepchild the other parent of whom is unable to support the child, but for the long definition see s 117(10). Examples • Your new partner has taken maternity leave to care for a new baby and is unable to support the resident child. • The child’s other parent is unable to support the child due to ill health. (b) that, in the special circumstances of the case, the costs of maintaining the child are significantly affected: (i) because of high cost of enabling a parent to spend time with or communicate with the child If it costs more than 5% of the parent’s child support income as calculated in s 117(2B); and, if the parent has at least “regular care” of the child, under s 5(2) meaning at least 14% of care (one night a week), those costs are limited to the cost
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: child If it costs more than 5% of the parent’s child support income as calculated in s 117(2B); and, if the parent has at least “regular care” of the child, under s 5(2) meaning at least 14% of care (one night a week), those costs are limited to the cost of travel to enable that care: s 117(2C). Bryant CFM in B & M [2003] FMCAfam 113 at [69] followed Kay J’s approach in Houlihan [1991] FamCA 99: “…to consider the amount the husband spends in excess of what the statute thinks is appropriate. It is to treat the husband in a like manner to somebody in a similar circum- stance by notionally reducing his child support income by the sum equivalent to the amount he would have to earn to have $2811 in his pocket…the cost of the two air fares…Taking into account his marginal tax rate of 30% the amount he would have to earn to provide him with $2811 after tax is $4015. If this amount is deducted from his child support income amount annual payment of $4326 or $83 per week is produced. In the circumstances I am satisfied that this process is a just and equitable result and also preserves the integrity of the child support assessment scheme as Kay J wished to do in Houlihan.” Examples • Airfares, bus, train, car costs for you to spend time with your child • Transport costs and overnight accommodation if you visit your child Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 25 • Long distance phone calls • You cannot claim costs of food, clothing or entertainment. Note – Section 117(2C)’s “travel only” amendment, which will apply to most fathers, now negates the ruling of the Full Court in Gyselman at [65] that “the provision is not confined to (the high cost of travel) and it will in an appropriate case include other costs… necessary for the non-custodian to incur for access to take place (which) may include accommodation”. (ia) because of special needs of the child Examples (see “special needs” at s 117(2)(a)(ii) above) (ib) because of the sole carer’s high child care costs for a child under 12 (if those costs exceed 5% of the carer’s taxable income under s 117(3A) and (3B)) Examples • Child care costs include day centre costs and before and after school care. • You can only claim actual costs after deducting rebates or government assistance available for child care. (ii) because the child is being cared for, educated or trained in the manner that was expected by his or her parents Examples • You and the other parent had agreed to send your child to a school that has high fees and educational expenses. • You and the other parent had agreed that your child should have music lessons or participate in sporting activities that have high costs. In F & S [2003] FMCAfam 531 at [15] Bryant CFM (as her Honour then was) applied Mee & Ferguson [1986] FamCA 3, saying: “The principles that emerged from the case…can be summarised as follows: a) where the non-custodian has agreed to the child attending a private school, that person is liable to contribute to the fees so long and to the extent that he or she has a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: Ferguson [1986] FamCA 3, saying: “The principles that emerged from the case…can be summarised as follows: a) where the non-custodian has agreed to the child attending a private school, that person is liable to contribute to the fees so long and to the extent that he or she has a reasonable financial capacity to continue to do so; b) where the non-custodian has not agreed to the child attending such a school, he or she is not liable to contribute to those expenses unless there are reasons relating to the child’s welfare which dictate attendance at the school rather than a non-private school. Then the non-custodian is required to contribute to the extent that he or she has a reasonable financial capacity to do so; and c) the mere fact that a non-custodian can afford the fees or is a wealthy person is not in itself a reason for imposing that liability.” Another example of a departure order so as to add school fees was Anderson [2014] FamCA 766. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 26 (c) that, in the special circumstances of the case, assessment of child support would result in an unjust and inequitable level of support by the liable parent because of: (i) the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of child Examples • Your child works and earns income to support themself. • Your children have inherited substantial assets that they are entitled to use. • Centrelink payments such as Youth Allowance are not considered part of a child’s income. (ia) the income, property and financial resources of either parent Examples • The income of one parent has changed significantly since the assessment was made. A tip Before your client thinks of bringing an application due to a reduction of their income, advise them to first lodge an “Estimate of income for use in a child support assessment” (para 1 of “administrative review” above). Kay J held in Mansfield [1991] FamCA 96 that an application under s 117(2)(c) based on a reduction of income could fail where the lodgment of an estimate of income would remedy the issue, as it could not be said that the administrative machinery in the Act produced an unjust or inequitable level of support. • One parent’s business structure means their earning capacity is not accurately reflected in their adjusted taxable income. Barry J held in Bassingthwaite & Leane [1993] FamCA 86 that while a liable parent is able to arrange their financial affairs as they see fit, they are not permitted to operate a business so that their child support obligations are reduced by alienating income or incurring business losses. • One parent has received a lump sum payment such as superannuation that was not taken into account in the property settlement. (ib) the earning capacity of either parent A
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: permitted to operate a business so that their child support obligations are reduced by alienating income or incurring business losses. • One parent has received a lump sum payment such as superannuation that was not taken into account in the property settlement. (ib) the earning capacity of either parent A liable parent’s child support income is based on earning capacity, not income. It is not open to a parent to quit their job or take lower paid employment in an attempt to minimise their obligations. In Spinks [2001] FamCA 197 at [37] Chisholm J said this: “The decisions seem to turn on whether the person acted reasonably in all the circumstances in taking the step that led to the reduced income. What is reasonable must be determined not only in the light of the particular facts, but also…in the light of the particular area of law involved. In child support cases…an important part of the context for determining what is reasonable is the explicit statement of the objects of the Act in s 4, in which there is a reference to the parents’ capacity.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 27 (ii) any payments, and any transfer of property, made or to be made by the liable parent to the child, to the carer entitled to child support or any other person for the benefit of the child Examples • Your property settlement transferred money into a bank account in the children’s names for their benefit. • You are paying off the mortgage on the house where your children live, and you have not yet had a property settlement. “Just and equitable” In determining this the court must have regard to the matters set out in s 117(4), including the parents’ primary duty to maintain their child; proper needs and means of the child; the means and commitments of each parent; a carer’s direct or indirect costs in providing care for the child; and any hardship. The Full Court said in Gyselman at [125]: “However, some of the matters listed in sub-section (4) may overlap with matters already considered under sub-section (2) and some of the paragraphs in sub-section (4) may be more significant in one case than they would be in another or of little relevance in a particular case. It is an essential part of the s 117 exercise to carry out the obligation under sub-section (4). However, that does not mean that it is necessary in each case to slavishly go through each of the paragraphs. The extent to which it is necessary to do so will depend upon the facts and conduct of the individual case and the analysis already performed under sub-section (2).” “Otherwise proper” In determining this the court must have regard to the parents’ primary duty to maintain their child and the effect that the order would have on the entitlement to, or rate of, any income
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: and conduct of the individual case and the analysis already performed under sub-section (2).” “Otherwise proper” In determining this the court must have regard to the parents’ primary duty to maintain their child and the effect that the order would have on the entitlement to, or rate of, any income tested pension, allowance or benefit: s 117(5) The Full Court said in Gyselman at [144]: “In the context of the statement by the Legislature that parents have the ‘primary duty to maintain the child’, the Court is required to consider whether the proposed reduction is ‘proper’ within this context, that is, the public interest and increased welfare expenditure.” “Proper needs of the child” In considering this the court must, under s 117(6), have regard to: • the manner in which the child is being, and in which the parents expected the child to be, cared for, educated or trained • any special needs of the child Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 28 “Income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of the child” In considering this the court, under s 117(7), must: • have regard to the capacity of the child to earn or derive income, including any assets of, under the control of or held for the benefit of the child that do not produce but are capable of producing income • disregard the means of any person who is not liable to maintain the child, or is liable but is not a party to the proceedings, unless in the special circumstances of the case, the court considers it appropriate to have regard to them • disregard any entitlement of child or carer entitled to child support to an income tested pension, allowance or benefit “Income, property, and financial resources of a parent” In considering this the court, under s 117(7A), must: • have regard to the capacity of the parent to derive income, including any assets of, under the control of or held for the benefit of the parent that do not produce but are capable of producing income • disregard the same two matters to be disregarded as applies for s 117(7) above “Earning capacity of a parent” In considering this the court, under s 117(7B), may determine a parent’s earning capacity to be greater than is reflected in his or her income only if the court is satisfied that: • one or more of the following applies: – the parent does not work despite ample opportunity to do so – the parent has reduced their hours of work below the normal hours for full-time work in their occupation – the parent has changed their occupation, industry or working pattern • the parent’s decision not to work, to reduce their hours, or to change their
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: ample opportunity to do so – the parent has reduced their hours of work below the normal hours for full-time work in their occupation – the parent has changed their occupation, industry or working pattern • the parent’s decision not to work, to reduce their hours, or to change their occupation, industry or working pattern, is not justified on the basis of: – their caring responsibilities, or – their state of health, and • the parent has not demonstrated that it was not a major purpose of that decision to affect the administrative assessment of child support in relation to the child Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 29 “Direct and indirect costs in providing care” In considering this, under s 117(4)(f), the court must have regard to the income and earning capacity forgone by the carer entitled to child support in providing that care: s 117(8) Departure order and property settlement If a property application under s 79 of the FLA is being heard at the same as your departure application (as occurred in the Gyselman trial), your client should argue that the court must regard this factor (forgone income and earning capacity) as informing its decision both as to ongoing child support under s 117(4) of the CSAA and the once-only capital provision of a s 75(2) adjustment to the property settlement. For the type of orders the court may make, see s 118. These include an order varying the annual rate of child support payable, or an order varying the various aspects of the assessment calculation such as a person’s cost percentage for a child, child support income, child support percentage, dependent child amount, self-support amount, and varying the costs of the children. Note – A pending departure application does not operate as a stay of an assessment: s 120. For a stay of the assessment, it is necessary to apply to the court for a stay under s 111C of the CSR&CA (see “application for a stay of proceedings” below). What to file? For a departure order and an affidavit in support, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 30 APPLICATION TO COURT FOR NON-PERIODIC CHILD SUPPORT This is Division 5 of Part 7 of the CSAA. If an administrative assessment is in force, either party may apply to the court under s 123(1) for: (a) Third party payments (in kind provision, such as school fees) an order that the liable parent provide child support otherwise than in the form of periodic amounts (which may or may not reduce the annual rate of child support payable); or (b) Lump sum payments (or transfer of property) an order that the liable parent provide child support in the form of a lump sum payment (including a transfer of property) to be credited against the assessed child support liability. Examples of third party payments The former Child Support Agency website (fact sheet “private payments”) gives the following examples: school fees, tuition or child care expenses; health insurance or payments for medical or dental treat- ment; food, clothing and household goods; rent, mortgage payments or free accommodation; loan, credit card or store account repayments; travel or holiday expenses; bills such as gas, electricity, tele- phone or council rates; motor vehicle expenses; sports club and coaching fees or other sporting expens- es; household repairs. (These examples are copyright of the Commonwealth of Australia, and are reproduced under permission of the Commonwealth.) What to file? For either type of application and affidavit in support, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. When an application may be made Only when an administrative assessment of child support is in force: s 123(2) Pending applications to court for a departure order Before hearing an application for non-periodic provision the court must determine any pending application for a departure order or for amendment of an administrative assessment more than 18 months old (see below): s 123(3) Also,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: child support is in force: s 123(2) Pending applications to court for a departure order Before hearing an application for non-periodic provision the court must determine any pending application for a departure order or for amendment of an administrative assessment more than 18 months old (see below): s 123(3) Also, the Registrar may intervene in the proceedings: s 123(4) Grounds for either type of non-periodic order The court may make an order under (a) or (b) upon the application of the carer entitled to child support or the liable parent in almost the same circumstances – upon the court being satisfied that it would be just and equitable for the child and parties, and otherwise proper, to make the order (and, in the case of (b), the lump sum equals or exceeds the annual rate of child support payable under the administrative assessment): ss 124 (non-periodic provision) and 123A (credited lump sum). “A lump sum payment” may include a payment by way of transfer of property: s 123A(2) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 31 Factors to be considered Under ss 124(2) (non-periodic provision) and 123A(4) (credited lump sum) the court must have regard to: • the administrative assessment • any Part 6A departure determination by the Registrar • any departure order by the court • whether the carer is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit • and, if not, whether their circumstances are such that they would be unable to support themselves without such pension, allowance or benefit upon the making of the order • the matters set out in s 117(4)–(8) set out above under “grounds for departure order” Matters to be specified in order for credited lump sum An order for a lump sum payment must state its amount and state that the payment is to be credited against a specified percentage of the amounts payable under the assessment: s 123A(3) Matters to be specified in order for non-periodic provision An order under s 124 must state whether the annual rate of child support payable by the liable parent under the assessment is to be reduced by the non-periodic child support ordered to be provided by the liable parent and, if so, state either the amount or percentage of that reduction: s 125(1) and (3) The Registrar will then adjust the assessment accordingly (s 127) but will also make a notional assessment under Part 7A to be used in the maintenance test in working out a person’s rate of family tax benefit (ss 146A and B). Note – The court may state in an order under s 124 that the annual rate of payable child support is not to be so reduced only if it is satisfied that in the special circumstances of the case it would be just and equitable
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: benefit (ss 146A and B). Note – The court may state in an order under s 124 that the annual rate of payable child support is not to be so reduced only if it is satisfied that in the special circumstances of the case it would be just and equitable for the child and parties, and otherwise proper, that such an order be made: s 125(2) In this regard, the court must consider the matters set out in s 117(4)–(8). Court’s approach to non-periodic child support The Full Court case of Ivanovic [1996] FamCA 41 best explains this, and also how matters like this get to court. The steps taken by the wife (including her mistakes) were as follows: 1. Administrative assessment by Child Support Registrar for H to pay W child support of $457 per month. 2. W applied to Registrar for change of assessment under Part 6A due to school fees costing $500 per month. Application refused. 3. W re-applied to Registrar for a change of assessment on the same grounds. Application refused as that ground had already been argued and dismissed. 4. W applied to the court for non-periodic support of $20,000 for school fees. Case was dismissed due to want of jurisdiction (W having applied under FLA not the CSAA). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 32 5. W re-applied to the court under the CSAA. Was awarded the $20,000 sought for school fees, and an order under s 125 that the amount not be credited against H’s liability under the assessment. The court amended W’s application so as to be under s 123 (not s 124) and also noted that W could have applied to the court for a departure order at Stage 3. 6. H appealed to the Full Court. The Full Court’s reason for its decision was summarised at [82]-[94] as follows: “The wife here seeks payment of school fees as the alteration to the child support assessment. (…) We agree with the dictum of Fogarty J [in Lightfoot & Hampson [1996] FamCA 8] that s 125 was inserted in the legislation ‘because it was apprehended that there might be unusual circumstances where there should not be a credit (against an existing assessment)’... We must therefore consider whether the facts of the present case come within the ambit of this description. In our opinion, the dominant purpose of the (CSAA) is to ensure, as far as possible, that children receive proper and adequate support. We think that in order to apply the test, it is necessary to look at the cumulative effect of the particular circumstances of the case, for although an examination of each individual factor may not produce such a result, a combination of all factors may well do so. In our opinion, the relevant factors in this case which lead us to the conclusion that this case does fall within s 125 are as follows. First, His Honour (the trial judge, Warnick J) found that prior to separation, it was the intention of both parties that the children should have a private school education. Secondly, His
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: this case which lead us to the conclusion that this case does fall within s 125 are as follows. First, His Honour (the trial judge, Warnick J) found that prior to separation, it was the intention of both parties that the children should have a private school education. Secondly, His Honour found that on the probabilities, the husband could have earned enough to have paid a proper level of child support and to have paid those fees had he wished to do so. Thirdly, as a consequence of the husband’s conduct, the wife has incurred a financial detriment by having had no contribution by the husband towards school fees. Fourthly, His Honour found that the husband was strongly motivated not to pay for private school education for the children and suggested that such lack of motivation extended to the payment of maintenance generally. He further found that he had deliberately reduced his income with a view to evading his child support obligations. Fifthly, His Honour found that he had deliberately concealed past income and was likely to continue to do so in the future. While all of the above factors are relevant, we think that the last two factors are particularly important, since the effect of the husband’s conduct as found by His Honour, was to heavily reduce the quantum of periodical payments for which the husband was liable and render the payments liable to further reduction if the payment of private school fees was to be credited against them. (…) There are some additional factors which support such a conclusion, while not being critical to it, these being the husband’s poor record of payment of periodical payments, the fact that he has assets sufficient to meet the additional obligation that His Honour’s order imposed and the fact that he
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: (…) There are some additional factors which support such a conclusion, while not being critical to it, these being the husband’s poor record of payment of periodical payments, the fact that he has assets sufficient to meet the additional obligation that His Honour’s order imposed and the fact that he allowed these proceedings to go ahead uncontested...” See Lightfoot and Ivanovic applied in Yanda & Jacome [2023] FedCFamC1A 116 at [5]-[12]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 33 Nil administrative assessments Lightfoot & Hampson (above) was a case where the court was unable to make a non-periodic order under s 123 to change the periodic child support assessment because it had been a nil assessment, meaning there was no order that could be changed. In such circumstances, you should apply instead for a departure order in the form of a lump sum under s 116 of the CSAA. Examples of non-periodic orders • Private school fees, as above in Ivanovic. The order made by Warnick J (left undisturbed by the Full Court) was that to satisfy his judgment that H pay $20,000 for school fees, an order was made for the sale of a parcel of land (owned by H) by W who was appointed the trustee for sale (the proceeds of which to be applied to W as to the $20,000 and H as to the balance of proceeds) • “Capitalisation orders may well be appropriate where there are difficulties in enforcement or where it is proper to sever the financial link between the parties”: Prpic [1994] FamCA 155 at [53] • Where there are assets but, especially as to income, “the father will do everything he can to avoid paying proper child support”: Lindenmayer J in Dwyer & Mcguire [1993] FamCA 82 at [101]. See also Hartnett & Baker [1995] FamCA 144; Bolton [1992] FamCA 48 and Melville & Dent (No. 4) [2009] FamCA 430 at [69]-[83] (unreliable respondent had access to capital) cf. Maider & Carrigan [2009] FamCA 483 at [90]-[102] (lump sum not ordered as respondent undertook to pay all peri- odic child support as assessed) • A husband’s repayments on a loan for a car used by the wife was regarded as child support by Bryant
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: had access to capital) cf. Maider & Carrigan [2009] FamCA 483 at [90]-[102] (lump sum not ordered as respondent undertook to pay all peri- odic child support as assessed) • A husband’s repayments on a loan for a car used by the wife was regarded as child support by Bryant CFM in B & M [2003] FMCAfam 113 at [40] • An unemployed father was ordered to pay a lump sum of $10,000 from a trust fund: Mancuso & Abbott [2012] FMCAfam 289 Sample of order capitalising payments for five years Note – The following order, capitalising child support for five years as sought by M (based on child support payable assuming a child support income of average weekly earnings), was made (without discount) by Bryant CFM in R & R (No. 1) [2002] FMCAfam 153 at [42]-[43] and [67]-[75] upon the Court doubting the motives of F who was paying (then) minimum child support of $5 per week and yet forewent $100,000 from his father’s estate, allegedly in favour of his sister and received $164,000 from his father’s estate which he used to reduce his own mortgage instead of paying child support. (1) THAT the administrative assessment of child support for the children M L R born 14 April 1988 and R N R born 11 October 1990 for the following periods be departed from: (a) 1 December 2000 to 28 February 2002; (b) 17 January 2001 to 28 February 2002; (c) 2 March 2001 to 28 February 2002; (d) 10 May 2001 to 28 February 2002; (e) 1 October 2001 to 31 December 2002. (2) THAT in lieu of the assessments departed from: (a) For the period from 1 December 2000 to 13 June 2001 the Father’s annual child support income be fixed at $82,485.00; Update 64 March
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: (d) 10 May 2001 to 28 February 2002; (e) 1 October 2001 to 31 December 2002. (2) THAT in lieu of the assessments departed from: (a) For the period from 1 December 2000 to 13 June 2001 the Father’s annual child support income be fixed at $82,485.00; Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 34 (b) For the period from 14 June 2001 to 30 June 2002 the Father’s annual child support income be fixed at an amount equal to average weekly earnings during that period. (3) THAT the [Child Support Registrar] give effect to the departures from the administrative assessment in Orders (1) and (2) hereof. (4) THAT for each 12 month period 1 July 2002 to 30 June 2007 the Father’s annual child support income be fixed at an amount equivalent to average weekly earnings (adjusted from time to time) and otherwise assessed in accordance with the administrative provisions of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. (5) THAT the Father forthwith pay to the Mother’s solicitors, M H A the sum of $50,000.00 to be held on trust by them in the names of the Mother and Father as trustees upon trust to: (a) Firstly, to pay to the Child Support [Registrar] on a monthly basis the amount due pursuant to Child Support Assessments created by the Child Support [Registrar] in accordance with these Orders; (b) Unless otherwise ordered by a Court exercising jurisdiction under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 as at 1 July 2007 disburse any monies then remaining: (i) firstly in payment of any outstanding fees to the Child Support [Registrar]; and (ii) any balance then remaining to the Father. (6) THAT the Wife’s amended Application filed on 4 February 2002 otherwise be dismissed. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
