chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 35 MODIFICATION OF ORDERS FOR NON-PERIODIC CHILD SUPPORT A court may under s 129(1) of the CSAA discharge, suspend or, if suspended, revive an order made under s 123A or 124, and may vary an order under s 124 in any way. Grounds for such an order The court must not make an order modifying an order under s 123A or 124 unless it is satisfied, having regard to any matter specified in s 123A or statement made under s 125, that it would be: • just and equitable for the child and the parties, and • otherwise proper to make the order: s 129(2) Grounds for varying an order under s 124 The court must vary such an order unless, under s 129(3), it is also satisfied: • that the variation is justified because of a change in the circumstances of the child, the carer entitled to child support or the liable parent since the order was made • that the variation is justified because of a change in the cost of living since the order was made • in a case of an order made by consent – that the order is not proper or adequate, or • that material facts were withheld from the court that made the order, or material evidence previously given before such court was false. “Just and equitable” In considering this the court must have regard to the matters set out in s 117(4)–(8). Cost of living Changes must be as have occurred in the relevant Consumer Price Index (CPI), and 12 months must have elapsed since the order before the court may vary the order on this ground: s 129(9) and (10) Variation of consent order In considering this the court must have regard to any
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: Changes must be as have occurred in the relevant Consumer Price Index (CPI), and 12 months must have elapsed since the order before the court may vary the order on this ground: s 129(9) and (10) Variation of consent order In considering this the court must have regard to any payments, and any transfer of property, previously made by the liable parent to the child, to the carer entitled to child support or to any other person for the benefit of the child: s 129(8) Discharge of an order Does not prevent recovery of any arrears due under the order at the time of discharge: s 129(11) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO COURT FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 36 CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENTS Any extract from the DHS or the former Child Support Agency (CSA) website below is copyright of the Commonwealth of Australia, and is reproduced under permission of the Commonwealth. What is the demand for child support agreements? Most parents seem to prefer the flexibility of not being tied to an agreement. Research conducted in 2006 by Ibolya Losoncz, Senior Analyst, Family Payments & Policy Branch, Department of Families, Community Services & Indigenous Affairs (“Longitudinal study of children – data on families with child support entitlement”) found that: “The proportion of resident parents who reported not having a child support agreement was surprisingly high (…) We found that resident parents without an agreement tend to be a ‘mixed bag’. It included a sizable group of parents with shared care arrangements. It also included a group of older parents with high educational attainment and income who may have above average means to provide for their children and therefore are less likely to pursue a child support agreement. At the same time, this group had a relatively high proportion of parents with low socio-economic status, many of them of indigenous origin, reporting low educational attainment and income, and low attachment to the labour force. This raises the concern that a significant proportion of separated families who are already facing multiple disadvantages tend not to have an agreement to ensure that their children receive the financial support they are eligible to from their non-resident parent.” Parents can choose from two types of child support agreements under Part 6 of the CSAA – binding child support agreements or limited child support agreements. Binding child support agreements Section 80C sets out the technical requirements for an agreement to be binding. They mirror the requirements for a financial agreement
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: can choose from two types of child support agreements under Part 6 of the CSAA – binding child support agreements or limited child support agreements. Binding child support agreements Section 80C sets out the technical requirements for an agreement to be binding. They mirror the requirements for a financial agreement under Part VIIIA of the FLA. Binding child support agreements have the following differences from limited child support agreements: • Each party must first seek independent legal advice (from another lawyer) about the agreement’s advantages and disadvantages and effect on their rights • Each lawyer must provide a certificate that they provided that advice (see “certificate of legal practitioner” under “administrative forms” below) • The agreement may be for any amount, even less than the assessed amount • The agreement may only be ended by a new binding agreement (for which independent advice is also required) terminating the agreement, or a court order setting it aside • A child support assessment does not have to be in place (Note – unless non-periodic provision is included in the agreement) • After signature, a copy of the agreement must be given to each party Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 37 Advantages and disadvantages of binding child support agreements You may be consulted about a binding child support agreement by your own client, or by someone else’s client for independent legal advice under s 80C(2) about its advantages and disadvantages and effect on their rights. In either case, it is suggested that you discuss with them: • any assessment made or, if none, an estimate of child support: – see “child support estimator” on the first page of this chapter • any misunderstanding about a binding agreement’s consequences • the prospect of having a limited child support agreement instead (see below) • any unequal bargaining power between the parties • that any change requires consent or a court finding “exceptional circumstances” In this statement from the former CSA website, advantages seem to merge with disadvantage: “Binding agreements are intended to provide a high level of certainty and finality about child support arrangements for parents. Legal advice is therefore required to ensure that parents understand the consequences of making such an agreement, and to provide some protection against coercive or misleading behaviour.” A binding agreement is bound to be an advantage to a payer wanting to lock the other party into an arrangement which will remain fixed, regardless of any future change in the parties’ needs or means that might render the agreement unfair. But what of the payee? Another advantage may be said to be the freedom to arrange one’s own affairs flexibly, although the use of non-periodic provision, such as school fees, and lump sum payments are available options to periodic child support under the Act without an agreement. The former CSA’s website stated that “due to the (stringent) requirements for ending a binding agree- ment, it is particularly important that binding agreements
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the use of non-periodic provision, such as school fees, and lump sum payments are available options to periodic child support under the Act without an agreement. The former CSA’s website stated that “due to the (stringent) requirements for ending a binding agree- ment, it is particularly important that binding agreements are drafted in a way that takes account of the changing circumstances in which parents may find themselves”, yet the most careful drafting is unlikely to be able to make such an agreement both “final” and open to change. The former CSA itself “recognise[d] that it can be difficult to anticipate what will happen…into the future” (see below). Clauses such as for CPI or other increases are unlikely to resemble the parties’ unfolding financial reality. Even consent to renegotiate upon significant change of needs or means would require a court order if they could not agree when such a clause should be invoked. Ultimately, a person who does wish an account to be taken of changing circumstances is unlikely to be seeking a binding agreement in preference to a limited agreement that is specially designed for that purpose. Terminating binding child support agreements Binding child support agreements cannot be varied (s 80CA). Neither can limited child support agree- ments (s 80F). Binding agreements can, however, be terminated by a termination agreement, a new binding child support agreement or court order (s 80D). See “application to set aside child support agreement” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 38 Limited child support agreements Limited agreements are more realistic as they may be brought to an end after three years if a party so wishes, or sooner in the case of a significant change of financial circumstances. They do have to be in writing, signed by both parents (s 80E) and lodged with the Child Support Regis- trar (to be enforceable), but separate legal advice is unnecessary. The requirements for a limited agree- ment are: • That there must be a child support assessment already in place • That the annual amount payable under the agreement must be equal to or more than the assessed annual amount Terminating limited child support agreements Section 80G enables limited child support agreements to be ended: • by making a new child support agreement replacing the agreement • by an order setting it aside (“application to set aside child support agreement” below) • if the notional assessment changes by more than 15% from the previous assessment, in a way not anticipated in the agreement, and one of the parents wants to end it Note – The Child Support Registrar is required, upon accepting a child support agreement, to make a “notional assessment” of the annual rate of child support that would be payable but for the agreement. That notional assessment enables parents to keep in touch with what would be payable, and is also used in the maintenance income test in working out a person’s rate of family tax benefit: Part 7A of the CSAA (s 146B). “This provides a safeguard, so that if circumstances change significantly the parties will not be locked into an agreement that does not reflect those new circumstances.” (former CSA website) • if more than three years has passed and written notice is given
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: benefit: Part 7A of the CSAA (s 146B). “This provides a safeguard, so that if circumstances change significantly the parties will not be locked into an agreement that does not reflect those new circumstances.” (former CSA website) • if more than three years has passed and written notice is given to the Child Support Registrar by a parent who wants to end it “This recognises that it can be difficult to anticipate what will happen more than three years into the future and provides the parties with the flexibility to elect to end their agreement if it no longer suits their circumstances.” (former CSA website) Change of care – Suspension and termination of agreements See s 86 which applies retrospectively from 1/7/18 to all agreements. In the absence of a change of care clause every child support agreement is suspended for up to 28 days if the eligible carer’s percent- age of care drops below 35% (s 86(1)). The suspension may apply for up to 26 weeks if the agreement provides for more than a 28 day suspension; the parties notify the Registrar within 26 weeks that they want a suspension for more than 28 days; or special circumstances are established (s 86(2)). The agreement resumes if the eligible carer (whose care dropped below 35 per cent) becomes an eligible carer again within the relevant period. If that period lapses without such a resumption the agree- ment is terminated (ss 80D(2A) and 80G(1B)). See The Guide here at our eBook. We recommend that all clients with an active child support agreement be advised to review their position. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 39 What may be included in child support agreements? Both types of agreement must under s 81(2) comply with s 84 by containing at least one of these: • periodic child support • a variation of the rate at which a parent is already liable to pay periodic child support • any provision that may be included in a departure order by a court • a non-periodic provision (e.g. school fees), stating how it is to reduce the annual rate of child support payable under the child support assessment (if at all): ss 84(1)(d) and (6) • a lump sum payment (and any transfer or settlement of property), stating that it is to be credited against the liability under the assessment: ss 84(1)(e) and (7) Note – Agreements must also under that section comply with s 82 (made in relation to children entitled to an assessment) and s 83 (made between parties entitled to an assessment). For sample clauses, see “application for departure order” below under “precedents”. Form of agreement The DHS provides a form for this. This form is annotated throughout, so is a helpful format for those unfamiliar with child support agreements. The form “child support agreement” (under “administrative forms” above) can either set out the agreement’s terms, or have the agreement attached to it. The form incorporates an application to the Registrar for acceptance of the agreement. Note – You must attach to a binding child support agreement a lawyer’s certificate under s 80C CSAA. Precedent agreements (and letter of advice) In addition to the Agency’s own form of agreement (see “administrative forms” above) precedents for a limited child support agreement and a binding child support agreement are set out below after the section “registering an agreement that provides for non-periodic
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: under s 80C CSAA. Precedent agreements (and letter of advice) In addition to the Agency’s own form of agreement (see “administrative forms” above) precedents for a limited child support agreement and a binding child support agreement are set out below after the section “registering an agreement that provides for non-periodic support” and are also available from ’s Online Forms and Precedents at www.thefamilylawbook.com.au (as is a precedent letter of advice). Registering an agreement that provides for periodic support only Once an agreement is made, the parties have the option of whether to register the agreement with the Child Support Registrar. Relevant to this choice is whether an assessment is already in place and the type of child support that is payable under the agreement. In most cases, it is beneficial to register the agreement as the payee is then able to ask the Registrar to monitor and collect any periodic payments payable under the agreement. If arrears accrue, the Registrar has the power to garnishee the liable parent’s tax returns, and treat the debt as one due to the Commonwealth. If an assessment is already in place, the agreement should be registered so as to ensure that the Registrar updates the liable parent’s obligation to pay in accordance with the agreement. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 40 To register, the parties must lodge with the Registrar (s 89 CSAA) an application to Registrar for acceptance of the agreement, using the form “Child Support Agreement” (under “administrative forms” above) to which the agreement’s terms must be attached or set out in the form itself. If an assessment is not in place: • the parties need not register the agreement if they are content to enforce it between themselves • in the case of a limited agreement, the parties will be unable to register the agreement until an administrative assessment has first been made or applied for: s 92(3) • the parties may register a binding child support agreement whether an assessment is in force or not. Registering an agreement that provides for non-periodic support The Child Support Registrar has no power to enforce payment of non-periodic child support, but once the agreement has been registered in the FCFCA or FCWA parties may file enforcement action themselves: s 95(3) CSAA. Such action would be taken in the FCFCA or FCWA: see the section “collection of child support and child maintenance” below. Note – You must have an administrative assessment in place before you may register an agreement that includes lump sum provisions: s 84(7) CSAA. While it is usually beneficial to have an assessment in place before registering an agreement that includes (third party) non-periodic provisions, such as school fees (so as to properly assess the effect of such payments being credited against any assessment) it is not mandatory as the acceptance of the agreement has the same effect as an application for an assessment in that a notional assessment will issue (see ss 93 and 95 CSAA). (An assessment is mandatory for a lump sum provision as the lump sum acts as a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: assessment) it is not mandatory as the acceptance of the agreement has the same effect as an application for an assessment in that a notional assessment will issue (see ss 93 and 95 CSAA). (An assessment is mandatory for a lump sum provision as the lump sum acts as a credit against the assessment. The crediting of school fees and other third party payments is possible but not necessary.) With an assessment in force, register the agreement with the Child Support Registrar, using the proce- dure (and form) above. Upon receiving notice that the Child Support Registrar has accepted the agreement, register the agree- ment with the FCFCA under FLR 15.08 (in WA, FCR 476) by sending the Court a letter and an affidavit (both available online at our website) in the following terms: The Registrar, Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 41 Dear Registrar, (NAME) – CHILD SUPPORT MATTER I refer to the above matter and confirm that I act for [X]. [Insert name of solicitor’s firm] act for [Y]. I seek to register the parties’ binding child support agreement with the Court under Rule 15.08 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. There are no proceedings on foot. I enclose for your attention: 1. Affidavit of the writer sworn [date], annexing a copy of the Agreement (1 x 2); 2. Stamped self-addressed envelope. I look forward to receiving registered copies in the envelope provided. Yours faithfully, Swear this affidavit (go online to www.thefamilylawbook.com.au for “affidavit” under “forms”) in the following terms to accompany the above letter: 1. I am a lawyer in the employ of the legal firm [name]. 2. I act for [X]. 3. [X] and [his/her] spouse, [Y] separated on [date]. 4. [X] and [Y] have [number] children, namely: (a) [full name of child] born [date]; and (b) [full name of child] born [date]. 5. [X] and [Y] have entered into a binding child support agreement within the meaning of Sections 80C and 81 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (“the Agreement”). 6. A true copy of the Agreement is annexed hereto and marked “A”. 7. The Agreement has been lodged with and accepted by the Child Support Registrar, a true copy of written confirmation of which is annexed hereto and marked “B”. 8. By filing this affidavit, I seek to register the Agreement under Rule 15.08 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. 9. The facts deposed to above are within my own knowledge except those that are deposed to from information only, in respect of which my
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: filing this affidavit, I seek to register the Agreement under Rule 15.08 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. 9. The facts deposed to above are within my own knowledge except those that are deposed to from information only, in respect of which my means of knowledge and source of information appear on the face of this affidavit. Precedent agreements available in our eBook and online The following child support agreements are downloadable at the links in each document title in our eBook and at our online “forms and precedents”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 42 BINDING CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT THIS AGREEMENT made the ______ day of ______________ 20 ______ BETWEEN: [FULL NAME OF FATHER] of [address] in the [State/Territory] of [specify] (hereinafter the “Father”) AND: [FULL NAME OF MOTHER] of [address] in the [State/Territory] of [specify] (hereinafter the “Mother”) RECITALS A. This is a binding child support agreement under section 80C and section 81 of the Act. B. The children are: 1) under the age of 18; 2) neither married nor living in a bona fide de facto relationship; 3) present in Australia at the date of this Agreement; 4) Australian citizens; and 5) ordinarily resident in Australia at the date of this Agreement. C. The parties are the parents of the children. D. The parties [married/commenced cohabitation] on [date] and separated on [date]. E. The children live with the Mother and spend each alternate weekend and half of each school holiday period with the Father [or specify applicable sharing of time]. F. The Mother is the eligible carer entitled to support under the provisions of the Act in relation to the children and is the person to whom child support is to be paid or provided under this Agreement. G. The Father is the liable parent and is the liable party for the purposes of section 84 of the Act. H. The Mother [is/is not] in receipt of the Family Tax Benefit A. I. The Mother [is/is not] in receipt of an income-tested pension. J. [Delete this recital if the Agreement is for periodic payments only, i.e. if there is no provision for non-periodic child support.] As of the date of this Agreement, an administrative assessment is in force in relation to the children in respect of whom this Agreement is made. IT IS AGREED DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATIONS 1.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the Agreement is for periodic payments only, i.e. if there is no provision for non-periodic child support.] As of the date of this Agreement, an administrative assessment is in force in relation to the children in respect of whom this Agreement is made. IT IS AGREED DEFINITIONS AND INTERPRETATIONS 1. In this Agreement: “Act” means the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and extends to all statutes amending, consolidating or replacing same; “Assessment” means any administrative assessment or amended administrative assessment for a Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 43 parent to pay child support, made or to be made by the Registrar pursuant to the Act; “Children” means: (a) [first child’s full name] born on [date of birth] (hereinafter “[first name]”); and (b) [second child’s full name] born on [date of birth] (hereinafter “[first name]”); and (c) [third child’s full name] born on [date of birth] (hereinafter “[first name]”); “Eligible carer” means a person with at least shared care of a child and otherwise as defined by section 7B of the Act; “Liable parent” means a parent by whom child support is to be paid or provided in this Agreement; “Registrar” means Child Support Registrar; “The parties” means the Mother and Father. 2. The terms of this Agreement are operative from the date of the Agreement. 3. This Agreement will cease to operate in relation to a child (except for any arrears due on the date this Agreement ceases to operate): 3.1 upon completion of Year 12 or, should the child not complete secondary schooling, upon the child’s 18th birthday; 3.2 if the child dies; 3.3 if the child ceases to be an eligible child under the regulations made under section 22(1) of the Act; 3.4 if the child is adopted; 3.5 if the child becomes a member of a couple as defined by the Act; 3.6 if the liable parent dies; or 3.7 if the eligible carer ceases to be an eligible carer of the child. The Agreement will remain operative in relation to any child to whom paragraph 3 does not apply. 4. chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 53 APPLICATION TO SET ASIDE CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT Child support agreements are covered by Part 6 of the Assessment Act. See “child support agreements” above. A party to a child support agreement may apply to a court for an order setting aside the agreement under s 136 of the CSAA. The section extends to a termination agreement, being an agreement terminating a prior child support agreement. Both agreements must have been accepted by the Registrar under s 92. Grounds for such an order These are set out in s 136(2) which requires the court to be satisfied: Limited or binding child support agreements (a) that the applicant’s agreement was obtained by fraud or a failure to disclose material information; or (b) that another party to the agreement or someone acting for another party: (i) exerted undue influence or duress in obtaining that agreement; or (ii) engaged in unconscionable or other conduct; to such an extent that it would be unjust not to set aside the agreement; or (c) Limited child support agreements (i) that because of a significant change in the circumstances of a party or child covered by the agreement, it would be unjust not to set aside the agreement; or (ii) that the agreement provides for an annual rate of child support that is not proper or adequate, taking into account all the circumstances of the case (including the financial circumstances of the parties); or (d) Binding child support agreements that because of exceptional circumstances that have arisen since the agreement was made, relating to a party or child covered by the agreement, the applicant or child will suffer hardship if the agreement is not set aside. See the cases set out in the chapter “property” in “exceptional new circumstances relating to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO SET ASIDE CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT

chunks.text: of exceptional circumstances that have arisen since the agreement was made, relating to a party or child covered by the agreement, the applicant or child will suffer hardship if the agreement is not set aside. See the cases set out in the chapter “property” in “exceptional new circumstances relating to welfare of child” under “setting aside or varying property orders” as to just how tough this requirement can be. “‘Exceptional circumstances’ … generally encompasses events which are quite extraordinary, (…) occurred unexpectedly, and (…) could not have been reasonably foreseen or contemplated. Those features incorporate both subjective and objective considerations. (…) It is a question of fact and degree in each case”: Venson (No. 2) [2010] FamCA 963 at [99] (Austin J). Also see Keane & Keane and Ors [2013] FamCA 332 at [40]-[80]. A “radical” change of care and relevant legislative change were held to have been “exceptional circumstances” in Cheyne & Masters & Anor (SSAT Appeal) [2014] FCCA 856. “Hardship” was said by the Full Court in Whitford [1979] FamCA 3 at [32] (for the purpose of s 44(4) as to leave to proceed) “to be akin to … hardness, severity, privation, that which is hard to bear or a substantial detriment”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO SET ASIDE CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 54 Onus of proof The applicant for an order under s 136 CSAA bears the onus of proving his case. In Telama (No. 2) [2017] FamCAFC 194 the payee mother won her appeal against the granting of the father’s application (for an order setting aside a binding child support agreement) on the ground that the father’s inad- equate disclosure made findings of “exceptional circumstances” and “hardship” impossible. Where the court sets aside a child support agreement • and is satisfied as to s 117(1)(b) matters (as to grounds for departure, “just and equitable” and “otherwise proper”) the court may make a departure order: s 136(4) • but is not satisfied as to those matters, and the payee has received or will receive benefits under the agreement, the court may still make a departure order where it is just and equitable to do so, having regard to the benefits already received under the agreement: s 136(5) • the court may make such orders (including orders for the transfer of property) as it considers just and equitable for the purpose of preserving or adjusting the rights of the child or a party to the agreement: s 137(2) Note – The court must have regard to the interests of, and make any order for the protection of, a bona fide purchaser or other person interested: s 137(4) What to file? For an application and affidavit in support, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION TO SET ASIDE CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 55 APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS If a proceeding has been instituted: • in a court having jurisdiction under the CSR&CA • before the child support registrar under Part VII CSR&CA (objection) • before the AAT for an AAT first review under Part VIIA CSR&CA • under Part 6A or 7 CSAA (administrative or judicial departure order) a party may apply to the court for an order staying or otherwise affecting the operation of the CSAA or CSR&CA until the hearing if the court considers it desirable to do so, taking into account the interests of those who may be affected by the outcome: s 111C CSR&CA. A court has no jurisdiction to stay an overseas order in proceedings to vary it etc under FLReg 36: Child Support Registrar & Vladimir and Anor [2017] FamCAFC 56 at [44]-[47]. Relevant matters include whether refusing to grant a stay will make any later proceedings as to an as- sessment or agreement nugatory; the balance of convenience; any financial hardship if a stay is or is not granted; the financial needs of any child; any delay in applying; the bona fides of the stay; and the merits of the application: Garth & Hope [2011] FMCAfam 41 at [128]-[132]. In Yathopoulos & Komine & Anor [2013] FCCA 267 it was held that a stay of a departure prohibition order “should only be made … in the rarest of cases”. Summary taken from the former Child Support Agency’s website Under s 111C of the CSR&CA a court can make an order staying or otherwise affecting the operation of child support legislation pending the resolution of court proceedings in a court having jurisdiction under that Act. A court can also make a stay order pending resolution of an objection
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: website Under s 111C of the CSR&CA a court can make an order staying or otherwise affecting the operation of child support legislation pending the resolution of court proceedings in a court having jurisdiction under that Act. A court can also make a stay order pending resolution of an objection under Part VII CSR&CA or the resolution of an application to the SSAT [now the AAT] under Part VIIA of that Act or matters under Part 6A or 7 of the Assessment Act. Prior to 1 July 2008 a stay order could only be made affecting the operation of the provision of the Assessment Act. As a result, stay orders could not be made in relation to the collection and disbursement powers of the Child Support Registrar under the Registration Act. After 1 July 2008, stay orders can address a specific collection action of the Child Support Registrar. For example, a stay order could: • order the Child Support Registrar to cease collecting from a payer’s salary; • order the Child Support Registrar to withdraw or modify a section 72A garnishment notice; • order the Child Support Registrar not to collect a payer’s taxation refund; • order the Child Support Registrar not to disburse monies held to the payee; or • order the Child Support Registrar to cease any and all administrative collection. What to file? For an application and supporting affidavit, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 56 APPEAL TO A COURT FROM AAT ON A QUESTION OF LAW A party may appeal from a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to the Federal Court of Australia on a question of law (s 44(1) AAT Act 1975 (“AATA”)) by filing in that Court and serving each other party and the Registrar of the Tribunal within 28 days a “Notice of appeal from a tribunal” (Form 75) in accordance with the procedure contained in Rule 33.12 of the Federal Court Rules 2011. OR may appeal to the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia from an AAT first review deci- sion or from a decision of the child support registrar to issue a departure prohibition order (s 44AAA(1) AATA) by filing in that Court and serving each other party, the child support registrar and the Registrar of the Tribunal within 28 days a Notice of Appeal (Child Support) in accordance rule 1.13 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. Links to those forms are above at our eBook and at our online “forms and precedents”. The court’s approach to such an appeal was reviewed by Slack FM in Hadley (SSAT Appeal) [2008] FMCAfam 1252 at [28]-[30]. Also see our archived case notes – child support under “appeal from AAT to Federal Court”; “appeal from AAT to FCC” and “SSAT, powers of, appeal from etc”. APPLICATION TO AMEND ASSESSMENT OVER 18 MONTHS OLD Beyond the scope of the Registrar upon a Part 6A review (administrative departure) is the amendment of an assessment that is more than 18 months and less than 7 years old. A liable parent or carer entitled to child support may apply to the court for leave for the amendment of such an assessment under s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPEAL TO A COURT FROM AAT ON A QUESTION OF LAW

chunks.text: upon a Part 6A review (administrative departure) is the amendment of an assessment that is more than 18 months and less than 7 years old. A liable parent or carer entitled to child support may apply to the court for leave for the amendment of such an assessment under s 111 of the CSAA. Under s 112, leave may be granted for the amendment to be made either by the Registrar under Part 6A or the court under Part 7. Matters to be considered include any responsibility or reason for the delay in applying; hardship to the applicant if leave is not granted; and hardship to the other party if leave is granted: s 112(4) An application under s 111 does not operate as a stay of the assessment: s 113A In Cantrell & Jennings [2009] FMCAfam 229 a father’s application was dismissed due to inadequate ex- planation of delay and the balance of hardship favouring the mother. The father was financially stronger, he having recently made loan payments and paid for renovations and white goods. He had also failed to make full disclosure. Also see Bauer & Becker [2009] FMCAfam 480, Hacherl & Berrios [2010] FMCAfam 668 and Ongal & Materns [2009] FMCAfam 476. What to file? For an application and supporting affidavit, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPEAL TO A COURT FROM AAT ON A QUESTION OF LAW

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 57 CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT We now come to a third piece of legislation – the Family Law Act – for the next few maintenance provisions which deal with the maintenance of children not covered by the CSAA: children over 18 (except the Child Support Registrar’s jurisdiction for children turning 18 in their last year of secondary schooling – see “right to apply” under “administrative assessment” above); and step-children. Child maintenance orders This is Division 7 of Part VII of the Family Law Act. Its object in s 66B of the FLA (to ensure a proper level of financial support of children by their parents having regard to their respective means) mirrors s 4(1) of the CSAA. And its principles under s 66C, as to a parent’s primary duty to maintain, are the same as in s 3 of the CSAA. In the case of step-children, a step-parent has a duty of maintaining the child, which is secondary to the primary duty of the child’s parents to maintain the child (provided that a court under s 66M determines that it is proper for the step-parent to have that duty): s 66D Payer not to prioritise between children of different relationships The Full Court held in Ganter & Grimshaw [1998] FamCA 52 that: • The effect of s 66C(2)(a) and (b) (as to priority of parents’ duty) is that a parent’s duty to maintain the children of one relationship has equal priority with the duty to maintain children of any subsequent relationship but is subservient to the primary duty of a parent to maintain himself or herself. • Equal priority between dependants does not necessarily equate to an equal division of the financial resources. A pro rata approach may ensure there is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: with the duty to maintain children of any subsequent relationship but is subservient to the primary duty of a parent to maintain himself or herself. • Equal priority between dependants does not necessarily equate to an equal division of the financial resources. A pro rata approach may ensure there is no discrimination between the dependants of a parent with limited resources. Relevance of Child Support (Assessment) Act A court must not make a child maintenance order if an application could properly be made under the CSAA: s 66E of the FLA. Who may apply for a child maintenance order? A parent; the child; a grandparent; or any other person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child: s 66F Court’s approach to child maintenance applications Under s 66H, the court must: • consider the financial support necessary for the maintenance of the child • determine the financial contribution that the parties should make towards that support Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 58 Necessary financial support The court under s 66J must take into account: • the object of the Division (s 66B) • the proper needs of the child, including the child’s age; the manner in which the child is being, and the parents expect the child to be, educated or trained; and any special needs of the child (and may consider any findings of published research) • the child’s income, earning capacity, property and financial resources, including any assets of, under the control of or held for the benefit of the child that do not produce, but are capable of producing, income provided that, in the special circumstances of the case, the court considers it appropriate to do so The court must disregard any entitlement of the child or any other person to an income tested pension, allowance or benefit: s 66J(3)(b)(ii) Contribution that should be made by parties The court under s 66K must take into account: • the objects in ss 66B, 66C and 66D (summarised above) • the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of each party • the commitments of each party necessary to enable their own support or that of any other child or person they have a duty to maintain (including any assets capable of producing income) • the direct and indirect costs in providing care for the child, including the income and earning capacity forgone by the parent or person providing that care • any special circumstances which, if not taken into account, would result in injustice or undue hardship to any person The court must disregard any entitlement of the child or person with whom the child lives to an income tested pension, allowance or benefit; and the means of any person who does not have a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: if not taken into account, would result in injustice or undue hardship to any person The court must disregard any entitlement of the child or person with whom the child lives to an income tested pension, allowance or benefit; and the means of any person who does not have a duty to main- tain the child (or has a duty but is not a party, unless in the special circumstances of the case the court considers it appropriate to have regard to the means of that person): s 66K(4) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 59 Balancing child’s needs with parent’s capacity to pay The Full Court in Mee & Ferguson [1986] FamCA 3 (FC) at [128] said: “[Counsel for the wife] challenged many of these items submitting that they were excessive or inappropriate...But the main thrust of (his) argument was that…it was incorrect in principle… to deduct from the husband’s income all of these expenses before considering the husband’s capacity to support his children. In our view counsel for the wife’s submission is clearly right. Some of the items obviously have to be taken into account before maintenance is arrived at; for example, the cost of reasonable transport, food and clothing, and other like expenses are necessary to the continued reasonable existence of a parent, and, barring legislative direction to the contrary, it would not accord with the understanding in this jurisdiction to suggest that those items should be put out of consideration before child maintenance is determined. On the other hand there is no doubt that one of the primary responsibilities of a parent is the continued support of children to the extent to which the parent continues to be able to do so and that may in appropriate circumstances mean making financial sacrifices or cutting one’s cloth to meet that commitment during the years when it applies.” Each party’s capacity to pay periodic maintenance to be considered first Section 66K(5) requires the court to consider this before any capacity of the parties to provide maintenance by way of lump sum payment; transfer of property; or in any other way. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 60 MAINTENANCE OF CHILDREN OVER 18 A court under s 66L of the FLA may make a maintenance order in relation to an adult child if it is satisfied that the provision of maintenance is necessary: • to enable the child to complete his or her education; or • because of a mental or physical disability of the child Under this section, the court may make an order when a child is 17 that is to take effect when or after the child turns 18. A child maintenance order ends upon the death of the child, payer or person entitled to receive payments unless the order provides otherwise (s 66U); if the child is adopted, marries or en- ters into a de facto relationship (s 66V) or if the child ceases the education or ceases to have the disabil- ity (s 66VA). Arrears of maintenance payable when the order ceases to be in force may be recovered (s 66W). Adult child maintenance due to disability Maintenance was awarded for a daughter of 28 in Re: AM (Adult Child Maintenance) [2006] FamCA 351. Unmarried, she had a degenerative disease preventing her employment and needed ongoing care. The case headnote stated: • Maintenance … mean[s] something more than mere subsistence or necessities of life. It includes financial provision for all reasonable, current and likely future daily requirements including out of pocket, adequate housing, health and education-related expenses as well as any special needs. • A parent’s capacity to pay … maintenance must first be considered. Periodic maintenance is nor- mally the preferred [consideration] as this can be adjusted over time if the needs and circumstances of the parties require this. The main object of child maintenance is income [not] capital focused. • Section 66B sets out the objects
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: pay … maintenance must first be considered. Periodic maintenance is nor- mally the preferred [consideration] as this can be adjusted over time if the needs and circumstances of the parties require this. The main object of child maintenance is income [not] capital focused. • Section 66B sets out the objects of child maintenance provisions; essentially, it is to ensure that children receive a proper level of financial support from their parents. The liability for child support should be distributed equitably…not necessarily equally. Note – Here the child applied for an order against the father who ‘cross-claimed’ against the mother by adding her as a second respondent in his Response. • The father was ordered to pay $525 per week and the mother to pay $975 per week both linked to the Consumer Price Index for Sydney. • Finality cannot be achieved. The order will last for five years with the prospect of reviewing in the future. The child’s claim for lump sum maintenance was dismissed. In Jamine and Anor (No. 2) [2011] FamCA 843 at [169]-[209] Cronin J ordered that $147,000 be held on trust for the maintenance of an adult child with Down’s Syndrome for use by M for that purpose and drawn at the rate of no more than $16,334 pa until the capital was expended. In Ballantyne [2015] FCCA 500 a backdated order was made that F pay $230 per week for the maintenance of a disabled adult child for 3 years despite the child’s savings of $85,000. Adult child maintenance enabling completion of education This was considered in Cosgrove [1996] FamCA 93. A wife sought maintenance for the 24-year- old son of herself and the husband. The son had left school in Grade 11 and returned to work on the Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: $85,000. Adult child maintenance enabling completion of education This was considered in Cosgrove [1996] FamCA 93. A wife sought maintenance for the 24-year- old son of herself and the husband. The son had left school in Grade 11 and returned to work on the Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 61 family’s farm. He completed agricultural and business courses, obtained a truck licence, was given $18,000 towards the purchase of land, returning to school to complete Grade 11. Warnick J held, as summarised by the headnote of the case: • The term “necessary” in s 66H involved a consideration of reasonableness. • “Education” (s 66L) might of itself be broadly interpreted, but connection between the course of “education” for the completion of which maintenance was sought, and prospects of employment might well bear upon the exercise of discretion. • There is no need for a nexus between the kind of course for the completion of which maintenance is sought and the kind of earlier education. • Matters likely to bear upon the exercise of discretion include: (i) whether the nexus of dependence between the child and parents had ceased and the application amounts to a resurrection of that dependence (ii) the time between initial cessation of dependence (if any) and the application (iii) whether the child had completed the course of education intended by the parents to outfit him/ her for employment sufficient to support himself/herself (iv) other assistance, benefits or education which the child has received (v) the ability of the child to complete the course in question (vi) the likelihood of the child completing the course in question (vii) the financial capacity of the child to maintain himself/herself to the completion of the “education” (viii) the financial circumstances of those responsible for support of the child (ix) the filial relationship between the child and the person from whom maintenance is sought. These and other authorities were applied in the dismissal of a maintenance application in Maher [2012] FMCAfam 147. In Paul [2012] FamCAFC 64 the Full Court set aside a maintenance order
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: support of the child (ix) the filial relationship between the child and the person from whom maintenance is sought. These and other authorities were applied in the dismissal of a maintenance application in Maher [2012] FMCAfam 147. In Paul [2012] FamCAFC 64 the Full Court set aside a maintenance order (remitting the case for re-hearing) in the absence of evidence of “necessity” or any inquiry into the children’s earn- ing capacities. In Masterton & Anor [2012] FMCAfam 913 the father was ordered to pay $1,000 per semester for his adult son’s tertiary education. For a review of case law as to the discharge of a child maintenance order, see Cooper & Kingsley [2013] FCCA 277 at [19]-[29]. Variation of child maintenance orders In Bridges [2011] FMCAfam 1288 at [16]-[18] the mother was granted variation of a contravened pe- riodic order under s 66S(2)(d) so as to require payment of a lump sum of $5,486 to cover the remain- ing 65 weeks of her adult daughter’s degree. In Wadsworth [2013] FCCA 2043 the court would not discharge but did reduce maintenance payable under an order where adult twins refused to seek any casual work while at uni. What to file? For an application and affidavit in support, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 62 MAINTENANCE OF STEP-CHILDREN A “step-parent” (s 4) is not a parent of the child; but is or has been married to a parent of the child (or is or has been the parent’s de facto partner); and treats, or at any time during the marriage treated, the child as a member of the family. A step-parent has the duty of maintaining a child if a court, by order under s 66M, determines it is proper for the step-parent to have that duty: s 66D(1). That duty is secondary to the primary duty of the child’s parents to maintain the child: s 66D(2) Section 66M confirms that a court may, by order, determine that it is proper for a step-parent to have a duty of maintaining a step-child; and in doing so is required to take into account: a) the matters referred to in ss 60F, 66B (proper level of support of children having regard to parents’ respective means) and 66C (parent’s primary duty to maintain) b) the length and circumstances of the marriage to the child’s parent c) the relationship that has existed between the step-parent and the child d) the arrangements that have existed for the maintenance of the child, and e) any special circumstances which, if not taken into account, would result in injustice or undue hardship to any person. An application for maintenance of stepchildren under s 66M must be coupled with an application for child maintenance under s 66F: Eames [2018] FamCAFC 204. Section 66N sets out the matters the court is to take into account when determining the amount of maintenance that should be paid by a step-parent. What to file? For an application and affidavit in support, see “procedures” and “precedents” below. Is a step-parent liable to maintain a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: FamCAFC 204. Section 66N sets out the matters the court is to take into account when determining the amount of maintenance that should be paid by a step-parent. What to file? For an application and affidavit in support, see “procedures” and “precedents” below. Is a step-parent liable to maintain a child over 18? Yes, held the Full Court in Keltie & Bradford [2002] FamCA 421 (agreeing with Chisholm J in Carpenter [1994] FamCA 89 that “child” in Division 7 of Part VII “refers to a relationship rather than an age”). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 63 CHILD-BEARING EXPENSES OF UNMARRIED MOTHERS This is Division 8 of Part VII of the FLA. Section 67B makes the father of a child who is not married to the child’s mother liable to make a proper contribution towards: a) the maintenance of the mother for the childbirth period (defined in s 4(1) as being from when the mother stops work on medical advice or 2 months before her due date – whichever occurs first – until 3 months after the birth); and b) the mother’s reasonable medical expenses in relation to the pregnancy and birth; and c) if the mother dies and the death is as a result of the pregnancy or birth, the reasonable expenses of the mother’s funeral; and d) if the child is stillborn, or dies and the death is related to the birth, the reasonable expenses of the child’s funeral. Time limit for applying Proceedings may be issued during the pregnancy and no later than 12 months after the birth except by leave of the court, leave not to be granted unless the court is satisfied that refusal to grant leave would cause hardship to the applicant, child or other person: s 67G Matters to be taken into account Section 67C requires the court, in determining whether a father should make a contribution, to take into account the following matters only: a) the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of the parties b) commitments of each that are necessary to enable them to support themselves or any other child or person whom they have a duty to maintain c) any special circumstances which, if not taken into account, would result in injustice or undue hardship to any person. The court must consider any assets capable of producing income
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: necessary to enable them to support themselves or any other child or person whom they have a duty to maintain c) any special circumstances which, if not taken into account, would result in injustice or undue hardship to any person. The court must consider any assets capable of producing income (s 67C(2)) and disregard any entitlement of the mother to an income tested pension, allowance or benefit (s 67C(3)). Orders the court may make are set out in s 67D, and in s 67E as to urgent orders. In Hampton & Temple [2012] FamCA 681 the respondent was ordered to pay the applicant $3,200 be- ing $200 per week for the four months prior to the birth for which she had medical advice to stop work. In Millar & Johnston [2015] FCCA 543 at [25] the Court deducted from the mother’s claim “items … referable to child support”, awarding her half of the other expenses claimed for the childbirth period. What to file? For an application and affidavit in support, see “procedure” and “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: CHILD MAINTENANCE UNDER THE FAMILY LAW ACT

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 64 OTHER CHILD MAINTENANCE PROVISIONS Application to court for urgent child maintenance A remedy unlikely ever to be required is s 139 of the CSAA enabling an urgent maintenance order to be made by the court for a child who is in urgent need of financial assistance at any time after an application has been made for administrative assessment, whether or not that application was accepted or refused by the Registrar. Specify maintenance component of any order for lump sum or property transfer Section 66R of the FLA requires the court in any order for payment of a lump sum or transfer of property, all or part of which is intended as child maintenance, to specify: • that Section 66R applies to the order • the child for whom maintenance was being provided by the payment or transfer • the portion of the payment, or the value of the portion of the property, attributable to the provision of maintenance Modification of child maintenance orders Section 66S of the FLA provides for this. Should you come across such a matter, your quickest route to the section is to copy and download it from the Family Law Act in www.austlii.edu.au You will find that the grounds and procedure are similar to applications to vary a spousal maintenance order (see “variation of spousal maintenance orders” in the chapter “spousal maintenance”). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 65 COLLECTION OF CHILD SUPPORT AND CHILD MAINTENANCE Child support and child maintenance can be collected by the Child Support Registrar under s 30 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act (CSR&CA) but “more than 60% of newly separated par- ents in 2006–2007 chose (private collect) because it’s flexible: you and the other parent work out the payment arrangements that best suit you and the children” (former Child Support Agency’s website). Our eBook on this page has a link to “CSA [Child Support] collection” and to “child support private collect” dealing with putting the arrangement in writing; setting up private payments; deciding on any in-kind (third party) payments; and asking the Child Support Registrar to start collecting payments (by lodging a “request to change payment collection method”) if private payments do not work out. The Act allows the Child Support Registrar to credit lump sum payments (s 69A), payments made direct to payee (s 71), third party payments (s 71A) and payments in kind (s 71B), and to offset debts between payer and payee (s 71AA). A debt under a child support agreement may be enforced in the FCFCA or FCWA once it has been registered there (see “child support agreements” above). Amounts payable under an assessment, court order or registered maintenance agreement are debts due to the Commonwealth, once the liability is registered with the Registrar under the Act (s 30). “Registrable maintenance liabilities” are defined in ss 17, 17A, 18 and 18A and include a court order for spousal maintenance (s 18). Money owed may be sued for and recovered by the Registrar (which, since August 2011, has had the option of outsourcing recovery to debt collection agencies) or, if a payee wishes to do so, by a payee in a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COLLECTION OF CHILD SUPPORT AND CHILD MAINTENANCE

chunks.text: 18A and include a court order for spousal maintenance (s 18). Money owed may be sued for and recovered by the Registrar (which, since August 2011, has had the option of outsourcing recovery to debt collection agencies) or, if a payee wishes to do so, by a payee in a court with jurisdiction for the recovery of debt (s 113). Payees doing so must notify the Registrar in writing of their intention to do so at least 14 days before the issue of proceedings (s 113A) and should obtain from the Registrar a certificate as evidence of the debt, if available (s 116). For your enforcement options, see pages 7-77 and 7-78. The court may include a payment deadline or payment by instalments. See Halley & Wyatt [2011] FMCAfam 278. For a debt of, say, at least $50,000 where the payer has significant assets the payee could apply for an enforcement order appointing a receiver of the payer’s income or property under FLR 11.48 (in WA, FCR 417): see Child Support Registrar & Garaty [2016] FCCA 2078. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COLLECTION OF CHILD SUPPORT AND CHILD MAINTENANCE

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 67 COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS In some scenarios a parent or carer can apply to the court for relief directly without going through the administrative departure process. In all other cases, however, they must first pursue administrative review as a prerequisite to their having standing to bring a matter to court. It follows that before bringing any court application, it is vital for a lawyer to review whether the client has standing to bring such an application or not. For more information see The Child Support Guide. Court procedure is governed by FLR 1.13 and, in WA, para 11 of the FCWA’s Case Management Guidelines. When can a party apply directly to the court? A parent may apply directly to the court as follows: 1. To apply for a declaration under ss 106A or 107 that a parent should or should not be assessed because they are or are not a parent of the child (“paternity disputes” above) 2. To seek a departure order where an assessment is in place and one of the following applies: • the parents are already parties to court proceedings, such as property settlement or enforcement matters • the Registrar has refused to change the assessment as the matter is too complex • the AAT has refused to make a Part 6A determination as to the assessment 3. To apply for child support in a form other than periodic amounts or to vary such an order 4. To apply for an order setting aside a child support agreement (accepted by the Registrar) 5. To apply for a stay of proceedings 6. To appeal to a court from the AAT on a question of law 7. To apply for leave to amend an old assessment (between
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: order 4. To apply for an order setting aside a child support agreement (accepted by the Registrar) 5. To apply for a stay of proceedings 6. To appeal to a court from the AAT on a question of law 7. To apply for leave to amend an old assessment (between 18 months and seven years) 8. To apply for maintenance for an adult child or step-child 9. To apply for child bearing expenses of an unmarried mother 10. To bring enforcement proceedings For all other circumstances, a party must proceed through the administrative review process before bringing a matter to court. • For an explanation of this process see “administrative review” above • For the forms see “administrative forms” above. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 68 How to apply to the Court (where no court proceedings on foot) The FCFCA practice direction Child support and child maintenance proceedings made on 1 September 2021 applies to applications for child maintenance or child support (and appeals from the AAT) filed before or after that date. Applicants for child maintenance must comply with the pre-action procedures, while applicants for child support need not (nor in WA: FCR 22(2)). 1. In child support proceedings in the FCFCA, prepare the following for filing: Initiating Application (Family Law); Financial Statement (except for declarations under ss 106A and 107 CSAA); Affidavit which contains: • the facts relied on in support of all aspects of the application; • an attached schedule specifying the section under which the application is made; a copy of any relevant decision or assessment of the Child Support Registrar (CSR) and statement of reasons; and a copy of any relevant document lodged by a party with the CSR or received by a party from the CSR; A copy of any relevant order; and A certified copy of any relevant child support agreement. 2. In child support appeals, file a Notice of Appeal – Child Support, to which you must attach a copy of the AAT’s (or CSR’s) decision; the reasons for such decision; a Financial Statement; an affidavit in support; and the brochure Child Support Applications. 3. In child maintenance proceedings, prepare the following for filing: Initiating Application (Family Law); Financial Statement; Genuine Steps Certificate; Affidavit in support of any interim application – or a Financial Questionnaire, if no interim orders are sought; FDR certificate or an Affidavit – Non-Filing of FDR Certificate; Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk; and A copy of any family violence order. Note – In the FCWA, prepare
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: Affidavit in support of any interim application – or a Financial Questionnaire, if no interim orders are sought; FDR certificate or an Affidavit – Non-Filing of FDR Certificate; Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk; and A copy of any family violence order. Note – In the FCWA, prepare for filing an Initiating Application; a Financial Statement; and an affidavit in support as in 1 above (FCR 67). 4. Swear and e-file them via the Commonwealth Courts Portal and, in WA, the eCourts Portal of West- ern Australia. The Court will list a first court event, at which a Judicial Registrar will review compliance and make directions. 5. Serve the sealed documents upon: • any Respondent (and the brochure Child Support Applications or, in a child maintenance case, Marriage, families and separation); Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 69 • the Child Support Registrar (for child support cases); and • the Registrar of the AAT and any other party to the appeal within 7 days of filing (child support ap- peals). Note – While the Rules require personal service of any Application, service on the CSR is usually ef- fected by post. It is recommended that lawyers post the sealed copies to the CSR and confirm in a cover- ing letter that they could be personally served if the Registrar required it. How to respond to such an Application 1. In child support proceedings in the FCFCA, prepare the following for filing: Response to Initiating Application (or Submitting Notice if the orders sought by the applicant are agreed); Financial Statement (not for ss 106A and 107 CSAA); and Affidavit in support of any interim orders sought by either party – if no interim orders are sought by either party, prepare and file a Financial Questionnaire. 2. In child maintenance proceedings, prepare the following for filing: Response to Initiating Application (or Submitting Notice if the orders sought by the applicant are agreed); Financial Statement; Genuine Steps Certificate; Affidavit in support of any interim orders sought by either party (or a Financial Questionnaire if no interim orders are sought); and Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk. 3. In child support appeals, file a Notice of Address for Service (if the appeal is opposed) or a Submit- ting Notice (if the appeal is agreed). If the respondent wishes to cross-appeal, a Notice of Cross-Ap- peal is to be filed. If the Respondent contends the decision should be affirmed but for reasons other than those given by the AAT, file a Notice of Contention. Note – In the FCWA, prepare for filing a Response
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: agreed). If the respondent wishes to cross-appeal, a Notice of Cross-Ap- peal is to be filed. If the Respondent contends the decision should be affirmed but for reasons other than those given by the AAT, file a Notice of Contention. Note – In the FCWA, prepare for filing a Response to Initiating Application, a Financial Statement and an affidavit in support. 4. E-file the documents via the above links. Disclosure requirements for both parties The parties (other than the CSR) are to attend the first court event with the documents listed below. See “first court event” at para 5 of the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management. The par- ties are required by FLR 6.06(8) to serve on each other before the first court date: • a copy of the party’s 3 most recent tax returns and assessments; • a completed superannuation information form for any superannuation interest; or, for a self- managed fund, the trust deed and a copy of the 3 most recent financial statements; • if the party has an ABN, a copy of the last 4 business activity statements; Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 70 • if there is a partnership, trust or company (other than a public company) in which the party has an in- terest, a copy of the 3 most recent financial statements and last 4 business activity statements lodged for the partnership, trust or company.” How to apply to the court (where court proceedings are on foot) Where court proceedings are on foot, a child support matter may be brought as follows: 1. Re-file the application as an Amended Initiating Application (Family Law), so as to encompass the child support orders sought. This document should be a copy of the Application previously filed, with the child support orders sought added. Those new orders must be underlined, and the word “Amended” added on the cover sheet and wherever else “Initiating Application” appears. There is no filing fee on an amended proceeding. Leave may be required (FLR 2.50). 2. Prepare and file an affidavit sworn by your client as to: • the basis of the application, and • if the application is for a departure order, the facts on which it is submitted the Court can be satisfied that it would be in the interest of both parties to consider whether the order should be made in the special circumstances of the case: s 116(1)(b) of the CSAA For sample text of the affidavit, see “precedents” below (also available online). 3. If the proceedings on foot relate to non-financial matters (not requiring a Financial Statement to be filed), prepare and file a Financial Statement. Simply download these forms from their eBook links or our online “forms and precedents”. A tip – Be wary of amendments that include child support in Division 1 of the FCFCA A proceeding under the CSAA for child support is a separate cause of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: COURT PROCEDURE AND FORMS FOR CHILD SUPPORT MATTERS

chunks.text: prepare and file a Financial Statement. Simply download these forms from their eBook links or our online “forms and precedents”. A tip – Be wary of amendments that include child support in Division 1 of the FCFCA A proceeding under the CSAA for child support is a separate cause of action which cannot be commenced in Division 1 of the FCFCA: s 50 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia Act 2021 (Cth). See Kwok & Beng (No 5) [2024] FedCFamC1F 463 where the Court held that such an application could only be filed in Division 2. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
