chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 71 PRECEDENTS A suggestion Prepare your application and affidavit in support, then email them to your barrister to settle and return to you for filing. APPLICATION FOR A DECLARATION THAT THE RESPONDENT SHOULD BE ASSESSED BECAUSE HE IS CHILD’S FATHER Note – Under FLR 1.13(3) (in WA, FCR 69) the time limit of 56 days after notice of the Child Support Registrar’s decision in which to file this application. The Court may extend this time limit under that rule. If your client is out of time, seek an interim order that the time for the filing of the application be extend- ed to the date on which it was filed. For the relevant factors see Jordan & Fielding [2013] FCCA 725 at [28]-[30]. Interim orders sought 1. That a parentage testing procedure be carried out on the parties and the child [full name] born on [date] under Section 69W(3) of the Family Law Act 1975 (“the Act”). 2. That the parentage testing procedure be carried out: 2.1 in accordance with Division 7 of Part 7 of the Family Law Regulations 2024; and 2.2 at a laboratory that is accredited by the National Association of Testing Laboratories, Australia for the purpose of carrying out parentage testing procedures; and 2.3 in accordance with standards of practice that entitle the laboratory to be so accredited. 3. That within 14 days after the date of this order the Respondent [his full name] be and is hereby required under Section 69X(3) of the Act to provide a bodily sample for the purposes of the parentage testing procedure. 4. That the procedure be supplemented by a report under Regulation 21M. Final orders sought 1. A declaration under section 106A of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 that the Respondent [full
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Section 69X(3) of the Act to provide a bodily sample for the purposes of the parentage testing procedure. 4. That the procedure be supplemented by a report under Regulation 21M. Final orders sought 1. A declaration under section 106A of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 that the Respondent [full name] should be assessed in respect of the costs of the child [full name] born [date] because the Respondent is a parent of the child. 2. A declaration of parentage under Section 69VA of the Act. 3. That if the Respondent is found to be a parent of the child, the Respondent shall pay all of the costs in relation to the carrying out of the parentage testing procedure and preparation of the report and the Applicant’s costs incidental to these proceedings. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 72 AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION FOR DECLARATION (HE IS THE FATHER) 1. I am the Applicant. 2. From [date] until [date] I had a [casual/de facto – specify] relationship with the respondent [full name] (referred to as “[insert his first name as they were known by your client]”) [referred to as “[X]” in this sample affidavit]. 3. Throughout that time, [X] and I had sexual intercourse and I did not have sexual intercourse with anyone else. 4. On [date of child’s birth] I gave birth to a child, [full name]. 5. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of the child’s birth certificate. [X] is named as the child’s father [OR] [X] is not named as the child’s father because [explain why]. 6. [Specify, in separate paragraphs, any instances where X indicated his acknowledgement of paternity such as statements made by him to your client; his attending the birth; visiting or playing with the child; giving any gift or monetary payment.] 7. [Specify any conversation between the parties as to paternity, indicating an admission or in which he does not deny sexual intercourse with your client.] 8. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of the notice of assessment issued by the Child Support Registrar on [date of issue]. 9. [If applicable] Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of the decision of the [Child Support Registrar or AAT] and statement of reasons for that decision relating to this matter. 10. I refer to my Financial Statement filed in this Court on [date of filing]. 11. [Specify X’s denial of paternity and then add the following sentence] and in the circumstances I am left to bringing this application for an order that will determine the parentage of my child, whose father I
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: refer to my Financial Statement filed in this Court on [date of filing]. 11. [Specify X’s denial of paternity and then add the following sentence] and in the circumstances I am left to bringing this application for an order that will determine the parentage of my child, whose father I believe on reasonable grounds to be [X]. 12. All the above facts are within my own knowledge except those which are deposed to from information only, my means of knowledge and sources of information for which appear in this affidavit. Note – A Financial Statement need not be filed: Family Law Practice Direction – Child support and child maintenance proceedings. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 73 APPLICATION FOR A DECLARATION THAT THE APPLICANT SHOULD NOT BE ASSESSED BECAUSE HE IS NOT CHILD’S FATHER Note – Under FLR 1.13(3) (in WA, FCR 69) the time limit of 56 days after notice of the Child Support Registrar’s decision in which to file this application. The Court may extend this time limit under that rule. If your client is out of time, seek an interim order that the time for the filing of the application be extend- ed to the date on which it was filed. Interim orders 1. That a parentage testing procedure be carried out on the parties and the said child under Section 69W(3) of the Family Law Act 1975. 2. That the parentage testing procedure be carried out: 2.1 in accordance with Division 7 of Part 7 of the Family Law Regulations 2024; and 2.2 at a laboratory that is accredited by the National Association of Testing Laboratories, Australia for the purpose of carrying out parentage testing procedures; and 2.3 in accordance with standards of practice that entitle the laboratory to be so accredited. 3. That within 14 days after the date of this order the Respondent, [full name] be and is hereby required under Section 69X(3) of the Family Law Act to provide a bodily sample for the purposes of the parentage testing procedure. 4. That the procedure be supplemented by a report under Regulation 21M. Final orders 1. A declaration under section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 that the Applicant, [full name] should not be assessed in respect of the costs of the child, [full name] born [date] because the Applicant is not a parent of the child. 2. A declaration of parentage under Section 69VA of the Family Law Act. 3. That
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR A DECLARATION THAT THE APPLICANT SHOULD NOT BE

chunks.text: Support (Assessment) Act 1989 that the Applicant, [full name] should not be assessed in respect of the costs of the child, [full name] born [date] because the Applicant is not a parent of the child. 2. A declaration of parentage under Section 69VA of the Family Law Act. 3. That if the Applicant is found not to be a parent of the child, the Respondent shall pay all of the costs in relation to the carrying out of the parentage testing procedure and preparation of the report and the Applicant’s costs incidental to these proceedings. 4. That the Respondent, [full name] repay to the Applicant the sum of $[amount] paid as child support for the child under Section 143(1) of the Act within [specify] days after the date of this order. 5. That the parties forthwith apply for the correction of the register of births as to the paternity of the said child. 6. That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s taxed costs of and incidental to this application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 74 AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION FOR DECLARATION (APPLICANT IS NOT THE FATHER) 1. I am the Applicant. 2. I deny that I am the father of the child [full name]. 3. From [date] until [date] I had a [describe the casual or other nature of the relationship with the respondent] with the respondent. 4. Throughout that time, [specify whether in that time the respondent went out with other men, and specify any evidence of actual intimacy between the respondent and such men]. 5. [Describe any circumstances at the time of the birth, including any statements by her to the Applicant as to paternity, to indicate that the Respondent was not looking at the Applicant as being the father]. 6. [Explain the circumstances if the Applicant was named as father on the child’s birth certificate, including when he first knew that he was so named.] 7. [Explain any other conduct or admissions by the Respondent relevant to doubt as to paternity.] 8. [Details of any other matter relevant to paternity.] 9. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of the notice of assessment issued by the Child Support Registrar on [date of issue]. 10. [If applicable] Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of the decision of the [Child Support Registrar or AAT] and statement of reasons for that decision relating to this matter. 11. I refer to my Financial Statement filed in this Court on [date of filing]. 12. All the above facts are within my own knowledge except those which are deposed to from information only, my means of knowledge and sources of information for which appear in this affidavit. Note – A Financial Statement need not be filed: Family Law Practice Direction – Child support and child maintenance proceedings. Update 64

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 75 APPLICATION FOR A DEPARTURE ORDER Note – The following orders and notes are edited from those provided by the former Child Support Agency’s website. This material is copyright of the Commonwealth of Australia, and is reproduced under permission of the Commonwealth. The application is made under s 116, the grounds are in s 117 and the various orders a court may make are set out in s 118. Sample affidavits in support are supplied here by . The clauses in the orders below may also be used in child support agreements. Varying the annual rate of child support Final orders 1. An order under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 for departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [payer’s full name] to [payee’s full name] for the children [full name]. Note – Before selecting these next two paragraphs, consider the (former) CSA’s suggestion below – “varying or setting components of the formula” – for your order to vary a formula element instead of seeking a fixed amount, as usually sought under the old child support scheme. 2. That for the period from [start date] to [end date] the annual rate of child support be set at $[amount] per child by payments of $[amount] per month for [full name of first child] and $[amount] per month for [full name of second child]. 3. The annual rate of child support payable by [payer’s full name] to [payee’s full name] will be adjusted from [day and month] each year in accordance with variations in the consumer price index for the [specify] quarter for [capital city OR weighted average of all cities]. 4. *The annual rate of child support payable under this order will reduce to $[amount] [OR] the minimum amount
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: will be adjusted from [day and month] each year in accordance with variations in the consumer price index for the [specify] quarter for [capital city OR weighted average of all cities]. 4. *The annual rate of child support payable under this order will reduce to $[amount] [OR] the minimum amount of child support that would be payable under a formula assessment] for any period in which [payer’s full name] receives an income tested social security benefit or pension at the full rate [“at the full rate” is optional] for any period in which [she/he] is not in full-time employment [OR for any period in which [payer’s full name]’s income falls below the equivalent of the self-support amount that would be used in the calculation of a formula assessment of child support.] For the purpose of this clause, ‘full-time employment’ means working at least [insert] hours per week [OR] earning a gross income of $[amount] per week]. *The former CSA advised that this can be a difficult clause for the Child Support Registrar to administer (if not adequately defined). Difficulties may include: fluctuations in a person’s income; requests for retrospective changes; lack of supporting evidence as to the exact level of, or changes to, earnings; consequences such as the creation of overpayment or arrears. Consider inserting clauses limiting retrospectivity and specifying requisite proof of income. You may also wish to discuss this with the Child Support Registrar before you consider inserting a “low income” clause. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 76 Varying or setting components of the formula A court can make a departure order that modifies one or more of the components of the formula the Child Support Registrar uses to calculate the rate of child support: s 118(1) In order to preserve some of the flexibility of the formula introduced 1 July 2008, it may be more appropriate to vary or set other components of the formula than to set a fixed annual rate. Such an order allows the Registrar to amend the assessment to take into account new information, while continuing to give effect to the order. See below for some examples of such clauses. Varying a parent’s adjusted taxable income Note – Such an order can now apply to both parties. It may raise income to a truer amount, having regard to real income or access to resources, or reduce it where capital is being spent to pay high expenses. Once the income is set, however, the parties can no longer lodge income estimates. Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable for the children, [their full names] in that for the period from [start date] to [end date] [payer’s full name]’s adjusted taxable income be fixed at an annual rate of $[amount] [OR] be increased/decreased by $[amount]. Varying either parent’s self-support amount Note – Such an order may be used where a parent is under a legal duty to maintain a person not being taken into account, or has high self-support expenses such as medical costs, or high child care costs. The clause also allows the Child Support Registrar to take into account the latest taxable income for each parent when they lodge
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: is under a legal duty to maintain a person not being taken into account, or has high self-support expenses such as medical costs, or high child care costs. The clause also allows the Child Support Registrar to take into account the latest taxable income for each parent when they lodge their tax returns, and other income information, and make any changes to the care percentage or other formula components, if necessary. The self-support amount can either be fixed at a set amount, or increased by an amount or by the allowance that would be made for a relevant dependant for that parent. Increasing the self-support amount, instead of fixing it, allows normal periodic increases in the self-support amount to occur. Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [payer’s full name] for the children [their full names] in that for the period from [start date] to [end date] [payer’s full name]’s self-support amount is increased by $[amount]* [OR] set at $[amount] [OR] the relevant dependent child amount that would be calculated for the children according to the child support formula if they were relevant dependent children]. [*The amount could be specified and be equal to the person’s annual recognisable child care costs or a portion of a parent’s costs of supporting the child who is over 18 during the period. Or increasing the self-support amount by what would be the parent’s allowance for a relevant dependant as used in the formula may be appropriate (s 46).] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 77 Setting a parent’s child support income Note – An order can set or vary a parent’s child support income by means of the same order above for “varying a parent’s adjusted taxable income” but substituting “child support income” for “adjusted taxable income”. This clause may be appropriate if the formula assessment does not accurately reflect current income(s) and allows for care changes to be reflected. A parent’s “child support income” reflects the resources they have available to support the children, after the self-support amount and any relevant dependent child amount has been deducted. If a parent’s resources are not accurately reflected in the assessment, it would normally be more appropriate to set or vary the parent’s “adjusted taxable income” (as in the earlier clause above), unless there is a specific desire to adjust the calculation of the resources available to support the children, instead of the parent’s total resources. Again, by setting the child support income, a parent cannot lodge income estimates. Varying the child support percentage Note – An order can adjust the amount payable by increasing or decreasing a parent’s child support percentage. Since 1 July 2008, a parent’s child support percentage is the share of the cost that the parent must transfer to the other parent. Also, varying the child support percentage does not increase the overall cost of the children. Where, for example, the parents agree that the special needs of the children require a parent to contribute a higher level of child support than is normally payable under the formula, it would be easier and more transparent to adjust another formula component, such as changing the cost of the child to reflect this (see below). It should also be noted that varying one parent’s child support percentage may
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: higher level of child support than is normally payable under the formula, it would be easier and more transparent to adjust another formula component, such as changing the cost of the child to reflect this (see below). It should also be noted that varying one parent’s child support percentage may have anomalous effects, depending on the other parent’s circumstances. It changes the share of the cost that one parent must transfer to the other, but in a somewhat artificial way. A parent’s child support percentage is the result of subtracting the parent’s cost percentage (share of costs that they bear directly, if any) from their income percentage (their share of the combined resources). It would usually be easier and more transparent to adjust the parents’ income percentages and/or cost percentages, leaving the child support percentages to be calculated automatically from these new figures. You should contact the Child Support Registrar for further information if you are considering inserting such a clause. Varying the costs of the children Note – An order can adjust the costs of children used in the formula. This recognises that the cost of the children, or a particular child, is higher or lower than the usual costs. They may be higher, for example, if the child has special needs or if school fees are high. Adjusting the costs of the children (rather than another element of the formula or the amount payable) will automatically distribute these additional costs between parents according to their share of the avail- able resources (income percentages). So it is not necessary to separately establish the payer’s share and add this to the amount payable. If for some reason it is appropriate for the paying parent to bear all the additional cost, for example, because they have agreed to meet all school
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: avail- able resources (income percentages). So it is not necessary to separately establish the payer’s share and add this to the amount payable. If for some reason it is appropriate for the paying parent to bear all the additional cost, for example, because they have agreed to meet all school fees in addition to the child support assessment, it would be more appropriate to add the fees to the amount payable. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 78 If the child is in shared care and there are additional costs, consider whether the parents are in fact both meeting the additional costs in the same proportions as they meet the standard costs. If the costs are high because the child has special needs requiring modification to the houses, this is likely to be the case. If the costs are high due to school fees and one parent actually pays the total amount to the school, this is not likely to be the case. The cost percentages (share of the cost that each parent meets directly) used in the assessment are also likely to require adjustment in such a case (see below). It may instead be preferable to adjust the annual rate to recognise one parent’s share of the additional cost borne by the other parent. Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable for the child, [full name] in that the cost of [child’s name] for child support purposes is to be increased/decreased by $[amount] per year [OR] the cost of [child’s name] for child support purposes is to be set at $[amount] per year. Note – If the second option is chosen, a clause indexing the cost (para 3 above) may be appropriate. Clauses to address situations such as unemployment could also be considered (para 4 above), as setting the cost may not allow for a reduction where income decreases. If child support is payable for more than one child, the order should indicate the increase or decrease in the cost, or the set cost, for each child. Or, the order or agreement could indicate how the increase in cost or set cost is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: for a reduction where income decreases. If child support is payable for more than one child, the order should indicate the increase or decrease in the cost, or the set cost, for each child. Or, the order or agreement could indicate how the increase in cost or set cost is apportioned between the children. This will ensure that if a terminating event (s 12) occurs in relation to one or more of the children, only the cost or increase per child will continue to be used, rather than the full cost or increase stipulated in the order. Varying the cost percentage Note – The formula in effect, from 1 July 2008, works out the share of the child’s costs that each parent is meeting directly, according to their share of the care, as set out in the table in s 55C. In some cases, the share of the cost that each parent meets directly may be significantly different from the figures in this table. For example, parents may have shared care, and be assessed as each meeting 50% of the child’s costs directly, but one parent may be paying all of the school fees or medical costs. It may be appropriate to vary the cost percentages in such a situation. This kind of variation would often be used in conjunction with a variation to the cost of the child. Parents may also choose to agree that they each meet 50% of the child’s costs, for example, although their care is not exactly equal. Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable for the child, [name] for the period from [start date] to [end date] in that the cost percentage of [Parent A]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: not exactly equal. Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable for the child, [name] for the period from [start date] to [end date] in that the cost percentage of [Parent A] is to be increased by [specify] percentage points (but not above 100%) and the cost percentage of [Parent B] is to be decreased by [specify] percentage points (but not below 0%) [OR] the cost percentage of [Parent A] is to be set at 50% and the cost percentage of [Parent B] is to be set at 50%. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 79 Note – If a parent’s cost percentage is adjusted or set, the other parent’s cost percentage should be adjusted or set so that the two figures will continue to add up to 100%. If the variation to the cost percentages is relevant for only one child, the court order or agreement should specify this. It is advisable to use percentage point variations, rather than varying the percentage by X%. Decreasing 50% by 10% could be interpreted as resulting in either 40% (reduction of 10 percentage points) or 45% (reduction of 10% of 50%). A child’s income Note – Under the CSAA, a child remains an eligible child for a child support assessment until their 18th birthday: s 12(1)(c). Where the child’s secondary education continues beyond that day, the assessment can be extended to the last day they receive secondary education in the school year of their 18th birthday, if an application to extend the assessment is received before they turn 18 (ss 151B, 151C and 151D). The Child Support Registrar cannot end a child support assessment because of the income earned by an eligible child, but a court can make a departure order that varies the assessment for that child if it believes that it is just and equitable to change the assessment because of the child’s income, earning capacity or financial resources: s 117(2)(c)(i) Also, if a child’s income is significant, that may indicate that a terminating event has occurred because the parents may cease to be eligible carers (ss 12 and 7B). The parents can also make a child support agreement to cover this situation, or the payee can make an election to end the assessment (ss 151 and 151A) for that child if he or she believes this is appropriate
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: parents may cease to be eligible carers (ss 12 and 7B). The parents can also make a child support agreement to cover this situation, or the payee can make an election to end the assessment (ss 151 and 151A) for that child if he or she believes this is appropriate (and he or she does not receive more than the base rate of Family Tax Benefit Part A). A court order or agreement could also reduce or set the assessed cost of that child or assess the costs of the children in the case as though the self-supporting child were not an eligible child. [Where child support is payable for only one child] Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [Parent A’s full name] to [Parent B’s full name] for the child, [full name] in that the annual rate of child support will reduce to $[nil or some other specified amount] for any period in which the child is self-supporting. 2. For the purpose of this paragraph, ‘self-supporting’ means [working at least X hours per week or earning a gross income of $[amount] per week]. [Where child support is payable for more than one child] Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [Parent A’s full name] to [Parent B’s full name] for the [child/children], [full names] as follows. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 80 2. For any period in which an eligible child of the assessment is self-supporting the costs of children amount for all of the children will be calculated as if the self-supporting child were not an eligible child; [optional clause as follows] and an additional amount of $[amount] will be added to the annual rate of child support that would otherwise be payable. 3. For the purpose of paragraph 2, ‘self-supporting’ means [working at least X hours per week or earning a gross income of $[amount] per week. Discharging arrears Note – The CSAA does not provide for the discharge of arrears payable under a child support assessment. However, this outcome can be achieved by an order that sets the rate of child support at an amount equivalent to the amount already paid. As the amount payable under an agreement designed to extinguish arrears will always be lower than the amount that was payable without the agreement, any such agreement will need to be a binding agreement, made with legal advice. (Limited agreements made for a past period must be for at least the amount payable over that period.) The implications for family tax benefit should also be considered when making such an agreement. The parent who is owed the arrears should contact Centrelink to discuss the circumstances before making an agreement to “discharge arrears”, and the effect will need to be considered in the legal advice provided to the parents. Final order 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [Parent A’s name] for the [child/children], [full name/s] as follows. 2. For the period from [commencement of the child support liability] to [date of order], the total amount

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 81 AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION FOR DEPARTURE ORDER Introduction 1. I am the Applicant. 2. The Respondent (“[X]”) [insert his/her first name that he/she was known by, e.g. Bill, then use that throughout the affidavit] and I were married at [place] on [date]. 3. We lived together from [date] until [date], when we separated. 4. There are [insert] children of our marriage namely [list full names and dates of birth of each child]. 5. I am [insert] years of age, born [date]. 6. Since our separation the children have been in [my/X’s] care at [address]. Departure from child support assessment Note – See “application to court for a departure order” above for the available grounds for a departure order. Your client’s affidavit will need to contain evidence that enables the court to be satisfied, in the special circumstances of the case, that your client’s ground(s) for departure is/are made out. Select from the following paragraphs and then focus the evidence upon the particular matters required to be proved under the subsection of s 117(2) being relied on. As a guide, download “Your application: Changing your child support assessment in special circumstances” from “administrative forms” above. It is the same application, but one that is made administratively. 7. A child support assessment was made on [date] for $[amount] per month. This compares with my total expenses for the children of $[amount] weekly, or $[amount] monthly. 8. Attached is a true copy of the Child Support Registrar’s notice of assessment of child support. 9. I refer to my Financial Statement filed in these proceedings. 10. My income since separation has been $[amount], from my pension of $[amount] and [If applicable] $[amount] X has been paying in child support. He has refused to pay any maintenance
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION FOR DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: Support Registrar’s notice of assessment of child support. 9. I refer to my Financial Statement filed in these proceedings. 10. My income since separation has been $[amount], from my pension of $[amount] and [If applicable] $[amount] X has been paying in child support. He has refused to pay any maintenance to help me with my own living expenses and debt [specify]. 11. Although I had some part-time work as a [specify] prior to our marriage, I have been out of the workforce for [insert] years so I have no skills for paid employment. 12. I refer to the affidavit sworn by my doctor (Dr [name]) as to my health and how it affects my life and ability to enter the paid workforce. [Specify in some detail, and in natural language, how ill health is limiting the seeking of employment] 13. My fixed and weekly expenses total $[amount] per week. My income of $[amount] leaves a shortfall of $[amount] weekly. I have had to meet that shortfall by using my bank savings. They have been reduced since separation from about $[amount] to $[amount] now. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 82 14. I also cannot afford the following essentials – ITEM WEEKLY COST ($) TOTAL ($) This brings my maintenance needs to $[amount] weekly. 15. [If applicable, detail any course looked into as a possible means of qualifying or gaining experience for an employed position. Explain nature of course; duration; breakdown of its cost] [Although interim lump sums are rare, you could include it in your claim – and this affidavit – if there is a case for, say, the upfront costs of a course being required to be paid and X has the funds to pay a lump sum. Stress the urgency of your need for the lump sum] 16. Since [X] left I have been going steadily into debt, unable to make ends meet. I have sought the backdating of maintenance to the date of filing of my maintenance application so as to be able to recoup savings of mine that I spent on [my/our] support, when no support was forthcoming from [X]’s ample income, savings and other resources throughout that time. Note – The Applicant must also file with this affidavit a sworn Financial Statement: Family Law Practice Direction – Child support and child maintenance proceedings. chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 83 APPLICATION FOR AN ORDER FOR NON-PERIODIC PROVISION OF CHILD SUPPORT (PAYMENTS TO THIRD PARTIES E.G. SCHOOL FEES) Note – The Act does not limit the types of provision that can be included, but the most common are school fees, mortgage payments, health insurance and the costs of orthodontic treatment. The payments may reduce, or be in addition to, the child support payable (the former Child Support Agency website, which also suggested the following form of orders). Editor’s note – Either party can apply for this – the payer, so that the payer’s payment of these third party expenses is credited against the assessed child support (or rationalised with a manageable amount for monthly child support, as covered by the second set of orders below) OR the payee, so that the payer’s payment of those expenses is over and above the assessed child support. The sample affidavit supplied will cover the usual scenario of a payer wishing to rationalise the payment the payer is making. If a payee is applying, simply adapt the sample to the payee’s needs. For your order to be enforceable by Child Support document it instead as a departure order so that it forms part of the child support assessment. Final orders Payments to third parties 1. That under Section 124 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 [Parent A’s full name] provide child support to [Parent B’s full name] for the [child/children], [full name/s] by way of payment of [all school fees] for [children’s name/s] while [that child/those children] continue to attend [name of school]. 2. That such payment is to commence for the [specify year] school year. 3. The child support ordered to be paid by way of [school fees] is to reduce the amount payable under the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION FOR DEPARTURE ORDER

chunks.text: [all school fees] for [children’s name/s] while [that child/those children] continue to attend [name of school]. 2. That such payment is to commence for the [specify year] school year. 3. The child support ordered to be paid by way of [school fees] is to reduce the amount payable under the administrative assessment of child support, in that for the period from [start date] to [end date] the [school fees] are to reduce the annual rate of child support by [specify percentage up to 100%]% for each child. [OR are to have an annual value of $[amount] for each child and the annual rate of child support for each child for the days in that period is to be reduced by that amount.] 3. OR [if the assessment amount is not to be reduced] The annual rate of child support is not to be reduced by the child support provided. Note – At the end of a liability (child is 18) any ‘unused’ non-periodic amount is not a credit and the Child Support Registrar cannot refund that amount. The parties could include a paragraph to ad- dress such an event. Some parents may wish to specify that the payment of school fees will only apply or continue if the child attends a particular school. Also, it may be prudent to define what ‘school fees’ do and do not include, such as non-tuition fees and extra-curricular activities. Enforceability of payment of third party payments by a payer is pursuant to FLR 11.01(2)(a)(i) (in WA, FCR 370(2)(a)(i)). The reduction clause is actioned by the Registrar immediately, whether or not the third party payment has been made (s 127). The court must consider social security implications before it makes the order: s 123A(4) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

I have had to meet that shortfall by using my bank savings. They have been reduced since separation from about $[amount] to the present figure of $[amount]. 14. Since our separation, I have been going into debt, often using bank savings (not income) to meet my child support responsibilities. 15. [If your client’s earning capacity may be called into question, anticipate this by explaining any recent reduction in income, as dealt with in s 117(7B)] 16. chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 86 APPLICATION FOR LUMP SUM PAYMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT Editor’s note – Only a payer will apply for this, so as to get a lump sum payment (which includes a transfer of property) credited against the assessment. This application has more to do with one-off lump sum payments or transfers of property for the benefit of a child than s 124’s provision for ongoing non-periodic third party payments such as school fees. The application is more likely to relate to a lump sum payment for a single child, although a lump sum payment or a transfer of property may also be made for the benefit of more than one child. The sample affidavit in support below assumes a single child. Child Support’s treatment of lump sum payments The lump sum must equal or exceed the annual rate of child support payable for the child under the assessment: s 123A(1)(c). The section itself notes that if the court makes such an order, the lump sum is treated as an advance payment and does not reduce the annual child support payable under the assessment. Final orders Lump sum payment 1. That under Section 123A of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 [Parent A’s full name] provide child support to [Parent B’s full name] for the [child/children], [full name/s] by way of a lump sum payment of $[amount]. 2. That this amount is to be credited against the administrative assessment of child support. 3. That from [start date] the lump sum payment is to be credited as [specify percentage up to 100%]% of the annual rate of child support payable, until the lump sum is exhausted. Note – At the end of a liability (child turns 18) any ‘unused’ lump sum amount is not a credit. It cannot be
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR LUMP SUM PAYMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT

chunks.text: lump sum payment is to be credited as [specify percentage up to 100%]% of the annual rate of child support payable, until the lump sum is exhausted. Note – At the end of a liability (child turns 18) any ‘unused’ lump sum amount is not a credit. It cannot be refunded by the Child Support Registrar who does not hold actual money but an accounting record of the transaction. The parties could include a clause to address this event. Enforceability is pursuant to an application to court under FLR 11.01(2)(a)(i) (in WA, FCR 370(2)(a)(i)). The reduction clause is actioned by the Registrar when the order is made and notification received that the lump sum payment has been duly paid: s 69A of the CSR&CA. The court must consider social security implications before it makes the order: s 123A(4) Lump sum payment may be by way of transfer of property (ensure that the value of the transfer is duly recited in your order): s 123A(2) Lump sum plus a fixed periodic amount Final orders Note – An order can provide for the payment of a lump sum combined with a periodic amount. 1. That under Section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, there be a departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [Parent A’s full name] to [Parent B’s full name] for the [child/children], [full name/s] as follows. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

That the order made by this [or if other court, specify which] court on [date of order] under Division 5 of Part 7 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be discharged. 2. That the Respondent pay child support to the Applicant: 2.1. in the sum of $[amount] per month, to an account to be nominated by the Applicant in writing; and 2.2 by way of non-periodic child support: 2.2.1 all tuition and non-tuition fees of [specify] School, or such other school as the child may attend from time to time, including but not limited to the cost of all text books, excursions, sports and other extra-curricular activities as and when they become payable; 2.2.2 one half of the child’s private health insurance premiums; and 2.2.3 reimbursement to the Applicant of one half of any excess or “gap” paid by the Applicant in respect of any medical, dental and/or orthodontic treatment of the child, such payment to be made within seven days after being provided by the Applicant with a written tax invoice, account or receipt for such expense. chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 90 AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION TO VARY ORDER FOR NON-PERIODIC PROVISION 1. I am the Applicant father. 2. Annexed to this affidavit is a true copy of the order made by this Court (“the Order”) for non-periodic provision of child support [or lump sum payment]. 3. [X] and I were married/began living together at [insert] on [insert]. 4. Our [child/children is/are]: (a) [full name of child] (“[first name]”) born [date of birth]. He/She was [age] at the time of the Order and is now [age]. (b) [full name of child] (“[first name]”) born [date of birth]. He/She was [age] at the time of the Order and is now [age]. 5. [X] and I separated on [date]. 6. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of the Child Support Registrar’s notice of assessment of child support. 7. At the time of the Order, I worked as [occupation], employed [full-time/part-time/casually] on [insert work routine say: flexible hours, on average X days each week, or X hours per day; full time during business hours; am unemployed, etc] and [X] worked as [specify]. 8. I now work as [specify position and whether full-time/part-time/casual and salary] and [X] now works as a [occupation] on a [full-time/casual/part-time basis and salary]. 9. [If relevant] The children now attend the following [day care centre(s)/school(s)]: 10. Since the making of the Order, there has been a change in our children’s [OR my OR X’s] circumstances [specify in detail that change, such as a serious illness of a child or your client causing significant rise in medical or other expenses; or some other unexpected change in circumstances since the Order, such as X’s fortunes (lottery win, inheritance or other windfall)]. 11. Since the making of the Order, the cost of living has increased so

chunks.text: serious illness of a child or your client causing significant rise in medical or other expenses; or some other unexpected change in circumstances since the Order, such as X’s fortunes (lottery win, inheritance or other windfall)]. 11. Since the making of the Order, the cost of living has increased so much that my average weekly grocery shop has increased from $[price range] to $[price range]. My income since the Order has gone from $[amount] to $[amount] but my total expenses have gone from $[amount] weekly to $[amount]. 12. [If the Order was by consent] The order is not proper or adequate because of [X]’s improved means and my increased living expenses for the family. 13. Material facts were withheld by [X] from the Court that made the Order [OR evidence given by [X] before the Court that made the Order was false, as follows. 14. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of [X]’s Financial Statement filed on [date]. [Specify the material facts withheld or false evidence, attaching any relevant documents, such as a bank loan application just before the Order setting out [his/her] assets at that time.] 15. [If X’s earning capacity is being called into question, refer to any reduction in income just before the Order and any evidence of X’s real earning capacity: see s 129(5A)] 16. [Specify any other reasons for applying for the orders sought.] Note – The Applicant must also file with this affidavit a sworn Financial Statement: Family Law Practice Direction – Child support and child maintenance proceedings. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 91 APPLICATION FOR AN ORDER SETTING ASIDE A CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT Final orders Note – See “application to set aside child support agreement” above. 1. [Include this clause if the Agreement has not been registered in court (so as to make it enforceable).] That the child support agreement made between the Applicant and Respondent on [date of agreement] (“the Agreement”) in relation to the child, [full name] born [date] (“the child”) be registered under Rule 15.08 (in WA, FCR 476) of the Family Law Rules 2004. 2. That under Section 136 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, the Agreement be set aside. 3. That the Respondent pay child support to the Applicant: 3.1. in the sum of $[amount] per month, to an account to be nominated by the Applicant in writing; and 3.2 by way of non-periodic child support: 3.2.1 all tuition and non-tuition fees of [specify] School, or such other school as the child may attend from time to time, including but not limited to the cost of all text books, excursions, sports and other extra-curricular activities as and when they become payable; 3.2.2 one half of the child’s private health insurance premiums; and 3.2.3 reimbursement to the Applicant of one half of any excess or “gap” paid by the Applicant in respect of any medical, dental and/or orthodontic treatment of the child, such payment to be made within seven days after being provided by the Applicant with a written tax invoice, account or receipt for such expense. Note about affidavit in support Note – The grounds to be addressed in your client’s affidavit under s 136(2) are similar to s 90K of the FLA (financial agreements), so see the chapter “financial agreements” for the cases cited under “grounds on which the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR AN ORDER SETTING ASIDE A CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT

chunks.text: account or receipt for such expense. Note about affidavit in support Note – The grounds to be addressed in your client’s affidavit under s 136(2) are similar to s 90K of the FLA (financial agreements), so see the chapter “financial agreements” for the cases cited under “grounds on which the court may set aside a financial agreement”. Email your draft affidavit and orders sought to counsel for them to settle before you file your court papers in an application such as this, where it is usually difficult to satisfy the court that it should take the extreme step of setting aside an agreement. A Financial Statement must also be filed by both parties. Evidence for limited or binding agreements (a) that the agreement was obtained by fraud (Note – fraud, being the deliberate or reckless use of a false representation to obtain an unjust advantage, is rare so if you think it applies, seek counsel’s advice on the evidence first as it is not easy to prove) or a failure to disclose material information (Note – this requires a full statement of facts surrounding the non-disclosure of important information, which was such that had your client known it at the time they would not have made the agreement); or Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR AN ORDER SETTING ASIDE A CHILD SUPPORT AGREEMENT

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 92 (b) that the respondent or someone acting for them: (i) exerted undue influence or duress in obtaining the agreement (Note – see the chapter “financial agreements” as referred to above, under “undue influence”. Duress requires physical intimidation, is rarely relied on and hard to prove); or (ii) engaged in unconscionable conduct (Note – also covered by that chapter); to such an extent that it would be unjust not to set aside the agreement; or Evidence for limited agreements (c) (i) that because of a significant change in the circumstances of a party or child covered by the agreement, it would be unjust not to set aside the agreement (Note – again, see that chapter under “material change in circumstances”, which is similar); or (ii) that the agreement provides for an annual rate of child support that is not proper or adequate, taking into account all the circumstances of the case (including the financial circumstances of the parties); or Evidence for binding agreements (d) that because of exceptional circumstances that have arisen since the agreement was made, relating to a party or the child, your client or the child will suffer hardship if the agreement is not set aside (Note – see the cases set out in the chapter “property” in “exceptional new circumstances relating to welfare of child” under “setting aside or varying property orders” as to the meaning of “hardship” and just how tough this ground can be to prove). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 95 APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS The former CSA’s website suggested the following wording for stay orders – (These stay orders and former CSA notes are copyright of the Commonwealth of Australia, and are reproduced under permission of the Commonwealth.) Note – In an Initiating Application, seek these orders as both interim orders and final orders. STAY ORDER PENDING AN OBJECTION, AAT REVIEW OR COURT PROCEEDINGS (STAY COLLECTION OF ARREARS BUT NOT THE LIABILITY) Interim and final orders 1. That under Section 111C of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 the operation of all child support assessments payable by [payer’s name] to [payee’s name] for [child’s name] be stayed pending determination of the application made by [applicant’s name] on [application date] and of any objection by the applicant and of any review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the Part 6A determination OR [if a stay pending court application] be stayed pending the final order of the Court. 2. That [payer’s name] continue to make payments of $[amount] per [week/fortnight/month, etc] in accordance with the current child support assessment. The amount payable is to be varied in accordance with any later assessments made for any period after [today’s date]. PAYING A DIFFERENT AMOUNT PENDING PROCEEDINGS Interim and final orders 1. That under Section 111C of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 the operation of all child support assessments payable by [payer’s name] to [payee’s name] for [child’s name] be stayed pending determination of the application made by [applicant’s name] on [application date] and of any objection by the applicant and of any review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the Part 6A determination OR [if a stay pending court application] be stayed pending the final order of the Court.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: stayed pending determination of the application made by [applicant’s name] on [application date] and of any objection by the applicant and of any review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the Part 6A determination OR [if a stay pending court application] be stayed pending the final order of the Court. 2. That while the assessments are stayed and from [today’s date], [payer’s name] shall make payments of child support to [payee’s name] of $[amount] per [week/fortnight/month, etc]. NO PAYMENTS PENDING PROCEEDINGS Interim and final orders 1. That under Section 111C of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 the collection of child support payable (current liability and arrears) by [payer’s name] to [payee’s name] for [child’s name] be stayed pending determination of the application made by [applicant’s name] on [appli- cant’s date] and of any objection by the applicant and of any review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the Part 6A determination OR [if a stay pending court application] be stayed pending the final order of the Court. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 96 Note – After 1 July 2008, an order can stay the collection of child support by ordering the Registrar: • to cease collecting from a payer’s salary; • to withdraw or modify a s 72A garnishment notice; • not to collect a payer’s taxation refund; • not to disburse monies held to the payee; or • to cease any and all administrative collection. The former Child Support Agency said on its website: consider the possibility that a collection opportu- nity could be forgone during a period where a stay order is in force that may not arise again in the im- mediate future. In some cases, it would be prudent to enable collection to proceed but stay the Registrar from disbursing monies collected. AFFIDAVIT IN SUPPORT OF APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS Introduction 1. I am the Applicant father. 2. I apply for a stay of proceedings in this case. 3. On [date], an assessment was issued by the Child Support Registrar for payment of child sup- port by me for [child’s full name] [“[C]”] born [date] being the child of my marriage to [full name] [“[Y]”]. 4. [Y] and I were married on [date] and separated on [date]. 5. When we separated I left our jointly owned home at [address] and began living in rented accommodation. [C] was [age]. 6. [Y] applied to the Registrar for child support for [C], and I was assessed to pay $[amount] per month. 7. A true copy of the notice of that assessment is attached to this affidavit. 8. On [date] I applied to the Registrar for a change of the assessment and on [date] the Registrar refused my application. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of that decision. 9. On [date] I lodged an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLICATION FOR A STAY OF PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: of the notice of that assessment is attached to this affidavit. 8. On [date] I applied to the Registrar for a change of the assessment and on [date] the Registrar refused my application. Attached to this affidavit is a true copy of that decision. 9. On [date] I lodged an objection to the decision on the grounds that [specify] [OR specify any other administrative action taken, such as your client’s application for change of assessment being granted and Y lodging an objection to that decision, or an application being made by either party to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a decision by the Registrar OR specify that on [date] an application was filed by [specify] in the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia for a [specify] order.] Stay of proceedings 10. I apply to this Court for a stay of proceedings until those proceedings have been finalised OR for a stay of the collection of child support by an order that the Registrar cease collecting payments from my salary OR that the Registrar withdraw or modify the “section 72A garnishment notice” served on my employer [name] OR that the Registrar not collect my tax refund that is due [date] OR that the Registrar not disburse money received from me to [Y] OR that the Registrar cease all further collection of child support from me until further order. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 98 APPEAL TO A COURT FROM AAT ON A QUESTION OF LAW A party may appeal from a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to the Federal Court of Australia on a question of law (s 44(1) AAT Act 1975 (“AATA”)) by filing in that Court and serving each other party and the Registrar of the Tribunal within 28 days a “Notice of appeal from a tribunal” (Form 75) in accordance with the procedure contained in Rule 33.12 of the Federal Court Rules 2011. OR may appeal to the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia from an AAT first review deci- sion or from a decision of the child support registrar to issue a departure prohibition order (s 44AAA(1) AATA) by filing in that Court and serving each other party, the child support registrar and the Registrar of the Tribunal within 28 days a Notice of Appeal (Child Support) in accordance rule 1.13 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. The procedure for a Notice of Appeal (Child Support) is set out in the preamble of the form. Also see FLR 1.13. An appellant must attach a copy of the AAT’s decision (or the registrar’s departure prohibition decision) and reasons for decision and may also file a financial statement and any affidavit to be relied on in the appeal. The time limit for an appeal from the AAT is 28 days of receiving the reasons for decision: ss 44(2A) and 44AAA(2)(a) AATA. Court papers are to be served on the other parent or eligible carer and the child support registrar or registrar of the Tribunal (as applicable) at least 28 days (and any other documents on which you intend to rely at least 21 days) before the hearing. A
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPEAL TO A COURT FROM AAT ON A QUESTION OF LAW

chunks.text: and 44AAA(2)(a) AATA. Court papers are to be served on the other parent or eligible carer and the child support registrar or registrar of the Tribunal (as applicable) at least 28 days (and any other documents on which you intend to rely at least 21 days) before the hearing. A Response is not required but the respondent must file and serve a notice of address for service. We recommend that you brief counsel to draw your grounds of appeal (on a question of law). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

That leave be granted under Section 111 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 for the court to make an order under Section 118 of the Act for departure from the administrative assessment of child support payable by [Parent A’s full name] to [Parent B’s full name] for the children [their full names] as follows. 2. That for the period from [commencement of the child support liability] to the date of this order, the total amount of child support be set equal to the monies already paid for that period, including the value of any non-agency payments credited for that same period, with the effect that no arrears remain payable and no overpayment is created. 3. That for the period from the date of this order to [end date] the annual rate of child support be set at $[amount] per child. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

The Respondent “[X]”) [insert his/her first name that he/she was known by, e.g. Bill, then use that throughout the affidavit] and I were married at [place] on [date]. 3. We lived together from [date] until [date], when we separated. 4. There are [insert] children of our marriage namely [list full names and dates of birth of each child]. 5. I am [insert] years of age, born [date]. 6. Since our separation the children have been in [my/X’s] care at [address]. Leave to amend child support assessment Note – This application is most likely to be brought by a payer (often in conjunction with other proceedings between the parties) wishing to have large arrears discharged and child support reduced to nil or a manageable amount. Select from the following paragraphs and then focus the evidence upon the particular matters required to be proved under the subsection of s 117(2) being relied on. As a guide, download “Your application: Changing your child support assessment in special circumstances” from “administrative forms” above. It is the same application, but one that is made administratively. 7. A child support assessment was made on [date] for the amount of $[amount] per month. This compares with my total expenses for the children of $[amount] weekly, or $[amount] monthly. 8. Attached is a true copy of the Child Support Registrar’s notice of assessment of child support. 9. I refer to my Financial Statement filed in these proceedings. 10. My income since separation has been $[amount], from my pension of $[amount]. 11. Although I had some part-time work as a [specify] prior to our marriage, I have been out of the workforce for [insert] years so

I refer to the affidavit sworn by my doctor (Dr [name]) as to my health and how it affects my life and ability to enter the paid workforce. [Specify in some detail, and in natural language, how ill health is limiting the seeking of employment] 13. My fixed and weekly expenses total $[amount] per week. My income of $[amount] leaves a shortfall of $[amount] weekly. I have had to meet that shortfall by using my bank savings. Explain nature of course; duration; breakdown of its cost] [Although interim lump sums are rare, you could include it in your claim – and this affidavit – if there is a case for, say, the upfront costs of a course being required to be paid and X has the funds to pay a lump sum. chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 102 APPLICATION FOR MAINTENANCE OF A CHILD OVER 18 Note – Under s 66Q, urgent child maintenance may be applied for if your client can show that the child is in immediate need of financial assistance (emergency funding). As this section is similar to s 77 for spousal maintenance, see “urgent maintenance orders” in the chapter “spousal maintenance”. In most cases, you would file an application seeking both interim and final orders. A Financial Statement must be filed too. An order can be made for a child who is 17, to take effect when or after the child turns 18. Who should bring such an application? Under s 66F a parent or the adult child may apply. If a child applies for an order against one parent, that parent could join the other parent as second respondent enabling an order to be made against both parents as occurred in Re: AM (Adult Child Maintenance) (see Case Table). If the child’s disability is a mental one, an application would have to be made by an appropriate adult, possibly a parent, for the appointment of a case guardian (see Chapter 8). Interim and final orders 1. That from [start date], [payer’s full name] shall pay to the adult child [applicant’s full name] main- tenance for [adult child’s name] at the rate of $[amount] per [week/fortnight/month, etc] to enable [him/her] to complete [his/her] [secondary schooling/tertiary training/education] at [specify] institution [and, if tertiary, name of course]. [OR if applicable] 1. That from [start date], [payer’s full name] shall pay to the adult child [applicant’s full name] main- tenance for [adult child’s name] at the rate of $[amount] per [week/fortnight/month, etc] for the duration of [his/her] mental or physical disability, such period being as agreed between the parties or ordered by
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

[and then, in either case, the next clause] 2. That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s taxed costs of and incidental to this Application. The Respondent (“[X]”) [insert his/her first name that he/she was known by, e.g. Bill, then use that throughout the affidavit] and I were married at [place] on [date]. 3. We lived together from [date] until [date], when we separated. 4. [Y], who was born on [date] is [age] at the time of my swearing of this affidavit. 5. I am [age] and working [full-time etc] as a [specify] and [X] is [age], working [full-time etc] as a [specify]. 6. Since our separation [Y] has been in [my/X’s] care at [address]. 7. A child support assessment for [Y] for [X] to pay child support of $[amount] per month expired on [date] when [Y] turned 18 [or finished high school, whichever applied]. [X] was paying the amount assessed but has refused to support [him/her] beyond [his/her] 18th birthday. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 103 Maintenance for Y 8. Since [date], [Y] has been attending [specify the place of tertiary education or training] as a full-time student in [specify course], which is a [specify] year course to complete [his/her] education, the cost of that course being as follows: [list under each year of the course, tuition fees, other fees, all incidental expenses such as books, levies and any necessary away from home accommodation and travelling]. OR 8. [Y] suffers from [specify Y’s mental or physical disability, with details of symptoms and their frequency and effect on the amount of care your client is required to give and the cost of that care]. 9. I refer to my Financial Statement, and [X]’s, filed in these proceedings. My Financial Statement sets out the costs I have just for [Y]’s continuing care, and to which [X] has refused to contribute. His words to me on the subject, on [date] at [occasion], were “[specify]”. [The following clauses apply whichever kind of application this is.] 10. My income since [Y] [turned 18/left school] has been $[amount], my living expenses $[amount] weekly and my debts total $[amount]. My only assets or resources are [specify]. [X]’s income is $[amount], his expenses $[amount] weekly. He has no debt, assets worth $[amount] and superannuation which he will be able to access at age 55 in [specify] years’ time. 11. Although I had some part-time work as a [specify] prior to our marriage, I have been out of the workforce for [insert] years so I have no skills for paid employment. 12. [If filing an affidavit from your client’s doctor] I refer to the affidavit sworn by my doctor (Dr [name]) as to my health and how it affects my life and ability to enter the paid workforce.

chunks.text: CHAPTER FIVE 5 – 104 APPLICATION FOR MAINTENANCE OF A STEP-CHILD Note – The former Child Support Agency’s website* stated that where a child maintenance order is made for a step-child, a parent may apply to the Child Support Registrar for an adjustment to their child support income. In effect, the parent will be assessed as having a relevant dependent child (which, under s 5 of the CSAA includes a child for whom such an order is in force), and will therefore have a relevant dependent child amount deducted from their adjusted taxable income when the Registrar calculates child support for their other child support children. Under the new formula (1 July 2008), both parents can have their adjusted taxable income adjusted by the costs relating to a relevant dependent child. *Any statements said to be from that website are copyright of the Commonwealth of Australia, and are reproduced under permission of the Commonwealth. Interim and final orders Note – Court delays are such that an interim application is likely to be necessary as well. 1. That it is proper for [step-parent’s full name] to have a duty of maintaining [step-child’s full name] under Section 66M of the Family Law Act 1975. 2. That from [start date], [step-parent’s name] shall pay child maintenance for [step-child’s name] to [step-child’s parent’s name] at the rate of $[amount] per [week/fortnight/month, etc]. 3. The amount of child maintenance payable under clause 2 will be adjusted from [day and month] each year, in accordance with variations in the Consumer Price Index for the [specify] quarter for [capital city OR weighted average of all cities]. Consequences of such an order Such an order may mean that a parent’s assessed income for child support (for children from another relationship) is reduced, so that parent pays less or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 8. Since [date], [Y] has been attending [specify the place of tertiary education or training] as

chunks.text: variations in the Consumer Price Index for the [specify] quarter for [capital city OR weighted average of all cities]. Consequences of such an order Such an order may mean that a parent’s assessed income for child support (for children from another relationship) is reduced, so that parent pays less or receives more child support for his or her other children (see definition of relevant dependent child in s 5 and also s 39 CSAA). An order under s 66M means that the step-parent has a legal duty to maintain the step-child. Should he or she separate from their spouse (the parent of the step-child) they may be required to pay child maintenance for the step-child. The order can be registered with the Child Support Registrar for collection as it is a “registrable maintenance liability” within the meaning of s 17(1) of the CSR&CA. If a person has a legal duty to maintain a step-child (because they are a relevant dependent child due to an order under s 66M) they may be able to seek a further adjustment of their child support assessment if their step-child has special needs that affect their capacity to financially support their child support children (ss 98B, 98C and 117(2)(a)(ii)). A person can also apply to the Child Support Registrar for a change of assessment if their capacity to provide financial support for the children of the child support assessment is significantly reduced because of their responsibility to maintain a “resident child”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 105 This provision allows a parent to have their financial responsibility for a child recognised in their child support assessment if: • the child lives with them, but is not their biological or adopted child • they have lived with the parent of the child for two years • neither of the child’s biological parents can provide financial support for the child due to death, ill health, or caring responsibilities and • the child is under 18, not a member of couple, and requires financial assistance. See s 117(10) of the CSAA for the full definition of a ‘resident child’. It is not necessary to establish legal responsibility for the child, nor for the person to be married to the child’s parent. Note that a parent will not be found to be unable to provide financial support simply because they pay a minimal amount of child support or do not comply with child support obligations. We were a family until [date], when we separated. [Y] was [age]. In all that time together until then, [X] treated [Y] as a member of the family. 5. I am now [age] and

chunks.text: CHILD SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE 5 – 107 APPLICATION FOR CHILD-BEARING EXPENSES OF UNMARRIED MOTHER Note – Such an application is quite rare, and not surprisingly, as an applicant’s legal costs are likely to be disproportionate to the amount of the claim. If one is brought, file it no sooner than three months after and no later than 12 months after the birth. This is because maintenance (of the mother) is recoverable for up to three months after the birth (see “child-bearing expenses of unmarried mothers” above) and s 67G applies a time limit of 12 months for applying). The father is liable under s 67B(a) to contribute to the maintenance of the mother for that period in relation to the birth of the child, so your client’s affidavit will need to be able to identify pregnancy- or birth-related expenses that are not covered by child support (CSAA) or medical expenses (s 67B(b)), both of which are separate, additional entitlements. The “childbirth maintenance period” begins on the day the mother stops working (if doing so more than two months before the due date, on doctor’s advice related to the pregnancy) or, in any other case, two months before the due date. Final orders sought 1. That the Respondent [full name] pay to the Applicant [full name] $[amount] per week for her maintenance for the childbirth maintenance period in relation to the birth of the child due to be born to the parties on [date]. 2. That the childbirth maintenance period for the purposes of this order [if the Applicant works in paid employment; and is advised by a doctor to stop working for medical reasons related to her pregnancy; and stops working after being so advised and more than two months before the child is due to be born] is the

[X] is the father of our child and is named as such in the birth certificate [OR X is not named as the child’s father because (explain why)]. 6. chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 2 ESTABLISHING A CLAIM The right of a spouse to maintenance This is governed by s 72(1) of the FLA: “(1) A party to a marriage is liable to maintain the other party, to the extent that the…party is reasonably able to do so, if, and only if, that other party is unable to support herself or himself adequately whether: (a) by reason of having the care and control of a child of the marriage who has not attained the age of 18 years; (b) by reason of age or physical or mental incapacity for appropriate gainful employment; or (c) for any other adequate reason; having regard to any relevant matter referred to in subsection 75(2).” This is known as the “threshold test” and is twofold: • Is the payer “reasonably able” to pay, and • Is the applicant “unable to support herself or himself adequately”? Nygh J said in Eliades [1980] FamCA 7 at [3]: “ … [T]he test of ability to support oneself is not identical to the test of whether one is in need but means whether the applicant is in a position to finance himself or herself from his or her own resources. That is to say, the test is whether by reason of earning capacity, by reason of capital or other sources of income which have accrued independently to the applicant, the applicant is in a position to look after herself.” De facto maintenance claims De facto couples whose relationships break down after 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA) (except in WA which as at June 2010 had not referred its de facto relationship power to the Commonwealth) must apply for maintenance under FLA: ss 39A(5) and 90RC(2). Those whose relationships broke down before then may choose to opt
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: down after 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA) (except in WA which as at June 2010 had not referred its de facto relationship power to the Commonwealth) must apply for maintenance under FLA: ss 39A(5) and 90RC(2). Those whose relationships broke down before then may choose to opt in to the new regime: s 86A, Part 2 of Schedule 1 of the Amendment Act (and s 90A in WA if it becomes a participating jurisdiction). This would be unlikely where opting-in would expose a party to a maintenance claim not available under their State or Territory law. Section 72 above (the right to maintenance) is equivalent to ss 90SD – 90SF for de facto claims. Such claims also require a 2-year relationship or a child or substantial contributions in relation to a de facto relationship (and serious injustice if the order sought is not made) or a registered relationship (s 90SB) AND either party being ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the application was made, and both parties being ordinarily resident there when the relationship broke down (s 90SD). The court’s (spousal and de facto) maintenance power • Section 74(1) empowers the court to make “such order as it considers proper for the provision of maintenance” of a party to the marriage (s 90SE for de facto claims). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 3 • The court, under s 75(1), is then directed that “in exercising jurisdiction under s 74, the court shall take into account only the matters referred to in subsection (2)” (s 90SF(2) and (3) for de facto claims). Note – In de facto claims the court can also take into account the terms of any property or maintenance order made or proposed in relation to a de facto party’s spouse or other de facto. • The various kinds of order available are set out in s 80(1) (s 90SS for de facto claims). • The court also has power under s 77 to order urgent spousal maintenance where a party is in immediate need of financial assistance (s 90SG for de facto claims). Three types of application for maintenance • Urgent maintenance (but see below) • Interim order for maintenance • Final order for maintenance Court procedure For how to issue and respond to maintenance proceedings, and for samples of orders to be sought (by both parties) and sample affidavits in support, see “procedure”, “forms” and “precedents” below. The Full Court held in Bevan [1993] FamCA 95 at [53] that the law relating to an award of spousal maintenance requires: (1) a threshold finding under s 72 (s 90SF for de facto claims); (2) consideration of ss 74 and 75(2) (or ss 90SE and 90SF(3)); (3) there is no fettering principle that the pre-separation standard of living must automatically be awarded where the respondent’s means permit; and (4) discretion should be exercised in accordance with s 74 (or s 90SE), “reasonableness in the circumstances” being the guiding principle. Bevan was followed by the Full Court in Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 at [68] which said: “The days are long gone when it is necessary for an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: permit; and (4) discretion should be exercised in accordance with s 74 (or s 90SE), “reasonableness in the circumstances” being the guiding principle.
