Bevan was followed by the Full Court in Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 at [68] which said: “The days are long gone when it is necessary for an applicant for maintenance to use up all of her assets and capital in order to satisfy the requirement that she is unable to support herself ‘adequately’. Where the line is to be drawn will depend on the circumstances of individual cases.” Onus of proof The Full Court applied these principles in M & M (McCrossen) [2006] FamCA 868, but ruled against an applicant wife who had failed to discharge the onus of satisfying the provisions of s 72 (s 90SF for de facto claims), having given evidence of not wanting to inquire about employment that was reason- ably available to her (see “maintenance factors” under (b) below). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 4 TIME LIMIT Spousal maintenance The deadline for issuing an application for spousal maintenance (and a property order) is 12 months after a divorce order has taken effect, except by leave of the court or consent of the parties: s 44(3) Leave to apply out of time shall not be granted unless the court, under subsection (4), is satisfied: • that hardship would be caused to a party or a child if leave were not granted; or • in the case of spousal maintenance proceedings, that at the time of the deadline, the applicant was unable to support himself or herself without an income-tested pension, allowance or benefit. De facto maintenance A party to a de facto relationship may apply for maintenance (and a property order) only if the application is made within 2 years after the end of the relationship (s 44(5)) or 12 months after a BFA is set aside (s 44(3B) or (5)), except by leave or consent. As to “consent”, see s 44(3AA) or (5A). The court may grant leave to apply out of time on the same grounds as for spousal maintenance above: s 44(6) Both types of maintenance This time limit does not apply to applications under s 83 or s 90SI to vary, revive, suspend or discharge an order: subsection (3) Nor does it apply for a maintenance application brought where previous maintenance orders have been satisfied: see Blevins [2019] FCCA 1923 which discusses the authorities. See “property” chapter (under “time limit”) for applications for leave to extend time. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 5 DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP This can be a preliminary issue in a de facto case. It is usually raised by a respondent who, by seeking an interim declaration under s 90RD FLA, disputes the applicant’s right to maintenance orders. (In WA a respondent must seek an interim order dismissing the case for want of jurisdiction under s 205Z FCA. If the court does lack jurisdiction it may still award costs: FCR 11.1.) See “de facto maintenance claims” above as to the right to bring such a claim. A person is in a “de facto relationship” with another person if they are not married or related to each other and, having regard to all the circumstances of their relationship, they have a relationship as a cou- ple living together on a genuine domestic basis: s 4AA(1) (in WA s 13A Interpretation Act 1984 (WA)). A “de facto relationship” includes same sex partners and can exist if a partner is married to someone else or is in another de facto relationship: s 4AA(5). Under s 4AA(2) those circumstances may include: • length of the relationship • ownership, use and acquisition of property • nature and extent of their common residence • degree of mutual commitment to a shared life • whether a sexual relationship exists • care and support of children • degree of financial dependence and support • reputation and public aspects of the relationship • whether the relationship is or was registered e.g. under Relationships Act (Tas & Vic), Civil Part- nerships Act (ACT & Qld) and Relationships Register Act (NSW and SA) A declaration may be sought under s 90RD (for WA see the 1st para above) that a de facto relationship of at least two years existed or did not
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP

chunks.text: e.g. under Relationships Act (Tas & Vic), Civil Part- nerships Act (ACT & Qld) and Relationships Register Act (NSW and SA) A declaration may be sought under s 90RD (for WA see the 1st para above) that a de facto relationship of at least two years existed or did not exist between the parties; that the relationship broke down before Part VIIIAB commenced (1/3/09 or 1/7/10 for SA); as to whether there is a child of the relationship; whether a party made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a), (b) or (c); and where each party was ordinarily resident during the relationship. For samples, see “Response” under “precedents” in Chapter 6 and “declaration” at our online “forms and precedents”. The leading case as to the existence of a “de facto relationship” is Moby & Schulter [2010] FamCA 748 at [126]-[142]. See also Jonah & White [2011] FamCA 221 at [34]-[67] and Taisha & Peng and Anor [2012] FamCA 385 at [6]-[21] as to the meaning of “couple” and “living together on a domestic basis”. The absence of a common residence did not prevent an affirmative outcome in Dakin & Sansbury [2010] FMCAfam 628 (see [170]-[173]) but did in Jensen & Taylor [2011] FMCAfam 1251 (see [51]). For WA cases under the FCA, see Truman & Clifton [2010] FCWA 91. Also see Dahl & Hamblin [2011] FamCAFC 202 at [48] (aggregation of time where an interrupted relationship is resumed); A & G [2009] FCWA 110 (separation under one roof); Miller & Trent [2011] FMCAfam 324 at [46]-[103] (substantial contributions and serious injustice under s 90SB(c)); Allenby & Kimble [2012] FamCA 614 at [91] (emails and documentation given weight); Kazama & Britton [2013] FamCA 4 (separate homes not fatal; prior inconsistent statement to Dept of Immigration). See Keene & Scofield (No. 2) [2013] FCCA
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP

chunks.text: FMCAfam 324 at [46]-[103] (substantial contributions and serious injustice under s 90SB(c)); Allenby & Kimble [2012] FamCA 614 at [91] (emails and documentation given weight); Kazama & Britton [2013] FamCA 4 (separate homes not fatal; prior inconsistent statement to Dept of Immigration). See Keene & Scofield (No. 2) [2013] FCCA 1107 at [419]-[432] for the effect of failing to adduce independent evi- dence in support of one’s case. For more case law, see “de facto” at our online “case notes – property”. Applicants where “relationship” will be disputed Where any relationship aspect of your client’s application is likely to be disputed, send a detailed proof of evidence as to all of the above relationship aspects to counsel for an opinion as to the likelihood of the relationship being held to satisfy the requirements of a de facto claim under the FLA (and, if not, which aspects of the evidence should be strengthened, and how). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 6 URGENT MAINTENANCE ORDERS Section 77 provides that: “Where, in proceedings with respect to the maintenance of a party to a marriage, it appears to the court that the party is in immediate need of financial assistance, but it is not practicable in the circumstances to determine immediately what order, if any, should be made, the court may order the payment, pending the disposal of the proceedings, of such periodic sum or other sums as the Court considers reasonable.” Note – The equivalent section for de facto claims is s 90SG. Nygh J in Ashton [1982] FamCA 9 said at [4]-[6]: “An application (for urgent maintenance) is heard at a time when all the evidence is not yet to hand…an application for interim maintenance must not be confused with an application for urgent maintenance…an application for interim maintenance can only be heard after each party has had the opportunity to adduce evidence (by) the filing of affidavits by both parties and the financial statements.” Watson SJ held in Malcolm [1977] FamCA 27 at [12] that the wife who continued to live in the home rent-free, had a part-time job and $6,000 was not in immediate need of financial assistance: “Section 77…is to provide emergency funding in those cases where the Court is unable to determine immediately what order should be made.” Urgent maintenance was refused in Grimshaw-Grieves & Grieves [2011] FMCAfam 125 as the appli- cant had bank savings of $17,300. Fogarty J has described s 77 as being “aimed at orders in circumstances of relieving pressing… need, and is determined on a rather pragmatic basis without any real hearing upon the merits. It is in the nature of a stop-gap order…for a short, ordinarily definitive period of time”: Williamson [1978] FamCA 57. This “stop-gap” nature
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 77 as being “aimed at orders in circumstances of relieving pressing… need, and is determined on a rather pragmatic basis without any real hearing upon the merits. It is in the nature of a stop-gap order…for a short, ordinarily definitive period of time”: Williamson [1978] FamCA 57. This “stop-gap” nature was illustrated in Dein [1989] FamCA 19 where urgent spousal maintenance of $250 per week was awarded for five weeks. Such an order enables the parties to file their material and proceed to an interim (or final) maintenance hearing on the merits. Urgent applicants must establish a right to maintenance under s 72: Gyopar [1986] FamCA 64. Note – Due to its short life, an application for urgent maintenance is rarely a good idea. Applicants can usually apply quickly for interim maintenance, completing a Financial Statement and a short affidavit of evidence as to the reason for it (see “procedure for maintenance applications” below). If you must apply for urgent maintenance, an application to the FCFCA with a short affidavit as to why it is sought is enough (no Financial Statement is necessary). If you struggle with it, however, you will not be allowed to re-label it an interim maintenance application: see Ashton (above). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 7 INTERIM MAINTENANCE An interim maintenance order may be made under s 74 or s 80 of the Family Law Act. For an example of how interim maintenance applications are dealt with, see the decision of Wicklow [2007] FamCA 792, where Judicial Registrar Johnston heard a matter where the wife sought interim spousal maintenance of $4,264 per month. In this case: • the wife’s ownership of shares in her own name worth $110,000 did not bar her from being awarded spousal maintenance; • the finding that she had not worked full-time for 24 years, but had a working capacity of 2.5 days a week as a design consultant, did not affect her maintenance claim either; • the husband was found to have an earning capacity of $2–300,000 per annum; • the husband, who alleged no capacity to pay, was found to have had funds to pay for rent on a waterfront apartment, recent overseas travel, and subscriptions to various sporting clubs. After assessing which of the parties’ claimed expenses were reasonable, the Court held: “In circumstances where the husband has control of his income, control of a considerable amount of property of the parties…then in my view the Court should not be shy about making…an order (for interim) spousal maintenance. The task at the present time is one in which the Court does not have to be too particular about making findings…especially where there will be ample opportunity for the Court to consider the matter in greater detail in a substantive (the final) hearing.” The wife’s reasonable needs were found to be $3,200 per month and an interim order for spousal maintenance was made for that amount. In Kitman [2007] FamCA 822, a husband on appeal to the Full Court won: • a reduction of interim
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: greater detail in a substantive (the final) hearing.” The wife’s reasonable needs were found to be $3,200 per month and an interim order for spousal maintenance was made for that amount. In Kitman [2007] FamCA 822, a husband on appeal to the Full Court won: • a reduction of interim maintenance from $660 to $110 per week due to his expenses (which properly included his payments towards a joint mortgage) • the halving of an interim lump sum award of $2,000 due to scant evidence of the wife’s immediate need An example of an interim order for periodic maintenance on top of an interim property settlement was Oates & Crest [2008] FamCAFC 29 where the husband of a judicial officer was granted $107,000 towards legal costs ($80,000); rental of “superior accommodation until the final hearing” ($30,000); furniture and household items ($14,000). As it was found that “the husband would be left with little or nothing of the $107,000 from which to support himself” after payment of such “debts and other reason- able expenses” (paras 33, 37–8), an order was made for his “reasonable weekly needs” until the final hearing in the sum of $984 per week. For a review of the relevant law, see Rainsford [2010] FMCAfam 231. Partial property settlement before interim maintenance The Full Court in Oates & Crest also held that interim (or partial) property settlement should be determined first, so that the need for interim periodic maintenance may be assessed in light of what lump sum provision had been made. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 8 MAINTENANCE FACTORS The matters to be taken into account under s 75(2) (and s 90SF(3) for de facto claims) are: (a) the age and state of health of each party Age Age is often raised as a factor for wives after a long absence from the workforce. It has been said of a 57-year-old wife working three days a week as a part-time shop assistant that despite the absence of “evidence about lack of training for employment, reduced health or mobility or other factors…(the court) can take judicial notice that 60 is the normal age of retirement for women and that it may be difficult for women approaching that age to retain or obtain full-time employment”: Nygh J in Atwill [1981] FamCA 72 at [21]. See the Full Court’s use of published research on “the feminisation of poverty” in Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 at [76]. But see B & B [2002] FMCAfam 439 at [21]-[25] where it was held, despite W’s age (59), that medical and other evidence was necessary to prove mental incapacity for employment. Age combined with serious ill health can substantially favour a maintenance applicant: Zubcic [1995] FamCA 143, about a 60-year-old man disabled in an industrial accident. On the other hand, it was held in Richardson [1979] FamCA 7 at [47] that “a considerable qualification to [a respondent’s] earning capacity is his age [which was 62]”, although the Court should also consider the respondent’s entitlement to significant superannuation at age 65. Health Shock suffered by a young wife at the end of her marriage worsened a pre-existing illness to such an extent as to render her unable to work: Tye (No. 2) [1976] FamCA 30. The trial judge awarded periodic maintenance until the time of the wife’s expected return to work.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Health Shock suffered by a young wife at the end of her marriage worsened a pre-existing illness to such an extent as to render her unable to work: Tye (No. 2) [1976] FamCA 30. The trial judge awarded periodic maintenance until the time of the wife’s expected return to work. She was also awarded lump sum main- tenance, upheld by the Full Court as a proper replenishment of capital spent on medical expenses. A wife with multiple sclerosis was awarded a property settlement and lump sum spousal maintenance by way of the transfer to her of the home, which was suitable for her needs, not having stairs and being close to transport and shops: Dow-Sainter [1980] FamCA 60. See also W & W [1997] FamCA 3 where the Full Court held that the wife’s state of health: “resulted in her having a need for a dwelling constructed of low maintenance materials, her need for special care and paid housekeeping assistance, a car and other special items”. An unemployed 53-year-old wife with past experience as a hairdresser called her GP whose evidence that she was overweight, suffered joint pain in her hands and knees and was unfit for full-time work was accepted by Roberts FM in A & A [2003] FMCAfam 216. The court did, however, find her capable of taking a computer course at TAFE and of full-time employment in another line of work within 12 months, awarding her lump sum maintenance of $10,000. A lump sum was granted to a wife with cancer for the 2 years that she was likely to survive: Bolton [1992] FamCA 48. Cohen J found “the need for the wife to be finished with litigation…a powerful con- sideration” in favour of a lump sum in preference to periodic maintenance. Update 64 March 2025 quarter
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a wife with cancer for the 2 years that she was likely to survive: Bolton [1992] FamCA 48. Cohen J found “the need for the wife to be finished with litigation…a powerful con- sideration” in favour of a lump sum in preference to periodic maintenance. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 9 A wife in reasonably good health who suffered occasional bouts of illness due to a recurring kidney complaint was considered by the trial judge to be “an intelligent woman who is capable of acquiring skills through a course of study”: Hope [1977] FamCA 39 at [5]. See also H & H [2003] FMCAfam 471 where Raphael FM dismissed the maintenance claim of a 47-year-old wife who was found to have a heart complaint but to have exaggerated her claimed disability and not met her obligation of seeking out work that, according to her doctor’s evidence, she was capable of undertaking. Her admission to being a regular bowler (of which her doctor was unaware) did not help her case. The court rejected a husband’s claim of incapacity for other employment due to profound hearing loss in both ears, and limited command of English, finding that he had been “continuously employed as a process worker (for) many years…was otherwise in good health…and was likely (to) continue in employment in the foreseeable future”: Penza [1988] FamCA 37 at [57]. A husband’s injuries were held not to be relevant where he had a reasonable prospect of recovering $70,000 for those injuries: Nicholson CJ in Townsend [1994] FamCA 144. Note – The affidavit of an applicant alleging a disabling state of health should be supported by an affidavit by a medical practitioner, but as will be seen from H & H above, it is always advisable to prepare well (see “precedents” below for a sample affidavit). Disputing medical evidence alleging ill health Cases where a husband has obtained an interim order from the court that a wife alleging ill health preventing her from working submit to an independent examination: Hunt [2001] FCWA 1 (by a rheumatologist, where pain and other
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: “precedents” below for a sample affidavit). Disputing medical evidence alleging ill health Cases where a husband has obtained an interim order from the court that a wife alleging ill health preventing her from working submit to an independent examination: Hunt [2001] FCWA 1 (by a rheumatologist, where pain and other symptoms were alleged) and Gilbert [1988] FamCA 48 (by a psychiatrist where a psychiatric condition was alleged). Note – Applications for an order for an independent examination are unusual, but as there is precedent for them they are available for the rebuttal of medical evidence filed by an applicant. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 10 (b) the income, property and financial resources of each party and the physical and mental capacity of each for appropriate gainful employment Applicant’s income A wife’s maintenance order was discharged when the court found that due to “an excess of income over outgoings (she was) able to maintain herself adequately”: Corner [1978] FamCA 30 at [22] (Bell J). An applicant is not disqualified by having a partial earning capacity: Kajewski [1978] FamCA 62. Respondent’s income In DJM & JLM [1998] FamCA 97 where a doctor reduced his income the Full Court said at [17.50]: “A judge might accept that it is unreasonable to expect a parent to continue to work 80 hours per week whilst having obligations to care for one child, and whilst that parent is still earning more than sufficient for his or her own needs and the needs of that parent’s children. Alternatively, a judge might conclude, based on a proven work history, that such a work pattern is entirely reason- able in the circumstances. Ultimately the matter reverts to the exercise of discretion by the trial judge based on the individual circumstances of the case … ” Property The Full Court said in Bevan [1993] FamCA 95 at [43]: “ … [W]e do not think that the law requires that a wife should deplete an already comparatively meagre capital sum [from the property settlement], to enable a much higher earning husband to avoid his obligation to maintain a former spouse who is in financial circumstances such as those in which she finds herself”. However, an applicant’s savings of $87,000 (not from a property settlement) have been held to be relevant: Padnall [2014] FamCAFC 145 at [34]-[38]. A three-bedroom house occupied by H was held to be a financial resource as H
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: is in financial circumstances such as those in which she finds herself”. However, an applicant’s savings of $87,000 (not from a property settlement) have been held to be relevant: Padnall [2014] FamCAFC 145 at [34]-[38]. A three-bedroom house occupied by H was held to be a financial resource as H could earn an income from the home by taking in boarders: Vartikian (No. 2) [1984] FamCA 63 (Gee J). In Kiesinger & Paget [2008] FamCAFC 23 at [27] an “imbalance in … capital resources … was a relevant consideration … [as to interim maintenance]”. For the courts’ approach to an interim maintenance application, see Fewster & Drake [2016] FamCAFC 214 at [103]-[108]. Financial resources Were defined by Fogarty J in Crapp [1979] FamCA 17 as “a source of financial support which a party can reasonably expect will be available to him or her to supply a financial need or deficiency”. W’s new husband was held in Mee & Ferguson [1986] FamCA 3 to be a financial resource of W and the children of her prior marriage. Also see Hall v Hall [2016] HCA 23 at [31]-[56] as to W’s capacity to call on executors of her father’s estate for an advance. The Full Court in Plut [1987] FamCA 52 held that a party could be required to use property or financial resources to pay spousal maintenance if income were not available. In Noble [2014] FCCA 421 at [109]-[114] a $1m trust “controlled by [the income-poor H]” was held not to be “sacrosanct” as a potential source of maintenance. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 11 As was a wife’s “reasonable expectation of (significant) future financial assistance, and ultimately substantial inheritance from her parents”: Campbell [1987] FamCA 68 (Lindenmayer J at [106]). See also White & Tulloch [1995] FamCA 127. The husband’s proceeds of sale of a taxi spent on himself and partly for the children was added back to the asset pool notionally by the Full Court as a financial resource: Townsend [1994] FamCA 144. Also, a husband who brought about his own incapacity for self-support by spending a damages award instead of investing it was refused maintenance: Berta [1988] FamCA 33. A payee was held to be obligated to maximise his return on his investments: Bassingthwaite & Leane [1993] FamCA 86. Trust beneficiaries The interest of a party as beneficiary of a discretionary trust has been held to be a financial resource where it was found that the party: • had actual control over the trust’s assets: Tiley [1980] FamCA 73 and Kelly (No. 2) [1981] FamCA 78 • could compel the trustee’s discretion in her favour: Whitehead [1979] FamCA 41 • had no control but a reasonable expectation of benefiting: Bailey [1978] FamCA 20 However, in another case where a husband had no control over the trust assets or income a trust interest was excluded from consideration because the children held the shares that created most rights to income and capital: Yates (No. 2) [1982] FamCA 11. Applicant’s capacity for appropriate gainful employment See the Full Court’s statement in DJM & JLM above that “based on a proven work history … such a work pattern is entirely reasonable”. Maintenance was refused for a wife who had been employed for years but wished to further her education due to her health being such as to limit her earning capacity,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: in DJM & JLM above that “based on a proven work history … such a work pattern is entirely reasonable”. Maintenance was refused for a wife who had been employed for years but wished to further her education due to her health being such as to limit her earning capacity, the court ruling that she had a capacity for employment: Dench [1978] FamCA 65. Also see Telford [2012] FamCA 995 at [20]-[32] where W’s interim maintenance application was dismissed but H’s application for the sale of the home was granted. The court was not satisfied that W could not adequately support herself and said that there was “a significant question about the father’s capacity to make the [mortgage and maintenance] payments sought by the mother” ([26]). A young applicant without children is expected to seek employment: Taguchi [1987] FamCA 16, but a parent with young, even school-age, children may not be: Rouse [1981] FamCA 57. However, in Astbury [1978] FamCA 28 (at [19]) the Full Court has also said this: “…if the parties have enjoyed a high standard of living and the husband has ample resources, it may be unreasonable to expect the wife to seek unskilled and low paid employment, especially if the marriage is of long duration and she has no recent work experience”. It has been held that in the absence of evidence about the state of the workforce, it was not open to the court to find that a 51 year old wife, who had been out of the banking industry for many years and was currently working temporarily as a school assistant, could be expected to re-enter the banking industry and earn $1,000 p.w. as she had once before: Causero [2006] FamCA 1290 at [34]-[37]. Also see Wah & Golay [2016] FamCAFC 67 at [27]-[30]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: out of the banking industry for many years and was currently working temporarily as a school assistant, could be expected to re-enter the banking industry and earn $1,000 p.w. as she had once before: Causero [2006] FamCA 1290 at [34]-[37]. Also see Wah & Golay [2016] FamCAFC 67 at [27]-[30] cited under para (k) below. For the evidence to support a case for impaired earning capacity, see Metzer [2020] FCCA 119 at [181]-[187]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 12 Court dismisses maintenance claim of wife wanting to retrain The Full Court in M & M (McCrossen) [2006] FamCA 868 heard expert evidence adduced by the husband that the wife (who wanted to train as a teacher) could return to employment in the public service after ten weeks of training. The wife’s evidence was that she had made no inquiries as she was not interested in doing that kind of work again. The Court (Bryant CJ, Finn and Coleman JJ) held that the trial judge, Hannon J, was correct in holding that the wife had the onus of satisfying the provisions of s 72 and in not being satisfied that the wife was unable to maintain herself adequately. The Court at [46] said: “We are satisfied that…the considerations the Full Court in Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 was concerned with, such as lack of experience, being out of the skilled workforce for years and high unemployment rates, (were) not apposite in this case where there was evidence that the wife had refused to contemplate or enquire into part time work commensurate with her past experience, and which on a reasonable enquiry…would be available to her…after a relatively short period of re-training.” Disputing an applicant’s alleged inability to support themselves The court in this case accepted the evidence of the manager of a recruitment agency (adduced by the respondent) that the wife’s qualifications, experience and skills were such that, after 10 weeks of training, part-time employment would be available to the wife, at an expected wage of about $495 per week (see “precedents” below for a sample affidavit). Respondent’s capacity for appropriate gainful employment A maintenance order was made against a husband based on his earning capacity as a builder instead of his actual income as a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: be available to the wife, at an expected wage of about $495 per week (see “precedents” below for a sample affidavit). Respondent’s capacity for appropriate gainful employment A maintenance order was made against a husband based on his earning capacity as a builder instead of his actual income as a public servant: Benjamin (1976) 11 ALR 211. See also DJM & JLM (above under “respondent’s income”) and Bolton (above under “health”) where a husband had voluntarily left his employment to avoid paying child support. A husband whose career as a writer was preceded by unemployment was found to have no income or capacity for gainful work: Scott [1994] FamCA 12. A bricklayer who ceased work due to back problems, enrolling in a draftsman’s course, was held to be capable of average weekly earnings (as published by ABS) as a clerk: Stojanovic [1990] FamCA 13 (Kay J). A wife without job skills was awarded a lump sum for 4 years of support while she re-trained or estab- lished herself in a business: Woolley (No. 2) [1981] FamCA 3 (Nygh J). (c) whether either party has care or control of a child of the marriage In Rouse (above) and Richardson [1979] FamCA 7 parents of young children were not expected to seek work. The Full Court allowed the mother of a 16-year-old child to work three instead of five night shifts a week, but did reduce the amount of the maintenance order: Lusby [1977] FamCA 96. A wife’s earning capacity as a nurse was held to be inhibited by caring for two children for the 17 weeks of the year and weekends when they were not at boarding school: Horsley [1991] FamCA 95. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 13 (d) the commitments of each party that are necessary to enable the party to support: (i) himself or herself; and (ii) a child or another person that the party has a duty to maintain. Self-support commitments allowed or disallowed have been as follows: • Some entertainment YES DJM & JLM [1998] FamCA 97 at [20.19] • Holidays and cigarettes YES W & W [1997] FamCA 3 • Gifts, donations, gardening NO DJM & JLM at [20.19] • Executive’s work expenses YES Brady [1978] FamCA 54 at [31] Wood J rejected a claim that a wife was paying too much rent, having quit two cheaper flats, accepting that the flats were unsuitable and the wife had shown “restraint”: Petterd [1976] FamCA 43 at [9]. A wife was not required to take in boarders as the children lived with her on weekends: Baber [1980] FamCA 22 at [16]. See W & W (above) and Dow-Sainter [1980] FamCA 60. Also see Wah & Golay [2016] FamCAFC 67 at [26]. A husband was not allowed a financial buffer for ‘vicissitudes of life’ in Simpkin [2020] FamCAFC 315 at [15]-[17]. Financial needs can be premised upon anticipated, not actual costs: Badir [2022] FedCFamC1A 109 at [58] and [62]-[63]. Commitments for the support of a child A moral duty to support a child is not enough: Vick & Hartcher [1991] FamCA 79. In Stein [2000] FamCA 102 at [44]-[57] it was held that it could not be said that the wife’s expenditure on the children, beyond that which she could obtain by way of child support, was necessary expenditure or an element of her self support. In Drysdale [2011] FamCAFC 85 at [36]-[41] it was held that a court may consider the expenses of chil- dren at an interim spousal maintenance
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: expenditure on the children, beyond that which she could obtain by way of child support, was necessary expenditure or an element of her self support. In Drysdale [2011] FamCAFC 85 at [36]-[41] it was held that a court may consider the expenses of chil- dren at an interim spousal maintenance hearing. Padnall [2014] FamCAFC 145 at [47]-[52] contains a discussion of those two cases. Forgotten commitments? The checklists in the court’s Financial Statement (ex-Form 13) for fixed expenses (Part G) and weekly expenses (Part N) are not exhaustive. See under “precedents” below for a one-page addendum containing everyday but omitted commitments, to be attached to Part O of the Financial Statement (“Additional Information”). Note – An applicant may reasonably claim expenses not being incurred due to inability to pay: Garston & Yeo (No. 2) [2019] FamCAFC 139 at [29]-[30]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 14 (e) the responsibilities of either party to support any other person Ryan J held in Pope [2012] FamCA 204 at [171] that para (e) relates to “someone other than the parties … or [their] children who have not attained … 18” and that the duty to support could be a legal or moral one. Para (e) is “couched in wide terms and ought to be given a broad interpre- tation”: Full Court in Soblusky [1976] FamCA 90 at [86] which added that “[a] court is required under para (e) to consider in a realistic way the fact that a party has assumed a responsibility to support another person, and the weight to be given to that fact depends upon the circumstances of each individual case”. The Court refused to assume that a responsibility to a spouse was higher than to any other person such as a spouse or children of a second marriage. The relevant authori- ties are summarised in Brown [2007] FamCA 151 at [117]-[122]. Applicant A wife’s cost of supporting children of a prior marriage was allowed where a maintenance order against their father was unmet (see Richardson [1979] FamCA 7 at [51]) but was ignored where the wife could, but would not, proceed against the father who could afford to pay: Penza [1988] FamCA 37. Respondent As to repartnering, the Full Court applied Soblusky (above) in Axtell [1982] FamCA 10 at [37]-[38], say- ing at [44]: “It is unrealistic to ignore the fact that a man sharing a household with a woman and her children from a former marriage may need to make some contribution to their support. If … the children’s father can and should be called on to contribute to the support of the children, this may affect the weight
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: fact that a man sharing a household with a woman and her children from a former marriage may need to make some contribution to their support. If … the children’s father can and should be called on to contribute to the support of the children, this may affect the weight given to that matter. This is quite different from … assigning priorities to one … responsibility over another … ” • Expenses claimed by a party for his second wife were halved: Vick & Hartcher [1991] FamCA 79 at [34] • Such expenses were irrelevant if husband could afford to pay: Campbell [1987] FamCA 68 • The costs of children of a new de facto treated differently: Lutzke [1979] FamCA 60 and Baber [1980] FamCA 22 • Court looks to means of parents before those of step-parent: Mee & Ferguson [1986] FamCA 3 Support of parents Provision of rent-free accommodation to a mother who had largely financed the unit (Aroney [1979] FamCA 62) was treated differently from a case that lacked evidence that parents were dependent on farm income alleged to be theirs for life: W & W [1980] FamCA 63. (f) subject to subsection (3) (pension etc to be disregarded in maintenance application), the eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance, benefit or superannuation “The only difficulty is to ensure that placing primacy on the respondent to pay maintenance before the public purse is looked to is not overdone by making unrealistically high orders right to the very edge of that person’s capacity to pay consistently with his entitlement to live as a human being and at a reasonable standard”: per Fogarty J in F & F [1982] FamCA 8 at [14]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 15 (g) a standard of living that in all the circumstances is reasonable The Full Court held in Bevan [1993] FamCA 95 that the pre-separation standard of living is not auto- matically to be awarded where the respondent’s means permit. Where parties enjoyed a standard of living “considerably above average” Nygh J held that “although the wife cannot necessarily claim that it should be maintained at (that) level…it should not be at a level considerably below that presently enjoyed by her husband”: W & W [1980] FamCA 63. The court has long held that the standard of living to which an applicant was accustomed must be considered in determining whether maintenance is adequate: Goldstein J in Evans [1978] FamCA 23; Murray J in Kutcher [1978] FamCA 31 (“…wife is entitled to live in comfort in an area reasonably close to where she has established herself”); Full Court in Olliver [1978] FamCA 24 (“…wife’s standard of living will govern the (children’s)”; Nygh J in Aroney [1979] FamCA 62 “[W] is entitled to live in quiet comfort…”); Full Court in Tiley [1980] FamCA 73 (“a standard of living…nearer to that to which…she was accustomed”); Full Court in Beck (No. 2) [1983] FamCA 7 (“…not at the standard she previously enjoyed, but in reasonable comfort”). Lindenmayer J has found “no basis (for concluding) that the welfare of these children calls for any sig- nificant reduction in their present standard of living” where the court had regard to the activities of the children and their parents’ expectations for them: Campbell [1987] FamCA 68. Gross disparity of incomes has led the Full Court to investigate the extent to which a husband’s expendi- ture should be given priority over the needs of the wife: Tyson [1993] FamCA 31. But where a husband
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of the children and their parents’ expectations for them: Campbell [1987] FamCA 68. Gross disparity of incomes has led the Full Court to investigate the extent to which a husband’s expendi- ture should be given priority over the needs of the wife: Tyson [1993] FamCA 31. But where a husband was supporting his children unaided and the wife chose not to work, Treyvaud J held that “the former standard of living…does not constitute an adequate reason for the wife being unable to support herself”: Gyopar [1986] FamCA 64. Cronin J said in Carmel-Fevia & Fevia (No. 3) [2012] FamCA 631 at [182]: “[Under s 75(2)(g) I propose to] make an adjustment so that there is a fair outcome which enables the wife to re-establish her financial security in the future with some confidence.” Also see Wah & Golay [2016] FamCAFC 67 at [31]. (h) the extent to which payment of maintenance would increase the earning capacity of the applicant by enabling that party to undertake a course of education or training or to establish himself or herself in a business or otherwise to obtain an adequate income A party is usually awarded maintenance to cover the cost of re-training: Albany [1980] FamCA 80; Bailey [1978] FamCA 20; Thomas [1981] FamCA 12 (lump sum for a car where re-training as a teacher); Hope [1977] FamCA 39. And the cost of establishing a business: Lyons [1978] FCWA 1(where the wife had not properly thought out a business plan as to how the maintenance sought would have the alleged result). (ha) the effect of any proposed order on the ability of a creditor of a party to recover the creditor’s debt, so far as that effect is relevant For a discussion of this provision, see Lemnos [2007] FamCA 1058 at [58]-[60] and [63]-[64].
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: maintenance sought would have the alleged result). (ha) the effect of any proposed order on the ability of a creditor of a party to recover the creditor’s debt, so far as that effect is relevant For a discussion of this provision, see Lemnos [2007] FamCA 1058 at [58]-[60] and [63]-[64]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 16 (j) extent to which the applicant has contributed to the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of the respondent Such matters “will almost always have been given weight in the determination of s 79(4)(a) and (b) con- tributions”: C & C (Nullity) [1998] FamCA 114 at [147]. Also see Fletcher & Maloney [2008] FamCA 864 at [285]-[291]. (k) the duration of the marriage and the extent to which it has affected the applicant’s earning capacity In Wah & Golay [2016] FamCAFC 67 at [27]-[30] a nil s 75(2) adjustment (where it had been found that W’s earning capacity was unaffected by the 8 year marriage) was set aside by the Full Court which noted W’s taxable income of $56,900 at cohabitation which soon reduced to no income when W became a full-time homemaker. (l) the need to protect a party who wishes to continue that party’s role as a parent An extension of paragraph (c) and the cases covered there. The Full Court has held that a wife who gave evidence of concerns about the children and likely problems if they were left alone for extended periods could reasonably be permitted to continue her role as a full-time mother rather than continuing part-time work: Heeks [1980] FamCA 8. In Hope [1977] FamCA 39 at [13] W’s wish to be homemaker and mother in the short term was held to be “reasonable”. There is no legal requirement to enlist family members as child minders: Patterson [1979] FamCA 37 at [26]-[29]. In Gamage [2017] FamCA 742 at [60]-[63] it was reasonable for a mother to work less than a full working week due to child caring duties. (m) financial circumstances relating to cohabitation with another person Where a wife had an arrangement with her new (de
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: [1979] FamCA 37 at [26]-[29]. In Gamage [2017] FamCA 742 at [60]-[63] it was reasonable for a mother to work less than a full working week due to child caring duties. (m) financial circumstances relating to cohabitation with another person Where a wife had an arrangement with her new (de facto) partner to receive no financial support from him, Fogarty J refused her application for maintenance against her husband, saying that paragraph (m): “…is not confined to any actual financial arrangements between the relevant persons. It may also include financial arrangements which would be appropriate in those circumstances. That is, the Court is entitled to take ‘this potential into account’…”: F & F [1982] FamCA 8. Also see P & W [2005] FamCA 1303 at [48]-[52] (“[para (m) does not mean] regarding those financial circumstances as entirely at the disposal of the [cohabiting] party”). (n) the terms of any order made or proposed to be made in relation to the property of the parties The Full Court held in Anast & Anastopoulos [1981] FamCA 96 that the applicant’s entitlement to an order under s 79 for a property settlement should be assessed before the question of entitlement to spousal maintenance under s 72 is considered; and that in some cases a property settlement may provide adequately for the maintenance of the other party so that a maintenance order need not be added to the property order. Examples of cases where the benefits of a property order such as an unencumbered home, a capital sum for investment, realisable assets are found to satisfy a maintenance claim are W & W [1980] FamCA 63; Bowman [1984] FamCA 28; Little [1990] FamCA 69; Clauson [1995] FamCA 10; Rosati [1998] FamCA 38. Note – For de facto claims, the court may also consider the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: home, a capital sum for investment, realisable assets are found to satisfy a maintenance claim are W & W [1980] FamCA 63; Bowman [1984] FamCA 28; Little [1990] FamCA 69; Clauson [1995] FamCA 10; Rosati [1998] FamCA 38. Note – For de facto claims, the court may also consider the terms of any property or maintenance order made or proposed in relation to a de facto party’s spouse or other de facto: s 90SF(3)(o) & (p) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 17 Clean break under s 81 (s 90ST for de facto claims) Section 81 requires the court “as far as practicable (to) make such orders as will finally determine the financial relationships between the parties…and avoid further proceedings between them”. The Full Court, however, has said of the section that “the ‘clean break’ concept may have been taken to extremes in the past and requires careful reconsideration in the light of changing economic and social circumstances and values”: Best [1993] FamCA 107 at [126]. Where awarded on top of a property order, spousal maintenance is usually limited to a specific period: D & D (Unrep) [2003] FamCA 1356 at [79] (9 months + 2 months until payment of property settlement); Matthews [1980] FamCA 18 (lump sum to cover 2 years transition “to make decisions and arrange investments”); Vautin [1998] FamCA 135 (lump sum “to meet inevitable but reasonable expenditure for her own support in the next few years”). Maintenance for an unlimited period was awarded in Kearney [1990] FamCA 159; Bevan [1993] FamCA 95; Ramsay [1997] FamCA 4; and Bucknell [2009] FamCAFC 177 at [53]-[56]. (na) any child support that a party has provided, is to provide, or might be liable to provide in the future for a child of the marriage The Full Court in Rosati [1998] FamCA 38 at [7.3] said that the trial judge’s finding that the wife was able to support herself was “particularly open…having regard to the level of child support he proposed to require the husband to pay”. On the other hand, the Court said in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10 that: “…it should not be forgotten that the payment of child support in no way compensates the custodial parent for the loss of career opportunity, lack of employment mobility and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: he proposed to require the husband to pay”. On the other hand, the Court said in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10 that: “…it should not be forgotten that the payment of child support in no way compensates the custodial parent for the loss of career opportunity, lack of employment mobility and the restriction on an independent lifestyle (that) the obligation to care for children usually entails”. Non-payment of assessed child support, and minimisation of assessed amount due to self-employment, was met with an extra percentage for s 75(2) factors: D & D [2003] FMCAfam 74. (o) any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account This rarely-used paragraph refers not to the marital history but “only to facts or circumstances of a broadly financial nature”: Full Court in Soblusky [1976] FamCA 90 at [25]. That is, “any other relevant financial matters not covered in para (a) to (m)”: Beck (No. 2) [1983] FamCA 7 at [38]. (p) the terms of any financial agreement that is binding on the parties Naturally, this will only apply to the terms of any (rare) financial agreement that does not bar the future issue of spousal maintenance proceedings. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 18 RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE AND PROPERTY ORDERS The Full Court in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10, referring to a long line of authority, made it clear that where spousal maintenance and a property order are sought, spousal maintenance is to be dealt with after the determination of property settlement. In Clauson it was held that the property settlement in favour of the wife was so substantial as to afford her a capital sum and investment opportunities that would prevent her from demonstrating that she would be unable to support herself adequately. The Full Court in Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 held that the property order in favour of the wife should not disqualify her from maintenance. The Full Court held in Bevan [1993] FamCA 95 that a wife is not required to deplete capital she could use to buy a home, when the husband’s higher income was available to pay her a weekly amount towards her living expenses. The Court held that the trial judge, in dealing with spousal maintenance in isolation from the property settlement, had not done justice to both parties. The periodic sum awarded for maintenance was reduced and lump sum maintenance was declined. Spousal maintenance should be determined after any child support issues: see, for example Anderson [2014] FamCA 766 at [21]-[22]. Property means “existing property … and does not extend to property that might be received in the future” such that an order obliging a husband to pay the wife’s future outgoings was a spousal mainte- nance order: Thorpe & Stirling [2021] FedCFamC1A 86 at [26]. Note – the scope for varying a property order under s 79A (s 90SN for de facto claims) is more limited than for a spousal maintenance order (see “variation of spousal maintenance” below), and that it
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE AND PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: was a spousal mainte- nance order: Thorpe & Stirling [2021] FedCFamC1A 86 at [26]. Note – the scope for varying a property order under s 79A (s 90SN for de facto claims) is more limited than for a spousal maintenance order (see “variation of spousal maintenance” below), and that it was held in O’Brien [1982] FamCA 76 that the inclusion of a maintenance component in a property settlement does not preclude a party from later claiming periodic or lump sum maintenance, subject to the time limit contained in s 44(3). BACKDATED MAINTENANCE ORDERS The Full Court in Milankov [2002] FamCA 195 (Nicholson CJ and Buckley J at [31], and Kay J at [91]-[102]) upheld Penny J’s backdating of maintenance, as being within the court’s power in respect of spousal maintenance. The trial judge had rejected the wife’s claim for lump sum maintenance (as no source of funds had been identified as being able to meet that order) but had had regard to the husband’s ability to pay over the previous 32 months of non-payment (during the court proceedings) and the wife’s need for maintenance in that time, in making a retrospective order for periodic maintenance at $300 per week for that period. That order created arrears of $36,100 which were ordered to be paid within 90 days. The court also made an order for a reduced figure of $200 weekly for prospective maintenance. See H & H [1985] FamCA 36 and Bassingthwaite & Leane [1993] FamCA 86 as authority for maintenance being backdated to the date of the application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE AND PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 19 LUMP SUM ORDERS The Court’s power to make lump sum orders comes from s 80(1)(a) and the wide discretion under s 74 (ss 90SS(1)(a) and 90SE respectively for de facto claims) to make such order as the Court “considers proper” for the provision of spousal maintenance. The Full Court in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10 held that: • property settlement must be dealt with before spousal maintenance, and • it is necessary to determine periodic maintenance first before lump sum maintenance, lump sum maintenance being the capitalisation of the periodic maintenance conclusion. The Court held that before lump sum maintenance can be awarded, the court must first satisfy itself of the components necessary to justify a periodic award, i.e. need and capacity, and determine the amount in question and the duration of that order. If those components are not established “that will end any claim for not only periodic maintenance but lump sum maintenance as well”. Limits of dependency Evatt CJ in Spano [1979] FamCA 43 held that (provided there are funds available to meet such an order) a lump sum order should not be made unless it is “possible to assess with some certainty the limits of the dependency of the recipient of the order, either as to the period or as to the amount”. Examples of limited dependency were given as: • short dependency when children were about to leave school • dependency until the wife’s return to the workforce • the wife having some earning capacity, though not sufficient to meet her full needs • the need to undergo a training course • a husband with limited means who could forgo some of his property award as lump sum maintenance For assessments of dependency see Bolton and Dow-Sainter, under (a) (“health”) above. Lump
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: some earning capacity, though not sufficient to meet her full needs • the need to undergo a training course • a husband with limited means who could forgo some of his property award as lump sum maintenance For assessments of dependency see Bolton and Dow-Sainter, under (a) (“health”) above. Lump sum maintenance was not payable by a convict as he had no ability to pay periodic maintenance: Re Q [1994] FamCA 158. But in Plut [1987] FamCA 52 the Full Court held that the husband’s earn- ing capacity was not likely to be reduced in retirement; that the wife’s incapacity for self-support “will probably extend well beyond her 61st year”; and that the trial judge’s chosen period for capitalisation of maintenance should be extended accordingly. See also Vartikian (No. 2) [1984] FamCA 63 where Gee J cited Rayden on Divorce to the effect that no lump sum award should be made unless the husband has capital assets out of which to pay it without crippling his earning power. When he has available capital assets sufficient for the purpose, the court: “should not hesitate to award a lump sum. The wife will then be able to invest and use the income to live off. This will reduce any periodical payments or make them unnecessary, which will also help to remove the bitterness which is often attended upon periodical payments.” See Milankov (above under “backdated maintenance orders”) where, although there was no fund from which lump sum maintenance could be ordered to be paid, an order for periodic maintenance was made retrospectively; creating arrears of maintenance which were ordered to be paid within 90 days. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 20 Getting another bite of the cherry? In Vautin [1998] FamCA 135 a wife re-applied for spousal maintenance six years after she was awarded the transfer of the home to her (as a property settlement) and spousal maintenance for her and child support for the children (of $2,000 per month). The husband was $24,400 in arrears of that maintenance despite the improvement of his means (to about $2m). The wife applied for lump sum maintenance of $250,000. She called medical witnesses to support her case that she was unable to be employed. It was ordered that the hus- band pay those arrears and varied periodic maintenance by awarding the wife $500 per week and $250 per week and education expenses for each of the then 3 children, aged 23, 20 and 18 during their tertiary and secondary education. The claim for lump sum maintenance was ad- journed as it was not then ready to proceed. A lump sum order was eventually made. The Full Court dismissed the husband’s appeal against the award of lump sum maintenance of $97,000 and allowed the wife’s cross-appeal by increasing her award to $136,000. The majority of Fogarty and Burton JJ (at [56]) said that this was: “a very unusual case...(in favour of) an additional lump sum for the wife to provide her with some capital to meet inevitable non-periodic but reasonable expenditure for her own support in the next few years. The likelihood of necessary expenditure of this type was not really challenged, nor was the husband’s capacity to meet such an order. The issue was whether her own meagre resources were sufficient.” $9,000 was added to the trial judge’s award, so as to allow the full net cost of a replacement motor vehicle for the wife instead of part
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: not really challenged, nor was the husband’s capacity to meet such an order. The issue was whether her own meagre resources were sufficient.” $9,000 was added to the trial judge’s award, so as to allow the full net cost of a replacement motor vehicle for the wife instead of part of that cost. A further $30,000 was awarded, which was said ([57]) to be “modest compared with the husband’s position but may be sufficient to meet the inevitable additional expenses of the wife involved in a reasonable standard for her over the next few years.” The trial judge’s award of $97,000, which had been for the replacement of white goods ($10,000) and furnishings ($12,000), $15,000 for part of the cost of a new car (that award increased to $24,000) and $60,000 (increased to $90,000) for home repairs and renovations, was increased overall by $39,000 from $97,000 to $136,000. The wife’s further claim of $50,000 for “the future vicissitudes of life” was declined, as was her claim (as an alternative to the cost of home repairs) of $150,000 to buy a new home. Finn, J (dissenting) disagreed, however, dismissing both the appeal and cross-appeal. This case is an example of: • a spousal maintenance order being increased 8 years later • the increase taking the form of a lump sum • the applicant’s case being improved by her losing her earning capacity, and the improvement of the husband’s circumstances • how judges can disagree about whether to vary a maintenance order Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 21 In a 2006 case, the Full Court adopted the broad approach taken by the majority in Vautin, who sought to stress “the wide discretion available…to a trial judge when making a spousal maintenance order, and to emphasise the flexibility, available in an appropriate case, to make a lump sum order”: JS and GP [2006] FamCA 150 at [151]. (The court said that as there was no question of maintenance default on the part of the husband, periodic payments were more appropriate than a lump sum payment: [152].) Also see Vault & Isle [2012] FamCAFC 93 where Kaeser AM’s dismissal of the wife’s maintenance ap- plication on the ground that the husband had complied with an earlier order to pay maintenance of $28,000 by instalments was set aside by Thackray J who said at [29] that s 80(2) FLA (allowing a subse- quent maintenance order to be made) appeared to have been “simply overlooked”. Murphy J held in Bereat [2010] FamCA 693 at [103]-[104], applying s 80(1)(a) and Vautin (above) that despite the Full Court’s preference for periodic orders over lump sum orders (Clauson [1995] FamCA 10) a payment of $13,000 to the wife was “proper” within the meaning of s 74(1) to enable “the pursuit of a course that will allow a sole-parent to pursue employment with hours more regular than those under which she currently labours”. A further $15,000 was awarded as the discounted capitali- sation of $400 per week (assessed as the wife’s needs) for the duration of the 45 week course having regard to the husband’s “peripatetic lifestyle in overseas countries” and “significant potential difficulties for the wife in securing regular payments of maintenance from the husband”. SPECIFICATION OF SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS Section 77A(1) (and s 90SH) says that
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: needs) for the duration of the 45 week course having regard to the husband’s “peripatetic lifestyle in overseas countries” and “significant potential difficulties for the wife in securing regular payments of maintenance from the husband”. SPECIFICATION OF SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS Section 77A(1) (and s 90SH) says that an order for payment of lump sum maintenance, or the transfer of property all or part of which is to provide for the maintenance of a party, must: • state that it is an order to which this section applies; and • specify the amount or value of the maintenance provision. A property settlement order containing but not specifying a maintenance component shall be taken not to be for the maintenance of a party: see subsection (2). Kay J in Doig [1999] FamCA 1363 at [23] referred to s 77A as being “designed to protect the revenue”, by requiring those receiving maintenance by way of a capital payment to be as accountable for Centrelink’s income-testing of pensions as those receiving maintenance income. The Court there dismissed the husband’s claim that the trial judge had erred by specifying a portion of the wife’s property settlement as a s 77A maintenance provision. Kay J on behalf of the Full Court held that although the specification may have been incorrect (the trial judge having held that the wife had no maintenance claim on top of her property settlement), it did not prejudice either party. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 22 VARIATION OF SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE ORDERS Section 83(1) (and s 90SI) FLA (and for de facto partners in WA, s 205ZL FCA) empowers the Court: • to discharge such an order “if there is any just cause for so doing”; • to “suspend its operation wholly or in part and either until further order or until a fixed time or the happening of some future event”; • to revive wholly or in part an order suspended under the previous paragraph; or • “subject to subsection (2) to vary the order so as to increase or decrease any amount ordered to be paid or in any other manner”. Subsection (2) (s 90SI has different subsection numbering) directs the court not to make an order increasing or decreasing an amount ordered to be paid by an order unless it is satisfied: (a) that, since the order was made or last varied: (i) the circumstances of the person for whose benefit the order was made have so changed (for a de facto claim this includes the person entering into a stable and continuing de facto relationship); (ii) the circumstances of the person liable to make payments under the order have so changed; or (iii) in the case of an order that operates in favour of, or is binding on, a legal personal representative the circumstances of the estate are such, as to justify its so doing. (b) that, since the order was made or last varied, the cost of living has changed to such an extent as to justify its so doing (provided that at least 12 months has elapsed since the order was made: subsection (5)); (ba) in a case where the order was made by consent, that the amount ordered to be paid is not proper or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: living has changed to such an extent as to justify its so doing (provided that at least 12 months has elapsed since the order was made: subsection (5)); (ba) in a case where the order was made by consent, that the amount ordered to be paid is not proper or adequate (the court being required to have regard to any payments and transfer or settlement of property previously made by a party to the other party or to any other person for the benefit of the other party: subsection (5A)); (c) that material facts were withheld from the court that made the order, or from a court that varied the order, or material evidence previously given before such a court was false. An order decreasing the amount of the periodic sum payable under an order or discharging an order may be expressed to be retrospective to such state as the court considers appropriate: s 83(6). Any money paid under that order that would not have been required to be paid under the second order may be recovered from the other party: subsections (6A) and (6B). In considering variation of spousal maintenance orders, the Court shall have regard to the provisions of s 72 and s 75 (s 90SF for de facto claims): s 83(7). Arrears of maintenance can be recovered despite the discharge of the order: s 83(8). Variation of a consent order for maintenance may occur under any ground in s 83(2)(a), (b) or (c), and is not limited to the proviso contained in (ba): Caska [1998] FamCA 118. An order for periodic maintenance may be varied by a lump sum award: Vautin [1998] FamCA 135. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 23 For a useful summary of the meaning of “just cause” for the discharge of a maintenance order, see Pratt [2012] FamCAFC 81 at [96]-[98]. A husband successfully sought the discharge of a maintenance order made at the time of the parties’ property settlement: Bastow [2009] FMCAfam 21. He called a doctor and a recruitment consultant to counter the wife’s case, also annexing to his affidavit the “Westpac-AFSA Retirement Standard for ‘a comfortable lifestyle’ for a single female in Tasmania”, of which the court found the wife’s claimed expenses were “well in excess”. In Dalrymple [2009] FMCAfam 931 a 2004 maintenance order and arrears thereunder were dis- charged when it was found ([110]) that the applicant had “no recurrent or reliable source of income from which to satisfy the order”. In Priddle & Ors (No. 2) [2009] FMCAfam 876 an interim mainte- nance order was discharged due to “a major change” of the applicant’s financial circumstances. For a review of case law as to the discharge of a spousal maintenance order, see Cooper & Kingsley [2013] FCCA 277 at [16]-[18] and [23]-[29]. It was held in Caska [2001] FamCA 1279 that a maintenance order, once satisfied (paid out) was incapable of variation under s 83 but in Vault & Isle [2012] FamCAFC 93 at [21]-[24] and [28]-[30] that a previously satisfied maintenance order did not prevent a party from re-applying for mainte- nance. Note – A maintenance claim is barred by a financial agreement between the parties: s 71A (or s 90SA) EFFECT OF DEATH ON MAINTENANCE PROCEEDINGS Property proceedings can be continued against the estate of the proposed payee under s 79(8) (and s 90SM(8))”, but maintenance proceedings cannot be continued if either party dies: s 82 (and s 90SJ) (subject to two exceptions under
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: parties: s 71A (or s 90SA) EFFECT OF DEATH ON MAINTENANCE PROCEEDINGS Property proceedings can be continued against the estate of the proposed payee under s 79(8) (and s 90SM(8))”, but maintenance proceedings cannot be continued if either party dies: s 82 (and s 90SJ) (subject to two exceptions under s 82(3) (see “cessation of spousal maintenance” below). Note – Because property claims may be continued but not issued against a deceased estate, it is advisable where a respondent is in seriously ill health to preserve a claim by issuing it without delay. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 24 CESSATION OF SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE ORDERS Section 82: A spousal maintenance order ceases to have effect upon: • the death of either party: subsections (1) and (2) • the remarriage of the party awarded maintenance “unless in special circumstances a court otherwise orders”: subsection (4) Where a maintenance recipient remarries, it is the duty of that person to inform the other party without delay of the date of the remarriage: s 82(6). Any money paid after remarriage may be recovered by the other party: subsection (7) Note – The equivalent section for de facto claims is s 90SJ. What maintenance can be recovered after payer’s death? • Arrears of maintenance: s 82(8) (and s 90SJ(5)) Note – The subsection applies after the payee’s death too. • Maintenance orders that are secured under s 80(1)(d) (and s 90SS(1)(d)) • A maintenance provision beyond the payer’s death made in a financial agreement s 71A and 90SA • In many States a spouse favoured by a maintenance order may claim against the payer’s estate Financial agreements A financial agreement or Part VIIIAB financial agreement may be used to bar a future claim for maintenance: s 71A or s 90SA. This is usually negotiated in conjunction with the terms of a prop- erty settlement between the parties. See the chapter “financial agreements”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 25 PROCEDURE FOR MAINTENANCE APPLICATIONS (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) The FCFCA practice direction Financial proceedings made on 1 September 2021 applies to applica- tions for spousal and de facto maintenance filed before or after that date. Such applications are to be filed after pre-action procedures have been completed (see below), unless the case is urgent; the applicant would be unduly prejudiced; or there has been a previous maintenance application within 12 months: FLR 4.01(3) (in WA, FCR 22). Once an Initiating Application is filed, the Court will allocate the matter before Division 1 or Division 2. E-filing is compulsory in each Court via the Commonwealth Courts Portal or, in WA, the eCourts Portal of Western Australia. Applicants Obtain from your client the details needed to complete: Initiating Application (Family Law); Financial Statement; Genuine Steps Certificate; Copy of any family violence order; Undertaking as to Disclosure; Affidavit (only in support of an interim application). If no affidavit is filed, prepare and file a Financial Questionnaire; Limits for affidavits at interim hearings are 25 pages and 10 annexures (in Division 1) and 10 pages and 5 annexures (Division 2): FLR 5.08(2). In WA, obtain from your client the details needed to complete an Initiating Application, a case infor- mation affidavit (FCR 27) and a Financial Statement. Affidavits for interim or procedural hearings may not be filed with an Initiating Application (para 5 of the FCWA’s Case Management Guidelines). Respondents Prepare the following for filing: Response to Initiating Application (or Submitting Notice if the orders sought by the applicant are agreed); Financial Statement; Financial Questionnaire (but see above); Genuine Steps Certificate; Affidavit (only if interim orders are sought by either party). A Response must be filed and served within 28 days of service of the application to which it
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (or Submitting Notice if the orders sought by the applicant are agreed); Financial Statement; Financial Questionnaire (but see above); Genuine Steps Certificate; Affidavit (only if interim orders are sought by either party). A Response must be filed and served within 28 days of service of the application to which it relates: FLR 2.18(2). In the FCWA, prepare for filing a Response to Initiating Application and a Financial Statement. A Response must be filed and served at least 7 days before the hearing to which the Response relates: FCR 153 FCR. Duty of disclosure Before the first court event the parties must (FLR 6.06(8)) exchange a copy of the party’s 3 most recent tax returns and assessments; a completed superannuation information form for any super- annuation interest; for a self-managed fund, the trust deed and a copy of the 3 most recent financial statements; if they have an ABN, a copy of the last 4 business activity statements; and, if there is a Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 26 partnership, trust or company (other than a public company) in which they an interest, a copy of the 3 most recent financial statements and last 4 business activity statements lodged for the partnership, trust or company. The respondent to an application for maintenance only must (FLR 6.06(9)) bring to the first court event their tax return and assessment for the most recent financial year; their bank records for the 12 months preceding the application; their most recent pay slip; if they have an ABN, a copy of the last 4 business activity statements lodged; and any document in their possession, custody or control that may assist the Court in determining the respondent’s income, needs and financial resources. Also obtain and send to your opponent a report from any expert witnesses e.g. medical practitioner or job consultant. Such reports should be converted to affidavits for the hearing (see “precedents” below). Court procedure See the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management and, in WA, para16 of the FCWA’s Case Management Guidelines. Negotiations Parties are required by the pre-action procedures to negotiate, but applicants should not unduly delay filing for maintenance in the hope that negotiations will be fruitful. Negotiated settlements (either interim or final) should be in writing, and then signed and filed as consent orders. See “consent orders” in the chapter “other routine procedures”. Beware settling an interim maintenance claim with a lump sum that is paid on the basis that it be “characterised as a partial property settlement” or “characterised at the final hearing”: see the Full Court decisions of SMB and MFB [2006] FamCA 46 and La Costa [2007] FamCA 1176. The outcomes of those cases (the lump sum not being added back to the asset pool and then deducted from the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: as a partial property settlement” or “characterised at the final hearing”: see the Full Court decisions of SMB and MFB [2006] FamCA 46 and La Costa [2007] FamCA 1176. The outcomes of those cases (the lump sum not being added back to the asset pool and then deducted from the appli- cant’s ultimate property settlement) did not favour the respondents as expected. If respondents consider an applicant unlikely to meet the threshold test for maintenance, they should have the matter determined at the interim hearing instead of settling on the basis of “characterisation” at the final hearing. Another tip An applicant will often think twice about applying for interim maintenance (legal costs usually being an issue) if the other party makes an offer of X dollars per week for a limited period say, 3–6 months (depending on the circumstances) on notice that it is expected that the applicant will endeavour to obtain work during that period and produce evidence of having done so. An applicant may threaten proceedings when those payments stop, but will often not proceed with an interim maintenance application in the face of a respondent who builds a defence like this. Miscellaneous As to interim hearings, Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management requires parties to: • File and serve all expert reports that are relevant to the issues to be determined no later than 7 days before the hearing (para 5.17); Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 27 • Forward to the Associate of the judge or Senior Judicial Registrar, not less than 2 business days be- fore the hearing, (a) a minute of the orders sought, and (b) a Case Outline document for interim hearing. The Initiating Application should apply for both interim orders (current need) and final orders (future need) for maintenance. Property orders are usually only sought as final orders unless an interim order, e.g. an injunction against disposing of assets or an order for payment of litigation costs, is called for. An interim order can be sought after an Initiating Application has been filed by filing an Application in a Proceeding (in WA, an Application in a Case) (“forms”) and an affidavit explaining why the interim order is sought. Before seeking an interim order, a party must make a genuine attempt to settle the matter: FLR 4.03 (in WA, FCR 79) Unless urgent due to alleged high risk, a party may only file up to 2 Applications in a Proceeding without leave: para 5.22 of the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management. Counsel Seek a recommendation of a barrister for your family law work, and use him/her readily. Brief counsel to appear at the interim and final hearings, if you are not appearing yourself; seek his/her advice; email your papers to counsel for settling before you file it. Trial directions and final hearing For any final hearing, the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management contains standard trial directions that include an exchange of any amended application/response together with a consoli- dated trial affidavit and financial statement; the filing of a Case Outline document for final hearing no later than 2 days prior to the trial date; and a list of authorities to be relied on.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: standard trial directions that include an exchange of any amended application/response together with a consoli- dated trial affidavit and financial statement; the filing of a Case Outline document for final hearing no later than 2 days prior to the trial date; and a list of authorities to be relied on. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
