chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 28 COURT FORMS Forms for use in the FCWA See our link to the FCWA forms here at our eBook and at our online members’ Practice News (“FCWA”). The following are the forms of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia. Applicants • Initiating Application (Family Law) This form may be used for spousal or de facto maintenance. Insert the interim and final orders from “precedents” below. If only maintenance is sought there is no filing fee: FL(Fees)Reg 2.08(3)(i). • Affidavit An affidavit should not be filed until you are directed to do so except in support of an interim appli- cation. In FCFCA (Div 2) an interim affidavit can be up to 10 pages and contain 5 annexures without leave. • Financial Statement Attach a page of expenses not covered by the court form (“financial statement addendum” in “precedents”) and at Part O of the Financial Statement, insert “see attached”. • Genuine Steps Certificate As to parties’ compliance with the pre-action procedures of Schedule 1 FLR. • Financial Questionnaire – Not required to be filed if an affidavit is filed with the application. • Undertaking as to Disclosure • Affidavit (of any witnesses) e.g. medical practitioner or job consultant. • Pay filing fee (see “fees” below) or complete (as applicable): Application for exemption from fees – general (card holders and other categories) Application for exemption from fees – financial hardship Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 29 • Swear and file the documents via the Commonwealth Courts Portal. (Also see Portal Navigation.) Upon allocation of a date for the first court event, serve the documents including court brochures and notices no later than 3 days before an interim and 7 days before a final hearing. In WA, filing is required via the eCourts Portal of WA. • Prove service of your papers on a party (not a lawyer) by arranging personal service and filing process server’s Affidavit of Service with Acknowl edgment of Service attached. Experienced process servers will have their own supply of these forms. Respondents • Response to Initiating Application • Affidavit This should reply to any disputed aspects of the applicant’s affidavit and financial statement, and deal with the financial and other aspects of the respondent’s case (see “precedents” for a sample). An affidavit should not be filed until you are directed to do so except in support of an interim application. In FCFCA (Div 2) an interim affidavit can be up to 10 pages and contain 5 annexures without leave. • Financial Statement See link supplied above. See “precedents” below for an addendum page of expenses that are omitted from the court form. Attach this sheet and at “Part O – Additional Information” in the Financial Statement, insert “see attached”. • Genuine Steps Certificate and Undertaking as to Disclosure. A Financial Questionnaire is only filed if no affidavit is filed with the Response. • Affidavit (of any witnesses) e.g. job consultant (see “precedents” below). • Swear, file and serve. Pay filing fee by credit card when lodging on the Commonwealth Courts Portal (or eCourts Portal of WA). Where applicant has no lawyer (on whom your papers may be served), arrange personal service by process server as for applicants
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: e.g. job consultant (see “precedents” below). • Swear, file and serve. Pay filing fee by credit card when lodging on the Commonwealth Courts Portal (or eCourts Portal of WA). Where applicant has no lawyer (on whom your papers may be served), arrange personal service by process server as for applicants above. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 30 Consent orders Terms of any settlement may be documented as a consent order signed by the parties and filed in the court. For the procedure for this, see “consent orders” in chapter “other routine procedures”. Later interim applications Interim orders (if not sought in the Initiating Application) may be sought after an Initiating Ap- plication has been filed, by filing an Application in a Proceeding and an affidavit of applicant explaining the reason for the application. Respondents must file and serve a Response to an Application in a Proceeding and an affidavit in support. Amended applications Any significantly different orders may be sought by re-filing and serving the application as an “Amended Initiating Application” showing the new orders sought underlined in red, and “amended” appearing wherever “initiating application” is mentioned. No filing fee is payable. An affidavit setting out the facts relied on for the new orders sought can be contained in an affidavit filed before the final hearing. A Financial Statement may also be updated in either party’s pre-final hearing affidavit if the previous one is out of date. A tip – Be wary of amendments that include spousal maintenance in Division 1 of the FCFCA A spousal maintenance claim is a separate “matrimonial cause” which cannot be commenced in Division 1 of the FCFCA: s 50 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia Act 2021 (Cth). See Kwok & Beng (No 5) [2024] FedCFamC1F 463 where an amended application for leave to proceed to seek spousal maintenance orders was dismissed as such an application could only be filed in Division 2. Need a different court form? A link to each court’s index of forms is available at our website. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 31 COURT FEES (for both courts unless otherwise stated) • Application for Consent Orders $200 • Initiating Application (parenting or financial, final only) $425 • Initiating Application (parenting or financial, final and interim) $570 • Initiating Application (parenting and financial, final only) $695 • Initiating Application (parenting and financial, final and interim) $840 • Response to Initiating Application $425 • Application in a Proceeding $145 • Setting down for final hearing (FCFCA Div 1 and FCWA) $1,045 • Daily hearing fee (excluding first day) (FCFCA Div 1 and FCWA) $1,045 • Setting down for final hearing (FCFCA Div 2 and magistrate FCWA) $770 • Daily hearing fee (excluding first day) (FCFCA Div 2 and magistrate FCWA) $770 • Conciliation conference $480 • Subpoena $65 • Application to register a NZ judgment under the Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010 (Cth) (TTPA) (FCFCA) $130 • Application under TTPA (FCFCA) $145 Note – From 1 January 2013, an application for reduction of fee will only be available for divorce applications: see Chapter 3 (“procedure for divorce applications”). As to the court fees above, an “application for exemption from fees – general” or “application for exemption from fees – financial hardship” (see “court forms” above for both forms) may be lodged on behalf of card holders (and other categories) and those claiming financial hardship respectively. ICLs please note that you are exempt from the interim application fee and the subpoena fee. Note – These fees are current and are now increased annually on 1 July every year. See FL(Fees) Reg. See “court fees” for FCFCA and FCWA. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 32 PRECEDENTS (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) Online precedents The following precedents apply to spousal and de facto maintenance. They are set out in full below in hard copy and are also downloadable from the doc headings here in our eBook and online at our website www.thefamilylawbook.com.au APPLICATION Interim orders sought [These cover the interim between now and the final hearing – orders for immediate maintenance, any injunction, etc as below – and are to be set out in your Application or Response.] 1. That until further order the Respondent pay periodic maintenance to the Applicant in the sum of $[amount] per week, commencing seven days after the date of this order. Note – the amount an applicant claims for periodic maintenance can be the amount of the weekly shortfall between income and expenses, plus the cost of any essentials claimed that your client states in their affidavit they need but cannot afford. 2. [If also applying for backdated periodic maintenance, add this paragraph to paras 1 and 3] That within [insert] days after the date of this order, the Respondent pay to the Applicant the sum of $[amount] being maintenance at the rate of $[amount] per week from [date of filing of application] to the date of this order. 3. That maintenance payable under this order shall be paid by being deposited into the Applicant’s account no. [insert] at the [insert] branch of the [insert] Bank. 4. That until further order the Respondent pay all mortgage repayments payable for the property [specify property address] when they fall due [Add in separate paragraphs any other expenses sought to be paid by respondent, e.g. loan repayments, rates instalments]. 5. [If seeking an injunction] That until further order the Respondent [full name] be and is hereby restrained from disposing
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: repayments payable for the property [specify property address] when they fall due [Add in separate paragraphs any other expenses sought to be paid by respondent, e.g. loan repayments, rates instalments]. 5. [If seeking an injunction] That until further order the Respondent [full name] be and is hereby restrained from disposing of any of the following assets: [specify]. 6. [If you act for a respondent] That the application of the Applicant for interim orders filed on [date] be dismissed. 7. [If you act for a respondent and this applies] That the Applicant submit to an examination by a [medical practitioner/psychiatrist – as applicable] arranged by the Respondent’s solicitors within [specify] weeks in respect of the issues relevant to these proceedings. 8. [If other party has refused a reasonable settlement offer] That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s taxed costs of and incidental to this application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 33 Final orders sought These are the orders sought to be made at the final hearing – property settlement, future maintenance, etc as below – and are to be set out in your Application or Response. 1. That the Respondent pay periodic maintenance to the Applicant in the sum of $[amount] per week, commencing seven days after the date of this order [add, if maintenance is sought to be limited to a particular period e.g. period of expected inability to support self or completion of re-training course] and be payable for [insert] years [or until (date)]. 2. [If also applying for backdated periodic maintenance, add this paragraph to para 1 and other relevant paragraphs] That within [insert] days after the date of this order, the Respondent pay to the Applicant the sum of $[amount] being maintenance at the rate of $[amount] per week from [date of filing of application] to the date of this order. 3. [If applying for a lump sum instead of periodic maintenance, use this paragraph instead of para 1] That the Respondent pay lump sum maintenance to the Applicant in the sum of $[amount] within seven days after the date of this order [OR by instalments of $amount per week commencing seven days after the date of this order]. 4. That maintenance under this order shall be paid by being deposited into the Applicant’s account no. [insert] at the [insert] branch of the [insert] Bank. 5. [Add property orders, if sought – see “precedents” in chapter on property – and any other necessary orders] 6. [If a lump sum or transfer of property is ordered, the purpose or one of the purposes of which is to provide for spousal or de facto maintenance, add this] That this is an order to which
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: see “precedents” in chapter on property – and any other necessary orders] 6. [If a lump sum or transfer of property is ordered, the purpose or one of the purposes of which is to provide for spousal or de facto maintenance, add this] That this is an order to which Section 77A (Section 90SH in a de facto case) applies, the amount attributable to maintenance being the sum of $[amount]. 7. [If applying to vary an existing maintenance order, add this] That the maintenance order of this Court [or specify which other court] be varied by increasing the amount of periodic maintenance from $[amount] per week to $[amount] per week commencing [date] [and/or by making an order for payment of lump sum maintenance in the sum of $[amount] payable within [insert] days.] [If the lump sum is to be in lieu of periodic payments i.e. because the respondent is not paying them, you should add after “payable within [insert] days” the words “and that the order for periodic maintenance be discharged”.] 8. [If you act for a respondent] That the application of the Applicant for final orders filed on [date] be dismissed. 9. [If you act for a respondent who is applying to reduce an existing maintenance order] That the maintenance order made by the [specify] Court on the [date] be varied by decreasing the amount of periodic maintenance from $[amount] per week to $[amount] per week commencing [date]. 10. [If other party has refused a reasonable settlement offer] That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s taxed costs of and incidental to this application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 34 RESPONSE Interim orders sought 1. [In a de facto claim, if relying on s 90SB or 90SD to dispute the Applicant’s right to maintenance] A declaration under section 90RD (insert whichever applies): 1.1 that a de facto relationship never existed between the parties or, in the alternative, if a de facto relationship is found to have existed, that the period or the total of the periods of such relationship was less than two years as required by section 90SB(a) [OR that the rela- tionship broke down before the commencement of Part VIIIAB of the Family Law Act 1975.] 1.2 that the child [full name] is not a child of a de facto relationship between the parties under section 90SB(b). (Add paternity testing orders, see under “precedents” in Chapter 4.) 1.3 that the Applicant did not make substantial contributions under section 90SM(4)(a), (b) or (c) or, in the alternative, if such contributions are found to have been made, that a failure to make the order sought by the Applicant would not result in serious injustice to the Applicant within the meaning of section 90SB(c). 1.4 that the parties were not ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when their relation- ship broke down as required by section 90SD(1A). [OR] 1.4 that neither party was ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the application was made nor were the parties ordinarily resident there for at least a third of the de facto relationship at the application time as required by section 90SD(1). [OR] 1.4 that neither party was ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the application was made nor did the Applicant make substantial contributions there under section 90SM(4)(a), (b) or (c) at the application time as required by section 90SD(1). 2. That the Applicant’s application filed
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: required by section 90SD(1). [OR] 1.4 that neither party was ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the application was made nor did the Applicant make substantial contributions there under section 90SM(4)(a), (b) or (c) at the application time as required by section 90SD(1). 2. That the Applicant’s application filed [date] be dismissed. 3. [If your client has made a reasonable offer for maintenance, which has been refused] If the application is not dismissed, the Respondent until further order pay periodic maintenance to the Applicant in the sum of $[amount] per week, commencing seven days after the date of this order. [Specify any other maintenance provision] 4. [Specify any interim property orders your client seeks] (see “interim orders sought” above). 5. [If 3 applies] That the Applicant pay the Respondent’s taxed costs of and incidental to the application. Final orders sought 1. That the Applicant’s application filed [date] be dismissed. 2. If the application is not dismissed, an order that [specify the final orders your client is seeking] (see “final orders sought” above). 3. [If your client’s reasonable settlement offer has been rejected] That the Applicant pay the Respondent’s taxed costs of and incidental to the application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 35 AFFIDAVITS An affidavit is the sworn evidence of the person making it, filed in support of a party’s case. An affidavit should use the witness’s everyday language, not yours. Build it in logical sequence, using separate paragraphs for each essential fact, covering all relevant issues. For credibility, check all figures with care. It must be admissible as to what the witness can say about her/his own situation (no “I believe…” or “I submit…”). An affidavit should state facts, not feelings. Get to the point (the need for maintenance) quickly and limit your pages to a comfortable read. The trick is to say much in a short space, and say it clearly. A well-formed affidavit can make all the difference. AFFIDAVIT OF APPLICANT FOR SPOUSAL OR DE FACTO MAINTENANCE (AND PROPERTY ORDERS) Introduction 1. I am the Applicant. 2. The Respondent (“[X]”) [insert his/her first name that he/she was known by, e.g. Bill, then use that throughout the affidavit] and I were married at [place] on [date]. [OR] began living together at [place] on [date]. 3. We lived at [specify each place] from [date] until [date], when we separated. 4. There are [insert] children of our marriage namely [list full names and dates of birth of each child]. 5. I am [insert] years of age, born [date]. 6. Since our separation the children have been in [my/X’s] care at [address]. 7. A child support assessment was made on [date] for the amount of $[amount] per month. This compares with my total expenses for the children of $[amount] weekly, or $[amount] monthly. Spousal maintenance 8. [If applicable] [X] is $[amount] in arrears of that child support. Annexed and marked “[insert]” is a true copy of a statement from the Child Support Registrar as to those arrears. All
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: This compares with my total expenses for the children of $[amount] weekly, or $[amount] monthly. Spousal maintenance 8. [If applicable] [X] is $[amount] in arrears of that child support. Annexed and marked “[insert]” is a true copy of a statement from the Child Support Registrar as to those arrears. All attempts to recover payment of those arrears have been unsuccessful. 9. I refer to my Financial Statement filed in these proceedings. 10. My income since separation has been $[amount], from my pension of $[amount] and [If applicable] $[amount] [X] has been paying in child support. He has refused to pay any maintenance to help me with my own living expenses and debt [specify]. 11. Although I had some part-time work as a [specify] prior to our marriage, I have been out of the workforce for [insert] years so I have no skills for paid employment. 12. I refer to the affidavit sworn by my doctor (Dr [name]) as to my health and how it affects my life and ability to enter the paid workforce. [Specify in some detail, and in natural language, how ill health is limiting the seeking of employment] 13. My fixed and weekly expenses total $[amount] per week. My income of $[amount] leaves a shortfall of $[amount] weekly. I have had to meet that shortfall by using my bank savings. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 36 They have been reduced since separation from about $[amount] to the present figure of $[amount]. 14. I also cannot afford the following essentials – ITEM WEEKLY COST ($) TOTAL ($) This brings my maintenance needs to $[amount] weekly. 15. [If applicable, detail any course looked into as a possible means of qualifying or gaining experience for an employed position. Explain nature of course; duration; breakdown of its cost] [Although interim lump sums are rare, you could include it in your claim – and this affidavit – if there is a case for, say, the upfront costs of a course being required to be paid and X has the funds to pay a lump sum. Stress the urgency of your need for the lump sum] 16. [Explain any other matters under s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3) for de facto claims) that apply, using a separate para for each] These are – (a) the age and state of health of each party (b) the income, property and financial resources of each party and the physical and mental capacity of each for appropriate gainful employment (c) whether either party has care or control of a child of the marriage (d) the commitments of each party that are necessary to enable the party to support: (i) himself or herself; and (ii) a child or another person that the party has a duty to maintain. (e) the responsibilities of either party to support any other person (f) the eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance, benefit or superannuation (g) a standard of living that in all the circumstances is reasonable (h) extent to which payment of maintenance would increase the earning capacity of an applicant by enabling them to undertake a course of education or training or establish themselves
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: either party for a pension, allowance, benefit or superannuation (g) a standard of living that in all the circumstances is reasonable (h) extent to which payment of maintenance would increase the earning capacity of an applicant by enabling them to undertake a course of education or training or establish themselves in a business or otherwise to obtain an adequate income (ha) the effect of any proposed order on the ability of a creditor of a party to recover the creditor’s debt, so far as that effect is relevant (j) extent to which the applicant has contributed to the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of the respondent (k) the extent to which the duration of the marriage has affected the applicant’s earning capacity (l) the need to protect a party who wishes to continue their role as a parent (m) financial circumstances relating to cohabitation with another person Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 37 (n) the terms of any property order (na) (para (q) for de facto claims) any child support that a party has provided, is to provide, or might be liable to provide in the future for a child of the marriage (o) (para (r) for de facto claims) any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account (p) (para (t) for de facto claims) the terms of any financial agreement that is binding on the parties 17. Since [X] left I have been going into debt, unable to make ends meet. I have sought the backdating of maintenance to the date of filing of my maintenance application so as to be able to recoup savings of mine that I spent on [my/our] support, when no support was forthcoming from [X]’s ample income, savings and other resources throughout that time. Variation of maintenance order 18. [If applicable] I have applied for the variation of the maintenance order by this [or specify which other court] made on [date] because of the above situation and the following substantial changes in [my/X’s] circumstances [or both my circumstances and X’s] since the order was made: [As at time of the order – detail your circumstances and, separately, X’s] [Then, At present – details of your and, if relevant, X’s present circumstances]. This sample affidavit may be used as a rough draft for either the interim or final hearing. The former will need to be enough to enable the court to award interim maintenance (and any interim property orders), and the latter comprehensive enough to justify the future maintenance sought into the future, such as a fixed period for retraining or some other reason under s 72 and/or 75(2)
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: The former will need to be enough to enable the court to award interim maintenance (and any interim property orders), and the latter comprehensive enough to justify the future maintenance sought into the future, such as a fixed period for retraining or some other reason under s 72 and/or 75(2) (or, in de facto claims, s 90SF)” – and the property settlement sought. Injunction 19. [Specify what behaviour by the respondent – including any threat to dispose of assets which in the absence of an injunction would be likely to be carried out – has caused you to apply for an injunction against disposal of assets. Explain the reason for any other kind of injunction sought] Property settlement It should be enough for your first affidavit to summarise your property claim as follows. Your affidavit filed for the final hearing, however, will need to be more detailed on property issues – as to description and value of asset pool; the various contributions under s 79(4) (or s 90SM); and s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)) factors (see precedent affidavit in chapter “property”). A sample affidavit for a property hearing is available under “precedents” in that chapter. Note – If your client in a de facto claim is relying on having made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a), (b) or (c), and serious injustice, to establish their geographical requirement under s 90SD (for maintenance orders or s 90SK for property orders), specify every such contribution and the likely serious injustice if the order sought is not made. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SIX 6 – 38 20. The asset pool is set out as follows: DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTY ESTIMATED VALUE ($) TOTAL ESTIMATED VALUE OF ASSETS ($) 21. At the beginning of our relationship I contributed property to the value of $[amount], and the Respondent $[amount]. chunks.text: SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE 6 – 41 AFFIDAVIT OF MEDICAL PRACTITIONER (CALLED BY APPLICANT) 1. I am a medical practitioner. 2. I hold the following qualifications: [Obtain these from your witness’ CV]. 3. My rooms are situated at [address]. 4. The applicant [insert full name] has been a patient of mine for [specify] years/[OR] The applicant [name] consulted me at my rooms on [date] for the purpose of these proceedings. 5. My diagnosis of the applicant’s medical condition is [details]. 6. I have been treating [name] for this condition since [date]. 7. The history given to me by [name] comprised symptoms of [fully describe symptoms], all of which are consistent with [state the medical condition diagnosed]. 8. The history included an inability to sit for long periods or to concentrate for any length of time, severe pain in the neck and shoulders, and headaches [state applicant’s symptoms that prevent her from working] that prevent her from holding down any clerical or other position or seeking any other kind of employment [describe the job types applicant is unable to seek]. 9. These disabilities are consistent with my diagnosis of [name] and can reasonably be expected to continue indefinitely unless employment is available that enables [her/him] to leave [her/his] desk hourly and move about, and is for no longer than six hours per day [OR whatever the evidence exactly is, e.g. a stress-related condition is unlikely to be resolved until after the resolution of the court proceedings OR some other condition is not expected to resolve sufficiently to enable a return to work for another twelve months]. 10. Physiotherapy or medication [name if applicable] is available, however, this would be unlikely to enable enough relief for pain-free employment [OR whatever can be said about the matter of treatment]. OR annex the doctor’s medical report

AFFIDAVIT OF JOB CONSULTANT (CALLED BY RESPONDENT) Note – This sample is based on evidence adduced in M & M (McCrossen) [2006] FamCA 868 at [42] and [51] (see under s 75(2)(b) at “section 75(2) factors” above). 1. I am a job consultant of [insert] years’ experience of the [State/Territory/city/region] job market. 2. I am the manager of the [insert] Recruitment Agency situated at [address]. 3. I was also asked to assume that [applicant’s name] may wish to limit [her/his] hours of work to between 9.00 am and 3.00 pm and have time off during the school holidays. 6. In my opinion, [name of applicant] appears to be well qualified, with a wide range of experience, was highly computer skilled and had obtained senior levels of responsibility that would enable her to re-enter the public service as a [specify position] for 25 to 30 hours a week quite readily. 7. Many job applicants seek the limited hours I am told [name of applicant] seeks. While there is competition for such positions, her/his multi-skilled background
