chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 3 JURISDICTION Property (and maintenance) proceedings are issued under Part VIII of the Family Law Act (FLA) or Part VIIIAB for de facto claims (in WA under FLA or Part 5A of the Family Court Act 1997 (WA) (FCA)). They may be issued if either party is either present or ordinarily resident in Australia or an Australian citizen when the application is filed: ss 39(4) and 39A(2) FLA. For WA, see s 205X FCA. A de facto claim requires a 2-year relationship or a child or substantial contributions in relation to a de facto relationship (and serious injustice if the order sought is not made) or a registered relationship (s 90SB) AND that either party was ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the application was made, and that (unless both were ordinarily resident there for a third of the relationship or substan- tial contributions had been made there) both parties were ordinarily resident there when the relationship broke down (s 90SK). For WA (yet to opt in to the FLA regime) see s 205Z FCA. A de facto partner may not apply under the FLA if their relationship broke down before 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA) unless both parties opt-in under the Amendment Act (No. 115 of 2008). Note – In de facto claims, a party’s spouse or other de facto may become a party: s 90SM(10) FLA Your venue for property proceedings is the FCFCA or, in WA, the FCWA. The court can decline to exercise jurisdiction where proceedings are pending in another country. The Full Court dealt with such a case in B & B (Re Jurisdiction) [2003] FamCA 105. The Court cited Henry v Henry [1996] HCA 51, adjourning proceedings in the Family Court of Australia pending a decision by
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: can decline to exercise jurisdiction where proceedings are pending in another country. The Full Court dealt with such a case in B & B (Re Jurisdiction) [2003] FamCA 105. The Court cited Henry v Henry [1996] HCA 51, adjourning proceedings in the Family Court of Australia pending a decision by the District Court of NZ (where proceedings were issued after the Australian case had begun). But see Ashforth [2010] FamCA 37 at [23]-[40]. The High Court applied its decision in Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd [1990] HCA 55 in which the Court held that a party who has properly issued proceedings in Australia has a prima facie right to have the proceedings determined by an Australian court unless Australia is the clearly inappropriate jurisdiction (the doctrine of forum non conveniens). TIME LIMIT The deadline for a property (or spousal maintenance) application is 12 months after a divorce order has taken effect (s 44(3)) or 2 years after the end of a de facto relationship (s 44(5)) or 12 months after a BFA is set aside (s 44(3B) or (5)), except by leave or consent. As to “consent”, see s 44(3AA) or (5A). This time limit does not apply to applications to set aside a property order under s 79A or s 90SN or to vary, revive, suspend or discharge a maintenance order under s 83 or s 90SI. Under s 44(4) (or s 44(6) for de facto claims), the court shall not grant leave unless it is satisfied: • that hardship would be caused to a party or a child if leave were not granted; or • in the case of maintenance, that at the time of the deadline for issuing proceedings the applicant’s circumstances were such that she/he would have been unable to support herself/himself without an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: • that hardship would be caused to a party or a child if leave were not granted; or • in the case of maintenance, that at the time of the deadline for issuing proceedings the applicant’s circumstances were such that she/he would have been unable to support herself/himself without an income tested pension, allowance or benefit: s 44(4) For Western Australia, s 205ZB FCA still applies. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 4 LAWYERS’ OBLIGATIONS The merger of courts in 2021 brought with it a shift in how family law cases proceed, with a greater emphasis on dispute resolution before and during a proceeding, and new rules to facilitate that shift. Lawyers must assist their clients to comply with their duty at all times to act consistently with the main purpose of the rules of court, being the just and timely resolution of disputes at a reasonable cost to the parties: FLR 1.04 (in WA, FCR 5-8). Also see ss 95 and 96 FLA introduced in 2023. You must comply with the lawyers’ obligations set out in clause 6 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 FLR (financial proceedings) and clause 6 of Part 2 (parenting proceedings). In the FCWA see clause 6 of Division 1 of Schedule 1 FCR (financial cases) and clause 12 of Division 2 of that Schedule (parenting cases). Give your new clients the brochure Marriage, families and separation (s 12E FLA; s 65F FCA) and by their second appointment, the brochures Before you file – pre-action procedure for financial cases and, if applicable, Before you file – pre-action procedure for parenting cases. This judicial shift in emphasis is contained in the FCFCA’s Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management (CPD), which requires “the parties and their lawyers [to] think about the best way to con- duct their cases” in accordance with that shift (para 1.3). “The Court expects parties and their lawyers to have in mind, at all times, the cost of each step in the proceedings and whether it is necessary … [P]arties and lawyers are expected to approach proceedings in a manner directed towards identifying the issues in dispute and ascertaining the most … cost efficient method of resolution or determination.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: have in mind, at all times, the cost of each step in the proceedings and whether it is necessary … [P]arties and lawyers are expected to approach proceedings in a manner directed towards identifying the issues in dispute and ascertaining the most … cost efficient method of resolution or determination. This includes … identifying the issues in dispute, complying with their obligation to provide full and frank disclosure in a timely manner … engaging in … resolution- focused communication with [the] other part[y], making appropriate admissions and pressing only issues of genuine significance. Ambit claims should be avoided and aggressive and unnecessarily adversarial conduct will not be tolerated. … [P]arties must avoid filing evidence that is … lengthy or … of limited relevance to the issues genuinely in dispute [para 1.4].” “Any failure to comply with these requirements may attract costs orders against parties and/or practitio- ners and other consequences including … the drawing of adverse inferences, the making of a summary decree pursuant to [s 45A FLA] or orders … that a matter be heard on an undefended basis [para 1.5]” In the FCFCA you must give a copy of this CPD to your clients before starting a case (and give it to any unrepresented party as soon as possible): para 1.8. PARTIES’ DUTY OF DISCLOSURE Parties have a duty to the court and to each other to make full and continuing disclosure of their finan- cial circumstances: FLR 6.01 and, in WA, FCR 197. See McNamara v Kasmeridis [2005] SASC 269 at [49]-[53] citing the 1862 ruling of Lord Westbury in Tyrell v Bank of London (1862) HL Cas 26. Each party must file a Financial Statement with their Initiating Application or Response (FLR 6.06(5) and, in WA, FCA 200), and file another one if their financial circumstances
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: [2005] SASC 269 at [49]-[53] citing the 1862 ruling of Lord Westbury in Tyrell v Bank of London (1862) HL Cas 26. Each party must file a Financial Statement with their Initiating Application or Response (FLR 6.06(5) and, in WA, FCA 200), and file another one if their financial circumstances change significantly (FLR 6.06(7) and, in WA, FCA 201).The documents required to be disclosed in a financial case are set out in FLR 6.06 and, in WA, FCR 199. See Chapter 8 under “discovery of documents”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 5 PARTIAL PROPERTY SETTLEMENTS It will often be useful for you to negotiate a partial property settlement with the other side. The leading case is Harris [1993] FamCA 49 in which the Full Court concluded at [43]: “( … ) Of necessity it is likely to be a somewhat imprecise exercise. Consequently, it must be exer- cised conservatively and the Judge must be satisfied that the remaining property will be adequate to meet the legitimate expectations of both parties at the final hearing, or that the order which is contemplated is capable of being reversed or adjusted if it is subsequently considered necessary to do so.” An advance of money to each party towards costs and expenses Unless your client has ready access to funds, negotiate an advance of funds to each party from bank accounts or realisable assets towards legal costs, valuation fees and other expenses. Characterise such advances as partial property settlements, so they stay notionally added to the asset pool (although ultimately debited to each party’s entitlement when property division is calculated). Propose that each party be advanced the same amount. If the other party is unrepresented, propose that they receive the same amount anyway (explaining that such amounts are brought into account at the end of the case). Document the advance and its terms by means of consent orders (for the wording of the order, see under “interim orders” in “precedents” below, and for the consent order procedure, see “consent orders” in chapter “other routine procedures”). A tip Do this early on, as a routine business-like arrangement for the equal benefit of both parties. Your recourse if your proposal is rejected is the unpredictability and great expense of an application to the court for an order for interim costs (see chapter “other routine
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: “other routine procedures”). A tip Do this early on, as a routine business-like arrangement for the equal benefit of both parties. Your recourse if your proposal is rejected is the unpredictability and great expense of an application to the court for an order for interim costs (see chapter “other routine procedures”). Although an example of an interim costs order is given below, steer clear of such applications whenever possible. Even when they succeed, they only serve to reduce the parties’ divisible asset pool by the amount of their legal bills to obtain the order sought. An advance of capital (in a larger asset pool) to a party to assist in purchase of a new home before trial Negotiate as a partial property settlement – in cases of delay until the final hearing, and where there are ample other assets to satisfy the other party’s entitlement – an advance of money enabling a party (particularly with children) to buy another property in which to live. File consent orders to that effect, describing the advance as a partial property settlement. The advance will ultimately be deducted from that party’s eventual entitlement. For the wording of the order, see under “interim orders” in “precedents” below, and for the consent order procedure, see “consent orders” in chapter “other routine procedures”. For an example of such an order see Sudono [2010] FamCA 54 at [27]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 6 Other examples of court application for interim provision The husband of a judicial officer was granted an “interim property settlement” of $107,000, in Oates & Crest [2008] FamCAFC 29 at [33]-[39]. This was a slight reduction, but substantially all, of the claim he made at trial being as follows: LEGAL COST AND DISBURSEMENTS $80,000 RENTAL OF “SUPERIOR ACCOMMODATION” UNTIL THE FINAL HEARING $30,000 FURNITURE AND HOUSEHOLD ITEMS (”TO MAKE HIS CURRENT RENTED ACCOMMODATION MORE LIVEABLE”) $14,000 TOTAL $124,000 Wenz & Archer [2008] FMCAfam 1119 contains a review of the authorities on interim property orders. See Ruane & Bachmann-Ruane [2010] FamCA 514 for interim distributions towards legal costs and loan repayment; Gordons & Hasse [2010] FamCA 1162 ($250,000 to W from interim sale of house); and Sresbodan [2010] FamCA 494 for an interim order for sale, the proceeds to repay H’s creditors. In Maggio & Turner [2021] FamCA 466 H’s application for an interim sale of a shareholding was dis- missed as there was no evidence of urgency and a sale would prejudice W. Also see “interim property orders” under “adjournment of property proceedings” later in this chapter. What to file? For the procedure for both types of consent order, see “interim orders sought” and for its formatting, see “consent orders” under the chapter “other routine procedures”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 7 DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP This can be a preliminary issue in a de facto case. It is usually raised by a respondent who, by seeking an interim declaration under s 90RD FLA, disputes the applicant’s right to property orders. (In WA a respondent must seek an interim order dismissing the case for want of jurisdiction under s 205Z FCA. If the court does lack jurisdiction it may still award costs: FCR 11.1.) See “jurisdiction” above as to the right to bring a de facto property claim. A person is in a “de facto relationship” with another person if they are not married or related to each other and, having regard to all the circumstances of their relationship, they have a relationship as a cou- ple living together on a genuine domestic basis: s 4AA(1) (in WA s 13A Interpretation Act 1984 (WA)). A “de facto relationship” includes same sex partners and can exist if a partner is married to someone else or is in another de facto relationship: s 4AA(5). Under s 4AA(2) those circumstances may include: • length of the relationship • ownership, use and acquisition of property • nature and extent of their common residence • degree of mutual commitment to a shared life • whether a sexual relationship exists • care and support of children • degree of financial dependence and support • reputation and public aspects of the relationship • whether the relationship is or was registered e.g under Relationships Act (Tas & Vic), Civil Partnerships Act (ACT & Qld) and Relationships Register Act (NSW and SA) A declaration may be sought under s 90RD (for WA see the 1st para above) that a de facto relationship of at least two years existed or did not exist between the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP

chunks.text: Relationships Act (Tas & Vic), Civil Partnerships Act (ACT & Qld) and Relationships Register Act (NSW and SA) A declaration may be sought under s 90RD (for WA see the 1st para above) that a de facto relationship of at least two years existed or did not exist between the parties; that the relationship broke down before Part VIIIAB commenced (1/3/09 or 1/7/10 for SA); as to whether there is a child of the relationship; whether a party made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a), (b) or (c); and where each party was ordinarily resident during the relationship. For samples, see “Response” under “precedents” in Chapter 6 and “declaration” at our online “forms and precedents”. As to the existence of a “de facto relationship” see Moby & Schulter [2010] FamCA 748 at [126]-[132]; Jonah & White [2011] FamCA 221 at [34]-[67] and Taisha & Peng and Anor [2012] FamCA 385 at [6]-[21] as to the meaning of “couple” and “living together on a domestic basis”. Family violence is highly relevant: Mayson & Wellard [2021] FamCAFC 115 at [35].The lack of a common residence was not fatal in Dakin & Sansbury [2010] FMCAfam 628 at [170]-[173] or Smyth & Pappas [2011] FamCA 434 at [9] and [110] but was in Jensen & Taylor [2011] FMCAfam 1251 at [51]. For WA cases under the FCA, see Truman & Clifton [2010] FCWA 91. Also see Dahl & Hamblin [2011] FamCAFC 202 at [48] (aggregation of time where an interrupted relationship is resumed); A & G [2009] FCWA 110 (separation under one roof); Miller & Trent [2011] FMCAfam 324 at [46]-[103] (substantial contributions and serious injustice under s 90SB(c)); Allenby & Kimble [2012] FamCA 614 at [91] (emails and documentation given weight); Kazama & Britton [2013] FamCA 4 (separate homes not fatal; prior inconsistent statement
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP

chunks.text: G [2009] FCWA 110 (separation under one roof); Miller & Trent [2011] FMCAfam 324 at [46]-[103] (substantial contributions and serious injustice under s 90SB(c)); Allenby & Kimble [2012] FamCA 614 at [91] (emails and documentation given weight); Kazama & Britton [2013] FamCA 4 (separate homes not fatal; prior inconsistent statement to Dept of Immigration); Keene & Scofield (No. 2) [2013] FCCA 1107 at [419]-[432] (onus of adducing independent evidence). For more case law, see “de facto” at our online “case notes – property”. Applicants where “relationship” will be disputed Where any relationship aspect of your client’s application is likely to be disputed, send a detailed proof of evidence as to all of the above relationship aspects to counsel for an opinion as to the likelihood of the relationship being held to satisfy the requirements of a de facto claim under the FLA (and, if not, which aspects of the evidence should be strengthened, and how). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DECLARATION ABOUT EXISTENCE OF DE FACTO RELATIONSHIP

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 8 INTERIM INJUNCTIONS TO PRESERVE PROPERTY The law Injunctions may be made: • under s 114(1)(e) FLA for marriages; s 114(2A)(c) for de factos and s 235 of the Family Court Act (WA) • under Part 5.4 of the FLR in conjunction with inspection or seizure of documents or property (eg a safe) under an Anton Piller order (now called a search order), usually sought ex parte i.e. without notice to the respondent (FLR 5.19) • “in relation to the property of a party that is directed to, or alters the rights, liabilities or property inter- ests of a third party”: Part VIIIAA FLA (for de facto claims, see s 90TA) (and Div 2A of Part 5A FCA) Injunction where risk of disposal of assets or their removal from Australia Under Rule 5.23, an order may be made restraining another person from removing property from Australia, or dealing with property in or outside Australia. An applicant is required by Rule 5.23(2) to file with the application an affidavit that includes: (a) a description of the nature and value of the respondent’s property, so far as it is known to the applicant, in and outside Australia; (b) the reason why the applicant believes: (i) property of the respondent may be removed from Australia; and/or (ii) dealing with (disposal of) the property should be restrained by order; (c) a statement about the damage the applicant is likely to suffer if the order is not made; (d) a statement about the identity of anyone, other than the respondent, who may be affected by the order and how the person may be affected; (e) additional information if the applicant has an existing or prospective claim that is able to be decided in Australia. The Full Court in Mullen & De
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: about the identity of anyone, other than the respondent, who may be affected by the order and how the person may be affected; (e) additional information if the applicant has an existing or prospective claim that is able to be decided in Australia. The Full Court in Mullen & De Bry [2006] FamCA 1380 at [49] said: “In some cases, the possibility (based on some evidence) of an intention or scheme may, with other factors, be sufficient to establish the probability of an objective risk of disposal with intent to defeat an order.” The court considered W’s overseas residency and her failure to respond to a request for undertakings or consent to retain funds were relevant to the degree of risk that she might remove property out of the jurisdiction. The case was applied in Josselyn and Ors [2016] FamCA 557 in which H and his brother as office holders for a family trust were restrained from changing the terms of its deed of settlement. What to file? For orders to be sought, see “interim injunction against disposal of assets” under “interim orders sought” in “precedents” below. For an affidavit in support, see the interim injunction clauses in “affidavit of either party seeking property order” under “precedents” below, and see the Full Court’s ruling in Waugh (see below). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 9 Risk of disposal of property that may defeat or prejudice a property claim The Full Court in Waugh [2000] FamCA 1183 upheld a husband’s appeal against an injunction obtained by the wife, applying the Court’s ruling in Stowe [1980] FamCA 92 that the power to grant injunctions is limited to cases where there is a real danger that a property claim under s 79 may be defeated or prejudiced unless an injunction is granted. In Waugh, the Court at [52] said: “Had there been some clear evidence given by the wife (even if denied by the husband) of some disposition of property by the husband, or other conduct by him from which an inference might reasonably be drawn that he had embarked, or was about to embark, upon a course of action which was designed to or, irrespective of design, would be likely to defeat any anticipated order in the substantive proceedings in the wife’s favour, then perhaps we might be persuaded to uphold His Honour’s orders…However…there was no such clear evidence.” What evidence to file? The Court at [53]-[57] commented on the state of the evidence in that case as follows: “The wife’s affidavit in support of her application was replete with statements that she ‘feared’ the husband would do this or that with the property under his control, or with one or other of the trusts through which he conducts his business operations, but it contained no assertion that he had in fact disposed of anything or incurred any liability other than in the ordinary course of his business… Although (she) asserted that (he) had replaced himself as appointor of the various trusts, he had…done that…many months…prior to the parties’ separation. In any event… His Honour’s orders…prevent any further alienation of the power of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of anything or incurred any liability other than in the ordinary course of his business… Although (she) asserted that (he) had replaced himself as appointor of the various trusts, he had…done that…many months…prior to the parties’ separation. In any event… His Honour’s orders…prevent any further alienation of the power of control of all the trusts until further order. Although the wife asserted that, since separation, the husband had removed her as a signatory of various trust and company bank accounts with the operation of which she had previously been involved, that is hardly a surprising thing for him to have done, in the circumstances, and is hardly a basis for inferring some intention on his part to dispose of or conceal assets. The wife’s material also disclosed that the husband had already paid to her…sums…pursuant to a partial property settlement agreement…and that he was paying her periodic maintenance… for herself and the children. The wife also asserted…that since separation she had been effectively excluded by the husband from the operation of the trusts and from access to its business records. Again, however, given the circumstances, including the partial settlement effected between the parties and the payment by the husband of not ungenerous maintenance for the wife, that is hardly surprising, and provides no basis for an inference of impropriety by the husband in relation to any property under his control. If the wife were dissatisfied with the lack of access to the husband’s business records, that could have been dealt with by an appropriate application without seeking to freeze or fetter the conduct of those businesses. …The wife asserted a conversation with the husband…in which, in response to his request to her to remove a caveat which she had lodged over a property…she requested certain information from him, to which
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: with by an appropriate application without seeking to freeze or fetter the conduct of those businesses. …The wife asserted a conversation with the husband…in which, in response to his request to her to remove a caveat which she had lodged over a property…she requested certain information from him, to which he responded: ‘I am not going to tell you anything. I have instructed my lawyer not to reply. I will do what I like. I will let it all go and you will get none of it. It can all go to tax and the bank.’ Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 10 That piece of evidence (denied by the husband…) represents the high watermark of the wife’s evidence, insofar as it might be relied upon as the basis for an inference that the husband was likely to dissipate his assets, in order to defeat the wife’s claim in the substantive proceedings, unless restrained from doing so by order of the court. However, in our view, that evidence is not sufficient to support such an inference…” The court went on (at [58]) to take account of the fact that in exchange for the wife’s removal of caveats, the husband was offering to give an undertaking to the court that he would not until further order cause a company on behalf of the trust to enter into any unconditional contract of sale of the property without giving to the wife’s solicitors 21 days notice in writing; nor, as director of the trustee company, vote in favour of any increase or cause there to be any increase in the secured borrowings beyond the present level. The court saw that as a willingness to give the wife security in terms of value and real estate which would match or slightly exceed that which she was seeking in her property claim. Failure to fully disclose bank account In Sheehan [2008] FMCAfam 655, W sought to freeze a bank account when H refused to give an undertaking not to reduce it below $229,000. Neville FM’s order was that H “cause $114,500…to be invested in an account in Australia in the names of his solicitors as trustee for the husband pending the final resolution of the proceedings”. Interference with company operations For an injunction against such interference see Krueger [2010] FMCAfam 466 at [31] (Scarlett FM). In Lampros and Anor [2012] FamCA 415 an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: in an account in Australia in the names of his solicitors as trustee for the husband pending the final resolution of the proceedings”. Interference with company operations For an injunction against such interference see Krueger [2010] FMCAfam 466 at [31] (Scarlett FM). In Lampros and Anor [2012] FamCA 415 an injunction was made to restore W’s employment with a com- pany. In Cao & Hong [2015] FamCA 884 an injunction was varied so as to increase W’s consent-free business drawings from $1K to $10K. In Scott [2019] FamCAFC 9 at [17]-[30] a judge’s appointment of a receiver and manager to the parties’ business was set aside. Broker allowed to continue normal trading In H & H (Unrep) [2003] FamCA 1391 a broker was allowed to keep trading. The Court was unwilling to grant an injunction, pointing out that an injunction is not for the purpose of restricting the conduct of normal trading, and that no injunction should be granted unless there is some evidence of conduct likely to defeat an anticipated property order. Kay J, expressing the view of the Court, said at [17]-[19]: “Parties ought only be restrained from conducting their normal affairs pending the outcome of disputed proceedings if the failure to so restrain them is likely to seriously interfere with the proper adjudication of the claim and the meeting of the entitlements. …There was no suggestion here that the husband was doing something to subvert the wife’s position. It is just that she and her advisers took a position that if they were in charge of the assets they would trade in a different way. In my view, that is not enough to meet the tests laid out in the authorities that say that the court ought to be loath to grant an injunction unless it is
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a position that if they were in charge of the assets they would trade in a different way. In my view, that is not enough to meet the tests laid out in the authorities that say that the court ought to be loath to grant an injunction unless it is proper and appropriate in the circumstances to ensure that the court will be in a position to deal with the assets when it is time for so dealing.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 11 An alternative to applying for an injunction Where the risk of disposal relates to an asset that is small in value relative to the value of the asset pool (such as a car, for example): • put the other party on notice that your client is aware of their intention to sell the asset • either propose that your client approve the sale, on the basis of agreeing method of sale and sharing proceeds (in which case, class it as a partial property settlement), or • object to the sale and call for a copy of the sale documentation so that the asset may be added back to the asset pool notionally and, if the other party spends the proceeds on themselves, the proceeds debited against their ultimate property entitlement (in which case, enter the sale in your draft asset pool as “notional property” (e.g. “Notional property – H’s unilateral sale of Jeep $20,000”), and obtain copy sale receipt for proof. A caveat may be quicker than an injunction If you lodge a caveat, ensure that it is or becomes non-lapsing, by the issue of proceedings under the FLA or as required by your State or Territory property law. Interest claimed – equitable estate or interest as co-owner in equity of one undivided half of an estate in fee simple. Grounds for a caveat – pursuant to a resulting and/or constructive trust arising by operation of law from certain monetary and non-monetary contributions made by the said caveator towards the acquisition, conservation and improvement of the said land. As your registrar of titles may check whether your proceedings do support the case for a caveat, add to your property orders sought a declaration that your client holds the property pursuant to such trusts in the same
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: said caveator towards the acquisition, conservation and improvement of the said land. As your registrar of titles may check whether your proceedings do support the case for a caveat, add to your property orders sought a declaration that your client holds the property pursuant to such trusts in the same terms (changing “the said caveator” to “the applicant”). In the ordinary course you would not have to pursue that aspect of the application at trial. See the paper on caveats (under Qld legislation, note) by then barrister Colin Forrest (now Forrest J) at our online Members’ Archive. When not to apply for an injunction • When the amount is small enough for your client’s ultimate property recovery not to be jeopardised (and you can prove the amount or value disposed of, enabling the court to add it back notionally to the asset pool) • When the asset disposal is in the ordinary course of business • When your client’s only or main complaint is being excluded from access to the business or its records • When your client’s concerns are based on ambiguous statements by the other party • When your client has no evidence of conduct by the other party that indicates an intention to do something to defeat your client’s claim • When your client’s case is based on mere suspicion or fear of assets being disposed of • If seeking to change the status quo, not preserve it: Qian & Xue [2022] FedCFamC1A 93 at [22] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 12 Seizure of documents or other property This was known as an Anton Piller order (named after a decision of the English Court of Appeal in Anton Piller KG v Manufacturing Processes Limited and Ors (1976) 1 Ch 55). It is now called a search order and is available under FLR 5.19 which entitles a party to apply for such an order: (a) requiring a respondent to permit the applicant, alone or with another person, to enter the respondent’s premises and inspect or seize documents or other property; (b) requiring the respondent to disclose specific information relevant to the case; and (c) restraining the respondent, for a period of no more than 7 days, from informing anyone else (other than the respondent’s lawyer) that the order has been made. A search order may be (and usually is) applied for without notice to the respondent: Rule 14.04(2). For the requirements of an application without notice, see “applying for interim or procedural order without notice” in chapter 8 as to FLR 5.11. Also: Rule 14.04(3) requires such an application to be supported by an affidavit that includes: (a) a description of the document or property to be seized or inspected; (b) the address of the premises where the order is to be carried out; (c) the reason the applicant believes the respondent may remove, destroy or alter the document or property unless the order is made; (d) a statement about the damage the applicant is likely to suffer if the order is not made; (e) a statement about the value of the property to be seized; (f) if permission is granted, the name of the person (if any) who the applicant wishes to accompany the applicant to the respondent’s premises. The affidavit must be served on the respondent
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: if the order is not made; (e) a statement about the value of the property to be seized; (f) if permission is granted, the name of the person (if any) who the applicant wishes to accompany the applicant to the respondent’s premises. The affidavit must be served on the respondent when the order is acted on: Rule 14.04(4). Lindenmeyer J explained search orders in Talbot [1994] FamCA 129 at [7] (also see [20]-[21]): “…[as being] to search for, inspect and remove for safekeeping (or take copies of) documents or things which are alleged by the [applicant] to be vital evidence in the action, where the [applicant] satisfies the court that there is a real risk that unless this is done the [respondent] will either destroy or hide the documents, so as to prevent their being placed before the court as soon as he or she gets wind of the [applicant’s] action…to ensure that [the court’s] proceedings are not rendered nugatory [futile] by the misbehaviour of a [respondent].” Also see Tassinari & Pesalaccio & Ors [2018] FamCA 12 at [85]-[94]. When and what to file? Apply for such an order where your client can prove their knowledge of the existence and location of a vital piece of evidence or valuable item of property and the respondent’s failure to disclose it or make it available for valuation. Apply without notice (ex parte) if respondent is likely to conceal the item if given notice of your application. Check with your barrister first. For your orders and supporting affidavit, see “interim orders sought” and interim injunction clauses in “affidavit of either party seeking property order” in “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 13 Orders and injunctions binding third parties This is Part VIIIAA of the Family Law Act (which now also covers the property of de facto partners: s 114(2A)(c)). Introduced on 17 December 2004, this amendment to the Act nullified the High Court’s ruling in Ascot Investments Pty Ltd v Harper [1981] HCA 1 that the Family Court of Australia had no power to make orders to the detriment of third parties. In WA see Division 2 of Part 5A of the Family Court Act 1997 (WA). The court is now allowed, in relation to the property of a party to a marriage, to: • make a property order; or • grant an injunction (in marital or de facto claims); that is directed to, or alters the rights, liabilities or property interests of a third party. See “creditors and other third parties” below. Injunctions in a case of violence or other conflict See “interim injunctions” in chapter “children” for injunctions for: • personal protection of child or party • sole occupancy of the home. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 14 ALTERATION OF PROPERTY INTERESTS “In property settlement proceedings, the court may make such order as it considers appropriate… altering the interests of the parties to the marriage in the property”: s 79(1) (s 90SM(1) being the equivalent section for de facto claims) Note – that the section goes on to include jurisdiction over the vested bankruptcy property of a bankrupt party. In the unusual event of this requiring your attention, it is advisable to brief counsel to advise. Just and equitable requirement “The court shall not make an order under this section unless it is satisfied that, in all the circumstances, it is just and equitable to make the order”: s 79(2) (or s 90SM(3) in de facto claims) FACTORS TO BE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT Section 79(4) or (s 90SM(4) in de facto claims) requires the court, when considering what order should be made, to take into account: (a) the financial contribution made directly or indirectly by or on behalf of a party or child of the marriage to the acquisition, conservation or improvement of any of the property of either party (whether or not the property has ceased to be the property of that party); (b) any non-financial contribution (made directly or indirectly, as above); (c) the contribution by a party to the welfare of the family (the parties and any children) in the capacity of homemaker, parent or otherwise; (d) the effect of any proposed order upon the earning capacity of either party; (e) any relevant matters under s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)); (f) any other order made under the Act affecting a party or child; and (g) any child support that a party has provided, or is to or might be liable to provide in the future. Section 75(2) matters (or s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (e) any relevant matters under s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)); (f) any other order made under the Act affecting a party or child; and (g) any child support that a party has provided, or is to or might be liable to provide in the future. Section 75(2) matters (or s 90SF(3) matters in de facto claims) to be taken into account under s 79(4)(e) (or s 90SM(4)(e)), where relevant, are: (a) the age and state of health of each party (b) the income, property and financial resources of each party and the physical and mental capacity of each for appropriate gainful employment (c) whether either party has care or control of a child of the marriage (d) the commitments of each party that are necessary to enable the party to support: (i) himself or herself; and (ii) a child or another person that the party has a duty to maintain. (e) the responsibilities of either party to support any other person (f) the eligibility of either party for a pension, allowance, benefit or superannuation Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 15 (g) a standard of living that in all the circumstances is reasonable (h) extent to which payment of maintenance would increase the earning capacity of an applicant by enabling them to undertake a course of education or training or establish themselves in a business or otherwise to obtain an adequate income (ha) the effect of any proposed order on the ability of a creditor of a party to recover the creditor’s debt, so far as that effect is relevant (j) the extent to which the applicant has contributed to the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of the respondent (k) the extent to which the duration of the marriage has affected the applicant’s earning capacity (l) the need to protect a party who wishes to continue their role as a parent (m) financial circumstances relating to cohabitation with another person (n) the terms of any property order (na) any child support that a party has provided, is to provide, or might be liable to provide in the future for a child of the marriage (o) any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account (p) the terms of any financial agreement that is binding on the parties Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 16 THE FOUR STEPS IN DETERMINING A PROPERTY DISPUTE Calculate your client’s property entitlement as the court does, in four steps. See Full Court deci- sions such as Ferraro [1992] FamCA 64 from [159]; Hickey [2003] FamCA 395 at [39]; and AJO & GRO (Omacini) [2005] FamCA 195 at [46] as to the following steps: 1. Identify and value the property, liabilities and financial resources of the parties as at the date of the hearing 2. Assess their financial, non-financial and welfare contributions under s 79(4)(a), (b) and (c) as a percentage of the net value of their property (“total net assets” or “asset pool”) 3. Assess any relevant s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)) factors, such as disparity of income and earning capacity and (the capital cost of) having the care of children, as an adjustment of the contri- bution based assessment (those factors being brought into account by s 79(4)(e)) (or s 90SM(3)) 4. Consider the effect of those findings and specify what order should in all the circumstances be made for a “just and equitable” outcome, as required by s 79(2) As to Step 1, the Full Court in Hickey referred to the necessity “to consider the whole of the property of the parties, however and whenever acquired” and the “obligation of each party to make a full and frank disclosure of their financial circumstances” ([40]). As to Step 2, a “global approach” has been applied by the courts as the guideline in most cases, by assessing contributions in terms of a proportion of the total assets of the parties. This approach was approved in Norbis [1986] HCA 17 by the High Court, which added that an “asset by asset” approach is also available (see “asset by asset approach” under “contributions” below). The “clean
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: THE FOUR STEPS IN DETERMINING A PROPERTY DISPUTE

chunks.text: cases, by assessing contributions in terms of a proportion of the total assets of the parties. This approach was approved in Norbis [1986] HCA 17 by the High Court, which added that an “asset by asset” approach is also available (see “asset by asset approach” under “contributions” below). The “clean break” principle – Under s 81 (s 90ST for de facto claims) “the court shall, as far as practicable, make such orders as will finally determine the financial relationships between the par- ties to the marriage and avoid further proceedings between them”. See para (n) of “maintenance factors” in Chapter 6. Spousal maintenance – Property orders can eliminate the need for maintenance as well (thus a prop- erty claim is determined first: Clauson [1995] FamCA 10, but the court will in an appropriate case make an order for maintenance: DJM & JLM [1998] FamCA 97 at [17]. See also Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 (where W needed maintenance after being awarded property settlement of 90%, but of a small asset pool of $300,000); and Bevan [1993] FamCA 95 at [53]. The four step approach continues to be applied by the courts since Stanford [2012] HCA 52 (HC). Stanford is summarised in Bevan [2014] FamCAFC 19 at [40]-[45]. In Bevan W “had arranged her life ‘as an independent woman’ in reliance on H’s representations over … 16 years[s] … that he would not make a claim against the property they owned in Australia” ([12]). Bryant CJ and Thackray J (with whom Finn J largely agreed) applied Stanford, dismissing H’s property application, saying ([82]): “The basis upon which it can be concluded in many cases that it is just and equitable to make orders interfering with existing interests in property following the breakdown of mar- riage is because it is no longer appropriate
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: THE FOUR STEPS IN DETERMINING A PROPERTY DISPUTE

chunks.text: J largely agreed) applied Stanford, dismissing H’s property application, saying ([82]): “The basis upon which it can be concluded in many cases that it is just and equitable to make orders interfering with existing interests in property following the breakdown of mar- riage is because it is no longer appropriate to proceed on the basis of the stated and un- stated assumptions between the parties to the marriage in circumstances where they have not expressly considered whether, or to what extent, there should be some different arrangement of their property interests (Stanford at [41]). In the present matter, however, the parties did give express consideration to what should become of their property. In such circumstances we consider the husband must do more than point to the end of the relationship in order to per- suade us that there is some principled basis upon which we should interfere with an existing state of affairs created by consent, or at the very least, acquiescence of the parties.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: THE FOUR STEPS IN DETERMINING A PROPERTY DISPUTE

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 17 IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY Property, as defined in s 4(1) FLA, was said in 1835 in an English case Jones v Skinner to be “the most comprehensive of … terms [to describe] every possible interest [a] party can have”, applied by the Full Court in Duff [1977] FamCA 24. The court’s power under s 79(1) is to alter the parties’ interests in all their property, regardless of when or how it was acquired and in whose name it is owned: Farmer & Bramley [2000] FamCA 1615. The identification and value of property is considered as at the date of the final hearing: Hickey [2003] FamCA 395 at [39]. Any premature distributions of property made to a party before then, or assets unac- counted for, are included by being “added back” notionally to the asset pool: Milankov [2002] FamCA 195. See below “notional property” and the assets below that have been held to be “property”. “Property” has been held to include – • All real and personal property: Duff (above) • Pre-marital property: Carter [1981] FamCA 18 • Post-separation lottery win: Farmer & Bramley (above) • Partnership in law firm (assignable with partners’ approval): Best [1993] FamCA 107 but see B & B [1999] FamCA 1142 at [74]-[88] • A bequest received by a party during the marriage: Bonnici [1991] FamCA 86 • Future bequest under irrevocable will: Parker [1983] FamCA 54 • Inheritance late in marriage, if no other assets allow for a just result: Bonnici (above) • A lottery win from a ticket bought during the marriage: Zyk [1995] FamCA 135 • An award of damages from a personal injury claim: Holmes [1988] FamCA 3 • A redundancy payment: Burke [1992] FamCA 85 but see Sherwin (No. 2) [2010] FMCAfam 77 at [54]-[60]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: result: Bonnici (above) • A lottery win from a ticket bought during the marriage: Zyk [1995] FamCA 135 • An award of damages from a personal injury claim: Holmes [1988] FamCA 3 • A redundancy payment: Burke [1992] FamCA 85 but see Sherwin (No. 2) [2010] FMCAfam 77 at [54]-[60] • Long service leave if in a capital sum: Burke (above) • Property value increase as a result of re-zoning: Zappacosta [1976] FamCA 56 • Vested interest in estate contingent on a life interest: White [1979] FamCA 40 • Overseas property: Myall [2007] FamCA 1680 at [14]-[17] • Premature distributions of property and wasted assets (see “notional property” below) • Sales not recorded in the books of a business (see Weir in “non-disclosure” below) • Unaccounted for proceeds of assets sold by a party: Mezzacappa [1987] FamCA 20 • An option to buy land granted to a wife by her father: Rickaby [1995] FamCA 146 • A taxi licence: Townsend [1994] FamCA 144 • Transferable licence to engage in trade: B & B [1999] FamCA 1142 • A beneficiary’s right to due consideration and due administration under a discretionary trust: Woodcock (No 2) [2022] FedCFamC1F 173 at [73] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 18 • Credit in loan account: C & C (Cunningham) [2005] FamCA 159 • An interest in superannuation: Coghlan [2005] FamCA 429 (including one in the payment phase: Semperton [2012] FamCAFC 132 at [177]-[179]) • Company shares (director may be ordered to transfer shares to a party: s 90AE(1)(d)) • Trust assets, control of which H transferred to his father (Milankov, above); H appointor (Ashton [1986] FamCA 20); H controlled corporate trustee (Stein [1986] FamCA 27) • Share options: Hurst & Weber [2009] FamCAFC 137; Nielson [2012] FamCA 70 at [70]-[81] • Royalty rights: Pope [2012] FamCA 204 at [117]-[118] • Life insurance: Bain (No. 3) [2013] FamCA 970 at [13]-[29] Other cases involving assets of a trust See BP & KS [2002] FamCA 1454; Coventry [2004] FamCA 249; and Kennon v Spry [2008] HCA 56 where a 4:1 majority of the High Court held that the assets of a trust in which W (as “spouse”) ceased to be a beneficiary after the parties’ divorce and where H subsequently removed himself as settlor, trustee and beneficiary did amount to “property of the parties”. In Harris & Dewell and Anor [2018] FamCAFC 94 a unit trust owned by H’s father but controlled by H was held to be H’s financial resource. In Ogden [2010] FMCAfam 865 at [82], [119]-[120], [126]-[128] it was held that W’s interest in a fam- ily trust was “property” and took an asset by asset approach, finding that H had made no contribution in respect of it. In Keach and Ors [2011] FamCA 192 a discretionary trust controlled by H’s father was held not to be a sham. Its assets were excluded from the pool but treated ([210]) as H’s financial resource. Something more than mere control is required: Atkins & Hunt and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: in respect of it. In Keach and Ors [2011] FamCA 192 a discretionary trust controlled by H’s father was held not to be a sham. Its assets were excluded from the pool but treated ([210]) as H’s financial resource. Something more than mere control is required: Atkins & Hunt and Ors [2020] FamCAFC 252 at [33]. In Harris [2011] FamCAFC 245 the Full Court held that a finding that a party (who held no position in a trustee company) had indirect control of trust assets was in error. In Morton [2012] FamCA 30 at [35]-[38] Bell J found that the assets of a discretionary trust, the corporate trustee of which was directed by H and his brother (who were also joint appointors) were not under the “control” of H, so were a financial re- source of his, not his property. See our archived case notes – property under “trust, company, control etc”. Notional property added back The Full Court in AJO & GRO (Omacini) [2005] FamCA 195 at [30]-[31] held that there are three cat- egories of cases where an asset that no longer exists will be notionally added back into the pool: 1. Paid legal fees: DJM & JLM [1998] FamCA 97 at [11] (unless paid not from joint funds but from a party’s post-separation income or money received in their own right e.g. inheritance or gift: NHC & RCH (Chorn & Hopkins) [2004] FamCA 633 at [56]-[60]). 2. Where a party has made a premature distribution of matrimonial assets by selling, and benefitting from the proceeds of sale of, an asset in which the other party had a legitimate interest: Townsend [1994] FamCA 144 (sale of a taxi business) per Nicholson CJ (the majority agreed). The Full Court held in C & C (Cerini) [1998] FamCA 143 that
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: assets by selling, and benefitting from the proceeds of sale of, an asset in which the other party had a legitimate interest: Townsend [1994] FamCA 144 (sale of a taxi business) per Nicholson CJ (the majority agreed). The Full Court held in C & C (Cerini) [1998] FamCA 143 that the notional add back approach should be the exception and not the rule. In Omacini (AJO & GRO) (above) the Full Court held that it was “unduly simplistic” for a trial judge to proceed on the basis that the mere fact that a party spent money obtained from a distribution of assets which had existed at separation would result in such Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 19 expenditure being added back, and that it was necessary for the court to “make some assessment of the reasonableness or otherwise of the expenditure”. This decision was followed in SMB & MFB [2006] FamCA 46 where a trial judge characterised $102,500 W had received via interim orders as wholly partial property settlement. It was held that even if the trial judge was correct in finding the interim sums paid were not “spousal maintenance” but property, such sums will not necessarily be added back to the net asset pool. The court must examine whether expenditure was “beyond that which funded a reasonable standard of living and necessary outgoings”: SL & EHL [2005] FamCA 132. The Full Court in Chorn & Hopkins [2004] FamCA 633 at [42] cited earlier Full Court authority as follows: “There seems to be no appropriate basis for notionally adding back monies that existed at separation but which have been subsequently spent on meeting reasonably incurred living expenses. Neither the FLA nor the case law require that parties go into a state of suspended economic animation once their marriage breaks down pending the resolution of their financial arrangements. Parties are entitled to continue to provide for their own support.” In Gollings & Scott [2007] FamCA 397 at [68] the Full Court held that as a general rule, subject to obligations of maintenance and support and the considerations described in Kowaliw (below) as to waste, separated parties are entitled to get on with their lives independently of the other. This was applied by Rose J in Danford [2010] FamCA 420 (money spent on prostitutes not added back) and by Walters FM in Owens (No. 3) [2010] FMCAfam 3 (gift to new partner to buy a car not added back, but repayments of dubious “loans” were).
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: independently of the other. This was applied by Rose J in Danford [2010] FamCA 420 (money spent on prostitutes not added back) and by Walters FM in Owens (No. 3) [2010] FMCAfam 3 (gift to new partner to buy a car not added back, but repayments of dubious “loans” were). In Miller [2009] FamCAFC 121, Strickland J held that a ruling that only part (instead of all) of H’s post-separation insurance proceeds should be added back as he was likely to have spent a portion of it on living expenses was in error without evidence from H as to how he had applied the funds. In Britton & Firmer [2011] FamCA 786 at [66] half of a $4m pool was added back, being the value of property transferred by H into his parents’ superannuation fund. Also see Talbot [2015] FamCAFC 132 at [48]-[53]. In Shimizu & Tanner [2011] FamCA 271 Bryant CJ did not add back spent post-separation income. OR a party may be given a credit Where W spent $56,000 on a post-separation tax debt of hers (from money treated as joint), and H paid $36,000 to refund marital earnings of his (jointly enjoyed but claimed post-separation by an employer), the Full Court required W to account to H for half of each of those amounts out of her share of the property settlement: Waters & Jurek [1995] FamCA 101. 3. What is often referred to as “waste”, being financial loss resulting from a party’s conduct designed to reduce the value of matrimonial assets or a party’s reckless, negligent or wanton actions which have reduced that value: per Baker J in Kowaliw [1981] FamCA 70 at [10], adopted in Browne & Green [1999] FamCA 1483 at [41]-[49] by the Full Court which held that in the absence of such
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: the value of matrimonial assets or a party’s reckless, negligent or wanton actions which have reduced that value: per Baker J in Kowaliw [1981] FamCA 70 at [10], adopted in Browne & Green [1999] FamCA 1483 at [41]-[49] by the Full Court which held that in the absence of such waste losses should be shared, marriage being “an economic partnership”. In De Angelis [1999] FamCA 1609 at [41] and [57]-[82] W’s gambling of family funds was “very high in the context of the total [pool]” so 50% was added back. Gambling of other funds was not added back. For gambling losses, also see Ryan FM’s decision in AB & GB (No. 2) [2005] FMCAfam 402; Kiefer [2009] FMCAfam 279 at [65], [70]-[72] (O’Sullivan FM); and Hamilton & Thomas [2008] FamCAFC 8 at [31]-[37]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 20 Effect of non-disclosure of assets The Full Court has held that a court may make an order going beyond the identified property upon proof that a party has not made full disclosure of their assets: Weir [1992] FamCA 69; Tate [2000] Fam- CA 1040; and Chang & Su [2002] FamCA 156. Another option is to apply for an undefended hearing: Melville & Dent [2008] FamCA 926. The Full Court also held in Bonnici [1991] FamCA 86 at [52] that due to non-disclosure by a husband his tax liabilities should not be brought into account. Furniture and other chattels The Full Court said in J & J [2006] FamCA 951 at [60] that “[i]t is not uncommon in many defended property settlement cases for one or both parties to provide estimates of the value of items such as furniture and other household items, motor vehicles, or tools of trade, and if such estimates are not chal- lenged, they are taken into account in determining the value of the property to be divided between the parties”. The Court also approved the trial judge’s acceptance of the wife’s estimate (unchallenged by the husband until his appeal) for tools of trade “ascertained after talking with persons with knowledge of what could be achieved for the tools on the second hand market” ([56]). In furniture disputes the court often orders that one party prepare two lists of equal value of all the furniture, the other party to choose one list: see a discussion of possible orders in Hamill [2007] FamCA 1736 at [127]-[131]. A valuation of jewellery many years out of date was not accepted in Karr [2010] FMCAfam 53 at [143]-[149] (the jewellery there was excluded from the pool given its “emotional value for the wife”: [147]). Pets and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: see a discussion of possible orders in Hamill [2007] FamCA 1736 at [127]-[131]. A valuation of jewellery many years out of date was not accepted in Karr [2010] FMCAfam 53 at [143]-[149] (the jewellery there was excluded from the pool given its “emotional value for the wife”: [147]). Pets and livestock are property to “be valued in the usual way”: Grunseth & Wighton [2022] FedCFamC1A 132 at [65]. Valuation The asset pool must be valued as at the time of the final hearing: Hickey [2003] FamCA 395 at [39]. See “valuation” under “procedure for property matters” below. • Real estate – requires valuation. An unchallenged “kerbside” valuation by a real estate agent was not accepted in Garden & Gavin (No. 2) [2010] FamCAFC 125 at [91]-[93]. If a court is in doubt over differing valuations it may order the sale of the property: Smith [1991] FamCA 101. • Motor vehicles – A “Red Book” figure may be used in the absence of a valuation: Herbert [2006] FMCAfam 254 at [132]-[135]. • Superannuation. The latest member statement or a Superannuation Information Form supplied by you to, and completed by, the fund trustee (see “procedure” below) will value the super. If the trustee uses a method not prescribed by the FL(Super)Regs (the trustees of defined benefit interests and government pension schemes often use an industry-specific formula instead of the regulations formula) employ an expert in super splitting to value the interest. The court must determine the value under the Regs or some other method: s 90XT(2). See “treatment of superannuation” below. • A business – H’s 50% share in an architectural business was valued on the basis of future maintain- able earnings, as an average of adjusted net profit for the past 3 years, and a 10% discount was applied in Georgeson
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: other method: s 90XT(2). See “treatment of superannuation” below. • A business – H’s 50% share in an architectural business was valued on the basis of future maintain- able earnings, as an average of adjusted net profit for the past 3 years, and a 10% discount was applied in Georgeson [1995] FamCA 62. A 65% discount was applied to the value of W’s shares in a company controlled by her father. For the courts’ approach to earning capacity v asset backing, see [23]-[25] of Mason J’s judgment in Mallet [1984] HCA 21. • Minority interests – Where market value does not apply, e.g. shares in a family company, the court “must look at the reality of the situation and value the shares on the basis of their worth to the share- holder”: Turnbull [1991] FamCA 26 at [17]. See a statement of principles in Ramsay [1997] FamCA 4 and a summary of the cases in Eaton [2012] FMCAfam at [24]-[44]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 21 • A controlling shareholding – will be worth the realisable value of the company upon a voluntary winding-up: Ramsay (above) (applying the High Court decision of Mallet, above). • Valuation based on owner’s unusual business model preferred to one that assumed a buyer would alter the business fundamentals (so as to comply with Spencer v The Commonwealth [1907] HCA 82 as to the need to value the property as at valuation not at some other time): Gelledge [2012] FamCA 641. • Land is to be valued for its “highest and best use”, including its development potential: Bania & Jacopo (No. 2) [2011] FamCAFC 139 at [40]-[46]. The principle applies to plant and equipment which should be valued for continuing use (e.g. signwriting an advantage, not a disadvantage): Martin & Crawley [2012] FamCA 1032. In Grieves [2012] FamCA 691 at [31]-[38] a “continuing use” valuation of a commercial property was preferred to a “highest and best use” redevelopment approach. • “Normally, the primary test is the hypothetical prudent purchaser but it is conceivable and often seen in family law cases that the commercial or capital value of the shares in a company do not reflect the value for the … spouse who controls or retains them after separation … ” per Cronin J in Ledarn [2013] FamCA 858 at [83] (it being held at [83]-[87] that W should retain the business). • Business goodwill – for a sole trader this is more likely to be personal attributable to personal skills, experience, reputation and relationships, thus not transferable (treated not as property but as the person’s earning capacity) but for a larger business will be commercial goodwill (established name, location, business, clientele), which is transferable: W & W (Unrep) [2000] FamCA 1302 at [59]-[71]; and Snell [2011] FamCA
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: to personal skills, experience, reputation and relationships, thus not transferable (treated not as property but as the person’s earning capacity) but for a larger business will be commercial goodwill (established name, location, business, clientele), which is transferable: W & W (Unrep) [2000] FamCA 1302 at [59]-[71]; and Snell [2011] FamCA 985 at [25]-[27]. See also Forsythe’s paper on business valuation (personal or commercial goodwill) at our online Members’ Archive. • A partnership interest can be valued: Best [1993] FamCA 107. • A property transferred subject to a life interest may be valued based on the deferral of current value for the period of the life tenant’s life expectancy at a current rate of interest if a life estate is held to have been created: Barton [2009] FMCAfam 1293 at [12], [29]-[31]. • Historical valuations: Kirk & Kane [2012] FamCA 115 at [67]-[79]; also Pope [2012] FamCA 204 at [135]-[137] (royalty rights). Note – See our papers on business valuations at our online Members’ Archive. Debts The net asset pool is calculated by deducting the debts of the parties from the value of their property, except alleged debts that are vague, uncertain or unlikely to be enforced (such as an unsecured loan from a parent of a party); or were unreasonably incurred: Biltoft [1995] FamCA 45 at [57]; and Prince [1984] FamCA 7 at [23]. The court may discount the amount of a debt in a case of uncertainty as to time for payment: Campbell & Kuskey [1998] FamCA 10 at [51]. In D & D [2003] FMCAfam 74 H was made to pay a debt resulting from his wilful cancellation of the loan agreement on W’s car. For a declaration as to the parties’ liability for debt where their debts exceeded their assets see Athanastos [2011] FamCA 66. In Rose
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: [51]. In D & D [2003] FMCAfam 74 H was made to pay a debt resulting from his wilful cancellation of the loan agreement on W’s car. For a declaration as to the parties’ liability for debt where their debts exceeded their assets see Athanastos [2011] FamCA 66. In Rose [2012] FamCA 236 at [23]-[25] and [36]-[40], where there was no divisible property, Murphy J held H was liable for a $458K debt to his parents which he would prob- ably not have to repay and W liable for a $106K debt to Centrelink incurred by her fraudulent conduct. See Adair & Milford [2015] FamCAFC 29 at [32]-[48] as to H’s $419K tax debt and James & Snipper and Anor [2018] FamCAFC 235 (W to pay $200K of H’s $2m tax debt). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 22 Is money from parents or other family a repayable loan or a financial contribution made on behalf of its recipient? Examples of the court’s approach – • In Af Petersens [1981] FamCA 50 at [31] and [60] Nygh J allowed a discounted princi- pal sum as a liability (but no interest) where H’s father failed to enforce repayment of his secured loan or interest for 5 years. That case was applied by the Full Court in Winston (No. 2) [2013] FamCAFC 147 at [22], [48]-[52]. In H & H (Unrep) [2001] FamCA 134 the Full Court treated a mother’s advance of “her money” ([20]) as a loan despite uncertainty as to its terms. • Watts J in T & T (Pension Splitting) [2006] Fam CA 207 at [75]-[83] accepted the evidence of a loan being repayable by H to his brother in light of their involvement together in a family con- cern – documentation including a loan account; interest payments; and evidence given by the creditor himself that the debt, which had been at call, was now being called in. Watts J applied Biltoft [1995] FamCA 45 in which the Full Court at [52]-[53] discussed the courts’ usual ap- proach to assessing secured and unsecured liabilities. • By contrast, Bryant CJ in C & B [2005] FamCA 94 at [75]-[8] held that money advanced by H’s mother was a s 79(4) contribution on his behalf not a loan as it did not have the usual indicators of a loan, such as interest being payable, repayments being required, and a time being set for capital repayment. In Maddock & Anor (No. 2) [2011] FMCAfam 1340 at [46], [63]-[68] and [72]-[73] those factors were considered and it was held that $240K paid by H’s father towards H
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: indicators of a loan, such as interest being payable, repayments being required, and a time being set for capital repayment. In Maddock & Anor (No. 2) [2011] FMCAfam 1340 at [46], [63]-[68] and [72]-[73] those factors were considered and it was held that $240K paid by H’s father towards H and W’s cost of buying acreage and building a house was neither gift nor compellably repayable loan but a contribution on H’s behalf. • In Kessey [1994] FamCA 162 the Full Court held that a gift by a spouse’s parent “will be taken to be a contribution … on behalf of [that spouse] unless there is evidence which estab- lishes it was not the intention of the parent to benefit only his or her child”. • In Liakos & Zervos and Anor [2011] FamCA 547 at [139]-[150], [156]-[158], [171], [217] a deed for “money lent” by H’s father to H was dismissed as “entirely self-serving”, as was a retrospective mortgage in Bircher and Anor [2016] FamCAFC 123 at [28]-[63]. • In Pelly & Nolan [2011] FMCAfam 530 a loan from H’s father said by him to be repayable was distinguished from his payments that he called gifts, so was included as a liability. • In Vadisanis and Anor [2014] FamCAFC 97 at [71]-[89] the Full Court held that the limitation period of six years for recovery of a loan from H’s mother (which was repayable on 3 months’ notice) ran from the date of demand. Gifts of land from parents and other relatives To whom a relative transfers title to property is usually “the strongest indicator of the intention of the donor” but a transfer of land from a wife’s parents that was registered in the joint names of W and H was held to have been a contribution made
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: and other relatives To whom a relative transfers title to property is usually “the strongest indicator of the intention of the donor” but a transfer of land from a wife’s parents that was registered in the joint names of W and H was held to have been a contribution made on behalf of W in Gosper [1987] FamCA 43. See a summary of Gosper and other case law in Muir & Royston [2010] FamCA 374 at [98]-[105]. In Barton [2009] FMCAfam 1293 ([50]-[56]) a gift of land to H by his aunts was held to have been meant for, thus a contribution by, both parties (90:10 to H). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 23 Realisation expenses and CGT These are usually deducted from the pool for investment properties: Rosati [1998] FamCA 38 at [6.31]- [6.36] although in Blake [2007] FamCA 10 it was held that CGT allowances should only be made on properties intended to be sold immediately. See “CGT, income tax, GST and stamp duty” below. Not “property” • Non-transferable licences or rights and choses in action such as partnership interests which are not wholly or partly assignable: B & B [1999] FamCA 1142 at [74]-[107] (but in Best [1993] FamCA 107 a partnership in a law firm, assignable with the partners’ consent, was held to be “property”) • Expected inheritance from living testator: White & Tulloch [1995] FamCA 127 cf De Angelis below • A capacity to borrow money: Walters [1986] FamCA 8 at [17]-[19] • Money held in bank account in trust for a child: Tamaris [2018] FCCA 3696 at [9]-[31] • Non-commutable disability insurance subject to insured’s health: Tomaras [2021] FedCFamC1A 82 Not “property” but a financial resource under s 75(2)(b) See s 75(2)(b) below in “assess Section 75(2) factors”. The following interests have been held not to be property for inclusion in the asset pool but a financial resource for consideration under s 75(2): • Business goodwill that is personal, not commercial: W & W (Unrep) [2000] FamCA 1302 at [59]-[71] • Long service leave if likely to be in cash or give time to retrain: Gould [1995] FamCA 142 • A future pension entitlement: Perrett [1989] FamCA 56 • Future benefit from past tax losses: JEL & DDF [2000] FamCA 1353 at [116]-[119] • Anticipated inheritance if testator has lost testamentary capacity: De Angelis [1999] FamCA 1609 • Accrued long service and annual leave if not paid: Dawes [1989] FamCA 71 at [57], [60]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: Perrett [1989] FamCA 56 • Future benefit from past tax losses: JEL & DDF [2000] FamCA 1353 at [116]-[119] • Anticipated inheritance if testator has lost testamentary capacity: De Angelis [1999] FamCA 1609 • Accrued long service and annual leave if not paid: Dawes [1989] FamCA 71 at [57], [60] and [84] and MM & DM [2005] FMCAfam 355 at [38] • Personal goodwill (treated as personal earning capacity): W & W (Unrep) above • Overseas superannuation: SHL & EHL [2006] FamCA 1287 at [9]-[14] and [45]-[47] • Assets of trust controlled by spouse’s parent: Keach and Ors [2011] FamCA 192 at [210] (pattern of past distributions); Harris [2011] FamCAFC 245 at [64]-[73] (H held no position in trustee company); Morton [2012] FamCA 30 at [35]-[38] (H and brother directors of corporate trustee); Searle & Pencious & Anor [2013] FamCA 375 at [345]-[347] (2% of $2m pool awarded under s 75(2) due to advances from trust) Property” yes, but may be treated as a separate pool • Inheritance late or post-separation: Bonnici [1991] FamCA 86 at [39-[44]; Bishop [2013] FamCAFC 138 at [25]-[29]; Jarrott (No. 2) [2012] FamCAFC 72 at [9]; and Holland [2017] FamCAFC 166 at [25] (“it is wrong … to refer to any … property … as ‘excluded’ from consideration”) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.section: IDENTIFY AND VALUE THE NET PROPERTY

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 24 YOUR FIRST STEP – START BY DRAWING UP AN OUTLINE OF THE ASSET POOL(S) Note – Drawing up a rough sketch of the parties’ assets and liabilities when first taking instructions, and updating it as property and debts become known and their value ascertained, will provide you with a rough figure for the total net assets (“net asset pool”) from which you can calculate and keep under review your client’s property settlement entitlement as the case proceeds. Include superannuation in the one pool with non-super assets unless the super came largely from outside the relationship (in which case add it separately as in Pool B below). Set out your estimated asset pool according to the following sample (the centre column below is just for guidance, so dispense with it in practice): POOL A – NON-SUPER AND SUPER TO BE INCLUDED POOL A – NON-SUPER AND SUPER TO BE INCLUDED (CONTINUED) ITEM ASSET TYPE VALUE ($) LIABILITIES VALUE ($) 1 FAMILY AVENUE HOME 750,000 MORTGAGE – 4 SMITH STREET 450,000 BLOCK OF LAND, EUPHORIA OTHER REAL ESTATE 50,000 SECOND MORTGAGE – W’S PARENTS 70,000 4 SMITH STREET INVESTMENT PROPERTY 450,000 H’S AGC CAR LOAN 12,000 FLIPPER’S BUSINESS 50,000 CGT ON SALE ON 4 SMITH STREET 38,000 BHP SHARES (W) SHARES 20,000 H’S CREDIT CARD 10,000 RIO TINTO (H) SHARES 15,000 W’S BANKCARD 10,000 CBA (W) BANK ACCOUNTS 8,000 TOTAL LIABILITIES 590,000 NAB (H) BANK ACCOUNTS 12,000 SUB TOTAL 900,000 H’S HOLDEN MOTOR VEHICLES 35,000 W’S HYUNDAI MOTOR VEHICLES 30,000 POOL B – OTHER SUPERANNUATION BOAT OTHER 10,000 H’S/W’S (SPECIFY) SUPER INTEREST (E.G.
