chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 26 ASSESS CONTRIBUTIONS Second step of your entitlement calculations Just as the court will undertake if your case does not settle, this is the next stage of calculations once the net asset pool has been identified – to apply a percentage of that pool as an assessment of the parties’ contributions under s 79(4) (or s 90SM(4) for de facto claims). Types of contribution a) Financial contributions “made directly or indirectly by or on behalf of a party … or a child … to the acquisition, conservation or improvement of any of the property of the parties … or either of them, or otherwise in relation to any of that … property, whether or not that … property has, since the making of the contribution, ceased to be the property of the parties … or either of them”. Examples – a party’s earnings; or money or other assets brought into the marriage by a party or their parents; or a party’s payment of deposit, loan repayments or other outgoings, or expenses to acquire, maintain or improve real estate, business, cars or other property. b) Non-financial contributions “made directly or indirectly by or on behalf of a party … or a child … to the acquisition, conservation or improvement of any of the property of the parties … or either of them, or otherwise in relation to any of that … property, whether or not that … property has, since the making of the contribution, ceased to be the property of the parties … or either of them”. Examples – work done towards the maintenance or improvement of property, including a business; or a wife’s unaided child and home duties enabling the husband to pursue his business activities. c) Contributions “made by a party … to the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: be the property of the parties … or either of them”. Examples – work done towards the maintenance or improvement of property, including a business; or a wife’s unaided child and home duties enabling the husband to pursue his business activities. c) Contributions “made by a party … to the welfare of the family constituted by the parties … and any children …, including any contribution made in the capacity of homemaker or parent”. Included in the above contributions are – • pre-cohabitation contributions: G & G [2000] FamCA 1075 at [11]-[14] • contributions during pre-marital cohabitation to property (Collins [1977] FamCA 54 at [32]) and as homemaker and parent (Olliver [1978] FamCA 24 at [27]) • an asset brought into (or received during – see Kern [2014] FCCA 1108 at [49]-[53]) the marriage by a party, the value of which as at time of hearing (despite resulting from market forces), not its value when first contributed: Williams [2007] FamCA 313 at [26]-[32] but see Jabour [2019] FamCAFC 78 at [31]-[87] • a party’s initial asset the later sale of which was a “springboard” for acquiring more valuable property: Manolis (No. 2) [2011] FamCAFC 105 at [71] • rent-free accommodation (usually provided by a party’s parents): Pellegrino [1997] FamCA 52 • contributions made to property after separation: Jacobson [1988] FamCA 15 • post-separation parent contributions (Pierce [1998] FamCA 74; DR & CAJ [2005] FamCA 213 at [52]-[55]) and “welfare” contributions (Williams [1985] HCA 52 at [4]) • contributions to an expectant interest in property: James [1978] FamCA 10 at [26]-[30] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 27 Rule of thumb – “equality or thereabouts” in most cases In the Full Court case of Waters & Jurek [1995] FamCA 101 Fogarty J (with whom Hase J agreed) said (at [29] of his Honour’s reasons): “In the majority of property cases little difficulty is encountered in the contribution step and increasingly in the general run of cases the conclusion is likely to be one of equality or thereabouts.” His Honour continued: “There is no doubt that the centre of gravity in the determination of property cases has, especially in more recent times, moved to the evaluation of the s 75(2) factors, and the significance of that has been heightened because of recent Full Court decisions which have emphasised those provisions and indicated that they should be given real rather than token weight.” This highlights the two-stage process of assessing a party’s property entitlement: • Firstly, assess contributions (as a proportion of the total net assets); and then • (again, as a proportion of the total net assets) evaluate s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)) factors. “Token weight” being given to those factors refers to the court’s practice in its early years of awarding the financially weaker party (usually then the wife) an extra 10–20% without any particular reference to its monetary value in compensation for those factors. However, just as s 75(2) factors are said to have been given real weight since the 90s, financial contributions have also been given closer attention since the late 90s by it being taken less for granted that contributions should be assessed as approximately equal where a significant financial contribution has been made by one of the parties. See, in particular, Pierce (above). Prior to then, the Full Court in Bremner [1994] FamCA 116 found itself weighing up competing judgments
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: by it being taken less for granted that contributions should be assessed as approximately equal where a significant financial contribution has been made by one of the parties. See, in particular, Pierce (above). Prior to then, the Full Court in Bremner [1994] FamCA 116 found itself weighing up competing judgments of its Court in Money [1994] FamCA 54 as to whether the significance of an initial contribution by a party (assets brought into the marriage) could only be offset by contributions of the other party that exceeded that initial contribution, or may be eroded by the other’s contributions even though they might not “outstrip” that initial contribution. The Court chose the latter approach in Money of Fogarty J (with whom Holden J agreed), his Honour adding at para 10 of his reasons: “The longer the marriage the more likely it is that there will be later factors of significance and in the ultimate the exercise is to weigh the original contribution with all other, later, factors and those later factors, whether equal or not, may in the circumstances of the individual case reduce the significance of the original contribution.” In particular, the role of homemaker and parent “should be recognised not in a token way but in a substantial way”: Mallet [1984] HCA 21 and Ferraro [1992] FamCA 64. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 28 Contributions equal Examples of contributions considered equal: • Superior financial contributions are not more important than contributions under s 79(4)(b) or (c) and will be held to be equal, not by applying a presumption of equality but if the effort made by the parties in their respective roles is found to have been equal: Fields & Smith [2015] FamCAFC 57 at [42]; Hoffman [2014] FamCAFC 92 at [61] and [73]; SL & EHL [2005] FamCA 132 and Bulleen [2010] FamCA 187 at [21]-[26] • “[There should be] no extra loading … [for] higher earnings … [A] merging of effort, finance, risk and support … [can be] of equal value”: Petruski & Balewa [2013] FamCAFC 15 at [25] • Lottery win during marriage or cohabitation: Zyk [1995] FamCA 135 • Property value increase as a result of re-zoning: Zappacosta [1976] FamCA 56 • H’s redundancy payment where employment was during marriage: Burke [1992] FamCA 85. Unequal contributions These are found where an initial contribution (of money or other property) is brought into the marriage by a party, or a significant asset contributed to the asset pool by one party during the marriage (such as money from parents or an inheritance). These become more significant: • The shorter the marriage (10 years qualified in Pierce below) • The closer the contribution is to the end of the marriage • The greater the contribution relative to the asset pool (Pierce’s was $200K out of $300K) Initial contributions (assets brought into the marriage by one party) In Pierce [1998] FamCA 74, where H had contributed about $200,000 at the beginning of the parties’ 10-year marriage representing about two-thirds of their total net assets, the Full Court overruled the trial judge’s assessment of 55% for his contributions (including his post-separation
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: brought into the marriage by one party) In Pierce [1998] FamCA 74, where H had contributed about $200,000 at the beginning of the parties’ 10-year marriage representing about two-thirds of their total net assets, the Full Court overruled the trial judge’s assessment of 55% for his contributions (including his post-separation care of a child) with an assessment of 70% with a further 5% for that child care contribution (total 75%), saying at [28]: “In our opinion it is not so much a matter of erosion of contribution but a question of what weight is to be attached, in all the circumstances, to the initial contribution. It is necessary to weigh the initial contributions by a party with all other relevant contributions of both the husband and the wife. In considering the weight to be attached to the initial contribution…regard must be had to the use made by the parties of that contribution. In the present case that use was a substantial contribution to the purchase price of the matrimonial home.” The Full Court said in Jabour [2019] FamCAFC 78 at [55]: “ … [T]he import of Pierce is that the weight to be attached to an initial contribution must be assessed against the rubric of all of the contributions, both financial and non-financial, made by the parties over the course of their relationship.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 29 Other examples of unequal contributions • H’s initial $180K and $150K waste by W = 80% of $1.6m pool to H: SJS & NS [2005] FamCA 66 • Home 50/50 but H’s pharmacy (from his father) 70% to H: Lenehan [1987] FamCA 8 • Third party contributions, such as from parents: Gosper [1987] FamCA 43 but in Barton [2009] FMCAfam 1293 ([50]-[56]) a gift by H’s aunts was held to have been meant for, thus a contribution by, both parties (90:10 in H’s favour) • Lottery win by a party pre-cohabitation in Brease [1997] FamCA 23 or early in marriage as in Zyk [1995] FamCA 135. In Eufrosin [2013] FamCA 311 H got nil for s 79(4) but $500K for s 75(2) re W’s post-separation $5m winnings. (H’s appeal dismissed: Eufrosin [2014] FamCAFC 191) • Inheritance. If late in marriage, no claim if justice achievable from other assets (Bonnici [1991] FamCA 86 at [39]-[44]) or it was quarantined without objection (Bishop [2013] FamCAFC 138 at [24]-[29]) • A party’s damages award: James [1983] FamCA 49; Aleksovski [1996] FamCA 111 • H’s alcoholism increased W’s welfare input: P & P [2002] FMCAfam 164 • Pre-relationship and/or post-separation contributions to super: see “treatment of super” below (“examples of separate pools approach”) • Pool of $200K solely from H, but W’s enormous work over 10 years gave her 60% under s 79(4): Columbia [2009] FamCA 311. In Franklin [2010] FamCAFC 131 W got 60% (of $9m) for superior financial and welfare contributions in an 18-year marriage • W lived half of 6-year marriage in Philippines and got 2.5% of $1.4m: Parke [2009] FMCAfam 934 • Short marriages: see Brandow [2010] FMCAfam 1026 and G & G [2006] FamCA 877 at [35]-[38] and the short marriage cases at “asset by
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: and welfare contributions in an 18-year marriage • W lived half of 6-year marriage in Philippines and got 2.5% of $1.4m: Parke [2009] FMCAfam 934 • Short marriages: see Brandow [2010] FMCAfam 1026 and G & G [2006] FamCA 877 at [35]-[38] and the short marriage cases at “asset by asset approach” below. • High earnings are not “special contributions”: Newman [2013] FamCA 37 at [116]-[118] Domestic violence The Full Court held in Kennon [1997] FamCA 27 that: “…[W]here there is a course of violent conduct by one party towards the other during the mar- riage which is demonstrated to have had a significant adverse impact upon that party’s contribu- tions to the marriage or…to have made his or her contributions significantly more arduous than they ought to have been, that is a fact which a trial judge is entitled to take into account in assess- ing the party’s respective contributions within s 79.” An adjustment must be weighed holistically, with all other s 79 contributions: Benson & Drury [2020] FamCAFC 303 at [35]. In Kozovska & Kozovski [2009] FMCAfam 1014 at [73]-[74] 10% of a $1.3m pool was awarded as a Kennon component of the contributions assessment and in Kucera [2009] FMCAfam 1032 at [110] 15% of a $600K pool was awarded. In Dixon [2011] FMCAfam 1244 W received 20% (of a pool of about $750K i.e. about $150K) for Kennon where contributions were otherwise found to be equal. In Damiani [2012] FamCA 535 at [175]-[179] Watts J awarded W 5% of a $3.9m pool for Kennon. Evidence must explain how violence made contributions more ardu- ous: Martell [2023] FedCFamC1A 71 at [23]-[37]. For more cases, see our archived property cases under “domestic violence (Kennon)”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 30 Guide to assessing contributions What follows is a rough guide to assessing your client’s contributions entitlement, which is your next calculation once the net asset pool has been identified and valued. This guide is simply based on the court’s own assessment of contributions in a variety of cases (both initial contributions and contributions during the relationship e.g. assets gifted by family members, as to which see Kern [2014] FCCA 1108). See table below. Keeping and updating a record like this will give you a feel for how the court ap- proaches the assessment of contributions, and keep you in touch with any shift in the court’s approach. The easier part of the exercise is to assess whether your client’s case is within that “majority of property cases” (Waters & Jurek [1995] FamCA 101 at [29]) where “equality or thereabouts” is the contributions assessment. Assessing how a court will rule in a case of obvious inequality, in the context of which is a discretionary exercise, is not as easy but can be made easier by comparing assessments in decided cases. Finding comparable contributions assessments should enable you to make a contributions assessment in your case (to which you then add your adjustment for s 75(2), or s 90SF(3), factors) and give you some forensic basis for arguing the question of your client’s entitlement with the other party or their lawyer. The Full Court said in Hoffman [2014] FamCAFC 92 at [59]: “The facts of each case are, of course, unique to it and the discretion wide. But, that does not mean that like cases ought not provide a path to consistency in the exercise of the discretion.” Definitions “Case” – see Case Table for the case citation “Years” – years of marriage including pre-marital cohabitation “Contribution/asset
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: are, of course, unique to it and the discretion wide. But, that does not mean that like cases ought not provide a path to consistency in the exercise of the discretion.” Definitions “Case” – see Case Table for the case citation “Years” – years of marriage including pre-marital cohabitation “Contribution/asset pool” – the financial contribution of the party whose initial (H or W) appears in the right-hand column/(compared to) the size of the net asset pool. (Where both parties have made initial or later financial contributions, “contribution” is the excess of the higher over the lower contribution.) Do not count any contribution that was not used for the benefit of the family. The onus of proof is on the party alleging that a contribution was not spent for the family’s benefit. In the absence of such evidence, the court may assume that it did benefit the family: Parshen [1996] FamCA 141. Note – The following table can also be used as a rough guide to previous adjustments made under s 75(2) or, in de facto cases, s 90SF(3) factors covered below as a rough proportion of the available pool. Search at our eBook’s case links in the table for awards made in cases that are similar as to the 2nd and 3rd columns and asset pool (the pool in particular), noting that as every case is different as to such factors you would not be relying on case law in court but doing this exercise as an aid to negotia- tion – and re costs if you make a written offer with a view to an ultimate costs order as per page 8-51, para (f). Also see “getting real value for your client’s s 75(2) or 90SF(3) factors” under “section 75(2) factors” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 35 Asset by asset approach to contributions While a “global approach” is adopted in most cases (where the court assesses contributions by both parties as a whole on an overall view), an “asset by asset” approach (which would be difficult to apply in most cases) may be taken in some cases (Norbis [1986] HCA 17 per Mason and Deane JJ at [16]). An “asset by asset” approach might be taken in the case of: • Superannuation where significant contributions were made by the member spouse pre-relationship or post-separation, or both (see “examples of separate pools approach” under “treatment of superannuation” below) • Super in the form of a pension payable to a member spouse for a disability arising from a work-related injury post-separation: T & T (Pension Splitting) [2006] FamCA 207 • A pension that cannot be converted into a lump sum (i.e. by being commuted): McKinnon [2005] FamCA 1245 • An inheritance received by a party late in the marriage, where the existence of other assets allow for a just result: Bonnici [1991] FamCA 86 at [41]-[44]. In Muir & Royston [2010] FamCA 374 at [81], [98], [147], [156], [159] and [184] a three pools approach was adopted to separately assess contri- butions as to inheritances received by each party cf. Singerson & Joans [2014] FamCAFC 238 where a global approach was taken despite H’s post-separation inheritance due to W’s greater marital contributions (also see Stone [2015] FamCAFC 18) • A short marriage, where the parties kept their assets separate: McMahon [1995] FamCA 145. In Edgar & Faines [2009] FamCAFC 22, Warnick J upheld Spelleken FM’s approach to reinstate the parties to a 3-year marriage with their respective pre-marital properties, with an adjustment to allow for money paid by the husband towards the wife’s house, holidays
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: kept their assets separate: McMahon [1995] FamCA 145. In Edgar & Faines [2009] FamCAFC 22, Warnick J upheld Spelleken FM’s approach to reinstate the parties to a 3-year marriage with their respective pre-marital properties, with an adjustment to allow for money paid by the husband towards the wife’s house, holidays and other joint expenses. See also Scofield & Shaw [2011] FMCAfam 1296 at [24]. But in Kiefer [2009] FMCAfam 279 at [46] and [51] O’Sullivan FM preferred a global approach despite the parties’ short marriage (less than 2 years) as their assets had not been kept entirely separate • A long marriage where the parties’ finances were kept separate: Stiller & Power [2011] FMCAfam 996 • A long separation (prior to the final hearing) during which the parties informally managed different assets: Zalewski [2005] FamCA 996 at [166]. See also Polonius & York [2010] FamCAFC 228 at [92] and [104] • A property transferred to a party as a gift or under a partnership: Barton [2009] FMCAfam 1293 at [12], [29]-[31] and [50]-[56] • An (inaccessible) interest in a family trust: Ogden [2010] FMCAfam 865 at [82], [119]-[120], [126]-[128] and [136] • A post-separation lottery win: Eufrosin [2013] FamCA 311 at [75]-[76]. For more cases, see our archived case notes – property under “separate pools approach”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 36 ASSESS SECTION 75(2) (OR, FOR DE FACTO CLAIMS, SECTION 90SF(3)) FACTORS Third step of your entitlement calculations Just as the court will undertake if your case does not settle, this is your next stage of calculations once the net asset pool has been identified and contributions assessed – to consider adjusting your contributions percentage by a percentage for s 75(2) factors. Applications for property settlement and spousal maintenance are heard together but the court will rule on the entitlement to a property order first, because after the property settlement there may be no need for maintenance as well: Anast & Anastopoulos [1981] FamCA 96. The Full Court held in that case that a distinction had to be drawn between a “maintenance component’’ and an order for lump sum maintenance because a “maintenance component’’ is part of a s 79 order and as such is final, and not capable of variation under s 83 as a spousal maintenance order is. See “relationship between spousal maintenance and property orders” in Chapter 6. Court’s approach to s 75(2) as part of a property settlement For the financially weaker party (traditionally, the wife) the court will add a percentage of the asset pool to the contributions assessment for any relevant s 75(2) factor. Alternatively, a specified amount may be awarded (e.g. Guthrie & Rushton [2009] FamCA 1144; Sinclair [2012] FamCA 388 at [103]; and Hayton & Bendle [2010] FamCA 592 at [198]). In the High Court case of Mallet [1984] HCA 21 at [18] of his judgment Wilson J said: “The objective of the section is not to equalise the financial strengths of the parties. It is to em- power the court, following a dissolution of a marriage, to effect a redistribution of the property of the parties if
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: [1984] HCA 21 at [18] of his judgment Wilson J said: “The objective of the section is not to equalise the financial strengths of the parties. It is to em- power the court, following a dissolution of a marriage, to effect a redistribution of the property of the parties if it be just and equitable to do so.” The Full Court in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10 said: “It has long been recognised that in most cases the most valuable ‘asset’ which a party can take out of the marriage is a substantial, reliable, income-earning capacity: see Best [1993] FamCA 107. There is, we think, at times a tendency to assess s 75(2) factors in percentage terms without considering its real impact, and we think there is legitimacy in the views expressed in more recent times that the Court has tended to operate in this area within artificially delineated boundaries. That is, it appears almost to be inevitable that the s 75(2) factors will be assessed in a range between 10% and 20%. A number of cases will justify an assessment outside those parameters and in any event it is the real impact in money terms which is ultimately the critical issue. ( … ) If one were to conclude that the contributions should have been no less than 25% ($350,000) then in our view the s 75(2) factors should be in the range of a further $350,000 or approximately 25%. Such a view would result in an overall conclusion that the property should be divided equally so that they each receive about $700,000. Equality is not … the justification for that conclusion. There are quite disparate factors at the beginning and the end of the marriage which must be balanced, that is, the husband’s substantial initial contributions and future income
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the property should be divided equally so that they each receive about $700,000. Equality is not … the justification for that conclusion. There are quite disparate factors at the beginning and the end of the marriage which must be balanced, that is, the husband’s substantial initial contributions and future income compared with the wife’s fu- ture income and responsibilities. It is to be tested by considering the outcome to each party within the parameters of the dictates of s 79. The husband will have substantial income, offset to an extent by his child support liabilities, and assets of about $700,000. The wife will have the same assets, but no income apart from the child support payments. That outcome appears to favour the husband but the Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 37 reason is that the s 79 exercise requires the Court to give appropriate weight to, inter alia, the initial financial contributions of a party. It is not an exercise in social engineering.” Section 75(2) factors For case law on each of the following see “maintenance factors” in Chapter 6. • The age and state of health of each party: s 75(2)(a) • Any disparity of income, earning capacity, property and financial resources: s 75(2)(b) • Whether a party has the care of a child: s 75(2)(c) • Each party’s commitments enabling self-support or the support of a child: s 75(2)(d) • Either party’s responsibility to support another person: s 75(2)(e) • Subject to (3) (which requires such eligibility to be disregarded in maintenance proceedings), a party’s eligibility for a pension, allowance or benefit: s 75(2)(f) • A reasonable standard of living: s 75(2)(g) • Any scope for increasing earning capacity by paying retraining or re-establishment cost: s 75(2)(h) • Effect of proposed order on creditor’s ability to recover debt: s 75(2)(ha) • Applicant’s contribution to other party’s income, earning capacity, property, financial resources: s 75(2)(j) • Extent to which duration of marriage has affected applicant’s earning capacity: s 75(2)(k) • The need to protect a party wishing to continue their role as a parent: s 75(2)(l) • The financial circumstances of any cohabitation with another person: s 75(2)(m) • The terms of any proposed property order: s 75(2)(n) • The terms of any proposed order under Part VIIIAB: s 75(2)(naa) • Any child support paid or to be paid in the future for a child of the parties: s 75(2)(na) • Any circumstance which the justice of the case requires to be taken into account: s 75(2)(o) • The terms of any binding financial agreement between
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Part VIIIAB: s 75(2)(naa) • Any child support paid or to be paid in the future for a child of the parties: s 75(2)(na) • Any circumstance which the justice of the case requires to be taken into account: s 75(2)(o) • The terms of any binding financial agreement between the parties: s 75(2)(p) • The terms of any binding Part VIIIAB financial agreement between the parties: s 75(2)(q) Economic and other consequences of divorce The Full Court in Mitchell [1995] FamCA 32 at [76]-[81] referred to social science research analysing “the feminisation of poverty” and took judicial notice of the social reality that: “Importantly, and particularly in more recent times, there is the notorious circumstance that there is a significant gap between theory and reality for employment, especially for people in middle age, lack- ing experience and confidence, and who have been out of the skilled work-force for many years (…) (In) the case at hand, it is important to recognise and give realistic effect to the circumstance that the acquisition and development by the husband of his professional skills (and thus his present high earning capacity) occurred during the marriage whilst at the same time the wife sacrificed her professional skills to care for the family. These are matters to which paragraphs (j) and (k) of s 75(2) are directed.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 38 Waters & Jurek [1995] FamCA 101 was a case of a 22-year marriage from which there was one adult child, where the husband and wife were psychiatrists with gross incomes of $171,000 and $74,000 respectively. Fogarty J ([35] of his reasons) discussed why that disparity of income should attract a property adjustment when the wife would not have been able to establish a need for spousal maintenance: “The responsibility of the Court, when hearing a s 79 application, is to make an order which recognises, as far as possible, the fact that the order is made on an arbitrarily determined day, but is to have a prospective effect on the parties’ lives.” Fogarty J, expressing a majority view of the Full Court, reviewed the earlier tendency of the court to regard s 75(2) as “needs factors”, a view later rejected by the Full Court (most strongly in Collins [1990] FamCA 141), saying at [36] of his judgment: “Both the Full Court and the High Court reiterated the view that the test [for any s 75(2) factor] is its relevance to a ‘just and equitable’ order.” The Full Court in Waters & Jurek (above) at [32]-[33] referred to: • disparity of income and earning capacity as a “commonly relevant” factor under s 75(2)(b), and • the care of the children as “traditionally calling for significant attention” under s 75(2)(c). Disparity of income and earning capacity In Waters & Jurek (above), Fogarty J at [52]-[59] of his Honour’s reasons: “Section 75(2) is concerned with the process of arriving at a just and equitable result and there are many circumstances in which the justice and equity of the case and specific paragraphs of s 75(2) would support, indeed require, an adjustment in a party’s favour for matters which
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Honour’s reasons: “Section 75(2) is concerned with the process of arriving at a just and equitable result and there are many circumstances in which the justice and equity of the case and specific paragraphs of s 75(2) would support, indeed require, an adjustment in a party’s favour for matters which could not be described as being of ‘financial or economic significance’. Indeed, Collins [referred to above] is a strong example of that. The s 75(2) adjustment, largely centred around s 75(2)(c), was of the dimen- sion of $1m. Given the custodian mother’s independent wealth, it could not and was not sought to be justified on financial or economic factors alone or even significantly. (…) Disparity in income and income earning capacities is a common basis for making an adjustment un- der s 79 quite independently of its maintenance implications. The rationale for that usually lies in the circumstance that the difference in income earning capacities is significant and/or has arisen either directly or indirectly as a consequence of the marriage and the roles which the parties played during the marriage. In most marriages, there is a division of roles, duties and responsibilities between the parties. As part of their union, the parties choose to live in a way which will advance their interests – as individuals and as a partnership. The parties make different contributions to the marriage, which the law recognises cannot simply be assessed in monetary terms or to the extent that they have financial consequences. Homemaker contributions are to be given as much weight as those of the primary breadwinner. On separation, the partnership, and the division of roles and responsibilities which it produced, come to an end. Individually, the parties are left largely in the personal situations that the mar- riage has assigned to them. However,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: are to be given as much weight as those of the primary breadwinner. On separation, the partnership, and the division of roles and responsibilities which it produced, come to an end. Individually, the parties are left largely in the personal situations that the mar- riage has assigned to them. However, the world outside the marriage does not recognise some of the activities that within the marriage used to be regarded as valuable contributions. Home- maker contributions, for example, are no longer financially equal to those of the bread-winner. Post-separation, the party who had assumed the less financially rewarded responsibilities of the Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 39 marriage is at an immediate disadvantage. Yet that party often cannot simply turn to more finan- cially rewarding activities. Often, opportunities to do so are no longer open; or, if they are, time is required before they can be accessed and acted upon. When the marriage ends, especially where that marriage has been a long one, one cannot separate the parties as individuals from the people they became in the context of the marriage relationship, and the allocation of roles, duties and responsibilities which it entailed. In some cases, an adjustment is called for because it would be unjust for the roles and activities of a party, which were recognised until separation, and which largely determined or influenced the personal development of that party and the arrangements between the parties, to suddenly count for little, while those of the other party, which were of equal significance during the marriage, to now have a far greater financial impact outside the home (...) An order under s 79 would be unjust and inequitable in its operation if it failed to address the manner in which the value of the parties’ roles, adopted in the course of, and for the purposes of, the marriage, can be altered by the fact of separation. Those roles can be instantaneously converted into liabilities. The equality of the parties’ positions is terminated. This Court values different kinds of contributions of parties equally while the marriage subsists. It would be inconsistent with the equality which that position recognises not to take into account the transformation which the termination of the relationship results in, at least in terms of the capacity for present and future income generation.” Bryant CJ in C & B [2005] FamCA 94 at [102] rejected a husband’s submission that his super
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: which that position recognises not to take into account the transformation which the termination of the relationship results in, at least in terms of the capacity for present and future income generation.” Bryant CJ in C & B [2005] FamCA 94 at [102] rejected a husband’s submission that his super should be assessed separately, saying that “to do so would be to ignore the earning capacity of each of the parties at the date of separation, a consequence of their marriage, the way that they conducted their lives prior to separation and the wife’s post-separation contributions to the welfare of the family”. “Disparity of income” refers to net not gross income: Phipson [2009] FamCAFC 28 at [44] In Farmer & Bramley [2000] FamCA 1615 Kay J at [71] said that the Full Court’s approach in Collins [1990] FamCA 141 in making an adjustment for a disparity of capital “put to rest any sugges- tion that there can only be an adjustment under s 75(2)(b) if there is some causal nexus between the disparity and the marriage itself”. Getting real value for your client’s s 75(2) or 90SF(3) factors Adjust your contributions estimate in favour of the financially weaker party by an amount or percentage of the pool approximating to the “real impact in money terms” (Clauson above) of their s 75(2) or 90SF(3) factors. Adduce evidence from a recruitment consultant as to the future income foregone due to your client’s decision to put family before career, having regard to their job situation when that decision was made. Use our tables from page A-22 to capitalise any future disparity of net income or capital cost of children, adducing evidence on that from a forensic accountant. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 40 Disparity of financial resources In a short (3½ year), childless marriage in which the husband had contributed about $3 million and the wife $117,000 to a $3 million asset pool, the wife was awarded $300,000 (10% of the pool) by the Full Court for her modest homemaker contributions and disparity of financial resources: Goodwin [1990] FamCA 147. Large superannuation in the hands of one party is no longer the s 75(2) factor it was before the introduction of Part VIIIB because such disparity is now rectified by the making of a splitting order. Care of children, including capital cost of children not covered by periodic child support The Full Court in Collins [1990] FamCA 141 said: “The child support order would have gone a considerable distance towards meeting the living expenses of the child, but would not have covered the capital costs involved in the provision of a home and the like which necessarily flows from the wife being the sole custodian of this young child. (And for use if your client’s spouse is a neglectful parent) Additionally in this case is the circumstance that the husband had had nothing to do with the child, either financially or socially, from the separation to the trial, and that appeared to be his attitude for the future. Consequently, the trial Judge was entitled to proceed as he did upon the basis that the whole of that responsibility would rest on the shoulders of the mother. It appears to us that the trial Judge was entitled to place quite significant weight upon this circumstance in this case.” Guest J cited that statement in Farmer & Bramley [2000] FamCA 1615 at [225]. As to child support in general, the Full Court in Clauson (above) said: “ ... it should
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to us that the trial Judge was entitled to place quite significant weight upon this circumstance in this case.” Guest J cited that statement in Farmer & Bramley [2000] FamCA 1615 at [225]. As to child support in general, the Full Court in Clauson (above) said: “ ... it should not be forgotten that the payment of child support in no way compensates the custodial parent for the loss of career opportunity, lack of employment mobility and the restriction on an inde- pendent lifestyle which the obligation to care for children usually entails.” Guest J in Farmer & Bramley (above) said at [227]-[228]: “In my view any evaluation of factors under s 75(2)(c) should be based on a readily identifiable structure in order to avoid the miscellany of vagueness. The Full Court properly stated the position in Brandt [[1997] FamCA 21]: ‘If, when evaluating factors under s 75(2), it is appropriate to give consideration to such non-economic matters, then presumably it is important to weigh into the process the pleasure, company and sense of purpose that children bring both now and in the future. The difficulty in evaluating such matters demonstrates why approaching the matter in the manner his Honour did is not an appropriate course to be adopted. It is proper to take into account the economic ramifications of having responsibility for the children and the quasi- economic contributions involved in raising children which include washing, ironing, cook- ing, transporting and the like. It is appropriate to bear in mind salary and income oppor- tunities foregone because of responsibilities to children. It is appropriate to recognise that such responsibilities involve sacrificing leisure and recreation time. It is however very difficult to give economic value to either the emotional trauma involved in raising children or the rewards and compensation that
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: mind salary and income oppor- tunities foregone because of responsibilities to children. It is appropriate to recognise that such responsibilities involve sacrificing leisure and recreation time. It is however very difficult to give economic value to either the emotional trauma involved in raising children or the rewards and compensation that come, often very late in life, when role-playing is reversed between parent and child.’ Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 41 In my view, the preferred approach is to evaluate economic matters, as best one can, in assessing contributions pursuant to s 75(2)(c) of the Act. ( … ) In my view, the proper matters for evaluation include those set out in Brandt (above), namely: • the economic ramifications of having the responsibility for the children; • the quasi-economic contributions involved in raising children which include washing, ironing, cooking, transporting and the like; and • the issue of income opportunities foregone by reason of responsibilities to children. This is not to be taken as being an exhaustive list, but an indication of relevant matters for consid- eration.” Reasonable standard of living In Collins [1990] FamCA 141 the Full Court at also reviewed the trial judge’s ruling as to paragraph (g) (“a standard of living that in all the circumstances is reasonable”): “His Honour referred to this aspect in the following terms: ‘Since separation (the standard of living) of the wife has sharply diminished but the husband has continued in the former lifestyle as witnessed by the residence in Hunters Hill, the acquisition of luxury cars and vessels, etc.’ The parties enjoyed a high standard of living during the course of their marriage. At trial the husband was a wealthy man living in a very substantial style. The wife was the custodian of their young child and it was legitimate for his Honour, in the quest to achieve a standard of living which was ‘reasonable’, to have regard to those circumstances.” Cronin J said in Carmel-Fevia & Fevia (No. 3) [2012] FamCA 631 at [182]: “[Under s 75(2)(g) I propose to] make an adjustment so that there is a fair outcome which enables the wife to re-establish her financial security in the future with some confidence.” OTHER SECTION
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to those circumstances.” Cronin J said in Carmel-Fevia & Fevia (No. 3) [2012] FamCA 631 at [182]: “[Under s 75(2)(g) I propose to] make an adjustment so that there is a fair outcome which enables the wife to re-establish her financial security in the future with some confidence.” OTHER SECTION 75(2) (OR SECTION 90SF(3)) FACTORS Contributions to the other party’s child Where a party provides financial, non-financial or welfare contributions to a child of the other party who is not their biological child the court can award an adjustment in favour of the contributing party under s 75(2)(o): see Robb [1994] FamCA 136. For cases where this ruling has been applied, use Law- Cite at AustLII’s home page. Robb was described by Faulks DCJ as ‘anomalous’ in L & L [2005] FamCA 317 at [75]-[78]. A party’s contribution to the cost of private schooling for the other party’s child was described as ‘an expensive exercise’ in Jarrott [2007] FamCA 1002 at [35] but was taken into account globally with all other contri- butions. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 42 EFFECT OF PROPOSED ORDER ON A PARTY’S EARNING CAPACITY This is s 79(4)(d) (or s 90SM(4)(d) for de facto claims). It appears for consideration just before para- graph (e) which deals with the s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)) factors. The Full Court explained the paragraph (d) factor in Lee Steere [1985] FamCA 57 as follows: “Section 79(4)(d) directs the Court to consider the effect of any proposed order on the earning capacity of either party to the marriage. This is clearly a relevant consideration where the only or major asset available for division between the parties is the asset from which one of the parties derives his or her livelihood, whether it be a business, a professional practice or a farm. But it is not an absolute factor: it is one of several factors to be considered in arriving at an order which in all the circumstances is just and equitable: s 79(2). An order which would deprive a party substantially of what he or she is entitled to by reason of contribution would not normally be considered just and equitable.” The Court said: “In our view, the correct principle was laid down by Asche J in Magas [1980] FamCA 67 at [13]: ‘If arrangements can be made which would relieve the spouse who is working a farm as a farmer, from selling the farm but at the same time doing proper justice to the claim of the spouse who is not living on the farm, then of course those arrangements should be made.’ However, his Honour then went on to say: ‘If there is no other way to do that which is just and equitable then a sale must take place. It becomes an incident of the sad fact that, when two persons separate,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: farm, then of course those arrangements should be made.’ However, his Honour then went on to say: ‘If there is no other way to do that which is just and equitable then a sale must take place. It becomes an incident of the sad fact that, when two persons separate, property which might have given them together a reasonable competence will not be sufficient for each when divided. That is an inescapable situation and cannot be used as an argument to deprive one party of that to which he or she is otherwise properly entitled.’” The Court then added: “Paragraph (d) is, in our view, mainly relevant to the question of the ways and means in which the entitlement of a party can be met. It may be that in certain cases the destruction of the business can be avoided by allowing the payment of the order in instalments: Smyth [1977] FamCA 74 (FC) or to postpone it for a period as was done in Magas (above) provided this can be done without injustice to the applicant. Payment cannot be postponed for too long, unless the amount earns interest in the meanwhile or is expressed as a percentage on sale: Waters [1981] FamCA 19, and adequate arrangements are made for the support of the applicant and any child dependants in the meanwhile. Where the business has an adequate cash flow, it may be preferable to provide for continued maintenance of the wife, despite the provisions of s 81. But if, as Asche J pointed out in Magas, injustice can only be avoided by the sale and division of the business property… this must be done.” Note – The only other s 79(4) (or s 90SM(4)) matters to be taken into account are paragraphs (f) (“any other order made…affecting a party…or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: as Asche J pointed out in Magas, injustice can only be avoided by the sale and division of the business property… this must be done.” Note – The only other s 79(4) (or s 90SM(4)) matters to be taken into account are paragraphs (f) (“any other order made…affecting a party…or a child”) which is rarely used; and (g) (“any child support…a party…has provided, is to provide, or might be liable to provide”), although see above “capital cost of children (not covered by periodic child support)”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 43 TREATMENT OF SUPERANNUATION (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) The law Superannuation interests both of spouses and parties to a de facto relationship are governed by Part VIIIB of the Act (Part VIIIC of the Act for de factos in WA), the key provisions of which are set out below. Part VIIIB: • enables a valuation of the true worth of a superannuation interest, and • empowers the court to make a splitting order requiring payments under a superannuation policy to be allocated between the member and the non-member spouse Property orders may include superannuation interests of spouses or de facto partners: s 90XS. Note – For de facto couples in WA, see the schedule of equivalent legislative sections at p 7-56A. Splitting orders Section 90XT(1) specifies the following types of splitting order: A court, in accordance with s 90XS, may make the following orders in relation to a superannuation interest (other than an unsplittable interest): (a) if the interest is not a percentage-only interest – an order to the effect that, whenever a splittable payment becomes payable in respect of the interest: (i) the non-member spouse is entitled to be paid the amount (if any) calculated in accordance with the regulations (FL(Super)Regs); and (ii) there is a corresponding reduction in the entitlement of the person to whom the splittable payment would have been made but for the order; Note – Before making such an order, the court must allocate a base amount to the non-member spouse not exceeding the value determined under s 90XT(2) below: s 90XT(4). (b) an order to the effect that, whenever a splittable payment becomes payable in respect of the interest: (i) the non-member spouse is entitled to be paid a specific percentage of the splittable payment; and (ii) there is a corresponding
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: exceeding the value determined under s 90XT(2) below: s 90XT(4). (b) an order to the effect that, whenever a splittable payment becomes payable in respect of the interest: (i) the non-member spouse is entitled to be paid a specific percentage of the splittable payment; and (ii) there is a corresponding reduction in the entitlement of the person to whom the splittable payment would have been made but for the order; (c) if the interest is a percentage-only interest – an order to the effect that, whenever a splittable payment becomes payable in respect of the interest: (i) the non-member spouse is entitled to be paid the amount (if any) calculated in accordance with the regulations by reference to the percentage specified in the order; (ii) there is a corresponding reduction in the entitlement of the person to whom the splittable payment would have been made but for the order; Note – Percentage-only interests will not come your way unless one of the parties is a judge, governor or member of parliament: FL(Super)Regs 9A and 9B. (d) such other orders as the court thinks necessary for the enforcement of an order under paragraphs (a), (b) or (c). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 44 Splitting orders A “type (a) order”, made under s 90XT(1)(a) above, is a base amount order. A “type (b) order” is a percentage order, made under s 90XT(1)(b). A “type (c) order” is rare, as explained above. See “superannuation orders, by courtesy of Stephen Bourke” under “precedents” below, and Stephen’s accompanying explanatory notes. Valuation of superannuation interest Before making a splitting order, the court must determine: (a) the interest in accordance with the regulations; or (b) its value by such other method as the court considers appropriate: ss 90XT(2) and (2A). Flagging orders A court, under s 90XU(1), may make a s 79 property order in relation to a superannuation interest (other than an unflaggable interest): (a) directing the trustee not to make any splittable payment in respect of the interest without leave of the court; and (b) requiring the trustee to notify the court, within a period specified in the order, of the next occasion when a splittable payment becomes payable in respect of the interest. In deciding whether to make such an order, the court may take into account the likelihood that a splittable payment will soon become payable in respect of the superannuation interest, and any other relevant matter: s 90XU(2) When to seek a flagging order When the super split is not to be effected immediately, but at the eventual payment phase: see Zoller [2012] FamCA 47. Trustee to provide information Section 90XZB allows an eligible person to apply to the trustee of a superannuation plan for informa- tion about a superannuation interest of a member of the plan. The section requires the application to be accompanied by a declaration in the prescribed form, stating that the applicant requires the information either to assist the applicant to properly negotiate a superannuation
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: trustee of a superannuation plan for informa- tion about a superannuation interest of a member of the plan. The section requires the application to be accompanied by a declaration in the prescribed form, stating that the applicant requires the information either to assist the applicant to properly negotiate a superannuation agreement or assist in connection with property proceedings. For the procedure for obtaining superannuation information, see “procedure for property matters” and “forms” below. Orders binding on trustee Section 90XZD provides that an order under this Part in relation to a superannuation interest may be expressed to bind the person who is the trustee of the eligible superannuation plan at the time when the order takes effect. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 45 The court’s approach to superannuation How a superannuation interest is to be treated in a property settlement was enunciated by the Full Court in Coghlan [2005] FamCA 429: “(T)he trial judge has a discretion as to how superannuation interests will be treated in a particular case. If superannuation is not included in the list of property but rather made the subject of a separate pool, it will be necessary where a splitting order is sought, or extremely prudent where no such splitting order is sought (in order to ensure that justice and equity is achieved) to: (a) value the superannuation interest (according to the Regulations if an order under Part VIIIB is sought or according to the Regulations or otherwise if no order is sought); (b) consider and make findings about the types of contributions referred to in s 79(4)(a), (b) and (c) which have been made by the parties to the superannuation interests on either a global approach or an asset by asset approach depending on the circumstances; (c) consider the other factors in s 79(4) being the matters in s 79(4)(d), (e) (which refers to the s 75(2) factors), (f) and (g); and (d) ensure that pursuant to s 79(2) the orders in relation to the parties’ property, and any order under Part VIIIB in relation to superannuation interests are just and equitable. In…a consideration of…(b) and (c)…the following matters may well be relevant: • the relationship between years of fund membership and cohabitation; • actual contributions made by the fund member at the commencement of the cohabitation (if applicable), at separation and at the date of hearing; • preserved and non-preserved resignation entitlements at those times; and • any factors peculiar to the fund or to the spouse’s present and/or future entitlements under
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: • actual contributions made by the fund member at the commencement of the cohabitation (if applicable), at separation and at the date of hearing; • preserved and non-preserved resignation entitlements at those times; and • any factors peculiar to the fund or to the spouse’s present and/or future entitlements under the fund.” Watts J in T & T (Pension Splitting) [2006] FamCA 207 assessed contributions to three pools: • the non-superannuation assets • H’s large super in payment (pension) phase, and • H’s super in growth phase in different proportions, but took the view (at [211]) that the adjustment for s 75(2) factors “can more conveniently be made by looking at all of the net property and superannuation together”. Watts J (at [210], [207]–[12]) also referred to this statement: “What is relevant is not so much the actual percentage but the (amount) of the adjustment against the background of the contribution based findings, the effect of the splitting order, and significantly whether the overall findings result in an order which is just and equitable (see Phillips [2002] FamCA 350 at [67]).” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 46 Global approach or asset by asset? The Full Court in Coghlan (above) at [62] said this: “The parties’ contributions to all items…(including the superannuation interest) would then be as- sessed on either a global or an asset by asset basis. It might then be necessary in the s 75(2) con- text to have regard to the parties’ future superannuation entitlements (having regard of course to any division proposed on the basis of their contributions), with consideration then being given to the overall justice and equity of any proposed award or order (including any proposed splitting order).” The Full Court in Coghlan held that super may be included in the one pool where the parties agree to do so or where it is of small value relative to the other assets or where features of the interest are such that it is appropriate to do so, but that otherwise a separate list should be prepared for other superannuation interests. The cases below, however, indicate a wider use being made by the courts since Coghlan of the one pool approach. In C & B, Bryant CJ did so in relation to super worth $320,000, representing 25% of the value of the non-super assets. And in L & L (Levick), Moore J did so for super of $421,000, equating to 33% of the non-super. In fact, it seems that the amount or relative value of the super are less relevant to the courts’ approach than its origin. In P and P, below, Brown FM separately considered super where 40% of it had accrued before and after the relationship. In T & T (Pension Splitting), below, both pool approaches were taken, enabling a small super to be in- cluded with non-super, Watts J dealing with the other super separately
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: P and P, below, Brown FM separately considered super where 40% of it had accrued before and after the relationship. In T & T (Pension Splitting), below, both pool approaches were taken, enabling a small super to be in- cluded with non-super, Watts J dealing with the other super separately where only 45% of its growth and none of its sizeable pension entitlement had accrued during the relationship. See below for examples of the (global) one pool approach and the (asset by asset) separate pools approach. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 47 EXAMPLES OF ONE POOL APPROACH 1. Small superannuation Super with a value of $19,680, was included by consent in an asset pool that totalled $539,168 (super representing a small proportion of the non-super value) in T & T (Pension Splitting) [2006] FamCA 207. Watts J said at [14]: “…the parties agreed that the wife’s Colonial First State superannuation entitlement would be treated as property; and given the amount of (her) superannuation in the context of this case, that would have been an appropriate course in any event.” Note – T & T (Pension Splitting) (above) also features below under the separate pools approach because the husband, a police officer who sustained a disabling injury after separation, had two superannuation policies with a total value of $1.8m which were considered separately (one of the interests being in the growth phase and the other in the payment phase). 2. Super accrued during marriage included in asset pool C & B [2005] FamCA 94 was a 24 year marriage with two children, where H was a doctor on $177,000 a year and W a dietitian earning $60,000. Their non-super assets totalled $1.29m, and super (in the growth phase) about $320,000 (H’s three policies worth $250,000 and W’s super $70,000 from her own policy and her account in their self-managed fund). Bryant CJ found that during the marriage the parties’ contributions were equal, but that post- separation an adjustment of 7% was required in H’s favour in light of $130,000 contributed by H’s father and H’s mortgage payments post-separation. As to s 75(2) factors, Her Honour at [107] said this: “By reason largely of the difference in income earning capacity which will continue into the future and will affect the future superannuation of the parties, there should in my view
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: contributed by H’s father and H’s mortgage payments post-separation. As to s 75(2) factors, Her Honour at [107] said this: “By reason largely of the difference in income earning capacity which will continue into the future and will affect the future superannuation of the parties, there should in my view be an adjustment of 7% to the wife in respect of these matters. That would thus require an equal division of the assets having regard to the findings on contribution.” Bryant CJ then posed this question: “Should superannuation be treated any differently from the other assets and if so to what extent?” H was contending that the super and non-super should be dealt with separately. Her Honour ([108]– [109]) calculated that such an approach would result in W receiving an adjustment via a splitting order of $90,000 more super (for the parties to have super of $160,000 each); and, as to the non-super, W would pay $131,000 to H made up as follows: Non-superannuation $1,288,000 Equal share for each party $644,000 Value of non-super being retained by W $775,000 Balance payable to H for equality of non-super $131,000 Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 48 Her Honour then posed this question: “What orders need to be made to effect a just and equitable outcome?” The Court (at [110]) next calculated that assessing super and non-super together meant a total pool of $1,616,000, being an entitlement of $808,000 each; and that as the value of W’s retained non-super assets and super together was $849,000, W would be required to pay H the difference of $41,000 (actually $41,206), Bryant CJ’s ruling at [111] being this: “I am satisfied in all the circumstances that the just and equitable order in the circumstances would be to leave the superannuation as it is and to require the wife to pay to the husband… $41,206 in addition to retaining the superannuation she currently has and the assets in her possession. I come to that conclusion for the following reasons: a) That although the husband will have more superannuation than the wife and less existing assets, the difference in the result achieved by such an order and what the husband was seeking is close to $90,000 and in my view is not something which will prejudice the husband in any demonstrated way; b) The husband’s financial position is fairly secure and whilst the extra cash which might have been payable by the wife would be of value to him there is no evidence that it is crucial to his finances; c) The husband’s earning capacity is significantly greater than the wife’s and if she wants to retain the former matrimonial home then it would be more difficult for her to repay higher borrowings to meet the greater obligation to the husband.” Note – The mix of tangible assets and super (for a just and equitable outcome) was that instead of more cash to H, and a super
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the former matrimonial home then it would be more difficult for her to repay higher borrowings to meet the greater obligation to the husband.” Note – The mix of tangible assets and super (for a just and equitable outcome) was that instead of more cash to H, and a super split giving W more super, W’s super was left as it was (with a roll- over from their self-managed fund to a fund of her choosing) and she paid H less cash. 3. Parties’ self-managed super assessed in same pool as non-super Here is another “one pool” case where a wife was given a lesser super split in exchange for more cash (for re-housing needs and the capital cost of children). L & L (Levick) [2003] FamCA 40 was a 22-year marriage with two children. The husband was a banker and the wife was studying as a naturopath. They had non-super assets of $1.28m net and super in the growth phase, in their self-managed fund, of $421,000. Moore J considered (at [39]) that it was “appropriate to the case” for the super to be included in the one asset pool and a global approach taken to assessing contributions. Contributions These were considered to just favour H at 51:49 as financial contributions from him and his father ($100,000+) slightly outweighed W’s non-financial contributions. Moore J ([46]) then said: “I apply this assessment also to the superannuation that was built up entirely in the time since their relationship began.” Section 75(2) factors These were then considered at [51]–[54]. The court said that the parties had “come out of this marriage with a marked gap in…continuity of work experience…as well as vastly disparate earning capacities”, and that those factors and W’s future responsibility for the children (offset by H’s child support payments and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: These were then considered at [51]–[54]. The court said that the parties had “come out of this marriage with a marked gap in…continuity of work experience…as well as vastly disparate earning capacities”, and that those factors and W’s future responsibility for the children (offset by H’s child support payments and care-sharing) called for an adjustment of 10% i.e. 59% of the non-superan- nuation assets in W’s favour, being $755K and a super split of $206K. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 49 Would that outcome be just and equitable? Noting at [54]–[7] that W, who had net assets of $52K (car, shares etc), would need another $703K in cash (from the sale of their home), Moore J at [60]–[70] considered the mix of non- super v super assets, concluding: “At the core of this is (the wife’s) need to rehouse after the…home is sold and to enable her to provide adequately for herself from investment funds. (After reviewing her likely expenses)… on that scenario things could end up being a bit tight, leaving her with little left over as a buffer for contingencies and independent living.” The court went on to consider the position of H (for whom the outcome should also be just and equitable) and decided to reduce W’s super split entitlement by 60% for more cash. The value of that 60% ($124K) was discounted for immediate payment and tax to $83K. Spousal maintenance Spousal maintenance at $550 per week was granted to the wife until receipt of her share of the proceeds of sale of the house, when she would have a fund to invest for an income stream until she was able to re-enter the paid workforce. 4. Disability pension that was commutable to a lump sum upon a splitting order being made In Balzano [2014] FCCA 615 Judge Bender adopted a one pool approach in respect of the hus- band’s superannuation indexed pension from which he was receiving $42,384 per annum. The rules of the pension ([14]) were such that there was “no provision to create a separate interest for the non member spouse and/or for the non member spouse to receive on-going pension payments” and a splitting order would mean “the non member spouse [would] be entitled to be paid as a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of the pension ([14]) were such that there was “no provision to create a separate interest for the non member spouse and/or for the non member spouse to receive on-going pension payments” and a splitting order would mean “the non member spouse [would] be entitled to be paid as a lump sum”. The superannuation benefit had been valued in accordance with the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2001 at $455,761 ([15]). Judge Bender said at [29]: “The cases to which the husband’s counsel referred … were all dealing with a Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme (DFRDB) pension in its payment phase. A DFRDB pension in its payment phase cannot be commuted to a capital sum.” In adopting a one pool approach, the Court said at [38]: “As the husband’s superannuation is able to be commuted to a known lump sum for division between the parties, I am of the view that this distinguishes it from those cases where the Full Court held that an asset by asset approach was the preferable approach when dealing with matters where a party’s superannuation is a pension in the payment phase.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 50 EXAMPLES OF SEPARATE POOLS APPROACH 1. Large super to which 40% of H’s contributions were extra-marital P & P [2005] FMCAfam 576 at [83]–[114] is an example of the former FMC’s approach to prop- erty settlement as to both non-super assets and large super. This was a 12-year marriage with no children. H, 41, was a member of the Defence Forces. W retired early from the Defence Forces and for some years had been in other employment. Their assets were non-super ($232,000); H’s super (three policies totalling $513,000); and W’s super (two policies totalling $41,000). H’s super included a DFRDB interest worth $458,000 acquired after 20 years of service, so that six years had accrued before the relationship and two years after separation. H also had long service leave and recreation leave due (worth $24,000, which was treated as a financial resource of his). Brown FM assessed the parties’ contributions to non-super and to the four small super policies (the parties having two each) as equal, referring to the marriage as having been a “genuine part- nership” as had been stated in Figgins [2002] FamCA 688 where each party had worked hard in their respective marital roles ([91]–[92]). Brown FM then examined the nature of the DFRDB interest, W’s contributions and the effect of a super split. It was found ([96]) to be significant that of his 20 year membership of the fund, H’s contributions financially and through his defence service when not cohabiting with W equated to 40% of the whole, so that 8 years of contributions were his alone. However, it was held to be wrong to approach the matter arithmetically alone ([98]) and unfair to “sheet home” to W her decision to retire prematurely from the Service, which she had done in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: W equated to 40% of the whole, so that 8 years of contributions were his alone. However, it was held to be wrong to approach the matter arithmetically alone ([98]) and unfair to “sheet home” to W her decision to retire prematurely from the Service, which she had done in conjunction with H, and in doing so had forgone her career for his. This amounted to an indirect contribution, as did the “travails of the husband’s frequent postings”. Brown FM concluded ([111]) that the parties’ contributions to the DFRDB super should be regarded as favouring the husband in the ratio of 65/35%. Contributions equality for 60% of the super accrued during marriage Although the parties in P & P (above) had no children, it does not necessarily follow that the wife’s contributions to the DFRDB would have been greater than 35% had she also made homemaker and parent contributions, because in this case significant weight was given to the wife’s significant contributions by her own earnings, and indirectly through forgoing her career for her husband’s and undergoing postings with him. The key to the 65/35 assessment of contributions to the super was that 8 of the 20 years (40%) of the DFRDB’s growth came from contributions made (by his monetary contributions and by his service) either before or after the end of the parties’ relationship. So if the interest had accrued entirely or substantially within the marriage or cohabitation, the wife should have been able to expect a contributions assessment closer to equality, as occurred in L & L (Levick) (above) under “examples of one pool approach” above. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 51 Note – There was no adjustment for s 75(2) factors as W would be receiving a significant splitting order in her favour towards her future needs. The court also considered that despite some disparity of income between H ($60,000) and W ($40,000), W’s income had for some years been steady. There were also no s 75(2) factors associated with children, such as the capital cost of children not covered by periodic child support; or a need to re-enter the workforce or retrain. 2. Post-separation super and real estate assessed separately Not a large super case, but in Ilett [2005] FamCA 432 the Full Court confirmed that the trial judge was entitled to exclude from the asset pool the post-separation superannuations of H and W (of $90,000 and $30,000 respectively) where the parties’ super had been negligible at sepa- ration and to take an asset by asset approach (but erred when doing so by not properly consid- ering W’s contributions to H’s super and to a post-separation house of his that was also left out of the pool or considering whether the overall result, which included the decimation of the main asset pool, was just and equitable). 3. Large disability pension (from post-separation injury) and super in growth phase both assessed separately T & T (Pension Splitting) (above under “example of one pool approach”, as to a “relatively small superannuation”) also involved super that was large. H and W, aged 42 and 39, were married for 10 years and had two children, their property and superannuation valued as follows: • Non-superannuation assets (including W’s small super), net $539,000 • H’s super (Category 1) in payment phase (fortnightly pension) $1,389,000 • H’s super (Category 2) in growth/accumulation phase $419,000 H became eligible for the Category 1 life pension,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: years and had two children, their property and superannuation valued as follows: • Non-superannuation assets (including W’s small super), net $539,000 • H’s super (Category 1) in payment phase (fortnightly pension) $1,389,000 • H’s super (Category 2) in growth/accumulation phase $419,000 H became eligible for the Category 1 life pension, due to permanent incapacity from being injured while on duty as a police officer post-separation. The policy gave him the right to ask the trustee to partially commute the pension into a lump sum at 55 (at age 60 he was able to commute the whole of his pension). Quick look at outcome of this unusual case The Category 2 super began 10 years before the marriage and continued for 3 years post- separation. H’s entitlement to the Category 1 super was triggered by his injury after separation. Contributions were assessed as 85/15 (Category 1) and 60/40 (Category 2) respectively in H’s favour. Section 75(2) factors were assessed in favour of W at $94,000. Note – Although that amount was then said to equate to 4% of everything; or 9.8% of non-super and Category 2; or 17.5% of just the non-super assets, it can be confusing to consider s 75(2) factors as a percentage of anything and also contrary to the approach advocated by the Full Court in such cases as Clauson – see “assess s 75(2) factors” above – being to assess such factors as an amount, not a percentage. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 52 Valuation of the superannuation interest The valuer gave evidence (paras 95–104) that the method prescribed by FL(Super)Reg 42(2) for valuing a pension payable for life as set out in Schedule 4 does not cover a pension in the payment phase that may be commuted to a lump sum at a later date, nor differentiate between value before and after normal retirement age. The valuer therefore assessed the value not in accordance with the regulations but on the assumption that the pension is commuted by H at age 60. He did so by dividing the super into two as follows: • Valuation of super until age 60 (via Schedule 5’s method for valuing fixed term pensions) • Valuation from age 60, assuming that it is taken as a 50% pension and a 50% lump sum The resulting valuations are above. Watts J (para 110) then referred to the intent of the legislation: “In his second reading speech, the Hon. Daryl Williams, Attorney-General said: ‘Valuation is a particularly important issue for defined benefit schemes where there is a vested benefit and an unvested value. The unvested value is generally not accessible until the fund member satisfies certain requirements specified by the fund. The value of an interest in such a plan is typically based upon years of service with an employer and salary levels prior to retire- ment, as well as contributions and investment earnings. As the final benefit is dependent on future events, the full value of the retirement benefit cannot be predicted with certainty at the time of marriage breakdown. The value of an accumulation plan is generally more easily ascertained. For this reason, the bill will provide for different methods of valuing a superannuation interest, depending on the type of interest. The details of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of the retirement benefit cannot be predicted with certainty at the time of marriage breakdown. The value of an accumulation plan is generally more easily ascertained. For this reason, the bill will provide for different methods of valuing a superannuation interest, depending on the type of interest. The details of how the value is to be calculated, including actuarial information, will be set out in the regulations.
