This will ensure that people are aware of the value of the interest they are dealing with…and will also ensure that there can be no dispute about how the value is to be calculated’.” Watts J at para 113 cited the Explanatory Memorandum to the Superannuation Bill 2000 at page 7: “While noting the difference between superannuation and other assets, the fair value of a superannuation interest should, like any other asset of the marriage, be taken into account in the division of assets on breakdown of a marriage especially as superannuation is becoming an increasingly significant asset in many marriages. Considerations of fairness dictate that its full value should be recognised.” Contributions to the Category 1 (disability) super Noting (at paras 137–8) that the amount of the interest is mainly based on H being hurt on duty, the circumstances of the injury and his then salary ($127K), Watts J at paras 141–5 said: “The wife cannot claim any direct contribution following the husband being hurt on duty. As Counsel for the husband pointed out, the parties were not together at the time. The wife has not nursed or attended to the husband in any way as a result of his injuries. The wife has made contributions after separation in the role as parent to the two children of the marriage. The husband is a good father but I find the wife’s role
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: The wife has not nursed or attended to the husband in any way as a result of his injuries. The wife has made contributions after separation in the role as parent to the two children of the marriage. The husband is a good father but I find the wife’s role as parent would have increased to some degree because of the husband’s injuries. More importantly the wife can point to contributions that she made that are relevant to the amount of the husband’s salary at the date of discharge. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 53 … It is clear that the wife during the course of the marriage supported the husband in applying for promotions and relocating herself and Blake on two occasions to facilitate the husband’s promotions. When moving to Goulburn the wife left her employment in Sydney and accepted a redundancy package. The increased responsibilities that the husband had as a result of his promotions placed additional burdens on the wife during the marriage and particularly at a time when the children were very young.” Watts J at [147]–[148] concluded that the wife could point to contributions that were relevant to the amount the husband was receiving by way of a superannuation interest in the payment phase, and assessed her contribution to Category 1 of the husband’s superannuation interest at 15%. Contributions to the Category 2 super Watts J at [149] referred to this statement from an early decision of the Full Court: “In Bailey [1978] FamCA 20 the Full Court said [at [30]]: ‘Contribution by one spouse to superannuation usually means the loss of moneys available for the current support of the family in order to provide security for both spouses on the retirement of the contributing spouse. Loss of the right to share in the superannuation by a divorced non-superannuated spouse is an important financial consequence of the dissolution of the marriage’.” How are super contributions made before and after cohabitation to be treated? The court put that question when it was noted that of H’s 23-year membership of the fund, only 10 years were during the marriage. The court at [154] said this in reply: “There are a number of things to consider: 1. The importance of the imbalance of initial contribution will lessen as the period of cohabitation increases 2. Even though it is neither
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: membership of the fund, only 10 years were during the marriage. The court at [154] said this in reply: “There are a number of things to consider: 1. The importance of the imbalance of initial contribution will lessen as the period of cohabitation increases 2. Even though it is neither practical or desirable to approach cases in a pseudo mathematical way, a calculation of initial contribution does provide a “rough initial point of reference” (Clauson [1995] FamCA 10) 3. There need not be an imbalance of contribution during the cohabitation in favour of one party to offset the initial contribution of the other party. The importance of the initial contribution can be eroded over time in circumstances where there is equality of contribution during the course of the cohabitation (Bremner [1994] FamCA 116) 4. Finally regard needs to be had for what the Full Court said in Pierce [1998] FamCA 74 where the Full Court said that it was “not so much a matter of erosion of contribution but a question of what weight is to be attached, in all the circumstances to the initial contribution.” Watts J then ([155]–[170]) reviewed the courts’ move away since the introduction of Part VIIIB from the “West and Green formula” (divide years in fund during cohabitation by years in fund overall; multiply result by net realisable value of immediate retirement benefit; divide result by 2), adding at [165]: “The Full Court in [Coghlan [2005] FamCA 429] suggested that something of West and Green might still survive, but said that contributions had to be looked at ‘in conjunction with all other contributions’. (…) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 54 One High Court has said that Mrs Trott’s ‘home maker and parenting’ contributions should be taken into account ‘not in a token way, but in a substantial way’ (Mallet [1984] HCA 21 at [4] of Gibbs CJ’s judgment). Another High Court has said that there should not be an ‘over-zealous attention to the ascertainment of the parties’ contributions’ (Mason, Dean JJ in Norbis [1986] HCA 17 at [17] of Mason and Deane JJ’s judgment). Having due regard to what the Full Court said in Bremner and (in) Pierce, I assess the wife’s contributions to the husband’s category 2 superannuation at 40%.” What type of splitting order should be made? Watts J at [182]–[184] said that an order giving a non-member spouse: • under s 90XT(1)(a) an assessed amount would usually be considered for a superannuation interest in the growth phase, and • under s 90XT(1)(b) a percentage when the interest is in the payment phase (adding at [197] that such an order eliminates debate over valuation methodologies) Commutation of pension Watts J (at [204]–[206]) described the future commutation options as follows: • If H did commute part of his pension at age 55, W would receive 15% of that lump sum and 15% of the remaining pension until H was 60 • W should be entitled to a lump sum payment when H reaches 60 should she choose that option • If W makes that choice and gives written notice to H, H will be required to commute his whole pension so as to make 40% of the resulting sum available to W • If W does not choose commutation of H’s super interest to a lump sum when he reaches 60, H can still choose to do so (and W would receive 40% of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: required to commute his whole pension so as to make 40% of the resulting sum available to W • If W does not choose commutation of H’s super interest to a lump sum when he reaches 60, H can still choose to do so (and W would receive 40% of the resulting lump sum) Approach to s 75(2) (or, in de facto claims, s 90SF(3)) factors Watts J (at [207]–[210]) reviewed the post-Part VIIIB case law as to whether property and super should be the subject of the one adjustment for s 75(2) or separate adjustments, citing the major- ity in Coghlan (above) that: “What is relevant is not so much the actual percentage but the quantum (amount) of the adjustment against the background of the contribution based findings (which in T & T (Pension Splitting) were different for each of three pools), the effect of the splitting order, and significantly whether the overall findings result in an order which is just and equitable.” Upon a review of s 75(2) factors on that basis (paras 213–248.2), Watts J made an adjustment for s 75(2) factors in favour of the wife in the sum of $94,000 (equating to 4% of everything; or 9.8% of all except the Category 1 pension; or 17.5% of non-super assets). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 55 Just and equitable That sum plus W’s contribution-based 37.5% of non-super assets gave her $297,000, and super of $208K (15% of Category 1) and $168K (40% of Category 2). The splitting orders for H’s two superannuation interests were described (para 250) as giving W “a nest egg in retirement”. Note – The assessed 15% contribution of the non-injured party to the injury-related pension in this and other cases was applied in Crawford [2012] FMCAfam 1315 at paras 46-57. But in Woodgate [2014] FCCA 2419 at [105]-[126], [153]-[162] and [178]-[179] W received 55% of H’s $1 million “hurt on duty” commuted lump sum super for her homemaker and parent contributions assessed as superior to H’s financial contributions, where the non-super assets were just $57,498. 4. Separate pool where some super accrued before marriage and after separation McCulough [2006] FamCA 840 was a 16-year marriage with two children between H (50 year- old computer consultant on a salary of $96,000) and W (aged 48 and long out of the workforce as a teacher, with an earning capacity of $30,000+). Their non-super assets, mainly the home, were worth $724,000, and their super $137,000 (H) (which began 4 years before separation and continued its growth post-separation) and $6,000 (W). The Full Court applied Coghlan (above) and took the following steps: 1. Identify each pool (including the nature of the super interest) and value each one. 2. Assess contributions to the non-superannuation (tangible) assets. 3. Assess contributions to the superannuation interests of the parties. 4. Identify s 75(2) factors and their impact on any intended splitting order. 5. Assess an adjustment for s 75(2) factors in relation to the non-superannuation assets. 6. Review and, if necessary for a just and equitable outcome for both parties, adjust the mix of tangible assets
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of the parties. 4. Identify s 75(2) factors and their impact on any intended splitting order. 5. Assess an adjustment for s 75(2) factors in relation to the non-superannuation assets. 6. Review and, if necessary for a just and equitable outcome for both parties, adjust the mix of tangible assets and superannuation interests. Outcome of the above steps 1. Non-super pool $724,000; and super interests $137,000 (H) and $6,000 (W) ([11] and [66]). 2. Contributions to non-super assessed at 55/45 (H/W) to reflect H’s initial financial contributions (60%) less W’s post-separation contributions (5%) ([12] and [67]). 3. Contributions to super also 55/45 “notionally at this stage” (i.e. subject to the outcome of 4 and 6 below) having regard to “the time at which the major (H’s) interest commenced (during the marriage)” (and factoring in W’s small super) ([69]). 4. Section 75(2) factors were as assessed by the trial judge (the parties’ ages; H’s greater earning capacity and superannuation; W’s care of two children for six more years that disadvantages her from re-entering the workforce and impairs her earning capacity and investment opportun- ities) ([14]-[9], [70]). Her need for money to buy a modest home for herself and the children, and her lesser capacity to borrow for that purpose, meant that she “needs to receive most of the ‘tangible assets’…(Because) the only asset of substance remaining is superannuation… it is appropriate for the husband to retain most or all of his superannuation…(and it is also) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 56 appropriate for there to be a splitting order in the wife’s favour of the husband’s superannuation of 20%”. ([71]-[4]). 5. The future financial circumstances of the parties were “revisited” ([75]-[7]) where the Court said: “If one addresses the size of the property pool and thinks in terms of 5 per cent lots, each represents just over $36,000. The major purpose of an adjustment in this case is to reflect the disparity in earning capacities, for a period reasonable in the circumstances. In our view, an appropriate adjustment in favour of the wife for s 75(2) factors is 22.5 per cent. This we consider likely to put the wife in the position of being able to obtain a modest home, but does not ignore the consequence to the husband in the nature of assets that he will retain.” 6. The outcome – that W receive 67.5% (45% + 22.5%) of the tangible assets, a split of H’s super interest of 20%, and retain her super ($6K); and H 32.5% of the tangible assets and 80% of his super – was impliedly confirmed as being just and equitable by the Court’s references to “a just and equitable mix” of tangible assets and superannuation throughout its judgment (at [26], [28], [31], [37], [39], [70], [73]-[4]). In Palmer [2012] FamCAFC 159 at [28], [67] and [75]-[77] the Full Court found the mother to be entitled to half the difference between the father’s super as at separation and its value as at cohabi- tation (there being no valuation before Brewster FM as at the date of the hearing, as there should have been). The Full Court ([45] and [77]) made up for that court’s failure to assess post-separation contributions in respect of the father’s super by making no adjustments to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: as at cohabi- tation (there being no valuation before Brewster FM as at the date of the hearing, as there should have been). The Full Court ([45] and [77]) made up for that court’s failure to assess post-separation contributions in respect of the father’s super by making no adjustments to her own super. 5. Super with “unusual characteristics” assessed separately from non-super In Guthrie & Rushton [2009] FamCA 1144 the parties’ various accumulation super interests totalling $151,000 in value were included in a $2.6m asset pool but the husband’s pension interest (notion- ally valued at $1.2m) was not, contributions to that interest being assessed separately. Murphy J said at [38] that adopting a global approach would produce “a distortive effect”. His Honour (who assessed the wife’s contributions to the first pool as 42.5% and to the pension as 30% granted as a splitting order to that effect) said at [148]: “…the assessment of contributions needs…to take account of the fact that the ‘value’ grows significantly as time progresses towards its earliest entitlement and grows during a period, here, after the parties have separated and the nature of their contributions changes accordingly.” On the question of s 75(2) factors, His Honour at [165] said: “A question arises as to whether any s 75(2) adjustment should be made to the overall ‘pool’, including superannuation interests, or whether an adjustment should be made to each ‘pool’… Section 79 points, in my view, to the s 75(2) evaluation required by s 79(4)(e) to be conducted in respect of the whole of the property and superannuation interests and not in respect of each ‘pool’”. The court did not assess s 75(2) factors as a percentage but at $200,000 in the wife’s favour. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PPRROOPPEERRTTYY 7 7– –5 6lvAii Provisions for de factos in WA As of 28 September 2022, de factos in WA can split superannuation via Part VIIIC of the FLA. The Part VIIIC provisions largely mirror the Part VIIIB provisions, save that the former specifically empowers the Family Court of Western Australia and Magistrates Court of Western Australia to split and flag super. Those Courts are also prevented from making an order inconsistent with a superannuation agreement. The geographical requirements are at s 90YZB - Either party must be resident in WA when the application is made. Further, both parties must have resided in WA for a third of the relationship, or significant contributions must have been made in WA. With reference to our precedents, the below ready reckoner is provided for the drafting of orders or agreements: Part VIIIC Part VIIIB (WA de factos) Function s 90XHA s 90YK Ability to include super splitting in a de facto financial agreement s 90XI s 90YM Operative time for a split s 90XJ(1)(c)(i) s 90YN(1)(c)(i) Super split by base amount (agreement) s 90XJ(1)(c)(ii) s 90YN(1)(c)(ii) Super split by formula (agreement) s 90XJ(1)(c)(iii) s 90YN(1)(c)(iii) Super split by percentage (agreement) s 90XL s 90YP Flagging by way of agreement s 90XO s 90YT Limitation of Court’s property adjustment power if there is a superannuation agreement s 90XP s 90YU Separation declarations s 90XT(1)(a) s 90YY(1)(a) Super split by base amount (order) s 90XT(1)(b) s 90YY(1)(b) Super split by percentage (order) s 90XT(1)(c) s 90YY(1)(c) Super split for percentage only interests (order) s 90XT(2) s 90YY(2) Requirement of the Court to make a finding as to the value of the interest being split. s 90XT(4) s 90YY(5) Allocation of base amount to non-member spouse that is less that the value of the interest (order)
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 90YY(1)(c) Super split for percentage only interests (order) s 90XT(2) s 90YY(2) Requirement of the Court to make a finding as to the value of the interest being split. s 90XT(4) s 90YY(5) Allocation of base amount to non-member spouse that is less that the value of the interest (order) s 90XU(1) s 90YZ Flagging orders s 90XZB s 90YZR Trustee to provide information s 90XZD s 90YZT Orders binding on trustee s 90XZJ s 90YZY Request to Commissioner of Taxation to provide superannuation information Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 57 WHAT ORDERS SHOULD BE MADE FOR A JUST AND EQUITABLE OUTCOME? The fourth step This is your final assessment stage once the asset pool has been identified, contributions and s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3)) factors assessed – to consider whether the result of those assessments would in all the circumstances be “just and equitable” as required by s 79(2) (s 90SM(3) in de facto claims). In Bonnaci [2012] FamCAFC 15 the Full Court said at [61]: “ … [The] Full Court has said on a number of occasions [that] the so-called fourth step is not an oppor- tunity to make a further adjustment; it is an opportunity for the [court] to determine finally how, in reality, a just and equitable order might be achieved based on the circumstances of the case before [it].” In Tomasetti [2000] FamCA 314 at [113]-[114], when reviewing an unjust “mathematical” outcome reached by adding percentages for a series of factors, the Full Court said: “In this context, the whole is not necessarily the sum of its component parts, and at the very least one has to stand back, at the end, and look at the final result, to ensure that the cumulative process has not produced a manifestly unjust result.” The court may adjust its assessment of steps 2 and 3 because of its likely impact on a party’s financial position (Full Court in Russell [1999] FamCA 1875 at [77]-[80]) and, where a split of super is available, may adjust the mix of assets each party is to receive. Bryant CJ in C & B [2005] FamCA 94 at [108]-[111] held it was just and equitable for both parties for W to be allowed to pay out H by way of a smaller cash sum (with no alteration of the parties’
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: mix of assets each party is to receive. Bryant CJ in C & B [2005] FamCA 94 at [108]-[111] held it was just and equitable for both parties for W to be allowed to pay out H by way of a smaller cash sum (with no alteration of the parties’ superan- nuation interests) instead of a much larger sum with an adjustment of superannuation. See also L & L (Levick) [2003] FamCA 40 at [60]-[70] where the court allowed the wife to forgo 60% of her superan- nuation outcome in exchange for a discounted cash sum. Moore J, after considering the wife’s need to rehouse and to be able to provide adequately for herself from investment funds, said that “…on that scenario things could end up being a bit tight, leaving her with little left over as a buffer for contingen- cies and independent living”. Moore J, upon adding that “the outcome must be just and equitable overall, not just for her”, went on to consider the husband’s situation and find the adjusted orders to be just and equitable for both par- ties. Since the introduction of Part VIIIB (superannuation interests), s 79(2) is commonly referred to as addressing a proposed order’s “mix” of tangible assets and superannuation interests to be retained by each party: e.g. McCulough [2006] FamCA 840 where the Full Court at [26] asked “what would consti- tute a just and equitable ‘mix’ of asset types for each party”. An example of an adjustment of payment terms to meet the needs of both parties in a farming case is Casper [2009] FamCA 989 where Fowler J ordered the wife’s property settlement to be payable in part within 30 days to enable her to complete the purchase of another property, the balance being payable in 12 months with
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to meet the needs of both parties in a farming case is Casper [2009] FamCA 989 where Fowler J ordered the wife’s property settlement to be payable in part within 30 days to enable her to complete the purchase of another property, the balance being payable in 12 months with interest enabling the husband to raise the rest of the settlement and retain the farm. In Bateman & Gaffney [2010] FMCAfam 103 at [30]-[33] Phipps FM, where both parties wanted to refinance and retain the home (one proposal involving the party’s mother selling her home and investing its proceeds too), held that “the just and equitable way to deal with the…home is to adopt the proposal with the more certainty”. Note – Another option is an auction at which both parties may bid. It may not be just and equitable to make any property order: Bevan [2014] FamCAFC 19 at [40]-[43], [80]-[86]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 58 PROPERTY SETTLEMENT CALCULATION You will arrive at your client’s entitlement as a percentage of the net asset pool by applying the four steps as set out above. The package of assets, debt liability and super you seek on their behalf will equal that entitlement. Any spousal maintenance should be added to the claim. Using this asset pool again, here are examples of your approach to a single pool and to separate pools. Again, delete the centre column below in practice. POOL A – NON-SUPER AND “RELATIONSHIP” SUPER IN ONE POOL POOL A – NON-SUPER AND SUPER TO BE INCLUDED (CONTINUED) ITEM ASSET TYPE VALUE ($) LIABILITIES VALUE ($) 1 FAMILY AVENUE HOME 750,000 MORTGAGE – 4 SMITH STREET 450,000 BLOCK OF LAND, EUPHORIA OTHER REAL ESTATE 50,000 SECOND MORTGAGE – W’S PARENTS 70,000 4 SMITH STREET INVESTMENT PROPERTY 450,000 H’S AGC CAR LOAN 12,000 FLIPPER’S BUSINESS 50,000 CGT ON SALE ON 4 SMITH STREET 38,000 BHP SHARES (W) SHARES 20,000 H’S CREDIT CARD 10,000 RIO TINTO (H) SHARES 15,000 W’S BANKCARD 10,000 CBA (W) BANK ACCOUNTS 8,000 TOTAL LIABILITIES 590,000 NAB (H) BANK ACCOUNTS 12,000 SUB TOTAL 900,000 H’S HOLDEN MOTOR VEHICLES 35,000 W’S HYUNDAI MOTOR VEHICLES 30,000 POOL B – OTHER SUPERANNUATION BOAT OTHER 10,000 H’S/W’S (SPECIFY) SUPER INTEREST (E.G. SIGNIFICANTLY ACCURUED OUTSIDE MARRIAGE 450,000 H’S BEQUEST FROM AUNT OTHER 30,000 W’S SUPER SUPER <$5K (CANNOT BE SPLIT) 5,000 H’S SUPER ADD OTHER SUPER BY CONSENT, OR WHERE 25,000 APPROPRIATE TO INCLUDE IT. E.G. ACQUIRED AND GREW DURING MARRIAGE TOTAL ASSETS 1,490,000 Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 60 One asset pool or separate pools? Yours will usually be the one pool approach where a super interest is involved because all or most of super usually comes from contributions made during the relationship. Put your client’s super in a separate pool if it significantly accrued outside the relationship. In fact, why stop there? Consider also putting non-super assets such as pre-relationship or post-separation financial contributions into a separate pool, and argue for equal treatment. The examples of distribution below – as to who gets what and how – cover both the one pool and the separate pools approach. Summary of the four steps Step 1 is for you to draw up the table above, to identify and value the net asset pool (or pools). Step 2 is when you assess contributions, taking a global approach to them. Contributions will usually be equal, unless there has been a significant (usually financial) contribution by one party. Step 3 is your assessment of s 75(2) (in de facto claims, s 90SM(3)) factors. How to approach s 75(2) (or s 90SM(3)) A better guide for assessing s 75(2) factors than using case law (or getting confused about whether such factors should be a percentage of just non-super or the non-super and super combined) is to follow the judicially approved path of estimating the monetary value (the amount) of each client’s own s 75(2) factors instead of thinking of them in terms of a percentage of anything (Full Court in Clauson under “assess s 75(2) factors” above). The percentage – which is only a reference point – will come from what your monetary valuation of those factors represents as a proportion of the pool. (In T & T (Pension Splitting) above, Watts J’s monetary assessment of s 75(2) was
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: in Clauson under “assess s 75(2) factors” above). The percentage – which is only a reference point – will come from what your monetary valuation of those factors represents as a proportion of the pool. (In T & T (Pension Splitting) above, Watts J’s monetary assessment of s 75(2) was said to represent different percentages of three separate pools.) Step 4 is any proposed adjustment of your client’s entitlement for a just and equitable outcome. The mix of super and non-super It is at this stage that the courts will consider the mix of non-super and super to be divided between the parties. For example, a wife’s super entitlement as calculated may be reduced (and the husband’s increased) to allow the wife to receive more cash (and the husband less), enabling the wife to re-house herself and the children. See C & B above (Bryant CJ) under “examples of one pool approach” and L & L (Levick) (Moore J). Also McCulough under “examples of separate pools approach”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 61 Now assume that each party will retain the following assets (from single pool) – WIFE LAND $50,000 BHP $20,000 CBA $8,000 HYUNDAI $30,000 W’S SUPER $5,000 TOTAL $113,000 HUSBAND BUSINESS $50,000 RIO TINTO $15,000 NAB $12,000 HOLDEN $35,000 BOAT $10,000 H’S LEGACY $30,000 H’S SUPER $25,000 TOTAL $177,000 One pool approach Contributions Remember our “guide to assessing contributions” and our table of comparative court assessments under “assess contributions” above. Assume here that contributions are assessed 60/40 in favour of H due to his significant initial financial contributions. The result of that assessment is: H $900,000 x 60% $540,000 W $900,000 x 40% $360,000 Section 75(2) (or s 90SM(3)) factors Assume these are in favour of W – her need for rehousing; the capital cost of children not covered by periodic child support; and disparity of earning capacity with that of H, assessed at $225,000. This equates to $900,000 x 25%. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 62 Entitlement W (40 + 25) 65% x $900,000 $585,000 H (60 – 25) 35% x $900,000 $315,000 Assume • The home and investment property are to be sold, to pay off debt • W is to keep the Euphoria land to build on; and H is to keep the business and boat • Each is to retain the other assets in their name (see previous page) Division of property Wife W’s entitlement (above) $585,000 comprising: Value of assets retained by W $113,000 Payable to W from sale proceeds $472,000 Husband H’s entitlement (above) $315,000 comprising: Value of assets retained by H $177,000 Payable to H from sale proceeds $138,000 (From the sale proceeds the mortgages and CGT are paid out, the parties being responsible for their own debts – car loan and credit card (H) and bankcard (W). The orders made (see “precedents” below under “final orders sought”) would then provide for the sale of assets, transfers and other orders for retained property, the parties’ share of sale proceeds and an indemnity for their respective debts.) Is the outcome just and equitable? Yes. More cash to W for her greater immediate needs. H benefits from greater earning capacity. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 63 Separate pools approach Contributions The courts are usually assessing contributions to non-super and super separately where significant contributions were made by one party before the relationship and/or after separation. Note – As the courts refine their approach to superannuation, there is scope for your counsel to argue for consistent treatment to be given to pre-relationship contributions to non-super assets, which are often deemed to have been eroded over the course of a medium to long relationship. Assume for this example that Pool A contributions were assessed as equal (50/50) (as per Brown FM in P & P); and that as 40% of Pool B contributions by H were extra-marital, Pool B contributions (after an allowance for W’s indirect contributions to H’s career) were assessed as favouring H 65/35. The result of this contributions assessment is: H $900,000 (Pool A) x 50% $450,000 450,000 (Pool B) x 65% current value = $292,500 W $900,000 (Pool A) x 50% $450,000 450,000 (Pool B) x 35% current value = $157,500 Section 75(2) (or s 90SM(3)) If we stay with the P & P analogy, using just the size of the respective pools, disregarding the particular assets to be retained by each party and the assumption of W in a weaker financial position, W may be assessed as requiring no further adjustment for s 75(2) in our example, having regard to her equal earn- ing power, the absence of need arising from the care of children, and her capacity to boost her eventual Pool B interest through some serious investment. Entitlement The parties’ entitlement will therefore remain as set out above, with no adjustment. Their respective entitlements to Pool A ($450,000) will be minus the value of any retained assets, and a splitting order will take care of the parties’
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: boost her eventual Pool B interest through some serious investment. Entitlement The parties’ entitlement will therefore remain as set out above, with no adjustment. Their respective entitlements to Pool A ($450,000) will be minus the value of any retained assets, and a splitting order will take care of the parties’ interests in Pool B. Is the outcome just and equitable? Yes. It has been a fair division of assets that were acquired and which grew during the relationship. W has been able to leave the marriage without financial disadvantage, and H was given due recogni- tion of the fact that a large proportion of Pool B came about by his own efforts prior to the marriage. What to file? For a precedent of the property order to be sought and sample affidavit in support, see “final orders sought” and “affidavits” under “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 64 SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS Section 77A(1) (and s 90SH for de facto claims) says that where an order requires payment of a lump sum or the transfer of property, all or part of which is to provide for the maintenance of a party, the order must: • state that it is an order to which this section applies; and • specify the amount or value of the maintenance provision. A property settlement order containing but not specifying a maintenance component shall be taken not to be for the maintenance of a party: see subsection (2). Kay J in Doig [1999] FamCA 1363 at [23] referred to s 77A as being “designed to protect the revenue”, by requiring those receiving maintenance by way of a capital payment to be as accountable for Centrelink’s income-testing of pensions as those receiving maintenance income. The Court there dismissed the husband’s claim that the trial judge had erred by specifying a portion of the wife’s property settlement as a s 77A maintenance provision. Kay J on behalf of the Full Court held that although the specification may have been incorrect (the trial judge having held that the wife had no maintenance claim on top of her property settlement), it did not prejudice either party. Note – You would only use a s 77A clause in your order if you couldn’t avoid an order for lump sum maintenance (usually when one party is in receipt of a government pension, which makes contracting out of maintenance near impossible). As to the amount to specify in such a case, it needs to be a sum that would neutralise any future maintenance claim for as long as possible. You would otherwise avoid such a clause because it enlivens s 83 by
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: pension, which makes contracting out of maintenance near impossible). As to the amount to specify in such a case, it needs to be a sum that would neutralise any future maintenance claim for as long as possible. You would otherwise avoid such a clause because it enlivens s 83 by which the order can be varied in the future. In other words, you create the risk of future variation by dealing with spousal maintenance in your property order. For this reason, an agreement as to spousal maintenance is usually best documented in a financial agreement. It carries less risk of future variation and can act as a release of spousal maintenance (our precedent for which is at page 9–39). What to file? See “property order” in “precedents” below. You will find a s 77A clause included. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 65 CGT, INCOME TAX, GST AND STAMP DUTY Property settlements and tax A most useful summary of tax issues, with case study examples, both covering the above and issues such as Division 7A, losses and the tax treatment of companies, trusts and partnerships, is contained in a paper by Damian O’Connor of Gadens Brisbane, published when special coun- sel at Hopgood Ganim (“Property settlements and tax”). It is available at our online Members’ Archive (“useful papers”). Capital gains tax General principles for the proper approach to the effect of potential CGT payable upon the sale of an income-earning (“investment”) property were stated by the Full Court in Rosati [1998] FamCA 38 at [6.36] as follows: “(1) Whether the incidence of Capital Gains Tax should be taken into account in valuing a particular asset varies according to the circumstances of the case, including the method of valuation applied to the particular asset, the likelihood or otherwise of that asset being realised in the foreseeable future, the circumstances of its acquisition and the evidence of the parties as to their intentions in relation to that asset. (2) If the Court orders the sale of an asset, or is satisfied that a sale of it is inevitable, or would probably occur in the near future, or if the asset is one which was acquired solely as an investment and with a view to its ultimate sale for profit, then, generally, allowance should be made for any Capital Gains Tax payable upon such a sale in determining the value of that asset for the purpose of the proceedings. (3) If none of the circumstances referred to in (2) applies to a particular asset, but the Court is satisfied that there is a significant risk that the asset will have to be
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: upon such a sale in determining the value of that asset for the purpose of the proceedings. (3) If none of the circumstances referred to in (2) applies to a particular asset, but the Court is satisfied that there is a significant risk that the asset will have to be sold in the short to mid term, then the Court, whilst not making allowance for the Capital Gains Tax payable on such a sale in determining the value of the asset, may take that risk into account as a relevant s 75(2) factor, the weight to be attributed to that factor varying according to the degree of the risk and the length of the period within which the sale may occur. (4) There may be special circumstances in a particular case which, despite the absence of any certainty or even likelihood of a sale of an asset in the foreseeable future, make it appropriate to take the incidence of Capital Gains Tax into account in valuing that asset. In such a case, it may be appropriate to take the Capital Gains Tax into account at its full rate, or at some discounted rate, having regard to the degree of risk of a sale occurring and/or the length of time which is likely to elapse before that occurs.” In Blake [2007] FamCA 10, the Full Court said (at [24]) that the above were “no more than…guidelines for the exercise of the property settlement jurisdiction under s 79…and must be applied as the justice and equity of (each) case requires”. Mr Blake, a developer, was claiming a deduction from the asset pool for CGT on the former home. Having originally acquired it with ultimate profit in mind, he was content to use it for its rental income and did not intend selling
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: the justice and equity of (each) case requires”. Mr Blake, a developer, was claiming a deduction from the asset pool for CGT on the former home. Having originally acquired it with ultimate profit in mind, he was content to use it for its rental income and did not intend selling it in the foreseeable future. The Full Court held that CGT should not be deducted, Finn J saying ([25]) that it was not “just and equitable for the wife to have to share the… potential future liability (for CGT)”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 66 Key features of CGT • It taxes capital gain upon disposal of assets acquired on or after 20/9/85 • Governed by Division 104 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (ITAA) • Capital losses can be offset against capital gains • A full list of CGT events (disposals) is set out at s 104.5 ITAA • “Asset” is any property or legal or equitable right: s 108.5 • Includes goodwill of a business and an interest in a partnership: s 108.5 • Includes a building post-CGT on land acquired pre-CGT (20/9/85): s 108.55 • CGT exemptions include pre-CGT assets, the home, cars, motor cycles, collectables, personal use assets, trading stock, bank accounts, life policies, superannuation funds (see from s 118.1) • Main residence exemption available to each spouse if separated: s 118.170 • Capital gain = capital proceeds – cost base of asset: s 104.5 • Capital loss = reduced cost base of asset – capital proceeds: s 104.5 • Cost base includes price paid for asset, incidental and capital costs: s 110.25 • Reduced cost base is the same less deductible amounts: s 110.55 • 50% discount if asset held for 12 months before disposal: s 102.3 • Discount available to individuals and trustees, but not companies • Small business concession: s 328.110 • Roll-over relief upon marriage breakdown: ss 126.5 and 126.15 (see below) Roll-over relief Roll-over relief is available where an asset is transferred under a property order (Part VIII Family Law Act) or a financial agreement (Part VIIIA): • between spouses (s 126.5 ITAA) • from a trustee or company to a spouse (s 126.15) “Roll-over relief” means the deferral of CGT liability until the transferee eventually disposes of the asset. The transferee is taken to have acquired the asset when
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: Act) or a financial agreement (Part VIIIA): • between spouses (s 126.5 ITAA) • from a trustee or company to a spouse (s 126.15) “Roll-over relief” means the deferral of CGT liability until the transferee eventually disposes of the asset. The transferee is taken to have acquired the asset when the transferor did, so the transferee’s eventual disposal of the asset: • will be CGT-free if the transferor had acquired it pre-CGT (pre-20/9/85): s 126.5(6) • will attract CGT if it had been acquired by the transferor post-CGT (on or after 20/9/85), the calculation of which will be based on the transferor’s cost base at the time of transfer to the transferee plus incidental costs: s 126.5(5) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 67 Role of the parties’ accountant When your asset pool involves an income-earning property, a business, loan accounts, a company or trust, CGT and other tax issues such as income tax or GST may apply. Protect yourself and your client in those cases by making contact with the parties’ accountant – or, if necessary, a specialist forensic accountant – for some written advice. Income tax Division 7A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (known as “Division 7A”) treats (deems) amounts paid or lent or debts forgiven by a private company to a shareholder or shareholder’s associate as dividends: s 109B. These are “deemed dividends”. “Associate” includes a shareholder’s spouse: s 318 This treatment makes the amounts assessable income of the shareholder or associate (under s 44). Exceptions include debt repayment (s 109J); inter-company payments and loans (s 109K); and certain business loans (ss 109L–R). Note – Again, seek expert tax advice as to the tax implications of such transactions. The forensic accountants you employ to value or investigate the company and its business should be asked to include such advice in their report (and any other tax advice relevant to the post-settlement tax liability of each party). Goods and services tax GST is governed by A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 (known as “the GST Act”). GST Ruling 2003/6 is said (at [1]) to “explain” the GST consequences of a transfer to a spouse of an enterprise asset of the spouses or either of them or a related entity registered or required to be registered for GST as a result of a property distribution under the Family Law Act. “Enterprise asset” is defined (at [12]) as including trading stock, plant, office equipment, motor vehicles and real property. GST appears not to be
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: either of them or a related entity registered or required to be registered for GST as a result of a property distribution under the Family Law Act. “Enterprise asset” is defined (at [12]) as including trading stock, plant, office equipment, motor vehicles and real property. GST appears not to be payable in such cases, although an adjustment of a transferor’s previously claimed input tax credit may be necessary. Again, defer to your client’s (or your own forensic) tax adviser. There are 86 paragraphs of “explanation” which are best left to an expert. The Ruling (GST Ruling 2003/6) is available from our website under this chapter. The necessity of proof In Manichaeus [2010] FamCA 397 Faulks DCJ held at [68] as to the CGT and GST sought to be included by the husband as liabilities that he had “failed adequately to prove what the liabilities are likely to be”. In disallowing them, His Honour at [72] said that it was “impossible in the circumstances to make any accurate prediction where the burden of any future tax imposed may fall [except that] each of the parties will bear some of that burden”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 68 Stamp duty Section 90 of the Family Law Act exempts from “any duty or charge” under any State or Territory law transfers and other instruments executed “for the purposes of, or in accordance with” a property or spousal maintenance order. This now includes Part VIIIAB orders (for de facto partners): s 90WA. Financial agreements, transfers and other instruments under them, are also exempt: ss 90L and 90WA Each State and Territory OSR will have its own administrative form and process for administering the duty and considering the grounds of exemption. In summary, stamp duty exemption is available: • New South Wales under s 68 Duties Act 1997, on a transfer of “matrimonial property” (property of spouses or either of them) to a party or child (and, from 11/4/12, in specie roll-outs between super trustees for spouses or de factos) in accordance with an FLA order or financial agreement. The exemption is thus not limited to the home. For an exemption claim gone wrong, see Agrinova Pty Ltd v Chief Commissioner of State Revenue [2024] NSWCATAD 170 where duty was assessed on land transferred pursuant to FLA orders from “various entities” to a company. To keep up to date with revenue rulings, see www.revenue.nsw.gov.au • Victoria under s 44 Duties Act 2000, on a transfer solely because of marriage or domestic relationship breakdown (supported by a Form 9A stat dec), from a spouse (or partner) (or trustee of a trust of which the spouses or either of them are beneficiaries) to a spouse or dependent child (or trustee of a trust if a spouse or dependent child are the only beneficiaries) provided that no other person is to take an interest. Again, not limited to the home but production of the order identifying the other property
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: of them are beneficiaries) to a spouse or dependent child (or trustee of a trust if a spouse or dependent child are the only beneficiaries) provided that no other person is to take an interest. Again, not limited to the home but production of the order identifying the other property for which exemption is sought is likely to be required. Provided that if a company is the transferor the dutiable value of the transfer does not exceed the value of the spouses’ interest in the company, and that as a result of the transfer, the value of the spouses’ interest in the company is reduced by the same amount as the dutiable value of the property transferred: s 44(3) Their website is www.sro.vic.gov.au • South Australia under ss 71CA and CB of the Stamp Duties Act 1923, on a transfer between spouses or to a spouse from the trustee of a superannuation fund under a FLA order, splitting order or financial agreement of the home (unless it forms part of industrial or commercial premises) and motor vehicle (i.e. no other property of the parties). Their website www.revenuesa.sa.gov.au • Queensland under s 424 of the Duties Act 2001, on a “transaction that gives effect to a matrimonial instrument”. On 4 March 2009, OSR introduced Duties Online by which transfers under an order or finan- cial agreement under FLA are self-assessable (if the lawyer is validly registered with OSR for Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 69 self-assessment, the transfer was not signed in escrow; and, if a financial agreement, it complies with the Act, contains a separation declaration and has certificates of independent legal advice) and exempt from duty. A transfer pursuant to an FLA order or financial agreement is exempt from stamp duty regardless of the parties to the transfer, although the transferee should be identified in the order or agreement. In the case of an agreement, a separation declaration is also required. Refer to www.qld.gov.au/housing/buying-owning-home/advice-buying-home/transfer-duty • Tasmania in accordance with s 56 of the Duties Act 2001, on a transfer of matrimonial property (as defined above) under an FLA order or financial agreement to a spouse or child under 18. Their website: www.sro.tas.gov.au • Australian Capital Territory in accordance with s 74B of the Duties Act 1999, on a transfer under an FLA order (or financial agreement if it is to a spouse or child under 18 or person in trust for such a child). Their website: www.revenue.act.gov.au • Northern Territory under s 91(1) of the Stamp Duty Act, on a transfer of property between spouses or de facto partners under an FLA order or financial agreement. Their website: www.treasury.nt.gov.au • Western Australia Under s 131 of the Duties Act 2008 nominal duty ($20) is payable on a transfer of property of the parties under an FLA or FCA order (or under a financial or splitting agreement under the FLA if the transfer is to a party, child or trustee of child or super fund) or a financial agreement under FCA if the de facto relationship has ended and the transfer is to a party, child or child’s trustee. Production of the order or agreement is likely to be required. Note – For an exemption for transfers between de factos
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: of child or super fund) or a financial agreement under FCA if the de facto relationship has ended and the transfer is to a party, child or child’s trustee. Production of the order or agreement is likely to be required. Note – For an exemption for transfers between de factos of interstate property, check with a local settlement agent whether a transfer under an FCA order or agreement would be accepted or whether a separation agreement under their de facto property law should be prepared for that transfer. Their website: www.finance.wa.gov.au Note – These links are all available on these pages of our eBook. Exemption for transfers under financial agreements Qld did, but no longer do, require de facto relationships to be of two years’ duration for stamp duty relief to apply to a transfer under a Part VIIIAB financial agreement so for shorter relationships check your local stamp duty legislation to ensure that no such proviso applies in your State or Territory. If a “two year minimum” does apply, a consent order would be your better option. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SPECIFY SPOUSAL MAINTENANCE COMPONENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 70 ADJOURNMENT OF PROPERTY PROCEEDINGS This is s 79(5) (or, for de facto claims, s 90SM(5) or in WA s 205ZG(5) FCA). A court may, if requested by either party, adjourn the proceedings if it is of the opinion: a) that there is likely to be a significant change in the financial circumstances of the parties or either of them and that, having regard to when that change is likely to occur, it is reasonable to adjourn; and b) that an order made at that time is more likely to do justice than an order made immediately. In forming an opinion as to the likelihood of a significant change in financial circumstances ahead, the court may have regard to any such change that may occur under a superannuation scheme, or discretionary trust (where its trustee distributes trust property to a party), or by other means: s 79(7) A matter was adjourned for 2½ years to allow for the vesting of a husband’s remainder interest in a trust in Grace [1997] FamCA 59. BAR & JMR (No. 2) [2005] FamCA 386 involved a six-year adjournment in relation to H’s superannua- tion interest, although Part VIIIB (splitting orders) put an end to adjournments on the basis of unrealisable superannuation. In Pratt [2012] FamCAFC 81 at [40]-[45] the Full Court upheld the husband’s appeal against Bell J’s three year adjournment of the final hearing, saying that the evidence did not support his Honour’s find- ing that there was a likelihood of a “significant” improvement in the value of two farms (nor one that would exceed the level of the parties’ debt). Interim property orders Interim orders may be made before any adjournment where appropriate: s 79(6) The Full Court said in Harris [1993] FamCA 49 at [43]: “( …
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: likelihood of a “significant” improvement in the value of two farms (nor one that would exceed the level of the parties’ debt). Interim property orders Interim orders may be made before any adjournment where appropriate: s 79(6) The Full Court said in Harris [1993] FamCA 49 at [43]: “( … ) Of necessity it is likely to be a somewhat imprecise exercise. Consequently, it must be exer- cised conservatively and the Judge must be satisfied that the remaining property will be adequate to meet the legitimate expectations of both parties at the final hearing, or that the order which is contemplated is capable of being reversed or adjusted if it is subsequently considered necessary to do so.” See “partial property settlements” above. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 71 LEAVE TO EXTEND TIME FOR ISSUING PROPERTY (OR MAINTENANCE) PROCEEDINGS The deadline for a property (or spousal maintenance) application is 12 months after a divorce order has taken effect (s 44(3)) or 2 years after the end of a de facto relationship (s 44(5)) or 12 months after a BFA is set aside (s 44(3B) or (5)), except by leave or consent. As to “consent”, see s 44(3AA) or (5A). This time limit does not apply to applications to set aside a property order under s 79A or s 90SN or to vary, revive, suspend or discharge a maintenance order under s 83 or s 90SI. Under s 44(4) (or s 44(6) for de facto claims), the court shall not grant leave unless it is satisfied: • that hardship would be caused to a party or a child if leave were not granted; or • in the case of maintenance, that at the time of the deadline for issuing proceedings the applicant’s circumstances were such that she/he would have been unable to support herself/himself without an income tested pension, allowance or benefit: s 44(4) Note – An application for leave to proceed out of time under s 44(3) cannot be continued after the death of the respondent: see Slater [1985] FamCA 45. Hardship The Full Court held in Whitford [1979] FamCA 3 at [28] that if the Court is satisfied as to hardship, a “second question arises, that is whether in the exercise of its discretion the Court should grant or refuse leave to institute proceedings”. May and Ainslie-Wallace JJ in Sharp [2011] FamCAFC 150 at [23] cited Whitford in which it was said that in the exercise of discretion due weight should be given to the intention of ss 44(3) and s 81 and “such
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the Court should grant or refuse leave to institute proceedings”. May and Ainslie-Wallace JJ in Sharp [2011] FamCAFC 150 at [23] cited Whitford in which it was said that in the exercise of discretion due weight should be given to the intention of ss 44(3) and s 81 and “such matters as the length of [and reasons for] the delay … , prejudice occa- sioned to the respondent by reason of the delay, … strength … of the applicant’s case, and the degree of … hardship which would be suffered unless leave were granted”. The majority in Sharp said ([17]-[18]) that it “is well accepted that hardship … is more than the loss of a right to commence proceedings … the applicant must have a prima facie claim worth pursuing”. (This would not include an uncommercial claim: Gadzen & Simkin [2018] FamCAFC 218 at [36]-[44]. A prima facie case does not mean a “real probability of success”: Skelton & Lindop [2022] FedCFamC1A 47 at [21].) Young J added at [128] that the Full Court in Whitford held that “‘hardship’” in s 44(4) is “akin to … hardness, severity, privation, that which is hard to bear or a substantial detriment”. The Full Court in Sharp ([15] and [131]) cited Whitford at [41] “the power [to grant leave] should be exercised liberally in order to avoid hardship ... in a manner which would not render [the time limit] nugatory”. The exercise of discretion The Full Court in Sharp (above) discussed delay (see below) at [75]-[77] and [149]-[151]; prejudice to respondent at [95]-[97] and [153]-[154]; and merits of applicant’s claim at [132]-[135] and [148]. Prejudice to respondent Nygh J in Frost & Nicholson [1981] FamCA 45 at [18] said that “prejudice” included evidence that “a party is faced with an action which he
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: below) at [75]-[77] and [149]-[151]; prejudice to respondent at [95]-[97] and [153]-[154]; and merits of applicant’s claim at [132]-[135] and [148]. Prejudice to respondent Nygh J in Frost & Nicholson [1981] FamCA 45 at [18] said that “prejudice” included evidence that “a party is faced with an action which he or she had no reason to expect or had been led to believe would not be brought”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 72 Delay The Full Court in Whitford (above) observed at [46]: “Until February 1978, the husband had continued to support the wife and the children at the standard at which the parties had lived for some years during cohabitation, and there was no good reason why proceedings should have been instituted any earlier.” Most of the leave cases deal with delays of between one and four years, although longer periods have been considered (10 years in Neocleous [1993] FamCA 42 and Vince (No.2) [2021] FCCA 282 at [207] and [307]; and 35 years in Catlin & Kent [1986] FamCA 53). In Edmunds [2018] FamCAFC 121 at [143]-[144] a 6 year delay was explained by W who had reasonably believed that she had an agree- ment with H which made it unnecessary for her to seek property orders. Delay by legal advisers will usually not be held against an applicant: Nygh J in Frost & Nicholson (above) at pp 76,424–5. Also Althaus [1979] FamCA 47 and Walker [1984] FamCA 55. Ignorance of the time limit or poor advice are not valid reasons to extend time: Waldmann & Paddack [2024] FedCFamC1A 100. Leave for maintenance applications out of time In Atwill [1981] FamCA 72 Nygh J at [15]-[26] discussed the principles relevant to an application for maintenance out of time and [24]-[26] referred to Whitford (above), saying: “If the wife can make out a prima facie case for maintenance, it follows almost automatically that she would suffer hardship if her claim was denied” (the mere denial of a claim for prop- erty settlement not leading automatically to a finding of hardship) ( … ) [However] an action for maintenance … arises from the inability of the applicant to support herself and the ability to pay of the respondent.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: if her claim was denied” (the mere denial of a claim for prop- erty settlement not leading automatically to a finding of hardship) ( … ) [However] an action for maintenance … arises from the inability of the applicant to support herself and the ability to pay of the respondent. If one of those factors is absent at the time the period of 12 months expires but accrues at a subsequent time, it cannot be said that there was any ‘delay’ in bringing action.” Note – Amendment of existing proceedings does not constitute the institution of proceedings under s 44(3) and may therefore be filed more than 12 months after divorce: Woolley [1980] FamCA 77 and Good [1982] FamCA 47. Where leave sought for both property and maintenance Evatt CJ expressed the view of the Full Court in Althaus (above) at [14] that: “If it were accepted…that the property claim should be heard, and hardship would be suffered if it were not heard, it seems in my view entirely unreasonable to split off the maintenance part of the wife’s application (which would be) to tie the hands of the Court because the issues in regard to property applications and maintenance applications are not really severable.” Nor does a cross-application (in a Response) require leave: Full Court in Good (above) at [28]. What to file? For a precedent of the order to be sought and sample affidavit in support, see “interim orders sought” and “affidavits” under “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 73 SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS Under s 79A(1) (or s 90SN for de facto claims) the court may set aside or vary a property order and, if considered appropriate, make another order under s 79 (or s 90SM) in substitution if it is satisfied of: a) a miscarriage of justice by reason of fraud, duress, suppression of evidence (including failure to disclose relevant information), the giving of false evidence or any other circumstance b) circumstances since the order which are such that it is impracticable for the order or part of the order to be carried out c) default in carrying out an obligation imposed by the order and, in the circumstances that have arisen as a result of that default, it is just and equitable to set aside or vary the order d) exceptional circumstances since the order relating to the care, welfare and development of a child where the child or applicant will suffer hardship if the order is not set aside or varied, or e) a proceeds of crime order having been made covering property of the parties or either of them, or having been made against a party. In Lancer [2008] FamCAFC 112 Bryant CJ said at [34]-[35] (as to para (a) above): “ … [S]ection 79A itself contains two aspects. One is essentially a fact finding exercise [as to] wheth- er the applicant can establish on … the balance of probabilities that there has been a miscarriage of justice by reason of one of the [specified] matters … That is often referred to as the threshold test. The second part which follows from a positive finding about the first is a discretionary one … that the court may in its discretion vary or set aside the original order and, if
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: reason of one of the [specified] matters … That is often referred to as the threshold test. The second part which follows from a positive finding about the first is a discretionary one … that the court may in its discretion vary or set aside the original order and, if appropriate, make another order. The decision … about whether to hold a single hearing [instead of a preliminary hearing of the threshold issue] will…be a matter to be determined … in the exercise of discretion having regard to the circumstances of each case.” Miscarriage of justice 1.1. Was there fraud, duress, failure to disclose or any other circumstance? Fraud A fraudulent misrepresentation must have induced the other party to consent to the order: Nyles [2011] FamCA 565 at [188]-[192]. For more cases on “fraud” see Chapter 9 (“grounds on which the court may set aside a financial agreement”). Duress ‘Duress…need [not]…involve a direct threat of physical violence so long as there is sufficient oppres- sion…to vitiate the reality of…consent.’: Teves & Campomayor [1994] FamCA 57 at [44] applied in Robert & Golden [2011] FamCA 443. False evidence or failure to disclose The Full Court said in Morrison [1994] FamCA 153 at [32] and [42]: “The constant emphasis of the [s 79] cases is that in order for there to be a just and equitable and an appropriate order altering the interests of the parties in their property there must be a full and frank disclosure between them of all circumstances which may be relevant to the determination of their true financial position both presently and in the foreseeable future. ( … ) … the duty of disclosure is a basic duty. Ordinarily, a failure to comply with that duty will amount to a miscarriage of justice.” Update 64 March 2025
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: which may be relevant to the determination of their true financial position both presently and in the foreseeable future. ( … ) … the duty of disclosure is a basic duty. Ordinarily, a failure to comply with that duty will amount to a miscarriage of justice.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 74 In Barker [2007] FamCA 13 at [124] the Full Court said: “… Where there is some intervening factor known to one party, but not the other, this may lead to a result which is unfair and unjust and can be characterised as a flaw in the judicial process by which the orders were made. There may also be circumstances in which the judicial process could be impugned by a sale after orders were made and in the absence of bad faith by either party or suppression of some relevant fact, if it led to a significant miscarriage of justice.” In Simon & Michel [2010] FMCAfam 1055 a property order was set aside for H’s non-disclosure of his new job and salary package of $200,000. In Pearce [2016] FamCAFC 14 at [19]-[21] H lost his appeal against the setting aside of a consent order for his non-disclosure of an inconsistent representation he had made to a bank as to the value of an asset. Any other circumstance This applies to any situation in which a miscarriage of justice has occurred: Gebert [1990] FamCA 105 (approved in Prowse [1994] FamCA 91 at [32]) e.g. “sharp practice” where W’s draft order contained a mistake which H knew to be wrong yet he allowed the order to be made (Lowe & Harrington [1997] FamCA 14). In Hogan [2010] FMCAfam 1255 at [65]-[66] a consent order was set aside for “a combination of factors” (H’s harassment of W into signing and her “manifestly inadequate” settlement). 1.2. Did the above circumstance amount to a miscarriage of justice? The miscarriage of justice must arise from circumstances in existence at the date of the order: Molier & Van Wyk [1980] FamCA 85 at [8]-[11]. Miscarriage of justice concerns the integrity of the judicial
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: and her “manifestly inadequate” settlement). 1.2. Did the above circumstance amount to a miscarriage of justice? The miscarriage of justice must arise from circumstances in existence at the date of the order: Molier & Van Wyk [1980] FamCA 85 at [8]-[11]. Miscarriage of justice concerns the integrity of the judicial process. It concerns an unfair trial, not an unjust result. It does not cover orders unjustly obtained for a reason unconnected with the judicial process, such as the incompetence of counsel. In such a case a party’s remedy lies against his lawyers: Clifton & Stuart [1990] FamCA 154. Legal advice or representation may constitute miscarriage of justice if it was so bad as to be perverse or non-existent: Patching (below) cited in Hogan (above) at [40]. The Full Court in Prowse [1994] FamCA 91 at [35] approved this statement of the trial judge Strauss J: “Such [s 79A] circumstances might include lack of any or any proper representation or advice, concealment by the husband or ignorance by the wife of relevant financial matters, pressure on or undue persuasion of her, or unequal bargaining power on her part, and no doubt there may be many other such circumstances.” In a case where a wife appealed against a consent order that she said she did not know was to be a final order, the Full Court when dismissing the appeal said: “Agreement to a consent order which may not adequately reflect a party’s entitlements under s 79 does not, of itself, show that there has been a miscarriage of justice. … [The trial judge] con- cluded that the result was ‘a compromise result well within the ambit of what could have been the ultimate result in any contested hearing’.”: Holland [1982] FamCA 31 at [18]. 2. Should the court exercise its jurisdiction
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: that there has been a miscarriage of justice. … [The trial judge] con- cluded that the result was ‘a compromise result well within the ambit of what could have been the ultimate result in any contested hearing’.”: Holland [1982] FamCA 31 at [18]. 2. Should the court exercise its jurisdiction to set aside or vary the order? In Patching [1995] FamCA 46 the Full Court held that the test was whether the result would be materially different to that which was ordered. There is no prima facie entitlement to have orders set aside upon establishing a miscarriage of justice: Ming & Leong [2025] FedCFamC1A 3 at [42]-[43]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 75 Impracticable for order to be carried out A husband’s application to set aside an order transferring a business to him on the ground that a downturn had reduced its value was dismissed by Kay J in La Rocca [1991] FamCA 97 who said: “My own view is that the concept of impracticability…is akin to the application of the doctrine of frustration in contractual matters. What the Parliament is concerned with and what ought to be concerning the Court is the happening of events which cannot be reasonably foreseen, which will have the effect of causing an injustice to one of the parties if the happening of such events is not given effect to. (…) The potential insolvency of one of the parties in the future is not such a matter, in my view. In every case before the Court property values may change, go up or down, business may flourish or not flourish, the vicissitudes of life may affect one of the parties.” As to “impracticability” see Cawthorn [1998] FamCA 37; Rushby & Sherry [2004] FMCAfam 260 at [16]-[28] and Carrington (No. 2) [2010] FamCA 982. Default in carrying out an obligation Variation of a payment clause for an innocently defaulting H was preferred to enforcement by W in Monticone [1989] FamCA 92. In Blackwell & Scott [2017] FamCAFC 77 an order was set aside where H’s 10 month delay in paying meant W, due to a rise in property value, would no longer receive an equal division of assets. In Cawthorn (above) an order was not dismissed for H where, despite his worsening means, he was found to have made no effort to comply with the order and enjoyed a high standard of living. Exceptional new circumstances relating to welfare of child Nygh J in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: equal division of assets. In Cawthorn (above) an order was not dismissed for H where, despite his worsening means, he was found to have made no effort to comply with the order and enjoyed a high standard of living. Exceptional new circumstances relating to welfare of child Nygh J in Liu [1984] FamCA 65 at [30] said that “exceptional circumstances” “…need not by themselves relate to the original property order. An obvious example would be a serious chronic illness of a child which causes a need for remodelling of the house in which he or she lives which cannot be met out of increased maintenance but only out of an increased share of capital. In this case, however, the wife is seeking to enforce arrears of maintenance and may, in the light of the husband’s refusal to pay maintenance in the past, have a basis for claiming lump sum maintenance for the future. However, she could make such claims without the need to re-open the original property proceedings.” In Simpson & Hamlin [1984] FamCA 62 the Full Court approved this conclusion of the trial judge: “The occurrence of a change in the responsibility for the daily care and control of children of a marriage, after the making of a property order under s 79 of the Family Law Act could not be held of itself to be an unusual circumstance. The ordinary vicissitudes of life coupled with the difficul- ties that parties to a marriage often experience in the task of restructuring their lives following the dissolution of their marriage and the division of their assets, and their obligations to the support of each other and the support, care and control of their children, frequently creates situations in which it is desirable having regard to the children’s welfare that such
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: of restructuring their lives following the dissolution of their marriage and the division of their assets, and their obligations to the support of each other and the support, care and control of their children, frequently creates situations in which it is desirable having regard to the children’s welfare that such a change occurs. ( … ) What amounts to ‘exceptional circumstances’ is very much a question of fact and degree.” In Sandrk [1991] FamCA 98 Gee J held that the children’s action in “voting with their feet” within four months of the property order to go and live with the mother amounted to “exceptional circumstances”, not having been within the parties’ contemplation or created by the applicant. See Hann & Green [2012] FamCA 113 at [50]-[95] for a discussion of case law and the need to prove “exceptional circumstances”, “hardship” to child or applicant and, relevant to the exercise of discretion, prejudice to the respondent. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 76 The Full Court held in Public Trustee & Gilbert [1991] FamCA 10 that the premature death of a party soon after a property order could constitute “circumstances of an exceptional nature”, but in the case before the Court those circumstances were found not to relate to the welfare of a child. Setting aside consent orders Two cases above involved a consent order – Holland; and Simpson & Hamlin. Here is another: In Anderson [1999] FamCA 1026 Chisholm J refused to set aside a consent order, sought by the husband on the ground that he had suffered loss through his wife not having disclosed her valuation of certain property. The court held that the wife was not obliged to disclose the valuation as it was privileged, and her decision not to inform the husband did not constitute suppression of evidence. He said that as the husband had not relied on any statement by the wife as to the property’s value, it could not be said that she either induced him to believe in a particular value or knew of his mistake. The husband had chosen not to value his own property, and the fact that he negotiated on a false view of its value did not indicate any improper behaviour on the part of the wife or her solicitors. See also Bigg & Suzy [1998] FamCA 14 at [6.52]. And, for a consent order set aside due to a party not disclosing a pre-settlement offer on a property, see Barker [2007] FamCA 13 at [123]. Setting aside an order by consent inferred from conduct Section 79A (1A) (s 90SN(2) for de facto claims) allows the discharge of a property order by consent. In McCabe [1995] FamCA 147 a couple had married in 1982 and separated in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: a property, see Barker [2007] FamCA 13 at [123]. Setting aside an order by consent inferred from conduct Section 79A (1A) (s 90SN(2) for de facto claims) allows the discharge of a property order by consent. In McCabe [1995] FamCA 147 a couple had married in 1982 and separated in early 1989. A final property order had been made by consent in July 1989. The parties reconciled and did not implement the order. They separated again in 1993 after having intermingled their financial affairs. The Full Court found that the parties had “by their conduct consented to the setting aside of the original order”, approving the following passage in Bourke (No. 2) [1994] FamCA 61: “…there is no reason to doubt that parties can expressly, by their conduct consent to the discharge of prior orders, so as to enable the court to make a fresh property order. Indeed, this would be a more likely conclusion in most cases of this type.” Also see Ozick [2012] FMCAfam 310 at [15] and [59]-[66]. The Slip Rule and other means to set aside orders A court may vary or set aside its order by consent or if the order was made ex parte, by fraud, is inter- locutory, an injunction or to appoint a receiver, does not reflect the court’s intention, there is a clerical mistake or accidental slip or omission: FLR 10.13 (in WA, FCR 311). See Higginson and Anor [2013] FamCA 902 at [5]-[8] (rectification of an error) and Xie & Zhao (No. 2) [2009] FMCAfam 1303 (ex parte order). If by consent send a jointly signed letter to the registrar attaching the correct minutes of consent orders.
