Explain the mistake and request – under the relevant rule – that the attached minutes is- sue to replace those that were incorrect.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: Zhao (No. 2) [2009] FMCAfam 1303 (ex parte order). If by consent send a jointly signed letter to the registrar attaching the correct minutes of consent orders. Explain the mistake and request – under the relevant rule – that the attached minutes is- sue to replace those that were incorrect. If not by consent file (with an affidavit in support) an Application in a Proceeding (or an initiating application if alleging fraud) for an order amending the order under the relevant rule. What to file? For a precedent of the order to be sought and sample affidavit in support, see “final orders sought” and “affidavits” under “precedents” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: SETTING ASIDE OR VARYING PROPERTY ORDERS

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 77 ENFORCEMENT OF PROPERTY ORDERS The best means to enforce an order is to anticipate the need to enforce by including in your terms of settlement self-executing enforcement remedies. Our precedent “final property orders”, for example, include default sale clauses where one party wishes to retain a property but may not obtain finance, an order for interest payable after the due date for any payment and an order for security for payment. We also include an order under s 106A enabling a registrar to sign any document. When implementing this, it is usually sufficient for a party to swear a brief affidavit annexing a copy of the order; directing the registrar’s attention to the s106A order; and setting out the attempts made to have the other party sign, their response and attaching any relevant correspondence. 1. One enforcement option is to issue an Application – Enforcement (Item 4 of FLR 2.01) to enforce an order pursuant to the court’s power to do so under s 105 FLA (with an affidavit in support), such as for default sale as above and costs. For the appointment of a trustee for sale see the order made in Kent & Marshall [2011] FamCA 232. It includes a vesting order which authorises the trustee to act (see Baker & Green & Kettle (No. 3) [2007] FamCA 1653 at [26]-[27]). While a solicitor was appointed in those cases the applicant party would usually be appointed. If you also need an order for vacant possession by the respondent see the order made in Painter-Ward & Ward [2012] FMCAfam 570. Note – Under s 117B(1) interest on an order for payment of money is payable on the unpaid bal- ance from the date of the order or date on which the order is said to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: possession by the respondent see the order made in Painter-Ward & Ward [2012] FMCAfam 570. Note – Under s 117B(1) interest on an order for payment of money is payable on the unpaid bal- ance from the date of the order or date on which the order is said to take effect, whichever is later. The rate at which interest is payable is prescribed by FLR 10.17 (in WA, FCR 313), being: (a) in respect of the period from 1 January to 30 June in any year – the rate that is 6% above the cash rate last published by the Reserve Bank of Australia before that period commenced; and (b) in respect of the period from 1 July to 31 December in any year – the rate that is 6% above the cash rate last published by the Reserve Bank of Australia before that period commenced. You need separate calculations for each half year period in each relevant year. For the relevant cash rates use this link at our eBook – www.rba.gov.au/statistics/cash-rate/. Add to your orders sought the daily rate of interest payable beyond the order made. 2. Issue an Application – Contravention AND at the hearing seek (1) a sanction for non-compliance with a financial order under Part XIIIA FLA (s 112AD(1) in particular) and (2) orders under s 112AD(4) as are “necessary to ensure compliance”. Those orders may only be made if a sanction has been imposed. And seek (3) costs on an indemnity basis caused by the respondent’s breach of the order: see the Colgate case under “costs” in Chapter 8. The applicant’s affidavit in support should itemise the interest and costs sought (and include a copy of their costs agreement). This procedure is pursuant to FLR 11.63 to 11.69 and, in WA, FCR 432-439. As
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the respondent’s breach of the order: see the Colgate case under “costs” in Chapter 8. The applicant’s affidavit in support should itemise the interest and costs sought (and include a copy of their costs agreement). This procedure is pursuant to FLR 11.63 to 11.69 and, in WA, FCR 432-439. As to the sanction to argue at the hearing, we suggest a (four figure) fine to be stayed for say 14 days pending the respondent’s compliance with the order, including interest and costs. See Iverson [2007] FMCAfam 257 at [56]-[66] and [81] where the applicant argued for imprisonment suspended upon compliance but the court imposed a fine ($3,300) that was suspended for 30 days pending compliance. 3. Once you have an order fixing the interest and costs payable, you can request the court (without notice to the payer) to issue an Enforcement Warrant (for seizure and sale of property in default of payment). See FLR 11.15-11.31 and 11.62 (or FCR 384-395). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 78 4. To enforce possession of real property a party has been ordered to vacate, you can file, upon 7 days notice to the respondent, an Application – Enforcement (above). See FLR 11.55-11.58 and 11.62 (in WA, FCR 425). 5. If you know of a third party who owes money to the payer you could, without notice, request the court to issue a Third Party Debt Notice pursuant to FLR 11.34 requiring payment by that third party (e.g. an employer). See FLR 11.32-11.43 (in WA, FCR 401-412) and the brochure “third party debt notices”. 6. If the above are not available, you could issue an Application – Enforcement for an order pursuant to FLR 11.07, such as an order for payment by instalments as made in Halley & Wyatt [2011] FMCAfam 278. The orders available to be sought under that rule include an order that the respondent attend an enforcement hearing, file a Financial Statement, give further evidence or produce documents. See FLR 11.01-11.14 (in WA, FCR 376) and the prescribed brochure “enforcement hearings”. 7. Less common enforcement options are the appointment of a sequestrator to manage the payer’s business (FLR 11.44-11.47 and, in WA, FCR 413-416) and a receiver of the payer’s income or property (FLR 11.48-11.54 and, in WA, FCR 417-423). For some cases, see our archived case notes – property under “enforcement”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 4. To enforce possession of real property a party has been ordered to vacate, you can file, upon 7 days

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 79 TRANSACTIONS TO DEFEAT CLAIMS The court may set aside or restrain the making of an instrument or disposition made or proposed to be made to defeat an existing or anticipated order or which, irrespective of intention, is likely to defeat any such order: s 106B The section goes on to cover bankruptcy; insolvency; orders charging money or property for costs, maintenance or payment into court; protection of bona fide purchasers; and persons eligible to apply. For a discussion of the cases see Markham [2010] FamCA 460 at [98]-[101]. In Davidson (No. 2) [1994] FamCA 33 a company which the court had earlier found to be the hus- band’s alter ego executed a deed of variation of a trust deed that removed him as appointor of the trust. The Full Court held that the trial judge was right to identify the deed of variation as a step in a scheme to defeat the earlier court order and to set aside the deed of variation. The husband was also ordered to execute an agreement nominating an accountant nominated by the wife to act as appointor of the trust, that order being available under s 80 by virtue of s 106B(4A). In Ivanovic [1999] FamCA 2087 Lindenmayer J set aside an assignment by a husband of his remainder interest in a property to his brother. A transfer of land by a husband 10 days before marriage back to his mother, being land he had re- ceived from his parents three years before marriage on which he had begun building a house, and on which the wife had worked during weekends – was held by Warnick J to be covered by s 85 (now s 106B) in Johnson [2000] FamCA 164. As to a deed of assignment under the Bankruptcy
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: three years before marriage on which he had begun building a house, and on which the wife had worked during weekends – was held by Warnick J to be covered by s 85 (now s 106B) in Johnson [2000] FamCA 164. As to a deed of assignment under the Bankruptcy Act see Milland [1980] FamCA 91. As to money transferred to an overseas relative see Wotton [2010] FamCA 194 and Bourke [2010] FamCA 199 from [139]. Factors relevant to exercise of discretion • Interests of bona fide purchaser or other interested person—The Full Court upheld the setting aside of a mortgage a husband had taken out in breach of his undertaking in Heath [1984] FamCA 17 at [26] saying: “under s 85 (s 106B)…an objective test is to be applied and…the test of bona fides is whether the appellant at the time of the taking of the mortgage was aware, or should have been aware by making due inquiry, that the disposition would be likely to defeat the claim of the wife”. • Whether a s 106B order would serve any useful purpose—In Public Trustee & Keays [1985] FamCA 51 the Full Court declined to set aside a trust deed where the trustees of H’s pension fund had agreed to invest $15,000 with the Public Trustee for the children, because to do so would only re-vest the fund in the trustees. Also see Vedders & Gittens [2023] FedCFamC1A 138 at [38]. • Transactions in normal course of business—Distributions many months before the issue of proceedings to two adult children from a family trust controlled by H were not set aside by Treyvaud J in Gelley (No. 2) [1992] FamCA 84 as the distributions would not affect the anticipated order; they were normal and prudent; could have been taken into account
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: before the issue of proceedings to two adult children from a family trust controlled by H were not set aside by Treyvaud J in Gelley (No. 2) [1992] FamCA 84 as the distributions would not affect the anticipated order; they were normal and prudent; could have been taken into account later and there was no evidence of bad faith (mala fides) by the trustee. The Full Court has held that an accommodation provided by a bank to H ought not to have been set aside as it had been provided in the normal course of business to enable H to trade out of his financial difficulties: Commonwealth Bank of Australia & Staatz [1988] FamCA 36. • Person acting in collusion with a party—may be ordered to pay the costs of other party, bona fide purchaser or interested person: s 106B(4) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 80 EFFECT OF DEATH ON PROPERTY PROCEEDINGS Section 79(8) (and s 90SM(8) for de facto claims) provides that where a party dies before property proceedings are completed: (a) Such proceedings may be continued by or against the personal representative of a deceased party. (b) The court may make a property order it would have made had the party not died, if still appropriate. (c) Such an order is enforceable by or against the deceased party’s estate. As to whether it is “still appropriate” to make a property order after the death of a party see Erdem & Ozsoy [2012] FMCAfam 1323 at [131]-[133]. The proceedings need only be filed, not filed and served, before death for these sections to apply: Nantz & Brettos [2011] FMCAfam 427. The Full Court in Tasmanian Trustees Ltd & Gleeson [1990] FamCA 65 upheld Wood J’s decision that it was no longer appropriate to make an order in favour of the deceased husband’s estate relating to the jointly owned home, 70% of which the husband had claimed due to his extreme illness. As the estate was small, and the wife had made substantial contributions and had overwhelming needs, it was held that the usual moral entitlement of a deceased’s legal representative to the deceased’s contribution- based share (and the freedom to dispose of it by will to strangers to the marriage) should not apply. The home therefore became vested in the wife by survivorship. A case of a larger estate, where the estate did receive the deceased’s due entitlement, was Menzies & Evans [1988] FamCA 35. See also Healy [2009] FMCAfam 351. Admissibility of evidence from witnesses to statement of deceased: s 63(2) Evidence Act 1995 (Cth). Where the wife died after the hearing but before written submissions her executor was
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: EFFECT OF DEATH ON PROPERTY PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: the estate did receive the deceased’s due entitlement, was Menzies & Evans [1988] FamCA 35. See also Healy [2009] FMCAfam 351. Admissibility of evidence from witnesses to statement of deceased: s 63(2) Evidence Act 1995 (Cth). Where the wife died after the hearing but before written submissions her executor was given leave to intervene: Cullen [2011] FMCAfam 375. If a party dies after a property order is made, the order may be enforced by or against the deceased’s estate: s 79(1A) (and s 90SM(2) for de facto claims). Proceedings may not be continued after the death of both parties: Pellissier [2011] FamCA 983; also Vesey [2012] FamCA 386. In the case of a dispute as to who the executor of an estate is the proceedings are suspended until a grant of probate or letters of administration: Midhurst (Deceased) & Midhurst [2008] FamCA 393. Where there is no such dispute a party – ideally the deceased’s lawyer – should, without awaiting such a grant, file and serve on the other side an Application in a Proceeding seeking an order that X as the legal personal representative of the deceased be substituted for the deceased as applicant/respondent (as applicable) pursuant to FLR 3.19(3). See Murdoch & Brown (No. 2) [2013] FamCA 732. The affidavit in support by the executor named in the deceased’s will should attach a copy of the probate if a grant has been made or, if not, should refer to the deceased’s will; his or her appointment as trustee and intention to apply for a grant of probate. For an intestacy, the applying legal personal representative should refer to his or her relationship to the deceased and intention to apply for letters of administration. For the effect of death on an Application for Consent Orders, see Hullet & Benton
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: EFFECT OF DEATH ON PROPERTY PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: and intention to apply for a grant of probate. For an intestacy, the applying legal personal representative should refer to his or her relationship to the deceased and intention to apply for letters of administration. For the effect of death on an Application for Consent Orders, see Hullet & Benton [2022] FedCFamC1A 13 at [32]-[38]. Suggestions If the other party is seriously ill, issue proceedings without delay because property proceedings may be continued after death, but not instituted. To cover the risk of a seriously ill client dying before the issue of their proceedings, you could lodge a severance of any joint tenancy. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: EFFECT OF DEATH ON PROPERTY PROCEEDINGS

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 81 BANKRUPTCY AND FAMILY LAW PROCEEDINGS The interaction of family law and bankruptcy was simplified by amendments introduced to the Bankruptcy Act and the Family Law Act on 18 September 2005. The court can now make a property order even though property has vested in the bankruptcy trustee of a party, altering the interests of the trustee in the vested bankruptcy property: s 79(1)(b) Such an order may require the trustee to transfer property to the non-bankrupt spouse: 79(1)(d)(ii) The bankruptcy trustee may be joined as a party to proceedings in which a property order is sought and a party was a bankrupt or, before completion of proceedings, a party becomes a bankrupt: s 79(11) The trustee may also, upon the application of the non-bankrupt spouse, be restrained from distributing dividends among creditors: s 114(4). So may the trustee of a personal insolvency agreement: s 114(6) Upon a bankruptcy trustee becoming a party, the bankrupt party is not entitled to make a submission to the court in connection with any vested bankruptcy property: s 79(12). See Walford & Bantock and Anor [2020] FamCAFC 210. Accordingly, the four step process to determining a property dispute still applies where a spouse is or becomes a bankrupt during the proceedings. The amendments added to the s 75(2) factors paragraph (ha) “the effect of any proposed order on the ability of a creditor of a party to recover the creditor’s debt, so far as that effect is relevant”. As to spousal maintenance, subsection (2) of s 72 was introduced. This provides that the liability of a bankrupt party to maintain the other party “may be satisfied, in whole or in part, by way of the trans- fer of vested bankruptcy property in relation to the bankrupt party”. An application to discharge,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: maintenance, subsection (2) of s 72 was introduced. This provides that the liability of a bankrupt party to maintain the other party “may be satisfied, in whole or in part, by way of the trans- fer of vested bankruptcy property in relation to the bankrupt party”. An application to discharge, suspend, revive or vary a spousal maintenance order may be issued by a trustee in bankruptcy: s 83(1A)(b) Note – It is advisable to brief counsel to advise in any case where a party is or becomes bankrupt. Bankruptcy and the family home In addition to that brochure (a link to which is here at our eBook), see the fact sheet of that name by Worrells Solvency & Forensic Accountants available online at our Members’ Archive. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 82 CREDITORS AND OTHER THIRD PARTIES Any person may apply for leave to intervene in proceedings: s 92(1). A person granted leave to in- tervene is deemed to be a party to the proceedings with all the rights, duties and liabilities of a party: s 92(3). The court has the power to make a property order (s 79) or grant an injunction (s 114) “that is directed to, or alters the rights, liabilities or property interests of a third party”: s 90AA. Part VIIIAA of the FLA (“orders and injunctions binding third parties”) also applies to de facto proceedings: s 90TA. Part VIIIAA enables the court to determine whether an alleged debt is a debt. See s 90AD which gives the court jurisdiction to determine liabilities as well as make orders in relation to property. The orders the court can make against a creditor or other third party are set out in s 90AE(1): (a) an order directed to a creditor of the parties to substitute one party for both parties in relation to the debt (b) an order directed to a creditor of one party to substitute the other party, or both parties, in relation to the debt (c) an order directed to a creditor of the parties that the parties be liable for a different proportion of the debt (d) an order directed to a director of a company or to a company to register a transfer of shares from one party to the other party. Other orders court may make Section 90AE(2) provides that in property proceedings, the court may make any other order that: (a) directs a third party to do a thing in relation to the property of a party to the marriage; or (b) alters the rights, liabilities or property
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: other party. Other orders court may make Section 90AE(2) provides that in property proceedings, the court may make any other order that: (a) directs a third party to do a thing in relation to the property of a party to the marriage; or (b) alters the rights, liabilities or property interests of a third party in relation to the marriage. Conditions to making orders Under s 90AE(3) the court can only make such an order if: (a) it is reasonably necessary or appropriate to effect a division of property between the parties; (b) it would not foreseeably result in the debt not being paid in full; (c) the third party has been given procedural fairness as to the making of the order [see Leith [2014] FCCA 2394 at [38]-[48]]; (d) the court is satisfied that in all the circumstances it is just and equitable to make the order; (e) the court is satisfied that it takes into account the matters mentioned in subsection (4). Matters court must take into account Under s 90AE(4) the court must take into account: (a) the taxation effect (if any) of the order on the parties to the marriage; (b) the taxation effect (if any) of the order on the third party; (c) the social security effect (if any) of the order on the parties to the marriage; Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 83 (d) the third party’s administrative costs in relation to the order; (e) as to an order relating to a debt, the capacity of the party to repay the debt after the order is made; Example – The capacity of a spouse to repay the debt (see s 90AE(3)(b) above) would be affected by their ability to repay the debt without undue hardship. (f) the economic, legal or other capacity of the third party to comply with the order; Example – The legal capacity of the third party to comply with the order could be affected by the terms of a trust deed. However, after taking the third party’s legal capacity into account, the court may make the order despite the terms of the trust deed. If the court does so, the order will have effect despite those terms (see s 90AC as to this Part overriding trust deeds). (g) any other matters raised by the third party [if joined: see Manichaeus and Ors [2010] FamCA 397 at [85] cf. Leith above where a bank did not object to orders sought so was not joined]; (h) any other matter the court considers relevant. In Ibbott and Anor [2008] FMCAfam 38 at [21]-[22] it was held that an order for substitution of spouses in relation to a debt might not be just and equitable if it results in the debt not being paid in full. In Chow & Harris and Anor [2010] FamCA 366 a creditor of H (his sister) was granted rectification of a loan agreement under s 90AE so as to reflect their true agreement by including a default interest rate and requiring payment of the due amount from the spousal parties’ property settlement. In Payne [2013] FCCA 794 at [100]-[107] H’s father was ordered to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (his sister) was granted rectification of a loan agreement under s 90AE so as to reflect their true agreement by including a default interest rate and requiring payment of the due amount from the spousal parties’ property settlement. In Payne [2013] FCCA 794 at [100]-[107] H’s father was ordered to substitute H in lieu of the wife as to debts owed to H’s father. In Coldham & Anor [2014] FCCA 2377 W’s entitlement to sale proceeds under a property order was granted priority over a creditor’s charge by guarantee given by H. Injunctions binding a third party Similar powers apply for the granting of an injunction binding a third party as relate to s 79 orders binding a third party (above). These are set out in s 90AF. Note – It is advisable to seek counsel’s advice if a creditor applies to intervene as a party in your property proceedings. Creditor intervention in family law case In a case where H had a tax liability well in excess of the parties’ assets, Commissioner of Taxation & Worsnop [2009] FamCAFC 4, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) joined the parties’ property proceedings in the Family Court of Australia as an intervenor. The Full Court dismissed ATO’s appeal from the judgment of the trial judge Rose J that the proceeds of sale of the family home be divided equally between W and ATO, rejecting ATO’s claim that it should receive the whole proceeds as W had benefited from H’s tax evasion, knowing that the home was bought with funds on which tax had not been paid. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 84 Rose J preferred W’s account that H did not inform her of his non-disclosure of income for tax purposes to H’s account that he did. W knew the home was bought in her name because H was having trouble with creditors, but it had not been put to her that she knew the purchase money should have been paid to meet H’s tax debt. The ATO relied on s 90AE(3)(d) but the Full Court held that the section related to: “[79] … the Court’s direct interference with a third party’s rights, for example, in respect of a creditor, rights relating to the person from whom recovery may be sought. In contrast, the aspect of a creditor’s position to which the Court must have regard under s 75(2)(ha) are not rights to recovery but the practical prospects of recovery from a debtor spouse’s property. [80] For example, one might imagine a circumstance where one spouse’s initial contributions and the shortness of the marriage might mean that the great bulk of property existing at the time of a property settlement trial had belonged to, and does belong to, that spouse and that position ought not be altered under s 79. In the meantime, a creditor might have lent, perhaps unwisely, to the other spouse, who lost the borrowed money and could not repay from his or her own assets. As we have said, we do not think that in such circumstances, either s 79(2) or s 75(2)(ha) has the result that the creditor has some opportunity, on the basis of justice and eq- uity, of improving the position that the creditor would have been in had he pursued the debtor spouse alone. In other words, the creditor who becomes a party does not step up in status
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: has the result that the creditor has some opportunity, on the basis of justice and eq- uity, of improving the position that the creditor would have been in had he pursued the debtor spouse alone. In other words, the creditor who becomes a party does not step up in status to become entitled to greater ‘justice and equity’ than the non-party creditor [unlike in bankruptcy (as Rose J noted at [83] the Full Court had ruled in Biltoft) “where a debt to the Crown does have priority”]. The Court at [94] said: “Rose J effectively found that the husband was on ‘a frolic of his own’. As to whether this was contrary to the wife’s express wishes, that could hardly be a fair question where the wife was, as Rose J found, kept uninformed.” A contrary decision as to a tax debt In Trustee of the property of Lemnos [2009] FamCAFC 20, where H’s debts of $6m put the pool into deficit, the Full Court at [173]-[181] ruled in favour of ATO having regard to: “the (amount) of the husband’s (debt), the identity of the creditor, the manner in which the (debt) arose and the reality that, on the evidence before (the trial judge), the wife must have benefited, directly or indirectly, from the husband’s non-payment of…his…(tax) obligations from 1991 to 2002.” Intervention by solicitor to recover unpaid fees In Devi & Devi and Anor [2021] FCWA 6 a solicitor failed in his application to intervene to recover $67,598 in unpaid fees as he did not have a judgment debt and the client still had rights under the Legal Profession Act 2008 (WA). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 85 PROCEDURE FOR PROPERTY MATTERS (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) Parties must first have complied with the pre-action procedure summarised in the brochure Before you file – pre-action procedure for financial cases. For the conduct of proceedings, see in particu- lar paras 1.3, 1.4 and 1.5 of the Central Practice Direction referred to below. Which court? A property proceeding is filed in the FCFCA or, in WA, the FCWA. In both Courts e-filing is via: • the Commonwealth Courts Portal • the eCourts Portal of Western Australia When an Initiating Application is filed in the FCFCA, it will be listed before Division 1 or Division 2 (the old FCC) for a directions hearing (the first court event). Give your client the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management made on 1 Sep- tember 2021, which applies to financial cases filed before or after that date. Allocation between Divisions is discretionary, the Court to have regard to complexity or importance; any international issues; multiple parties or experts; length of case; the Divisions’ workload; impact on litigants of a transfer; any serious criminal conduct; or other reason for referral to a specialist list. Also see Family Law Practice Direction – Financial proceedings made on 1 September 2021 and the FCWA’s Case Management Guidelines. Both parties 1. Go through your client’s returned Client Information Sheet (see “lawyer-client documentation” under chapter “client preliminaries” above), completing details of: • assets, liabilities and financial resources of each party • financial, non-financial and family welfare contributions by each party Investment properties If there are a number of investment properties, ask your client to prepare a separate page for each property, setting out (as they must for the home and all previously owned properties too) what each paid for its purchase, borrowing and upkeep; exactly
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: welfare contributions by each party Investment properties If there are a number of investment properties, ask your client to prepare a separate page for each property, setting out (as they must for the home and all previously owned properties too) what each paid for its purchase, borrowing and upkeep; exactly what work each did towards maintenance or improvement; and what any parent or other person did to contribute on behalf of each spouse. • any windfalls, inheritances, lottery wins, gifts or loans or other financial, non-financial or other contributions made by parents, other family or friends • the future needs of each party – specifically, each party’s age, income, capacity for employment, capital and financial resources, dependants, whether either party has re-partnered; a living standard that is reasonable in the circumstances, duration of the marriage and the extent that it has had an impact on each party’s earning capacity • the wish of each party to continue their role as a parent, and in particular, their financial needs if time with the children is to be significantly shared Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 86 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above). 3. Interim issues. Obtain details of any alleged violence or continuing conflict, as to which see our sample interim orders and affidavits in support at Chapter 4. 4. Preservation of assets. Seek instructions as to any risk of disposal and need for an injunction. 5. Interim costs. Consider negotiating a consent order for a mutual release of $x to each party. Applicants 1. Attend to steps 1-5 above. If 3 or 4 is urgent you may apply for an interim order that the matter be listed on an urgent basis and compliance with all pre-action procedures be waived pursuant to FLR 4.01(2)(e) (or FCR 22(2)), but your affidavit and covering letter should point clearly to that urgency. 2. If your client has an interest in superannuation, complete and send a Superannuation Information Kit to the fund trustee. See “superannuation interests” below. 3. Assemble your client’s documents and supply a copy to the other party or their lawyer. See “first letter to other party or their lawyer” under “precedents” below. 4. Write to the other side with your nomination, for their selection, of valuers of assets the value of which has not been agreed. See letter referred to in 3 above. 5. Write to the other party or their lawyer setting out the net asset pool according to your instructions (see “start by drawing up an outline of the asset pool(s)” under “identify and value the net property” above); and an outline of s 79(4) or 90SM(4) contributions and s 75(2) or 90SF(3) factors. See “first letter to other party” in “precedents” below. 6. Before starting a case, a pre-action procedure letter must be sent to the other side or your ap-
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: “identify and value the net property” above); and an outline of s 79(4) or 90SM(4) contributions and s 75(2) or 90SF(3) factors. See “first letter to other party” in “precedents” below. 6. Before starting a case, a pre-action procedure letter must be sent to the other side or your ap- plication risks an adjournment, a stay or a costs order. The letter must invite dispute resolution; give notice of intention to issue proceedings; a list of issues in dispute and orders to be sought; an offer and time for reply of at least 14 days. See “pre-action procedure letter” below. 7. In the FCFCA, an applicant must file: Initiating Application; Financial Statement; Copy of any family violence order; Genuine Steps Certificate; Undertaking as to Disclosure; Affidavit in support (only if interim orders are sought) (or a Financial Questionnaire if no interim orders are sought). Such affidavits are limited to 25 pages and 10 annexures in Division 1; and 10 pages and 5 annexures in Division 2 (FLR 5.08(2)). In the FCWA, an affidavit and a Financial Statement must be filed with an Initiating Application that seeks financial orders. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 87 A suggestion Email your court papers to your barrister to advise to what extent your evidence may be deficient in proving your case for any interim orders. Your counsel should also settle the updated affidavit you later file prior to the final hearing. If you are seeking an injunction against the disposal of assets by the other party, review the law on this first (see “interim injunctions to preserve property” above) as to what evidence is required to be filed. Respondents 1. Attend to steps 1–5 under “both parties” above. 2. If your client has an interest in superannuation, complete and send a Superannuation Information Kit to the fund trustee. See “superannuation interests” below. 3. Assemble your client’s documents and supply a copy to the other party or their lawyer. 4. Respond to the other side’s nomination of any valuer (para 4 under “applicants” above) or nominate valuers of any asset in your client’s control. 5. Respond to the other side’s draft asset pool, contributions and factors as per para 5 under “ap- plicants” above. 6. Respond to the other side’s pre-action procedure letter as per para 6 under “applicants” above. 7. If proceedings have been issued by the other party, obtain instructions about accepting service of their court papers, then instructions in sufficient detail for completion of: Response to Initiating Application (or Submitting Notice if the orders sought by the applicant are agreed); Financial Statement; Genuine Steps Certificate; Affidavit (if interim orders are sought by either party) (or a Financial Questionnaire if no interim orders are sought). A Response must be filed and served within 28 days: FLR 2.18(2). In WA, prepare for filing a Response to Initiating Application; a Financial Statement; and an affidavit. That Response must be filed and served at least 7
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: either party) (or a Financial Questionnaire if no interim orders are sought). A Response must be filed and served within 28 days: FLR 2.18(2). In WA, prepare for filing a Response to Initiating Application; a Financial Statement; and an affidavit. That Response must be filed and served at least 7 days before the hearing to which the Response relates: FCR 153. Superannuation interests Either prior to or when preparing your client’s court documents, review whether your client has any interest in superannuation. If so, complete and send a Superannuation Information Kit to the relevant superannuation fund trustee so as to obtain a valuation of that interest. The completed Kit should be attached to your client’s Financial Statement when filed or filed and served separately before the first court date. See “forms” below. Orders are to be served on the trustee too. If seeking a superannuation split as part of your property settlement application, a copy of your Appli- cation must also be served on the trustee so as to accord the trustee procedural fairness: s 90XZD and FLR 1.12(5) (FLR 10.06 if applying for consent orders). Orders are to be served on the trustee too. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 88 Valuations See “valuations” under “the four steps in determining a property dispute” above. The opinion of a valuer is expert evidence, which is governed by Part 7.1 FLR (or, in WA, Division 5 of Part 15 FCR).. Leave is required to rely on any expert evidence that is not the evidence of a single expert witness: FLR 7.10 (in WA, FCR 274). It follows that before obtaining any valuation, the other side should be consulted and agreement reached as to the appointment of a valuer, so as to appoint him or her as a single expert witness (and thereby make the evidence admissible without leave). The pre-action letter should nominate three potential experts, and request the other side to select one (see “letters” below). If agreement cannot be reached, directions can be sought from the Court at the first court event. All instructions to an expert witness must be in writing. The expert is to be given a copy of Divisions 7.1.4, 7.1.5 and 7.1.6 FLR, with notice that the report may be used in a proceeding and a description of the issues about which the opinion is sought: FLR 7.13 (in WA, FCR 279). If a single expert valuer is appointed, but your client is not happy with the report, then: • the report may be clarified via conference (FLR 7.25). Questions to the expert are to be put within 7 days of such conference or, if no conference is held, within 21 days of the report: FLR 7.26 (in WA, FCR 292). The expert’s fees when answering the questions are to be met by the asking party: FLR 7.28 (in WA, FCR 294(3)). • if leave is sought to adduce evidence from a second expert, such leave is to be sought via an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: of the report: FLR 7.26 (in WA, FCR 292). The expert’s fees when answering the questions are to be met by the asking party: FLR 7.28 (in WA, FCR 294(3)). • if leave is sought to adduce evidence from a second expert, such leave is to be sought via an Application in a Proceeding with an affidavit to address the matters listed at FLR 7.11. See Salmon & Salmon and Ors (No. 2) [2019] FamCA 910 at [14]-[19] as to the Court’s ap- proach in applications for leave. Also Royce & Donovan [2012] FamCA 168 at [20], [30]-[52] and [68]-[74]. Valuations should ideally be completed before issuing proceedings (so that the net asset pool can be quantified at the outset). If this is not possible, do so at the latest before the dispute resolution event so that settlement negotiations may begin in earnest and not be delayed. Any expert report to be relied on at an interim hearing must be filed no later than 7 days prior to the hearing: para 5.17 of the Central Practice Direction. Where more than one expert is appointed, see the prescribed brochure “Experts’ Conference”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 89 Disclosure See “discovery of documents” in Chapter 8 for the court procedure. Before the first court event the parties must serve on each other (FLR 6.06(8); in WA, FCR 190): • a copy of their 3 most recent tax returns and assessments • the completed superannuation information form for any super interest (in WA, the 2 most recent member benefit statements for any accumulation fund) • the trust deed and the 3 most recent financial statements for any self-managed super fund • a copy of the last 4 business activity statements if the party has an ABN • a copy of the 3 most recent financial statements and the last 4 business activity statements lodged by any partnership, trust or company After a case has been given a first court date a party may, in writing, ask another party to provide a list of documents to which the duty of disclosure applies. The disclosing party must within 21 days serve on the requesting party a list of documents: FLR 6.09 or FCR 216. Negotiations Negotiations may occur at any time. However, they can only properly occur when the parties’ assets, liabilities and financial resources, contributions and s 75(2) or s 90SF(3) factors have been identified, property valued and relevant documents exchanged. Change of venue See the factors set out in FLR 9.01 (in WA, FCR 186,187) and Romano & June [2010] FamCA 1027 at [72]-[132] for a discussion of those factors. Urgent listing If seeking an urgent listing see Myers [2011] FMCAfam 1104 at [87] as to your available grounds. Review of registrar’s order A registrar’s powers are set out in FLR 14.04 and Schedule 4 FLR (in WA, FCR 321). For an appli- cation for the review of a registrar’s order e.g. refusal to list
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: urgent listing see Myers [2011] FMCAfam 1104 at [87] as to your available grounds. Review of registrar’s order A registrar’s powers are set out in FLR 14.04 and Schedule 4 FLR (in WA, FCR 321). For an appli- cation for the review of a registrar’s order e.g. refusal to list urgently, see Bardon [2012] FMCA- fam 1116 (urgent release of funds to brief experts). In the FCFCA use an Application for Review (under FLR 14.05) and, in the FCWA, an Application in a Case (FCR 322). Your application will be heard de novo (FLR 14.07 or FCR 323). Priority Property Pools under $500,000 cases (PPP500 cases) From 1 March 2020 financial cases filed in the Brisbane, Parramatta, Adelaide and Melbourne registries that meet the definition of a PPP500 case will follow the procedure set out in practice direction Priority Property Pools under $500,000 and the Guide for practitioners and parties in Family Law Priority Property Pools under $500,000 cases. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 90 This procedure will not apply if parenting, child support, child maintenance, contravention or en- forcement orders are sought. Parties in such a case must file with their Initiating Application (and Response) a Genuine Steps Certificate and a Financial Summary (instead of a Financial State- ment). The Guide sets out the six steps of a PPP500 case comprising (1) chambers orders made before first court date; (2) first court date before registrar to settle balance sheet and referral of case to conciliation conference, private mediation or legal aid conference; (3) alternative dispute resolu- tion; (4) second court date if the case does not settle, to check balance sheet and refer case to judge); (5) procedural hearing (judge); (6) final hearing (judge). First court event In WA, the first hearing is to be within 42 days after the case starts. The Court will consider any need for urgent or interim orders and case management directions, e.g. for a Case Assessment Conference. In the FCFCA, see Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management. The timeframe is within 1-2 months for directions by a Judicial Registrar. Before that event, each lawyer must provide to the court and each party notice that their client has made a genuine attempt to resolve issues in dispute; of the costs paid and anticipated; likely duration of final hearing and costs thereto; of whether a party is legally aided; and of whether the parties have agreed to privately fund the cost of any expert report and dispute resolution. The Court will make any orders by consent; list any interim hearing; direct any parties who have not complied with the pre-action procedures to do so; identify the issues in dispute and the steps required to resolve them; consider whether the case is suitable for
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: expert report and dispute resolution. The Court will make any orders by consent; list any interim hearing; direct any parties who have not complied with the pre-action procedures to do so; identify the issues in dispute and the steps required to resolve them; consider whether the case is suitable for court-based dispute resolution, having regard to the means and resources of the parties, or whether it is suitable for referral to ex- ternal dispute resolution (or, with the consent of the parties, arbitration); consider whether the case requires individual case management or is so urgent or exceptional that it requires immediate transfer to a judge or Senior Judicial Registrar; and make orders e.g. for future listings, prepara- tion of expert reports, subpoena issuing and exchange of documents. The Court will also consider a timetable for the exchange of any outstanding documents; whether a single expert report should be obtained; and the parties’ views as to the suitability of the case for arbitration. Interim hearings Applications for interim orders will be listed at the first court event having regard to urgency and the need for any report. Before applying, parties must make a reasonable and genuine attempt to arrive at consent orders (FLR 4.03). Not less than 2 business days before an interim hearing, the parties must forward to the associate of the judge or Senior Judicial Registrar a minute of orders sought and an Outline of Case Document (Interim Hearing). In WA a Certificate of Conferral is to be filed with a Form 2 or 2A prior to interim hearings in property cases (CMG 12.3). An interim hearing proceeds on the papers i.e. without viva voce evidence or cross-examination. Parties may only file up to 2 Applications in a Proceeding without leave, unless an urgent “high risk” matter (para 5.22
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: with a Form 2 or 2A prior to interim hearings in property cases (CMG 12.3). An interim hearing proceeds on the papers i.e. without viva voce evidence or cross-examination. Parties may only file up to 2 Applications in a Proceeding without leave, unless an urgent “high risk” matter (para 5.22 of the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 91 Dispute resolution event Within 5 months of filing in the FCFCA, the parties will be referred to a privately funded mediation (if they can afford it) (and/or arbitration, if they agree) OR the case will be listed for a Concilia- tion Conference, a Judicial Settlement Conference or an FDR Conference – at which lawyers will be expected to identify the disputed issues and the relevant evidence. Parties must exchange the documents to be disclosed under Chapter 6 FLR by 14 days before the dispute resolution event and give a Confidential Case Outline Document (Dispute Resolution) to the mediator and parties 7 days beforehand, with a Certificate of Dispute Resolution for completion by the mediator. In WA, a Conciliation Conference will be listed with a Registrar (paras 17 & 21 CMG). The form (NP6) Conciliation Conference Particulars is to be filed and served no later than 14 days before the Conference: FCR 190 and 191. After the dispute resolution event A compulsory offer to settle is to be made within 28 days after any conciliation conference or mediation: FLR 4.11 (in WA, FCR 159). If the case does not settle, the Court (within 6 months of filing if possible) will set it down for a compliance and readiness hearing where a judge or Senior Judicial Registrar will assess whether the parties have complied with all orders; explore whether genuine efforts to resolve the matter have been exhausted and, if so, make directions for a final hearing (and for the parties to file evidence they wish to rely on at that hearing). Parties must file and serve a Certificate of Readiness by 7 days before that hearing. A trial management hearing may be listed, to ensure that the case is ready to proceed to trial. Trial directions and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 2. Check your deadline for applying for property or maintenance orders (“time limit” above).

chunks.text: for the parties to file evidence they wish to rely on at that hearing). Parties must file and serve a Certificate of Readiness by 7 days before that hearing. A trial management hearing may be listed, to ensure that the case is ready to proceed to trial. Trial directions and final hearing For any final hearing, the Central Practice Direction – Family Law Case Management contains standard trial directions that include an exchange of any amended application or response; a consolidated trial affidavit and financial statement; the filing of an Outline of Case Document (Final Hearing) no later than 2 days before the trial date; and a list of authorities to be relied on. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 92 COURT FORMS Forms for use in the FCWA See our link to the FCWA forms here at our eBook and at our online members’ Practice News (“FCWA”). The following are the forms of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia. Applicants • Superannuation Information Kit Before preparing your court papers, have your client complete details on pages 4 and 5 of the document (leave the rest blank, those pages are for the trustee to complete) and forward to the trustee of your client’s superannuation fund. This applies where a party has a superannuation interest, regardless of the type of order being sought and also applies to Applications for Consent Orders. Either attach the completed Kit to your client’s Financial Statement when you file it or file and serve the completed Kit separately, no later than the first court date. See FLR 6.06. • Initiating Application (Family Law) This form may be used for marital or de facto property claims. Insert the final and any interim orders from “precedents” below. Interim orders would be necessary for such orders as an injunction, preser- vation of assets and interim costs. An interim order can be sought after an Initiating Application has been filed by filing an Application in a Proceeding (see “forms”) and an affidavit explaining why the interim order is sought. • Financial Statement Attach a page of expenses not covered by the court form (“financial statement addendum” in “precedents”) and at Part O of the Financial Statement, insert “see attached”. Attach completed Superannuation Information Kit to your Financial Statement if applicable and available. • Affidavit An affidavit should not be filed until you are directed to do so except in support of an interim ap- plication. In FCFCA (Div 2) an interim affidavit can comprise
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Financial Statement, insert “see attached”. Attach completed Superannuation Information Kit to your Financial Statement if applicable and available. • Affidavit An affidavit should not be filed until you are directed to do so except in support of an interim ap- plication. In FCFCA (Div 2) an interim affidavit can comprise 10 pages and 5 annexures without leave. See “precedents” below for sample affidavit of either party for property orders. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 93 • Genuine Steps Certificate as to parties’ compliance with the pre-action procedures of Schedule 1 FLR. • Financial Questionnaire – Not required to be filed if an affidavit is filed with the application. • Undertaking as to Disclosure • Subpoena (to produce documents) For guidelines and precedents see “subpoenas” in chapter “other routine procedures”. • See “court fees” below. If required, complete: – Application for exemption from fees – general (card holders and other categories) – Application for exemption from fees – financial hardship These forms are available here in our eBook and at our online “forms and precedents”. Swear and file the documents via the Commonwealth Courts Portal. (Also see Portal Navigation.) Upon allocation of a date for the first court event, serve the documents including court brochures and notices no later than 3 days before an interim and 7 days before a final hearing. In WA, filing is required via the eCourts Portal of WA. • Prove service of your papers on a party (not a lawyer) by filing process server’s Affidavit of Service with Acknowledgment of Service attached. Experienced process servers will have their own supply of these forms and be able to supply you with a sworn affidavit for filing. • A Reply should be filed and served by an applicant if the respondent applies for orders in a cause of action not brought in the initiating application (e.g. applicant seeks financial orders only and respon- dent applies for parenting orders as well as financial orders). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 94 Respondents • Superannuation Information Kit (see “Superannuation Information Kit” above). • Response to Initiating Application • Financial Statement See “Financial Statement” under “applicants” above. • Affidavit An affidavit should not be filed until you are directed to do so except in support of an interim application. In FCFCA (Div 2) an interim affidavit can comprise 10 pages and 5 annexures without leave. • Genuine Steps Certificate; Financial Questionnaire and Undertaking as to Disclosure (to be filed too as for applicants) • Pay filing fee by credit card when lodging on the Commonwealth Courts Portal (or eCourts Portal of WA). • Swear, file and serve. Where applicant has no lawyer (on whom your papers may be served), arrange personal service by process server as for applicants above. Both parties Consent orders Terms of any settlement may be documented as a consent order, signed by the parties and filed in the court. For the format of these terms (and precedent cover sheets) see “consent orders” in the chapter “other routine procedures”. Later interim applications See “affidavit” above as to the page and annexure limit for interim affidavits. Interim orders (if not sought in the Initiating Application) may be sought after an Initiating Application has been filed, by filing an Application in a Proceeding. Also file and serve an affidavit of applicant explaining the reason for the application. Respondents to such an application must file and serve a Response to an Application in a Proceed- ing and an affidavit in support. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 95 Amended applications Any new orders may be sought by re-filing and serving the application as an “Amended Initiating Appli- cation” showing the new orders sought underlined in red, and “amended” appearing wherever “initiat- ing application” is mentioned). No filing fee is payable. An affidavit setting out the facts relied on for the new orders sought can be contained in an affidavit filed before the final hearing, unless your new orders sought are interim in which case you would have to file another affidavit prior to the interim hearing. While, strictly, leave is required if the amendment is being sought after the first court date or procedural hearing (FLR 2.50; FCR 182), the practice is to file an amendment without leave but seek leave at the next return either formally or if the other side is taking an objection. Financial Statements A Financial Statement may also be updated in either party’s pre-final hearing affidavit if the previous one is out of date. A new Financial Statement must be filed upon any significant change in financial circum- stances (or an affidavit of fewer than 300 words filed instead): FLR 6.06(7); FCR 201. Compulsory offer to settle Note – In a property case, each party must (FLR 4.11; FCR 159) make a genuine settlement offer within 28 days after a Conciliation Conference. The offer must include the statement – “This offer to settle is made under Division 4.2.2 of Part 4.2 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021.” In WA refer to “Division 1 of Part 10 of the Family Court Rules 2021” (FCR 159). A party who withdraws such an offer must, at the same time, make another genuine offer to settle: FLR 4.12 (and, in WA, FCR 160). For more on
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021.” In WA refer to “Division 1 of Part 10 of the Family Court Rules 2021” (FCR 159). A party who withdraws such an offer must, at the same time, make another genuine offer to settle: FLR 4.12 (and, in WA, FCR 160). For more on this, see “offers to settle” in the chapter “other routine procedures”. Need a different court form? A link to each court’s index of forms is available at our website. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 96 COURT FEES (for both courts unless otherwise stated) • Application for Consent Orders $200 • Initiating Application (parenting or financial, final only) $425 • Initiating Application (parenting or financial, final and interim) $570 • Initiating Application (parenting and financial, final only) $695 • Initiating Application (parenting and financial, final and interim) $840 • Response to Initiating Application $425 • Application in a Proceeding $145 • Setting down for final hearing (FCFCA Div 1 and FCWA) $1,045 • Daily hearing fee (excluding first day) (FCFCA Div 1 and FCWA) $1,045 • Setting down for final hearing (FCFCA Div 2 and magistrate FCWA) $770 • Daily hearing fee (excluding first day) (FCFCA Div 2 and magistrate FCWA) $770 • Conciliation conference $480 • Subpoena $65 • Application to register a NZ judgment under the Trans-Tasman Proceedings Act 2010 (Cth) (TTPA) (FCFCA) $130 • Application under TTPA (FCFCA) $145 Note – From 1 January 2013, an application for reduction of fee will only be available for divorce applications: see Chapter 3 (“procedure for divorce applications”). As to the court fees above, an “application for exemption from fees – general” or “application for exemption from fees – financial hardship” (see “court forms” above for both forms) may be lodged on behalf of card holders (and other categories) and those claiming financial hardship respectively. ICLs please note that you are exempt from the interim application fee and the subpoena fee. Note – These fees are current and are now increased annually on 1 July every year. See FL(Fees) Reg. See “court fees” for FCFCA and FCWA. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 97 PRECEDENTS (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) Online precedents The following precedents apply to marital and de facto property claims. They are set out in full below in hard copy and are also available online at our website. LETTERS Note – If child matters are also involved send this as your first letter, and see “procedure” in the “children” chapter as to FDR and other preliminary arrangements. If not, go straight to the next letter. Family dispute resolution letter (to other party or their lawyer) We have been retained by [insert client’s name] in regard to parenting issues. At this stage, we have recommended to our client that you both/the parties discuss arrangements for the [child/children] with the assistance of a Family Dispute Resolution (FDR) practitioner. We find that better progress is usually made at the early stage of a separation by not involving lawyers until after the parties have discussed child issues informally with an FDR person. We have given our client the name of an experienced FDR provider who would be available, namely [insert FDR provider’s name, address and telephone numbers]. Any agreement reached during FDR can be documented and filed in the court as a joint application for binding consent orders. Although FDR is compulsory, would you please confirm that you agree to attending, and let us know of any preferred times. An appointment would then be made for FDR to occur at a convenient time. We suggest the FDR provider’s fee be shared equally, unless for some reason it is not reasonable for the fee to be shared. We look forward to hearing from you soon. Yours faithfully, Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 98 First letter to other party or their lawyer We act for the [husband/wife]. We enclose copies of the following relevant documents: • [His/Her] 3 most recent tax returns and notices of assessment • [His/Her] bank statements for the past 12 months • Completed superannuation information form [if applicable and not already filed] • Trust deed and the 3 latest financial statements for any self-managed super or trust • The 3 latest financial statements and tax returns for any relevant company • Such company’s latest annual return of directors and shareholders • Partnership agreement and 3 latest financial statements for any partnership • Any business activity statement for the 12 months before the first court date • Market appraisal or valuation of any property We request you to forward a copy of your client’s documents and invite your client’s response to our draft asset pool below; the value of each asset; and the parties’ respective contributions and Section 75(2) (or, in a de facto case, Section 90SF(3)) factors. As to the asset pool, we are instructed as follows: [Set out a preliminary asset pool. See “start by drawing up an outline of the asset pool(s)” in “identify and value the net property” above. Next, under the subheading “contributions” specify in summary form e.g. “Parties’ respective financial and other contributions, including contributions for welfare of family, equal.” OR specify any special (usually, financial) contribution as the basis of an unequal assessment. Then, under the subheading “Section 75(2) (or 90SF(3)) factors” specify those factors e.g. “Disparity of income and earning capacity, the capital cost of children not covered by periodic child support, calling for a substantial adjustment in favour of our client.”] We will be issuing proceedings in due course, but confirm our willingness to have settlement discussions
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (or 90SF(3)) factors” specify those factors e.g. “Disparity of income and earning capacity, the capital cost of children not covered by periodic child support, calling for a substantial adjustment in favour of our client.”] We will be issuing proceedings in due course, but confirm our willingness to have settlement discussions with you once document disclosure, valuation and identification of issues have been attended to. [If applicable] As to the question of interim costs, we propose that each party’s lawyer be advanced the sum of $20,000 towards legal costs, to be categorised and ultimately brought into account as a partial property settlement. If you agree, we will then send you a consent order for your signature. Yours faithfully, Note – Send a copy to your client for their information. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 99 Letter to your client [Send your client for their information a copy of the above letter or letters, as applicable] Letter to other party or their lawyer as to valuation We nominate [specify 3 valuers for, say real estate and for any other asset the value of which is unlikely to be agreed] for your selection of a joint valuer of [specify asset to be valued]. Upon your nomination, we will send you a joint brief to valuer for your signature. Yours faithfully, Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 100 Joint letter to valuer (FCFCA) RE: [NAME] – FAMILY LAW MATTER We act for the [husband/wife]. The [wife/husband] is represented by [solicitor’s name]. This firm, jointly with [other solicitor’s name], hereby appoint you as single expert witness to prepare a valuation of the following: [address of property] As this is a joint brief, would you kindly include both of us in any discussions or queries and send each of us your valuation and any correspondence. As the parties have agreed to share your valuation fee, please invoice each of us for half your fee. As your report will be expert evidence before the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia, we en- close: • A copy of Divisions 7.1.4, 7.1.5 and 7.1.6 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021 as to instructions to an expert witness, disclosure of an expert’s report, an expert’s duties and rights and clarification of a single expert’s report. • Prescribed brochure “Experts’ Conference” Please advise what documents and information you require to undertake this valuation. Yours faithfully, Yours faithfully, [your firm] [other solicitor’s firm] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 101 Pre-action procedure letter (to other party or their lawyer) We enclose for your attention: 1. [Where financial orders are being sought] Copy brochure “Before you File – Pre-Action Procedure for Financial Cases” 2. [Where parenting orders are also being sought] Copy brochure “Before You File – Pre-Action Proce- dure for Parenting Cases” This letter is required by the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021 to be sent before the issue of proceedings. [Delete these three lines if parenting orders are not being sought] As family dispute resolution has either been attended by the parties or declined by one or both of them and the parenting dispute remains unresolved, our client intends to begin court proceedings. The issues in dispute [Set out issues in dispute] The court orders to be sought [Set out the orders to be sought – for interim and final orders, see “precedents” below] Our client’s genuine offer to resolve the issues [Set out your/your client’s proposal to resolve the matter] Nominated time We nominate 14 days from the date of this letter within which we require you to reply. You should state in your reply whether our client’s offer is accepted. If it is, then we can prepare an Application for Consent Orders. If not, you are required to set out: • The issues in dispute; • The court orders you/your client seek(s); • Your/your client’s genuine counter-offer to resolve the issues; • Your nominated time for our reply (at least 14 days from your reply). If you fail to respond to this letter within 14 days, we will be free to issue proceedings without further notice. Yours faithfully, Note – Give a copy of this letter and brochure(s) to your client. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: reply (at least 14 days from your reply). If you fail to respond to this letter within 14 days, we will be free to issue proceedings without further notice. Yours faithfully, Note – Give a copy of this letter and brochure(s) to your client. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 102 INTERIM ORDERS SOUGHT (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) (in Application or Response) Interim orders Interim orders – to apply until the final hearing – may be sought in a marital or de facto claim by an applicant in their Initiating Application (or, for later applications, Application in a Proceeding) or by a respondent in their Response to Initiating Application (or Response to Application in a Proceeding) (“forms” above). Precedents for routine interim property orders are set out below, for you to select the ones you need. For any interim child orders, simply add them at the beginning or end of your financial orders sought. De facto property claims For a sample of a declaration sought by a Respondent disputing an applicant’s right to a property order, see “Response” under “precedents” in Chapter 6 except that in para 1.4 substitute “s 90SK” for “s 90SD” being the same geographical requirements as for maintenance but put in a different section for property cases. Also online under “sample interim property orders”. Note – For the next two consent orders, download minutes of consent orders (and their cover sheets) from our website under “consent orders” for chapter “other routine procedures” and then enter the clause you need into the minutes. (Consent order for payment to each party towards interim costs) 1. That the sum of $20,000 be advanced to each party towards their costs or expenses, which will be brought into account by the Court as a partial property settlement upon the final resolution of these proceedings. (Consent order for a partial property settlement for a party) 1. That the sum of $400,000 be advanced to the [Respondent/Applicant] to [enable/assist in] the purchase of a new home prior to the final hearing. 2. That such payment will be brought into
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: upon the final resolution of these proceedings. (Consent order for a partial property settlement for a party) 1. That the sum of $400,000 be advanced to the [Respondent/Applicant] to [enable/assist in] the purchase of a new home prior to the final hearing. 2. That such payment will be brought into account by the Court as a partial property settlement upon the final resolution of these proceedings. Note – For these next orders, download and attach them [headed “Interim orders sought”] as an attachment to your Application or Response, inserting “See attachment” under the form’s section for “interim orders sought”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 103 (Interim injunction against disposal of assets) 1. That the [Respondent] [full name] be and is hereby restrained from selling, encumbering or disposing of the interest of the parties or either of them in the following assets: [Specify each asset in respect of which there is alleged to be a risk of disposal] 2. That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s taxed costs of and incidental to this application. (Inspection or seizure of documents or other property) 1. That the Respondent be and is hereby required to permit the Applicant, alone or with another person, to enter the Respondent’s premises and inspect or seize documents or other property. 2. That this order be made without notice to the Respondent. 3. That the Applicant cause the Respondent to be served with a copy of this order upon its execution. (Leave to proceed out of time) 1. That leave be and is hereby granted to the Applicant under Section 44(3) [or, for de facto claims, Section 44(6)] of the Family Law Act to institute proceedings against the Respondent for orders under Section 79 [or s 90SM ] [and, if spousal maintenance is also being sought, add ‘and Section 72’ (or, for de facto maintenance, ‘and Section 90SF’) of the Act within 14 days after the date of this order.] 2. That the Respondent file and serve a Response to the Initiating Application for final property [and maintenance] orders, an affidavit in support and a Financial Statement within 14 days. 3. That the proceedings be adjourned for mention on [date and time]. What evidence to file? For sample evidence dealing with each of the above, see “affidavits” below. That the Applicant and Respondent do all acts and sign all documents as are necessary to transfer to the Respondent at the expense of the Respondent all of the Applicant’s right, title and interest in the property situate at [address] in the [State/Territory] of [insert] and more particularly described in Certificate of Title Folio Identifier [insert]. 3. In consideration and exchange for the transfer referred to in Order 1 hereof the Applicant shall pay to the Respondent the sum of $[amount] within 30 days after the date of these Orders (“the settlement date”). 4. In consideration and exchange for the transfer referred to in Order 1 hereof the Respondent shall pay to the Applicant the sum of [insert] within 30 days after the date of these Orders (“the settlement date”). 5. To complete the transfer (by “the transferor”) and the payment (by “the transferee”) the following shall apply: 5.1 Settlement will take place on the settlement date. 5.2 The transfer documentation will be prepared by the transferee’s solicitor and delivered to the transferor’s solicitor for signature by the transferor no later than 14 days prior to the settlement date. 5.3.1 [Except in Tas and NT] Settlement will occur by way of electronic conveyance and: (a) The transferor will sign and deliver the transfer documentation to the transferee’s solicitor no later than 14 days

chunks.section: 1. That the [Respondent] [full name] be and is hereby restrained from selling, encumbering

chunks.text: solicitor for signature by the transferor no later than 14 days prior to the settlement date. 5.3.1 [Except in Tas and NT] Settlement will occur by way of electronic conveyance and: (a) The transferor will sign and deliver the transfer documentation to the transferee’s solicitor no later than 14 days prior to the settlement date. (b) Each party will instruct their legal representative to do all acts and things and sign all docu- ments necessary to give effect to the settlement via the electronic conveyancing platform, Property Exchange Australia (“PEXA”). (c) If either party is self-represented at any time, that party will instruct a subscriber to PEXA for the purposes of the settlement, and will meet their own costs of the practitioner instructed by them. (d) The parties will pay their own PEXA fees and if one party meets the other party’s fees at the date of settlement, the party who did not pay their own fees will reimburse the other party within seven (7) days of the date of settlement. 5.3.2 [In Tas and NT] If the transferee requires the return of the transfer for stamping purposes then: (a) The transferee’s solicitor will advise the transferor of this requirement at the time the transfer documentation is delivered. (b) The transferor will then sign and deliver the transfer to the transferee’s solicitor no later than 14 days prior to the settlement date. (c) The transferee’s solicitor will hold the transfer in escrow and use this transfer for stamping purposes only pending settlement. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 105 5.4 If the property is encumbered by mortgage, then: (a) In consideration and exchange for the transfer referred to in Order 1 hereof, the Applicant do all acts and things and sign such documents necessary to procure the Respondent’s release from any liability or claim of the mortgagee in respect of the mortgage; (b) Each of the parties do all acts and things to sign an authority and any other document required by the mortgagee to release the mortgage (“the release documents”); and (c) Each of the parties sign and provide the release documents to the mortgagee in such time- frame necessary to enable the said release to occur on or by the settlement date. 5.5 If the Certificate of Title to the property is held by someone other than the transferor or transferee or mortgagee, then the parties will: (a) Sign an irrevocable authorisation and direction (such document to be prepared by the transferee’s solicitor) to release the Certificate of Title to the transferee’s solicitor and deliver the authorisation document to the transferee’s solicitor no later than 10 days prior to the settlement date. (b) The transferee’s solicitor will use the authorisation and direction to obtain and hold the Certificate of Title (in escrow) pending the settlement. 5.6 Pending the transfer [or sale of the property under Order 9]: (a) The [Applicant/Respondent] shall have the sole right to occupy the property and during such right of occupation the [Applicant/Respondent] shall be responsible for all mortgage payments, rates and outgoings of the property as they fall due up to and including the settlement date. (b) The parties hold their respective interest in the property upon trust pursuant to these Orders. (c) Neither party shall encumber the property without the consent in writing of the other party
