chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 107 9.1 The property shall be listed for sale by private treaty with such real estate agent as is agreed between the parties and failing agreement within 14 days from the date of these Orders the real estate agent will be as nominated by the then [President/CEO] of the Real Estate Institute [full name] at the request of the parties or either of them. 9.2 The list price of the property shall be such amount as is agreed between the parties and failing agreement within 14 days of the date of these Orders the list price will be as nominated by the real estate agent. 9.3 The sale price of the property shall be such amount as is agreed between the parties and failing agreement any offer to buy the property that is at least 80% of the list price shall be accepted by the parties as the sale price. 9.4 The parties are to co-operate in every way with the real estate agent in relation to the marketing of the property for sale including making the key readily available, allowing inspection of the property at all times reasonably requested by the agent and ensuring that the property is clean, neat and in good order at the time of inspection by any prospective buyer. 9.5 That upon agreement being reached for sale of the property the parties shall execute the contract of sale and all other documents necessary to complete the sale of the property including all transfer documentation forthwith upon its submission to them by the agent or their solicitor. 9.6 The contract of sale shall provide for completion within 30 days after the date of the contract. 9.7 The proceeds of sale of the property shall be paid in the following manner and priority: (a)

[insert] to [insert] Bank. (b) Payment of the agent’s commission and advertising or other expenses, if any, payable on the sale. (c) Payment of the legal costs and outlays relating to the sale. In the event that the property is not sold by private treaty pursuant to Order 9 on or before six months from the date of this Order then the Respondent and the Applicant (“the parties”) shall do all acts and sign all documents as are necessary to sell the property by auction and the following shall apply: 10.1 The property shall be listed with the agent appointed under Order 9.1 (hereinafter called “the auctioneer”) for sale by auction within a further 3 months. 10.2 The parties shall execute all documents requested by the auctioneer for sale of the property by auction. 10.3 The reserve price of the property shall be such amount as is agreed between the parties and failing agreement being reached between the parties 21 days prior to the auction, then the reserve price shall be nominated by the auctioneer. chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 112 SUPERANNUATION ORDERS (BY COURTESY OF STEPHEN BOURKE) [Add the applicable super orders to your property orders] Precedent superannuation orders These precedent orders and notes have been supplied by courtesy of Stephen Bourke. Stephen was formerly the head of the Family Law Division of the Commonwealth Attorney-General’s De- partment and project leader on the amendments for superannuation and family law. He consults to other practitioners on superannuation and family law through the consulting practice, Super- Splitting. Stephen is the author of “Super Splitting for Family Lawyers” which is available from www.supersplitting.com.au Index of superannuation orders Accumulation plan, growth phase: a split to retain 7 – 115 non-member spouse interest (fixed amount) in same fund Accumulation plan, growth phase: a split to enable rollover 7 – 116 of fixed amount by non-member to another complying super fund Accumulation plan, growth phase: a split to enable payment 7 – 117 of lump sum to non-member (and release of member) Defined benefit plan, growth phase: payment split calculated 7 – 118 from amount, separate payments made to each party when payments made to member Defined benefit plan, growth phase: a split to create a new interest 7 – 119 (fixed amount) for non-member in same fund or rollover to another fund – if permitted by trust deed Accumulation plan, growth phase: percentage split to retain 7 – 120 non-member spouse interest in same fund Accumulation plan, growth phase: percentage split to enable 7 – 121 rollover of non-member spouse interest to another fund Accumulation plan, growth phase: a split to enable a percentage 7 – 122 to be paid to non-member in a lump sum (and release of member) (value at date of transfer) Self-managed superannuation 7 – 123 Payment phase order (to split pension payments): 7 – 124

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 113 General notes on drafting 1. The splitting of superannuation occurs through the combined operation of two sets of laws. The first set of laws is, of course, the Family Law Act 1975. The second set of laws is the law governing the prudential regulation of superannuation, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and associated regulations as well as the governing rules of the superannuation trusts. 2. All splitting orders require provisions derived from the first set of laws, the Family Law Act 1975. These might be called the mandatory elements. 3. However, provisions in a splitting order relying on superannuation law are not mandatory but may be used depending on the type of superannuation involved. Trustees of superannuation in an accumulation plan are required to observe the operating standards of Part 7A of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations 1994. Trustees of superannuation in a defined benefit plan are bound by the terms of the governing rules of the superannuation trust. 4. Superannuation splitting for de factos in WA is pursuant to Part VIIIC of the Act. See at p 7-56A a schedule of the equivalent legislative provisions when drafting orders and agreements that include such a split. The mandatory elements – the Family Law Act requirements 1. The power of a court exercising jurisdiction under the Family Law Act 1975 in relation to superannuation is a power to split payments (s 90XS). 2. The court does not have the power to order the superannuation trustee to split the underlying superannuation interest. All splitting orders must therefore be made in accordance with that limitation on the court’s power (s 90XT). 3. The trustee of the superannuation plan is a third party to the marriage but is not bound by the terms of the payment splitting order unless
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 1. The splitting of superannuation occurs through the combined operation of two sets of laws.

chunks.text: split the underlying superannuation interest. All splitting orders must therefore be made in accordance with that limitation on the court’s power (s 90XT). 3. The trustee of the superannuation plan is a third party to the marriage but is not bound by the terms of the payment splitting order unless the trustee has been accorded procedural fairness (s 90XZD). 4. The court may make one of three types of payment splitting orders (the first two will be the most frequently used): a. an order which allocates an amount (“the base amount”) – this may be referred to as a type (a) order because it is an order made in accordance with s 90XT(1)(a); b. an order which prescribes a percentage – this may be referred to as a type (b) order because it is an order made in accordance with s 90XT(1)(b); c. an order which prescribes a percentage for the percentage-only interests – this may be referred to as a type (c) order because it is an order made in accordance with s 90XT(1)(c). However, these orders will be quite rare as they would only apply to a few judicial, parliamentary and governors’ superannuation schemes. 5. The four required elements of a payment splitting order are as follows: a. Allocate the base amount or prescribe the percentage, depending on whether the order is a type (a) or a type (b) order; b. Order that the non-member spouse has an entitlement to be paid from payments made to the member spouse; Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 1. The splitting of superannuation occurs through the combined operation of two sets of laws.

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 114 c. Order that the superannuation trustee is to: i. calculate the entitlement of the non-member spouse in accordance with the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025; ii. pay that entitlement whenever the trustee makes a splittable payment (this is the part of the order that binds the trustee); iii. set the operative time. The optional elements – superannuation law 1. Part 7A of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations 1994 requires that trustees of superannuation in an accumulation plan must, upon service of a payment splitting order made under the Family Law Act, create a new interest for the non-member spouse (“the non-member spouse interest”). 2. The trustee is then required to give the non-member spouse three options in relation to that interest: a. Retain that new entitlement for the non-member spouse in that plan; b. Rollover or transfer the entitlement to another complying superannuation plan; or c. Pay the entitlement to the non-member spouse but only if the non-member spouse has met a superannuation condition of release. 3. Trustees of superannuation in a defined benefit plan are not governed by Part 7A of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations but they are required to observe the governing rules of the superannuation trust. These rules may or may not have been amended to mirror the pathway under Part 7A of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations for accumulation plans. It will depend on the particular superannuation plan in question. 4. There are optional elements that may be added to a super splitting order to cover the superannuation law elements in the splitting process. These optional clauses of an order would be in personam orders to define the pathway for a clean break using both family law and superannuation law. 5. However, care needs to be taken that the optional
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 1. The splitting of superannuation occurs through the combined operation of two sets of laws.

chunks.text: a super splitting order to cover the superannuation law elements in the splitting process. These optional clauses of an order would be in personam orders to define the pathway for a clean break using both family law and superannuation law. 5. However, care needs to be taken that the optional elements of the splitting order will bind only the parties to the marriage. The court cannot bind the third party trustee under Part 7A of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations. The optional in personam clauses of the order would direct the parties to do things within the scope of the options under superannuation law such as exercise a request to rollover or transfer to another complying superannuation fund. Remember, the Court has no power under Part VIIIB of the Family Law Act to bind the superannuation trustee in this area. 6. Notations may also be made to a splitting order noting that the superannuation trustee will have additional obligations under: a. Part 7A of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (in the case of trustees of superannuation in an accumulation plan); or b. the governing rules of the superannuation trust (in the case of trustees of superannuation in a defined benefit plan and only if the rules of the plan have been amended). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 115 Guide to these superannuation orders The following precedents provide a guide for the most common types of splitting of superannuation – accumulation plans (about 50% of all superannuation), defined benefit plans (such as government schemes and large corporations) (about 20%) and self-managed superannuation funds (about 30%). Select and download the set of orders you require from our online precedents. The field codes for your entry of applicable particulars are as follows: 96 = base amount 97 = non-member spouse (or de facto partner) 98 = member spouse (or de facto partner) 99 = name of fund 101 = specified percentage Accumulation plan, growth phase: a split to retain the non-member spouse interest (fixed amount) in same fund 1. That in accordance with Section 90XT(4) of the Family Law Act 1975, a base amount of $[`96`] is allocated to the [`97`] out of [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 2. That, in accordance with Section 90XT(1)(a) of the Family Law Act 1975: a. [`97`] (or [`97`]’s administrators, executors, beneficiaries, heirs or assigns) is entitled to be paid, using the base amount allocated in the immediately preceding order, the amount calculated in accordance with Part 6 of the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025; and b. the entitlement of [`98`] in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund (or the entitlement of such other person who becomes entitled to receive a payment out of [`98`]’s superannuation interest) [Note – this refers to the beneficiary of a deceased estate] is correspondingly reduced by force of this Order. 3. That the trustee of the [`99`] Superannuation Fund (“the trustee”) shall do all such acts and things and sign all such documents as may be necessary to: a. calculate, in accordance with the requirements of the Family Law Act 1975 the entitlement awarded to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 1. The splitting of superannuation occurs through the combined operation of two sets of laws.

chunks.text: by force of this Order. 3. That the trustee of the [`99`] Superannuation Fund (“the trustee”) shall do all such acts and things and sign all such documents as may be necessary to: a. calculate, in accordance with the requirements of the Family Law Act 1975 the entitlement awarded to the [`97`] in the immediately preceding clause of this Order; and b. pay the entitlement whenever the trustee makes a splittable payment from [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 4. That this order has effect from the operative time and the operative time is the beginning of the day on the date of valuation of the said interest, being [insert date of valuation]. 5. That, after service of the payment split notice in accordance with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations 1994 (“the SIS Regulations”), the [`97`] shall do all such things and sign all such documents as may be necessary, including but not limited to exercising the [`97`]’s request in accordance with the SIS Regulations, for the retention of the non-member spouse interest in the [`97`]’s name in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. That the trustee of the [`99`] Superannuation Fund do all such acts and things and sign all such documents as may be necessary to: a. calculate, in accordance with the requirements of the Family Law Act 1975 and the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025 the entitlement awarded to the [`97`] in the immediately preceding clause of this Order; b. pay the entitlement whenever the trustee makes a splittable payment from [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 3. That this Order has effect from the operative time and the operative time is the beginning of the day upon which this order is made. 4. That, after service of the payment split notice in accordance with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations 1994 (“the SIS Regulations”), the [`97`] shall do all such things and sign all such documents as may be necessary, including but not limited to exercising the [`97`]’s request in accordance with the SIS Regulations, for the payment of the non-member spouse interest in the [`97`]’s name in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 5. That
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 123 Self-managed superannuation The splitting of a super entitlement in a self-managed super fund (SMSF) can be complex, especially where the structures and investments within the super fund are complex and elaborate. There may be a unit trust structure over the super fund or the fund may have business premises as an investment either with or without a unit trust. The splitting of this form of super not only involves the payment splitting pro- visions under the FLA but also considerations of how to split the investments of the SMSF. In general, the precedent orders set out above for super interests held in an accumulation plan can be applied to the self-managed context since super in a self-managed plan is accumulation style super. However, if you are in any doubt about how to deal with this form of superannuation or the split departs from a standard cash transfer to another complying superannuation fund, seek specialist advice (either from your barrister or a specialist recommended by your counsel) to avoid having to notify your insurer about a possible negligence claim. Explain to your client that complex superannuation involves specialist advice about how to disentangle the fund. A typical self-managed superannuation plan will have the husband and wife as members. The entitle- ments will typically be disparate. Part of the settlement may be that one of the parties agrees to leave the superannuation fund and rollover their entitlement to another complying superannuation fund. An order to achieve this (to be added to any splitting order) follows: 1. That the [husband/wife] do all such acts and things and sign all such documents, including but not limited to the signing of trustee minutes, rollover requests and related documents, that may be necessary to rollover or transfer the entitlement of the [husband/wife]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: be added to any splitting order) follows: 1. That the [husband/wife] do all such acts and things and sign all such documents, including but not limited to the signing of trustee minutes, rollover requests and related documents, that may be necessary to rollover or transfer the entitlement of the [husband/wife] in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund to another complying superannuation fund of the [husband/wife]’s choosing. Editor’s note i) Ensure the SMSF is a compliant fund. Refer to the compliance audit accompanying the fund’s annual financial statements or the fund’s accountant. Rectify any non-compliance via an accountant or super fund specialist; ii) Consider each member’s balance and, if one party is to roll out their interest or a newly created inter- est post-split, how that will work in practice. If it will require an in specie transfer of property (e.g. shares) we suggest this clause (as well as any splitting/roll out clause from the accumulation plan precedents above): For the purpose of paras [insert para nos of roll-over/transfer of transferable benefits clauses] the trustee on behalf of the fund shall transfer its right, title and interest in and to the following property to the [name of transferee fund]: x.1 the sum of [insert cash amount]; and x.2 [number of] shares in [relevant company name]; the said transfers to constitute [part/the entirety] of the wife’s transferable benefits [and existing member’s interest] in the fund, and that the wife otherwise abandon in favour of the husband any further right, title and interest that she may otherwise have in or to the fund; iii) An individual cannot be a sole trustee and member of a SMSF. Where both spouses were trustees and one resigns the remaining trustee should appoint another person (who may become a member) or a corporate trustee; and iv) Obtain a copy
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: may otherwise have in or to the fund; iii) An individual cannot be a sole trustee and member of a SMSF. Where both spouses were trustees and one resigns the remaining trustee should appoint another person (who may become a member) or a corporate trustee; and iv) Obtain a copy of and read the trust deed. The rules of all super interests (this applies to commercial funds too) can differ, based on the terms on which the trustee holds the members’ interests. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 124 Payment phase orders There will be occasions where the superannuation is in payment phase and the order required is an order to split ongoing pension payments. The type of order will depend on the type of superannuation being paid – account based pensions or defined benefit pensions. Account based pensions (or allocated pensions) Account based pensions are paid from a superannuation account which has a sum invested with sufficient liquidity so that the amount available for draw down is within the prescribed band under superannuation law. Superannuation law prescribes that the rate of draw down must be between 4% and 10% per annum of the lump sum invested to fund the pension. Once the lump sum is exhausted, the pension ceases. An order for the splitting of an account based pension will identify the amount or the percentage of the invested lump sum to be allocated to the non-member spouse. The type (a) order or a base amount order (an order made in accordance with s 90XT(1)(a) of the Family Law Act) may be used. In the alternative, the type (b) order or a percentage order (an order made in accordance with s 90XT(1)(b)) may be used. Type (a) order 1. That in accordance with section 90XT(4) of the Family Law Act 1975, a base amount of $[`96`] is allocated to the [`97`] out of [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 2. That, in accordance with section 90XT(1)(a) of the Family Law Act 1975: a. [`97`] (or [`97`]’s administrators, executors, beneficiaries, heirs or assigns) is entitled to be paid, using the base amount allocated in the immediately preceding order, the amount calculated in accordance with Part 6 of the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025; and b. the entitlement of [`98`] in the [`99`] Superannuation
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a. [`97`] (or [`97`]’s administrators, executors, beneficiaries, heirs or assigns) is entitled to be paid, using the base amount allocated in the immediately preceding order, the amount calculated in accordance with Part 6 of the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025; and b. the entitlement of [`98`] in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund (or the entitlement of such other person who becomes entitled to receive a payment out of [`98`]’s superannuation interest) is correspondingly reduced by force of this Order. 3. That the trustee of the [`99`] Superannuation Fund (“the trustee”) shall do all such acts and things and sign all such documents as may be necessary to: a. calculate, in accordance with the requirements of the Family Law Act 1975 the entitlement awarded to the [`97`] in the immediately preceding clause of this Order; and b. pay the entitlement whenever the trustee makes a splittable payment from [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 4. That this order has effect from the operative time and the operative time is the beginning of the day on the date of valuation of the said interest, being [insert date of valuation]. 5. That, after service of the payment split notice in accordance with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations 1994 (“the SIS Regulations”), the [`97`] shall do all such things and sign all such documents as may be necessary, including but not limited to exercising the [`97`]`s request in accordance with the SIS Regulations, for the retention of the non-member spouse interest in the [`97`]’s name in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 126 Defined benefit pensions A defined benefit pension will typically be paid by a State, Territory or Federal Government superannuation scheme. Judicial and parliamentary pensions as well as public service pensions are examples. Lawyers may also find examples of defined benefit pensions in payment where the member was employed as an executive in a large corporation. Where the order is an order to split the ongoing payments of the defined benefit pension, the order of choice is the type (b) order or the percentage order. However, care should be taken in cases where the governing rules of the defined benefit superannuation plan have been amended to require the trustee to create separate pension entitlement. The new entitlement may be actuarially determined and the annual amount may not be the same as the member’s amount because of age and gender differences in the actuarial calculations. Lawyers should also note that the operative time is 7 days after service of the order on the trustee on the basis that the computer systems of the superannuation administration may need additional time to commence the splitting of the pension payments. The following is an order to split the ongoing pension payments. 1. That, in accordance with section 90XT(1)(b) of the Family Law Act 1975: a. the [`97`] (or the [`97`]’s administrators, executors, beneficiaries, heirs or assigns) is entitled to be paid the specified percentage out of the [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund; b. the [`98`]’s entitlement (or the entitlement of such other person to whom a payment may be made out of the [`98`]’s interest) in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund, is correspondingly reduced by force of this Order; and c. the percentage specified for the purposes of this Order is [`101`]%. 2. That the trustee of the [`99`]
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: entitlement of such other person to whom a payment may be made out of the [`98`]’s interest) in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund, is correspondingly reduced by force of this Order; and c. the percentage specified for the purposes of this Order is [`101`]%. 2. That the trustee of the [`99`] Superannuation Fund do all such acts and things and sign all such documents as may be necessary to: a. calculate, in accordance with the requirements of the Family Law Act 1975 and the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025 the entitlement awarded to the [`97`] in the immediately preceding clause of this Order; b. pay the entitlement whenever the trustee makes a splittable payment from [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] Superannuation Fund. 3. That this Order has effect from the operative time and the operative time is the beginning of the day upon which this order is made. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 127 Flagging orders The flagging order is an order to prevent the trustee from making any splittable payments while the flag is in place. It may be used where the member is on the cusp of payment and there is concern that the member may abscond with the superannuation. While it is called a “flagging order”, the text of the section directs the trustee not to make any splittable payments. An example follows: 1. That in accordance with section 90XU(1)(a) of the Family Law Act 1975, the trustee of the [`99`] superannuation fund is directed not to make any splittable payments out of the [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] superannuation fund without leave of the Court. 2. The [`98`] shall notify the [`97`] within twenty-eight (28) days prior to making an application to the Trustee for any payment out of the [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] superannuation fund. 3. That in accordance with section 90XU(1)(b) of the Family Law Act 1975, the Trustee of the [`99`] superannuation fund is to notify the Court within the period specified in the immediately succeeding clause of this order of the next occasion that a splittable payment becomes payable out of the [`98`]’s interest in the [`99`] superannuation fund. 4. That the period specified for the purposes of the immediately preceding clause of this order is a period which commences 14 days prior to the next occasion that a splittable payment becomes payable out of the ‘98’s interest in the ’99’ superannuation fund and ceases 14 days after that occasion. In Zoller [2012] FamCA 47 Murphy J granted an ex parte flagging order under s 90XU due to the pros- pect of the husband withdrawing super from his pension plan, being “a substantial part of the property of the parties”. Editor’s
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: superannuation fund and ceases 14 days after that occasion. In Zoller [2012] FamCA 47 Murphy J granted an ex parte flagging order under s 90XU due to the pros- pect of the husband withdrawing super from his pension plan, being “a substantial part of the property of the parties”. Editor’s note as to operative time The “operative time” for a split differs between orders and superannuation agreements: s 90XD. The section defines the operative time for a split under an order as “the time specified in the or- der” (Stephen Bourke’s view being that that time should be the time of valuation). A split under an agreement “has the meaning given by s 90XI”, which prescribes “the beginning of the fourth busi- ness day after the day on which a copy of the agreement is served on the trustee” as the operative time. The courts, however, have been seen to be making orders in which the operative time is the fourth business day after service of the order on the trustee (with the result that trustees have begun requiring draft orders to be so worded). Stephen Bourke (author of the above precedents) sees at least three problems with this approach. 1. If a non-member should die between the order and the operative time 4 business days after service of the order i.e after the court (having made a final order) is functus officio, s 90XZC (which allows a payment split where a non-member dies after the operative time for a split to be implemented by the executor of the deceased’s estate or to continue if it has been imple- mented) would not keep the split alive for non-members who die after the court is functus officio but before the order is operative. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 128 2. Depending on: a) the date of valuation; b) the time that has elapsed between valuation and implementation; c) the type of fund; and d) the investment returns secured by the trustee. setting the operative time 4 business days after service will have financial consequences for both the member and the non-member. In accumulation plans, the non-member will be disadvantaged in times of positive returns and the member will be disadvantaged in times of negative returns. In defined benefit superannuation, the non-member will be disadvantaged. And in self-managed superannuation funds the loss will depend on a comparison between investment returns and the statutory rate under Reg 45D of the Family Law (Superannuation) Regulations 2025. 3. The third issue, Stephen says, is that it is not unknown for lawyers to overlook serving the order on the trustee. This means that where the operative time under an order is linked to service of the order, the order may in some cases never become operative or not become operative for some time. Stephen suggests that where trustees require a “4 business days” operative time you advise them that you will comply with their request if they agree in writing to pay the damages to the party who may be disadvantaged as well as the cost of any litigation to remedy the consequences of Scenario 1 or Scenario 2 occurring (the death of the non-member before their required operative time and investment losses). As for Scenario 3, your use of precedents that link the operative time to service of the order could be a liability headache for you if service of the order on the trustee is overlooked. The above precedents have been amended by Stephen Bourke in respect of “operative time” with a view to avoiding these problems.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: of precedents that link the operative time to service of the order could be a liability headache for you if service of the order on the trustee is overlooked. The above precedents have been amended by Stephen Bourke in respect of “operative time” with a view to avoiding these problems. OTHER FINAL ORDERS (Setting aside or variation of property order) 1. That the order made by the [specify] Court on [date] be set aside. [Then, in separate paragraphs, set out the new order sought] [OR if your client only seeks a variation of a paragraph or two] 1. That the order made by the [specify] Court on [date] be varied so as to delete paragraphs [specify paragraph numbers sought to be deleted] and substitute the following paragraph(s). [insert the new paragraphs]. What evidence to file? For sample affidavits dealing with each of the above final orders, see “affidavits” below. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 129 AFFIDAVITS (MARITAL AND DE FACTO) A suggestion about affidavits Being the sworn evidence of the person making it, filed in support of a party’s case, an affidavit should use the witness’s simple everyday language, not your own legalese. The precedent sub-headings should help guide you through the relevant facts and issues involved. An affidavit in support of an application for interim orders may include hearsay evidence (“I was told by…”) if the deponent states their source of information, but an affidavit in support of final orders does not allow that and the offending statements would be struck out as being inadmissible. Opinion and feelings are not allowed (except from an expert witness), so avoid “I believe…”, “I feel...” and “I submit…” and for the sake of credibility, check all your figures with care. Feel free to email your draft affidavit and orders sought to counsel to settle before you file them. See a paper “Affidavits, Objectionable material in” by Newcastle barrister John Hamilton at our online members’ Archive. A note about the following precedents As the first affidavit below (after the Financial Statement Addendum sheet) includes sample evidence for different interim (and final) orders, simply delete what you do not need. The affidavit may be filed either with an Application or a Response. Leave to proceed out of time is an interim order, so your application should also seek the final orders your client will be seeking if leave is granted. Its affidavit in support is set out below. Variation of a property order is a final order. A NOTE ABOUT INTERIM AFFIDAVITS An affidavit may be relied on at an interim hearing if it does not exceed 25 pages and contain more than 10 annexures unless leave is granted by the court: FLR 5.08 (cf.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: set out below. Variation of a property order is a final order. A NOTE ABOUT INTERIM AFFIDAVITS An affidavit may be relied on at an interim hearing if it does not exceed 25 pages and contain more than 10 annexures unless leave is granted by the court: FLR 5.08 (cf. FCR 84 in WA). If leave is sought, apply for an order “that leave be granted to [etc] to rely upon the affidavit of [name of deponent] notwithstanding its non-compliance with Rule 5.08 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021” and each affidavit should contain facts relevant to why leave should be granted for further material e.g. multiple issues needing to be ad- dressed at the interim hearing: complexity; financial issues that could not otherwise be addressed via discovery or subpoena). For general provisions about interlocutory applications, see FLR 5.01-5.10 and Central Practice Directions 5.15-5.25. A respondent may file a longer affidavit if they are responding to both interim and final issues: Genesalio [2020] FamCAFC 113 at [131]-[134]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 131 OTHER EXPENSES PER WEEK FOR ME ($) FOR CHILDREN ($) OTHER ADULTS ($) PET FOOD VETERINARIAN EXPENSES KENNEL EXPENSES DURING HOLIDAYS SICKNESS AND ACCIDENT INSURANCE COSTS SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS OTHER INSURANCE OR PENSION CONTRIBUTIONS OFFICE OR WORK CLOTHING FARES TO AND FROM WORK TOLL CHARGES SELF-EDUCATION COSTS CHILD CARE COSTS LUNCHES ACCOUNTANCY COSTS LEGAL FEES (PAID BY INSTALMENTS) COMPUTER, SOFTWARE, INTERNET OTHER SUB TOTAL PLUS EXPENSES FROM PART N ABOVE TOTAL A suggestion about Financial Statements Clients should be realistic with their expenses, and not go overboard. Where not explainable, as an identifiable depletion of capital or credit card or other debt, an extreme deficit of expenses (total of Parts G, N and O) over income has no credibility: see M & M (McCrossen) [2006] FamCA 868 at [53] where “gross exaggeration” of the wife’s alleged “necessary commitments” did not help her case. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

It is adaptable for either a spouse or de facto partner. I, [FULL NAME IN CAPITALS] of [address] in the [State/Territory] of [name], [occupation] make oath and say: Introduction 1. The children are now attending [specify each

chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 133 Declaration sought [if applicable] 14. [If the Respondent in a de facto claim has applied for a declaration as to the non-existence of a de facto relationship or other matter under s 90RD, they should here set out in detail the facts on which they rely in support of their application that the Applicant is not entitled to a property order.] Interim injunction against disposal of assets (delete if not applicable) 14. Note – If the injunction is sought urgently (although see “when not to apply for an injunction” under “interim injunctions to preserve property” above), you are unlikely to have time to complete the detailed sections set out below. In that case, leave them to a later affidavit and concentrate on the evidence in support of the injunction application, inserting some paragraphs here that: • Give a rough estimate of the parties’ assets and liabilities, and superannuation • State that your client’s property claim is based partly on their financial, homemaker, parent and any other contributions throughout the relationship • State that their case is also based on their current needs, the capital cost of children, disparity of income, any other economic disadvantage such as a career forgone in the support of family and the respondent’s own career (as applicable) • Specify your and your client’s attempts to warn the respondent off disposing of the asset; and the respondent’s actions and any statements by respondent – quoted verbatim) that indicate an intention to dispose of the asset in question • Indicate the approximate value of the item and that its significance is such that disposal of the asset may defeat part of your client’s recovery (again, see “when not to apply for an injunction” above) • Attach a copy of any relevant title search •
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the asset in question • Indicate the approximate value of the item and that its significance is such that disposal of the asset may defeat part of your client’s recovery (again, see “when not to apply for an injunction” above) • Attach a copy of any relevant title search • Any other evidence relevant to injunction sought Inspection or seizure of documents or other property (delete if not applicable) 15. Note – See “when and what to file” under “seizure of documents or other property” under “interim injunctions to preserve property” above. In the event of urgency, follow the same guidance given in the preceding paragraph for injunctions, except that your evidence as to the respondent’s conduct will be directed to respondent’s refusal or failure to respond to your request for full discovery of documents or production of the asset for valuation. Then add in compliance with FLR 5.19(3) (in WA, FCR. 230(3)): • a description of the document or property to be seized or inspected • the address of the premises where the order is to be carried out • the reason the applicant believes the respondent may remove, destroy or alter the document or property unless the order is made • a statement about the damage the applicant is likely to suffer if the order is not made • a statement about the value of the property to be seized Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 134 • if permission is granted, the name of the person (if any) who the applicant wishes to accompany the applicant to the respondent’s premises. Also – You will usually apply without notice to the respondent (ex parte) so as to have the benefit of surprise. This requires you to comply with FLR 5.11 (in WA, FCR 87) by your affidavit stating: • That shortening the time for service of the application and the fixing of an early date for hearing after service would not be more appropriate because to do so would alert the respondent to the application and enable him to further his refusal or failure to disclose or produce the document or asset by destroying or more permanently concealing it • That an order should be made without notice to the other party in light of the respondent’s past refusal or failure to disclose or produce • whether there is a history or allegation of child abuse or family violence between the parties • whether there has been a previous case between the parties and, if so, the nature of the case • the particulars of any orders currently in force between the parties • whether there has been a breach of a previous order by a party to the case • whether the respondent or the respondent’s lawyer has been told of the intention to make the application • whether there is likely to be any hardship, danger or prejudice to the respondent, a child or a third party if the order is made • the capacity of the applicant to give an undertaking as to damages • the nature of the damage or harm that may result if the order is not made • why the order must be urgently made
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

We agreed that I would stop working when we began a family, so that I could devote all of my time to home and family, taking on such part-time work as I could manage; and that he would continue working full-time, pursuing advancement as much as he could. chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 137 History of financial contributions Note – If you have it in writing from the other side that contributions are agreed as being equal, just insert a subheading “Contributions” under which, in a numbered paragraph, state “It has been agreed that our respective financial, non-financial and family welfare contributions should be treated as equal.” Then skip this and the next few sections, and continue with “our current financial circumstances”. If not, set out all direct and indirect financial contributions either by your client or his parents or others on his behalf to the purchase, maintenance or improvement of any property of either party during the relationship (whether currently or previously owned). In de facto claims, if your client is relying on having made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a), (b), or (c), and serious injustice, to establish their geographical requirement under s 90SK, specify all such contributions and the likely serious injustice if the order sought is not made. 24. I would reconcile all of the credit card payments with our bank statements. 34. I am also the company’s secretary and, until I left in [date], its salaried manager. 35. During our [number] years together, in my position of company secretary and manager of our company’s affairs, I performed all of our bookkeeping. Our accountant organised [X]’s contracting into a small business concern, and I had to keep a record of all expenses and income. I also paid all accounts that came in and did all of our banking. I prepared and issued annual PAYG payment summaries. I did all the paperwork that the accountant required for our individual, company and our self-managed superannuation fund tax returns. When GST was introduced on 1 July 2000 I had to prepare the quarterly activity statements. I had to deal with any paperwork that required attention. When we decided to split up in [date], [X] asked me to show him what he had to do to take over this work from me. 36. We let our property at [address] from [year] to [month and year]. While I was doing these things at night, as well as feeding or settling the babies, [X] would watch television. On week days after work he would watch television until going to bed. 50. I had to feed, bath and comfort a baby and look after a toddler. While doing so when [X] was home he was either watching television or reading the newspaper. chunks.text: PROPERTY 7 – 143 Disparity of income and earning capacity 95. [X] enjoys a high income of $[amount] and the potential for a substantial future earning capacity. 96. I have referred to my having no income once [X]’s support ends, and to my forgoing director’s fees and salary from our company when this case is over. 97. [If applicable] My agreed role as homemaker has adversely affected me by my withdrawal from the workforce and need to try to re-enter it as a middle-aged, unskilled person now that we are separated and heading for divorce. I seek a property settlement that fairly makes up for that financial and career disadvantage, over and beyond a splitting order for a proper share in our superannuation. 98. I am now [age] years of age and my skills as a [former occupation] are now [number] years out of date. I calculate that but for our marriage, I would have continued in my employment as a [specify] from [year] and progressed until normal retirement age in that career to the same extent of a close friend of mine [name] who graduated when I did and is currently a [position]. 99. I refer to the affidavit of the job consultant [name] filed on my behalf as to my employment status and salary range had I continued working in [year, as above] and kept doing so until normal retirement age. Note – An affidavit should be obtained and filed by such a career expert as a career consultant, because your client is not able to go on and say what someone else may be earning, as that would be hearsay and therefore inadmissible. Such a witness may be asked to assume your client’s qualifications; the year she held them and the years available for advancement had she

Other matters 100. [Add any of the following matters from s 79(4) or 90SM(4) that have not already been dealt with above.] (d) the effect of any proposed order upon the earning capacity of either party (typically where a farmer resists the spouse’s attempt to sell the family farm because such an order would effectively destroy the farmer’s means of livelihood); (e) any relevant factors under s 75(2) (or s 90SF(3) in de facto claims) not covered above (see “factors to be taken into account” earlier in this chapter); (f) any other order made under the Act affecting a party or child; and (g) any child support that a party has provided, or is to or might be liable to provide in the future. 101. chunks.text: CHAPTER SEVEN 7 – 152 Note – This covers the happening of relevant events since the order which cannot reasonably have been foreseen, which will have the effect of causing an injustice to the applicant if an order is not made reflecting such events. • default in carrying out an obligation imposed by the order and, in the circumstances that have arisen as a result of that default, it is just and equitable to set aside or vary the order Note – This usually deals with payment or enforcement problems being experienced under the order where it may be just and equitable for a compliant applicant to be granted a variation of a payment clause, or a new order for more effective enforcement against a non-compliant other party. • exceptional circumstances since the order relating to the care, welfare and development of a child where the child or applicant will suffer hardship if the order is not set aside or varied Note – An example of this would be a serious illness of a child causing the need for remodelling of the house in which the child lived, which could not be met out of increased maintenance but only out of an increased share of capital; or some other unexpected change in circumstances since the order. • a proceeds of crime order has been made covering property of the parties or either of them, or has been made against a party 11. All the above facts are within my own knowledge except those which are deposed to from information only, my means of knowledge and sources of information for which appear in this affidavit. Note – A Financial Statement must also be filed. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 2 CONSENT ORDERS Parties to a proceeding may apply for a consent order as follows: Proceedings pending • Orally during a court hearing • By tendering a draft consent order to a judicial officer during a court event • By lodging a draft consent order See FLR 10.04(1) and, in WA, FCR 166(1)(a). Proceedings not pending • By filing an Application for Consent Orders in the FCFCA or FCWA: see FLR 10.04(4) and, in WA, FCR 166(1)(b). Signed during a court event Hand-written minutes of consent orders may be drawn up and signed during a court event (as defined in FLR 1.05(1) and FCR 4), then handed up to the judicial officer who will then direct the applicant’s solici- tor to arrange for a typed copy of the minutes to be emailed to the court. The email address is usually provided by the judicial officer on the day. Add cover sheets for the order (for procedure and precedent, see “signed in your office” below). The court will then seal the order and upload an e-version of the order to the Courts Portal to download. The format (below and available at our website) SMITH [PARTIES’ SURNAME]: 100/2009 [COURT FILE NUMBER] MINUTES OF CONSENT ORDERS 1. That [insert orders, for samples of which see “interim orders sought” and “final orders sought under “precedents” in the relevant chapter]. 2. [etc] DATED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– SIGNED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– [APPLICANT/APPLICANT’S LAWYER] [RESPONDENT/RESPONDENT’S LAWYER] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 3 Signed in your office – for filing in pending FCFCA proceedings Note – In the FCWA the consent terms are to be documented within the Court’s Minute of Consent Orders with (in a parenting case) a Consent Order Annexure as to any allegations of abuse, both forms being available at our online members’ practice news (“FCWA”). What to file? File by emailing the docketed judge’s associate or (if that address is not known) the registry (with a copy to the other party): • in Word form, two cover sheets in the form below and unsigned minutes • a PDF and a Word version of the original signed Consent Orders (in the form below and available at our website) • (in a parenting case) an Annexure to Proposed Consent Parenting Order (Current Case) as to any allegations or concerns about child abuse or family violence pursuant to FLR 10.05. • a covering letter (the content of which should be agreed between the solicitors for each party), citing the name and court file number, in which you refer to the orders as being interim or final, as appli- cable, and request that sealed orders issue in due course • (for a consent order splitting superannuation) an affidavit from a lawyer that the superannuation interest has been valued, and the superannuation trustee given procedural fairness (for precedent, see “affidavit in support of superannuation split” below and available at our website) Note – That affidavit sets out your obligations in the event of a consent order that includes the making of a splitting order. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 5 FAMILY LAW ACT 1975 IN THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA AT [REGISTRY] FILE NO: [Court file number] of [year] BETWEEN: [APPLICANT’S FULL NAME] (Applicant) AND [RESPONDENT’S FULL NAME] (Respondent) BEFORE A REGISTRAR THE DAY OF 20 [Leave blank] UPON APPLICATION TO THE COURT IT IS ORDERED: 1. BY CONSENT and pursuant to Part 10.2 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021, orders, declarations and notations are made in terms of the Consent Orders at- tached. 2. (For child orders) Pursuant to Section 65DA(2) of the Family Law Act 1975 the particulars of the obligations these orders create and the consequences that may follow if a person contravenes these orders are attached and are included in these orders. 3. This is an Order to which Section 77A of the Family Law Act applies pursuant to Order No. [insert] as contained herein/There are no orders for maintenance contained herein. 4. That this matter be removed from the Pending Cases List. By the Court Registrar Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 6 FAMILY LAW ACT 1975 IN THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA AT [REGISTRY] File no: [Court file number] of [year] BETWEEN: [APPLICANT’S FULL NAME] (Applicant) AND [RESPONDENT’S FULL NAME] (Respondent) CONSENT ORDERS BY CONSENT IT IS ORDERED 1. That [insert orders, for samples of which see “interim orders sought” and “final orders sought” under “precedent” in the relevant chapter]. 2. [etc] Signed by the Applicant Signed by the Respondent Dated: ........../........../20 Dated: ........../........../20 Note – Each page of the settlement terms should end with the date and signature provision set out. If there is an ICL, add a provision for their signature. Each party is to sign at the end of each page of the terms. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 7 Application for Consent Orders – no pending proceedings If you have negotiated a settlement without having to issue court proceedings, you may document and file it as an Application for Consent Orders (in the FCFCA or, in the FCWA, a Form 11 available at our online members’ practice news (“FCWA”)). A tip Because your local State Magistrates Court may also receive such an application (check first that it still has a family law list), some lawyers make it a practice of filing an Application for Consent Orders there instead. Before doing so, however, consider the implications of s 47A(1) of the FLA (this does not apply to a family law magistrate of WA: s 47A(2)). Section 47A provides that: • a party to an order from a court of summary jurisdiction can appeal to the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Division 1) • they may do so within 28 days (FLR 13.03) • such an appeal is as of right (no grounds of appeal need to be established) • the matter will be heard de novo (afresh, not limited to a point of law) The fact that the order was made by consent is not a valid objection to a rehearing: Robinson & Willis [1982] FamCA 16. You can avoid giving disgruntled parties an easy avenue for changing their mind by filing all your Applications for Consent Orders in the FCFCA or FCWA. Effect of delay in filing the Application A respondent’s consent to an application for consent orders lapses if 90 days have passed since the date of the first affidavit in the Application: FLR 10.08 In the event of such delay between signature by the parties, the first party should re-swear their affidavit prior to the second party signing. Update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 8 What to file? Note – This procedure is adaptable in WA by using the FCWA’s Minute of Consent Orders available at “forms” at our online members’ Practice News (“FCWA”). Prepare and eFile at the comcourts portal: 1. Application for Consent Orders (also available online at our website) 2. Cover sheets and draft consent order as per Application for Consent Orders – Proposed Orders Template 3. (If seeking a super splitting order by consent) file a lawyer’s affidavit as to valuation and procedural fairness (see “affidavit in support of superannuation split” below) 4. Brochure “Compliance with parenting orders”. If seeking a parenting order, attach this to the minutes 5. (For a parenting order) a Notice of child abuse, family violence or risk 6. If your Application is requisitioned for any irregularity, you will receive a letter or email from the court, referring you to the matters requiring attention. When you have attended to those matters, you may re-file the Application. 7. Once the Application for Consent Orders is approved by the Court a sealed copy of the orders may be downloaded from the portal. Filing fee? $200 Opting-in by de factos separating before 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA) An opt-in and lawyer’s statement to attach to Answer 29 of the Application for Consent Orders, if applicable, is available at our online precedents (via a keyword search for “opting in”). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IN THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 9 Affidavit in support of superannuation split by consent 1. I am a lawyer in the employ of [insert], lawyers for the Applicant Husband [full name] (“the husband”). 2. On [date] I was instructed to prepare minutes of consent orders for a final property settlement between the parties. 3. The draft minutes prepared by me are attached and marked “A” (“the minutes”). 4. Paragraphs [insert] to [insert] of the minutes propose that an order be made to split a base amount of $[amount] from the husband’s member interest in [insert] superannuation fund and that the wife [full name] have the option to then roll that amount over into a superannuation fund of her choice. 5. On [date] I wrote to the trustee of that fund (“the trustee”) putting them on notice of the proposed order as required by Rule 10.06 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. Attached and marked “B” is a true copy of my letter to the trustee. 6. On [date] I received a letter from the trustee stating that they did not object or wish to be heard in the matter. Attached and marked “C” is a true copy of that letter. 7. On [date] I also received a valuation prepared by the trustee. A true copy of that valuation is attached and marked “D”. 8. I am instructed that the husband holds no interest in any other superannuation fund or financial resource other than those referred to in this affidavit. 9. The trustee has been given procedural fairness with respect to the proposed consent orders in accordance with the Rules. 10. The trustee does not object to an order issuing in the terms of the proposed consent orders. 11. There are sufficient funds in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: IN THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA

chunks.text: those referred to in this affidavit. 9. The trustee has been given procedural fairness with respect to the proposed consent orders in accordance with the Rules. 10. The trustee does not object to an order issuing in the terms of the proposed consent orders. 11. There are sufficient funds in the husband’s superannuation fund to enable the proposed split and roll-over to the wife. 12. The husband has obtained a valuation and disclosed his interest in all superannuation funds that stand in his sole name. 13. I apply to the Court for the issue of the consent orders as soon as possible. 14. Upon issue of the sealed orders I will serve a copy on the trustee. 15. The facts sworn by me above are within my knowledge except those that are deposed to from information only, in respect of which my means of knowledge and source of information appear on the face of this affidavit. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
