chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 10 SUBPOENAS TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS See FLR 6.26-6.41 (in WA, FCR 245-261). A subpoena is an order requiring a person to produce documents (to the court by the specified date) or give evidence (or both), the first of those being the most often used in family law. The former enables you to get documents from a person who has refused to provide them. Or you will be looking for potential corroboration of your client’s case as to family violence or child abuse, or per- haps previous psychiatric treatment of the other party, prior convictions, child protection records and so on; or in a financial case, business records of some kind. The form The FCFCA’s form is here at our eBook and at our online “forms & precedents”. The FCWA’s form is at “forms” at our online practice news (“FCWA”). For their text, see “precedent subpoenas to produce documents” below. Tips for completion of subpoena • State the name of the person the subpoena is directed to, or their position, ensuring that they are authorised to act on behalf of their organisation. • Specify exactly each document to be produced (i.e. not “all documents relating to…”) How and when to file it • In the FCFCA (not the FCWA) subpoenas (except up to 5 subpoenas to produce documents at an interim hearing) may only be issued if the Court has granted permission. • In the FCFCA upload your completed subpoena to produce in the Cth Courts Portal via its interactive prompt screen (it generates a cover sheet and includes payment options for the filing fee). Court fees here and, for FCWA, here. • For all other subpoenas (and all FCWA subpoenas) email the completed subpoena to the registry with a credit card payment form and, for FCWA,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: via its interactive prompt screen (it generates a cover sheet and includes payment options for the filing fee). Court fees here and, for FCWA, here. • For all other subpoenas (and all FCWA subpoenas) email the completed subpoena to the registry with a credit card payment form and, for FCWA, a credit card payment authority. • A covering letter may be needed if, say, there are less than 7 days before the hearing. Serve the subpoena • personally (or by ordinary service or as agreed for subpoenas for production) (with, in WA, prescribed brochure) (Note – Qld police require personal service, so check the requirements of the entity being served.) • at least 10 days before production is required (FLR 6.29 and FCR 249(5)) • on each party, ICL or person who reasonably has an interest in the subpoena by delivery, post, or email to an address for service or, if none, delivery or post • with compliance/conduct money ($25–40 for documents, or as sought – within reason – by person served) (at least $75 a day if attendance required) • with prescribed brochure (both available at our website) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 11 Inspection (and copying) of documents A subpoena is only listed to hear an objection (see overleaf). A party or ICL may inspect and obtain copies without leave if the subpoena was served on the named person, any interested person and any ICL at least 10 days before its production date, no objection was filed, the subpoena was complied with and a Notice of Request to Inspect are filed (child welfare, crimi- nal, medical and police records require leave to copy): FLR 6.37. Compliance may be by copies unless an original has been subpoenaed: FLR 6.39 (in WA, FCA 255). Non-compliance can mean a warrant for the named person’s arrest and an order that they pay the costs caused by failure to comply: FLR 6.41 (in WA, FCR 261). Cost of complying with subpoena if not a party The FCFCA may order the issuing party to pay a subpoenaed third party their cost of compliance if, before complying, that party has given the issuing party notice that “substantial loss or expense would be incurred in properly complying with the subpoena” (and given an estimate of that expense) and the court is satisfied of such cost and fixes the amount payable: FLR 6.35 (in WA, FCR 250) (the amount payable is in addition to any conduct money). In Markoska and Anor (Costs) [2011] FamCA 833 Murphy J said at [57]-[63]: “[‘Substantial loss or expense’] means that the expense must be large causing loss; it must be unusual in the sense of requiring normal activity to be stopped; or it must cause an unfair incon- venience having regard to the fact that the recipient has nothing to do with the litigation. ( … ) in a large organisation, the capacity to cover the expense is greater than
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: unusual in the sense of requiring normal activity to be stopped; or it must cause an unfair incon- venience having regard to the fact that the recipient has nothing to do with the litigation. ( … ) in a large organisation, the capacity to cover the expense is greater than in a small organisation ( … ) the rules are not intended to put the individual presenting the documents in a position where they lose income or capital … and each situation must be determined on its peculiar facts ( … ) Thus, in a case where a professional fee is claimed or the bobcat driver claims significant hours of ‘downtime’, the question still remains whether the finding, collecting, collating, marshalling and producing the documents or materials required the attention of the owner, partner or professional or whether it could be done by a clerical person … with … professional oversight.” Cronin J said in Moriarty [2009] FamCA 369 at [54]: “ … there is nothing in the rules nor should there be that gives any profession or business sector a right to claim expenses based upon their respective scales or charges. It is inappropriate for a court to look at those scales as anything more than a guide.” Carmody J said in G & D & D [2005] FamCA 1429 at [18] that compensation had been held “to include recovery of the costs of legal advice and representation in relation to documents under subpoena”. In Lavell [2012] FamCA 34 at [250]-[261] an accountant’s $4,000 claim was reduced to $1,000. A named person seeking payment of the cost of compliance should send a letter to the issuing party giving notice and an estimate of that cost and, ideally, apply for an order at the subpoena hearing (see Lavell, above, at
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: at [250]-[261] an accountant’s $4,000 claim was reduced to $1,000. A named person seeking payment of the cost of compliance should send a letter to the issuing party giving notice and an estimate of that cost and, ideally, apply for an order at the subpoena hearing (see Lavell, above, at [228]-[231]) supported by an affidavit). Note – A subpoena being an order for production, the subpoenaed person (who is paid at least the minimum conduct money under “serve the subpoena” above) may not refuse to produce documents until their compliance cost is paid. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 12 Objections to produce Possible objections are privilege; relevance (not a fishing exercise); abuse of process (not by being used as an alternative to discovery); oppressiveness; and lack of conduct money, late service or defective wording. For a summary of the law and the court’s approach see O’Hara & Ors [2007] FamCA 1346 at [26]-[40]. Privilege may be claimed if the document was made for the dominant purpose of litigation or obtaining legal advice: Pratt Holdings Pty Ltd v Commissioner of Taxation [2004] FCAFC 122. Privilege attaches to documents, not files. Legal professional privilege belongs to the client, not the lawyer (Mullen & De Bry & Anor [2007] FMCAfam 10 at [19]). The client should be asked whether privilege is waived and, if not, the objection made. Care should be taken to ensure privilege is not waived: Bell [2009] FMCAfam 595. In Mark & Messina [2009] FamCA 1021 M who deposed to her state of mind (anxiety) about her child’s relationship with F being formed by her discussions with her lawyers was held to have impliedly waived her right of legal privilege, requiring production of her lawyer’s file relating to the advice given on that issue. See also Dargan & Chesnik [2010] FMCAfam 726 at [18]-[35]. A person whose medical records have been subpoenaed may by notice in writing to the registrar before the production deadline seek to inspect those records so as to consider whether to object to inspec- tion or copying. Inspection may occur 7 days after the production deadline or the determination of an objection: FLR 6.38 (in WA, FCR 257). For a discussion of whether the benefit of relevant evidence should prevail over doctor/patient confidentiality see Jermyn & Carling [2012] FMCAfam 814 from [44]. In Vitalis & Kazan (No 2) [2022] FedCFamC1F
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 7 days after the production deadline or the determination of an objection: FLR 6.38 (in WA, FCR 257). For a discussion of whether the benefit of relevant evidence should prevail over doctor/patient confidentiality see Jermyn & Carling [2012] FMCAfam 814 from [44]. In Vitalis & Kazan (No 2) [2022] FedCFamC1F 601 it was held that the public and children’s interest in having relevant evidence regarding a parent’s mental health outweighed the parent’s right to privacy. The question is not admissibility but “apparent relevance”: Hatton & Attorney General of the Common- wealth & CBA [2000] FamCA 892 (also as to whether a subpoena is an abuse of process or oppressive i.e. an unreasonable burden on its recipient). Also see Deffia & Zuddro and Ors [2008] FamCA 643 at [9]-[14]. In MacDowell & Williams and Ors [2012] FamCA 479 the wills of W’s parents who had not lost testamentary capacity and documents of a company in which they were directors but had no proprietary interest were held not to be discoverable. Determining an objection is evaluative but a party’s access to documents is discretionary: Pedersen [2024] FedCFamC1A 229 at [53]-[54]. A subpoena should not be used as an alternative to discovery: Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564 at [572]-[575]. See the law and correct procedure for “discovery of docu- ments” in this chapter. Compliance is not required if the Rules have not been complied with as to service or payment of con- duct money: FLR 6.41 (in WA, FCR 261). A named person who nevertheless complies may pursue an order for their cost of compliance: Zova & Elliott and Anor [2008] FamCA 166 at [89]. Suggested procedure for objections The named person (or an interested person) may object by completing, filing and serving on the parties, any ICL
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: FCR 261). A named person who nevertheless complies may pursue an order for their cost of compliance: Zova & Elliott and Anor [2008] FamCA 166 at [89]. Suggested procedure for objections The named person (or an interested person) may object by completing, filing and serving on the parties, any ICL and the named person (if an interested person) the Notice of Objection attached to the sub- poena before the day specified for production (FLR 6.38 and, in WA, FCR 257). Expand the room given in the Notice by attaching a table to set out the nature of the objections. The objection will be listed. Despite an objection the documents must be produced to the court: they are usually produced on the day listed for the objection by the objecting person’s lawyer in two bundles, the first being documents to which objection is taken, the other being any uncontroversial documents. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 13 If acting for an objector it is suggested that in a letter to the lawyer for the issuing party you enclose the sealed Notice of Objection and: • refer to the attached table as identifying each document in question and the reason for your objection; • estimate the likely costs to argue the matter in court and say that those costs will be sought at the hearing if necessary; • invite the lawyer to release your client from compliance under FLR 6.32 (in WA, FCA 252); and • confirm a timeframe after which it will be assumed that the lawyer is insisting on compliance despite the objection, and that costs will be incurred thereafter. If necessary, brief counsel to appear at the hearing. The subpoenaed documents should be copied (but not provided to the other party) and brought to the hearing unless alleged oppressiveness makes that impracticable. File an affidavit to prove any relevant facts behind the objections. For privilege, the court must be satis- fied that each document in respect of which privilege is claimed was made for the dominant purpose of litigation or obtaining legal advice. Detailed evidence must be filed which sets out how the documents came into existence such that the court can make a finding as to its dominant purpose. A general asser- tion that merely asserts that a document was created for the dominant purpose of litigation or obtaining legal advice is unlikely to support an objection: Strahan [2013] FamCAFC 203. Take care not to reveal the content of the document or any advice in it or provide a summary of its content as privilege will then arguably have been waived. File a further affidavit specifying the costs incurred in complying with the subpoena, so that an order
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: [2013] FamCAFC 203. Take care not to reveal the content of the document or any advice in it or provide a summary of its content as privilege will then arguably have been waived. File a further affidavit specifying the costs incurred in complying with the subpoena, so that an order for costs can be sought at the hearing. Annex the correspondence between you and the other lawyer as to the subpoena. Documents in the possession of another court Under FLR 6.28 (in WA, FCR 259) the procedure for obtaining documents from another court is not by subpoena but by writing to your registrar, giving the name and address of the court in possession of the document; a description of the document to be produced; when the document is to be produced; and the reason for seeking production. The registrar will then ask that court to send the document to the registry by a specified date. A party may then apply for leave to inspect and copy. Centrelink, ATO and Child Support documents Centrelink, ATO and Child Support Registrar are not required to comply with a subpoena to produce documents. Centrelink relies on s 207 of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 (Cth) (also see Piras & Thaisawat [1993] FamCA 106); ATO (secrecy and/or privacy provisions); and Child Support Registrar under ss 16(5) CSR&CA and 150(5) CSAA (unless the documents sought are in relation to child support proceedings). Your recourse in such a case would include issuing a subpoena against, say the relevant person’s accountant for tax records. Because the person whose social security and child support information is being held is entitled to receive same (by FOI request, if necessary) your option there is to apply to the court for discovery of related documents by the respondent. See the order
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the relevant person’s accountant for tax records. Because the person whose social security and child support information is being held is entitled to receive same (by FOI request, if necessary) your option there is to apply to the court for discovery of related documents by the respondent. See the order made in Theobald & Delancy (No. 3) [2012] FMCAfam 96 requiring the respondent to submit an FOI request. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 14 PRECEDENT SUBPOENAS Your approach to issuing subpoenas In Commissioner for Railways v Small (1938) 38 SR (NSW) 564 at 572-575 Jordan CJ stated some principles which have been widely followed in family law proceedings: “A subpoena to a stranger must specify with reasonable particularity the documents which are required to be produced. ( … ) It is not legitimate to use a subpoena as a substitute for an application for further and better particulars, or for discovery of documents.” Note – In parenting cases where family violence or welfare risk is alleged (including cases in the Evatt List) the Court routinely makes orders under s 67ZBE for the Police Commissioner or child welfare department to produce all documents in their possession as to the parents and child/ren. Once made, the Court sends such orders to each department, then informs the parties when docu- ments are produced. Where there is a limit of 5 subpoenas for interim hearings, consider seeking a s 67ZBE order, rather than seeking a subpoena to the Police or child welfare department. (Hospitals) TO: [Specify position, e.g. The Administrator] [Insert name of hospital] 1. Copies of all files, notes, correspondence, memos, and other documents recording: 1.1 admissions, attendances, symptoms, diagnoses, medication, treatment or discharges in relation to [insert relevant name] born [date] and last residing at [insert last known residential address] from [insert relevant date] to date; (Schools) TO: The Principal [or specify position of other authorised person] [Insert name of school] 1. All attendance records, principal’s and teacher’s reports, school reports, memoranda, behaviour reports, assessments, test results, correspondence and other documents in your possession or control, including all records prepared by any behavioural team/body or school guidance officer in relation to the [child/children]: 1.1 [child’s full name] born [date]; (State or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: 1. All attendance records, principal’s and teacher’s reports, school reports, memoranda, behaviour reports, assessments, test results, correspondence and other documents in your possession or control, including all records prepared by any behavioural team/body or school guidance officer in relation to the [child/children]: 1.1 [child’s full name] born [date]; (State or Territory Police) TO: The Commissioner of Police [or specify authorised officer] [Relevant State/Territory] Police Service 1. The record of prior convictions of [insert name], date of birth [date]. 2. Reports of all incidents or complaints allegedly involving the said [insert name] as a victim or a perpetrator, such alleged incidents being likely to have occurred at [name of likely place/s of any offence]. 3. Copies of any domestic violence orders [insert correct name of order] and pending applications involving the said [name] as an applicant or respondent. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 15 (Child welfare department) TO: Director General [or specify authorised officer] Department of [specify] 1. Copies of all file and other records held by your Department in relation to any notifications or any other issue concerning: 1.1 [insert name of wife/mother/husband/father] born [date]; from [insert relevant date] to date. (Bank manager) TO: [The Manager] [Name of bank] 1. A copy of all loan applications received by you from [name] [also, if possible, give details, e.g. “to be secured on X property”] in the period from [date] to [date]. 2. A copy of [name of account holder]’s bank statements for account number [specify] for the period from [date] to [date]. 3. A copy of all other bank statements of [name] or any of their related entities for the period from [date] to [date]. 4. (Any other specific document sought) (Accountant or company secretary) TO: [Name of accountant or company secretary] [firm name] Copies of the following documents held by you in relation to (name of person whose documents you are seeking) and their related entities for the period from [date] to [date]: 1. Tax returns (client copy) and notices of assessment 2. All loan statements or letters from mortgagee 3. Any loan agreement or application for loan 4. Member statements for any superannuation interest 5. Any deed of family or other trust and its financial statements 6. Any deed of self-managed superannuation and fund’s financial statements 7. Financial statements, tax returns, minutes for related business or company 8. Such company’s latest annual return of directors and shareholders 9. Deed of any partnership and its financial statements 10. All bank statements 13. Business activity statements 11. Credit card statements 14. Share portfolio 12. Company’s share register 15. (Specify any other document sought) Update 64 March 2025 quarter
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: company 8. Such company’s latest annual return of directors and shareholders 9. Deed of any partnership and its financial statements 10. All bank statements 13. Business activity statements 11. Credit card statements 14. Share portfolio 12. Company’s share register 15. (Specify any other document sought) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 16 DISCOVERY OF DOCUMENTS Duty of disclosure Parties to a family law proceeding must disclose all information and produce all documents that are or have been in their possession or under their control which are relevant to an issue in the case and must file an undertaking to the court: FLR 6.01-6.03 (in WA, FCR 197, 202, 211, 212). In Black & Kellner [1992] FamCA 2 at [25] the Full Court referred with approval to the following remarks of Smithers J in the case of Briese: “I believe that the conclusion of the House of Lords in the case of Livesey v Jenkins is apposite, namely, that in financial proceedings between spouses, each party must make a full and frank dis- closure of all material facts. In that case it was made clear that full and frank disclosure of all mate- rial facts was required as a matter of principle in the light of the fact that it was the duty of the court, taking into account a number of designated criteria, to make a decision which basically involved the exercise of discretion. This is quite different from common law litigation between strangers in which such a general duty does not exist, and obligations would only exist insofar as statute or court rules required. In my view it is fundamental to the whole operation of the Family Law Act in financial cases, that there is an obligation of the nature to which I have referred.” Disclosure in parenting cases The duty of disclosure applies here too. Discoverable documents include a party’s criminal records, documents filed in relevant intervention order proceedings, a child’s or party’s medical records and school reports: FLR 6.05. Disclosure in financial cases A party to a financial case must make full and frank
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: in parenting cases The duty of disclosure applies here too. Discoverable documents include a party’s criminal records, documents filed in relevant intervention order proceedings, a child’s or party’s medical records and school reports: FLR 6.05. Disclosure in financial cases A party to a financial case must make full and frank disclosure of the party’s financial circumstances (FLR 6.06 and, in WA, FCR 199), including: • income of theirs or of a legal entity fully or partially owned or controlled by them or income paid or assigned to another party, person or legal entity • any vested or contingent interest in property of theirs or owned by a legal entity fully or partially owned or controlled by them • the party’s other financial resources • any trust in which a party is involved (FLR 6.06(3)(f) and FCR 199(2)(f)) • any disposal of property (whether by sale, transfer, assignment or gift) made by the party, a legal entity as above, a company or a trust that may affect, defeat or deplete a claim in the 12 months im- mediately before separation or since the final separation of the parties (except a disposal made with the consent or knowledge of the other party or in the ordinary course of business) • liabilities and contingent liabilities. Starting a proceeding A party must file with their Initiating Application or Response a Financial Statement: FLR 6.06(5)-(7) and, in WA, FCR 200-201. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 17 Before the first court date Such a party (except a respondent to a maintenance application only) must serve on each other party (FLR 6.06(8) and, in WA, FCR 190): • a copy of their 3 most recent tax returns and assessments • the completed superannuation information form for any super interest (and, in WA, the 2 most recent member benefit statements for any accumulation fund) • the trust deed and the 3 most recent financial statements for any self-managed super fund • a copy of the last 4 business activity statements if the party has an ABN • a copy of the 3 most recent financial statements and the last 4 business activity statements lodged by any partnership, trust or company Maintenance application only A respondent must bring to the court on the first court date (FLR 6.06(9) cf. FCR 214 in WA): • a copy of their tax return for the most recent financial year • a copy of their tax assessment for the most recent financial year • copies of their bank records for the 12 months immediately before the date when the application was filed • their most recent pay slip • a copy of the last 4 business activity statements if they have an ABN • any document in their possession, custody or control that may assist the court in determining their income, needs and financial resources. Disclosure by list of documents After a case has been given a first court date a party may, in writing, ask another party to provide a list of documents to which the duty of disclosure applies (FLR 6.09 and, in WA, FCR 216). The disclosing party must within 21 days serve on the requesting party a list of documents identifying: • the documents
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: court date a party may, in writing, ask another party to provide a list of documents to which the duty of disclosure applies (FLR 6.09 and, in WA, FCR 216). The disclosing party must within 21 days serve on the requesting party a list of documents identifying: • the documents to which the duty of disclosure applies; • the documents (if any) no longer in the disclosing party’s possession or control to which the duty would otherwise apply (with a brief statement about the circumstances in which the documents left the party’s possession or control); and • the documents (if any) for which privilege from production is claimed. If a document that must be disclosed is located by, or comes into the possession or control of, a disclos- ing party after service of the list under sub-rule (2), the party must disclose the document within 7 days after it is located or comes into the party’s possession or control. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 18 Request for disclosed document A disclosing party may also (FLR 6.10, 6.13; in WA, FCR 204) be asked in writing to: • provide copies of documents disclosed in a list of documents, whereupon that party must within 21 days and at the expense of the requesting party provide those copies, if practicable, in an electronic format; or • produce documents for inspection If it is not convenient to provide copies due to the number and size of the documents, the disclosing party must produce the documents for inspection (see below). Request for other identified document A party may also be asked in writing to provide a copy of or produce for inspection (see below) a docu- ment referred to in a document filed or served by them or in correspondence: FLR 6.11 (in WA, FCR 204). Request to inspect original document A party may be asked in writing to produce for inspection (see below) the original of a document that must be produced under the duty of disclosure: FLR 6.12 (in WA, FCR 205). Production of documents for inspection If asked in writing to do so (see above), a party must within 14 days: • notify, in writing, the requesting party of a convenient place and time (within 21 days or as agreed) to inspect the document; • produce the document for inspection at that place and time; and • allow copies of the document to be made, at the expense of the party requesting it. A party who fails to inspect such a document may not later do so unless they tender an amount for the reasonable costs of providing another opportunity for inspection: FLR 6.14 (in WA, FCR 206, 207). Documents that need not be produced A party must disclose, but need not
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: it. A party who fails to inspect such a document may not later do so unless they tender an amount for the reasonable costs of providing another opportunity for inspection: FLR 6.14 (in WA, FCR 206, 207). Documents that need not be produced A party must disclose, but need not provide or produce a document for which there is a claim of privi- lege from production; that is no longer in that party’s possession or control; or a copy of which has already been provided: FLR 6.15 (in WA, FCR 208). Note too that the duty of disclosure does not extend to documents that are not relevant to an issue in the case (see “duty of disclosure” above). Further, is the document sought under your client’s “control”? Objecting to production If a party claims privilege from production of a document or that the party is unable (or not obliged) to produce a document and another party, in writing, challenges the claim, the claimant must, within 7 days after the challenge, file an affidavit setting out details of the claim. The court may inspect the docu- ment for the purpose of determining whether the claim is valid: FLR 6.16 (in WA, FCR 209). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 19 The duty of disclosure is subject to a party’s claim that the documents sought are subject to a claim of privilege (such as legal professional privilege, or the privilege against self-incrimination) or that the documents are not, as required by FLR 6.03, relevant to an issue in the case or in their possession or under their control. As to the latter, should the other party seek a document from your client that is not in your client’s possession or under their control or is irrelevant to an issue in the case or is subject to a claim of privilege, you should arrange for your client to swear an affidavit as to those circumstances. In Schweitzer [2012] FamCA 445 O’Reilly J dismissed W’s application for disclosure by H of the financial statements, tax returns and bank statements for two discretionary trusts and the minutes of the corporate trustee as to trust distributions, holding that as the trustee company was not a “one man company” the documents sought could not be said to be under the husband’s “control” within the meaning of FLR 6.03. Also see Masoud [2016] FamCAFC 24 at [13]-[23]. Consequences of non-disclosure If a party does not disclose a document as required by these Rules they must not offer the document, or present evidence of its contents, at a hearing without the other party’s consent or the court’s permission; may be guilty of contempt for not disclosing the document; may be ordered to pay costs; and the court may stay or dismiss all or part of the party’s case: FLR 6.17 (in WA, FCR 210). Powers of court as to disclosure, production or inspection A party may (FLR 6.18(1); in WA, FCR 218) seek an order that: • the respondent comply with a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: pay costs; and the court may stay or dismiss all or part of the party’s case: FLR 6.17 (in WA, FCR 210). Powers of court as to disclosure, production or inspection A party may (FLR 6.18(1); in WA, FCR 218) seek an order that: • the respondent comply with a request for a list of documents in accordance with rule 6.09; • the respondent provide an affidavit of documents; • the respondent disclose a specified document, or class of documents, by providing a copy of the document, or each document in the class; • the respondent produce a document for inspection; • the respondent file an affidavit stating that a specified document, or class of documents, does not exist or has never existed OR the circumstances in which a specified document or class of documents ceased to exist or passed out of the possession or control of that party; or • the applicant be partly or fully relieved of the duty of disclosure. An applicant must satisfy the court that the order sought is appropriate in the interests of the administra- tion of justice: FLR 6.18(2). The court may make any of the above orders if it is satisfied that the order is appropriate in the interests of the administration of justice: FLR 6.18(3). In making such an order, the court may consider whether the disclosure sought is relevant to an issue in dispute; the relative importance of the issue to which the document or class of documents relates; the likely time, cost and inconvenience involved in disclosing a document or class of documents, taking into account the amount of the property, or complexity of the corporate, trust or partnership interests (if any), involved in the proceeding; and the likely effect on the outcome of the proceeding of disclosing, or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: likely time, cost and inconvenience involved in disclosing a document or class of documents, taking into account the amount of the property, or complexity of the corporate, trust or partnership interests (if any), involved in the proceeding; and the likely effect on the outcome of the proceeding of disclosing, or not disclosing, the document or class of documents: FLR 6.18(4). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 20 If the disclosure of a document is necessary for the purpose of resolving a proceeding at a dispute reso- lution event, a party may, on the first court date, seek an order that another party provide a copy of the document or produce the document to for inspection and copying: FLR 6.18(5). The court may make an order under sub-rule (5) only in exceptional circumstances: FLR 6.18(6). The court may inspect a document to decide an application made under this rule or whether to make an order under sub-rule (3): FLR 6.18(7). Cost of compliance If the cost of complying with the duty of disclosure would be oppressive to a party, the court may order an- other party to pay the costs; contribute to the costs; or give security for costs: FLR 6.19 (in WA, FCR 219). Electronic disclosure The court may make an order directing electronic disclosure of documents: FLR 6.20 (in WA, FCR 220). Disclosure from employer FLR 6.25 (in WA, FCR 226) sets out the circumstances in which an order may be made requiring the other party’s employer to give particulars of any debt to the employee; their earnings; conditions of employment; leave entitlements; or entitlement to earn bonuses. A suggestion Before issuing an application against a defaulting party (below), consider whether the documents in question are likely to be in the possession of a third party. The sample affidavit below is in support of an application against a party who has refused to disclose an inheritance. In that case, the estate’s lawyer would have all the documents the applicant would need to prove the nature and extent of the inheritance. Issuing a subpoena against that lawyer to produce such documents would achieve a more cost effective result (or even just asking
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: refused to disclose an inheritance. In that case, the estate’s lawyer would have all the documents the applicant would need to prove the nature and extent of the inheritance. Issuing a subpoena against that lawyer to produce such documents would achieve a more cost effective result (or even just asking that lawyer, or perhaps a search of your probate registry, may elicit the information sought). See “subpoenas” above. Procedure for applying for discovery of documents • Prepare and file an Application in a Proceeding seeking an order as required from the options set out below. • Also prepare and file an affidavit in support sworn by your client. Sample of order for discovery of documents File and serve an Application in a Proceeding, with an affidavit in support (along the lines of our online precedent “affidavit for discovery”), for the following orders as applicable: 1. That within 14 days of the date of this order the Respondent: 1.1 provide a list of documents to the Applicant in accordance with rule 6.09 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 21 1.2 provide the Applicant at the expense of the Respondent with copies in electronic format or hard copies of [specify documents]. 1.3 produce for inspection by the Applicant [specify documents]. 1.4 produce for inspection by the Applicant the original of [specify document/s]. 1.5 file and serve an affidavit stating the circumstances in which [specify document] passed out of the possession or control of the Respondent. 2. That the Applicant be relieved of the duty of disclosure. 3. That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s costs of and incidental to this Application. 4. Such further or other order as the Court sees fit. Sample of affidavit in support Introduction 1. I am the Applicant husband. 2. The Respondent to my Application is [name] (“[Y]”). 3. [Y] and I began living together in [date], were married on [date] and separated on [date]. Y’s failure to disclose inheritance 4. [Y]’s mother, [name] (“[Z]”) died about [time] before [Y] and I separated. [Y]’s father died some years ago. 5. [Y] was an only child. 6. [Y] had often remarked to me during our marriage that she expected a large inheritance upon [Z]’s passing, but has not disclosed any inheritance in the Financial Statement filed by [her/him] on [date of filing]. 7. On [date] I requested my lawyers to write to [Y]’s lawyers to seek a copy of [Z]’s last will, should it be in [Y]’s possession, and a statement from the lawyers acting in [Z]’s estate as to any interest of [Y] in [Z]’s estate. A true copy of my lawyer’s letter dated [date] is attached and marked “1”. 8. Having received no reply, I instructed my lawyers to repeat their request for documents, and foreshadow an Application for discovery and costs, in the absence of production. Attached and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: interest of [Y] in [Z]’s estate. A true copy of my lawyer’s letter dated [date] is attached and marked “1”. 8. Having received no reply, I instructed my lawyers to repeat their request for documents, and foreshadow an Application for discovery and costs, in the absence of production. Attached and marked “2” is a true copy of my lawyer’s letter in this regard. 9. [Y] has told me verbally which lawyers are acting in the estate, but refuses to reply to our letters with the information sought. Administration of justice 10. I have stayed with [Y] at [Z]’s home, a [description of property – e.g. ‘double storey 6 bedroom home’] at [address] (“the property”). 11. Attached and marked “3” is a true copy of a title search for the property, which still records [Z] as registered owner of an unencumbered title. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 22 12. I have sought advice as to the likely market value of the property and attach, marked “4”, a true copy of an appraisal from [insert name of real estate agent], in the sum of $[amount]. 13. I am unaware of any other property that might form part of [Z]’s estate. 14. I seek an order compelling [Y] to provide documentary evidence of [Y]’s interest in the estate as being relevant to my Application and to an ultimate order that is just and equitable. 15. All the facts deposed to above by me are within my own knowledge except those that are deposed to from information only, in respect of which my means of knowledge and sources of information appear on the face of this affidavit. An option for uncooperative respondents In seeking discovery of a document from an uncooperative party, you could give notice of intention to apply for “a Weir Order”, being the Full Court’s ruling in Weir [1992] FamCA 69 at [33] where the Court said: “It seems to us that once it has been established that there has been a deliberate non-disclosure…then the Court should not be unduly cautious about making findings in favour of the innocent party. To do otherwise might be thought to provide a charter for fraud in proceedings of this nature.” Cases since have consistently taken the approach of assuming that a party failing to make full and frank disclosure has property that is being hidden. In Chang & Su [2002] FamCA 156 the Full Court dismissed an appeal against the decision of the trial judge (Moore J) who, satisfied that the husband had not disclosed his property interests in Taiwan, awarded the wife the entire asset pool in Australia, unencumbered, despite there being limited evidence as
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Chang & Su [2002] FamCA 156 the Full Court dismissed an appeal against the decision of the trial judge (Moore J) who, satisfied that the husband had not disclosed his property interests in Taiwan, awarded the wife the entire asset pool in Australia, unencumbered, despite there being limited evidence as to the value of the husband’s overseas property interests. In Gerber [2010] FamCA 861 Coleman J, applying Weir (above), notionally increased the $1.6m asset pool by $500,000 in reliance upon benefits derived after separation by the (non-disclosing) husband from a business in which he had an interest. Another option is to foreshadow that you will be seeking an undefended hearing if the non- disclosure persists: see Melville & Dent [2008] FamCA 926. What if my client won’t disclose a relevant fact or document? Clause 6(5) of Parts 1 and 2 of Schedule 1 of the FLR (the pre-action procedures) states that if a client will not disclose a fact or document that is relevant to the case, a lawyer has an obligation to take the appropriate action, being to cease to act for the client. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 24 REQUEST TO ANSWER SPECIFIC QUESTIONS UNDER OATH For financial or parenting proceedings, the Rules allow a party to serve on another party a request to answer specific questions (interrogatories) once a case has been allocated a first court date: FLR 6.22 (in WA, cf. FCA 222. In the Family Court/FCWA, once a case has been allocated to a first day before a judge: A party may serve one set of up to 20 written questions on the other party. If an answering party is required under FLR 6.09 (in WA, FCR 216) to provide a list of documents, they are not required to answer the questions until the time for disclosure under Part 6.2 or an order has expired. An answering party must within 21 days file and serve on each other party an affidavit which answers each question, or sets out objections to each specific question with a brief statement of facts which sup- port any objection: FLR 6.23 (in WA, FCR 223). A party may apply for an order as to an answer or objection: FLR 6.24 (in WA, FCR 224). There is no prescribed form for the Request, so we suggest the following, also at our online “forms & precedents” as “specific questions” (in WA, adapting the form to the FCWA and substituting “rule 222 of the Family Court Rules 2021). Family Law Act 1975 IN THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA FILE NO: [court file no.] BETWEEN: [APPLICANT NAME] (Applicant) AND: [RESPONDENT NAME] (Respondent) REQUEST TO ANSWER SPECIFIC QUESTIONS UNDER RULE 6.22 OF THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (FAMILY LAW) RULES 2021 The Applicant/Respondent hereby requests answers to the following questions: 1. DATED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– SIGNED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Note – The answers should be sworn in the form
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUEST TO ANSWER SPECIFIC QUESTIONS UNDER OATH

chunks.text: (Applicant) AND: [RESPONDENT NAME] (Respondent) REQUEST TO ANSWER SPECIFIC QUESTIONS UNDER RULE 6.22 OF THE FEDERAL CIRCUIT AND FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (FAMILY LAW) RULES 2021 The Applicant/Respondent hereby requests answers to the following questions: 1. DATED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– SIGNED: –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Note – The answers should be sworn in the form of an Affidavit. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUEST TO ANSWER SPECIFIC QUESTIONS UNDER OATH

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 25 OFFERS TO SETTLE Parties to proceedings are encouraged to make an effort to resolve a case without a trial by making an offer to settle to the other party at any time. How to make an offer A party may offer to settle all or part of a case or an appeal by serving on the other party an offer to settle at any time before the court disposes of the case: FLR 4.06 (in WA, FCR 154). An offer to settle: • must be in writing • must not be filed • will be deemed to be without prejudice unless stated to be an open offer • must not be divulged in any document filed or at any hearing unless it is an open offer or is the subject of an application for costs: FLR 4.07 (in WA, FCR 154, 155) How to withdraw an offer Before it is accepted or the case is disposed of, a party may withdraw it by: • serving a written notice on the other party that the offer is withdrawn, or • making a later offer: FLR 4.08 (in WA, FCR 156) How to accept an offer Before it is withdrawn or the case is disposed of, a party may accept an offer by notice in writing to the party making the offer, whereupon the parties must sign and file a draft consent order (see “consent orders” above): FLR 4.09 (in WA, FCR 157) Note – A party may accept an offer even though the party has made a counter-offer to settle: FLR 4.10 (in WA, FCR 158) Offers to settle are compulsory in property cases Each party to a property case must make a genuine offer to settle to all other parties within 28 days after
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: party may accept an offer even though the party has made a counter-offer to settle: FLR 4.10 (in WA, FCR 158) Offers to settle are compulsory in property cases Each party to a property case must make a genuine offer to settle to all other parties within 28 days after a conciliation conference or mediation (or, if neither is held or is to be held, within 28 days after the first court date): FLR 4.11 (in WA, FCR 159) The offer must include (but not in WA) the statement: “This offer to settle is made under Division 4.2.2 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021. A party who withdraws such an offer must, at the same time, make another genuine offer to settle: FLR 4.12 (in WA, FCR 160) Note – FLR 12.05 (in WA, FCR 326) requires lawyers, when an offer is made, to inform their clients of their costs to date (paid and owing) and estimated future costs to complete the case. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 26 APPLYING FOR AN ORDER FOR INTERIM COSTS (INCLUDING EXPERT WITNESS EXPENSES) Note – This section has been left until nearly last in this chapter as the editors do not recommend your taking this action except as a last resort. It will be far better all round if you were to amicably negotiate a mutual release of funds towards each party’s costs and outlays. See the comments on this below, and under “partial property settlements” in the chapter “property”. Introduction No later than their second appointment with you, give your clients a rough idea of their future costs if the matter does not settle but proceeds to a final hearing (see chapter “client preliminaries” under “initial consultation” and “the second appointment”), and discuss with them how they intend to meet those costs. It is when your client has access to insufficient funds with which to finance your representation and the preparation of their case that it becomes necessary to review the merits of a court application for an order for those costs to be paid by the other party or from liquid or realisable assets under that party’s control. Is there a better option? Yes. The disadvantages of such an application are that, being adversarial by nature, it would be contested; is expensive, say, $5–15,000 including counsel (see its involved procedure below); may not result in as much as was sought; and may fail (good money then being thrown after bad). For these reasons, it is common for lawyers to negotiate with each other at an early stage of discussions the advance to each lawyer of a negotiated amount – say $20–30,000 – from available funds (such as a joint or investment account, or by the sale of a non-essential asset) towards each party’s future costs
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: common for lawyers to negotiate with each other at an early stage of discussions the advance to each lawyer of a negotiated amount – say $20–30,000 – from available funds (such as a joint or investment account, or by the sale of a non-essential asset) towards each party’s future costs and outlays for the case. If the other party should come to you with such a proposal, agree to it. There can be no prejudice to either party, there is only mutual benefit. A “strictly business” approach like this, on non-adversarial lines and on the basis of the advance being a partial property settlement that is brought into account at the end of the case, will usually produce ready agreement from the other party’s lawyer (and even an unrepresented party, who would usually have needs other than legal costs) who will see the mutual advantage to be gained by such an arrangement. It is best to try for as much of your client’s future costs and outlays as you can, to avoid having to keep returning to the other party’s lawyer for further advances. Partial property settlement This is also called a premature distribution of matrimonial assets, where part of the asset pool is advanced for the benefit of either party or both of them. The amounts are notionally added back to the pool and deducted from each party’s ultimate share in the property settlement. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 27 Litigation loan Litigation loans are available from lenders specialising in pre-matrimonial settlement funding. In obtaining such a loan, the client would incur administration fees and pay interest, but the application process would be quicker, more predictable and possibly cheaper than running a Hogan application. You would, of course, be required by the lender to satisfy yourself as to the terms and conditions of the loan, and some lenders will only provide funds if the borrower’s law firm guarantees re-payment. Court action as a last resort The court has the power under both ss 80(1)(h) and (k) and 117(2) of the FLA to make an order requir- ing a party to provide the other with the funds necessary to be able to prosecute their case: Zschokke [1996] FamCA 79 at [71]-[72]. The purpose of the remedy is to ensure that there is a “level playing field” between the litigants, pending trial. This type of application is known as an application for interim costs, or “Hogan Order” (the leading case being Hogan [1986] FamCA 34) (AKA a Barro order, after another case on the same issue). Ordinarily a “Hogan Order” is an order that: • the respondent pay a lump sum to the applicant (or the applicant’s solicitors’ trust account) towards their legal costs; or that • the parties do all acts necessary to sell an asset so as to realise a lump sum, and then pay such sum either to the applicant (or the applicant’s solicitors’ trust account) towards their legal costs. In Wicklow [2007] FamCA 840, Steele J heard an application for a review of an order of Johnston JR that the husband pay the wife towards her costs the same sum he had paid his own lawyers for his, the wife’s application being
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: solicitors’ trust account) towards their legal costs. In Wicklow [2007] FamCA 840, Steele J heard an application for a review of an order of Johnston JR that the husband pay the wife towards her costs the same sum he had paid his own lawyers for his, the wife’s application being that he pay her $100,000 for her interim costs. Steele J found that that sum was not really in dispute, but that the parties disagreed as to how those funds should be realised. It was found that there were ample assets, such as four valuable cars any of which could realise the amount required. The court was also willing to make an equivalent order for each party if that were desired. For an interim costs order to fund an application to set aside a financial agreement see Salvage & Fosse [2020] FamCAFC 144. There, Ryan and Aldridge JJ said that the “critical question … is whether the ap- plicant has ‘any real prospects of obtaining justice unless the [interim costs] order sought is made’” ([14]) and that the Court must assess “the nature and quality of any property claim” including “the likely divi- sion” and whether the proceedings are justified by “the nature and quality of the claim” and “the likely costs involved” ([25]). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 28 The court ordered the husband to pay $100,000 towards the wife’s interim costs, saying that it should: “…be left to him to find the source of those funds and in the event that he is unable to do so, or does not do so within 30 days, then provision be made for the sale of one of the luxury motor vehicles.” The case of the judicial officer’s husband A useful precedent for an order being made for interim costs is Oates & Crest (2008) FamCAFC 29 in which the Full Court made an interim order awarding the husband of a judicial officer $80,000 towards his legal costs, as well as other moneys for re-establishment costs and main- tenance pending the final hearing (see under “interim maintenance” in the chapter “spousal maintenance”). Threshold requirements To succeed with such an application, the applicant must satisfy the following threshold matters: • There must be a disparity in the parties’ financial positions to the extent that the respondent controls the parties’ assets, while the applicant does not have access such that they are unable to meet their legal costs pending trial; and • The respondent to the application has the capacity to meet their own legal costs; and • The applicant’s case for a final property settlement has merit – i.e. the amount sought by the applicant is less than the amount the applicant is likely to receive by way of final property settlement; and • The applicant’s needs (in terms of actual costs and disbursements incurred to the date of the hearing and anticipated costs in preparing the matter for trial) are in evidence before the court. For a discussion of these matters, see Ritchie [2007] FMCAfam 327. As to the need to identify a fund as an
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (in terms of actual costs and disbursements incurred to the date of the hearing and anticipated costs in preparing the matter for trial) are in evidence before the court. For a discussion of these matters, see Ritchie [2007] FMCAfam 327. As to the need to identify a fund as an available source of litigation funding, see Abrams [2010] FMCAfam 560. The Full Court’s ruling on interim costs Strahan (Interim Property Orders) [2009] FamCAFC 166 concerned an asset pool of $80m+ where the wife had spent $11m in legal costs, largely in pursuit of the husband for non-disclosure of valuable assets. Previous interim costs orders enabled half of that expense, the wife’s latest application for such costs being for $5m as an interim property order. The trial judge reduced her award for those costs to $1m. The Court upheld the wife’s appeal, allowing the $5m sought by her, holding: • That an interim costs order may be made as a maintenance order under ss 72 and 74; as a property settlement under ss 79 and 80(1)(h); or as a costs order under s 117 • That the source of power should be identified so as to ascertain the Act’s prerequisites for the interim costs order • That more than one such order may be made in the course of s 79 proceedings to fund the legal costs of a party Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 29 • That in the exercise of the power under ss 79 and 80(1)(h), the test is not whether there were “compelling circumstances”, but whether “in the circumstances, (such an order) is appropriate” (para 132) The Court at paras 144 and 145 said: “…all that his Honour was required to consider was whether it was an appropriate case to make an interim order for property settlement because the Wife required funds to defray legal costs and expenses of the pending proceedings. It did not require a detailed inquiry into the conduct of the litigation on the part of the Wife (…) As…the trial Judge was satisfied that the Wife needed funds to meet ongoing legal costs of the proceedings and that she did not have the funds to pay those costs…it was an appropriate case to exercise the jurisdiction to make an interim order for property settlement.” In Osferatu [2012] FamCA 408 at para 35 Watts J said: “The notion of a ‘level playing field’ is one which almost axiomatically is in the interests of justice and an important matter to consider when deciding whether it would be appropriate to make an interim property order.” Procedure The procedure to obtain such a Hogan Order is: 1. If proceedings are not on foot, comply with any relevant pre-action procedure (see “procedure” in relevant chapter) then include in the orders sought in your Initiating Application this interim order: That within 30 days, the husband pay to the wife’s solicitors trust account the sum of $[amount] and such sum be used by the wife towards payment of her legal and other costs of and incidental to these proceedings. OR That the husband and the wife do all acts to sell the [year, model] motor vehicle to any third
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: wife’s solicitors trust account the sum of $[amount] and such sum be used by the wife towards payment of her legal and other costs of and incidental to these proceedings. OR That the husband and the wife do all acts to sell the [year, model] motor vehicle to any third party purchaser who makes an offer greater than $[amount] and apply the net sale proceeds as follows: (i) the sum of $[amount] to the wife’s solicitors’ trust account and such sum be used by the wife in the payment of her legal and other costs of and incidental to these proceedings; (ii) the balance to be paid to the wife’s solicitors trust account and be held pending further agreement between the parties, or order of this court. 2. If proceedings are already on foot, prepare an Application in a Proceeding seeking an order in the above terms; 3. Prepare a Financial Statement for your client. 4. Prepare an affidavit of your client in support of the application (see sample “affidavit of client in support of an interim costs order below). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 30 5. Prepare an affidavit for you to swear, detailing the professional costs and disbursements that the client has incurred to date, and an estimate of the likely costs and disbursements that will be incurred in preparing the matter for trial (see sample “affidavit of solicitor in support of an interim costs order” below). 6. Prepare an affidavit to be sworn by any expert that is likely to be retained, detailing their likely professional costs and disbursements (see sample “affidavit of expert valuer” below). 7. Swear and file the documents via the Commonwealth Courts Portal. Upon filing a Court date will be allocated, then serve the documents no later than 3 days before an interlocutory hearing: FLR 2.31. In WA filing is required via the eCourts Portal of WA. 8. Upon receipt of the sealed copies, arrange for them to be served and brief counsel to appear at the return date. Effect of different orders Two types of order have been included as alternative orders below: • An order for Respondent to pay Applicant’s interim costs and outlays • What is known as a “dollar for dollar” order (Respondent to pay to Applicant’s lawyers what he pays to his lawyers for his own costs and outlays), the order made by O’Reilly J in G & T [2003] FamCA 1076 (see discussion in that judgment at paras 103 to 109). See also Iphostrou and Ors [2011] FamCA 20 (Cronin J). An interim costs order would result in costs paid prior to the final hearing being added back to the pool notionally (see p 7-18 above). A dollar for dollar order may result in the applicant receiving nothing if the respondent’s solicitors and counsel agree to carry their costs until after the final hearing (see Shelbourne [2019] FamCAFC
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 5. Prepare an affidavit for you to swear, detailing the professional costs and disbursements that

chunks.text: costs paid prior to the final hearing being added back to the pool notionally (see p 7-18 above). A dollar for dollar order may result in the applicant receiving nothing if the respondent’s solicitors and counsel agree to carry their costs until after the final hearing (see Shelbourne [2019] FamCAFC 196). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 31 Sample interim orders sought Note – Paragraphs 2–6 of the following sample are the orders made by O’Reilly J in G & T [2003] FamCA 1076 (see discussion in the judgment at paras 103 to 109). 1. That within [specify] days the Respondent pay $[amount] to the Applicant’s lawyers towards the Applicant’s legal costs and outlays in these proceedings. 2. That in the alternative, paragraphs 2–5 of this Order be made, that within 7 days after the payment by or on behalf of the husband of any money in payment of accounts: (a) rendered by the husband’s lawyers in respect of these proceedings; (b) rendered by any accountant, valuer or other expert engaged by the husband in respect of these proceedings; the husband pay or cause to be paid the same amount of money to the wife’s lawyers. 3. That within 1 day after the payment by or on behalf of the husband of any money referred to in Order 2(a) or (b), the husband shall cause to be given to the wife’s lawyers a memorandum stating the amount or amounts so paid. 4. All money paid to the husband’s lawyers by or on behalf of the husband referred to in Order 2 be held in trust by the husband’s lawyers and not be applied in payment of his legal costs and outlays until such time as the same amount has been paid by or on behalf of the husband to the wife’s lawyers, and in the event that such payment to the wife’s lawyers has not been made within 7 days after the payment by or on behalf of the husband of any money referred to in Order 2, the husband direct his lawyers to pay 50% of the amount or amounts so
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 5. Prepare an affidavit for you to swear, detailing the professional costs and disbursements that

chunks.text: and in the event that such payment to the wife’s lawyers has not been made within 7 days after the payment by or on behalf of the husband of any money referred to in Order 2, the husband direct his lawyers to pay 50% of the amount or amounts so held by them in trust to the wife’s lawyers. 5. The amounts paid by or at the direction of the husband to the wife’s lawyers under these orders be applied by them in the payment of the wife’s legal costs and outlays incurred and to be incurred by the wife in the conduct of these proceedings, including but not limited to the reasonable costs and outlays: (a) rendered by the wife’s solicitors in respect of these proceedings; (b) rendered by any accountant, valuer or other expert engaged by the wife in respect of these proceedings. 6. The determination as to whether the payments made by or on behalf of the husband to the wife’s lawyers are to be treated as a debt due from the wife to the husband, or as part of the wife’s entitlement to property settlement, or the provision of maintenance for the wife, or in payment by the husband of the wife’s costs of and incidental to these proceedings, or otherwise, be adjourned to the trial judge. 7. That the Respondent pay the Applicant’s taxed costs of and incidental to this application. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update

[X] has also provided me instructions regarding the net asset pool in this matter, which are detailed in [X]’s affidavit filed contemporaneously with this affidavit. 14. I note [X]’s instructions in this regard that the non-superannuation net asset pool is of an approximate value of about $[amount], and superannuation asset pool is about $[amount]. 15. Based on my experience in family law litigation and my assessment of the authorities, I consider that [X] can expect a property adjustment of at least 50% of the non-superannuation net asset pool and superannuation. 16. All the facts and circumstances deposed to by me above are within my own knowledge except those that are deposed to from information only, in respect of which my means of knowledge and sources of information appear on the face of this affidavit. Affidavit of valuer in support of an interim costs order 1. I am a practising valuer in the employ of [specify], a company that specialises in valuations. 2. I am a certified practising valuer, Registered Valuer Number [insert]. 3. Attached and marked “A” is a copy of an enquiry from [firm name] lawyers that I received as to the likely cost of preparing a report as to the current market value of real estate properties at [address/es] (“the [property/properties]”) for the purpose of matrimonial proceedings. 4. Save for any unforeseen complications, I estimate that the likely cost of preparing the requested reports will be $[amount] including
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 30. As detailed above, [Y]’s income was about $[amount] gross per annum as at the date we

chunks.text: as to the likely cost of preparing a report as to the current market value of real estate properties at [address/es] (“the [property/properties]”) for the purpose of matrimonial proceedings. 4. Save for any unforeseen complications, I estimate that the likely cost of preparing the requested reports will be $[amount] including GST 5. All the facts deposed to by me above are within my own knowledge save such as are deposed to from information only, in respect of which my means of knowledge and sources of information appear on the face of this affidavit.
