chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 39 APPLYING FOR INTERIM OR PROCEDURAL ORDER WITHOUT NOTICE The ex parte application was used quite freely in the early days of the Family Court of Australia, but was often used where there was really no need for the respondent not to be given notice of the application. Such an application soon became less routine when conditions were imposed (see below) requiring ap- plicants to justify the making of an ex parte order. FLR 5.11 (in WA, FCR 87) provides that an applicant seeking an interim or procedural order without notice to the respondent must: (a) satisfy the court as to why: (i) shortening the time for service of the application and the fixing of an early date for hearing after service would not be more appropriate; and (ii) an order should be made without notice to the other party; and (b) in an affidavit or orally, with the court’s permission, make full and frank disclosure of all the facts relevant to the application, including: (i) whether there is a history or allegation of child abuse or family violence between the parties; (ii) whether there has been a previous case between the parties and, if so, the nature of the case; (iii) the particulars of any orders currently in force between the parties; (iv) whether there has been a breach of a previous order by a party to the case; (v) whether the respondent or the respondent’s lawyer has been told of the intention to make the application; (vi) whether there is likely to be any hardship, danger or prejudice to the respondent, a child or a third party if the order is made; (vii) the capacity of the applicant to give an undertaking as to damages; (viii) the nature of the damage or harm
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLYING FOR INTERIM OR PROCEDURAL ORDER WITHOUT NOTICE

chunks.text: make the application; (vi) whether there is likely to be any hardship, danger or prejudice to the respondent, a child or a third party if the order is made; (vii) the capacity of the applicant to give an undertaking as to damages; (viii) the nature of the damage or harm that may result if the order is not made; (ix) why the order must be urgently made; and (x) the last known address or address for service of the other party. For a discussion of the court’s approach to an ex parte application in a parenting case (a recovery order) see Drew & Jensen [2017] FCCA 656 from [26] (a decision of the former FCC made under its then similar rules). Note 1. This Rule requires the applicant to file any existing family violence order when filing the application: FLR FLR 2.10 (in WA, FCR 32). 2. An order made without notice to the other party must be expressed to operate until a time specified in the order or, if the hearing is adjourned, until the date of the next hearing: FLR 5.12 (in WA, FCR 88). 3. The evidence required for an affidavit in support of an ex parte application is set out in FLR 5.11 (in WA, FCR 87) above. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLYING FOR INTERIM OR PROCEDURAL ORDER WITHOUT NOTICE

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 40 Applicant’s undertaking as to damages The history behind FLR 5.11(b)(vii) (in WA 87(b)(vii)) above is the legal custom that a person seeking a temporary injunction against a respondent is required to give an undertaking to pay damages to a respondent who incurs loss due to the injunction and is held ultimately to have been wrongly restrained. For the wording of an undertaking in damages see FLR 10.18(5) (in WA, FCR 316(4)). The Full Court, however, did hold in Blueseas Investments Pty Ltd & Mitchell & McGillivray [1999] FamCA 745 that an undertaking is not required of a person with limited means. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: APPLYING FOR INTERIM OR PROCEDURAL ORDER WITHOUT NOTICE

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 41 APPOINTMENT OF LITIGATION GUARDIAN A person under a disability may only start, continue, respond or seek to intervene in a case by their litigation guardian in the FCFCA (FLR 3.13) or case guardian in the FCWA (FCR 103). Such a person is defined by FLR 3.12 as a person who does not understand the nature and possible consequences of the proceeding or is not capable of adequately conducting, or giving adequate instruction for the conduct of, the proceeding. An adult with no adverse interest who can fairly and competently conduct the case for that person may be such a guardian (FLR 3.14; in WA, FCR 104). The court may appoint, replace or remove such a guardian under FLR 3.15 (in WA, FCR 105). Keyes [2009] FMCAfam 347 at [20]-[31] contains a discussion of the law relating to the appointment of a litigation guardian. For the removal of one, see Eastman & Pellis [2021] FCCA 1358. What to file? • Application (or Response) seeking the appointment (see below) • Affidavit of the proposed appointee (see precedent below) Notice of appointment to be given to other parties: FLR 3.17 (in WA, FCR 107). For an order for a litigation guardian’s costs see FLR 3.18 (in WA, FCR 108). For service on a person with a disability see FLR 2.37 (in WA, FCR 127). For a litigation guardian’s duties, see FLR 3.13 (in WA, cf. FCR 109). Guide to your Application (or Response) Either in an Initiating Application or in a Response to Initiating Application, recite in the title as the name of the party under a disability “X [full name] by [his/her] litigation guardian [OR case guardian, if in the FCWA] [full name of that guardian]”. The document should be signed by the proposed appointee (under
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: Application or in a Response to Initiating Application, recite in the title as the name of the party under a disability “X [full name] by [his/her] litigation guardian [OR case guardian, if in the FCWA] [full name of that guardian]”. The document should be signed by the proposed appointee (under “X [full name] by his/her proposed litigation guardian [OR case guardian, if in the FCWA]” [full name of proposed appointee]) Seek interim orders: 1. That pursuant to rule 3.15 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia (Family Law) Rules 2021 [full name of appointee] is appointed to act as litigation guardian for the [wife/husband] in proceedings [Action Number]. Note – For the FCWA, substitute “rule 105 of the Family Court Rules 2021” and “case guardian”. 2. That the costs and expenses of the litigation guardian [OR costs of the case guardian, if in the FCWA] be paid from the income or property of [full name of person under a disability] [OR by (specify party to pay, if applicable)]. Precedent affidavit of proposed appointee 1. [I am the (specify relationship e.g. sister) of (full name of person to be represented] [OR] [I have known (full name of person to be represented) for (number) years. I will refer to (him/her) in this affidavit as [“X”]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 42 2. [On (specify date/s and context) X told me that he did not understand the (specify type of proceedings) or what they meant, asking me to help by handling the case on [his/her] behalf. (His/her) words to me were: (specify)] [OR] 2. [On (date) the existence of court proceedings involving [X] came to my attention when (specify). Due to my concern as to (his/her) capacity to understand the nature and possible consequences of the proceeding or give adequate instructions for the conduct of the case, I made an appointment for [him/her] to see his doctor about the matter. 3. Attached to this affidavit is a report from [X’s] [specify type of medical or psychiatric practitioner] Dr [name] dated [specify] in relation to [X’s] capacity to understand the nature and possible conse- quences of the proceeding [AND/OR] give adequate instructions for the conduct of the case. Note – Ensure that your expert does cover the symptoms, diagnosis and findings leading them to reach those conclusions about that incapacity – such incapacity being the basis for the court’s appointment. Either incapacity would be enough. If both apply, the report should make that clear too. 4. I am an adult and have no interest in the case that is adverse to [X’s] interest. [Add a short sentence explaining why the applicant is applying for the appointment.] 5. I can fairly and competently conduct the case for X and I consent to act as [his/her] litigation guard- ian [case guardian, if in FCWA]. 6. [X] has agreed to pay any legal costs that may arise as a result of my acting as [his/her] litigation guardian. Precedent affidavit of applicant’s lawyer (Note – File this where it has been difficult to obtain adequate instructions and so as to annex your
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: guardian, if in FCWA]. 6. [X] has agreed to pay any legal costs that may arise as a result of my acting as [his/her] litigation guardian. Precedent affidavit of applicant’s lawyer (Note – File this where it has been difficult to obtain adequate instructions and so as to annex your medical evidence) 1. I am a legal practitioner in the employ of [firm name] of [address]. 2. I act for the [applicant/respondent] [husband/wife], [full name of X] in respect of proceedings (insert Court file number) in relation to [specify issues e.g. property and child issues]. 3. I was retained by [specify] to act for [X] on [date]. 4. I have found it impossible to obtain coherent instructions from [X]. 5. On [date], [X] and I had a conference with [barrister] in his chambers to prepare material and discuss possible strategies in respect of this case. At that conference [X] exhibited behaviours which caused me to become a little concerned about him giving evidence and providing instructions. He showed physical signs of aggression and being irrational, by: 5.1 becoming angry and raising his voice in response to basic questions as to the financial history between the parties; 5.2 becoming ‘fixated’ on a few small issues and being unable to move beyond those issues so that neither I nor [barrister] were able to obtain adequate instructions as to all aspects of [X’s] case; Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 43 5.3 becoming agitated and loud when I pressed for responses to questions, asking me to repeat the question saying that he could not remember it, and when it was repeated, yelling for minutes on end. During one such period, he picked up a letter opener on the desk and waved it around, gesticulating with his hands. I was anxious throughout the meeting and concerned as to [X’s] state of mind; 5.4 when not yelling, increasingly making irrelevant and irrational digressions away from the topic of conversation. 6. When we ceased asking questions with respect to [X’s] case [X] became visibly more relaxed and we spent the next thirty minutes discussing [X’s] emotional state. 7. In my previous similar meetings with that barrister, they usually take between an hour and 90 minutes. My meeting with [X] took 3 hours, after which I still remained without instructions as to how [X] wished to proceed. 8. After our meeting, I arranged at the suggestion of [name of barrister] for a report to be obtained from [X’s] treating psychiatrist as to [X’s] capacity for understanding the proceedings or providing adequate instructions. 9. Attached to this affidavit is the report I requested of Dr [name]. 10. In light of my experiences with X and the content of the report, I foresee that I will have difficulties in fulfilling my duty to [X] as well as my duty to the Court to present [X’s] case in a succinct, coherent manner, should a litigation guardian [or case guardian, if in the FCWA] not be appointed. Note – Being an interim application, an annexed report should be sufficient, especially if the appoint- ment is not opposed. If it is opposed, an affidavit from your expert would be preferable. Sample affida- vits of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: should a litigation guardian [or case guardian, if in the FCWA] not be appointed. Note – Being an interim application, an annexed report should be sufficient, especially if the appoint- ment is not opposed. If it is opposed, an affidavit from your expert would be preferable. Sample affida- vits of medical experts are available at pages 4-169, 6-41 and 6-44. An example of a case guardian appointment is Richardson [2010] FamCA 275. A party’s close friend was appointed in preference to a nominated lawyer in Stellard & Dresdon-Stellard [2010] FamCA 971. A case (or litigation) guardian may bring a divorce application (and should file an affidavit to prove that the party intended to end the marriage and that the parties had been separated for 12 months before filing the application): Price & Underwood (Divorce Appeal) [2009] FamCAFC 127. Manager of the affairs of a party The donee of a power of attorney or person otherwise authorised by a Commonwealth, State or Territory law (and is eligible under FLR 3.14; in WA, FCR 104) is taken to be appointed as the litigation guardian of a party under FLR 3.15(2) (in WA, FCR 105(2)) if that person has filed a notice of address for service and an affidavit which evidences their appointment as “manager of the affairs of the party” as defined in FLR 3.16 (in WA, FCR 102) and states that the person consents to being appointed. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 44 APPEALS Introduction Appeals are governed by Chapter 13 of the FLR. A party may bring an appeal from an order of a court by filing a Notice of Appeal within 28 days after the date of the order: 13.02 and 13.03 (in WA, FCR 452, 453). See the FCFCA’s brochure “Family Law: Appeals”. A Notice of Appeal is here at our eBook or at “forms & precedents”. Filing fee on Notice of Appeal: $1,665. That fee also applies to an application for leave to appeal. These fees are now increased annually on 1 July every year. See “court fees” for FCFCA and FCWA. An appeal is not a re-hearing but must be on a point of law (except for an appeal from a court of sum- mary jurisdiction, as to which see s 47A FLA). A respondent may argue that the decision below should be varied or set aside by filing a Notice of Appeal endorsed as a cross-appeal: FLR 13.07 (in WA, FCR 456). A copy of a Notice of Appeal must be served on each other party within 14 days after it is filed: FLR 13.05 (in WA, FCR 455). As to an application to extend time see June & Romano [2011] FamCAFC 31 at [4]. An appellant must file a draft index to the appeal books within 28 days after filing the Notice of Appeal: FLR 13.14 (cf. FCR 464). A Notice of Appeal may be amended without leave at any time up to and including the date fixed for the procedural hearing for the appeal: FLR 13.10 (in WA, FCR 458). The filing of a Notice of Appeal does not stay the operation or enforcement of an order. A stay applica- tion must be made to the court that made the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: up to and including the date fixed for the procedural hearing for the appeal: FLR 13.10 (in WA, FCR 458). The filing of a Notice of Appeal does not stay the operation or enforcement of an order. A stay applica- tion must be made to the court that made the order: FLR 13.12 (in WA, FCR 460) (see stay of proceed- ings below). For any such application, file an Application in an Appeal and supporting affidavit. No filing fee. Appeals from a judge of Division 1 of the FCFCA must be heard by the Full Court but appeals from a judge of Division 2 (and a Family Law Magistrate of WA) will usually be heard by a single judge. See the Court’s brochures “Appeal Procedures – Full Court” and “Appeal Procedures – Single Judge”. The rules are separate but similar – FLR 13.15-13.23 (for the former) and FLR 13.24-13.28 (for the latter) – so the following will be a summary of both. Procedural hearing Orders to be made at this hearing are set out at FLR 13.18 (for an appeal from Division 1) and FLR 13.27 (an appeal from Division 2) (in WA, FCR 464). These will usually include the contents of an ap- peal book, governed by FLR 13.20-13.21 (Division 1) (adaptable under FLR 13.27 for Division 2). In WA, see FCR 465. Appeal books The form of the appeal book is prescribed by FLR 13.21, including the following order of documents: Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 45 • Notice of Appeal • Any family or expert report received in evidence in the case relevant to the appeal • The order appealed from • A list of exhibits and each relevant exhibit (if • Reasons for judgment practicable) • Any relevant previous or subsequent order • The relevant parts of the transcript • Each relevant application • If the appeal involves a challenge to the exclu- sion of evidence – the document that is the • Any relevant response subject of the challenge • Relevant affidavits Transcripts may be obtained from the court’s reporting service at the expense of the Appellant. A summary of argument and list of authorities are also to be filed: FLR 13.23 (in WA, FCR 464). See the court brochures “Appeal procedures – Single Judge” and “Appeal procedures – Full Court”. Stay of proceedings PARENTING CASES In Aldridge & Keaton (Stay Appeal) [2009] FamCAFC 106, the Full Court outlined the applicable prin- ciples at [17] and [18], dismissing an appeal brought by a mother against Pascoe CFM’s refusal pend- ing the hearing to stay an order allowing the (same sex) respondent to continue spending time with their child. The Full Court at [21] said: “Referring to whether the refusal of a stay would render a successful appeal nugatory or make it impossible or impracticable to restore the position, he concluded that it would be likely to be more difficult to re-establish the existing warm and significant attachment between the respondent and the child if it was ended or significantly limited rather than if it was allowed to continue as he had proposed.” A limited stay of part of an interim parenting order has been granted due to a mother’s distress (which, the court accepted, would become apparent to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: the respondent and the child if it was ended or significantly limited rather than if it was allowed to continue as he had proposed.” A limited stay of part of an interim parenting order has been granted due to a mother’s distress (which, the court accepted, would become apparent to the child) over that aspect of the case, and the child’s own upset during an overnight visit to her father: Treloar & Nepean [2009] FMCAfam 847. Altobelli FM held at [6] that “the real question in a stay application is whether to grant a stay is in the best interests of the child and, if so, on what grounds should a stay be granted”. The order was modi- fied pending the appeal. See also Strahan (Stay) [2009] FamCA 1238. In Sheldon & Weir (Stay Application) [2011] FamCAFC 5 the Full Court at [14]-[16] referred to the principles governing the granting of a stay in child-related proceedings and at [21]-[22] and [55] upheld Ryan J’s refusal to stay an order for overseas reloca- tion. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 46 FINANCIAL CASES The Full Court in Gull (Stay Application) [2009] FamCAFC 104 at [9] followed established High Court authority that: “The jurisdiction to grant a stay depends on whether a stay is necessary to preserve the subject- matter of the litigation. If an application for special leave to appeal would be futile unless a stay is granted, the jurisdiction arises.” (Jennings Construction Ltd v Burgundy Royale Investments Pty Ltd (No 1) [1986] HCA 84 at [3] per Brennan J, who at [5] described a stay to preserve the litigation’s subject matter as “an extraordinary jurisdiction”, and that “exceptional circumstances must be shown before its exercise is warranted”). In Jackson & Balen [2009] FamCAFC 131 at [28] the Full Court said: “The principles to be applied in hearing a stay application pending an appeal are well settled [cases cited]. Those authorities stress the discretionary nature of the application which should be determined on its merits. Principles relevant to this matter include the following: • the onus to establish a proper basis for the stay is on the applicant for the stay. However it is not necessary for the applicant to demonstrate any ‘special’ or ‘exceptional’ circumstances; • a person who has obtained a judgment is entitled to the benefit of that judgment; • a person who has obtained a judgment is entitled to presume the judgment is correct; • the mere filing of an appeal is insufficient to grant a stay; • the application must be bona fides; • a stay may be granted on terms that are fair to all parties - this may involve a court weighing the balance of convenience and the competing rights of the parties; • a weighing of the risk that an appeal may be rendered nugatory if a stay
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: bona fides; • a stay may be granted on terms that are fair to all parties - this may involve a court weighing the balance of convenience and the competing rights of the parties; • a weighing of the risk that an appeal may be rendered nugatory if a stay is not granted – this will be a substantial factor in determining whether it will be appropriate to grant a stay; • some preliminary assessment of the strength of the proposed appeal – whether the appellant has an arguable case.” It was held in Goldsmith & Stinson (No 2) [2023] FedCFamC1A 25 at [113] that a stay operates from the date of the order so that time for compliance did not run until dismissal of the appeal. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 47 COSTS AND SECURITY FOR COSTS Parties to proceedings under the Family Law Act are usually ordered to pay their own costs, according to the general rule to that effect contained in s 117(1). An order for costs may be made if the court finds that there are circumstances justifying the making of such an order: s 117(2). The High Court said in Penfold [1980] HCA 4 at [13]: “Sub-section (2) requires a finding of justifying circumstances as an essential preliminary to the making of an order. Beyond this there is … [no] additional or special onus on an applicant for an order for costs. Consequently … we do not agree with the suggestion … that an order can only be made under s 117(2) in ‘a clear case’.” The factors relevant to whether a costs order should be made are set out in s 117(2A): a) the financial circumstances of each party; b) whether a party has legal aid and, if so, the terms of the grant; c) the conduct of the parties as to particulars, discovery of documents and such matters; d) whether non-compliance with previous orders necessitated the proceedings; e) whether any party has been wholly unsuccessful in the proceedings (Marvis [2023] FedCFamC1A 34 at [17]-[25]); f) the terms of any written offer to settle (Firmer & Britton [2012] FamCA 576; Petruski & Balewa [2013] FamCAFC 15 at [31]; 80% of costs awarded due to a maintenance claim being opposed in Bronson (No. 2) [2012] FamCA 676; indemnity costs awarded for “enormous” difference between offer and outcome in Lad & Gittins [2014] FamCA 439; but in Paradin [2020] FamCAFC 245 a costs order was set aside as W’s offer did not conclude all matters in issue); and g) such other matters as
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: (No. 2) [2012] FamCA 676; indemnity costs awarded for “enormous” difference between offer and outcome in Lad & Gittins [2014] FamCA 439; but in Paradin [2020] FamCAFC 245 a costs order was set aside as W’s offer did not conclude all matters in issue); and g) such other matters as the court considers relevant. For a useful review of each factor see Parker & Jacks (No. 3) [2009] FMCAfam 993 at [29]-[53]. A costs application is made under FLR 12.13 (in WA, FCR 331). If a costs order is made it is usually for payment of “party/party” costs. In “exceptional circumstances” an order can be made for payment of “indemnity” costs (costs as between lawyer and client i.e. a complete indemnity for all the costs reason- ably incurred by that party) under FLR 12.17(1)(b) (in WA, FCR 335(1)(b), 331(3)): see Rohnan [2010] FMCAfam 1091 at [31]-[37] and Parker & Jacks (No. 3) (above) at [62]-[64]. Examples – Indemnity costs have been awarded for false statements knowingly made; misconduct causing loss of time to the court or a party; commencement or continuation of a case for an ulterior motive or in wilful disregard of known facts or clearly established law; making allegations that ought never to have been made or groundless allegations causing a case to be unduly prolonged; an impru- dent refusal of a settlement offer; and contempt of court: Colgate-Palmolive v Cussons [1993] FCA 536 at [16]-[21] and [24], followed in Yunghanns & Ors [2000] FamCA 681 (FC) at [25]-[34] and [46]-[48]. Under FLR 12.17 (subject to FLR 12.13) both courts may set the amount to be paid; state the method of calculation; or refer the costs for assessment under FLR 12.45 (in WA, FCR 349), using the scale of costs in Schedule 3 and factors in FLR 12.47
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: [25]-[34] and [46]-[48]. Under FLR 12.17 (subject to FLR 12.13) both courts may set the amount to be paid; state the method of calculation; or refer the costs for assessment under FLR 12.45 (in WA, FCR 349), using the scale of costs in Schedule 3 and factors in FLR 12.47 (or FCR 351) (or, for indemnity costs, a costs agreement); also the matters set out in FLR 12.48 (or FCR 352). The assessment process (at FLR 12.39-12.51 or, in WA, FCR 337-355) is started by the service of a lawyer’s Itemised Costs Account pursuant to FLR 12.34 available at our online “forms & precedents” (or FCR 338). See FLR 12.33-12.38. For the review of an assessment, see FLR 12.52-12.54 (or FCR 367-369). If seeking fixed or composite costs your affidavit should contain enough information to enable those costs to be assessed. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 48 Other costs provisions • False statements. Section 117AB (which made mandatory a costs order against a party who “know- ingly made a false allegation or statement in the proceedings”) was repealed on 7 June 2012 by the Family Law Legislation Amendment (Family Violence and Other Measures) Act 2011 for the purpose (according to [79] of the Explanatory Memorandum) of removing a provision that had “operated as a disincentive” to the disclosure by “vulnerable parents” of “legitimate safety concerns”. Given that s 117AB was not repealed for being bad law and that the Explanatory Memorandum noted that “s 117 … will allow family courts to make cost orders in response to false statements in appropriate cases” a cost order, while now discretionary, should arguably be granted in such cases, under s 117(2). The following case law should be relevant to the type of conduct that hitherto attracted a mandatory costs order. Also rely on Colgate (above) for indemnity costs for “false state- ments knowingly made”. A false denial is intended to be included: Charles [2007] FamCA 276 at [30]. See Penfold (above) at [16] of the majority judgment and [4] of Murphy J’s judgment; also Parker & Jacks (No. 3) (above) at [54]-[68] and Garrod & Davenort [2021] FamCA 276. In Charles (above) at [24] Cronin J said: “For a Court to be satisfied that a person knowingly made a false allegation or statement in the proceedings must mean that a Court could be comfortable in finding that the person lied. (…) The finding must be elevated above the ‘probable’ level set out in s 140(1) of the Evidence Act 1995…That is, the Briginshaw test [a finding beyond reasonable doubt] applies.” • Costs may be awarded in vexatious proceedings (s 102QB(2)(c)); against a party who fails
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: finding that the person lied. (…) The finding must be elevated above the ‘probable’ level set out in s 140(1) of the Evidence Act 1995…That is, the Briginshaw test [a finding beyond reasonable doubt] applies.” • Costs may be awarded in vexatious proceedings (s 102QB(2)(c)); against a party who fails to disclose a discoverable document (FLR 6.17(a)(iii); in WA, FCR 210(a)(iii)); and parties (except if legal aid or hardship) may be ordered to share the cost of an ICL (s 117(3) and (4)). • An order can be made under s 117(2) for security for costs (see below) • Costs may be awarded against a lawyer (see below) • Costs may be awarded against a non-party: Yunghanns & Ors (above) at [36]-[45] Note – The above FLA provisions and related rules apply to child support proceedings: s 100 CSAA Security for costs The Full Court in Luadaka [1998] FamCA 1520 at [59]-[63] upheld the order of the trial judge Hilton J that the wife pay $10,000 as security for the husband’s costs in relation to her application to set aside a previous order, the Court taking into account that while she did not have legal counsel representing her, the husband did. It was also considered that he did have a potential claim against her for costs if her application failed, which would be unlikely to be met (the wife alleging that “she had no money”) without such an order being made. The Court (at [59]-[63]) said: “…it is necessary to establish that there are justifying circumstances. The decision to order security for costs is discretionary, both as to whether to order security, and as to the amount to be secured. The purpose of an order for security is to secure justice between the parties by ensuring that an unsuccessful party
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: establish that there are justifying circumstances. The decision to order security for costs is discretionary, both as to whether to order security, and as to the amount to be secured. The purpose of an order for security is to secure justice between the parties by ensuring that an unsuccessful party does not occasion injustice to the other. In considering whether or not to make an order, apart from those referred to in s 117(2A), matters which may be relevant include the following: Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 49 (…) In appropriate circumstances an order may be made even if the applicant for security has the means to pay his or her costs. The prospects of success is a relevant matter to take into consideration (…) It is a relevant consideration whether the applicant’s claim is made bona fide, whether it is genuine and not trivial, vexatious or a sham (…) It may be relevant to consider whether or not an order for costs would be oppressive or stifle the litigation…(in) that the order may…mean that the action cannot proceed. That prospect does not require refusal of the application but it is often a significant matter (…) It may be relevant to consider whether or not the litigation may involve a matter of public importance…this will militate against the making of an order. It may be relevant to consider whether or not there has been delay in bringing the application. An application may be refused if there is delay in making (it) and prejudice is caused to the respondent to the application (…) Other relevant matters may include any difficulties of enforcing an order for costs and the amount of costs to be incurred.” A party’s impecuniosity was given weight as a significant factor in Jones [2001] FamCA 460 (FC). For a review of the authorities, see Emmett [2011] FamCAFC 213 (FC) at [53]-[69]. The codification of the Luadaka factors These factors are now contained in FLR 12.02 (in WA, FCR 328), summarised as follows: • the means of the person from whom security is sought • the prospects of success of that person’s application • the genuineness of the application • whether their lack of means was caused by the other party’s conduct • whether an order for security would be oppressive
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: as follows: • the means of the person from whom security is sought • the prospects of success of that person’s application • the genuineness of the application • whether their lack of means was caused by the other party’s conduct • whether an order for security would be oppressive or stifle the case • whether the case involves a matter of public importance • whether a party has a costs order against the other party that is unpaid • whether the person from whom security is sought lives overseas • the likely costs of the case • whether the party from whom security is sought is a corporation • whether a party is receiving legal aid Note – If the court orders a party to give security for costs, the court may also order that upon non-compliance the case of the party be stayed: FLR 12.03 (in WA, FCR 329). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 50 Costs orders against lawyers Under s 117(2) a costs order may be made (“subject to subsections (2A), (4) and (5) and the appli- cable Rules of Court” – see below) if “the court is of opinion that there are circumstances that justify it in doing so”. Subsection (2) not being limited to “parties” (as subsection (1) is) a costs order may be made against a non-party, e.g. a solicitor: Z (a solicitor) & Limousin [2010] FamCAFC 59. In that case the Full Court upheld orders made by Guest J against a solicitor for costs wasted by his unrea- sonable conduct of the case without any, or any proper, consideration of the prospects of success. In Dwyer & Brent & Anor [2010] FMCAfam 1224 at [9] and [18] a lawyer was ordered to pay costs having regard to “the way the case [was] conducted” (the filing of an inappropriate Notice of Risk of Family Violence). See also Parker & Jacks (No. 3) [2009] FMCAfam 993 at [25]-[28] and [69]-[87] which includes a discussion as to whether an order for indemnity costs should be made against a lawyer. An indemnity costs order was made against a lawyer in Lambert & Jackson and Anor [2011] FamCA 275 at [76]-[81], [114]-[117] and [130]-[138] for concealing from the court important financial information relevant to her client’s case; in Benard & Eames and Anor [2020] FamCAFC 47 at [35]-[36] for the “unreasonable conduct of a case”; and in Reaney & Paggett [2021] FCCA 190 for an interim application that lacked professional analysis of the merits. FLR 12.15 (in WA, FCR 333) enables a person to apply for an order against a lawyer for costs thrown away during a case, because of: • the lawyer’s failure to comply with the Rules or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: [2021] FCCA 190 for an interim application that lacked professional analysis of the merits. FLR 12.15 (in WA, FCR 333) enables a person to apply for an order against a lawyer for costs thrown away during a case, because of: • the lawyer’s failure to comply with the Rules or an order • the lawyer’s failure to comply with a pre-action procedure • the lawyer’s improper or unreasonable conduct • undue delay or default by the lawyer Note – As of 6 May 2024, s 96 empowers the court to make a costs order against a lawyer for failure to assist their client to comply with the duty set out in s 95. The orders a court can make under this Rule include an order that the lawyer: • not charge the client for the work specified in the order • repay money the client has already paid towards those costs • repay to the client any costs the client has been ordered to pay to another party • pay the costs of a party • repay another person’s costs found to be incurred or wasted Lawyer-client costs From 1 July 2008, the courts opted out of the regulation of lawyer-client costs, allowing lawyers to make costs arrangements with their clients in accordance with their own State or Territory laws without having to comply with federal law as well. As to costs agreements now, see “lawyer-client documentation” in the chapter “client preliminaries”. Lawyers still have the following obligations in relation to their clients’ costs. For more on this, see chapter “client preliminaries”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 51 Costs disclosure obligations If an offer to settle is made during a property case, lawyers must tell their client their paid and payable costs to the date of the offer and their estimated future costs, to enable the client to estimate the net amount they will receive if the case is settled in accordance with the offer to settle: FLR 12.05 (in WA, FCR 326). Costs notices FLR 12.06 (cf. FCR 327 in WA) applies (unless the court otherwise orders) to all court events, except an appeal. It provides that: The lawyer for a party Not less than 1 day before each court event, must give their client a written notice of: (a) their costs, both paid and owing, up to and including that court event; (b) their estimated future costs up to and including each future court event; and (c) any expenses paid or payable to an expert witness or, if those expenses are not known, an estimate of the expenses. The lawyer must also file with the court, and serve on each other party, a copy of the notice given to their client (which, in a financial case, should specify the source of the funds for the costs paid or to be paid). An unrepresented party Not less than 1 day before each court event, must file with the court, and serve on each other party, a written statement of the costs incurred by that party up to and including that court event and the estimat- ed future costs of the party up to and including each future court event. A legally aided party The above rule does not apply to the party’s lawyer, but not less than 1 day before the first day of the trial, the lawyer must file with
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: event and the estimat- ed future costs of the party up to and including each future court event. A legally aided party The above rule does not apply to the party’s lawyer, but not less than 1 day before the first day of the trial, the lawyer must file with the court, and serve on each party, a written statement of the costs incurred by the lawyer up to and including the trial. An independent children’s lawyer Not less than 1 day before the first day of the trial, an ICL must file with the court, and serve on each party, a written statement of the costs incurred by the ICL up to and including the trial. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 53 CONFLICT OF INTEREST The law was summarised by the Full Court in Osferatu [2015] FamCAFC 177 at [20]-[26] as follows: “There are three established categories on the basis of which solicitors may be restrained from acting against their client or former client. They are: breach of confidence, breach of fiduciary duty and the inherent jurisdiction of a court over its officers and to control its process. Each cat- egory has its own principles which guide its operation. ( … ) The case before the trial judge was only concerned with the first category: the risk of the misuse of confidential information and we thus confine ourselves to it. The manner in which a client’s confidential information is to be protected in family law proceed- ings was clearly explained by the Full Court in McMillan & McMillan [2000] FamCA 1046 where the Full Court … reviewed … authorities in the Family Court and in … other courts. The follow- ing statement of Frederico J in Thevenaz & Thevenaz [1986] FamCA 44 [at [15]] was expressly adopted by the court: ‘Thus “a practitioner who wishes to cease acting for one party and to continue to act for the other party will be restrained from doing so by the court if there is any evidence that confidential communications have been made to him by the party for whom he is ceasing to act. In such a case the court will not weigh conflicting evidence as to confidence. It will act upon the evidence of the client who swears that he has made the confidential commu- nication”. (Reference omitted).’ The following passage from Thevenaz was also expressly adopted by the Full Court in McMillan: ‘It is my view that in this case [the lawyer] should not continue to
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: It will act upon the evidence of the client who swears that he has made the confidential commu- nication”. (Reference omitted).’ The following passage from Thevenaz was also expressly adopted by the Full Court in McMillan: ‘It is my view that in this case [the lawyer] should not continue to act on behalf of [the wife]. It may well be that the risks were he to do so are more theoretical than practical. How- ever, it is asserted and not contradicted that material in the files does relate to confidences exchanged in the course of the former firm previously acting on behalf of both parties and would embarrass the husband. It is of the utmost importance that justice should not only be done but should appear to be done. In the circumstances of the present case, there is a risk which may well be merely theoretical but still exists, that justice might not appear to be done. In S & S (Unrep) (“Stewart”) [1997] FamCA 65 Lindenmayer J said: ‘ ... All that is necessary is that the wife swears that she has conveyed confidential informa- tion to the solicitors and that she believes, not unreasonably, that that information may be used against her, or at least to her disadvantage, in these current proceedings...’ Of that passage the Full Court in McMillan said at [87]: ‘In other words, the client need only give evidence that he has provided confidential infor- mation to the solicitor (or in this case, the law clerk/secretary). The client does not have to divulge the content of that information. ( … )’ It is, however, important to recognise that McMillan, as were Thevenaz and Stewart, was a case where the applicant was seeking to restrain a solicitor or a clerk to whom they had recently, and
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: clerk/secretary). The client does not have to divulge the content of that information. ( … )’ It is, however, important to recognise that McMillan, as were Thevenaz and Stewart, was a case where the applicant was seeking to restrain a solicitor or a clerk to whom they had recently, and directly, given instructions from acting, or the firm to which they had moved, from acting, in those proceedings. Because the applicants in those cases had given instructions to the solicitor about the very matter in issue, it follows easily that there would be a finding that the solicitor who had moved was in possession of confidential information which is or may be relevant to that matter. It is for that very reason that the passage of Lindenmayer J in Stewart commenced with the words Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 54 ‘All that is necessary is that ...’. His Honour was simply saying that, in such circumstances, the burden borne by the applicant was discharged by such evidence. Nothing that appears in Stew- art, Thevenaz or McMillan obviates the need for an applicant seeking such relief from discharg- ing his/her burden of proof by adducing cogent and persuasive evidence. This is particularly so where, as here, the circumstances differ from McMillan. In this case Mr F had never taken instruc- tions from the wife.” The Full Court concluded (at [48]): “ … for evidence to be persuasive and cogent [the wife] should have identified the nature of the information received or likely to have been received by Mr F … that was now, or could now be, relevant to the current proceedings. She did not do so. It is not sufficient to say that, as family law proceedings cover a range of matters, any information at all received by Mr F could have been relevant. This was especially so given that three years had passed since he could have received any information and both sets of substantive proceedings … had resolved.” It was also held that the court below erred in giving no reasons as to why the wife’s email to the husband (waiving objection) did not carry significant weight. Effect of delay in objecting In McGillivray & Mitchell [1998] FamCA 96 at para 36 the Full Court said this: “It is our opinion that if a family law litigant has a genuine concern about a former legal adviser acting against him or her in later family law litigation, the litigant must take the point at least in correspondence with the other side at the earliest possible opportunity. If he or she does not do so,
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a family law litigant has a genuine concern about a former legal adviser acting against him or her in later family law litigation, the litigant must take the point at least in correspondence with the other side at the earliest possible opportunity. If he or she does not do so, then he or she is possessed of a weapon which can later be used as a delaying tactic at some point in the proceedings convenient to his or her position. Furthermore a failure to take the point initially must also cast doubt on the bona fides of any later complaint concerning the existence of confidential information in the practitioner in question, and on the bona fides of any alleged apprehension regarding the possible mis-use of such confidential information.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES 8 – 55 LITIGANTS IN PERSON A family lawyer’s approach to a litigant in person This is an edited extract of Part 4 of the Best Practice Guidelines for lawyers doing family law work (4th edition) by the Family Law Council and Family Law Section of the Law Council of Australia. A litigant in person (LIP) requires procedural fairness. A LIP may be experiencing stress … , desperation, anger, fear, anxiety or bitterness and may be suspicious of the independence of judges and lawyers ( … thinking there is collusion between the two). So be patient and adaptable. Maintain a professional and courteous demeanour … Avoid [appearing to be] too friendly with a judge or registrar and speak- ing in legalese. Keep in mind that your client will suffer if a judgment or consent order can be set aside on appeal for procedural unfairness to the LIP. Be familiar with Re F below and be aware of and take steps to avoid the risk, by your dealings with a LIP, of becoming a witness in the case. “Litigants in person – A counsel’s perspective” (2014) by Lindsay Ellison SC of the NSW bar “Litigants in person” (2015) by Tony Allen barrister of the NSW bar Acting against a litigant in person 1. Further to the above, avoid giving legal advice to or making submissions for a LIP but correct any blatant misstatement of law or fact and any concession by a LIP that is wrongly made. Volunteer information favourable to a LIP’s case if not doing so would mean that a court would form an er- roneous view of the evidence or the law. 2. Comply with your own State’s or Territory’s rules of conduct. 3. Remind a LIP of the rules as to alternative dispute resolution.
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: information favourable to a LIP’s case if not doing so would mean that a court would form an er- roneous view of the evidence or the law. 2. Comply with your own State’s or Territory’s rules of conduct. 3. Remind a LIP of the rules as to alternative dispute resolution. 4. Familiarise a LIP with resources available to a LIP (see below). 5. Pre-trial, explain that a judge is required to ensure procedural fairness so may give the appearance of assisting the LIP; counsel them about how to react to cross-examination by their former partner; and advise them that the court may allow a non-lawyer (a “McKenzie friend”) to attend court to as- sist the LIP. 6. Upon a LIP’s non-compliance with directions or an order require them in writing to comply (so as to avoid an application by you and costs). 7. Remind anyone for whom you cease to act of the need to comply with any undertakings. 8. Tell a LIP that any settlement negotiations must not be repeated. Resources for litigants in person • FCWA handbook for self-represented litigants (children’s cases) • FCWA handbook for self-represented litigants (property cases) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER EIGHT 8 – 56 Acting for a litigant in person in discrete tasks 1. Doing so may expose you to liability for any advice grounded on inaccurate, false or incomplete information. 2. In some States lawyers may limit their liability by certain wording in client engagement letters. Even without such legislation you may limit your liability by defining in writing the work you have been asked to carry out and the information you require before it is carried out. Don’t sign an Application for Consent Orders without sufficient information. 3. As a lawyer will not usually be able totally to control the limits set on their involvement these liability issues need to be anticipated in any retainer agreement. Such an agreement should provide for termination immediately upon completion of the task for which you were engaged. Acting as an ICL where a party is a litigant in person See the FCFCA’s guidelines for independent children’s lawyers here at our eBook and at our “useful papers” archive (“Independent children’s lawyers, guidelines for”). Also see www.icl.gov.au Courts’ approach to litigants in person In Re F: Litigants in Person Guidelines [2001] FamCA 348 at [253] the Full Court reviewed the guide- lines for a LIP set down in Johnson [1997] FamCA 32, restating them as follows – ‘A judge: 1. Should ensure as far as is possible … procedural fairness … a fair trial; 2. Should inform the [LIP] of the manner in which the trial is to proceed, the order of calling witnesses and the right which he or she has to cross-examine the witnesses; 3. Should explain … any procedures relevant to the litigation; 4. Should … assist … by taking … from witnesses … name, address and occ upation; 5. May, if … there is [a] … possibility of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: 1. Doing so may expose you to liability for any advice grounded on inaccurate, false or incomplete

chunks.text: calling witnesses and the right which he or she has to cross-examine the witnesses; 3. Should explain … any procedures relevant to the litigation; 4. Should … assist … by taking … from witnesses … name, address and occ upation; 5. May, if … there is [a] … possibility of … injustice … explain … the effect and perhaps … undesir- ability of [any change in usual procedure e.g.] interposition of witnesses [sought by a party] and [their] right to object; 6. May … advi[s]e … a [LIP] … [of their] right to object to inadmissible evidence and … [ask] whether [they] object. A judge is not obliged to [give] advice … [each time] questions … arise; 7. [Should] if a question is asked or evidence is sought to be tendered in respect of which the [LIP] has a possible claim of privilege … inform the [LIP] [of their] rights; 8. Should … clarify … the submissions of the [LIP] … where because of … misconceived advocacy the substantive issues are … ignored, given little attention or obfuscated … ; 9. May, where the interests of justice and the circumstances of the case require it: • draw attention to the law applied by the Court in determining issues before it; • question witnesses; • identify applications or submissions which ought to be put to the Court; • suggest procedural steps that may be taken by a party; • clarify the particulars of the orders sought by a [LIP] or the bases for such orders.’ Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
