chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 2 INTRODUCTION Financial agreements were introduced on 27 December 2000 as a means of enabling couples to opt out of the court’s jurisdiction to deal with property and spousal maintenance under Part VIII of the Family Law Act. A new Part VIIIA was inserted, enabling financial agreements: • before marriage (s 90B) (known as “pre-nuptial agreements”) • during marriage (s 90C) (whether or not the parties are separated) • after divorce (s 90D) Couples have the option of either entering into such contracts, or not doing so out of preference for less formal financial arrangements should the need (any separation) ever arise – and when the parties’ means and needs will be known. Such informal arrangements can be by way of the parties reaching agreement, then filing an application for consent orders; or negotiating a settlement after applying to the FCFCA or FCWA for property and/or spousal maintenance orders. The jurisdiction of the court ceases to apply once a financial agreement is made (s 71A). The court does, however, retain its power to set aside such an agreement (s 90K). THE DE FACTO AMENDMENT The Part VIIIAB “de facto amendment” of the FLA introduced on 1 March 2009 includes Division 4, which mirrors Part VIIIA of the Act, so as to make financial agreements available to de facto partners. • Agreements between future, current and ex-de facto partners are called “Part VIIIAB financial agreements”: ss 90UB, UC and UD • These agreements can only be made if the de facto couple are ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction: s 90UA • Part VIIIAB agreements cannot be made if a de facto relationship broke down before 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA) unless the parties opt-in to the new regime: ss86 and 86A of Part
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: if the de facto couple are ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction: s 90UA • Part VIIIAB agreements cannot be made if a de facto relationship broke down before 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA) unless the parties opt-in to the new regime: ss86 and 86A of Part 2 (transitional provisions) of Schedule 1 of the Amendment Act (Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008 (No. 115 of 2008)). Note – Our online precedent Part VIIIAB agreements contain notes as to the opt-in requirements of Part 2 of Schedule 1 of the Amendment Act. • Agreements made in Territories and referring States where the de facto relationship has not broken down are taken to be a Part VIIIAB agreement: s 92 of Part 2 of the Amendment Act • Agreements in non-referring States (WA) can become Part VIIIAB agreements if the parties move to a participating jurisdiction: s 90UE • A future, current and ex-marital or de facto couple are to be known as “spouse parties”. People linked to either party via other relationships are called “third parties” and may be added as parties. See s 4(1) • The requirement of a separation declaration mirrors s 90DA: s 90UF Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 3 • A clause requiring a third party to pay maintenance for a spouse party during the spouse party’s marriage is not binding: s 90DB • A clause for the provision of other matters between a spouse party and third party is not binding until the spouse party’s marriage breaks down: s 90DB • A termination agreement is valid if all parties to the original agreement are parties to it: subsec (4) of ss 90B, C and D • Declarations can be made about the existence of a de facto relationship and other prerequisite factors: s 90RD A NOTE OF JUDICIAL CONCERN In an address to the NSW Bar Association on 20 May 1999, the then Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia, Alastair Nicholson, spoke of the proposed introduction of financial agreements to the Fam- ily Law Act, saying this: “In relation to pre-marital agreements, the great difficulty about them is that the bargaining power may not be equal, and in many cases the parties may not have the same degree of objectivity as would a party considering entering into a commercial transaction. A pre-marital agreement is an open-ended contract that may extend for 50 years or more and it is impossible for the parties to envisage what may happen over that period. It seems unlikely that many couples will avail themselves of the option of entering into an agreement during the marriage while their relationship remains a happy one. In the case of violent or abusive marriages there may be extreme pressure to enter into such an agreement and I doubt that the provision for independent advice is likely to overcome such pressure. At the same time, proof of duress in such cases is notoriously difficult. (…) Many lawyers are not expert in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: violent or abusive marriages there may be extreme pressure to enter into such an agreement and I doubt that the provision for independent advice is likely to overcome such pressure. At the same time, proof of duress in such cases is notoriously difficult. (…) Many lawyers are not expert in family law (for the protection of people by means of adequate legal advice) (...) the measure will not reduce litigation in the area and will in all probability increase it. There will be countless arguments about the meaning of contracts; whether there was full disclosure at the time that they were made; whether or not this constituted fraud; and whether there has been a change of circumstances since the agreement was made. (…) (It) is unrealistic to expect that these property proposals will reduce the…disputes which end up requiring judicial determination. These options have the capacity to introduce greater predictability but if such certainty is at the cost of justice, then Australians will pay dearly for so-called reform.” Such observations, from the Family Court of Australia’s then most senior judge, will remind us of the controversy that marked the debate and eventual passage of the Part VIIIA amendment. Most of us would probably agree that financial agreements are no less contentious today. contends that financial agreements can have their place in some circumstances, but that they are otherwise fraught with problems, and should be handled with care. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 4 REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING To be binding, a financial (and termination) agreement (as of 4 January 2010) must: • be a written agreement as to how the parties’ property and financial resources are to be dealt with upon breakdown of the marriage, and/or as to spousal maintenance: ss 90B, C and D(1) and (2) • be made when no other financial agreement is in force as to any of those matters: ss 90B, C and D(1)(aa) • be expressed to be made under either s 90B, 90C or 90D: ss 90B, C and D(1)(b) (See Balzia & Covich [2009] FamCA 1357.) • contain a separation declaration signed by at least one of the parties stating that they have separated and are living separately and apart when the declaration was signed (or last signed, if both signed); and, in the opinion of the parties making the declaration, there is no reasonable likelihood of cohabitation being resumed: s 90DA • for any maintenance clause, specify each recipient and the amount of (or value of the property attributable to) their maintenance: s 90E • as a release of future maintenance, recite the recipient as able to support themselves without an income tested pension, allowance or benefit: s 90F (see Salvage & Fosse [2020] FamCAFC 144) • be signed by both parties: s 90G(1)(a) • if made before 14 January 2004 be signed after each party was provided with independent legal advice from a legal practitioner about:- (i) the effect of the agreement on the rights of that party; and (ii) whether or not, at the time when the advice was provided, it was to the advantage, financially or otherwise, of that party to make the agreement; and (iii) whether or not, at that time, it
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: about:- (i) the effect of the agreement on the rights of that party; and (ii) whether or not, at the time when the advice was provided, it was to the advantage, financially or otherwise, of that party to make the agreement; and (iii) whether or not, at that time, it was prudent for that party to make the agreement; and (iv) whether or not, at that time and in the light of such circumstances as were, at that time, reasonably foreseeable, the provisions of the agreement were fair and reasonable”: s 90G(1)(b) • if made on or after 14 January 2004 be signed after each party has been provided with independent legal advice from a legal practitioner about either: – the effect of the agreement on the rights of that party and about the advantages and disadvantages, at the time the advice was provided, to that party of making the agreement; OR – all of the items (i) to (iv) above • if made after 4 January 2010 be signed by parties who have each been provided (whether before or after the agreement was signed) with a signed statement from their legal practitioner that the above advice was provided to that party (s 90G(1)(c)) and a copy of that statement has been provided to the other party or their lawyer (s 90G(1)(ca)) Note – Compliance with s 90G is mandatory: Senior & Anderson [2011] FamCAFC 129 (FC) at [141]-[143]. Section 90G(1A) may save a non-compliant agreement – see Dragomirov [2024] FedCFamC1A 187 where despite defective legal advice an agreement was declared binding. But also see Senior & Anderson [2011] FamCA 802 where a pre-4/1/10 agreement without legal advice could not be saved. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 5 • not have been terminated (by a binding termination agreement under s 90J) or set aside by a court: s 90G(1)(d) Part VIIIAB financial agreements (for de facto partners) New sections were introduced to the FLA on 1 March 2009 that mirror the above sections for financial agreements between de facto partners (called “Part VIIIAB financial agreements”). The equivalent sec- tions are ss 90UB (for s 90B), 90UC (for s 90C), 90UD (for s 90D), 90UF and UG (for s 90DA), 90UH (for s 90E), 90UI (for s 90F), and 90UJ (for s 90G). The Full Court in Black [2008] FamCAFC 7 set aside a financial agreement for not containing a statement acknowledging that the parties had received independent legal advice as required by s 90G(1)(b) (above). The Act, however, was amended on 4 January 2010 as to s 90G as above, (1A) being added to empower the court to declare a financial (or termination) agreement to be binding despite: • each party not having been provided with the required advice; or • in respect of post-4/1/10 agreements – each party not having been provided with a signed statement by a legal practitioner as to the advice provided to them, or given a copy of the other’s party’s lawyer’s statement; if the court is satisfied that it would be unjust and inequitable if the agreement were not binding on the spouse parties to the agreement (disregarding any changes in circumstances from the time the agreement was made). This amendment extends to Part VIIIAB agreements. The Full Court held in Parker [2012] FamCAFC 33 that ss 90G(1A), (1B) and (1C) should be construed liberally (“whether as to ‘technicality’ or otherwise” being added by Murphy J, in dissent but where a view was not expressed by the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: was made). This amendment extends to Part VIIIAB agreements. The Full Court held in Parker [2012] FamCAFC 33 that ss 90G(1A), (1B) and (1C) should be construed liberally (“whether as to ‘technicality’ or otherwise” being added by Murphy J, in dissent but where a view was not expressed by the majority). We recommend • That although an agreement no longer needs (a) to state that the parties received independent advice or (b) a lawyer’s statement to be annexed, we recommend as good practice that you con- tinue preparing agreements that do both (as per our precedents, which we will keep as they are). • That you make sure a photocopy of the original of your (lawyer’s) statement is provided to your client (before or after the agreement is signed) and also given to the other party or their lawyer before you archive the original. Both to be provided with a covering letter. In Fevia & Carmel-Fevia [2009] FamCA 816, Murphy J ruled invalid a (pre-marital) s 90B agreement where the husband had disclosed a list of his assets, but no annexure was attached to the agreement when the wife signed it; and the agreement had an annexure attached when signed by the husband, but no copy of what he had signed had been given to the wife. In Hoult [2013] FamCAFC 109 the Full Court held that the court need “only to be satisfied that the ad- vice referred to in s 90G(1)(b) had been given” not “the content of the legal advice” ([100] per Thackray J and [279] per Strickland and Ainslie-Wallace JJ) and that the certificate (supported by any relevant recital) should be treated as prima facie evidence of compliance with s 90G(1), so that the party alleg- ing non-compliance bears the burden of adducing or eliciting sufficient
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: the legal advice” ([100] per Thackray J and [279] per Strickland and Ainslie-Wallace JJ) and that the certificate (supported by any relevant recital) should be treated as prima facie evidence of compliance with s 90G(1), so that the party alleg- ing non-compliance bears the burden of adducing or eliciting sufficient evidence to put compliance in doubt. If that burden is discharged the onus passes back to the party relying on the agreement to prove the giving of the requisite legal advice to both parties. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 6 In Adamidis [2009] FMCAfam 1104, Lapthorn FM severed a release of maintenance clause from an agreement which contained no provision for payment or allocation of maintenance as required by s 90E, enabling a party to apply for maintenance he would not have been able to seek had the agree- ment been drawn properly. HOW TO TAKE INSTRUCTIONS IN RELATION TO A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT Despite the importance of consensus between parties as to what they want, it is advisable to take instructions from one party only so that the parties each consult their own lawyer independently. If you draft an agreement after seeing the parties together, you would have to refer each of them to a second lawyer for the requisite independent advice (and a conflict of interest would then prevent you from representing either party in any contentious marital matter later). When a party asks you about having an agreement, they are in need of your advice. Avoid jumping in and necessarily recommending one. Your basic roles are to: • advise as to the effect of the agreement on their rights and the advantages and disadvantages to them of entering into it (in accordance with the certificate you will sign) • advise against a financial agreement if that is your advice (whichever party you act for), and say so in a written advice to your client with your reasons for that advice • provide legal advice so that your client can make an informed decision whether or not to enter into the agreement (see Parker [2010] FamCA 664 at [113]-[114] per Strickland J, set aside on appeal – see “strict compliance no longer necessary” above), your role not being to refuse to prepare or witness a financial agreement or refuse to sign a statement of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: whether or not to enter into the agreement (see Parker [2010] FamCA 664 at [113]-[114] per Strickland J, set aside on appeal – see “strict compliance no longer necessary” above), your role not being to refuse to prepare or witness a financial agreement or refuse to sign a statement of independent advice – unless you doubt your client’s capacity to make the agreement (voluntarily and with informed consent) or the capacity of your own draftsmanship to achieve the intended aim of the agreement • prepare a draft agreement – if so instructed after (or despite) the giving of that advice – that complies with Part VIIIA or Part VIIIAB of the FLA • then summarise the purpose of the agreement and your advice in a covering letter to your client with your draft agreement, for discussion between the parties in private prior to the other party seeking their independent advice (for sample letter, see “precedents”) • advise as to any proposed amendments, ensuring that the agreement is exchanged (Fevia & Carmel-Fevia [2009] FamCA 816) and your certificate is signed after all amendments have been made, not before (Parker [2010] FamCA 664, although set aside on appeal, see above) Should de factos separating before 1 March 2009 (1/7/10 in SA) opt for a Part VIIIAB financial agreement? Section 86A(6) of Part 2 of Schedule 1 of the Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008 allows this (except in WA). Before advising your client, compare your State or Territory law with the FLA – for example as to enforcement or the grounds for varying or setting aside an agreement. The FLA may expose an agreement to being varied or set aside on maintenance grounds not available under your State or Territory law. Update 64 March 2025 quarter
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: or Territory law with the FLA – for example as to enforcement or the grounds for varying or setting aside an agreement. The FLA may expose an agreement to being varied or set aside on maintenance grounds not available under your State or Territory law. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: REQUIREMENTS FOR AN AGREEMENT TO BE BINDING

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 7 DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT Our approach becomes clearer if we recognise the different circumstances in which our services will usually be required: A one-sided unilateral quarantine – Scenario 1 You are consulted by a person wanting a pre-marital agreement to quarantine his or her entire wealth, for the sole or primary purpose of securing that wealth against claim by the other party, without any particular thought being given to that party’s future needs. The unilateral quarantine of one party’s existing property – especially when accompanied by a (usually equal) division of the couple’s future assets – is where problems can arise for both parties. For examples of what can occur behind the scenes for the other party to end up “agreeing” to sign such agreements see Jacobs & Vale [2008] FMCAfam 641 (“unjust enrichment” below) or the more extreme case of G & G [2000] FamCA 1075 before the Full Court (“undue influence” below). You will find that the initiating party will expect the agreement you prepare to be and remain binding regardless of what their partner’s future needs might be. It is important here (if only in terms of your liability) to manage that expectation. Advise your client of the advantages and disadvantages of financial agreements as set out below, including the circumstances in which they can be set aside. Consider whether it is even within the scope of your draftsmanship to protect your agreement from future challenge. A case study The facts of Jacobs & Vale (above) are typical except that here the husband was the financially weaker party, the quarantined wealth ($1.29m) being the wife’s. The husband’s assets were worth just $55,000. Jarrett FM (at [23]) recounted this evidence filed by Mr Jacobs: “At the commencement of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: case study The facts of Jacobs & Vale (above) are typical except that here the husband was the financially weaker party, the quarantined wealth ($1.29m) being the wife’s. The husband’s assets were worth just $55,000. Jarrett FM (at [23]) recounted this evidence filed by Mr Jacobs: “At the commencement of our relationship I was working…full time as a project architect on a salary of $80,000…I was also working part time, mornings and afternoons…as a project manager for 25 hours a week at $35.00 an hour. (Ms Vale) was working as a solicitor on $55.000.00… About 6 months prior to our marriage, (she) and I had discussed entering into a BFA. (Ms Vale) told me that her parents would not allow her to marry me without one. I initially objected to the agreement. I did not think it was necessary. However, in order to keep the peace, I said to (Ms Vale) at one stage that ‘what’s yours is yours, what’s mine is mine and what we do together is split down the middle’. …(Ms Vale) then instructed her solicitors to prepare a (s 90B) Financial Agreement…(and) ar- ranged for me to meet with a lawyer to discuss the agreement. I did not want to sign the agreement. I did not consider that it was a positive step at the begin- ning of our marriage. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 8 During our engagement I was living on the Gold Coast but would travel to Brisbane to spend the weekends with (Ms Vale) at her home. On the evening of Sunday 6 October 2002, as we were going to bed (she) told me that she had arranged a meeting for me the following day at the solicitors firm…on the Gold Coast. I was travelling to the Gold Coast the next day for work. (Ms Vale) told me that evening that we would not be getting married unless I attended the offices of (a Gold Coast law firm) to sign the agreement. I attended (those) offices…on the 7 October 2002 during my lunch break. I was there for approximately 30 minutes. I had not seen a copy of the agreement before attending those offices although I had provided (Ms Vale) with information for the Schedule setting out my assets and liabilities at the time. I signed the agreement because I wanted the wedding to go ahead. Prior to my signing the agreement (we) did not discuss (its) terms... The only discussions we had were (as) to the compensation payment to me for my assistance with the supervision of the construction of the house and the conceptual design. We agreed that I would sketch a design of the house and have a builder design and construct the home. I would supervise as the superintendent of the construction. I had fully intended to keep working full time during the construction. There was no suggestion by either of us that I quit my job or take a larger role in the construction. I did not intend to renew my builder’s licence as I was only supervising the construction. (Ms Vale) and I agreed that it would take approximately two months
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: construction. There was no suggestion by either of us that I quit my job or take a larger role in the construction. I did not intend to renew my builder’s licence as I was only supervising the construction. (Ms Vale) and I agreed that it would take approximately two months to produce the conceptual design and approximately ten months to supervise the construction. We estimated that it would take 100 hours for the design process and 500 hours for the supervision. At a rate of $50 an hour over 600 hours, this equates to $30,000. This is the figure we used for the compensation payment in the agreement. As it happened, however, I had to leave full time employment and take on the responsibility for the construction of our home to the extent that neither of us had foreseen when entering into the BFA on the 7 October 2002.” The wife’s application for summary dismissal was dismissed and the husband was allowed to continue with his claim for a property settlement in the order of $380,000. Comment Many of the insidious aspects of unilateral agreements (allegedly) occurred there – manipulation, marriage having its “price”, ultimatum, subjugation (and even, some time later, unforeseen hardship) – and are typical of the kind of pressure that is often brought to bear in the lead up to the signing of such agreements – quite often just days before the wedding (see G & G at “undue influence” below). It makes for uncomfortable reading to see allegations of a loving partner being worked on – initial resistance, then acquiescence, (short-lived) bravado (“what’s yours is yours”), retraction of consent and then, ultimately, resignation. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 9 Relationship inequality a gender-free issue That case dealt with a future husband as vulnerable party. For an example of the more usual case of a future wife being caught in an unequal relationship see G & G below under “undue influence”. Many Scenario 1 agreements will recite mutuality of quarantine, which you know is not true as soon as you are given the respective schedules of assets. Unilateral agreements that go on to make all future assets jointly owned compound the disadvantage of the weaker party who in the absence of such a provision would be rightly entitled to an unequal adjust- ment of property in their favour. There is also much extreme draftsmanship in circulation, with its sliding scale of annual percentages or amounts; guaranteed sums or percentage of total assets; fixed maximum amounts; a deal to pay out a mortgage after X years etc, so as to anticipate the parties’ future needs and means, allocate an appropriate settlement and hope that it holds up. Avoid this – noting what Nicholson CJ had to say (above) about long-term pre-marital agreements. Such agreements will be found elsewhere than here. has confined its precedent agreements to Scenario 3 below, in which there is real agreement or mutual benefit. Independent legal advice – Scenario 2 You are consulted by a person whose partner wants one. Here our function is to advise as to the effect of the agreement on their rights and as to the advantages and disadvantages of the agreement, and to and sign a certificate as prescribed by s 90G(1)(b) (see “requirements for an agreement to be binding” above). The role of an independent legal adviser naturally includes the protection of a weaker party from exploitation. It is notable that of the nine laws of
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: disadvantages of the agreement, and to and sign a certificate as prescribed by s 90G(1)(b) (see “requirements for an agreement to be binding” above). The role of an independent legal adviser naturally includes the protection of a weaker party from exploitation. It is notable that of the nine laws of the Commonwealth, States and Territories as to relationship agreements prior to 1 March 2009 only one, the Domestic Partners Property Act 1996 (SA), required the independent adviser to elicit “credible assurances that the party was not acting under coercion or undue influence”. If your client insists on signing despite your advising against doing so, you should sign the lawyer’s cer- tificate; and protect yourself by means of a letter to your client confirming your advice and, if you feel the need to, a simple (one page) deed of release signed by the client. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 10 Real agreements – Scenario 3 Here, an agreement is sought by both parties or recommended by you or the other party’s lawyer in an appropriate case. This is the purest form of client consultation where a financial agreement makes sense to everyone – real agreement. They are set out below under “when a financial agreement may be appropriate” and may be summarised as: • Mutual quarantine of assets • Unilateral quarantine of a special asset • Release of spousal maintenance in exchange for a satisfactory property settlement Note – We discuss a fourth type of financial agreement, being a mutual quarantine of existing assets with provision also made for future assets, for couples late in their relationship with no children. THE TWO MAIN PROBLEMS WITH FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS A client seeing you for the first time about a financial agreement should be informed that the main problems with such agreements are that: • they can either be impossible for the financially weaker party to get out of in the event of later hardship, where there are no children to each other and none intended; or • where children are or might be involved, can require constant (and tedious) re-doing, so as not to risk being set aside for a party’s hardship due to a change in circumstances relating to a child (this being a problem for the financially stronger party expecting the agreement to be “binding”) Consider this from our poll: Question: In the 8 years since their inception, how many of your financial agreements (1–2 a month) have been updated by later financial agreements? Answer: A handful. Some agreements recite that the parties “will review the agreement” if a child comes along and the mother forgoes employment to care for the child, but that will
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: since their inception, how many of your financial agreements (1–2 a month) have been updated by later financial agreements? Answer: A handful. Some agreements recite that the parties “will review the agreement” if a child comes along and the mother forgoes employment to care for the child, but that will not go far enough without a clause revoking the agreement (requiring them to negotiate and make a fresh agreement in light of the new financial circumstances of the parties). Even if you were to program the sending of, say, annual client reminders of the need to renew financial agreements as circumstances change, could you possibly ensure that they did so? Or would they begin resenting your “interference in their lives”, perhaps even doubting your competence (“why couldn’t all this have been sorted out to start with”)? Will you then begin wondering if it is worth having an agreement that requires such ongoing monitoring? Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: DIFFERENT SCENARIOS IN WHICH YOUR SERVICES MAY BE SOUGHT

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 11 OTHER DISADVANTAGES OF FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS • A financial agreement is not required to be fair (see s 90K), whereas a property settlement from the court is required to be “just and equitable” (s 79(2) of the FLA) • A financial agreement cannot be set aside on the ground of hardship if the parties have no children to each other • A financial agreement should be weighed against the option of not having one – the freedom to negotiate a settlement should the need arise (and when respective needs and means are known); apply for consent orders; or issue proceedings and negotiate that way (nine out of 10 cases settle before trial) Consider this from the same poll: Question: Is Part VIII less likely to give a fair result in the absence of a financial agreement? Answer: No. • An inappropriate financial agreement – whether it binds a financially weaker client to a deal of which she/he later complains or gives, say, the wife of your financially stronger client a loophole of which he later complains – can have implications for your own liability Consider this from the poll: Question: What proportion of your financial agreements remain untested by the court because the parties are still together? Answer: 95% • A time of marriage preparations is unlikely to be a sound basis for making a pre-marital contract (the husband in Jacobs & Vale signed his five days before the wedding, and the wife in G & G, two days before) and may well render the agreement voidable (see “void, voidable or unenforceable” below). • The disadvantages outlined by Nicholson CJ above in “a note of judicial concern” • A unilateral financial agreement may be in conflict with a couple’s marriage vows and, if not limited in
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: G, two days before) and may well render the agreement voidable (see “void, voidable or unenforceable” below). • The disadvantages outlined by Nicholson CJ above in “a note of judicial concern” • A unilateral financial agreement may be in conflict with a couple’s marriage vows and, if not limited in the scope of its quarantine, may be construed as a condition precedent to marriage and thus voidable on the ground of public policy “In sickness and in health” You will rarely, if ever, find a clause in an agreement that recognises the value of intangible contributions by the financially weaker party such as to the maintenance or improvement of property; the nursing of the other party in times of sickness; or the forgoing of full-time work for the good of family or husband’s career (see G & G under “undue influence” below, in which the Full Court adopted the stance of the trial judge – again, Nicholson CJ – in this regard). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 12 WHEN A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT MAY BE APPROPRIATE A financial agreement may be appropriate when it makes sense to both parties and is likely to be enforceable, such as where its purpose is: • to enable both parties for the future benefit of the children of their previous marriages to preserve certain assets of theirs from future claim by the other, and to limit the agreement to such property (mutual quarantine) • to enable one party for the future benefit of the children of their previous marriage to preserve from future claim by the other certain special assets, and to limit the agreement to that purpose (limited unilateral quarantine) • (after separation) for the agreement to operate as a release from future spousal maintenance in exchange for a satisfactory property settlement (release of spousal maintenance) Note – A fourth type of financial agreement, being a mutual quarantine of specific existing assets that also provides for the joint ownership of all future property subject to some exceptions may be feasible, as was held to be valid by Cronin J in Cording & Oster [2010] FamCA 511. However, as one of our subscribers has pointed out, “the facts of that case contributed to the court find- ing the agreement to be enforceable. The agreement was signed towards what was ultimately the end of the relationship, not at the beginning, and there were no children of the relationship. Would the court view a pre-nuptial agreement, similar to Cording entered into by a couple at the begin- ning of their relationship who go on to have a long relationship and children, as enforceable? That remains to be seen.” In the first two cases it should be sufficient to confine the agreement to a simple quarantine of the relevant assets; leaving
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: WHEN A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT MAY BE APPROPRIATE

chunks.text: into by a couple at the begin- ning of their relationship who go on to have a long relationship and children, as enforceable? That remains to be seen.” In the first two cases it should be sufficient to confine the agreement to a simple quarantine of the relevant assets; leaving division of all other and future assets to be as agreed informally or by follow- ing the FCFCA’s pre-action procedures (Part 1, Schedule 1 of the FLR) or resolved by court proceedings under Part VIII as a last resort. Section 90K (grounds for setting aside an agreement) was put there for the protection of the vulnerable or disadvantaged. Neither party could reasonably object to the court having a role in applying such safeguards should the making or application of an agreement be properly called into question. Nor should we shy away from the court’s jurisdiction under Part VIII of the Family Law Act, ss 79 and 75(2) being two of the most durable – least amended – sections of the Act. The Court’s pre-action procedures may be adopted in your Agreement as a non-adversarial means of resolution. This kind of structure offers both a consensual financial arrangement and independence from the court in the resolution of any dispute. Identifying a proper and limited basis for a financial agreement will lend itself to simple expression. If you keep the agreement simple, the parties will understand it and make sense of it. For samples of such agreements, see “precedents” below. Note – Not included in the above list are other instances in which a financial agreement may be used – for maintenance for a stepchild or adult child (s 90E) or for superannuation (s 90XH). They are, however, rare and are not recommended, as court proceedings and consent orders are usually a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: WHEN A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT MAY BE APPROPRIATE

chunks.text: Not included in the above list are other instances in which a financial agreement may be used – for maintenance for a stepchild or adult child (s 90E) or for superannuation (s 90XH). They are, however, rare and are not recommended, as court proceedings and consent orders are usually a better option, if only for enforcement reasons. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: WHEN A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT MAY BE APPROPRIATE

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 13 WHEN A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT MAY NOT BE APPROPRIATE • for any couple intending to have a family – children being the basis of setting the agreement aside due to a party’s hardship following a material change in circumstances (see below) • where there are no children and none intended, and your client is the financially weaker party who, upon later suffering hardship by being bound by its terms, may look to you for compensation – unless you are content to defend yourself against a claim one day that you were responsible for their loss • where your most creative drafting effort to anticipate the other party’s future needs (sliding scale of provision and so on) may one day still not be enough for that party • where your client requires a guarantee from you that the quarantine you prepare for him will hold up against any attempt to upset it • where you are not able or willing to supervise your client in an annual review of the agreement and see that the parties make a new one in the event of a material change in circumstances – a party’s child-related hardship being a ground for an agreement being set aside • where neither party has any significant assets, liabilities or financial resources • an unlimited unilateral quarantine (benefiting only one party) • where you are instructed to prepare one shortly before an important event, such as the parties’ wedding, where a claim of undue influence might later arise (see G & G below “undue influence”) Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: WHEN A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT MAY NOT BE APPROPRIATE

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 14 GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT The following also applies to a termination agreement. Section 90K(1) empowers a court to make an order setting aside a financial agreement if, and only if, the court is satisfied that: (a) the agreement was obtained by fraud (including non-disclosure of a material matter); or (aa) either party to the agreement entered into the agreement: (i) for the purpose, or for purposes that included the purpose, of defrauding or defeating a creditor or creditors of the party; or (ii) with reckless disregard of the interests of a creditor or creditors of the party; or (b) the agreement is void, voidable or unenforceable; or (c) in the circumstances that have arisen since the agreement was made it is impracticable for the agreement or a part of the agreement to be carried out; or (d) since the making of the agreement, a material change in circumstances has occurred (being circumstances relating to the care, welfare and development of a child of the marriage) and, as a result of the change, the child or, if the applicant has caring responsibility for the child (as defined in subsection(2)), a party to the agreement will suffer hardship if the court does not set the agreement aside; or (e) in respect of the making of a financial agreement — a party to the agreement engaged in conduct that was, in all the circumstances, unconscionable; or (f) a payment flag is operating under Part VIIIB on a superannuation interest covered by the agreement and there is no reasonable likelihood that the operation of the flag will be terminated by a flag lifting agreement under that Part; or (g) the agreement covers at least one superannuation interest that is an unsplittable interest
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: operating under Part VIIIB on a superannuation interest covered by the agreement and there is no reasonable likelihood that the operation of the flag will be terminated by a flag lifting agreement under that Part; or (g) the agreement covers at least one superannuation interest that is an unsplittable interest for the purposes of Part VIIIB. “Creditor” in s 90K(1)(aa) includes a person who could reasonably have been foreseen by the party as being reasonably likely to become a creditor of the party: s 90K(1A) “Caring responsibility” in s 90K(1)(d) refers to a parent with whom the child lives (or is to live under a parenting order), or who has parental responsibility under such an order: s 90K(2) The law of contract Whether an agreement is valid, enforceable or effective is to be determined by the court under the law of contract: s 90KA. In Kostres [2009] FamCAFC 222 at [128]-[129] and [132]-[123], the Full Court ruled an agreement’s ambiguous clauses about future assets to be unenforceable. Part VIIIAB financial agreements (for de facto couples) The equivalent section in Part VIIIAB for de facto partners is s 90UM. The grounds for setting aside such an agreement are the same, with the addition of an intention to defraud the spouse of a de facto partner or (oddly) a de facto partner’s partner from another relationship. Agreements in non-referring States that come under the Act are covered by the section too. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 15 “The agreement was obtained by fraud” The clearest explanation of “fraud” comes from Lord Denning MR in Barclays Bank Ltd v Cole [1966] 3 All ER 948 at 950 when applying the definition of Lord Herschell LC in Derry v Peek (1889) 14 AC 337 at 374 (adopted by the Full Court in Green & Kwiatek [1982] FamCA 54: “’Fraud’ in ordinary speech means the using of false representations to obtain an unjust advantage… Likewise in law ‘fraud’ is proved when it is shown that a false representation has been made knowingly, or without belief in its truth, or recklessly, careless whether it be true or false.” Fraud can be hard to prove: see Wallace & Stelzer [2011] FamCA 54 at [10], [50]-[51] and [290]. “Non-disclosure of a material matter” In Adame [2014] FCCA 42 where the husband did not disclose that he had “bought another house in California” ([67]) Judge Jarrett said at [131]-[133]: “I am satisfied that when Mr Adame signed the agreement he knew that the representation that all of his assets were detailed in Schedule A to the agreement was false. I am satisfied that he know- ingly made that representation to Mrs Adame. I am satisfied that he intended that she rely on that representation. ( … ) I am satisfied that Mrs Adame relied upon Mr Adame’s statement set out in Recital J of the financial agreement (… ) In those circumstances the financial agreement was void- able at Mrs Adame’s election.” “Void, voidable or unenforceable” Under common law and equity a court may hold an agreement to be voidable by a party or unenforce- able on such grounds as duress, undue influence, unjust enrichment and unconscionability (the last of those also being a separate ground under s 90K
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: Mrs Adame’s election.” “Void, voidable or unenforceable” Under common law and equity a court may hold an agreement to be voidable by a party or unenforce- able on such grounds as duress, undue influence, unjust enrichment and unconscionability (the last of those also being a separate ground under s 90K – see below). An agreement was held in Adame (above) to be voidable at the wife’s election for the husband’s misrepresentation of his assets. It was also found that the wife had signed the agreement under duress ([138]-[146]). Duress ‘Duress…need [not]…involve a direct threat of physical violence so long as there is sufficient oppres- sion…to vitiate the reality of…consent.’: Teves & Campomayor [1994] FamCA 57 applied in Robert & Golden [2011] FamCA 443. Case law was discussed in Thorne v Kennedy [2017] HCA 49 at [26]-[29] (also see [2]). Undue influence In G & G [2000] FamCA 1075 a pre-marital agreement, not under Part VIIIA, made by a NSW de facto couple two days before their wedding was not enforced by Boland J, whose decision was upheld by the Full Court despite the agreement being made on legal advice. Nicholson CJ, at [34], in a judgment of the whole Court, said: “I believe that she was entitled to take into account her findings as to the unilateral imposition by the husband of his will on the wife and that…may well be a relevant factor in considering agreements of this sort.” Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 16 The couple in their 70s had had a close friendship for 13 years. The court heard evidence ([16]) that the parties had discussed marriage. The wife’s evidence was: “After his mother’s death we spoke on a number of occasions regarding marriage. I would say…`Why don’t we get married?’ He would say…`In time’. Later he would say… `I will marry you if you sign a Pre-Marital Agreement’. I felt that he either wanted to marry me or not and that such an Agreement was not necessary. On such occasions I said to him… `I do not want to sign a Pre-Marital Agreement’. The husband would say… `I am not going to marry you unless you sign it.’ After a considerable period of time I relented and that Agreement was signed.’’ After noting, at [22], that the agreement had been entered into on legal advice, Nicholson CJ, at [23] and [24], referred to the trial judge saying this about the wife: “I have some doubts about the circumstances under which the wife entered into the agreement, and whether her agreement was truly voluntary and the husband’s actual understanding of the effect of the agreement. ( … ) I find the wife relented to sign the agreement because after a 13 year relationship she wished to have the parties’ relationship formalised. She was no doubt in a position of vulnerability because of the uncertainty of her status, and I find there was inequality in her bargaining position with the husband who unilaterally imposed his condition precedent on the wife prior to the marriage.” His Honour, at [26], then referred to these further remarks of the trial judge, Boland J: “The agreement may have been considered to make a just and equitable provision for the wife at the time
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: the husband who unilaterally imposed his condition precedent on the wife prior to the marriage.” His Honour, at [26], then referred to these further remarks of the trial judge, Boland J: “The agreement may have been considered to make a just and equitable provision for the wife at the time of its execution. It may have seemed in fact generous to the wife if the marriage had only lasted a short time or it may have in fact reflected the past contributions made by the wife over the parties’ preceding 13 year relationship. However, it contained no provision to increase the wife’s entitlements to recognise long term contributions she may make to the marriage, for example, if the husband suffered illness and she provided substantial nursing services to him or the marriage endured for many years. The agreement did not contemplate the circumstances as have occurred in this case that the wife’s assets may diminish, that she may suffer ill health requiring domestic assistance and that she could be dependant on the aged pension to meet her daily living expenses. In these circumstances the provisions and particularly having regard to her contributions during the marriage cannot now be regarded as just and equitable.” For a discussion of the case law on undue influence see Thorne v Kennedy [2017] HCA 49 at [30]-[36]; also [1]-[2] and [54]-[60] of the majority judgment. Unjust enrichment In Jacobs & Vale [2008] FMCAfam 641, Jarrett FM had occasion to review the authorities both as to unjust enrichment and unconscionability in respect of a wife’s application for summary dismissal of the husband’s application for an order setting aside a financial agreement under Part VIIIA. In this case, a wife who wished to quarantine her assets valued at $1.29m prepared a financial agreement, prevailing upon her husband
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: unjust enrichment and unconscionability in respect of a wife’s application for summary dismissal of the husband’s application for an order setting aside a financial agreement under Part VIIIA. In this case, a wife who wished to quarantine her assets valued at $1.29m prepared a financial agreement, prevailing upon her husband (his assets being worth just $50,000) to sign it. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 17 Jarrett FM, at [29], referred to “Mr Jacobs’ claim that Ms Vale would be ‘unjustly enriched’ by the con- tributions made by him”, and cited David Securities Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [1992] HCA 48 in which the High Court at [46] said: “…the law recognises, in a variety of distinct categories of case, an obligation on the part of a defendant to make fair and just restitution for a benefit derived at the expense of a plaintiff ( … ) (but) it is not legitimate to determine whether an enrichment is unjust by reference to some subjective evaluation of what is fair or unconscionable. Instead, recovery depends upon the existence of a qualifying or vitiating factor such as mistake, duress or illegality.” Example The High Court in David Securities continued at [46]: “In other words, receipt of a payment which has been made under a fundamental mistake is one of the categories of case in which the facts give rise to a prima facie obligation to make restitution, in the sense of compensation for the benefit of unjust enrichment, to the person who has sustained the countervailing detriment.” Note – Jarrett FM was not required to determine the merits of the husband’s claim that the financial agreement should be set aside, the case being confined to whether he had an arguable case (the Court holding that he did). “Impracticable for the agreement to be carried out” A husband’s application to set aside an order transferring a business to him because a downturn had reduced its value was dismissed in La Rocca [1991] FamCA 97 by Kay J who said: “My own view is that the concept of impracticability…is akin to the application of the doctrine of frustration in contractual matters. What the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: an order transferring a business to him because a downturn had reduced its value was dismissed in La Rocca [1991] FamCA 97 by Kay J who said: “My own view is that the concept of impracticability…is akin to the application of the doctrine of frustration in contractual matters. What the Parliament is concerned with and what ought to be concerning the Court is the happening of events which cannot be reasonably foreseen, which will have the effect of causing an injustice to one of the parties if the happening of such events is not given effect to. (…) The potential insolvency of one of the parties in the future is not such a mat- ter…In every case before the Court property values may change, go up or down, business may flourish or not flourish, the vicissitudes of life may affect one of the parties.” See also Sanger [2011] FamCAFC 210 (FC) at [63]-[67], [82], [85]-[86] and [97]-[99]. In Herold & Kay [2012] FMCAfam 1071 at [41]-[43] an agreement was held to be unenforceable due to impracticability (also on the ground of frustration) when a party was unable to refinance a home mortgage. “A material change in circumstances relating to…child…resulting in hardship” Proving “a material change in circumstances” is less onerous than proving “exceptional circumstances” for the setting aside of a property order, so does not require “hardship…of such a serious nature (result- ing) in such inequity that it can only be rectified by the extreme step of setting aside…an existing order of the Court”: Simpson & Hamlin [1984] FamCA 62 at [36]. See Hann & Green [2012] FamCA 113 at [50]-[95] as to a change in the care of children. Hardship must result from such a change, not from another cause eg the terms of the agreement: Fewster & Drake
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: order of the Court”: Simpson & Hamlin [1984] FamCA 62 at [36]. See Hann & Green [2012] FamCA 113 at [50]-[95] as to a change in the care of children. Hardship must result from such a change, not from another cause eg the terms of the agreement: Fewster & Drake [2016] FamCAFC 214. For a discussion of the para (d) ground see Pascot [2011] FamCA 945 at [349]-[381]. See “hardship” under s 44(4) FLA (“leave to extend time for issuing property proceedings” in Chapter 7). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 18 The Full Court in Whitford [1979] FamCA 3 at [37] said: “Hardship may be caused to an applicant if leave were not granted to institute proceedings, although the application is not in necessitous circumstances. Whatever the financial situation of an applicant may be, his or her loss of a prospective entitlement to property including money, or his or her inability to have the financial and property relations of the parties adjusted or resolved, may constitute hardship.” “Hardship” has been construed as “substantial detriment”: Whitford (above) at [32]. “Unconscionable conduct (in the making of the agreement)” Unconscionable conduct was considered in the High Court case of Commercial Bank of Australia v Amadio [1983] HCA 14 by Deane J who at [13] of his judgment said: “Unconscionable dealing looks to the conduct of the stronger party in attempting to enforce, or retain the benefit of, a dealing with a person under a special disability in circumstances where it is not consistent with equity or good conscience that he should do so.” His Honour further explained this principle in Louth v Diprose [1992] HCA 61 at [11]: “It has long been established that the jurisdiction of courts of equity to relieve against unconscionable dealing extends generally to circumstances in which (i) a party to a transaction was under a special disability in dealing with the other party to the transaction with the consequence that there was an absence of any reasonable degree of equality between them and (ii) that special disability was sufficiently evident to the other party to make it prima facie unfair or ‘unconscionable’ that that other party procure, accept or retain the benefit of, the disadvantaged party’s assent to the impugned transaction in the circumstances in which he or she procured or accepted it.” Examples
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: that special disability was sufficiently evident to the other party to make it prima facie unfair or ‘unconscionable’ that that other party procure, accept or retain the benefit of, the disadvantaged party’s assent to the impugned transaction in the circumstances in which he or she procured or accepted it.” Examples Deane J referred to some examples of such special disability given by Fullagar J in Blomley v Ryan [1956] HCA 81 at 405: “…poverty or need of any kind, sickness, age, sex, infirmity of body or mind, drunkenness, illiteracy or lack of education, lack of assistance or explanation where assistance or explanation is necessary…the common characteristic of such adverse circumstances (seeming) to be that they have the effect of placing one party at a serious disadvantage (in relation to) the other”. Kitto J in that case (at 415) referred to any “special disadvantage in dealing with the other party because illness, ignorance, inexperience, impaired faculties, financial need or other circumstances affect his ability to conserve his own interests, and the other party unconscientiously takes advantage of the opportunity thus placed in his hands”. Note – Relevant passages from the above judgments were cited at length in Pascot [2011] FamCA 945 at [265]-[270]. Amadio was applied by the High Court in Thorne v Kennedy [2017] HCA 49: see the majority judgment at [37]-[40]; [1]-[2] and [63]-[65]. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 19 Onus of proof Deane J said in Amadio (above) at [12] of his judgment that “where such circumstances [a ‘special dis- ability’ on the part of one party which was ‘sufficiently evident to the stronger party to make it prima facie unfair or ‘unconscientious’ that he procure or accept the weaker party’s assent’] are shown to have ex- isted, an onus is cast upon the stronger party to show that the transaction was fair, just and reasonable”. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: GROUNDS ON WHICH THE COURT MAY SET ASIDE A FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 20 EFFECT OF DEATH OF PARTY TO FINANCIAL AGREEMENT A binding financial agreement continues to operate despite the death of a party to it. In that event, the agreement operates in favour of and is binding on the personal representative of that party: s 90H (or for de facto couples, s 90UK) Likewise, an order setting an agreement aside under s 90K may, after the death of a party, be enforced on behalf of or against the estate of the deceased party: s 90K(4) Upon the death of a party during proceedings under s 90K: (a) the proceedings may be continued by or against the personal representative of the deceased and the applicable Rules of Court may make provision for the substitution of the personal representative as a party to the proceedings; and (b) if the court is of the opinion: (i) that it would have exercised its powers under this section if the deceased party had not died; and (ii) that it is still appropriate to exercise those powers; the court may make any order that it could have made under s 90K(1) or (3) (s 90K(3) being the court’s power to make an order for a transfer of property or other orders adjusting the rights of the parties upon an agreement being set aside); and (c) an order under paragraph (b) may be enforced on behalf of or against the estate of the deceased party. EXEMPTION FROM STAMP DUTY Any deed or other instrument executed for the purposes of or in accordance with an order or financial agreement under Part VIIIA is not subject to “any duty or charge under any law of a State or Territory or any law of the Commonwealth that applies only in relation to a Territory”: s 90L The
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: EFFECT OF DEATH OF PARTY TO FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: executed for the purposes of or in accordance with an order or financial agreement under Part VIIIA is not subject to “any duty or charge under any law of a State or Territory or any law of the Commonwealth that applies only in relation to a Territory”: s 90L The same exemption applies to a deed or other instrument under a de facto property order or a Part VIIIAB financial agreement: s 90WA Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)
chunks.section: EFFECT OF DEATH OF PARTY TO FINANCIAL AGREEMENT

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 21 PRECEDENTS Letter of advice to client as to a proposed financial agreement I enclose a draft of your proposed financial agreement, with a copy for your partner. Purpose of the Agreement The purpose of the Agreement is (delete the following purposes that do not apply): • Mutual quarantine of assets – to enable both parties for the future benefit of children of a previous marriage or relationship (or other intended beneficiary) to preserve certain assets of theirs from future claim by the other, and limit the agreement to such property OR • Unilateral quarantine – to enable one party for the future benefit of children of a previous mar- riage or relationship (or other intended beneficiary) to preserve from future claim by the other certain assets, and limit the agreement to that purpose OR • Release of maintenance – (after separation) for the agreement to be a release from future spousal maintenance in exchange for a satisfactory property settlement, as a “clean break” from each other financially Effect of the Agreement on your rights This Agreement means that one party will be giving up their right to include in the “asset pool” in any future property claim any asset being quarantined by the other party. There is a clause by which such an asset either may or may not be taken into account (as a financial resource of the party who owns it) in any future court proceedings for property settlement, in favour of the financially weaker party. It is for you both to agree upon this in the agreement as to whether or not a quarantined asset may be indirectly taken into account in that way. An agreement solely operating as a release of maintenance will prevent any such claim being made in the
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: financially weaker party. It is for you both to agree upon this in the agreement as to whether or not a quarantined asset may be indirectly taken into account in that way. An agreement solely operating as a release of maintenance will prevent any such claim being made in the future, so a party agreeing to waive any further claim to maintenance should only do so as part of a satisfactory property and/or spousal or de facto partner maintenance settlement. Could the Agreement be set aside by the court? Yes if there has been fraud (such as non-disclosure of a material matter); an intention to defeat or reckless disregard of the interests of a creditor; any duress, undue influence or unconscionable conduct (taking advantage of any weakness of a party); or circumstances have arisen making it imprac- ticable for the Agreement to be carried out; or where the care arrangements for a child of the parties have materially changed so that a party will suffer hardship if the Agreement is not set aside. If the Agreement includes a third party an intention to defraud, or defeat the property interests of that third party or the reckless disregard of those interests are grounds for the Agreement being set aside. An agreement operating as a release of maintenance will be of no effect if, at separation (confirmed by the signing of a separation declaration attached to the agreement), a party is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 22 [Superannuation. Other grounds to set aside an agreement are where any superannuation has a “payment flag” operating or is an “unsplittable interest”.] Advantages of making the Agreement • The Agreement will implement your joint purpose, as set out above • In the case of a quarantine of assets, it will leave all other assets available for any future property settlement negotiations or proceedings in court Disadvantages of making the Agreement • If you have no children to each other and intend having none, the Agreement will remain legally binding despite any unexpected worsening of a party’s financial circumstances (such as loss of job; failure of a business; serious injury) • The Agreement could be set aside in the event of a material change of circumstances relating to a child of the marriage as a result of which a party will suffer hardship if the court does not set the agreement aside Note – A clause terminating the Agreement upon or within a certain time after the birth of a child (requiring you to negotiate a fresh agreement) could guard against that. • A unilateral quarantine of all or most of one party’s assets is likely to produce for the other party a worse ultimate outcome than could otherwise be expected in any later court proceedings Should we each make or have wills? Yes. The Agreement will apply in the event of the death of either party, so long as both of you make or have wills now that are consistent with its terms. Varying or terminating the Agreement Your Agreement may be varied or terminated by a later agreement between you. A new agreement will be necessary if your marital or de facto status changes. Next steps Your partner is required to receive independent legal
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: wills now that are consistent with its terms. Varying or terminating the Agreement Your Agreement may be varied or terminated by a later agreement between you. A new agreement will be necessary if your marital or de facto status changes. Next steps Your partner is required to receive independent legal advice from another law firm before signing the Agreement. If any changes are required, please see me. If not, your partner should take their copy to a lawyer for independent advice and, if approved after receiving that advice, should sign in front of that lawyer (who will sign the certificate at the back of the Agreement). Would you then kindly make an ap- pointment with me, for us both to sign it too. If you have any questions please let me know. Yours faithfully, Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 23 Sample of simple mutual quarantine of assets FINANCIAL AGREEMENT THIS AGREEMENT is made the ______ day of ______________ 20 ______ BETWEEN: [name] of [address] (in this Agreement called “ the husband”) AND: [name] of [address] (in this Agreement called “ the wife”) RECITALS A. This Financial Agreement is made in contemplation of marriage under Section 90B of the Family Law Act 1975. OR A. This Financial Agreement is made during marriage under Section 90C of the Family Law Act 1975. B. The purpose of this Agreement is to enable both parties for the future benefit of the children of their previous marriages (or identify any other intended beneficiary) to preserve certain assets of theirs from future claim by the other, and to limit the agreement to such property. C. The husband was born on [date] and the wife was born on [date]. D. The parties are contemplating marriage. OR D. The parties began living together on [date] and married on [date] at [place] OR D. The parties married on [date] at [place]. E. The parties have no children to each other. OR E. The parties have [number] children to each other, namely: (a) [full name of child] born [date] (b) [full name of child] born [date] F. The parties have the following children of [previous marriages/unmarried relationships] [specify]: (a) [full name of child] born [date] (b) [full name of child] born [date] Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: CHAPTER NINE 9 – 24 OR F. The parties have no children of previous marriages or unmarried relationships. G. The husband is a [occupation] with a gross income of about $[specify]. H. The husband’s assets, liabilities and financial resources are set out in Schedule A of this Agreement. I. The wife is a [occupation] with a gross income of about $[specify]. J. The wife’s assets, liabilities and financial resources are set out in Schedule B of this Agreement. K. Each party acknowledges that they are entering into this Agreement of their own free will. L. There is no other financial agreement in force between the parties under the Family Law Act. IT IS AGREED THAT 1. The parties agree and acknowledge that: (a) Before signing this Agreement and as certified in an annexure to this Agreement, the husband received independent legal advice from a legal practitioner as to: (i) the effect of this Agreement on the husband’s rights; and (ii) the advantages and disadvantages, at the time of that advice, of the husband making the Agreement. (b) Before signing this Agreement and as certified in an annexure to this Agreement, the wife received independent legal advice from a legal practitioner as to: (i) the effect of this Agreement on the wife’s rights; and (ii) the advantages and disadvantages, at the time of that advice, of the wife making the Agreement. 2. The following property will remain the property of the husband free from any future claim by the wife as an asset of the husband: [specify the property being ‘quarantined’ by the husband] 3. The following property will remain the property of the wife free from any future claim by the husband as an asset of the wife: [specify the property being ‘quarantined’ by the wife] 4. The financial relationship
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: an asset of the husband: [specify the property being ‘quarantined’ by the husband] 3. The following property will remain the property of the wife free from any future claim by the husband as an asset of the wife: [specify the property being ‘quarantined’ by the wife] 4. The financial relationship of the parties in the event of their ever separating will be otherwise finalised as agreed between them through reasonable negotiation or as governed by Part VIII of the Family Law Act 1975, including the pre-action procedures for financial matters (property settlement and spousal maintenance) set out in Part 1 of Schedule 1 of the Federal Circuit and Family Court of Aus- tralia (Family Law) Rules 2021. 5. This agreement will take effect from the date of signing of the attached separation declaration and will continue until terminated by another written agreement of the parties. If either party dies during the subsistence of the marriage the agreement will instead take effect from the time of such death. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 25 6. The Agreement will be binding upon the personal representatives, legal representatives, trustees, executors and administrators of each party or their estate. 7. This is not an agreement as to spousal maintenance to which s 90E of the Family Law Act applies. 8. [Delete this clause if Agreement is not in contemplation of marriage] This Agreement shall be void if the parties do not marry within 12 months after the date of this Agreement. chunks.text: FINANCIAL AGREEMENTS 9 – 39 Sample of financial agreement as release of spousal maintenance Note – This (post-separation) agreement is recommended as a release from future maintenance as s 83 allows an order to that effect to be set aside. As to property issues, we recommend that you use consent orders (filed at the same time as the financial agreement is made). We do so because a property order is generally harder to set aside (under the lesser scope of s 79A) than a financial agreement (which runs the gauntlet of ss 90G, 90K and 90KA) and for stamp duty reasons too. In Queensland, for example, the identity of the transferee under an order is irrelevant for stamp duty exemption whereas OSR (Qld) guidelines for transfers under a finan- cial agreement require stamp duty to be paid by a non-spouse transferee.
