chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 2 ADDENDUM This summary – also available at our website www.thefamilylawbook.com.au – covers the amendment of the Family Law Act which brings de facto financial cases for most States and Territories under the jurisdiction of federal courts, and changes to Part VII’s definitions of “children”. Although this amendment was incorporated into our June quarter 2009 update of , we have kept this summary here as a quick reference to its key points. FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT (DE FACTO FINANCIAL MATTERS AND OTHER MEASURES) ACT 2008 Introduction On 1 March 2009 the Family Law Act was amended to provide for financial matters arising out of the breakdown of de facto relationships and other measures. Schedule 1 of the Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008 applies to all States and Territories except WA, which has not referred its power to deal with such matters to the Commonwealth. SA referred its power on 1 July 2010. Exclusive jurisdiction in de facto financial causes Except in WA, State and Territory laws do not apply to financial matters between parties to a de facto relationship that has broken down after the commencement of the amendment, being 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA upon its referral of power): Exception – insufficient link to a participating jurisdiction or Division 2 not applicable because of s 90SB (see below). Section 90RC(3) offers the following example: “Cleo and Dan are parties to a de facto relationship that has broken down after the commencement of this section. Early in their relationship, they made a financial agreement under the law of a non referring State, but later spent most of their relationship in a participating jurisdiction. Cleo and Dan now have a sufficient geographical link with a participating jurisdiction for either
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: down after the commencement of this section. Early in their relationship, they made a financial agreement under the law of a non referring State, but later spent most of their relationship in a participating jurisdiction. Cleo and Dan now have a sufficient geographical link with a participating jurisdiction for either of them to apply for an order under this Part in relation to financial matters arising out of the breakdown of their relationship. This means that subsection (3) will not apply and that their financial agreement will not be enforceable under State law because of subsection (2). However, their financial agreement will be enforceable under this Part as a Part VIIIAB financial agreement (see section 90UE).” Parties to a de facto relationship that broke down before that date may seek their relief under their State or Territory law, or opt in to the new regime: Part 2, Amendment Act If a de facto couple marries, the pre-amendment provisions of the FLA apply: s 90SC “De facto financial cause” covers proceedings for (partner) maintenance, distribution of property (including super splitting) and provision for financial agreements: s 4(1) Exclusive jurisdiction for such matters rests with the FCFCA, Supreme Court of the NT and courts of summary jurisdiction of each Territory: s 39B Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 3 De facto relationships A “de facto relationship” includes same sex partners, and can also exist if a de facto partner is legally married to someone else or in another de facto relationship: s 4AA(5) The section defines partners as being in a de facto relationship if they are not married or related to each other and, having regard to all the circumstances of their relationship, live together on a genuine domestic basis. Those circumstances may include: • length of the relationship • the nature and extent of their common residence • whether a sexual relationship exists • the degree of financial dependence and any financial support • the ownership, use and acquisition of their property • the degree of mutual commitment to a shared life • whether the relationship is or was registered in a State or Territory • the care and support of children • the reputation and public aspects of the relationship Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 4 PART VIIIAB – FINANCIAL MATTERS RELATING TO DE FACTO RELATIONSHIPS Editor’s note This amendment – bringing the financial rights of de facto couples on to the same footing as those of married couples – was achieved not by the strategic amendment of Parts VIII (maintenance and property) and VIIIA (financial agreements) but by inserting yet another part to the Family Law Act, which then largely mirrors those Parts. More seamless change did occur for Part VIIIB (s 90XC being amended to extend super splitting to de facto couples), and for s 4(1) definitions, Part V (jurisdiction) and Part VIIIAA (orders against third parties, using a cross-referencing schedule in s 90TA). The purpose of being to contain family law within one volume, this 100 page amendment has not been given its own chapter but instead has been integrated into our Chapters 6 (maintenance), 7 (property) and 9 (financial agreements), and all incidental matters of significance incorporated in the relevant chapter. The new Part VIIIAB largely mirrors the Act’s existing sections as to maintenance, property and financial agreements, and also provides for a declaration to be made about the existence of a de facto relation- ship (likely to be a popular preliminary issue for determination as to the application of Part VIIIAB). The layout of Part VIIIAB (with the mirror existing sections in brackets) is as follows: Division 1 Preliminary Sections 90RA and RB Definitions Section 90RC Relationship with State and Territory laws Sections 90RD-90RH Declaration about existence of de facto relationship Division 2 Maintenance and property Section 90SA Division excluded by financial agreement (s 71A) Section 90SB Circumstances where Division applies Section 90SC Division ceases to apply upon marriage Section 90SD Maintenance – geographical requirement (s 39) Section 90SE Power of court in maintenance proceedings (s 74)
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 6 The right to apply under Part VIIIAB (maintenance and property) Under s 90SB, a court may only make an order concerning maintenance or property in relation to a de facto relationship if it is satisfied as to the existence of a de facto relationship and: a) that the period, or total of the periods, of the relationship is at least 2 years; or b) that there is a child of the relationship; or c) that: (i) the applicant made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a)–(c); and (ii) a failure to make the order would result in serious injustice to the applicant; or d) that the relationship is or was registered in a State or Territory (Tas, Vic, ACT, NSW) and is satisfied under s 90SD (maintenance) and s 90SK (property): • that either party was ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the application was made; and • that either: (i) both were ordinarily resident during at least a third of the relationship; or (ii) the applicant made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a)–(c) in a participating jurisdiction or participating jurisdictions when the application was made; or • that the parties were ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when the relationship broke down. Division 2 does not apply to matters covered by binding financial agreements: s 90SA Part VIIIAB ceases to apply to parties to a de facto relationship if they marry: s 90SC Time limit for issuing maintenance or property proceedings An application by a party to a de facto relationship for maintenance or property orders must be made within 2 years after the end of the relationship: s 44(5) The court may grant leave to apply out of time under s 44(6) if it is satisfied that: a) hardship would be caused to the party or
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: a de facto relationship for maintenance or property orders must be made within 2 years after the end of the relationship: s 44(5) The court may grant leave to apply out of time under s 44(6) if it is satisfied that: a) hardship would be caused to the party or a child if leave were not granted; or b) for maintenance cases – the applicant as at the time limit would have been unable to support himself or herself without an income tested pension, allowance or benefit. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 7 Threshold declaration about existence of de facto relationship One major point of difference between married and unmarried parties is that jurisdiction rarely troubles domiciled spouse applicants. They need only prove the marriage, and they do so by filing the marriage certificate. The existence of a de facto relationship, however, is an arguable question of fact which can make or break the right to apply. Section 90RD(1) enables a declaration to be made by the court that a de facto relationship existed, or never existed, between the parties. See Moby & Schulter [2010] FamCA 748 at paras 126-142 and Jonah & White [2011] FamCA 221 at paras 34-67. Under s 90RD(2) such a declaration may also declare any or all of the following: a) the period or periods of the relationship (as to s 90SB(a) above) b) whether there is a child of the relationship c) whether a party made substantial contributions under s 90SM(4)(a)–(c): see Miller & Trent [2011] FMCAfam 324 at paras 32, 53-64, 86-88 and 103 d) when the relationship ended (after 1 March 2009 – 1 July 2010 in SA – to be eligible) e) where each party was ordinarily resident during the relationship Note – Your court application should seek such a declaration as an interim order and the ultimate orders sought as final orders. Such a declaration may be set aside for non-disclosure: s 90RH Maintenance and property proceedings – power of court and relevant factors The court’s powers and matters to be taken into account in your applications for de facto partner maintenance and property orders mirror existing sections of the Family Law Act. See the table above for a cross-referencing of those provisions. Superannuation The superannuation interests of de facto partners may be split under amendments made to ss
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: to be taken into account in your applications for de facto partner maintenance and property orders mirror existing sections of the Family Law Act. See the table above for a cross-referencing of those provisions. Superannuation The superannuation interests of de facto partners may be split under amendments made to ss 90XA, 90XC(2) and 90XS of the existing Part VIIIB of the Act. Section 90XX deals with multiple relationships by providing for multiple payment splits applying to the same splittable payment. Procedure Court procedure will also substantially be the same as for spousal maintenance and property cases except that in a case of a preliminary hearing as to the existence of a de facto relationship and, in par- ticular, whether “substantial contributions” were made or when the relationship ended, special attention will need to be given to the evidence necessary to be filed in support of such a proceeding. For a sample declaration, see “Response” under “precedents” in Chapter 6. Our precedent affidavit in support has been adapted to accommodate a de facto claim and a declaration being sought by a respondent disputing an applicant’s right to the order sought. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 8 Financial agreements Again, Division 4 (see table above) mirrors the Act’s existing provision (Part VIIIA). Agreements under that part are called “financial agreements” and those made under Part VIIIAB are called “Part VIIIAB financial agreements”. Also introduced, for both types of agreement, is the awkward concept of the “spouse party” (i.e. a party to the agreement and to the contemplated, existing or former marriage or de facto relationship) and “third party” (party to agreement who is not a spouse party): s 4(1) Note – “Spouse parties” may enter into a financial agreement with “one or more other people” (ss 90UB(1), 90UC(1) and 90UD(1)). This facility stems from the extension of a “de facto relationship” under s 4AA(5) to a case where one (or presumably both) of the partners are “legally married” to someone else or in another de facto relationship (in which a de facto couple might conceivably be involved in three marital or de facto relationships at once). Geographical requirement for Part VIIIAB agreements A Part VIIIAB financial agreement may be made by two or more people only if the spouse parties are ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction when they make the agreement: s 90UA Types and formalities of Part VIIIAB agreements and other provisions These are the same as for financial agreements (Part VIIIA). See the table above. Agreements in non-referring States can become Part VIIIAB agreements Agreements validly made in a non-referring State with respect to maintenance, property or financial resources may be accepted as Part VIIIAB agreements if the parties’ circumstances later change by a move to a participating jurisdiction: s 90UE The section refers to the Amendment Act’s “Part 2 – Transitional provisions” of Schedule 1 which also deems agreements made under the law of a State that becomes a
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: be accepted as Part VIIIAB agreements if the parties’ circumstances later change by a move to a participating jurisdiction: s 90UE The section refers to the Amendment Act’s “Part 2 – Transitional provisions” of Schedule 1 which also deems agreements made under the law of a State that becomes a participating jurisdiction to be Part VIIIAB agreements (see below). Existing agreements in referring States (and in Territories) Existing agreements validly made between de facto partners in a referring State with respect to main- tenance, property or financial resources will be “taken” to be a Part VIIIAB agreement provided that immediately before 1 March 2009 (1 July 2010 in SA): a) the agreement was in force; b) the relationship had not broken down; c) the couple were not married to each other. Existing agreements taken to be Part VIIIAB can only be enforced, varied or terminated under the new legislation (i.e. as though the existing Agreement was a Part VIIIAB agreement). Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 9 Additional ground for setting aside Part VIIIAB financial agreements Section 90K(1)’s grounds (set out in Chapter 9) have been applied to Part VIIIAB financial agreements with the addition of a ground that a person entered into the agreement: • for the purpose of defrauding a third party who is a de facto partner or spouse of either party to the agreement, or, • for the purpose of defeating the property interests of that third party, or • with reckless disregard of those interests Note – Agreements from non-referring States that become Part VIIIAB agreements under s 90UE above, and agreements from referring States, can be set aside under ss 90UM(1)(k). • if, before signing the agreement, a spouse party was not provided with independent legal advice about its effect on the party’s rights and the advantages and disadvantages to the party of making the agreement at the time of such advice, or • if the advice was provided but a statement signed by the lawyer as to the advice being provided was neither included in or attached to the agreement, nor given to the party Additional ground for varying existing maintenance order The existing s 83 and the new s 90SI (for de facto financial cases) as to modification of maintenance orders both now include in the ground of changed circumstances of a person since an order was made “the person entering into a stable and continuing de facto relationship”. State and Territory law The relevant State or Territory law in a participating jurisdiction will continue to apply where a de facto relationship broke down before the commencement of Part VIIIAB (1 March 2009, or 1 July 2010 in SA) (s 86), unless the parties opt into the new regime under s 86A for the issue
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: State or Territory law in a participating jurisdiction will continue to apply where a de facto relationship broke down before the commencement of Part VIIIAB (1 March 2009, or 1 July 2010 in SA) (s 86), unless the parties opt into the new regime under s 86A for the issue of FLA proceedings or entry into a Part VIIIAB financial agreement. (These sections are in Part 2 of Schedule 1 of the Amendment Act – transitional provisions.) The new regime will not, however, apply to de facto financial matters in the non-referring State of WA. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 10 OTHER AMENDMENTS – BROADER DEFINITIONS OF “CHILDREN” “Child of a de facto relationship” Such a child, for the purposes of Part VIIIAB, means a child of both parties to the relationship: s 90RB “Child of a person” Section 90RB goes on to note that to determine who is a child of a person, see the amendments to Part VII introduced by this Amendment Act, including the repeal of s 60H(1) and (4). Now, both parties to a marriage or de facto relationship (opposite or same sex) will be parents, under the Act and for child support purposes, of a child: • of whom each party is the biological parent or a child adopted by either or both with the consent of the other: ss 60F and 60HA • born through artificial conception procedures where one of the parties is the birth mother and the donor of the genetic material has consented to its use: s 60H(1) • born as part of a surrogacy arrangement where a court has made an order under a State or Territory law concerning parentage: s 60HB “Step-parent” The definition of “step-parent” in 4(1) – a person who is or has been married to a parent of a child – now includes a person who is or has been the parent’s de facto partner. “De facto partner” “De facto partner” is defined in s 60EA as including a party to a de facto relationship that is registered under State or Territory law. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 22 DISCOUNT AND LIFE TABLES Judge Brewster explained in a property case, Tremayne & Steen [2014] FCCA 2188 at [45, footnote 2], when calculating W’s share in H’s superannuation as follows: “[T]he concept of discounting emerged from compensation law where a loss extending over a pe- riod of years had to be converted into a lump sum. If for example a person is to be compensated for a loss of a salary of $1,000 a week, or $52,000 a year, over a period of ten years this is not accurately represented by an award of $520,000. The reason is that this amount could be put in an interest bearing account and, if $1,000 were withdrawn each week, there would be money left over after ten years. On the other hand inflation would likely mean that the $1,000 a week salary would have increased over time. In 1981 the High Court in Todorovic v Waller [1981] HCA 72 … ruled that a discount rate of 3% should be applied. In the hypothetical case I have used one would calculate the sum that would be required which, if invested at 3% per annum, would allow $1,000 to be withdrawn each week and be exhausted after ten years. Whilst what I am about to say is an oversimplification the 3% was said to represent the ‘real’ rate of interest, that is the dif- ference historically between the rate of interest that could be earned in a secure fund and the rate of inflation. Whether or not this is still true is debatable given the Global Financial Crisis and the resulting low interest rates now applying.” Of the handful of family law (property, maintenance and child support) cases in which Todorovic v Waller was cited (just 6 according to AustLII’s LawCite
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: rate of inflation. Whether or not this is still true is debatable given the Global Financial Crisis and the resulting low interest rates now applying.” Of the handful of family law (property, maintenance and child support) cases in which Todorovic v Waller was cited (just 6 according to AustLII’s LawCite as at June 2015) a 3% discount was applied in all of them. An actuary’s opinion on this would nonetheless be advisable. Court’s approach to capitalisation No discount was applied by Bryant CFM in R & R (No. 1) [2002] FMCAfam 153 at page 5-33 above in the capitalisation of child support over 5 years. The court’s discretion in relation to lump sum and non-periodic child support under s 123 CSAA is gov- erned by what is under ss 123A and 124 CSAA “just and equitable” and “otherwise proper” (and the sum equaling or exceeding the annual rate of child support). In a spousal maintenance case, Brown [2007] FamCA 151 at [60]-[92] the Full Court held that capitali- sation does not necessarily require a mathematical approach, the assessment of lump sum maintenance being discretionary as to what is “proper” within the meaning of s 74(1) FLA both as to “the form of order and its quantum” ([58]). In an adult child maintenance case, Jamine and Anor (No. 2) [2011] FamCA 843 at [204]-[209] Cronin J awarded a sum capitalised over 9 years without discount. Adult child maintenance under s 66L FLA is determined by the standard of what the court considers “necessary to enable the child to complete his or her education or because of a mental or physical disability of the child”. In calculating a client’s s 75(2) factors in a property case such as disparity of income, the Full Court in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10 said that “it
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: considers “necessary to enable the child to complete his or her education or because of a mental or physical disability of the child”. In calculating a client’s s 75(2) factors in a property case such as disparity of income, the Full Court in Clauson [1995] FamCA 10 said that “it is the real impact in money terms which is ultimately the criti- cal issue”. A capitalised costing of disparity (adding any other expectant future capital expense) would provide an evidentiary basis for the amount sought in accordance with Clauson, thus presenting a claim less easy for the other side (and the court) to dismiss or devalue. A percentage approach can allow a court to “talk up” a party’s future needs but award conservatively for those needs. Update 64 March 2025 quarter update
chunks.chapter: CHAPTER EIGHT – OTHER ROUTINE PROCEDURES (WITH PRECEDENTS)

chunks.text: ADDENDUM A – 23 Discount tables As an example, the present value of $100 per week for 5 years: • (applying the 3% discount table where the 5 year multiple is 243) is: $100 x 243 = $24,300. • (applying the 5% discount table where the 5 year multiple is 232) is: $100 x 232 = $23,200. See the 3% and 5% discount tables below. For a calculation to cover the rest of a person’s expected life, see the life table below.
